Title: U.S. Accuses China of Intellectual Property Theft, Raising Questions on Innovation and Trust

Article:

In a report on Monday, the Pentagon accused China of stealing innovative ideas from American industries for strategic gain. This allegation, while not new in business circles, marks the first time the United States government has made such a claim so explicitly. The accusation forces China's leaders to confront two questions:

1. Why does China resort to systematic intellectual property theft through cyber-espionage, reverse engineering, and other means, when it could trust itself to innovate?
2. Why can't China simply innovate independently, given its significant government investments in research and the production of engineers?

Industrial theft is common in almost every country, including the U.S. However, China's scale and official level of intellectual property theft have led the U.S. government to point a finger at Beijing. According to one American think tank, the Information Technology & Innovation Foundation, China's theft of U.S. intellectual property cost nearly 1 million U.S. jobs in 2009.

Despite China's investments in "independent innovation," such as science parks and clean energy, the country's top-down economic planning and state-run enterprises hinder the emergence of a Steve Jobs-type figure. An official policy since 2006 to quickly innovate Chinese industry has led to high rates of plagiarism in scientific papers and other research misconduct.

China's long dependency on foreign technology and its drive to develop its economy quickly may be reasons for its tendency to take other people's creative work. However, it could also be that a people living under a ruling party that suppresses the truth don't feel safe in striving for truth. India, which has far less government money for research, does well in its open society to inspire technological innovation.

Truth-seeking has a long tradition in the West, where religion focuses on the idea of a rational Creator. China also has a long history of importing ideas, such as Mao Zedong importing communism and Deng Xiaoping bringing in Western-style market capitalism. The quest for truth is not alien to China; it now simply needs to look to its own people for creativity rather than take it from elsewhere.

Title: White House Security Clearance Process Allegedly Weaponized by Career Bureaucrats, Says Federal Security Clearance Lawyer

Article:

A federal security clearance lawyer, Sean M. Bigley, has accused a small group of career bureaucrats in the White House personnel security office of using the security clearance process as a tool to obstruct President Trump's agenda and prevent him from installing appointees who will execute it. This allegation bolsters White House Chief of Staff John F. Kelly's criticism of the security office and sheds light on recent incidents involving security clearances that have embarrassed the administration.

Mr. Bigley, who represents several senior administration officials caught up in the process, stated that the security clearance process is being weaponized by anti-Trump bureaucrats. He described the process as quicksand that ensnares the President's team. The foot-dragging in the security clearance process is prevalent throughout the administration, but it is most visible and startling at the White House.

The completed FBI background checks routinely get snagged by the office, also known as EOP Security, which is manned by fewer than a dozen career officials. The office has a reputation for bureaucratic inefficiency stretching back several administrations, but it now has adopted an adversarial stance toward Mr. Trump.

According to Mr. Bigley, there is a hostility and institutional arrogance in the lack of willingness to engage from EOP Security. He stated that he is unable to get a phone call returned, and he is representing senior people in the administration who are asking for basic answers as to why EOP Security is still sitting on their background investigation a year after it has been completed.

Security clearance problems grabbed headlines in early February when Rob Porter was forced to resign as White House staff secretary after his two ex-wives went public with accusations of spousal abuse. The White House mishandled the episode, and public outrage, fueled in part by a photograph of ex-wife Colbie Holderness with a black eye, quickly forced the White House to oust Mr. Porter.

The nearly yearlong delay occurred in the personnel security office. Mr. Porter was one of as many as 40 officials at the White House working with interim security clearance after more than a year because the process was mired. When the FBI background check reveals negative information about a White House official, the personnel security office usually would inform the chief of staff and White House counsel about the "suitability" concern. A White House aide with a "suitability" problem would usually resign.

The FBI delivered the background check to the personnel security office in March 2017. Security clearance professionals have questioned why the information was not transmitted to Mr. Kelly or White House counsel Donald McGahn. "The question mark is whether that was communicated to anybody else in the administration," said Mr. Bigley. "Based on my experience dealing with EOP Security, I think they probably did just sit on this and drop the ball."

Mr. Kelly targeted the communication breakdown in a memo outlining an overhaul of the security clearance process in the wake of the Porter debacle. He ordered the FBI to hand-deliver background investigation files to the White House counsel, bypassing the personnel security office.

The overhaul of the security clearance system, including reining in the number of interim clearances, prompted Mr. Kelly to order the downgrade of Mr. Kushner's top-secret clearance. Mr. Kushner still has clearance for access to government secrets although not at the highest level, which would include the president's daily briefings by intelligence agencies.

Title: President Trump's Actions and Media Interactions: A Daily Political Update

Article:

In a series of events over the past week, President Donald J. Trump has engaged in a public feud with CNN, continued efforts to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act, and hosted a Fourth of July celebration at the White House.

On Friday, President Trump shared a video of himself body-slamming someone with a CNN logo superimposed on his face, prompting a response from CNN stating, "It's a sad day when the President of the United States encourages violence against reporters... We will keep doing our jobs. He should start doing his."

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell is reportedly working on changes to the GOP health care bill this week, rather than repealing Obamacare first as suggested by the president. Trump is set to return to Washington D.C. tonight to celebrate the Fourth of July. He and First Lady Melania Trump will host a picnic for military families at the White House Tuesday, followed by a viewing of fireworks.

The president's actions towards the media have been described as a "strategy" but also as impulsive outbursts driven by short-term tactical decisions. The president's tweets and actions are a source of controversy, with some viewing them as a return to the norm and others as a cause for concern.

New Jersey Governor Chris Christie's spokesperson stated that Christie and his family spent Sunday on a closed beach despite ordering a government shutdown. In response to criticism, Christie's spokesperson said, "He did not get any sun. He had a baseball hat on."

President Trump's homeland security adviser, Tom Bossert, defended the president's CNN tweet Sunday, stating that "no one would perceive that as a threat." Bossert also praised Trump as the "most genuine president... we've seen in [ his ] lifetime."

Republican Governor John Kasich of Ohio has criticized the current version of the Senate Republican health care bill, stating that it is "not an acceptable choice" and makes it harder for states to treat opioid addicts. Kasich said, "If you cut $750 billion out of Medicaid, and in the out years you basically starve the program, we have to choose between children, seniors, the disabled, the addicted, the mentally ill."

At least 17 states are balking at the Trump administration's request for voter registration data as part of the new election integrity commission, with six states outright declining to provide the information. Minnesota Secretary of State Steve Simon has expressed "serious doubts about the commission's trustworthiness."

The Note is a daily feature that highlights the key political moments of the day ahead. Please check back tomorrow for the latest.

Title: US Justice Department Launches Criminal Investigation into Michael Cohen, Trump's Former Lawyer

Article:

The United States Justice Department has announced that Michael Cohen, President Donald Trump's former lawyer, is under criminal investigation. Prosecutors are reportedly focusing on Cohen's business dealings rather than his work as a lawyer.

According to a court filing, Cohen has been under investigation for months. The filing was in response to efforts by Cohen's own lawyer to stop prosecutors from reviewing material seized from Cohen's office on Monday. Cohen's team argues that the papers are covered by the attorney-client privilege.

President Trump has condemned the office raid, calling it "disgraceful" and "an attack on our country." During a court hearing in New York on Friday, prosecutor Tom McKay accused Cohen of trying to use attorney-client privilege "as a sword to challenge the government's ability to review evidence."

Government prosecutors also said they believed Cohen had "a low volume of potentially privileged communication" because he seems to only have one client - President Trump. The filing stated, "It is neither apparent that Cohen, in his capacity as an attorney, has many, or any, attorney-client relationships other than with President Donald Trump."

The filing added that while Cohen was an attorney, "he also has several other business interests and sources of income." The investigation is reportedly focused on Cohen's personal business dealings.

A new lawyer for President Trump, Joanna Hendon, said the president had an "acute interest" in the case. Ms. Hendon, who was hired on Wednesday, asked the judge to adjourn the session so she had more time to prepare.

According to a New York Times report, the president phoned Cohen to "check in" on him today. Lawyers tend to advise clients not to discuss investigations, which means their discussion could cause them problems, depending on what they talked about.

In a separate development, Cohen reportedly negotiated a $1.6 million settlement with a former Playboy model on behalf of a Republican fundraiser, according to a Wall Street Journal article. Elliott Broidy, a Los Angeles investor, acknowledged "a consensual relationship" with the Playmate, who became pregnant.

Mr. Broidy said it was "unfortunate" that the personal matter was "the subject of national discussion" because of the involvement of Cohen. Mr. Broidy was previously in the news after he urged President Trump to sack then-Secretary of State Rex Tillerson over a diplomatic dispute.

Cohen has admitted to having paid a porn actress, Stormy Daniels, $130,000 before the 2016 US presidential election. Ms. Daniels claims she had an affair with Mr. Trump, and he and his lawyers made attempts to buy her silence.

Title: "The New York Times Corrects Inaccuracies and Errors in 2016 Reporting"

Article:

The New York Times, in a move to maintain transparency and uphold journalistic integrity, has issued corrections for several significant errors, inaccuracies, and misrepresentations in its reporting from 2016. The following is a list of the five most notable instances:

1. Claim of 17 Intelligence Agencies Agreeing on Russia:
In a June report, The New York Times repeated the baseless claim that 17 U.S. intelligence agencies agreed Russia was responsible for meddling in the 2016 election. This claim was debunked by the ███ News Foundation fact-check team in a report published approximately one month prior. The New York Times later issued a correction, acknowledging that only four intelligence agencies came to a consensus on Russian meddling.

2. Parody Twitter Account Mistaken for North Korean Government:
New York Times reporters incorrectly attributed a tweet mocking American military efforts to the North Korean government, when the tweet was actually the product of a parody account. The DPRK News Service, which claims to be the "official News feed of the Democratic Peoples Republic of Korea," is run by two Americans, according to The Washington Post. The New York Times later issued a correction acknowledging they fell for the parody.

3. Food Stamps and Soda Reporting:
The New York Times misreported data from a government study on what people buy on food stamps, then updated the story with an additional error without issuing a correction. The central claim of the January story, headlined, "In the Shopping Cart of a Food Stamp Household: Lots of Soda," was that the Department of Agriculture has a report showing food stamps recipients spend nearly 10 cents of every dollar on soft drinks. However, this number is almost double what the report actually said. The updated version still incorrectly stated that soft drinks are not included in the "sweetened beverages" category, when in fact, they are.

4. Attorney General Jeff Sessions Statement:
New York Times editor Jonathan Weisman was forced to retract a June tweet insinuating Attorney General Jeff Sessions was corrupt. Weisman asserted former FBI Director James Comey testified that Sessions asked him directly to call the Russia probe "a matter." However, Comey had actually testified that former Attorney General Loretta Lynch, not Sessions, had approached him with that request.

5. Correction to Editorial Attacking Sarah Palin:
After a man shot up a GOP congressional baseball practice in May, The New York Times used a debunked conspiracy theory to attack former Alaska Gov. Sarah Palin in an editorial. The paper baselessly linked her campaign messaging to the shooting of Democratic Rep. Gabby Giffords in 2011. After substantial public backlash, The New York Times heavily edited the piece and added a correction, stating, "An editorial on Thursday about the shooting of Representative Steve Scalise incorrectly stated that a link existed between political rhetoric and the 2011 shooting of Representative Gabby Giffords. In fact, no such link was established. The editorial also incorrectly described a map distributed by a political action committee before that shooting. It depicted electoral districts, not individual Democratic lawmakers, beneath stylized cross hairs."

Title: Understanding Narrow Political Victories: A Call for Empathy and Bipartisanship

Article:

The recent electoral college votes have confirmed the narrow victories of the expected candidates, with Donald Trump winning by 77,744 votes in Pennsylvania, Michigan, and Wisconsin. This small margin of victory has led to significant changes, including a more conservative Supreme Court, a potential rollback of Obamacare, and a shift in policies regarding fossil fuel usage.

This is not the first time that such a large difference in public policies has been made by a small vote margin. For instance, if Al Franken had not been declared the winner of the 2008 U.S. Senate race in Minnesota by 302 votes, there would have been no 60th vote to push through Obamacare in 2010.

The political system in the United States is known for producing big policy consequences from small vote margins, even microscopic ones. This has been strengthened in recent decades by increasing partisan polarization. In the past, political scientists suggested that the country should have one clearly liberal and one clearly conservative party. Today, we have a two-party system that incentivizes each party to aim for more than 50 percent of the vote.

However, this system also emphasizes what divides us, as often neither party gets to 50 percent. This has been the case in 15 of the 41 Democratic-Republican presidential contests since 1856, and in the 1876 presidential race, when Samuel Tilden lost by one electoral vote.

In light of the recent election results, Michael Barone, a senior political analyst for the Washington Examiner and a resident fellow at the American Enterprise Institute, offers suggestions for moving forward. One suggestion is to empathize with those who hold different political views. By understanding why good people support the candidate you oppose, one can change one's view and foster a more empathetic society.

Another suggestion is to stop playing team ball, as there is a gulf between Trump's views and those of many conservatives and elected Republicans. With no incumbent Democratic president, liberals will have no single leader setting an agenda.

Lastly, Barone advises against getting strung out on process arguments, such as the recent debate about the Electoral College. Process arguments are often insincere, and all parties should focus on understanding and working towards a more empathetic and bipartisan society.

Title: U.S. and China Agree on Denuclearization of Korean Peninsula; Trump, Xi Discuss Tensions with North Korea

Article:

In a phone conversation on Friday, U.S. President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping agreed on the shared goal of a nuclear-free Korean Peninsula, according to a White House statement and a report on Chinese state television. During the call, Xi requested that the U.S. and North Korea tone down their recent rhetoric and avoid actions that could escalate tensions.

The leaders affirmed that the recent adoption of a new United Nations Security Council resolution regarding North Korea was an important and necessary step toward achieving peace and stability on the Korean Peninsula. They agreed that North Korea must stop its provocative and escalatory behavior. The leaders also reiterated their mutual commitment to denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula.

The White House confirmed early Saturday that Trump and Xi spoke on Friday. The statement added that Trump was looking forward to meeting with Xi in China later this year. The trip, announced in April, was recently confirmed by Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi, who met in Manila with U.S. Secretary of State Rex Tillerson, according to the Sydney Morning Herald.

Trump has urged China to pressure North Korea to halt its nuclear weapons program, which North Korea says is nearing the capability of targeting the United States. China is North Korea's biggest economic partner and source of aid, but says it alone cannot compel Pyongyang to end its nuclear and missile programs.

Meanwhile, Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe pledged Saturday to do "everything, to the best of my ability," to protect his nation's people as tensions escalate over North Korea's plans to send missiles over Japan toward Guam. Abe made the comments while visiting his father's tomb in his ancestral hometown of Nagato, in western Japan.

On Friday, Japan's Defense Ministry said it was deploying four surface-to-air Patriot interceptors in western Japan to respond to a possible risk of fragments falling from missiles. The ministry did not confirm whether newly appointed Defense Minister Itsunori Onodera has already issued an order to shoot down incoming missiles.

Trump on Friday issued fresh threats of swift and forceful retaliation against nuclear North Korea, declaring the U.S. military "locked and loaded" and warning that North Korea's leader, Kim Jong Un, would "regret it fast" if he takes any action against U.S. territories or allies.

Title: U.S. Job Growth Surges in January, Wages Increase at Largest Pace in Nearly a Decade

Article:

The United States added 200,000 jobs in January, and wages rose at the fastest pace in more than eight years, according to the latest report from the U.S. Department of Labor. The unemployment rate remained at a 17-year low of 4.1 percent.

The nonfarm payrolls increased by 200,000 jobs last month, following a rise of 160,000 in December. The average hourly earnings rose 0.3 percent in January to $26.74, building on December's solid 0.4 percent gain. This boosted the year-on-year increase in average hourly earnings to 2.9 percent, the largest rise since June 2009.

The robust employment report indicates a strong momentum in the economy. Economists attribute job gains to buoyant domestic and global demand. However, the report suggests that the U.S. economy is approaching full employment, and job growth is expected to slow this year. Companies are reporting difficulties finding qualified workers, which economists say will force some to significantly raise wages as they compete for scarce labor.

Wage growth in January was likely supported by increases in the minimum wage that came into effect in 18 states in January, as well as the tax cut. Companies like Starbucks Corp and FedEx Corp have announced plans to boost wages for workers due to the tax cuts, and further gains are expected in February when Walmart raises entry-level wages for hourly employees at its U.S. stores.

While the fundamentals of the U.S. economy are unquestionably healthy, the actual growth numbers for the first quarter of 2018 remain to be seen. The New York Fed's estimate for Q4 of 2017 was robust, but the actual number ended up falling well short. The economy's strength and the extent of its growth are subjects of ongoing debate among economists.

Title: CIA Director Warns of Potential Increased Terrorist Attacks, Political Divide on Prevention Measures

Article:

CIA Director John Brennan delivered an urgent warning to the Senate Intelligence Committee on Thursday, stating that the Islamic State (ISIL) has the capacity to carry out further Orlando-style terrorist attacks in the near future. Brennan stated, "We judge that ISIL is training and attempting to deploy operatives for further attacks."

Brennan explained that ISIL is exploring various methods for infiltration, such as joining the flow of refugees into Western countries, using smuggling routes, and commercial travel. The Islamic State reportedly has a significant number of Western fighters who could potentially serve as operatives for attacks in the West.

The political landscape regarding the prevention of future terrorist attacks in the United States is divided, with Democrats advocating for stricter gun laws and Republicans urging tougher action against ISIS and Islamic extremists. Critics of President Barack Obama argue that his immigration policies and foreign policy decisions have contributed to terrorist attacks, such as the Orlando massacre.

Sen. John McCain, R-Ariz., stated that the president is "directly responsible" for the Orlando mass shooting due to the withdrawal of all U.S. troops from Iraq in 2011, which led to the rise of ISIS. McCain later retracted the statement, saying the president's policies led to the attack.

Meanwhile, the Senate is set to vote on new gun control legislation on Monday. Democrats are advocating for a policy called "no fly, no buy," which would prohibit individuals on a terror watch list from purchasing a firearm. Under current law, the FBI is already notified when terror suspects attempt to buy weapons. House Republicans have stated they do not plan to consider new gun legislation.

Presumptive GOP nominee Donald Trump criticized the president during a speech in Dallas on Thursday, vowing to protect American gun rights. Trump stated, "To a large extent he's blaming guns and I'm going to save your Second Amendment folks. I'm going to save your Second Amendment." Earlier in the week, Trump suggested that more people at the Orlando nightclub with guns could have prevented the tragedy.

During his visit to Orlando on Thursday, President Obama criticized this suggestion, stating, "The notion that the answer to this tragedy would be to assure that more people in a nightclub are similarly armed to the killer defies common sense."

In a show of solidarity, Vice President Joe Biden and President Obama placed flowers at the Orlando memorial. Meanwhile, a Christian from Illinois drove 1,200 miles to place 49 crosses at the site, each cross bearing the name of a victim. The individual, Greg Zanis, explained, "My message today is love your brother, love your neighbor. Do not judge them... I'm just offering hope in a very hopeless situation."

Title: FBI Foils Terror Plot in Brooklyn, New York, Arresting Three Uzbek Men Planning to Join ISIS

Article:

The Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) conducted a series of terror raids in Brooklyn, New York, on Wednesday, resulting in the arrest of three men from Uzbekistan who were allegedly planning to travel to Syria to join the Islamic State (ISIS) and potentially carry out acts of domestic terrorism in the United States.

According to NBC News, the youngest man, identified as Akhror Saidakhmetov, reportedly posted on an Uzbek-language website in the last six months that he would buy a machine gun and shoot police officers and FBI agents if his plan to join ISIS was thwarted. In August 2014, 24-year-old suspect Abdurasul Hasanofvich Juraboev allegedly posted on the same board that he would kill President Obama if ISIS asked him to.

The plot is described as "aspirational, not operational," but the early stages of the plan seemed to be progressing, as Saidakhmetov was arrested at John F. Kennedy International Airport (JFK) while attempting to board a plane to Istanbul. Juraboev's plane ticket would have taken him to Turkey a month later. The third suspect, Abror Habibov, allegedly operated a domestic support network for the trio.

The individuals were reportedly inspired by the Islamic State's social media outreach program, including Tweets and forum posts calling for "lone wolf" jihadis to launch attacks in America and Europe. Fox News reports that two of the men came to the attention of law enforcement last summer after they expressed online support for the group. They have been charged with conspiracy to provide material support to the Islamic State and could face up to 15 years in prison if convicted.

The UK Daily Mail quotes Saidakhmetov's detailed plans, as laid out to a criminal informant, to carry out acts of violence if he could not enter Syria. He reportedly stated that he would "just go buy a machine gun, AK-47, and shoot all police." He had a four-stage plan in mind: "It is legal in America to carry a gun. We will go and purchase one handgun and then go and shoot on a police officer. Boom! Then we will take his gun, bullets, and bulletproof vest. Then we will do the same with a couple of others. Then we will go to the FBI headquarters and kill the FBI people."

The New York Daily News also reports a quote from a post allegedly left by Juraboev on an ISIS-aligned website: "We too wanted to pledge our allegiance and commit ourselves while not present [in Syria]. I am in the USA now but we don't have any arms. Is it possible to commit ourselves as dedicated martyrs anyway while here? What I'm saying is to shoot Obama and then get shot ourselves, will it do? That will strike fear in the heart of infidels."

The three men do not appear to have been particularly skilled or sophisticated terror operatives. However, as the New York Daily News notes, "lone wolf" jihad does not require much in the way of clever strategy or slick tradecraft. The report concludes with a reminder from NYPD counter-terrorism chief John Miller, who warned back in June that there were more than 100 would-be jihadis lurking in New York City.

Title: Romney's Vice Presidential Pick: Condoleezza Rice - A Potential Game Changer for the 2012 Race

Article:

The speculation surrounding Mitt Romney's vice presidential pick for the 2012 presidential race has gained momentum, with former Bush administration Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice emerging as a strong contender. This development was reported by the Drudge Report on Thursday, and Romney's wife, Ann, has hinted at the possibility of a female running mate.

Rice received a warm reception at Romney's donor retreat in Utah and a standing ovation at a GOP women's fundraiser in Washington, D.C. This week. If selected, Rice would be the first African-American woman to be on a major party's presidential ticket, a move that could help the GOP regain ground with minority, female voters, and single women, who have been a demographic challenge for the party.

Rice's selection would not be a mere political fad, as her experience and political acumen would compensate for Romney's lack of international experience. As a former secretary of state, Rice's expertise on foreign policy would be a valuable asset to the ticket. However, her stance on abortion and her role in the Bush administration, particularly in the Iraq war and the weapons of mass destruction controversy, could face opposition from both the left and the right.

Rice has also shown political courage by standing up for immigrants, opposing individual states' efforts to increase the pursuit of illegal immigrants. This stance could help the Romney campaign win over Latino voters, a critical demographic in the upcoming election.

Another critical reason for Romney to pick Rice is her involvement in the education reform movement. She has partnered with Joel Klein, the former chancellor of the New York City public school system, to draw attention to the crisis in American public education. The duo co-chaired a Council on Foreign Relations panel that examined the failure of public education as a threat to America's national security.

The panel's report found that 75 percent of American young adults do not qualify to serve in the military due to criminal records, physical unfitness, or inadequate levels of education. This includes about half of the nation's black and Hispanic students, who drop out of high school. The report also highlighted the U.S. State Department's inability to find enough foreign-language speakers to serve as interpreters and translators.

"The education crisis may well be the greatest threat to our national security," Rice stated at a recent speech before the Heritage Foundation in Washington. "The crisis in K-12 is producing unemployable people who will ultimately be on the dole because they will have nowhere else to go."

In his election night speech in New Hampshire last week, Romney expressed a desire to "stop the unfairness of urban children being denied access to the good schools of their choice." Rice's message on education reform could help jump-start the debate and potentially reform Romney's image, giving the education reform movement a boost.

Regardless of the outcome in November, a Romney-Rice ticket could create a political legacy for both candidates and serve their country by addressing the critical issue of education reform. An earlier version of this column originally appeared in The Hill newspaper and on TheHill.com.

Title: Wood Mackenzie Predicts Solar Energy as the Next Major Breakthrough in U.S. Energy Supply

Article:

The declining oil prices may be slowing the U.S. shale boom, but the nation will remain a leading global producer of oil and natural gas well into the future, thanks to advances in drilling technology. As the U.S. energy sector looks to the future, a new study by Scotland-based consultancy Wood Mackenzie suggests that solar energy could be the next major breakthrough.

In a study titled "Is Solar the Next Shale?", Wood Mackenzie argues that steep reductions in the costs of making solar modules put that technology in a strong position to compete with other forms of electric power in many parts of the U.S. The study predicts that by 2020, parity between the economics of large-scale solar installations and those for gas combined-cycle and combustion plants will exist in 19 states, increasing to 38 by 2030.

The study asserts that, just as shale extraction reconfigured oil and gas markets, no other technology is closer to transforming power markets than distributed and utility-scale solar. Solar energy will continue to be a small part of total U.S. electric generating capacity, accounting for 6% of the nation's generating mix in 2035, compared to just 1% now. However, a relatively small amount of solar capacity can go a long way toward disrupting electric power markets.

For example, solar power contributes the most during the day, when the sun is shining and demand for electricity is often at its peak. That's also when fossil-fuel power plants, including natural gas units, make most of their money. Moreover, the trend is set to continue, as the cost of solar continues to come down while the cost of combined-cycle gas plants, the preferred option for utilities, rises.

Prajit Ghosh, a research director with Wood Mackenzie, explains, "We certainly see an upside to solar, a significant upside. And you really don't need that much solar to hurt the economics of fossil-fuel plants. Even a small amount of solar can have a pretty significant impact on the value of gas and coal plants and reliability."

The growing challenge for the electric power industry and its regulators is to integrate solar into the grid without forcing gas-fired power plants offline and disrupting the reliability of utility systems. California is already grappling with the issue, and other regions with significant solar potential, like Arizona, New Jersey, and Texas, will increasingly do so.

Regarding the federal investment tax credit for solar systems on residential and commercial properties, which is set to expire on Dec. 31, 2016, Ghosh does not see any major setback for solar. He states, "The level of cost savings we expect [in solar] will more than compensate for any reduction in tax credit support."

Bill Loveless, a veteran energy journalist and television commentator in Washington, wrote the article. Loveless is the former host of the TV program Platts Energy Week.

Title: CNN Tonight with Don Lemon Draws Criticism for Segment Mocking Trump Supporters

Article:

A segment on CNN Tonight with Don Lemon has sparked controversy after guests Wajahat Ali and Rick Wilson engaged in a discussion that some viewers perceived as mocking President Trump's supporters. The conversation, which took place on Saturday, included derogatory comments about the President's base, their geographical knowledge, and their reading and writing abilities.

Rick Wilson initiated the exchange by stating that Secretary of State Mike Pompeo "knows deep in his heart that Donald Trump couldn’t find Ukraine on a map if you had the letter U and an actual crane." He further described Trump's base as a "credulous, boomer rube" demographic.

Wilson then mimicked a southern accent to say, " 'Donald Trump’s a smart one and y’ all elitists are dumb.' " Host Don Lemon laughed as Wilson mocked the voters. Ali joined in, saying, " 'Your geography, maps, spelling, knowing other countries, sipping your latte.' "

Wilson continued, " 'All those lines on the map,' " as Lemon's laughter persisted. Ali added, " 'Only them elitists know where Ukraine is,' " with both men laughing.

In response to the criticism, Ali jokingly apologized, saying, " 'I'm sorry, it was Rick’s fault. I blame Rick.' " Lemon also attempted to regain his composure, stating, " 'That was good. Sorry.' "

The segment has drawn criticism on social media, with some users expressing disapproval of the perceived disdain, bigotry, and disrespect towards Trump supporters. Critics argue that the segment demonstrates a lack of decency and a disregard for those who hold different political views.

The controversy has led to discussions about the role of media in shaping public opinion and the importance of maintaining respectful and inclusive dialogue, particularly during political discourse.

Title: Senate Judiciary Committee Releases Transcripts of Interviews Regarding Trump Tower Meeting

Article:

The Senate Judiciary Committee has released over 1,800 pages of transcripts from interviews with numerous figures involved in the June 9, 2016 meeting at Trump Tower. The controversial meeting, which initially fueled allegations of Trump campaign coordination with Russia, was downplayed in significance by Donald Trump Jr. and other key figures.

Donald Trump Jr. testified that he was "skeptical" going into the meeting with Russian lawyer Natalia Veselnitskaya. In an email to him, Rob Goldstone, who arranged the meeting at the request of pop singer Emin Agalarov, suggested that someone had official documents and information that would incriminate Hillary Clinton and her dealings with Russia. However, the meeting provided no meaningful information and was primarily focused on Russian adoptions, according to Trump Jr.

Veselnitskaya, in her written response, stated that no information specific to Clinton was provided in the meeting. She also lamented the "kind of apocalyptic Hollywood scenario" that a private conversation between a lawyer and a businessman can be turned into.

Trump Jr. testified that if he was given information on Clinton, he would have then consulted with counsel to "make an informed decision as to whether to give it any further consideration." He also noted that he was not aware of who would be in the meeting.

In addition to Trump Jr., the committee interviewed four other people who attended the Trump Tower meeting in New York: Rob Goldstone, Rinat Akhmetshin, Ike Kaveladze, and a translator. The panel was not able to interview Jared Kushner, Trump's son-in-law, or Paul Manafort, Trump's former campaign manager, despite both attending the Trump Tower meeting.

The White House has stated that the president was involved in drafting an initial statement after news of the meeting broke last year. The statement said the meeting primarily concerned a Russian adoption program, though Trump Jr. later released emails showing he agreed to the sit-down after he was promised information on Clinton. The emails also show he accepted the meeting despite it being described as part of a Russian government effort to aid his father's campaign.

Asked in the interview if his father was involved in drafting the statement, Trump Jr. said: "I do not know. I never spoke to my father about it." Trump Jr. also stressed that he did not tell his father about the meeting, saying "I would not have wasted his time with it."

Trump Jr. also told the Senate Judiciary Committee that he could not remember whether he had discussed the Russia investigation as a whole with his father, according to transcripts. He also said he did not think there was anything wrong with attending the Trump Tower meeting.

Like Trump Jr. and Kushner, who released a public statement about the meeting last year, Goldstone said the meeting was disappointing. He said he reported back to Emin Agalarov that "this was the most embarrassing thing you've ever asked me to do. I've just sat in a meeting about adoption."

The meeting is under scrutiny in Special Counsel Robert Mueller's Russia investigation. The testimony of Fusion GPS co-founder Glenn Simpson was also made public Wednesday, for a second time. His firm was behind the composition of the Trump dossier, filled with salacious and unverified allegations against the president regarding matters related to Russia.

Despite Fox News' past reporting that Simpson was with Veselnitskaya before and after the Trump Tower meeting, Simpson said in testimony that he was not aware of the meeting beforehand, and was "stunned" to later learn about it. Trump Jr. testified that at the time of the Trump Tower meeting, he "had never heard of Glenn Simpson or Fusion GPS."

Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Chuck Grassley, R-Iowa, said in a statement: "These materials, taken in their entirety, provide the most complete public picture of the events surrounding the meeting to date. Americans can now review this unfiltered information and arrive at their own conclusions."

Title: Former FBI Director James Comey's Memos Detail Conversations with President Trump

Article:

Former FBI Director James Comey's memos detailing his conversations with President Donald Trump have been released to the press. The documents, which span from early January to April of 2017, include accounts of their first meeting, phone calls, and various other interactions.

According to one memo, President Trump expressed "serious reservations" about the "judgment" of former National Security Adviser Michael Flynn. Flynn later pleaded guilty to lying to the FBI about conversations he had with a Russian ambassador.

In a memo dated January 28, 2017, Comey claims he reassured Trump during a dinner that the FBI would be fair in its investigation into Russian collusion and interference in the 2016 election. Comey wrote that Trump had expressed a need for loyalty and expected it in return.

During a phone conversation on March 30, Comey and Trump allegedly discussed the Russia investigation, with Trump urging Comey to tell the public that he was not under investigation. Comey wrote that he would "see what we could do and we would do the work well and as quickly as we could."

The Associated Press (AP) reported on Thursday that the classified memos were sent to Congress and subsequently leaked to the press. The memos provide insight into the relationship between Comey and Trump during the early stages of the Trump administration.

Title: Florida Surpasses 300,000 Confirmed COVID-19 Cases, Governor Addresses Testing Delays and Hospital Capacity

Article:

Florida surpassed 300,000 confirmed cases of the coronavirus on Wednesday, according to data collected by Johns Hopkins University. The state now sits behind only California and New York in the number of confirmed cases it has reported. Health officials reported an additional 10,181 new confirmed cases Wednesday.

Florida took more than three months to reach 100,000 coronavirus cases but then took just two weeks to jump from 100,000 to 200,000. Florida Governor Ron DeSantis addressed the surge in infections during a news conference Wednesday, stating that the state is doing roughly 90,000 tests per day but that the results were taking too long to process.

"One thing that I think is clear is that we need to get these testing results back in a timely fashion," DeSantis said. The governor also announced that the state would be shifting business away from commercial labs that have not been able to return test results in 48 hours, as originally agreed upon when testing was expanded in the beginning of May. Contact-tracers have also said delays in testing results are making their jobs more difficult.

Florida also reported an additional 112 deaths on Wednesday. This was the third time in the past seven days it has reported more than 100 deaths, according to CBS Miami. More than 4,500 people have died in the state due to COVID-19.

Florida's emergency management director, Jared Moskowitz, compared the state's response to a hurricane, but one complicated by politics. "When a Category 5 hits, nobody argues whether it was whether it was a Category 5, and in this disaster, we are arguing over everything," Moskowitz told ███.

DeSantis said additional medical personnel have been sent to Miami-Dade County, which is facing some of the highest infection rates in the state. Although the county's ICU beds are at capacity, the governor said the hospitals in the county still have plenty of other space that can be utilized for coronavirus patients. However, he added the real issue is a lack of healthcare workers.

The governor also announced the state will be introducing lanes at testing sites specifically for those exhibiting COVID-19 symptoms. People who use those lanes will administer the swabs themselves and their test results will be expedited, DeSantis said.

Title: Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg Threatens Legal Battle if Elizabeth Warren Tries to Break Up Facebook

Article:

Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg has indicated that he would expect a significant legal battle if Democratic presidential candidate Elizabeth Warren were to become president and attempt to break up Facebook. In an internal employee meeting in July, Zuckerberg stated that he was "worried" about the possibility of a breakup and that he would "bet that we will win the legal challenge" if Warren were to pursue such a move.

In response to Zuckerberg's comments, Warren tweeted, "What would really'suck' is if we don't fix a corrupt system that lets giant companies like Facebook engage in illegal anticompetitive practices, stomp on consumer privacy rights, and repeatedly fumble their responsibility to protect our democracy."

In March, Warren outlined a plan to break up several tech giants, including Facebook, arguing that they have "stifled innovation." If elected president, Warren stated that she would appoint regulators to unwind anti-competitive mergers like Facebook's acquisitions of Instagram and WhatsApp.

Other Democratic presidential candidates, such as Senators Bernie Sanders and Amy Klobuchar, have also expressed support for breaking up the tech giants.

In the July employee meeting, Zuckerberg expressed concern about the growing discussion around the power and dominance of tech companies and increased antitrust scrutiny from regulators. He argued that breaking up companies like Facebook would not solve the issues at hand and could actually make them worse. Zuckerberg argued that a broken-up Facebook would have fewer resources to detect hate speech and election interference efforts.

Zuckerberg's comments were made in the same month that Facebook reached a $5 billion settlement with the Federal Trade Commission over privacy failures related to the Cambridge Analytica scandal. Critics argued that the deal was a slap on the wrist for a company that generates $16 billion in revenue in a three-month period. The Facebook staff meetings happened in the midst of an escalating national discussion over the power and dominance of the giant tech companies and increased antitrust scrutiny from regulators.

Title: U.S. Evacuates Non-Emergency Personnel from Iraq Amidst Escalating Tensions with Iran

Article:

The United States has ordered the departure of non-emergency American employees from its diplomatic missions in Iraq due to perceived threats from Iran. The Trump administration is implementing new sanctions against Tehran and deploying additional forces to the Middle East to counter what it deems as an increased threat to U.S. soldiers and interests in the region.

Iran has labeled these actions as "psychological warfare," and a British commander has expressed skepticism regarding U.S. military concerns about threats to its approximately 5,000 soldiers in Iraq, who are assisting local security forces in combating Islamic State jihadists.

The U.S. State Department announced that employees at both the U.S. embassy in Baghdad and its consulate in Erbil, the capital of the semi-autonomous Kurdistan region, are being immediately withdrawn due to safety concerns. The number of personnel affected and any specific threat details were not disclosed. Visa services were also suspended at the heavily fortified U.S. missions.

A State Department spokesman stated, "Ensuring the safety of U.S. government personnel and citizens is our highest priority... and we want to reduce the risk of harm."

In a similar move, Germany, which has 160 soldiers in Iraq, suspended military training operations due to increasing regional tensions. The Netherlands also suspended a mission providing assistance to Iraqi local authorities, according to Dutch news agency ANP.

Both the United States and Iran have stated they do not wish for war, and Iraqi Prime Minister Adel Abdul Mahdi said on Tuesday he had indications "things will end well" despite the rhetoric. Iraq has stated it will maintain strong ties with Iran, the U.S., and regional neighbors, some of whom, like Saudi Arabia, view Tehran as an arch-rival.

U.S. Senator Chris Coons, a Democrat on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, told CNN in an interview on Wednesday, "I think we are now in a quite dangerous situation where a miscalculation by either side could lead us into conflict." Coons added, "When you project force into a very volatile region and you've got real tension between Iran and the Saudis -- we have to be careful. We need a strategy."

The State Department reissued a travel advisory for Iraq, stating U.S. citizens were at high risk of violence and kidnapping. "Anti-U.S. sectarian militias may also threaten U.S. citizens and Western companies throughout Iraq," it said.

A senior Iranian official stated on Wednesday that any conflict in the region will have "unimaginable consequences."

Title: Descendants of Confederate Military Leaders Divided on Military Base Name Changes

Article:

A recent poll by ███/Morning Consult indicates a significant majority of the general public is either indifferent or in favor of leaving military bases named after Confederate military leaders unchanged, or removing them. In an effort to shed light on the perspectives of the descendants of these leaders, ███ tracked down 16 relatives of eight Confederate military leaders whose names are associated with military bases or other prominent facilities.

The relatives, hailing from various political, geographical, and racial backgrounds, hold surprisingly consistent, though not unanimous, views. Most believe it is time for a change, with many advocating for the removal of their ancestors' names from all military monuments, buildings, streets, ships, planes, or paraphernalia. A minority, however, argue their ancestors deserve to be honored. Some family members hold diametrically opposing views, with some not speaking to each other over the issue.

The Army bases in question are Fort Rucker in Alabama, Forts Benning and Gordon in Georgia, Fort Polk and Camp Beauregard in Louisiana, Fort Bragg in North Carolina, Fort Hood in Texas, and Forts A.P. Hill, Pickett, and Lee in Virginia. These bases were established after the Civil War, primarily during two key military buildups to wage World War I and World War II.

At the time, many elected leaders from the South, including powerful members of Congress, were avowed racists and sought to recast the Civil War as not about slavery but a defense of states' rights. Only recently has the Army expressed a willingness to reconsider the names, following a deadly mass shooting in a Black church in South Carolina by a white supremacist in 2015.

For many descendants, there is no doubt about what needs to be done. Mimi Kirk, the great-great-great granddaughter of General John Brown Gordon, wants Georgia's Fort Gordon renamed to avoid honoring a leading white supremacist. Others, such as Tim Hill, 53, oppose changing the post in Virginia named for his direct ancestor, A.P. Hill, arguing that his ancestor fought for what he believed in and the fight was not about slavery but "Northern aggression."

Others, like Milbry Polk, 66, whose forebear Gen. Leonidas Polk is honored with Fort Polk in Louisiana, argue for a reassessment of historical figures, advocating for role models from various backgrounds, including Native Americans, women, and African Americans.

The issue remains a contentious one, with many descendants still grappling with how their ancestor's legacy should be remembered. Stephen M. "Sam" Hood, Hood's cousin, maintains that it is instructive to look at the individuals who are honored, not the causes for which they served for a brief period of their lives or careers. However, most of the descendants who have shared their views believe it is past time to honor only Americans whom everyone can agree are deserving.

Title: Attorney General Barr Instructs Federal Prosecutors to Monitor State and Local Shutdown Orders

Article:

Attorney General William Barr has directed federal prosecutors to be vigilant for overly restrictive state and local shutdown orders that may infringe upon individuals' constitutional rights. In a memo issued on Monday, Barr acknowledged that some restrictions are necessary and proper for combating the coronavirus pandemic, but others could potentially exceed constitutional and statutory protections.

The memo comes as some states begin to lift stay-at-home orders, while others remain cautious. Protests have emerged in certain parts of the country due to the surge in unemployment rates resulting from the shutdown orders.

Barr stated that if a state or local ordinance exceeds the appropriate authority to halt the spread of COVID-19 and becomes an excessive infringement on constitutional and statutory protections, the Department of Justice may need to intervene in federal court.

The Justice Department previously filed a statement of interest in a Mississippi lawsuit, supporting a church after local officials attempted to prevent Holy Week services in a parking lot where people were sitting in their cars.

In an interview on Hugh Hewitt's radio program, Barr expressed concern that some state orders were "disturbingly close to house arrest." He emphasized that while the objective was to flatten the curve of COVID-19 cases, that goal has largely been achieved, and states should now employ "more targeted approaches."

Barr's memo appoints the head of the Justice Department's civil rights division and the U.S. attorney for the Eastern District of Michigan to coordinate the department's efforts to monitor state and local policies and take action if necessary.

"Many policies that would be unthinkable in regular times have become commonplace in recent weeks," the memo states. "We do not want to unduly interfere with the important efforts of state and local officials to protect the public, but the Constitution is not suspended in times of crisis."

President Trump was asked about Barr's directive during a Monday press briefing. Trump responded, "Well, you'd have to ask Attorney General Barr, but I think he wants to see—like everybody—he wants to see people get back and he wants to see people get back to work. He doesn't want people to be held up when there's no reason for doing it. In some cases, perhaps it's too strict. He wants to make sure people have the rights and they maintain the rights, very importantly."

Title: Trump Questions Obama's Commitment to Fighting Radical Islamic Terrorism

Article:

In a phone interview on "Fox and Friends" on Monday, Donald Trump, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, expressed doubts about President Obama's commitment to fighting radical Islamic terrorism. Trump stated, "We're led by a man that either is not tough, not smart, or he's got something else in mind."

Trump further elaborated, "And the something else in mind, you know, people can't believe it, people can't believe that President Obama is acting the way he acts and can't even mention the words 'radical Islamic terrorism.' There's something going on—it's inconceivable. There's something going on."

The businessman has previously raised questions about Obama's birthplace and suggested he is not a Christian. In 2011, the White House responded to Trump's "birther" claims by releasing the president's long-form birth certificate.

During an interview on NBC's "Today" show, Trump argued that Obama intentionally pursues ignorance on the topic of Islamism. Although Trump considered the president to be clueless, he also gave consideration to conspiracy theories that the president has ulterior motives.

"There are a lot of people who think maybe he doesn't want to get it. A lot of people think maybe he doesn't want to know about it," Trump said.

Trump has repeatedly criticized Obama's handling of terrorism and, in February, accused the president of apologizing to Muslims after he visited a mosque to combat rhetoric against Muslim-Americans.

Several journalists highlighted Trump's comments on Monday, a day after Omar Mateen killed 49 people and injured dozens more in a shooting at an Orlando, Fla., nightclub.

Trump's comments on Monday were met with criticism on social media, with some comparing his statements to a Democratic suggesting 9/11 was an inside job on the day after the terrorist attacks.

During the "Today" show interview, Trump stated, "The president doesn't know [about radical Islamic terrorism] because he certainly does not do much about it in terms of intelligence, in terms of intelligence gathering."

"I'm not sure that the president knows, if you want to know the truth. He won't even use the term 'radical Islamic terrorism.' I think he thinks that everyone's just a sweetheart," Trump said.

"He won't even use the term 'radical Islamic terrorism,' which I think is insulting to our country and it's insulting to everybody," he added.

Title: Rep. Chris Collins Suspends Re-election Campaign Following Insider Trading Charges

Article:

Rep. Chris Collins, a New York Republican and one of President Trump's staunchest supporters on Capitol Hill, has suspended his re-election campaign following his arrest on insider trading charges on Wednesday.

In a statement, Mr. Collins said, "After extensive discussions with my family and my friends over the last few days, I have decided that it is in the best interest of the constituents of NY-27, the Republican Party, and President Trump's agenda for me to suspend my campaign for re-election to Congress."

The FBI accused Mr. Collins of dumping stock of a pharmaceutical company for which he was a board member and the biggest shareholder after learning that the clinical testing on a key drug turned out to be a complete "failure." The FBI claims his family saved $760,000 through the stock sale.

Democrats have seized on the news, stating that the charges are further evidence of a culture of corruption that has permeated the GOP since President Trump took office. They also assert that they would perform better if given the opportunity to run the House.

Mr. Collins described the charges as "meritless" and vowed to clear his name. He suggested he did not want to become a distraction in the high-stakes election this fall, where control of Congress is at stake.

"Democrats are laser-focused on taking back the House, electing Nancy Pelosi Speaker, and then launching impeachment proceedings against President Trump," Mr. Collins said in a statement. "They would not do anything more than to elect an 'Impeach Trump' Democrat in this District, which is something that neither our country or my party can afford."

Initially, Mr. Collins stated he planned to stay on the ballot after the news first broke. It is unclear whether Mr. Collins will meet the criteria for removing his name from the ballot. Democrats are optimistic that the seat, previously considered safely in the GOP's hands, could now be in play.

Title: Tucker Carlson Criticizes CNN for Misrepresenting DOJ IG Report on FISA Abuse

Article:

In a recent episode of his show "Tucker Carlson Tonight," Fox News host Tucker Carlson criticized CNN for misrepresenting the Department of Justice Inspector General (IG) report on Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA) abuse during the 2016 election. Carlson accused several CNN hosts, contributors, and guests of attempting to convince viewers that the Steele dossier was "totally irrelevant" to the FISA warrant application.

Carlson specifically targeted CNN primetime anchor Don Lemon, who had previously claimed that the report purportedly found the Russia probe's origins "legally sound" and "unbiased." In response, Carlson argued that Lemon was irresponsibly doubling down on a false narrative, as the report did not express what the CNN host claimed it did.

Senator John Kennedy (R-LA) also weighed in, stating that reading the DOJ IG report made him feel as if he had taken acid. In a recent clip, CNN primetime host Chris Cuomo mocked President Trump for claiming he is a "victim" in the FISA firestorm, to which Carlson responded by suggesting that Cuomo had not read the report himself.

Carlson also singled out CNN anchor and former Obama administration staffer Jim Sciutto, who in a 2018 tweet claimed the FBI would "further corroborate information in the [Steele] dossier... before using such intel to justify the FISA warrant." Carlson argued that Sciutto was incorrect "at best" and had not yet issued a correction.

The host also criticized NBC News intelligence correspondent Ken Dilanian, who tweeted in 2018 that Trump is "wrong about Carter Page, the dossier and the FISA warrant." Carlson remarked that Dilanian and his sources in the intelligence community were "completely wrong."

Overall, Carlson's criticism of CNN and other media outlets centers on their coverage of the DOJ IG report, which he claims has been misleading and inaccurate in portraying the origins and legitimacy of the Russia probe.

Title: Former House Speaker Newt Gingrich Criticizes President Obama's Immigration Policy as Unconstitutional Executive Action

Article:

Former House Speaker Newt Gingrich has criticized President Barack Obama's immigration policy, characterizing it as an unconstitutional executive action rather than a new government program. In an opinion piece for CNN and his Gingrich Productions website, Gingrich argues that the president's policy, as outlined in a White House memo, includes several new programs without Congressional approval, budget appropriation, or spending authorization.

In his prime-time address on Thursday, President Obama described a plan that prioritizes the deportation of felons, criminals, and gang members over other undocumented immigrants. However, Gingrich notes that the White House's real policy, as outlined in the memo, is a 17-point plan that includes a deferred action program to provide work permits for at least three years to eligible illegal immigrants and establishes criteria to keep people exempt from deportation.

According to the White House, the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) will create a deferred action program to give work permits to eligible illegal immigrants and establish criteria to keep people exempt from deportation. The DHS will have to employ thousands of bureaucrats to process those who "come forward and register, submit biometric data, pass background checks, pay fees, and show that their child was born before the date of the announcement." Applicants will also have to prove they have been in the country for at least five years and will have to pay taxes.

Gingrich argues that the policy is not just a pause on deportations for millions of people in the United States illegally, but a new program that hands out work authorizations and processes more paperwork than many state Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV) offices. He also notes that while the president said his executive action will offer relief to a narrow number of people, the policy memo states that DHS will "direct all of its enforcement resources at pursuing people who are 'national security threats, serious criminals, and recent border crossers.'"

Gingrich also criticizes the president for assuring the nation that his actions are lawful and the same kind taken by presidents over the past half-century. Gingrich argues that Obama does not have any congressional sanction like his predecessors and that his actions are "an order of magnitude larger" than those of previous presidents.

Gingrich also compares the president's actions to those of Obamacare co-architect Jonathan Gruber, who infamously stated that the Obama administration depended on "the stupidity of the American voter" to enable the healthcare reform plan. Gingrich describes the address as "a Gruber speech, and was designed to sound acceptable, even if it was a lie, a reference to Obamacare co-architect Jonathan Gruber's statements on how the Obama administration depended on 'the stupidity of the American voter' to enable the healthcare reform plan."

Gingrich concludes by stating that the president has described on video 22 times how he does not have the legal and Constitutional authority to enact the reforms he announced Thursday night. In 2011, Gingrich notes, Obama said that there are "laws on the books by Congress that are very clear in terms of how we have to enforce our immigration system that for me to simply through executive order ignore those congressional mandates would not conform with my appropriate role as President." However, Gingrich argues that this has all changed, and "it's a shame he apparently thinks, like Gruber, that Americans are all so stupid we won't figure out he's not telling us the truth today."

Title: U.S. Christian Leaders Urge Recognition of Jerusalem as Israel's Capital, but Embassy Move Delayed

Article:

More than 60 influential U.S. Christian leaders have sent a letter to President Donald Trump urging him to recognize Jerusalem as Israel's capital and move the U.S. Embassy there. However, a White House official told Reuters that President Trump will not move the embassy now due to concerns about complicating a resumption of Israeli-Palestinian negotiations.

The U.S. has a long diplomatic history in the Holy Land, with the first U.S. consulate established in 1844 inside the walls of the Old City, near the Jaffa Gate. The building is now used by the Christian Information Center. In 1912, the consulate moved to a location on Prophet's Street, and then to a location where the U.S. representative to the Palestinian Authority now sits. This consulate reports directly to the State Department rather than the U.S. Embassy in Tel Aviv. A U.S. government building providing consular services for U.S. citizens is about a 10-minute drive away, while the embassy remains in Tel Aviv.

The question remains whether the embassy will ever move to Jerusalem. In 1995, David Parsons, media director of the International Christian Embassy Jerusalem (ICEJ), helped draft the Jerusalem Embassy Act. "We actually met with [Arizona] Senator John Kyl up on Capitol Hill one day and we gauged that he was serious…that moving the embassy was an issue that he wanted to do on principle. It was not politics. It was principle, and he asked us to draft a bill," Parsons told ███ News.

However, the bill was changed as it went through Congress, and it included a presidential waiver authority, which allowed the president to suspend the bill if he certified it was in U.S. national security interests. "It's fear that has kept us out," Parsons explained. "It's been more than two decades since successive presidents have signed that waiver." The current waiver expires in June.

Israeli leaders hope that one day includes relocating the embassy. "Israel reunited Jerusalem 50 years ago, in 1967. But the connection with the Jewish people to Jerusalem spiritually goes back 2,000 years," Dore Gold, president of the Jerusalem Center for Public Affairs (JCPA), told ███ News. "And our claim, our presence in Jerusalem, has been here for decades…Jews have been streaming back to their ancient capital for years. And the movement of the embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem is an American recognition of the special ties of Jerusalem to the Jewish people. It may be symbolic, but it goes to the core of the identity of Israel."

"I think the U.S. moving the embassy to Jerusalem is the right thing to do. It's – it's way overdue, and, of course, it would be a blessing to – to the U.S," Parsons said. In 1950, Israel declared Jerusalem as its capital, and in 1967, it captured the Old City and the eastern part of Jerusalem. Then in 1980, Israel passed the Basic Law Jerusalem, incorporating all of the land captured in 1967 as its capital. That's when most embassies left Jerusalem for Tel Aviv, and ICEJ moved in.

"To represent Christians from all over the world who want to stand in solidarity with Israel, help secure it and help it reach its destiny and also want to stand in solidarity with their claim and connection to Jerusalem," Parsons said. And whether or not the U.S. Embassy eventually moves to Jerusalem, Parsons sees a glorious future for the city. "This is that promised Son of David, the Messiah, [who] will rule and reign over the world in peace and righteousness. We believe that's Jesus, but I think a house of prayer for all people, that exalted throne of the Messiah during the Messianic age. This is Israel's ultimate destiny and Jerusalem's."

Title: Sheriff Joe Arpaio Challenges Obama's Immigration Policy in Court, Claims Constitutional Violation

Article:

Arizona County Sheriff Joe Arpaio, known for his hardline stance on illegal immigration, argued in a U.S. District Court on Monday that President Barack Obama's immigration policy, which aims to protect nearly 5 million people from deportation, is unconstitutional. The hearing marked the first courtroom challenge to Obama's immigration actions.

Arpaio and his attorney, Larry Klayman, presented their case before U.S. District Judge Beryl Howell in Washington, D.C. During the hearing, Howell seemed skeptical of the lawsuit, questioning whether Arpaio has legal standing to challenge Obama's action. She suggested that Congress is in a better position to question the president's authority rather than a federal court.

A lawyer for the Obama administration called Arpaio's case a "political dispute" that should be dismissed. Howell, an Obama nominee, said she would issue a ruling soon. Klayman and Arpaio argue that the president violated the Constitution by bypassing Congress and making drastic changes to immigration programs.

Klayman, a conservative who has previously targeted the president, has alleged that Obama falsely claimed U.S. citizenship. In October, Klayman petitioned the Homeland Security Department to start deportation proceedings against Obama.

Under the immigration program, the Homeland Security Department would prioritize the removal of immigrants who present threats to national security, public safety, or border security. DHS officials could deport someone if an Immigration and Customs Enforcement field office director determined that removing the person would serve an important federal interest.

In the lawsuit, Klayman and Arpaio argue that the administration's policy change encourages more illegal immigration and leads to increased crime, burdening law enforcement. The Justice Department argues that this theory is speculative and unsubstantiated. Obama's program places greater emphasis on removing criminal aliens and recent border crossers, the government countered.

Evidence in the case includes a set of Arpaio press releases and letters to Homeland Security officials that claim more than 35 percent of immigrants living in Maricopa County illegally who wound up in Arpaio's jails in 2014 were repeat offenders, indicating, in the sheriff's view, that DHS has done a poor job of deporting criminals. Jennifer D. Elzea, a spokesperson for Immigration and Customs Enforcement, says that as a matter of policy, ICE does not comment on pending litigation. ICE, a DHS agency, can and does release immigrants who have been arrested on criminal charges, including those who have yet to be convicted, for a variety of reasons. In some instances, immigrants are released from immigration jails because they are from countries that won't provide travel documents or otherwise are not likely to be deported within a reasonable time.

Title: Central American Migrant Caravan Reaches Tijuana as US Deploys Troops to Border

Article:

Hundreds of Central American migrants, including members of the LGBTQ community, have reached the Mexican border city of Tijuana, having separated from a larger caravan of 5,000 people in Mexico City. The smaller group, which numbered approximately 400, traveled by bus, unlike the majority of the larger group who have been making their journey on foot.

The 5,000 migrants, who are fleeing persecution, poverty, and violence in their home countries of Honduras, Guatemala, and El Salvador, began their journey from the city of San Pedro Sula in Honduras on October 13, a distance of approximately 4,350km (2,700 miles) from Tijuana.

The smaller group, which reached Tijuana on Tuesday, joined a smaller group of about 80 migrants who arrived at the border city on Sunday. The larger group is expected to arrive at the border in the coming days.

The smaller group, which includes many LGBTQ individuals, reportedly parted ways with the main caravan after weeks of what they described as discriminatory treatment by local residents and fellow travelers.

Despite a harder US stance against them, the migrants have stated their intention to continue their journey to claim asylum. The journey poses numerous dangers, including attacks by criminal gangs, which is why many migrants feel safer traveling in numbers.

US Defense Secretary James Mattis is scheduled to visit the US-Mexico border on Wednesday, his first visit since thousands of troops were deployed. In response to the approaching caravan, up to 9,000 troops have been ordered to the border by President Donald Trump, who has referred to the caravan as an "invasion."

US authorities closed down several lanes of traffic at two border crossings from Tijuana to California on Tuesday to install barbed wire fencing and barricades to reinforce security. There is a legal obligation to hear asylum claims from migrants who have arrived in the US if they express fear of violence in their home countries.

Last week, Mr. Trump signed a proclamation temporarily barring migrants who enter illegally from claiming asylum. The caravans became a campaign issue in the US mid-term elections that took place last week, with Mr. Trump warning without evidence that the caravan includes "gang members," "hardened criminals," and even "Middle Eastern terrorists."

Title: Trump Calls for Samantha Bee's Firing Following Crude Remark About Ivanka Trump

Article:

U.S. President Donald Trump called for the termination of comedian Samantha Bee from her cable television program on Friday, following her use of a vulgar term about his daughter and White House advisor Ivanka Trump on her show "Full Frontal." The incident marked the latest episode in a week-long debate over the language used by two television personalities, which has become a symbol of the country's political divide.

On Tuesday, Walt Disney Co's ABC network canceled a revival of "Roseanne" after its star, Roseanne Barr, made a racist remark in a post on Twitter, comparing a former top Obama administration official to an ape. Trump criticized ABC and Bob Iger, chief executive officer of Disney, on Twitter, but did not address the content of Barr's comments.

Bee's use of a crude term for the female anatomy to describe Ivanka Trump on "Full Frontal" on Wednesday, while discussing the president's controversial immigration policies, prompted Trump's criticism. "Why aren't they firing no talent Samantha Bee for the horrible language used on her low ratings show?" Trump said on Twitter on Friday. "A total double standard but that's OK, we are Winning, and will be doing so for a long time to come!"

Both Bee and the TBS cable network, which airs the show, apologized on Thursday. "I would like to sincerely apologize to Ivanka Trump and to my viewers for using an expletive on my show to describe her last night," Bee said on Twitter. "It was inappropriate and inexcusable. I crossed a line, and I deeply regret it."

Following Trump's remarks on Friday, TBS spokesman Sal Petruzzi said there would be no further comment beyond the earlier apologies. State Farm Insurance suspended its commercials, and Autotrader also suspended its sponsorship, calling Bee's comments "offensive" in a statement.

Trump's presidential candidacy was thrown into crisis in 2016 after a tape emerged of him boasting about being able to grab women by their genitalia because of his star status. He had made those comments as he waited to film a segment for the TV program, "Access Hollywood," in 2005.

After "Roseanne" was canceled, the White House said the president would not defend Barr's comments but pointed to alleged media bias against the TV show, which portrays a working-class American family. The program, which originally aired from 1988 to 1997, has drawn praise from Trump since its return. Its reboot featured Barr portraying a Trump voter facing off against her sister, an ardent opponent of the president, and tackled other issues reflecting America's political divide.

TBS is owned by Time Warner Inc, which is seeking to merge with AT&T Inc in a move opposed by the Trump administration. Disney is seeking to merge with Twenty-First Century Fox Inc.

Title: Trump Shifts Focus from North Carolina Rally Chants to Criticism of Liberal Lawmakers

Article:

President Donald Trump on Friday attempted to redirect political pressure from his supporters' chants at a North Carolina rally, focusing instead on the comments made by four liberal lawmakers regarding U.S. policy and Israel.

During his departure from the White House en route to his New Jersey golf club, Trump stated, "They say things about Israel that's so bad I'm not even going to repeat them. They can't get away with that act."

The controversy arose after a Greenville crowd chanted, "Send her back!" on Wednesday, referring to Representative Ilhan Omar, a Somali refugee who became a U.S. citizen before being elected to Congress from Minnesota.

Trump has been critical of Omar, who is part of a quartet of freshman Democrats known as "The Squad." He has portrayed all four as the new "extreme" face of the Democratic Party. In a Sunday tweet, he told them to "go back" to their countries if they're unhappy. All four are citizens, and Omar is the only one who was born outside of the U.S.

Trump disavowed the chant on Thursday, but since then, he has focused on the liberal lawmakers' comments rather than the criticism that he is stoking an ugly side of his base ahead of the 2020 election.

"I don't care if it's good or bad about politics. Many people say it's good. I don't know if it's good or bad," Trump said. "I can tell you this—you can't talk that way about our country, not while I'm president."

When asked whether the liberal lawmakers are exercising their First Amendment rights when they criticize U.S. policy, Trump responded, "We have First Amendment rights, also. We can certainly feel and say what we want."

Trump also stated that he did not take advice from First Lady Melania Trump or his daughter, Ivanka, on how to respond to the chants, denying reports to the contrary as "fake news."

Title: Polls Show Enduring Opposition to Obamacare, With Critics Citing Broken Promises and Rising Costs

Article:

Two recent polls have revealed a persistent opposition to the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare. The Washington Post/ABC News poll, published yesterday, showed a 30 to 55 majority deeming President Obama's presidency a failure, with a significant number of respondents citing the president's divisive leadership and the implementation of Obamacare as key factors. The survey also reported a dismal 38 to 56 presidential approval rating on the implementation of Obamacare, and a majority opposed to the law itself, despite the poll's question wording that omits any mention of 'Obamacare' or the 'Affordable Care Act.'

A similar trend is observed in a new Kaiser Family Foundation poll, with support for the president's signature domestic accomplishment significantly outweighed by opposition.
