Healthcare industry expert Bob Laszewski argues that the law may have been largely out of the news for the last few months, but a fresh round of cancellations and the coming open enrollment period are about to change that.

The 2015 Obamacare open-enrollment, set to begin in November, is expected to be problematic, according to Laszewski. The HealthCare.gov backroom is not yet built, a year and counting after it should have been. The number of people enrolled in Obamacare is currently unknown due to the lack of a government to insurance company accounting system.

Large businesses expect to pay between 4 and 5 percent more for health-care benefits for their employees in 2015, according to employer surveys conducted this summer. Few employers plan to stop providing benefits with the advent of federal health insurance mandates, but a third say they are considering cutting or reducing subsidies for employee family members. Employees are also paying more each year in out-of-pocket health care expenses, according to the surveys.

Numerous polls have consistently found that roughly twice as many Americans say they've been personally hurt by Obamacare than helped. However, most consumers have responded that they have not been impacted one way or another. This trend is expected to change for millions in the coming months and years.

The Washington Post reports that higher costs and reduced benefits are on the way for many who are among the large majority of Americans receiving health coverage through their employers. The White House knew this was coming, and Senate Democrats voted down a Republican effort to reinforce the president's "keep your plan" promise, which continues to unravel for consumers for years to come.

In conclusion, the opposition to Obamacare remains strong, with critics citing broken promises and rising costs as key factors. The upcoming open enrollment period is expected to bring further challenges and confusion, with millions of people potentially facing higher rates and the need to change their plans.

Title: Mitt Romney Criticizes President Trump in Washington Post Op-Ed, Trump Responds on Twitter

Article:

Senator Mitt Romney, who will be sworn in to the Senate on Thursday, began the new year with a public condemnation of President Donald Trump in a Washington Post op-ed published Tuesday night. In the article, Romney criticized Trump for lacking the character and principles the office requires.

"When he won the election, I hoped he would rise to the occasion," Romney wrote. "But, on balance, his conduct over the past two years, particularly his actions this month, is evidence that the president has not risen to the mantle of the office."

As expected, the president responded to Romney's criticism on Twitter Wednesday morning. "Here we go with Mitt Romney, but so fast!" he wrote. "Question will be, is he a Flake? I hope not. Would much prefer that Mitt focus on Border Security and so many other things where he can be helpful. I won big, and he didn't. He should be happy for all Republicans. Be a TEAM player & WIN!"

Some have speculated that Romney's decision to speak out against the president's style, while still praising many of his policies and his appointment of conservative judges and Cabinet members, may mean he is positioning himself as a potential replacement to Jeff Flake, the Republican who most often publicly criticized the president.

In 2016, Romney openly criticized Trump, calling the candidate a "phony" and "fraud." Trump also criticized Romney, calling him a "failed presidential candidate" who "choked like a dog." After Trump's election, Romney changed his tune, and while he still said he thought the president was not "a role model for my grandkids on the basis of his personal style," he praised some of the president's policy decisions and expressed interest in joining his administration. Trump also publicly supported Romney in his bid for the Senate.

Title: Trump Pursues Bipartisan Tax Reform, Suggests Higher Taxes for Wealthy

Article:

President Donald Trump is advocating for bipartisanship in his latest push for tax reform, meeting with a group of moderate members of Congress from both parties on Wednesday, September 13. The meeting follows Trump's recent deal with Democratic leaders to raise the debt ceiling, a move that has sparked controversy among some Republicans.

During the meeting, Trump suggested that wealthy Americans may face higher taxes under a new tax plan, stating, "If they have to go higher, they'll go higher, frankly." This statement could potentially create a rift with Republicans, who generally oppose tax hikes. However, Trump's eagerness to strike a deal on tax reform may indicate a willingness to partner with Democrats.

As part of his tax push, Trump also scheduled a private dinner at the White House with congressional Democratic leaders, Sen. Charles Schumer of New York and Rep. Nancy Pelosi of California. The meetings come just one week after Trump made a deal to raise the debt ceiling with Schumer and Pelosi, a move that angered some Republicans and disrupted their legislative strategy through the end of the year.

Trump appeared confident about an agreement over taxes, stating, "The rich will not be gaining at all with this plan. We are looking for the middle class and we are looking for jobs – jobs being the economy." Trump's tax efforts are linked to the need for recovery efforts from hurricanes Harvey and Irma, as he tweeted, "With Irma and Harvey devastation, Tax Cuts and Tax Reform is needed more than ever before. Go Congress, go!"

Some Republicans who generally oppose tax hikes have not rejected Trump's idea of higher taxes for the wealthy outright. Rep. Mark Meadows, R-N.C., leader of the conservative House Freedom Caucus, said, "I'm willing to look at everything in trying to make sure that we get hard-working American taxpayers the most relief that we can."

A tax overhaul is a key promise for Trump and other Republicans. Rep. Mark Sanford, R-S.C., stated, "They want to see a pelt on the wall." He added, "If it’s not this, I don’t know what it is." Despite Trump's enthusiasm for a deal, skeptics note that neither the Trump administration nor Congress have a specific tax plan yet.

Trump's bipartisan push this week began at dinner Tuesday night at the White House with a group of senators in both parties. The White House stated that Trump and his guests discussed "advancing the administration’s legislative priorities, in particular tax cuts for the middle class." House Speaker Paul Ryan, R-Wis., who has clashed with Trump on some issues, said, "We're going to do it no matter what." However, he added, "We'd love to have the Democrats supporting and working with us in a constructive way on tax reform."

This article is based on information from the Associated Press and does not include personal opinions, political bias, or subjective language.

Title: Trump Administration's Efforts to Include Citizenship Question in 2020 Census May Affect Accuracy and Districting

Article:

The Trump administration is pursuing legal options to potentially include a citizenship question in the 2020 census, despite the Supreme Court's previous blocking of the question. The administration's efforts, according to legal and political experts, could lead to an undercount of residents in Democratic-leaning areas, which could benefit the Republican party in redrawing voting districts across the country.

The latest development came on Sunday evening, with the U.S. Department of Justice installing a new team of lawyers to handle the ongoing litigation that has been ongoing for over a year. Thomas Wolf, a lawyer who focuses on census issues at the Brennan Center for Justice, stated, "Even if the question is [taken] off, if people are tweeting as if it may be a real possibility, it continues to raise fears and depress the count."

The U.S. Constitution requires the government to count all residents, regardless of their legal status, every ten years. The information collected becomes the basis for voting maps and distributing some $800 billion in federal funds each year. It is illegal for the Census Bureau to share information about individuals with law enforcement or immigration authorities.

The idea of asking residents about their citizenship status has nonetheless stoked fears that the survey would become a tool for the Trump administration's hardline immigration policies. The president and his allies have argued that it is important to know about citizenship status, and characterized the question as something that should not draw controversy.

A poll earlier this year showed 66% of Americans support the inclusion of the citizenship question. However, demographers, advocacy groups, corporations, and even the Census Bureau's own staff have said the citizenship question threatens to undermine the survey. Communities with high immigrant and Latino populations could have low response rates, potentially benefiting non-Hispanic whites, a core part of Trump's support, and helping Republicans gain seats in Congress and state legislatures, critics have said.

The question seemed dead in June, when the Supreme Court blocked it, saying the administration had given a "contrived" rationale for its inclusion. However, the high court left open the possibility that the administration could offer a plausible rationale. Department of Justice lawyers said on Friday that they were exploring other explanations. Trump also said he may try to force it into the survey through an executive order.

Legal experts immediately slapped down the ideas. It will be hard to convince justices that a new explanation is not also contrived, and an executive order would not override the Supreme Court decision or undo other court orders blocking the citizenship question, they said. Thomas Saenz, the president and general counsel of MALDEF, a Latino rights group pursuing one of the cases against the administration, stated, "Our government is not a dictatorship."

Trump also said on Friday that although census forms are already being printed, the government could later produce "an addendum." It is not clear how that might work, but census experts said it would be an unprecedented disruption to a process that has been in motion for years. An addendum would also likely be challenged in courts for running afoul of various administrative laws.

On Friday, the American Civil Liberties Union filed a motion to prevent the citizenship question from being added. In the meantime, attention surrounding the legal debacle may already be hurting the census and helping Trump achieve his goals, said Jessica Levinson, a professor at Loyola Law School in Los Angeles. "The longer he has this conversation, the worse it is for an accurate census count," she said.

Title: U.S. Ambassador to the U.N. Demands Action Against Cuba and Bolivia for Disrupting Political Prisoners Event, Causing Property Damage

Article:

U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations, Nikki Haley, has demanded action from U.N. Secretary-General Antonio Guterres following disruptions caused by the Bolivian and Cuban delegations during a U.S. event highlighting the plight of political prisoners in Cuba. The event, titled "Jailed for What? The plight of Cuba’s political prisoners," took place in the U.N.'s Economic and Social Council (ECOSOC) chamber on Tuesday.

The event descended into chaos as diplomats from the two countries, including Bolivian Ambassador Sacha Llorenti, disrupted the event by banging on tables and shouting slogans. Speakers, including former prisoners and relatives of those currently imprisoned under the communist regime, struggled to be heard over the noise.

In a letter sent to Guterres on Friday and obtained by ███, Haley described the behavior of the Cuban and Bolivian diplomats as "outrageous" and called for action from the Secretary-General. The letter states, "Due to the outrageous behavior of the Cuban and Bolivian U.N. delegations, this diplomatic event became a mob scene, and resulted in significant damage to U.N. property."

Haley called for Guterres to condemn the unprofessional conduct of the Cuban and Bolivian diplomats and require the two delegations to pay for the property damage they caused. Initially, the U.N. stated that the U.S. would be contacted to pay for the damage to desks and earphones, but U.N. officials later said that the U.N. itself would bear the cost. Haley deemed this "completely unacceptable" considering the U.S. is the largest contributor to the U.N. budget, paying 22 percent of the budget and, therefore, any repair cost as well.

In a statement to ███, Haley was critical of the behavior of the delegations. "Cuba’s UN delegation destroyed property with their juvenile, unprofessional behavior that was a mockery of diplomacy," she said. "There’s no way the U.N. should pay for those repairs – with U.S. taxpayers footing 22 percent of that bill. The bill needs to be sent directly to Cuba."

The Cuban Mission has already called for an investigation into the event, stating it was a "political comedy staged on false arguments and with supporting actors of a dark history at the service of a foreign power." The mission also accused the U.S. of subverting the legitimately established constitutional order and of pursuing an interventionist agenda.

Stephane Dujarric, spokesman for Guterres, told ███ that missions must certify that public meetings are consistent with the purposes and principles of the U.N. and are non-commercial in nature. He also stated that it is not the role of U.N. security to remove disruptive delegates unless they pose a physical threat.

Haley welcomed the Cuban call for an investigation and suggested that the U.N. should also investigate the damage and the misconduct by the Cuban and Bolivian delegations, including removing access to the U.N. for those responsible. "This conduct was an assault on the dignity, ideals, and fundamental purposes of the U.N.," she said.

Dujarric told ███ that the Secretary-General's office had received the letter and was looking into it. The Bolivian and Cuban missions did not immediately respond to requests for comment. The event on Tuesday still went ahead, with speakers yelling over the protesters, but the U.S. stated that the event was delayed after the Cuban delegation refused to allow security to conduct a sweep of the chamber.

Haley, who is stepping down from her role at Turtle Bay in January, has been vocal in standing for the interests of the U.S. and its allies at the U.N. Last week, she criticized the U.N. General Assembly for electing a number of countries with poor human rights records to the controversial Human Rights Council, including Eritrea, Cameroon, Somalia, and Bangladesh. "This lack of standards continues to undermine the organization and demonstrates again why the United States was right to withdraw from it earlier this year," she said.

Title: Rick Perry's 2016 Presidential Campaign: An Analysis of His Exit and the Implications

Article:

Rick Perry, the former Governor of Texas, has announced his withdrawal from the 2016 presidential race. The author of the article expresses disappointment over Perry's decision, attributing it to the preferences of Republican voters, the Republican Party apparatus, and the media's focus on other candidates.

The author argues that Perry, despite not being particularly skilled at debating and lacking a significant polling boost, was a more qualified candidate than several others in the race. They question whether people genuinely believe Perry is less credible than candidates like Ben Carson, Carly Fiorina, or Chris Christie, or that he is less capable of uniting the party and winning the White House.

The author criticizes the Republican National Committee and media organizations for allowing opinion polls to dictate the candidates' inclusion in debates during a time when public interest in the election is low. They argue that this approach unfairly favors low-polling candidates who can gain attention through unconventional means, such as memorable debate moments or controversial statements.

The article highlights Texas' success under Perry's governorship, citing its thriving cities, economic recovery, and equitable distribution of economic growth. The author suggests that Texas' record of success, particularly in contrast to the Mormon-Mountain West, offers a compelling narrative that the Republican Party should share with the nation.

The author criticizes the current debate-centric nature of the presidential race, arguing that being a skilled debater does not necessarily translate to being a successful president. They suggest that the early polling numbers, which led to Perry's exclusion from the main debates, unfairly burdened his campaign.

The author concludes by expressing their belief that Perry's presidential aspirations were lost due to the whims of the electoral process rather than his own inadequacies. They suggest that Perry's tax plan and record as a campaigner have improved since his previous run in 2012, and that his record as a governor is more credible than those of other candidates, such as Chris Christie, Scott Walker, and Bobby Jindal.

Title: Study Reveals Disparities in Neighborhood Opportunities for Minority Children in U.S.

Article:

Researchers from Brandeis University and Ohio State University have found significant disparities in the neighborhood opportunities for children of different racial and ethnic backgrounds in the United States. The findings, published in the Child Opportunity Index, reveal that about 40 percent of black children and 32 percent of Hispanic children live in the lowest-opportunity neighborhoods in their respective metropolitan areas, compared to just 9 percent of white children.

The researchers analyzed data from diversitydatakids.org, examining various neighborhoods based on socioeconomic indicators such as housing foreclosure rates and access to educational and healthcare facilities. The study shows that minority children are more likely to reside in disadvantaged neighborhoods that lack access to early childhood education centers, parks, health-care facilities, and other essential resources.

White children do not experience this debilitating disadvantage even in the cities where they are worst off. The problem is most pronounced for white children in Honolulu, where 23 percent live in the lowest-opportunity neighborhoods. In contrast, 60.3 percent of the Albany metro area's black children and 57.6 percent of Boston's Hispanic children live in the worst neighborhoods.

Living in disadvantaged neighborhoods can have long-lasting consequences for children, according to a 2008 study published in Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences. The study found that living in a disadvantaged neighborhood is equivalent to missing a year or more of school, and the negative impact persists even after the child moves out of the area.

The Atlantic's Ta-Nehisi Coates covered similar research in "The Case for Reparations," focusing on Chicago, one of the most economically and racially segregated major U.S. cities. The average per capita income of Chicago's white neighborhoods is almost three times that of its black neighborhoods. A 2012 study by Harvard sociologist Robert J. Sampson found that a black neighborhood with one of the highest incarceration rates (West Garfield Park) had a rate more than 40 times as high as the white neighborhood with the highest rate (Clearing).

Based on the Child Opportunity Index's data, these neighborhood disparities persist across the nation, placing America's minority children on a worse trajectory at the start of their lives.

Title: Navy Secretary Nominee Philip Bilden Withdraws from Consideration

Article:

Philip Bilden, President Donald Trump's nominee for Secretary of the Navy, has withdrawn from consideration for the post, citing concerns about privacy and separating himself from his business interests. This marks the second time a Trump nominee for a military post has withdrawn before confirmation.

Bilden, an intelligence officer in the Army Reserve from 1986 to 1996, relocated to Hong Kong to establish an Asian presence for HarbourVest Partners, a global private equity management firm. He recently retired from HarbourVest Partners after 25 years.

Earlier this month, Vincent Viola, a West Point graduate and former airborne officer, also withdrew from consideration to be Secretary of the Army. Viola is the founder of several businesses, including the electronic trading firm Virtu Financial, and owns the National Hockey League's Florida Panthers and is a past chairman of the New York Mercantile Exchange. Viola withdrew due to his inability to navigate the confirmation process and defense department rules concerning family businesses. The Army secretary post remains unfilled.

Reports of Bilden's withdrawal had been circulating for days but were denied by White House Press Secretary Sean Spicer, who stated that Bilden was 100% committed to the role. In a statement on Sunday, Defense Secretary Jim Mattis confirmed Bilden's decision and stated that he would recommend a new nominee in the coming days.

"This was a personal decision driven by privacy concerns and significant challenges he faced in separating himself from his business interests," Mattis said.

In his own statement, Bilden said, "I informed Secretary of Defense Mattis with regret that I respectfully withdraw from consideration as nominee for the 76th secretary of the navy." He determined that he would not be able to satisfy Office of Government Ethics requirements without what he called "undue disruption and materially adverse divestment of my family's private financial interests."

Title: House Republican Leadership Scramble: McCarthy Steps Down as Speaker Candidate, No Clear Successor Emerges

Article:

In a historic turn of events, House Republican leader Kevin McCarthy has announced he will not run for Speaker of the House, plunging the House Republican Conference into a leadership scramble not seen in more than a decade. The decision leaves the House with no apparent line of succession to power, as Republicans grapple with ideological divisions and an uncertain governing agenda amid several legislative battles in the coming weeks.

McCarthy's decision, made Thursday afternoon before a planned closed party election, was influenced by a host of factors. He had initially believed he would win the speakership, but was reportedly crippled by the same problems that had dogged former Speaker John Boehner. One of these issues was the creation of the Select Committee on Benghazi, which some Republicans perceived as an attempt to harm Hillary Clinton's presidential campaign.

As of now, the general consensus within the House Republican Conference is that there is only one man who can garner the 218 votes needed to be speaker: Wisconsin Rep. Paul Ryan. Ryan has resisted calls to run in the past, but both Boehner and McCarthy have asked him to reconsider. He has canceled his fundraising appearances for the next 48 hours and is considering a bid.

Other names being floated include Reps. Lynn Westmoreland of Georgia, Mike Conaway and Bill Flores of Texas, John Kline of Minnesota, and Tom Cole of Oklahoma. Some of these lawmakers, most notably the retiring Kline, have been mentioned as caretakers of the office until after the 2016 elections. Reps. Daniel Webster of Florida and Jason Chaffetz of Utah, the two men who ran against McCarthy, are still in the race for the speakership.

With McCarthy remaining as majority leader, there will be no race for his position or whip. Reps. Steve Scalise of Louisiana and Tom Price of Georgia, who had been running for the majority leader job, will have to abandon their campaigns. Reps. Patrick McHenry of North Carolina, Pete Sessions of Texas, and Markwayne Mullin of Oklahoma will all be forced to abandon their campaigns for whip.

Former Speaker John Boehner had planned to resign effective Oct. 30, but he will now stay on as speaker until Republicans select his successor. Boehner canceled an appearance on NBC's "The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon" after McCarthy withdrew from consideration.

The current state of chaos in the House Republican Conference recalls another dark time for the party. In Dec. 1998, during the impeachment proceedings of President Bill Clinton, Louisiana Rep. Bob Livingston plunged the House into chaos by admitting to extramarital affairs and resigning from Congress. Livingston was speaker designate, slated to take the job from the outgoing Newt Gingrich. The admission stunned Capitol Hill, and the country.

The Republicans will need a unifying force once again, and this process will begin Friday morning when the party retreats to a room in the Capitol basement for a special GOP conference meeting. Party leaders want to get the Republican lawmakers on the same page.

"If we're going to be strong, we need to be united," McCarthy said at a news conference after his announcement. He said the party needs a "new face," and he did not want to win the job with the bare minimum level of support. The conservative House Freedom Caucus, a bloc of roughly 40 Republicans, continues to loom large, having endorsed Webster Wednesday and vowing to vote together in the closed party election.

Title: President Trump Honors Heroes of Dayton and El Paso Shootings, Renews National Debate on Gun Control

Article:

President Donald Trump on Monday honored 11 individuals who displayed acts of bravery during the mass shootings in El Paso, Texas, and Dayton, Ohio, in August. The president presented the nation's highest award for public safety officers to six police officers who confronted the gunman in the Dayton shooting, and five civilians who helped others during the El Paso shooting.

In his address at the White House, Trump acknowledged the tragic events that occurred on August 3 in El Paso, where a white supremacist opened fire, killing 22 people and wounding 27 others. He also addressed the Dayton shooting on August 4, where a shooter killed nine people and injured 34 others.

"On Saturday, August 3rd, at a Walmart in El Paso, Texas, the soulless and bigoted monster killed 22 innocent people and wounded 27 others. It was a racist attack motivated by pure evil," Trump said. "The next day in Dayton, Ohio, a vile and wicked murderer stole nine lives and injured 34 others."

In Dayton, officers confronted the shooter within 30 seconds, a swift response credited with preventing more deaths. The officers awarded the Public Safety Officer Medal of Valor were Sgt. William Knight and Officers Brian Rolfes, Jeremy Campbell, Vincent Carter, Ryan Nabel, and David Denlinger. All returned fire on the gunman, but it was unclear which officer or officers fired the bullets that killed Connor Betts, 24.

Trump also honored five civilians who helped others as a gunman opened fire at a Walmart in El Paso. The five — Robert Evans, Gilbert Serna, Marisela Luna, Angelica Silva, and Chris Grant — risked their lives to help others. Grant, who was still recovering from a pair of gunshot wounds, was represented by his mother, Minnie Grant.

Grant threw bottles and other merchandise at the gunman, Patrick Crusius, 21, to distract him and prevent him from shooting others. Trump highlighted Grant's actions, stating, "Chris Grant was picking out snacks for his kids when he suddenly saw the murderer firing at innocent shoppers a few aisles away from him. Chris grabbed — listen to this — soda bottles and anything else in front of him and began hurling them at the gunman, distracting him from the other shoppers and causing the shooter to turn toward Chris and fire at Chris."

Trump praised the heroes, stating, "In the moments of darkness, danger, and despair, God calls the bravest to action. These 11 individuals answered the call. They stared down evil. They put love of neighbor above life itself, and we are blessed by their courage."

The twin shootings have sparked renewed national discussion on gun control, with Democrats and mayors from cities affected by mass shootings, including Dayton, pressuring the Senate and White House to act on House bills calling for stricter background checks. The president has at times expressed support for tougher background checks but has also questioned their value and praised the NRA since the latest mass shootings.

Title: Iran's Nuclear Program Expansion: A Look at the Centrifuge Numbers

Article:

In a recent news conference, Secretary of State John Kerry addressed the expansion of Iran's nuclear program, suggesting that the current number of centrifuges, estimated at 19,000, was a result of the program's growth during the Obama administration.

According to Kerry, in 2003, Iran had 164 centrifuges, an offer that was not taken by the Bush administration. He stated that since then, the number of centrifuges has grown significantly. Analysts suggest that approximately 74% of the current centrifuges were installed since the Obama-Biden administration took office.

By late 2007, Iran reportedly possessed about 3,000 centrifuges. Over the course of the Bush administration's final 12 to 15 months, it is estimated that Iran added to, but did not fully double, the number of centrifuges it had installed. This would mean that roughly 25% of the current total of centrifuges had been installed when the Bush-Cheney era ended.

Secretary Kerry's concise history of the Iranian nuclear program, which encompassed only the years 2003 and 2013, omitted significant details. Determining exactly when the regime crossed a given technical threshold can be difficult, given the opacity of the government and the complex of commercial, military, and scientific institutions that have contributed to the program over the last two decades.

In interviews before leaving Geneva, Kerry expanded on his theme, telling ABC News' George Stephanopoulos, "You can't always start where you want to wind up." Kerry's spokeswoman, Jen Psaki, stated that the administration has not questioned the fact that Iran has made progress on enrichment and developing a nuclear weapon, and that this is one of the reasons why they stepped up sanctions over the past couple of years.

Secretary Kerry is scheduled to testify before Congress on Iran in a House Foreign Affairs Committee hearing on Dec. 10, an opportunity to provide more clarity on the matter. When confronted with the notion that at least 70% of the expansion in Iran's centrifuge program took place on President Obama's watch, Psaki countered that the administration is focused on halting and rolling back the progress of Iran's program and working towards a comprehensive agreement to bring an end to it.

Title: Senator Jeff Merkley Announces Support for Iran Nuclear Deal, Narrowing Vote Gap for President Obama

Article:

Democratic Senator Jeff Merkley of Oregon has announced his intention to vote in support of the Iran nuclear deal, bringing the number of senators publicly favoring the agreement to 31. This development places President Barack Obama just three votes short of securing the necessary support to protect the pact in Congress.

In a statement issued on Sunday, Senator Merkley expressed his belief that the accord represents "the best available strategy to block Iran from acquiring a nuclear weapon." The Iran nuclear deal involves easing economic sanctions on Iran in exchange for curbs on its nuclear program.

With Merkley's support, the Senate now has 31 senators publicly in favor of the deal. Barring defections, Obama needs three more votes from 13 Senate Democrats who have yet to declare their position. If Obama can secure 41 Senate votes by gaining the support of most of the remaining Democrats, the Senate may not vote on the agreement at all.

The Republican-controlled Congress has until September 17 to pass a resolution disapproving the deal reached in July between six world powers and Iran. President Obama has pledged to veto that resolution if it reaches his desk.

While Republicans have been united in their opposition to the deal, only two Democratic senators - Charles Schumer of New York and Robert Menendez of New Jersey - have joined them so far. Senator Chris Coons, a Delaware Democrat on the Foreign Relations Committee, is expected to announce his decision on Tuesday. Among other Democrats yet to disclose a position are Maryland's Ben Cardin and New Jersey's Cory Booker.

The only uncertain Senate Republican vote is that of Senator Susan Collins of Maine, who remains undecided and is expected to make her decision after September 7.

In a statement on his website, Senator Merkley outlined his reasons for supporting the deal, while acknowledging "significant shortcomings" that require addressing with "a massive intelligence program" and monitoring. Merkley expressed concerns about the deal's allowance for Iran to import conventional arms after five years and ballistic missile technology after eight years, as well as the lack of restrictions on how Iran can use money it reclaims when sanctions are lifted.

However, Merkley rejected a proposal from deal opponents to renegotiate the accord for better terms. If the U.S. rejects the deal and Iran resumes its nuclear program, "the United States would be viewed by the international community as undermining a strong framework for peacefully blocking a potential Iranian bomb," Merkley stated.

While the Republican-controlled House has enough votes to pass a resolution rejecting the deal, it remains unclear whether the Senate does. Assuming all 54 Senate Republicans oppose the accord, they would need support from six Democrats to get the 60 votes necessary to advance a resolution.

Title: Republican Strategist's Predictions on Trump's Reelection and Impeachment Proceedings

Article:

In April 2018, political analyst and commentator Mark McKinnon, in a piece titled "Trump 2020 Campaign Forecast: 99 Percent Chance of Thunder and Lightning," predicted that the impeachment of President Donald Trump could coincide with his reelection campaign. This prediction was based on the potential for a "nation divided" and the "ultimate stress test" on American democracy.

Fast forward to September 2019, and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi has announced formal impeachment proceedings against President Trump, leading to renewed interest in McKinnon's prediction. In a follow-up piece titled "Will Trump's Reelection Campaign Collide with Impeachment?", McKinnon cited comments from veteran GOP strategist Roger Stone and a report from Axios, which suggested that Trump would run for reelection while playing the "victim card" if impeached but not convicted.

Since Pelosi's announcement, McKinnon has received a series of messages from the Trump campaign and allied GOP organizations, which appear to be operationalizing the strategic concepts mentioned in McKinnon's pieces. These messages encourage supporters to turn impeachment into a campaign advantage, play the victim card, and exploit the circumstances to raise funds.

The messages assume that, as a Republican, McKinnon will overlook and excuse Trump's behavior, a presumption that troubles him. He states, "I am proud to be an American who values the Constitution, separation of powers, and the well-being of our nation before my party."

McKinnon's renewed interest in the potential collision of Trump's reelection campaign and impeachment proceedings has led to questions about the future of the Republican Party and the nation. He wonders if Republican elected leaders and voters will stand with Trump no matter what, even if the evidence proves he violated his oath of office. He also questions whether the country is heading towards a monumental constitutional crisis that could lead to an "uncivil war."

McKinnon concludes by questioning the actions of Senator Lindsey Graham and invoking the name of the late Senator John McCain, suggesting that McCain would have acted differently in this situation. The article ends with McKinnon expressing his hope that the Republican Party will do what is right for the nation.

Title: Michelle Obama Stumps for Virginia Governor Candidate Terry McAuliffe, Raises Funds for US Senate Candidate Edward J. Markey

Article:

Michelle Obama, the wife of President Barack Obama, is actively campaigning in key 2013 races, despite the ongoing political scandals surrounding the White House. On Thursday, she will raise funds for Terry McAuliffe, the former Democratic National Committee chief running for Virginia governor, at a hotel fundraiser in Fairfax County.

Josh Schwerin, spokesman for the McAuliffe campaign, stated, "Michelle Obama has been a leader on standing up for women, military families, and children. Terry McAuliffe is committed to continuing that work. She is one of the most popular figures in America, and we're really excited to have her here in Virginia."

The Virginia race is an off-season election, but it is critical as the state, captured twice by President Obama, is considered purple and is a target for Democrats aiming to convert it for the foreseeable future. The contest between McAuliffe and GOP nominee Ken Cuccinelli is heating up, with both candidates trying to woo female voters and reach across the aisle to build a winning coalition to succeed Republican incumbent Bob McDonnell.

Larry Sabato, director of the Center for Politics at the University of Virginia in Charlottesville, commented, "The first lady is traditionally a great draw for a big crowd, and she has little of the downside presented by her husband's controversies. People assume that the first lady is not involved in Oval Office skullduggery, and usually, this is the correct evaluation."

Last week, Michelle Obama brought in an estimated $600,000 for Rep. Edward J. Markey (D), who is running for the US Senate in Massachusetts against Republican Gabriel Gomez. Obama has also appeared recently at the Democratic National Committee's Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, and Transgender Leadership gala in New York City.

At these events, the first lady's message is that in backing these candidates or issues, voters are helping her husband's cause. Republicans, with a national leadership void, do not have an equally charismatic counterpart for her.

According to Gallup, President Obama's approval rating has slipped below the 50 percent watermark, at 48 percent. By contrast, Gallup's most recent polling of the public's view of the first lady showed her with a 65 percent favorable rating.

Tracy Sefl, a Washington-based Democratic consultant, said the first lady "speaks with a combination of accessible language and emotion" and "audiences find her magnetic." At campaign events, she does not have to delve into the weeds of congressional inquiries, and the questions or interruptions that have sometimes intruded on the president's public events do not occur when the first lady hits the trail.

"Her calendar is highly strategic," Sefl adds. "Democrats recognize that her appearances on behalf of marquee candidates like Terry McAuliffe are all the more valuable during this lighter election cycle year. The spotlight she commands becomes even brighter. She's proven to be a Teflon first lady."

However, some speculate that the recent appearances could indicate more than a savvy political use of the more popular Obama. In the waning months of her husband's tenure, Hillary Clinton turned her attention to a US Senate bid in New York, so could this be an early sign of how formidable a candidate Michelle Obama might be?

Or has the Princeton and Harvard Law grad effectively tired of the Washington scene?

Professor Sabato, for his part, thinks the first lady – despite her proven campaign skills – will probably move onto other things. "I'd be willing to bet Michelle Obama won't run for office," he says. "While she's clearly enjoying the platform her current unofficial office brings, she would not have chosen politics as the family profession. Hillary Clinton is the exception that proves the rule about first ladies. Unlike Hillary, the rest have been quite happy to move back into semi-private life once the White House tour of duty is over."

Michelle Obama will appear Thursday for McAuliffe at the Sheraton in Tysons Corner. Tickets range from $100 to $750; several hundred supporters are expected.

Title: Trump Called to Release Secret Obama Administration Documents for Transparency

Article:

President-elect Donald Trump is expected to face doubts about his legitimacy from the day he takes office, with opponents potentially portraying him as governing in unprecedented and reckless ways. In response, it is suggested that Trump should follow the precedent set by President Obama by releasing secret memos and documents from the Obama administration.

In 2009, shortly after taking office, President Obama released many of the secret Bush administration legal memos that explained the president's authority to order torture, deploy troops in American towns and cities, and ignore the Fourth Amendment's prohibition on warrantless, unreasonable searches. These disclosures signaled a new era in Washington and helped give Obama a reputation as a champion of civil liberties.

It is proposed that Trump should quickly reveal the secret memos underlying Obama's "targeted killing" drone assassination program, as well as the paper trail preceding and following the U.S. bombing of Libya in 2011. The release of these documents could help prevent similar foreign policy follies in the future and vindicate Trump's warnings on the campaign trail about U.S. intervention in the Syrian Civil War.

The Obama administration has been criticized for its handling of Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) requests, with federal agencies reportedly censoring government files or denying access to them. If Hillary Clinton had won the presidency, some people would have blamed the State Department's "slow walking" of FOIA requests for her emails, which she improperly kept on a private server.

The Department of Homeland Security also has a dreadful FOIA record, with political appointees stifling FOIA responses in a process that "reeks of a Nixonian enemies list." Under Obama, the Transportation Security Administration (TSA) became far more intrusive and abusive, launching "enhanced patdowns" that require screeners to touch passengers' breasts and genitals. The TSA conceals almost all information over its groping (which has caught zero terrorists) with a "sensitive security information" FOIA designation that justifies perpetual secrecy.

Exposing TSA coverups and reining in the agency would create a bounty of early goodwill for the Trump administration. House GOP should not get a pass on ethics, and Trump's promise to end and replace the Affordable Care Act would be greatly assisted by releasing the memos behind Obama's endless "fixes" to that law.

Recent polls show that fewer than 20% of Americans now trust the federal government. Excessive secrecy spurs many Americans to presume that their rulers are up to no good. Regardless of the policies that Trump chooses, it would be a booster shot for democracy to reveal the back story of the Obama era.

Title: Gender Pay Gap Remains Stagnant Despite Progress, Research Shows

Article:

Tuesday marks Equal Pay Day, a day designated annually by the National Committee on Pay Equity to highlight the number of additional days women must work to earn what men did in the previous year. In 1963, when President John F. Kennedy signed the Equal Pay Act, a woman working full-time year-round typically earned 59 cents for every dollar paid to her male counterpart. By 2013, the latest year of available census data, this ratio had improved to 78 cents on the dollar.

However, a closer examination reveals that progress in closing the gender pay gap has slowed over the past decade. The longer the gap persists, the less it can be attributed to factors other than discrimination.

Recent research by the Economic Policy Institute shows that men still outearn women at every rung of the income ladder. The higher up the ladder, the larger the gap. In 2014, women in the 95th percentile of female earners made 79% of wages for men at the 95th percentile, while women in the lowest 10th percentile made 91 cents for each dollar earned by their male counterparts. At the high end, corporate norms are likely the biggest factor influencing pay scales, and while policies differ from company to company, the result is that women are still paid much less than men. At the low end, the minimum wage is a significant factor influencing pay scales, and since that applies to everyone, there is less pay disparity at the bottom of the ladder. Yet, even at that, women in low-wage jobs are paid less than men in low-wage jobs.

The gender pay gap is also pronounced among college-educated workers. The higher the level of education, the larger the gap. Men and women who have attended but did not graduate from college have the narrowest gap, with women making about 80% of what men made (or about $16 an hour on average for women versus $20 for men). Among those who have graduated from college, women's pay is about 78% of men's pay (or about $26 an hour on average for women; $33 for men), and among those with advanced degrees, women make about 74% of what men make (or about $33 an hour on average for women; $44 for men).

Title: EPA's Tier 3 Gasoline Regulations: Costs Outweigh Benefits, Critics Argue

Article:

The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has promulgated 1,920 regulations since President Obama's 2009 inauguration, with many of these regulations imposing high economic and unemployment costs while providing few health or environmental benefits, according to The Heritage Foundation. The latest regulation, known as the Tier 3 rules, aims to further improve air quality by reducing sulfur in gasoline. However, critics argue that the benefits of these regulations are minimal, while the costs are significant.

Since 1970, cars in the United States have reduced 99% of pollutants that once came from tailpipes, according to air pollution expert Joel Schwartz, co-author of "Air Quality in America." Recent models start out cleaner and stay cleaner throughout their lives, reducing on-road emissions by an average of 8-10% per year. This has led to improved air quality, a trend that continues.

From 2004 under Tier 1 and 2 rules, refiners have reduced sulfur in gasoline from an average of 300 parts per million to 30 parts per million, a 90% drop. By 2022, existing emission-reduction requirements will further reduce volatile organic pollutants by 62%, carbon monoxide by 51%, and nitrous oxides by 80%, on top of reductions achieved between 1970 and 2004.

Despite these reductions, the EPA is now proposing to further lower sulfur levels to 10 parts per million. However, the agency's own computer models demonstrate that the Tier 3 rules would yield essentially no air quality or health benefits when earlier and ongoing reductions are factored in. In fact, Tier 3 improvements would reduce monthly ozone levels by barely 0.5 parts per billion on average to 1.2 parts per billion at peak levels, according to estimates by Environ International Corp. Using EPA models, these reductions would be equivalent to saving 5 to 12 cents out of $100 million.

The American Petroleum Institute and other industry experts estimate that the Tier 3 rules would cost $10 billion in upfront capital expenditures and an additional $2.4 billion in annual compliance expenses. They would raise the price of gasoline by 6 to 9 cents per gallon, on top of new state fuel-tax hikes and gasoline prices that have increased from $1.79 to $3.51 per gallon of regular unleaded under President Obama.

These costs ripple throughout the economy, affecting job creation and retention, the price of goods and services, commuting costs, and the price tag on family vacations. They kill jobs and harm poor families most of all.

Moreover, these Tier 3 rules are part of a larger regulatory regime that imposes costs to address risks and achieve benefits that exist only in EPA and environmental-activist computer models, press releases, and fear campaigns. They are an integral part of the administration's war on coal and other fossil fuels.

Another serious problem is that the EPA always assumes there is no safe threshold level for pollutants and that they must constantly be ratcheted downward, eventually to zero. This flies in the face of what any competent epidemiologist knows: The dose makes the poison. There is a point below which a chemical is not harmful. There are even chemicals that at low or trace quantities are essential to proper operation of our muscular, brain, and other bodily functions but at higher doses, can be poisonous. There are also low-level chemical, radiation, and pathogen exposures that actually safeguard our bodies from cancer, illness, and other damage, in a process known as hormesis.

Critics argue that the EPA's actions are forcing us to expend vast financial, human, and technological resources to achieve minimal or even zero quantifiable health benefits. They call for science-based standards and common-sense regulations. Scrapping the unnecessary Tier 3 rules is a good place to start, according to critics. Citizens and lawmakers need to make certain the EPA and the president get the message.

Title: Western Women Joining ISIS: A Closer Look at Female Jihadists

Article:

An estimated 30 Muslim women from the West, primarily British, are believed to have traveled to the Middle East to join ISIS, sparking shock among the wider public. This development, however, is not a new phenomenon, as Muslim women have long been influential in Islamic jihad.

In her book "Wanted Women," Deborah Scroggins details the case of Afia Siddiqui, a neuroscientist from Pakistan who was found guilty in New York City of attempted murder of U.S. personnel investigating her material support to Al Qaeda. Siddiqui, now serving an 86-year sentence in federal prison, is a chilling example of a female Islamist who became a violent jihadist.

Experts at Kings College International Center for Radicalization in Britain have been monitoring the online activities of 21 women among the 500 Britons thought to be in Syria with ISIS. These women's social media activity reveals they often attract other women to ISIS and support ISIS' recognition that in order to perpetuate itself, it must procreate.

Women are drawn to ISIS for various reasons. Some respond to ISIS' leader, Baghdadi, who has called upon them to help build the new Islamic State and assume traditional roles of marriage and childbearing. Others are skilled workers, such as doctors, nurses, and engineers, who are sought after by ISIS. Some women, however, seek combat and are joining to wage war.

In the United States, the recent case of 19-year-old Sharon Conley of Colorado is a chilling example of an American female newly converted to Islam and seeking jihad, imagining she will engage in combat, work as a nurse, and marry a fighter. Even under FBI interrogation, she remained committed to waging jihad.

Female Islamists, even violent jihadists, have long been prominent. In 2010, Afia Siddiqui was found guilty in New York City of attempted murder of U.S. personnel investigating her material support to Al Qaeda. Siddiqui's descent into radicalization and her equally disturbing rise to national adulation in Pakistan, where she remains lionized as a "Daughter of the Nation," was detailed by Deborah Scroggins in her book.

ISIS, recognizing Siddiqui's stature, even offered to give up its captives in return for her release in an attempt to broaden its global outreach. In our correspondence, Scroggins reminded that her scholarship of Siddiqui underlined how "women have always been swept up by the romance of jihad just like men."

At their most extreme, female jihadists become suicide bombers. Developed by the female Tamil Tigers, suicide bombing was imported by Hezbollah and became the hallmark of the Second Intifada against Israel. Radical clerics issued fatwahs legitimizing women as suicide bombers.

Dr. Anat Berko, a counterterrorism expert with the Israeli Defense Force, named them "The Smarter Bomb," based on her 14-year studies of captured female Palestinian jihadists. Berko found their motives were as numerous as their identities. Some, sexually compromised in ways that they thought sullied their honor, believed martyrdom would absolve them of sin. Others were militant operatives, as politically motivated as their male counterparts.

Regardless of what attracts them, women jihadists serve a fleeting purpose for ISIS. They are unaware that they will progressively lose their freedoms as they empower Islamism through their actions. Western women are joining ISIS nonetheless, so Americans must recognize the deadly ideology that attracts them for what it is: lethally totalitarian, misogynistic, anti-Semitic, supremacist, and profoundly anti-democratic. Political Islamism, whether espoused by men or women, is the gravest threat to secular democracy man has known. By unveiling these invisible women for the radical Jihadists they truly are, we can begin to confront Islamist ideology for what it is: a singularly lethal assault upon our sacred ideals.

Title: Two Members of Congressional Hispanic Caucus Removed from Meeting with Immigration and Customs Enforcement

Article:

Two members of the Congressional Hispanic Caucus, Representatives Luis Gutiérrez of Illinois and Norma Torres of California, were removed from a meeting with the acting director of Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), Thomas Homan, on Thursday. The meeting was scheduled to discuss the recent raids on immigrant communities.

On Thursday, Gutiérrez and Torres said Republicans asked them to leave the meeting with Homan. Gutiérrez stated, "In 20-plus years, I have never heard of the Republicans controlling what meetings Democrats can have with officials of the executive branch and never had a staffer ask me to leave a meeting to which I am entitled to attend."

House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi said during a press conference that ICE determined the guest list for the meeting. Initially, the list excluded all members of the Congressional Hispanic Caucus, but the Democrats were able to convince them to invite the caucus chairwoman, Michelle Lujan Grisham.

Caucus members said the decision to exclude them was striking as they had initiated the meeting with Homan to discuss the raids happening in cities across the country. Agents have arrested more than 680 undocumented immigrants in what President Donald Trump touted on Twitter as a "crackdown on illegal criminals."

The meeting was canceled at the last minute, with ICE stating that Homan's decision not to meet with the Hispanic Caucus was because they had invited too many people, and holding a meeting of that size without making it bipartisan would have broken congressional rules.

At a press conference on Tuesday, Representative Grace Napolitano of California called the explanation "bullshit" and said administration officials routinely met with nonpartisan groups of lawmakers. A bipartisan meeting with the acting director was arranged for Thursday, but members of the Hispanic Caucus were not invited.

Gutiérrez and Torres attempted to enter the meeting while other members of the caucus waited outside. Gutiérrez was asked to leave first, followed by Torres. After leaving the meeting, the Democrats waited outside with other members of the caucus and held a prayer vigil for the families affected by the immigrant raids.

AshLee Strong, a spokeswoman for House Speaker Paul Ryan, said his office had organized the briefing and "at the request of DHS, limited to members with jurisdictional interests in immigration enforcement." Strong added, "Members of the CHC expressed interest in attending, and to accommodate the request, we welcomed the chair of the CHC to join on behalf of the other members. We are confident that the CHC chair is capable of representing the views of her caucus, and this arrangement was made very clear to the CHC ahead of time."

Immigrant rights groups brace for more deportation raids, with Pelosi stating, "I've never seen anything like it and hopefully never [will] again." Meanwhile, Senator Kamala Harris of California took to the floor of the Senate to denounce the president's actions on immigration. Harris stated, "I rise because the president's actions have created deep uncertainty and pain for our refugee and immigrant communities."

Across the country on Thursday, immigrants—naturalized citizens, legal residents, and undocumented—refused to go to work in protest against Trump's immigration actions. The boycott, known as a "day without immigrants," was intended to highlight immigrants' contributions to the American workforce.

Raids and mass detentions were tools that President Barack Obama frequently used from 2009 to 2017, and he deported at least 2.4 million people, more than any previous president. However, the first operations of Trump's presidency fanned fears around the country that his promised plan to deport millions of undocumented people had begun. ICE has stated that the raids were "routine" and no different than the arrests, detentions, and deportations carried out under the Obama administration, which targeted undocumented immigrants with criminal backgrounds or repeated immigration violations.

Title: President Trump and London Mayor Engage in Public Spat Ahead of State Visit

Article:

In a series of tweets on Monday, President Donald Trump criticized London Mayor Sadiq Khan as he arrived in England for a three-day state visit. In the tweets, Trump referred to Khan as a "stone cold loser" and accused him of being "nasty" to the U.S. President.

In an op-ed published in the Observer, Khan had previously described Trump as "one of the most egregious examples of a growing global threat." Khan blamed Trump for stoking the rise of the "far right" around the world. Trump is seen as a figurehead of this global far-right movement.

Khan's comments came in response to Trump's criticism of him in a tweet earlier this month, in which Trump called Khan a "very nasty guy" who had done a "terrible job" as mayor of London.

In another diplomatic kerfuffle, Trump on Sunday denied calling Meghan Markle, now a member of the royal family, "nasty." In an audio recording of his comment to The Sun newspaper, Trump did use the word "nasty," but he also was complimentary about Meghan. The reporter asked Trump if he would be sorry not to see Markle, who is on maternity leave. Trump responded that he did not know that Markle had been critical of him during the campaign.

The reporter then asked Trump about having an American become a member of the British royal family. Trump responded, "I think it's nice. I'm sure she'll do excellently." Trump also expressed hope that Meghan would do well as a member of the royal family.

The exchange between Trump and Khan is the latest in a series of public spats between the U.S. President and foreign leaders. The state visit is expected to focus on trade and security issues, as well as the special relationship between the U.S. and the U.K.

Title: Hawaii Legislature to Consider Marriage Equality Act in Special Session

The Hawaii Legislature is set to begin a special session on Monday to consider the Marriage Equality Act, which would legalize same-sex marriage in the state. The governor called for the session to allow lawmakers to deliberate on the bill.

The debate over same-sex marriage in Hawaii dates back to 1990, when gay couples applying for a marriage license in the state sparked the national debate that led to the Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA), a federal law that was struck down by the U.S. Supreme Court earlier this year.

Proponents of the bill, including Hawaii Governor Neil Abercrombie, are advocating for legislation that would make Hawaii the 15th state to legalize gay marriage. They argue that the bill aligns with the state's Aloha spirit of equality and could boost tourism.

Opponents of the bill have organized protests, contending that Hawaiian voters, not the state's lawmakers, should decide the issue. In 1993, the state's supreme court ruled in favor of same-sex unions, but a constitutional amendment adopted five years later transferred jurisdiction from the courts to the Legislature, which then banned same-sex marriages.

Rallies in support of and against the bill have taken place in Honolulu over the weekend, with more rallies scheduled for Monday. The Episcopal Diocese of Hawaii has announced its support for the bill, marking the largest denomination to endorse the issue, which has divided people of faith.

If the measure is approved, it would take effect on November 18. A public hearing on the matter will be part of the special session on Monday, according to the Hawaii Legislature's website.

In addition to the 14 states where same-sex marriage is already legal and the District of Columbia, 35 states have enacted laws restricting marriage to opposite-sex couples, as a recent map by The Washington Post shows.

Title: 2020 Candidate Kamala Harris Suggests Potential Prosecution of President Trump Post-Office

Article:

Senator Kamala Harris (D-Calif.), a 2020 presidential candidate, has stated that if she were to win the White House, her Department of Justice would likely charge President Donald Trump with obstruction of justice. In a recent interview with NPR Politics Podcast, Harris expressed her belief that former Special Counsel Robert Mueller did not recommend prosecuting Trump due to the Justice Department's policy against indicting a sitting president. Once out of office, Trump would be subject to charges, according to Harris.

Harris emphasized the importance of accountability for all individuals, including the president. "I believe that they would have no choice and that they should [pursue charges]," Harris said, referring to the Department of Justice.

This suggestion from Harris follows House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's (D-Calif.) reported comments last week, stating, "I don't want to see him impeached, I want to see him in prison."

Senator Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.) and Representative Tulsi Gabbard (D-Hawaii) have also hinted at the possibility of criminal charges against Trump, while Senator Cory Booker (D-N.J.) has stated that no one is above the law without explicitly advocating for charges against the president.

President Trump has reacted to these comments by calling Pelosi a "nasty, vindictive, horrible person." Representative David Cicilline (D-R.I.) defended Pelosi's remarks, comparing them to then-candidate Trump's "lock her up" chants directed at Hillary Clinton during the 2016 election. A 2018 New York Times report also mentioned that Trump looked into prosecuting Clinton and former FBI Director James Comey.

Title: NRCC Launches Fake News Websites to Disguise Political Messaging

Article:

The National Republican Congressional Committee (NRCC) has reportedly created a series of fake news websites to disseminate Republican messaging, disguised as local news. The websites, such as "Des Moines Update" and "Aurora Update," are tailored to the districts of Democratic candidates and promote partisan messaging under the guise of news articles.

The sites, which have been active since 2014, are designed to appear as authentic local news websites, with sections for popular and most-viewed articles and videos. However, these sections are populated with content culled from NRCC opposition research. The source of the content is not immediately apparent, with the NRCC disclaimer appearing only at the bottom of the page, well below other links and separated by a significant amount of white space.

One example of the content on these sites is an article from the "Tuscon Update" targeting Arizona Democrat Ron Barber. The article, titled "Arizona Democrat Ron Barber faces questions about pay equality," excerpts an article from the Arizona Daily Star reporting on the NRCC's attacks on Barber regarding his office's pay gap between men and women. The article, however, is actually a piece of NRCC-funded content, as it relies on statistics and calculations provided by the NRCC.

This practice, known as talking-point laundering, represents a streamlined approach to disguising GOP messaging as news. In the past, the NRCC would have had to rely on the lax ethics standards of certain cable news outlets to transform their handiwork into "journalism." The NRCC is reported to have created around two dozen of these sites, targeting both Democratic challengers and incumbents across the country.

Title: Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos Criticizes Social Media Companies for Fostering Polarization and Confirmation Bias

Article:

Amazon founder and CEO Jeff Bezos has criticized social media companies for contributing to identity politics and tribalism by creating echo chambers for their users. In a surprise interview at the Wired 25 conference on Monday, Bezos stated that the internet, in its current form, is a confirmation bias machine.

When asked about his perspective on the current state of technology, Bezos responded to Wired editor-at-large Steven Levy's question, "how you’re viewing this difficult moment for technology." A 2017 study published in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences suggested that social media algorithms rely on confirmation biases to surface the most relevant content for users.

Alessandro Bessi, a postdoctoral researcher with the Information Science Institute at the University of Southern California who co-authored the paper, told CNN, "Our analysis showed that two well-shaped, highly segregated, and mostly non-interacting communities exist around scientific and conspiracy-like topics. Users show a tendency to search for, interpret, and recall information that confirms their pre-existing beliefs."

Last week, Facebook announced it had removed 800 pages and accounts that were stirring up political engagement ahead of November's midterm elections by publishing misleading or fake stories that preyed on people's ingrained biases. Google's search has consistently been accused of political bias, but Google's explainer on how Google News chooses items states that most headlines a user sees are selected via Google's algorithms based on past usage history on Google Search, YouTube, the News app itself, and other properties. Conspiracy theory rabbit holes on YouTube show how users can create confirmation bias feedback loops for themselves.

Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey has been criticized for allowing tribalistic abuse to run rampant on the platform, and recently announced a plan to start addressing the problem. Bezos, however, remains optimistic about technology despite its shortcomings. He argued that it's better to disrupt than not innovate at all.

Bezos also acknowledged that biotech, while having dual uses, will save lives and cure diseases, but will also have dual uses. While Bezos was quick to point the finger at social media giants, he also welcomed scrutiny and criticism.

Title: Misleading Crowd Photos: A Look at the Camera Trick Used in News Photography

Article:

As businesses reopen and people venture out to parks and beaches, photographs of seemingly crowded areas may appear in the news or on social media, leading to concerns about social distancing guidelines being ignored. However, these images can be misleading due to a common camera technique used by photographers.

Photographers often use a zoom or telephoto lens when shooting crowds, which compresses the foreground and background of a picture, making everyone appear closer together. An article on crowd photos in Outdoor Photography Guide explains that a 300mm lens "compresses the crowd and makes it look larger yet more compact, creating more vibrant, more amplified photos."

This technique can make a "crowd" appear denser than it actually is, as demonstrated in a comparison of two photographs of the same beach on the same day, taken by the same photographer. In the original shot, people may appear to be standing very close to each other, but an aerial view shows that they are actually quite far apart.

This camera trick can be used deliberately to mislead, but it is also a convenient way to show many people in a crowd without having them appear at different sizes or with a lot of space between them. It's important to note that a photographer who uses this technique is not necessarily trying to deceive; there may be another reason why they photographed the scene the way they did.

For example, one newspaper editor pointed out that the photographer of a much-shared beach reopening shot "shot the photo... with a long lens because she wanted to get as much of the beach as she could to accurately depict the scene."

Landscape architect Jeff Cutler also demonstrated how different camera lens lengths can change the appearance of a crowd by photographing a local beach with several different lenses. This technique can also be used in video, as shown in a tweet that features a boardwalk in Ocean City, Maryland, which appears to be "packed" with people. However, upon closer examination, it becomes clear that the camera lens exaggerates the density of the crowd.

These misleading crowd shots can create unnecessary anxiety and tension, as people may be trying to avoid crowds and these shots may make it appear as though social distancing rules are being ignored. If infections do not rise with reopening, some may use these photos to claim that everything was crowded and that social distancing was not necessary. It's important to remain vigilant and maintain proper social distancing, but it's also important to be aware of the camera tricks that can make a situation appear more dire than it is.

Title: Six Key Points to Watch in the CNBC Republican Presidential Debate

Article:

The Republican presidential debate is set to take a more combative turn as candidates prepare for the CNBC debate on Wednesday. The GOP field has seen a shake-up in recent weeks, with Donald Trump no longer maintaining his invincible front-runner status due to the rise of Ben Carson. Jeb Bush has faced struggles, but promises a more assertive approach. Carly Fiorina has failed to convert strong debate performances into winning poll numbers, and Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker has left the race.

Here are six key points to watch in the CNBC debate:

1. Donald Trump vs. Ben Carson: Trump, who has primarily targeted more seasoned politicians like Bush, Marco Rubio, and Rand Paul, is expected to take on Carson following the latter's rise in the polls. Trump's recent attacks on Carson's religious affiliation have fueled speculation that Carson could be on Trump's vice presidential shortlist. Carson, known for his reserved demeanor, has stated he has no interest in becoming an attack dog.

2. Jeb Bush's comeback: Bush will be two spots removed from Trump for the first time, signaling his recent struggles. The former Florida governor's national poll numbers have remained in the single digits behind political novices like Trump and Carson. Bush's advisers suggest he may show a more fiery and loose side during the debate.

3. Carly Fiorina's momentum: Fiorina, who had a breakout performance in the last debate, is expected to discuss her focus on winning over voters at a steady pace, rather than relying on a series of breakout moments.

4. The debt limit issue: Raising the debt ceiling has become a divisive topic among Republicans. This week, congressional leaders and the White House reached a two-year budget deal that would raise the debt ceiling. Candidates' stances on the debt limit could potentially divide the candidates on the stage.

5. Lower-tier candidates' performances: Mike Huckabee, Chris Christie, John Kasich, and Rand Paul rank at the bottom of the polls and face pressure to boost their rankings and persuade donors to continue funding their campaigns.

6. Audience engagement: With the Iowa caucuses three months away, candidates will need to persuade viewers not to change the channel, as the debate coincides with Game 2 of the World Series. The first two GOP debates were record-setting blockbusters, but it may be challenging to maintain such high viewership numbers as the novelty of the debates wears off.

Title: Former Governor Mark Sanford Seeks Old Congressional Seat in South Carolina

Article:

Former South Carolina Governor Mark Sanford, who was disgraced by an extramarital affair in 2009, is seeking to return to Congress. The vacancy in the state's 1st Congressional District was triggered by the resignation of Republican Rep. Tim Scott, who was appointed to replace outgoing Sen. Jim DeMint in December.

Sanford is one of 16 Republican candidates vying for the open seat. He previously held the position before running for governor. With a bitter divorce from his wife, Jenny, now behind him, Sanford is seeking a second chance from the public.

In an interview with CNN, Sanford expressed, "At some level or another we all hope for redemption." Sanford's colorful past, which includes an infamous affair that led to his public admission of being on the Appalachian Trail while he was actually traveling to Argentina, is not the only distraction in the race.

One of Sanford's GOP rivals, Teddy Turner, is the son of CNN founder Ted Turner. Turner's family ties, deep pockets, and sudden rise in some internal polling have made him a significant target. Opponents are filling mailboxes with attack ads on Turner, with some tying the candidate to one of his father's ex-wives, Jane Fonda.

If the Republican primary winner manages to navigate the race, they will likely face Elizabeth Colbert Busch, the sister of Stephen Colbert, the host of Comedy Central's "Colbert Report." Colbert Busch insists her candidacy is no joke, stating, "This is not a joke. I don't think anybody would think that this was a joke. This is all too important."

Other notable candidates in the race include State Sen. Larry Grooms, who has collected important local endorsements and boasts a staff that includes Hogan Gidley, a former spokesman for Rick Santorum, a former senator and Republican presidential candidate in 2012.

With such a short election schedule and a crowded field of candidates, the race could turn on name recognition, potentially favoring Sanford. John Avlon, a CNN political contributor whose family has lived in South Carolina for decades, noted that Sanford's honesty about his imperfect personal life has made him more relatable to voters.

Despite his transgressions, the former governor maintains he is worthy of the public trust. Sanford asserts he has learned some important life lessons after wandering off-trail. "Oddly enough, I think you learn from the valleys of life rather than the peaks," Sanford said.

Title: Speculation Mounts Over Steve Bannon's Future in Trump Administration

Article:

Rumors are circulating that Steve Bannon, a key advisor to President Donald Trump, may be on his way out of the White House. After two months of policy blunders that have tarnished Trump's image, speculation is rife that Bannon, the former Breitbart chief and campaign strategist, is losing favor with the President.

In a recent interview, Trump was asked about his feelings towards Bannon. The response, a reflection of Trump's familiar pattern, suggested that Bannon played a minor role in his campaign and that Trump's success was largely self-achieved.

"I like Steve, but you have to remember he was not involved in my campaign until very late," Trump said. "I had already beaten all the senators and all the governors, and I didn’t know Steve. I’m my own strategist and it wasn’t like I was going to change strategies because I was facing crooked Hillary."

This statement, reminiscent of Trump's previous declarations about other top campaign aides, has historical significance. According to Bill Palmer, the last two times the Trump team distanced itself from top campaign lieutenants who were implicated in the ongoing investigation of Russian espionage ties to Trump's presidential bid, the move was intended to distance the White House from Paul Manafort and Michael Flynn.

Whether Trump's statement implies that Bannon, too, is about to be implicated in Russian ties is unclear. However, "he was not involved in my campaign until very late" as a response to "do you have confidence in Steve Bannon?" is, at the least, a clear sign that Trump is contemplating distancing himself from Bannon.

Title: Fact-Check: Bernie Sanders' Proposed Tax Rate on Incomes Above $29,000

Article:

Multiple social media posts claim that 2020 presidential candidate Bernie Sanders is proposing a 52% tax rate on incomes above $29,000 a year. Examples of these claims can be found on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, and Reddit.

During the ninth Democratic debate on February 19, 2020, in Las Vegas, Nevada, former South Bend mayor Pete Buttigieg questioned Sanders' alleged plan to raise taxes for incomes above $29,000 to fund his health care plan. However, the debate transcript and video show no instances of anyone saying "52%" in relation to Sanders' proposed tax increase.

In the debate, Buttigieg expressed concerns about the lack of transparency in funding Sanders' health care plan, stating that even after raising taxes on incomes above $29,000, there would still be a multi-trillion-dollar funding gap. Sanders responded by stating that premiums would be eliminated, and individuals would save money due to the elimination of out-of-pocket expenses, co-payments, and deductibles.

The 52% figure in the claim likely originates from a memo released by Sanders' Senate office ahead of the introduction of the Medicare for All Act of 2019. The memo discusses different tax proposals to finance Sanders' healthcare program, including a progressive income tax schedule with a 52% tax rate strictly applied to incomes over $10 million.

However, the only evident proposal in the debate that could raise taxes on incomes above $29,000 is a 4% income-based premium applicable to all households making more than $29,000. This 4% premium is the only tax increase mentioned during the debate that could potentially affect incomes above $29,000.

In conclusion, the claim that Bernie Sanders plans to tax anyone making above $29,000 a year 52% is false. The 52% tax rate is only mentioned in relation to incomes over $10 million in Sanders' financing proposals for Medicare for All.

Title: The GOP Establishment's Record of Choosing Candidates: A Review

Article:

The article discusses the perceived failure of the Republican Party (GOP) establishment in choosing successful candidates. It highlights several high-profile GOP candidates, including Mitt Romney, John McCain, Bob Dole, and both George Bush presidents, and argues that their presidencies were not successful. The article also mentions Ronald Reagan, who is considered the only undeniably successful Republican president of the modern era, but notes that he overcame the opposition of the GOP establishment.

The article further discusses the Senate, stating that today's Republican stars were once primary enemies of the GOP establishment, citing examples such as Ted Cruz, Mike Lee, Rand Paul, and Marco Rubio. The article also mentions the Conservative Victory Project launched by Karl Rove, a former advisor to George W. Bush, which aims to protect entrenched Republicans against future challengers like Marco Rubio.
