The article criticizes the GOP establishment's record of choosing candidates, citing examples such as former Florida Governor Charlie Crist, who abandoned the party after losing the primary to Marco Rubio. The article also compares the GOP establishment's record to that of Sarah Palin, who is credited with influencing the election of several successful Republican candidates, including Ted Cruz, Mike Lee, Rand Paul, and Marco Rubio.

The article also discusses the upcoming 2014 elections, with 13 Republican senators facing re-election. The average tenure of these senators in Washington is over 18 years, and the article argues that they have failed to address the economic and moral deficit of increasing federal spending and national debt. The article mentions Senators Thad Cochran of Mississippi and Pat Roberts of Kansas, who have been in office for 40 and 32 years, respectively.

The article concludes by discussing a new, independent group called The Real Conservatives National Committee, which aims to take on the GOP establishment and elect real conservative leaders. The article cites the success of grass-roots challengers in primary races against the GOP establishment candidates and argues that the party needs more candidates like Ted Cruz, Mike Lee, Rand Paul, and Marco Rubio. The article ends with a call to action, urging readers to take a page out of Sarah Palin's playbook and take on the establishment.

Title: NRA Files Lawsuit Against Florida Over New Gun Law

Article:

The National Rifle Association (NRA) filed a lawsuit against the state of Florida on Friday, hours after Governor Rick Scott signed legislation imposing new restrictions on guns in response to the February 14 mass shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Florida. The lawsuit, filed in the Northern District of Florida, alleges that the new Florida law violates the Second and 14th Amendments of the U.S. Constitution.

The Second Amendment guarantees the right to bear arms, and the 14th Amendment guarantees equal protection under the law. The NRA's lawsuit argues that the bill, which raises the age to buy firearms to 21, infringes on the Second Amendment rights of young adults. The NRA contends that the bill is particularly offensive to women under the age of 21, who are "much less likely to engage in violent crime than older members of the general population who are unaffected by the ban."

The Florida bill includes new gun control measures, such as a three-day waiting period on most firearms, a ban on bump stocks, and a provision that allows police to petition in court for a risk protection order, which would let authorities restrict gun and ammunition possession for those considered a danger to themselves or others. The bill does not include an assault weapons ban.

The NRA's lawsuit names Florida Attorney General Pam Bondi and Rick Swearingen, commissioner of the Florida Department of Law Enforcement, as defendants. Bondi, a Republican, said in a statement that she is proud of the law. "This bill is not perfect, and sadly it will not bring back the 14 lives lost in the horrific school shooting, but the safety of our children is not a political issue — it's simply the right thing to do," she said.

Cameron Kasky, one of the survivors of the Parkland shooting, said in a tweet that the Florida bill was only the first step. The bill also includes a controversial provision to allow certain school employees to carry guns as part of new school security measures. School districts can participate in "school guardianship" programs that train and arm school employees.

Title: U.S. Officials Grapple with Threat Posed by American Fighters in Syria

Article:

U.S. officials are grappling with the issue of American citizens joining the conflict in Syria, with at least 140 individuals reported to have gone to fight in Syria and Iraq so far. The number of U.S. passport holders involved in the fighting has more than doubled since the beginning of the year, according to U.S. intelligence officials.

One such individual is Eric Harroun, a former Army private who spent about six weeks fighting with rebel groups in Syria. Harroun's case highlights the complexity and potential dangers of American citizens joining the conflict in Syria.

Harroun initially joined the Free Syrian Army, a group that the Obama administration is considering supporting with more arms and training. However, he later joined an avowedly anti-American Islamist fighting force called the Al-Aqsa Islamic Brigades. This led to his arrest on terrorism charges upon his return to the U.S.

Harroun's case is not unique. Andrew Tabler, a Syria expert at the Washington Institute for Near East Policy, noted that Harroun's story is an example of an American with concern for the Middle East who gets caught up in a situation beyond their comprehension. Neil MacBride, the U.S. attorney who led the Harroun prosecution, stated that there has yet to be a happy ending from a U.S. citizen going abroad and fighting on the ground in Syria.

The problem in Syria is the chaotic nature of the fighting, making it difficult to distinguish one group from another. In Harroun's case, his lack of Arabic language skills compounded the issue.

U.S. law enforcement's approach now appears to be to assume the worst, with the FBI starting to arrest people before they leave for Syria. This is due to the complex and challenging nature of the Syrian battlefield, where groups overlap and allegiances shift.

Eventually, U.S. officials decided Harroun was not such a threat. After six months in solitary confinement in Alexandria, Va., he was released with time served and charged with illegally providing weapons to a foreign fighting force. However, Harroun's story ends tragically, as he died of an overdose of prescription pills in April. His family attributed his death to an accident.

Title: Donald Trump Faces Three Challengers in 2020 Republican Primary

Article:

Donald Trump, the incumbent U.S. president, has faced criticism from three Republican candidates vying for the party's nomination in the 2020 primary contest. The latest challenger, Mark Sanford, a former South Carolina governor, announced his candidacy during an interview with Fox News on Sunday.

In a series of tweets, President Trump referred to Mr. Sanford, two other hopefuls, and their campaigns as "badly failed candidates." He also brought up Mr. Sanford's extramarital affair with an Argentine woman in 2009, describing her as his "flaming dancer friend."

Mr. Sanford, aged 59, is expected to center his campaign on cutting government debt and spending. In his interview, he expressed concerns about the president's approach to debts and deficits, stating, "The president has called himself the king of debt, has a familiarity and comfort level with debt that I think is ultimately leading us in the wrong direction."

Donald Trump now has three official challengers for the 2020 Republican presidential nomination. This is noteworthy given the president's current popularity within the party. However, none of the candidates appears to pose a serious threat to the president at this time.

In April, former Massachusetts Governor Bill Weld became the first person to challenge Mr. Trump. He was followed by conservative radio host and former lawmaker Joe Walsh at the end of August. The Republican National Convention, at which the nominee will be formally chosen, will take place in late August 2020 after a series of state primary elections and party caucuses.

Some state Republican parties, including in South Carolina, have decided not to hold primaries in 2020, clearing the path for Mr. Trump and saving money. This move is expected to benefit the incumbent president, as no sitting president in the modern era has lost the race to be their party's nominee.

Mr. Sanford criticized Mr. Trump during the 2016 presidential election but ultimately supported him. However, he became one of the president's toughest Republican critics in Congress when Mr. Trump took office. That stance cost him the Republican primary when his seat was up for re-election last year. He was beaten by a pro-Trump challenger who went on to lose the election to her Democratic opponent.

Election day is still more than a year away, but the race to become the Democratic challenger to Mr. Trump is already well underway. Find out who is already running and who might join them.

Title: President Trump Signs Executive Order on Law Enforcement Reform

Article:

President Donald Trump signed an executive order titled "Safe Policing for Safe Communities" on Tuesday, aiming to address racial disparities in policing and the criminal justice system. The order, which follows the death of George Floyd, is intended to uphold clear and high policing standards, promote accountability in law enforcement, and equip police officers for constructive community engagement.

The executive order covers use of force best practices, information sharing to track officers with repeated complaints, and federal incentives for police departments to deploy non-police experts on issues like mental health, homelessness, and addiction.

Trump's order also addresses efforts in Congress to pass legislation on criminal justice reform, which have reportedly faced obstacles. The president did not provide details of the order during a Monday roundtable, stating that it would have "some solutions."

The White House emphasized that the order aims to help law enforcement build trust and effectively serve the community as the first line of defense. Trump has been sparring with local officials and dealing with backlash over his handling of the unrest following Floyd's death, trying to balance his desire to be a "LAW & ORDER!" president with his campaign's efforts to court black voters.

In a separate development, multiple Atlanta officers have resigned this month as morale is reportedly at an all-time low. The White House stated that the order would help law enforcement build trust and effectively serve the community.

Trump has faced criticism over his handling of the protests and riots, particularly regarding an incident in which federal law enforcement cleared protesters from Lafayette Square. Critics have suggested that the clearing of the square was to allow Trump to visit a nearby church, while Trump allies, including Attorney General Bill Barr, have stated that the clearing of the square had been planned well in advance.

Currently, Trump is threatening to step in with federal forces to clear protesters from a six-block area of downtown Seattle, known as the "Capitol Hill Organized Protest" or CHOP, which has been declared "cop-free" by its occupants. Trump has urged local officials to take back control of the occupied part of their city, but neither Governor Jay Inslee nor Seattle Mayor Jenny Durkan has expressed much desire to do so.

Title: Uber Driver Accused in Michigan Shooting Rampage

Article:

The suspect in a shooting rampage that left six people dead and two others injured in Michigan on Saturday night is identified as Jason Dalton, a married father of two who was working as an Uber driver, according to USA Today. Dalton, 45, passed a background check when he was hired by Uber, the company told the paper.

Authorities are investigating a Facebook post that suggests Dalton picked up Uber customers around the time of the shootings. Kalamazoo County Prosecutor Jeff Getting said he was aware of the post but was not prepared to discuss it.

Dalton lived in a ranch-style house just outside Kalamazoo, where the shootings occurred, with his wife of at least 15 years and two children, ages 10 and 15, according to USA Today.

Law enforcement sources told WMMT-TV that Dalton was arrested without incident early Sunday morning in downtown Kalamazoo following a massive manhunt. Four people were killed and a 14-year-old girl was wounded outside a Cracker Barrel restaurant, and a father and son were killed outside a Kia dealership, Kalamazoo County Undersheriff Paul Matyas said. A woman shot outside an apartment complex was in serious condition as of early Sunday, Matyas said. The 14-year-old girl was in critical condition.

Matyas said earlier that authorities did not believe the shootings were targeted at specific people, describing them as "our worst-case scenario."

The shooting spree began about 6 p.m. in the parking lot of an apartment complex in Richland Township on the eastern edge of Kalamazoo County, where a woman was shot and seriously wounded. The suspect was arrested about 12:40 a.m., authorities said. Matyas told WWMT-TV that the man did not resist when approached by law enforcement officers, and that weapons were found in his vehicle.

Michigan State Police Lt. Dale Hinz called the shooting spree "incomprehensible," according to Fox 17 Online. Kalamazoo, with a population of about 75,000, is about 160 miles west of Detroit. It is home to Western Michigan University and the headquarters of popular craft beer maker Bell's Brewery. The city also is known for the anonymously funded Kalamazoo Promise program, which has paid college tuition for students who graduate from Kalamazoo Public Schools for more than a decade.

Title: Saudi Arabia Maintains 2 Million Barrels Per Day Spare Capacity, White House Says

Article:

The leader of Saudi Arabia has affirmed that the Kingdom maintains a two million barrel per day (bpd) spare capacity, which it will use if and when necessary to ensure market balance, according to a statement from the White House. The announcement comes after President Donald Trump asked the Saudi Arabian King to increase oil production during a phone call on Friday.

Trump had earlier tweeted that Saudi Arabia had agreed to produce more oil, potentially up to 2 million bpd, to offset a decline in supply from Iran following the U.S. withdrawal from the Iran nuclear deal in May and the imposition of oil sanctions. However, the White House statement on Saturday rowed back on Trump's tweet, stating that the Saudi leader was ready to raise output if needed but did not specify a specific increase.

Saudi Arabia, along with other Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) and non-OPEC nations, including Russia, had agreed on June 22 to boost production by a combined 700,000 to 1 million bpd. Any 2 million bpd increase would be at least double market expectations.

The White House statement undercut Trump's earlier tweet, which suggested that the extra Saudi oil would help offset a decline in supply from Iran. Trump was not specific on whether the additional 2 million barrels was a per-day figure, but worldwide daily demand is nearing 100 million bpd.

Saudi Arabia has a maximum sustainable capacity of 12 million bpd, but it has never tested that level of production. Saudi Energy Minister Khalid al-Falih met with U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo in Washington on Thursday to discuss energy security.

The Trump administration is pushing countries to cut all imports of Iranian oil from November when the United States re-imposes sanctions against Tehran. U.S. officials are pressing allies in Europe, Asia, and the Middle East to adhere to the sanctions, with the aim of pressuring Iran into negotiating a new agreement.

Iran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei accused Washington of trying to turn Iranians against their government, while Iran's rial currency has lost up to 40% of its value since last month, when Trump pulled out of the nuclear deal. Iran's OPEC governor, Hossein Kazempour Ardebili, accused the United States and Saudi Arabia of trying to push up oil prices and acting against the foundation of OPEC.

Title: Justice Department Faces Challenges in Federal Investigation of George Zimmerman's Case

Article:

The Justice Department is encountering obstacles in its investigation of potential civil rights violations by George Zimmerman in the shooting death of Trayvon Martin, with the main hurdle being the lack of evidence indicating racial bias on Zimmerman's part before the 2012 shooting.

In the aftermath of Zimmerman's acquittal, the department announced its intention to consider a possible federal case. However, previously filed FBI documents reveal that agents have not uncovered any accounts suggesting Zimmerman exhibited racial bias prior to the shooting. Sanford police detective Chris Serino told FBI agents last year that he considered Zimmerman as having "a little hero complex," but not as a racist.

Attorney General Eric Holder, in his first post-verdict comments, confirmed on Monday during a speech in Washington, D.C., that the department continues to investigate while expressing concern for the Martin family and those pressing the DOJ. He stated that the department is "mindful of the pain felt by our nation" over the "tragic, unnecessary shooting death" of Martin.

Holder emphasized the opportunity to address the charged issues involved in the case and urged that "we must not... let this opportunity pass." He even suggested the possibility of bias in this case, stating it's important to address "underlying attitudes, mistaken beliefs and stereotypes that serve as the basis for these too common incidents."

The attorney general, however, stated that the department would act "in a manner that is consistent with the facts and the law." White House Press Secretary Jay Carney indicated that President Obama would keep his distance from the consideration, adding that the merits of the case will be "evaluated by the professionals at the Department of Justice."

Florida defense attorney Brian Tannebaum told FoxNews.com that the "number one challenge" for DOJ is the evidence, or lack thereof. "There's been an acquittal. The evidence has not changed. It's not like the feds are going to go in and find more evidence," he said. Tannebaum understands the Justice Department's response to public sentiment, but "I don't foresee it becoming a federal case."

The question of racial bias is crucial because, if the Justice Department were to pursue a federal case against Zimmerman, federal hate-crimes law is one of the few tools the department would have. The statute bars "willfully" causing injury to someone else "because of the actual or perceived race, color, religion, or national origin of any person."

The department has used federal civil rights law before to pursue defendants who had been acquitted at the state level. However, in what is perhaps the most famous such case—the Rodney King beating—the circumstances were different. First, there was a highly publicized video of the King beating. No such video of the Martin shooting is known to exist.

Second, the two officers ultimately convicted on federal charges in that case were charged with using or permitting unreasonable force under "color of law"—this applies only to law enforcement. The separate federal hate-crimes law applies to both law enforcement and civilians. However, it's unclear how the Justice Department could prove racial bias.

Serino, the Sanford detective, told FBI agents last year that after examining the case, it appeared Zimmerman was suspicious of Martin because of his "attire, the total circumstances of the encounter, and the previous burglary suspects in the community." Serino told the FBI that there had been several burglaries in the area, and that gang members in the community "typically dressed in black and wore hoodies."

"When Zimmerman saw Martin in a hoody, Zimmerman took it upon himself to view Martin as acting suspicious," Serino said, while describing Zimmerman as "overzealous." The FBI document was posted on the Smoking Gun website.

McClatchy also has reported on another set of documents that show FBI agents interviewed dozens of people in the course of probing possible racial bias, but nobody would say Zimmerman showed such bias before the shooting.

The department may find itself in a vulnerable spot, not only because of prior interviews which found no evidence of bias, but also due to allegations of intervention in the case. Last week, a conservative watchdog accused an obscure agency within the DOJ of helping support the "pressure campaign" against Zimmerman in the wake of the shooting last year.

Judicial Watch claimed documents and public accounts showed "extraordinary intervention" by the department in the campaign that eventually led to Zimmerman's prosecution. The department, however, claims that it dispatched agency representatives to reduce tensions in the community—not to take sides.

The department is under heavy pressure from some groups to pursue the case further. Rep. Charles Rangel, D-N.Y., and other House Democrats called a press conference on Monday to urge the Justice Department to "conduct an immediate and thorough investigation." The NAACP started the drive to pressure the DOJ to continue its probe by posting a petition Sunday morning on the website MoveOn.org.

"The most fundamental of civil rights—the right to life—was violated the night George Zimmerman stalked and then took the life of Trayvon Martin," the group wrote. Attorney General Eric Holder plans to speak at the NAACP convention on Tuesday.

Title: U.S. Faces Looming Deadlines as Obama Administration Warns of Early Debt Limit Crisis

Article:

The United States is facing a potential fiscal crisis as the Obama administration has warned House Republicans that a deal on increasing the federal debt limit may need to be reached earlier than expected. In a letter from Treasury Secretary Jack Lew to House Speaker John Boehner, the administration expressed concern over two looming deadlines that have yet to be addressed.

The first deadline is the prevention of a partial government shutdown, which requires Congress and the Obama administration to agree on at least a temporary spending deal. While such a bill is typically reached without significant partisan wrangling, this year's effort is complicated by Republicans insisting any measure should include the steep cuts known as sequester that started in the spring, and by some Democrats demanding their removal. Additionally, a small group of Tea Party-backed Republicans is pushing for the defunding of the president's health care law, whose official signup date is Oct. 1, to be stripped from any budget bill.

The second deadline is the debt-ceiling deadline, which Lew stated in his letter on Monday will follow close behind. According to Lew, the Treasury Department will run out of "extraordinary measures" – tactics to avoid bumping up against the debt ceiling – in the middle of October, risking a default unless Congress raises the cap.

Treasury Secretary Jack Lew told Boehner, R-Ohio, that extending borrowing authority does not increase government spending; it simply allows the Treasury to pay for expenditures Congress has previously approved. Lew emphasized that protecting the credit of the United States is the responsibility of Congress because only Congress can extend the nation's borrowing authority.

Boehner's office responded, stating that the debt ceiling is a reminder that "under President Obama, Washington has failed to deal seriously with America's debt and deficit."

In 2011, Boehner and Obama reached a complex deal, agreeing to roughly $900 billion in immediate spending cuts in exchange for an increase in borrowing authority by a similar amount. This deal set the groundwork for the sequester cuts now in place, as well as more increases in the debt ceiling. However, the high-wire act had a significant economic impact, roiling financial markets worldwide and contributing to Standard & Poor's downgrading the credit rating on U.S. bonds.

The current debt ceiling is $16.7 trillion. Economists had predicted for months that the federal government would no longer be able to pay its bills after Labor Day, but at least some thought the deadline was closer to November.

If the government cannot increase its borrowing authority, Lew stated that the Treasury would have to use the $50 billion in cash it currently holds, with no solid way of predicting when all of that money will be spent.

The White House and a group of Republican senators have reportedly been working on proposed fiscal deals to avoid last-minute negotiations, but these talks have allegedly stalled. Though Boehner indicated last week that he wants to pass a short-term spending bill to avoid a government shutdown, he reportedly vowed on Monday to put up a "whale of a fight" over the debt limit.

"I've made it clear that we're not going to increase the debt limit without cuts and reforms that are greater than the increase in the debt limit," Boehner said at a fundraiser for Idaho Republican Rep. Mike Simpson, according to the Idaho Statesman.

Michigan Rep. Sander Levin, the top Democrat on the House Ways and Means Committee, after Lew's letter, urged the GOP to increase the debt limit.

"With just nine legislative days currently scheduled in September, Republicans must return to Congress prepared to move beyond the kind of brinksmanship that undermined our economic recovery two years ago," Levin said. "It is time for Republicans to do the right thing – not the far right thing."

Title: Florida Hurricane Irma: Governor's Response and Media Coverage

Article:

A massive storm, identified as Hurricane Irma, moved through Florida, displacing an estimated five million people. The storm affected the entire state, including a large population of retired Americans. Florida Governor Rick Scott issued numerous warnings and monitored the activities of the state's National Guard and first responders. He described the storm as a "catastrophic" event and urged citizens to pray for the state.

In the midst of this crisis, the national media, often referred to as the Mainstream Media, faced criticism for its response. The Washington Post published an article titled "Florida Governor Has Refused to Recognize Climate-Change Risks, Critics Say." The article focused on Governor Scott's perceived lack of acknowledgment of climate change risks, with no response from the Governor's office.

The debate about climate change and its role in hurricanes like Irma is ongoing. Some scientists argue that global warming contributes to such events, while others dispute this claim. It is important to note that the connection between hurricanes and global warming is not yet conclusively proven.

Governor Scott, like many others, has expressed concern about the potential human factor in global warming. He advocates for policies that allow for global growth, arguing that this would enable the world to address climate issues through technological development and innovation.

The article concludes by mentioning the persistence of political rhetoric, particularly from the left, which is described as "poisonous." The author expresses doubt about the effectiveness of the proposed solutions to address global warming and questions the consensus among scientists regarding the issue.

The author also touches on the role of anger in politics, noting its prevalence among the left and the lack of a similar phenomenon on the right. The article ends with a reference to the Ku Klux Klan, suggesting a comparison between the intensity of political anger on the left and on the far right. This comparison may be seen as controversial or divisive, and it is important to note that the Ku Klux Klan stands for ideologies that are widely condemned as hateful and discriminatory.

Title: Trump Sets Six-Month Deadline for Congress to Address DACA, Ending Obama-Era Program

Article:

U.S. Attorney General Jeff Sessions announced on Tuesday that President Donald Trump has given Congress a six-month deadline to address America's immigration system, with the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program set to end after that period. The DACA program, established in 2012, grants work permits to undocumented immigrants who came to the U.S. as children.

President Trump's decision to end DACA, which protects approximately 800,000 people from deportation, was based on the argument that it was an unconstitutional exercise of authority by the executive branch. Only Congress has the power to create such programs, Sessions stated.

In a statement, President Trump said, "As President, my highest duty is to defend the American people and the Constitution of the United States of America. At the same time, I do not favor punishing children, most of whom are now adults, for the actions of their parents. But we must also recognize that we are a nation of opportunity because we are a nation of laws."

Before the announcement, Trump had hinted at his decision through a tweet on September 5, 2017, stating, "Congress, get ready to do your job - DACA!"

The administration hopes that six months will be sufficient time for Congress to come up with a legislative fix before the government stops renewing permits for people already covered by the program. President Trump said, "The legislative branch, not the executive branch, writes these laws – this is the bedrock of our Constitutional system, which I took a solemn oath to preserve, protect, and defend."

The DACA program was created to protect young immigrants, often referred to as "dreamers," who did not choose to violate U.S. immigration law as they were brought into the country by their parents or other family members.

Many people have protested ending the program due to its economic impact. According to a survey from the Center for American Progress, 91 percent of DACA recipients are employed. A survey respondent stated, "Because of DACA, I opened a restaurant. We are contributing to the economic growth of our local community. We pay our fair share of taxes and hire employees... It will be hard to maintain my business if DACA ended."

Some members of President Trump's evangelical advisory board have asked him to protect the "dreamers." The Washington Post reports that Atlanta pastor Jentzen Franklin and others pleaded with the president to preserve DACA last week in a meeting in the Oval Office. A White House official stated that delaying the enforcement by six months will give Congress time to act on a broader solution for immigration reform.

Title: Trump Endorses Paul Ryan, Reunites with House Speaker After Public Spat

Article:

U.S. presidential candidate Donald Trump has publicly endorsed House Speaker Paul Ryan, days after a public spat between the two top Republican figures. In a campaign stop in Green Bay, Wisconsin, Mr. Trump expressed his support for Mr. Ryan, stating, "I support and endorse our Speaker... Paul Ryan."

The endorsement comes after Mr. Trump refused to endorse Mr. Ryan and Senator John McCain in their campaigns for re-election in November, shocking party members on Tuesday. Mr. Ryan, the party's highest-ranking elected official, had himself long delayed endorsing Mr. Trump.

During the campaign stop, Mr. Trump emphasized the need for unity, stating, "We need unity - we have to win this election." He added that while they might "disagree on a couple of things," they agreed on a lot as well. Mr. Trump also endorsed Sen. McCain and New Hampshire Sen. Kelly Ayotte.

In an earlier interview with the Washington Post, Mr. Trump had stated he was "just not quite there yet" when asked if he would endorse Mr. Ryan and Sen. McCain. The same phrase was used by Mr. Ryan before he finally endorsed the Republican presidential candidate.

Mr. Ryan and Sen. McCain had both criticized Mr. Trump's attacks on the bereaved parents of a U.S. Muslim soldier killed in Iraq. The soldier, Humayun Khan, was killed by a car bomb in 2004 at the age of 27.

Anthony Zurcher, BBC North America reporter, provides analysis on the Trump campaign, suggesting that the candidate's enthusiastic audiences and campaign coffers full of cash make a comeback story likely. The roller-coaster ride of the Republican establishment's relationship with Mr. Trump has seen periods of reluctant acceptance and sky-is-falling hysteria. However, the general election sprint is only just beginning, and there may still be periods of resigned accommodation ahead. If Mr. Trump can maintain a focused message and avoid controversial statements, the polls could narrow to a more typical partisan split.

Title: Hollywood Stars Call for Unity at the 92nd Academy Awards, but Media Focuses on Political Divide

Article:

The 92nd Academy Awards, held on February 9, 2020, witnessed a call for unity and camaraderie from two key award winners, Renee Zellweger and Joaquin Phoenix. However, their messages of inclusion, civility, and the importance of finding common ground were largely overshadowed by the political divide in media coverage.

Renee Zellweger, who won the award for her lead role in "Judy," emphasized the unifying power of shared heroes. She stated, "When we look to our heroes, we agree, and that matters. Neil Armstrong, Sally Ride, Dolores Huerta, Venus and Serena and Selena, Bob Dylan, Scorsese, Fred Rogers, Harriet Tubman... When we celebrate our heroes, we're reminded of who we are as one people united."

Joaquin Phoenix, who won for his role in "Joker," also emphasized the need for unity in the face of various societal issues. He said, "I've been thinking a lot about some of the distressing issues that we are facing collectively. I think, whether we're talking about gender inequality or racism or queer rights or indigenous rights or animal rights, we're talking about the fight against injustice."

The calls for unity and common ground made by Phoenix and Zellweger during one of the most glamorous events on the U.S. calendar received little media attention. While Phoenix's calls for equality were the subject of a CNN entertainment piece, both their speeches were satirically analyzed in an article from Vulture.

As political polarization continues to threaten the fabric of American democracy, reminders of commonalities are crucial. It is baffling that these calls for civility, made during a highly publicized event, received little media attention.

In a time when the media often seems eager to acknowledge extreme polarization, it is encouraging to see powerful voices championing the value of common ground. This positive message is one that all Americans can get behind.

We invite our readers to share their thoughts on this topic. Be a part of the solution to finding solutions. Tell us here.

Title: Deaf Community Highlights Systemic Barriers and Awareness of Police Interactions

Article:

The recent performance of the national anthem at the Super Bowl by a deaf individual has sparked discussions about the experiences of deaf individuals, particularly in interactions with law enforcement. The performer, whose name is unavailable, highlighted several instances of mistreatment and fatal encounters between deaf individuals and police officers.

Robert Kim, a deaf man, was beaten and tasered by a police officer in a St. Louis suburb in 2012. Daniel Kevin Harris was shot and killed by a North Carolina state trooper in 2016. In 2014, Pearl Pearson was badly beaten by police officers, and Magdiel Sanchez was shot and killed by police in front of his home in Oklahoma City in 2017.

These incidents are part of a pattern, as Amiel Fields-Meyer noted in a 2017 article for The Atlantic. The Americans with Disabilities Act requires the government to provide "effective communication" and "reasonable accommodation," but gaps in cultural competency among law enforcement have led to strained and sometimes deadly interactions with the deaf community.

The performer, in their article, also highlighted other inequalities faced by the deaf community, such as limited access to mental health services, healthcare, sign language, inadequate online accessibility, lack of employment opportunities, and more. These inequalities disproportionately affect people of color.

The performer's appearance at the Super Bowl was intended to raise awareness of systemic barriers and stigmas attached to deafness, and to move people to action. Despite the failure of Fox to make the performance accessible to all, the performer hopes that it did achieve that goal.

The performer's parents took action by learning to sign for their deaf children, making them feel seen and respected. Today, the performer is teaching their hearing child to sign as well. Respecting all languages and identities, the performer believes, can only lead to better laws and a higher quality of life.

The National Association of the Deaf (N.A.D.) has posted video of the performer's entire performances of "America the Beautiful" and the national anthem on YouTube.

Title: Senate Intelligence Committee Members Allege Obama Administration Broke Law in Bergdahl Prisoner Exchange

Article:

The controversy surrounding the Obama administration's decision to release five high-level Taliban members in exchange for Army Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl without Congressional consent persists on Capitol Hill. As more details emerge about the deal, which many view as a bad decision, several lawmakers are questioning the legality of the swap.

One of these lawmakers is Democratic Senator Dianne Feinstein, who chairs the Senate Intelligence Committee. On Tuesday, two top lawmakers on the Senate Intelligence Committee stated that the Obama administration violated the law by not informing Congress before the prisoner exchange that led to Bergdahl's release.

Senator Feinstein and Republican Senator Saxby Chambliss argued that the administration disregarded serious concerns they had about the deal to swap Bergdahl for five Taliban detainees. Chambliss stated he had not had a conversation with the White House about a possible exchange for at least 18 months.

"It comes to us with some surprise and dismay that the transfers went ahead with no consultation, totally not following the law," Feinstein told reporters following a closed-door meeting. "And in an issue with this kind of concern to a committee that bears the oversight responsibility, I think you can see that we're very dismayed about it."

Former federal prosecutor Andy McCarthy, who put the Blind Sheik in prison for his role in the first World Trade Center bombing, echoed these concerns on Fox News' The Kelly File. McCarthy, who has a new book out, has stated that this situation could be grounds for impeachment. Judge Andrew Napolitano agrees, stating that this argument is "very, very valid."

The White House, who expected the Bergdahl decision to be met with "euphoria," now faces a significant issue.

Title: US Government Shutdown Reaches 22nd Day, Longest in U.S. History

Article:

The ongoing partial shutdown of the United States government has surpassed the previous record, marking the longest shutdown in U.S. history at 22 days. The standoff between political parties shows no signs of resolution.

President Donald Trump is withholding approval of a budget unless it includes funding for a border wall with Mexico. Approximately a quarter of the federal government remains shut down until a spending plan is agreed, leaving 800,000 employees unpaid.

On Friday, these workers, including prison guards, airport staff, and FBI agents, missed their first salaries of the year. President Trump has recently dismissed speculation that he is planning to declare a national emergency to bypass Congress and secure the necessary funds for the border wall, a key election promise.

In response to a question about an emergency declaration, Trump stated, "If they can't do it [resolve the problem], I will declare a national emergency. I have the absolute right." However, Democrats have indicated they would mount an immediate legal challenge if Trump were to make such a move.

On Friday, some workers who missed their first payday of the year shared their blank payslips on social media. Oscar Murillo, an aerospace engineer at NASA, posted his $0 check on Twitter and stated he had actually lost money due to mandatory deductions. Another Twitter user, Cat Heifner, shared what she said was her brother's payslip, showing he had been paid one cent for his work as an air traffic controller.

A food bank in Washington, D.C., is arranging five pop-up markets on Saturday for unpaid federal workers. Radha Muthiah, head of Capital Area Food Bank, said dozens of volunteers were working to pack bags of food for affected staff.

Craigslist has been inundated with listings from government employees trying to sell their possessions. Items ranging from beds to old toys have been listed as "government shutdown specials." One advertisement for a child's rocking chair reads, "Sells for $93.88 at Walmart. Asking $10." The seller notes, "We need money to pay bills."

Of the 800,000 federal employees going unpaid, about 350,000 are furloughed, a kind of temporary lay-off, while the rest are continuing to work. Thousands have reportedly applied for unemployment benefits amid the financial uncertainty.

One major airport, Miami International, will close an entire terminal this weekend due to a shortage of security agents caused by the shutdown. The agents are "essential" federal workers and are expected to work, despite not being paid until the shutdown ends. Instead, many agents are calling in sick in protest of the situation, according to the Miami Herald.

The House and Senate overwhelmingly passed a bill on Friday to ensure all government workers receive retroactive pay after the shutdown ends. The president is expected to sign the legislation. However, this may provide little consolation to those federal employees currently facing financial hardship with no end in sight to the impasse.

At a roundtable discussion about border security on Friday with state and local leaders, Mr. Trump again demanded that Democrats approve funding for a wall or steel barrier. However, the Democratic leader of the U.S. House of Representatives, Nancy Pelosi, stated, "When the president acts, we will respond to whatever he does."

According to the Associated Press, senior White House aide Jared Kushner, Mr. Trump's son-in-law, is among those who have cautioned the president against declaring a national emergency. US media report the White House is considering diverting some of the $13.9 billion allocated last year by Congress for disaster relief in areas such as Puerto Rico, Texas, and California to pay for the wall. However, Republican congressman Mark Meadows, who is close to the president, stated that this option was not under serious consideration.

Title: Obama's Address to the United Nations and the Middle East Crisis

Article:

In a recent address to the United Nations General Assembly, President Barack Obama promised "a leadership strong enough to recognize that nations share common interests and people share a common humanity." However, the Middle East has been embroiled in a series of violent incidents, including a shooting in Israel that resulted in the murder of an American and his Israeli wife, and the celebration of the act by Palestinians.

The shooting occurred near Nablus, with Palestinian gunmen killing the couple in their car while their four children, aged 9, 7, 4, and 4 months, watched. The perpetrators fled, leaving the terrified children to deal with the aftermath of the unspeakable cruelty. The Palestinian response was one of celebration, with Palestinian newspapers describing the act as a "heroic" one.

In response to the violence, the White House expressed "deep concern" and "strongly condemned" the violence against Israeli and Palestinian civilians. However, the statement also called for both parties to "refrain from actions and rhetoric that would further escalate tensions," with an implied blame towards Israel. The U.S. government is "monitoring" the situation with a "growing sense of alarm."

Israeli President Benjamin Netanyahu faced a difficult time getting a fair hearing for Israel at the U.N. During his address, he pointed out that Iran, guaranteed by Obama's deal to obtain a nuclear bomb, continues to threaten the Jewish state. The General Assembly audience remained silent during Netanyahu's speech, with no applause or even a rumble of applause.

The same audience had cheered Obama the day before for his deal with the Iranian government. The silence of the American delegates during Netanyahu's speech was particularly notable, with no response to his statements about Iran's continued spread of fear and terror, and its opposition to American and democratic interests.

President Obama's handling of the Middle East has been criticized, with some accusing him of not liking Jews or Israelis. However, the White House dismisses such accusations as canard. The ongoing violence in the region has raised concerns about the effectiveness of Obama's leadership in the Middle East, with some questioning his understanding of the situation.

Title: Veteran Lawyer Emmet Jopling Bondurant II to Argue Redistricting Case Before Supreme Court 55 Years After Initial Voting Rights Case

Article:

Emmet Jopling Bondurant II, a veteran lawyer who was part of a landmark voting rights case in the 1960s, is set to argue before the Supreme Court once again, 55 years later. The case, which concerns partisan redistricting, or gerrymandering, will see Bondurant representing the side that seeks to block the practice.

Bondurant, now 82, was a student at the University of Georgia during the 1950s, but he did not actively participate in the civil rights movement. However, his legal career took a significant turn in the 1960s when he became involved in the Wesberry v. Sanders case, a case that aimed to ensure equal populations in congressional districts.

Historian Doug Smith, author of On Democracy's Doorstep: The Inside Story Of How The Supreme Court Brought "One Person, One Vote" To The United States, noted that urban populations had grown significantly leading up to the 1960s, but politicians were not adjusting the districts. In Michigan, for example, about 800,000 people lived in the largest district, which included Detroit, while just over 117,000 people lived in the smallest district.

Bondurant compared the practice at that time to partisan redistricting today. "They did not want the districts changed," he said. "They did not want new competition. They did not want new voters. They wanted the old voters they already had. And that is one form of gerrymandering."

In the upcoming case before the Supreme Court, Bondurant is set to argue for the side asking the court to block the practice. He spent his nights and weekends working on the Wesberry v. Sanders case for free, a time-consuming effort due to the data involved, as it was before even hand-held calculators.

Bondurant argued before the Supreme Court for the first time on November 18, 1963, at the age of 26. He has since won numerous big corporate cases, but he is perhaps best known for his work in civil rights cases. In the 1990s, he helped secure the exoneration of Gary Nelson, who spent about a decade on death row. In the 1980s, he risked his reputation arguing for an Atlanta woman in a gender bias case.

Bonduratn has also backed small civil rights groups like the Asian American Legal Advocacy Center in Atlanta, founded by Helen Kim Ho. Kim Ho, the center's founder, praised Bondurant's work, stating, "Ultimately the work and the fight was ours, but he stepped in at a critical time, and we're grateful for it."

In 1964, the Supreme Court ruled in favor of Bondurant's side, requiring states with more than one House representative to have districts with the same population. The ruling gave more power to urban and suburban areas, and it forced politicians to get more creative about how they draw districts, according to Smith.

"It's at that point then when the drive toward gerrymandering really starts to kick up to another notch," Smith said.

55 years later, Bondurant is set to argue before the Supreme Court again. This time he's asking the court to block partisan redistricting in North Carolina, where the legislature ensured that Republicans would dominate the congressional delegation despite the state being closely politically divided. Bondurant has no plans to retire or quit trying to improve democracy in the country through the courts.

"I'd rather spend my time doing that than playing golf, in part because I play golf so badly that the opportunity not to play is itself a positive," Bondurant said. "But, this is really important stuff, and it's very fundamental."

Title: Colorado House Passes Limits on Ammunition Magazine Size and Universal Background Checks

Article:

The Colorado House of Representatives passed bills on Monday, limiting the size of ammunition magazines and implementing universal background checks for gun purchases. The debates, which took place over two days, have attracted national attention as lawmakers attempt to address recent mass shootings.

The Democratic-controlled House passed four bills amidst strong opposition from Republicans, who were joined by a few Democrats in some of the close votes. The proposed ammunition restrictions limit magazines to 15 rounds for firearms and eight for shotguns. The bill passed with a vote of 34-31.

Representative Rhonda Fields, a Democratic sponsor of the bill and representative of the district where the shootings at an Aurora theater occurred last summer, stated, "Enough is enough. I'm sick and tired of bloodshed." Fields' son was also fatally shot in 2005.

Republicans argued that the proposals infringe upon Second Amendment rights and will not prevent mass shootings, such as those in Aurora and a Connecticut elementary school. Republican Rep. Jerry Sonnenberg stated, "This bill will never keep evil people from doing evil things."

The House also approved a bill requiring background checks on all gun purchases, including those between private sellers and firearms bought online. Other proposals would ban concealed firearms at colleges and stadiums, and another requires that gun purchasers pay for their own background checks.

The closest vote was on the background check measure, which passed with a vote of 33-32. Democratic Rep. Ed Vigil, who represents rural southern Colorado, voted against the four bills, stating his decision was rooted in the state's rugged history.

The Senate still needs to consider the proposals. Democrats will need to be more unified in their support there because their advantage is only 20-15, meaning Republicans need only three Democrats to join them to defeat the bills.

House lawmakers began debating the bills on Friday. During the debate, Vice President Joe Biden called four Democrats, including two in moderate districts, to solidify support for the measures. Democratic Rep. Dominick Moreno, who represents a district in suburban Denver, was among the four lawmakers. He said Biden "emphasized the importance of Colorado's role in shaping national policy around this issue."

Castle Rock Republican Rep. Carole Murray brought up Biden's calls during Monday's debate, stating she did not appreciate "East-coast politicians" trying to influence Colorado legislators.

Democratic Gov. John Hickenlooper supports the expanded background checks and thinks gun buyers should pay for them. He also said he may support limits on the size of magazines, if lawmakers agree to a number between 15 and 20. He has not decided whether to support banning concealed firearms on campuses and stadiums.

Republicans argue that students should have the right to defend themselves. Republican Rep. Jim Wilson said, "Do not disarm our young adults in general and our young women in particular on our college campuses in the name of a gun-free zone."

The gun debate highlights a fundamental philosophical difference between many Democrats and Republicans. Democratic Rep. Dickey Lee Hullinghorst, the Democrats' leader in the House, stated, "I resent the implication that unless we all arm ourselves, we will not be adequately protected."

Republican Rep. Christ Holbert became emotional while explaining his opposition to the bills. He said he understood Rep. Rhonda Fields' concern, given her district and her son's shooting in 2005, but stated, "I care passionately about the United States Constitution and the constitution of this state, and the oath that we have taken."

Title: Biden Leads Among Voters Dissatisfied with Both Candidates in 2020 Presidential Race

Article:

In the 2020 United States presidential race, presumed Democratic nominee Joseph R. Biden is currently leading incumbent President Donald Trump among voters who view both candidates unfavorably. This trend is particularly noticeable among disgruntled voters in key states such as Pennsylvania, Michigan, and Wisconsin, which Mr. Trump won by narrow margins in 2016.

According to exit polls in 2016, approximately 1 in 5 voters in these states did not have a favorable opinion of their presidential options. Mr. Biden outperformed Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton among these disillusioned voters by significant margins in Wisconsin (37 percentage points), Pennsylvania (25 points), and Michigan (21 points). These voters contributed to Mr. Trump's slim victories in their states, with the president carrying all three by fewer than 80,000 votes combined.

Recent polls indicate that the same dissatisfied voters will be crucial this fall. Surveys from Monmouth University show that the share of respondents who do not have high opinions of either Mr. Trump or Mr. Biden has been hovering around 20% since March. However, the most recent poll showed Mr. Biden besting Mr. Trump among this subset of voters by a 59% to 17% margin.

Patrick Murray, director of the Monmouth University Polling Institute, notes a shift in the composition of the "dislike both" group compared to the 2016 election. In 2016, these voters were evenly split between those leaning Democratic (42%) and those leaning Republican (40%). This year, an overwhelming 51% of "favor neither" voters lean Democratic, while 21% lean Republican.

Another difference between the two election cycles is that the pool of "favor neither" voters has shrunk because more Republicans appear to have picked sides, according to Mr. Murray. "Either they have decided to like Trump or they no longer consider themselves Republican," he said.

A Morning Consult poll of 27,754 registered voters released this month found Mr. Biden holding a 45% to 42% lead over Mr. Trump. Mr. Biden also holds a substantial lead among voters with unfavorable views of both candidates, with a 46% to 14% advantage.

A recent OH Predictive Insights poll in Arizona, a state that Democrats have carried only once since 1972 (Bill Clinton in 1996), found Mr. Biden with a 50% to 43% edge over Mr. Trump among likely voters. The poll also shows Mr. Biden with a massive lead among voters who think their choices are unappealing. "The gap in their support is striking," said Mike Noble of OH Predictive Insights, noting that more than six in ten (63%) of these voters say they would vote for Mr. Biden, while only 6% say they would vote for Mr. Trump.

Title: Democratic Senators Coordinate Disruptions at Kavanaugh's Confirmation Hearing

Article:

The confirmation hearing for Judge Brett Kavanaugh before the Senate Judiciary Committee on Wednesday witnessed a series of disruptions, orchestrated by Democratic senators who aimed to delay the Supreme Court nomination process due to concerns about document access.

During Tuesday's hearing, Kavanaugh delivered his opening statement, vowing to be a "neutral and impartial arbiter" after facing harsh criticisms from Democrats. Many Democrats attempted to object, delay, or adjourn the hearing, citing the lack of access to documents and time to review the files they had received.

Senate Minority Whip Dick Durbin, D-Ill., seemed to acknowledge the coordinated nature of the disruptions when asked by GOP Sen. Thom Tillis about reports that Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer, D-N.Y., led a phone call over the holiday weekend discussing protest plans. Durbin stated that there was a phone conference where "many issues were raised," including concerns about the release of over 100,000 documents related to Judge Kavanaugh and the committee's decision to classify these documents as "committee confidential."

According to Politico, citing unnamed sources, Democrats considered staging a mass walkout during the confirmation hearing. However, the party's top lawmakers decided against such a move, fearing the backlash from a made-for-TV moment would only help the Republican Party and impede any chances to stop the nomination of Kavanaugh.

The consideration of such a drastic move revealed a split between the party's more liberal wing, who wish to stop the confirmation of Kavanaugh by any means necessary, and more senior Democrats, who believe the nomination should be defeated only by following rules and norms.

Younger Democrats, such as California Sen. Kamala Harris, disrupted Tuesday's hearing almost immediately and urged the committee to delay the hearing amid protests by liberal activists, some of whom were arrested. Harris received praise for her defiance of the chamber's norms.

By not staging a walkout, however, Democrats allowed themselves to become part of the process and question Kavanaugh in the upcoming hearings, hoping to mobilize opposition to his candidacy.

The obstructionist tactics, which may boost some lawmakers' reputations among the increasingly liberal base, may still backfire when it comes to the confirmation of Kavanaugh. Democrats ultimately need to convince moderate Republicans to vote against Kavanaugh's confirmation. Alaska Sen. Lisa Murkowski, one of the swing votes that could stop the nomination, dismissed Tuesday's protests as "a lot of drama."

Another notable moment from Tuesday's hearing was when Fred Guttenberg, father of Jaime Guttenberg who was killed in the Parkland shooting, approached Kavanaugh for a handshake, only for the nominee to walk away. The committee's top Democrat, Sen. Dianne Feinstein, invited Guttenberg to sit in the audience, stating that he "knows firsthand how Brett Kavanaugh's extreme views on guns could lead to more massacres." Guttenberg, however, stated that it was his decision to approach Kavanaugh.

Title: Who Lost Egypt? A Look at U.S. Relations and the Arab Spring

Article:

The question of who lost Egypt has been a topic of discussion following the U.S. government's reported decision to reduce aid to Egypt against the wishes of key Arab allies and Israel. The answer can be traced back to June 4, 2009, with President Obama's speech, "A New Beginning," at Cairo University, where he outlined his vision for U.S. relations in the Middle East.

In his speech, Obama expressed his belief in the yearning of people for freedom, the rule of law, and equal justice. Many in the Arab world took his words at face value, but the promises turned out to be hollow.

Jonathan Guyer, a senior editor of the Cairo Review of Global Affairs, wrote this week that contradictory diplomatic and military messages suggest a weakened U.S. in dealing with one of its closest allies in the Middle East. Guyer noted that Washington does not even know what it expects from Cairo.

The term "Arab Spring," used to describe the wave of protests that swept across the Arab world in 2011, is a source of contention for many Egyptians and those familiar with the country. The term, apparently first used by the Christian Science Monitor and Foreign Policy, irked Arab writers like Rami Khouri of the Beirut-based Daily Star. He noted that the protesters themselves preferred the words revolution or "thawra" in Arabic, and awakening, or "sahwa."

The term Arab Spring also rings hollow because it can refer to the failed Prague Spring of 1968, which Russian troops put down brutally, or the Spring of Nations in Europe of 1848, which also arguably resulted in little change.

During Egypt's election campaign, many journalists and the Obama team failed to understand the Muslim Brotherhood, a group many reporters described as "moderate." Mohammed Morsi, the head of a party backed by the Brotherhood, won roughly 25 percent of the votes in the first round of the elections in late May 2012. In a runoff election against a discredited crony of ousted President Hosni Mubarak, Ahmed Shafik, Morsi won 51.7 percent of the vote to 48.3 for Shafik. That's hardly a resounding endorsement.

Within months, Morsi essentially declared himself the supreme ruler of the country and led Egypt through the arrest and torture of opponents, along with the collapse of the economy that left many people without food. Western journalists and the Obama team described the Muslim Brotherhood as the democratically elected government. After 14 million Egyptians protested against the Brotherhood, the military took over, albeit with a heavy hand that I abhor.

The reduction in foreign aid to Egypt is likely to make relations significantly worse rather than bringing about democratic change—if that is the administration's intention. The question of who lost Egypt is complex, but it can be argued that the Obama administration has made numerous errors, while Western journalists have played a significant role in losing one of our most important allies.

Title: U.S. Proposes Collecting Social Media History from Visa Applicants for Enhanced Vetting

Article:

The U.S. State Department has proposed a new policy that would require nearly all visa applicants to disclose their social media identities used in the past five years. The proposal, which affects approximately 14.7 million people annually, would also request five years of telephone numbers, email addresses, and travel history.

The information gathered would be used to identify and vet those seeking both immigrant and non-immigrant visas. Applicants would also be asked if they had ever been deported from a country or if any relatives had been involved in terrorist activity.

The proposal does not apply to citizens from countries that the U.S. grants visa-free travel status, such as the United Kingdom, Canada, France, and Germany. However, citizens from non-exempt countries like India, China, and Mexico could be affected if they visit the U.S. for work or a holiday.

Officials have defended the proposal, stating it would help identify potential extremists. The proposal comes after the shootings in San Bernardino, California, in 2015, where authorities missed signs of radicalization in messages on a messaging platform sent between the attackers.

Under rules brought in last May, officials were told to seek social media handles only if they felt "that such information is required to confirm identity or conduct more rigorous national security vetting." The tougher proposal comes after President Trump's promise to implement "extreme vetting" for foreigners entering the U.S., which he said was to combat terrorism.

The State Department stated, "Maintaining robust screening standards for visa applicants is a dynamic practice that must adapt to emerging threats." They further added, "We already request limited contact information, travel history, family member information, and previous addresses from all visa applicants. Collecting this additional information from visa applicants will strengthen our process for vetting these applicants and confirming their identity."

The proposal is subject to approval by the Office of Management and Budget and will allow the public two months to comment before a decision is made. Civil liberties groups have condemned the policy as an invasion of privacy that could damage free speech.

"People will now have to wonder if what they say online will be misconstrued or misunderstood by a government official," said Hina Shamsi of the American Civil Liberties Union. "We're also concerned about how the Trump administration defines the vague and over-broad term 'terrorist activities' because it is inherently political and can be used to discriminate against immigrants who have done nothing wrong."

The social media platforms covered in the proposal include US-based entities such as Instagram, LinkedIn, Reddit, and YouTube. The New York Times reports that overseas platforms such as China's Sina Weibo and Russia's VK social network would also be included.

Title: Legal Expert Warns of "Dangerous" Impeachment Process Against President Trump

Article:

An expert legal witness, Jonathan Turley, a law professor at George Washington University Law School, testified Wednesday that the current legal case for impeaching President Trump is "woefully inadequate" and "dangerous." The House Judiciary Committee held its first impeachment inquiry hearing.

In his opening statement, Turley expressed concern about the "integrity" of the impeachment process based on the case being built against Trump. He stated, "One can oppose President Trump’s policies or actions but still conclude that the current legal case for impeachment is not just woefully inadequate, but in some respects, dangerous, as the basis for the impeachment of an American president."

The impeachment inquiry, which began in September, centers on Trump's July 25 phone call with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky. During the call, Trump pressed Zelensky for investigations that could help him politically, including those relating to former Vice President Joe Biden and his son, Hunter.

Turley argued that while Trump's comments about the Hunter Biden deal with Burisma are worthy of criticism, they do not constitute a case of bribery. He stated, "The issue is not whether these comments are correct, but whether they are corrupt." Turley added that if Trump "honestly believed that there was a corrupt arrangement with Hunter Biden that was not fully investigated by the Obama administration, the request for an investigation is not corrupt, notwithstanding its inappropriateness."

Turley, a Republican witness, testified alongside three other legal scholars, all of whom are witnesses for the Democrats. The hearing is set to establish the stage for the next phase of the House impeachment inquiry into the president. House Judiciary Committee Chairman Jerrold Nadler, D-N.Y., announced the hearing, which will weigh whether the president’s actions reach a level of "high crimes and misdemeanors" and warrant articles of impeachment.

The president and counsel declined the invitation to participate in the hearing, as stated in a letter from White House counsel Pat Cipollone. The hearing is expected to follow a similar format to the House Intelligence Committee’s public hearings last month, with Democrats and Republicans given equal time to present their arguments.

Trump's July 25 phone call with Zelensky prompted a whistleblower complaint to the intelligence community inspector general and, in turn, the impeachment inquiry in the House. Trump has challenged the accuracy of that complaint, though the transcript released by the White House did support the core allegations that he pressed for politically related investigations.

This week, House Intelligence Committee Chairman Adam Schiff, D-Calif., transmitted a report with the majority's findings from their inquiry, which concluded that Trump withheld nearly $391 million in military aid from Ukraine, conditioning its delivery as well as a White House visit for Zelensky on a public announcement that he was conducting investigations into former Vice President Joe Biden and his son, Hunter Biden's, business dealings in Ukraine, as well as issues related to the 2016 election. The Democrats' report also accuses Trump of committing obstruction by instructing witnesses not to comply with congressional subpoenas.

Meanwhile, Republicans on the Intelligence Committee drafted a report of their own, which rejected Democrats' claims, stating there is no evidence for impeachment.

Title: U.S. and U.K. Pledge to Pursue "Phenomenal" Post-Brexit Trade Deal

Article:

President Donald Trump has expressed his commitment to a significant post-Brexit trade deal between the United States and the United Kingdom during his state visit to London. At a joint news conference with U.K. Prime Minister Theresa May, Trump stated, "As the UK makes preparations to exit the European Union, the United States is committed to a phenomenal trade deal between the US and the UK."

Trump suggested that the potential trade between the two countries could be two to three times the current amount. May, who is stepping down as head of her Conservative Party this week, has faced criticism for her handling of Brexit. The new prime minister will be responsible for achieving Brexit and any bilateral trade deal with the U.S.

Trump praised both Boris Johnson, a leading Brexit supporter, and Jeremy Hunt, the foreign minister, during the news conference. He expressed his support for Johnson, stating, "I know Boris, I like him, I've liked him for a long time. I think he would do a very good job." Trump also expressed his appreciation for Hunt, saying, "I know Jeremy, I think he'd do a very good job."

The issue of Huawei's involvement in 5G networks was discussed, with Trump stating that he would work out any differences with the U.K. regarding security cooperation. The Trump administration has advised allies to avoid using Huawei's 5G technology due to concerns about potential Chinese espionage. Huawei denies these allegations.

Trump's state visit, initially promised in January 2017, is intended to celebrate the "special relationship" between the U.S. and the U.K., boost trade links, and reaffirm security cooperation. The visit has been criticized for potentially embarrassing May, but Trump steered clear of such rhetoric during the visit.

May praised the "precious and profound" alliance between the two nations but acknowledged that friends could also disagree, as demonstrated by their differing stances on the Iran nuclear deal and the Paris climate agreement. The U.K. continues to support the international agreement aimed at curbing Iran's nuclear ambitions, while the U.S. has withdrawn from the deal. May also emphasized the importance of cooperation and compromise in strong alliances.

Title: Media Outlets Facing Financial Struggles Amid Anti-Trump Strategy

Article:

The financial struggles of several media outlets, including The Weekly Standard and Vice, have been reported, with some outlets looking for buyers or reevaluating their strategies in a bid to become profitable. The Weekly Standard, a 28-year-old neoconservative institution, is reportedly heading towards dissolution, following its founder, Bill Kristol's, three-year focus on attacking President Trump and his supporters.

The same week that The Weekly Standard's troubles broke, Vanity Fair published a report about the struggles faced by left-wing, millennial-targeted digital media outlets with a focus on anti-Trump content, such as Vice, Vox, Mic, Buzzfeed, and Mashable. These outlets are either looking for buyers or significantly reevaluating their strategies. Mic laid off most of its workers, while Vice and Vox are reportedly firing staff.

Cable TV network CNN has also been criticized for devoting its resources to a relentless, partisan crusade against President Trump. CNN's ratings have suffered, with the network falling behind both the Hallmark Channel and Home and Garden Television in October.

The financial struggles of these media outlets, which have focused on attacking President Trump, have been dubbed as a "resistance" media strategy. The strategy, however, has been criticized for being corrosive to the country and a losing business model.

Kristol, a neoconservative hero during the George W. Bush administration, was the editor-at-large of The Weekly Standard, which was one of the most important conservative outlets. However, during the 2016 campaign, Kristol became determined to oppose President Trump, promising a major, serious third-party candidate to defeat both Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton. Despite most of the Republican Party coming together to elect Trump, Kristol continued his anti-Trump crusade, even going as far as to primary pro-Trump Florida Congressman Matt Gaetz with a Never Trump challenger.

Kristol's relentless anti-Trump campaign has been criticized as ego, obsession, and farce, as President Trump delivered victory after victory on issues Kristol long claimed to care about. Despite Kristol's continued threats against President Trump, it appears that the bulk of The Weekly Standard's funding will be reassigned to its sister publication, The Washington Examiner.

Jeff Ballabon, CEO of B2 Strategic, a political advisor, media consultant, and former CBS executive, has commented on the financial struggles of these media outlets, stating that building resistance credentials by demonizing President Trump is not only lousy for journalism, but also terrible for business.

Title: Tulsi Gabbard Advocates for Iran Nuclear Deal, Criticizes U.S. Foreign Policy at Democratic Debate

Article:

In the first Democratic debate of the 2020 presidential campaign, Representative Tulsi Gabbard (D-HI) distinguished herself by advocating for the United States to rejoin the 2015 Iran nuclear deal and criticizing the country's foreign policy.

When asked about rejoining the Iran nuclear deal, Gabbard, a veteran of the Iraq War, responded with an unequivocal "yes." She warned about the potential consequences of war, stating, "War with Iran would be worse than war with Iraq." Gabbard criticized President Donald Trump and his advisors, including Mike Pompeo, John Bolton, and others, for creating a situation that could lead to a war with Iran.

Gabbard's position contrasted with the other candidates on stage. Senator Cory Booker (D-NJ) stated that he would not automatically re-enter the Iran deal, suggesting a better deal could be negotiated. Senator Amy Klobuchar (D-MN) expressed a desire to reenter the deal but also advocated for stricter terms. Klobuchar also emphasized that any war with Iran would require congressional authorization.

Throughout the night, Gabbard kept the focus on the U.S.'s aggressive foreign policy. When asked about the gender pay gap, Gabbard declined to answer the moderators' question, instead choosing to denounce the country's interventionist foreign policy.

Later in the debate, when Representative Tim Ryan (D-OH) referenced the recent deaths of two U.S. soldiers in Afghanistan as a reason to continue the war in the country, Gabbard responded, "Will you tell the parents of those two soldiers that we have to be engaged? That is unacceptable. We have lost so many lives, we have spent so much money."

Gabbard's single-minded focus on war and peace has been a central theme of her longshot campaign from the beginning. When announcing her intention to run to CNN's Van Jones, Gabbard stated, "There is one main issue that is central to the rest, and that is the issue of war and peace."

This focus on foreign policy is unlikely to win her many votes, given the predominance of domestic policy in the debate and the Democratic primary as a whole. However, Gabbard's willingness to prioritize foreign policy over a softball, red meat question about raising wages for women was a refreshing moment amidst the otherwise dreary, shockingly left-wing rhetoric from the rest of the Democratic field on stage tonight.

Title: Lame-Duck Speaker John Boehner Clears the Way for Budget Agreement Ahead of House Speaker Election

Article:

Just days before the election of a new speaker of the House, outgoing Speaker John Boehner, a Republican from Ohio, has fulfilled his promise to "clear the barn" for his successor. In a swift move, two contentious issues were resolved: raising the debt ceiling by next Tuesday and reaching a budget agreement.

Shortly before midnight, a 144-page budget resolution was submitted to the House Rules Committee. The tentative agreement increases federal spending by $80 billion over the next two years, with half of the increase allocated to defense programs and the other half to domestic programs. The agreement also includes cuts to Medicare and Social Security disability benefits to help offset the spending increase. Additionally, the deal lifts the debt ceiling until March 2017.

Rep. Steve Womack, R-Ark., expressed support for the deal, stating, "This is one of those moments when it's important that leadership step in and take the ball and run with it."

However, as details of the agreement leaked, many hard-line conservatives objected to being excluded from the negotiations. The deal was reportedly reached in talks that involved only five parties: the top two Republicans in Congress, the top two Democrats, and the White House.

Rep. Justin Amash, R-Mich., criticized the process, saying, "This is what we've been going through for five years, where the leadership team negotiate a deal without speaking to any members of the [Republican] conference—apparently not even the committee chairmen who are in key positions—and then expect all of us to vote for it."

While Boehner hopes "clearing the barn" will make his successor's job easier, some members of the Republican caucus argue that his presumptive heir—Rep. Paul Ryan of Wisconsin—will inherit a deal many Republicans are already criticizing. They contend that Ryan should have been involved in the negotiations.

However, Rep. Bill Flores, R-Texas, believes it is beneficial that Ryan's fingerprints are not on this budget deal. "I think this somewhat insulates Paul [Ryan]," said Flores. "But I still believe if there's somebody that does not like this and they're passionate about it, that they'll take out their feelings on Paul."

The House could vote on this budget agreement as early as Wednesday, the same day Republicans are expected to officially nominate Ryan as the next speaker.

Title: Candidates Obama and Romney Campaign in Iowa and Nevada Ahead of November 6 Election

Article:

With 13 days remaining until the November 6 election, both President Barack Obama and his Republican challenger, Mitt Romney, included trips to Iowa and Nevada on their schedules. Each candidate aimed to energize their supporters and cast doubts about the other in a race that appears to be tied.

At rallies in Davenport, Iowa, and Denver, Colorado, President Obama employed attack lines he has used in recent days against the former Massachusetts governor. He referred to one of his latest jibes against Romney as "Romnesia," suggesting that his opponent forgets his past positions due to this condition.

Obama stated, "I want to go over the symptoms with you, Davenport, because I don't want you to catch it. I do not—I—I do not want it to spread. If you say you won't give a big tax cut to the wealthy but you're caught on video promising your tax cut would include the top 1 percent, then you might have 'Romnesia.' If you talk about how much you love teachers during a debate, but just a few weeks ago you said we should not hire anymore teachers because they won't grow the economy, you probably have 'Romnesia.'"

Obama also attempted to counter Romney's charge that he lacks a second-term agenda by pointing voters to a plan his campaign made public this week.

In Reno, Nevada, a state that was hit hard by the housing market collapse, Romney stayed with his main economic argument as to why he should be elected president instead of Obama.

Romney said, "I—I was just a few days ago speaking with a—a man. As I recall, he was in his 50s. And he said that the job he used to have was at $25 an hour plus benefits. But the job he has now is $9 an hour without benefits. And he said, you know, I'm showing up on the employment rolls, but my life has changed dramatically."
