Obama has consistently led Romney in state polls in Nevada, though his lead has generally been within the margin of error. Similarly, several Iowa polls have given the president a slight lead or show the race as tied.

On Obama's schedule for Wednesday was a trip to Burbank, California, for a taping of the Tonight show with Jay Leno and a stop in Nevada where Romney had been earlier in the day.

The president's midweek travels were part of a 48-hour campaign blitz meant to energize his voters. Besides Iowa and Colorado, the president was scheduled to hit Florida, Ohio, and Virginia with a stopover in Chicago where he hoped to set an example for others by voting early.

For his part, Romney had Iowa on his Wednesday schedule as well, while his running mate, Rep. Paul Ryan of Wisconsin, was in Cleveland delivering a speech on upward mobility.

Meanwhile, Obama campaign officials on Wednesday tried to undo a minor but gratuitous mess they created by changing their minds and releasing a transcript of Obama's interview with Des Moines Register executives, part of the president's effort to seek the endorsement of that newspaper's editorial board. The president gave the interview on the condition that it would be off-the-record. A similar interview with Romney was done on-the-record.

The Romney campaign had a bigger mess to deal with: continued fallout from a comment by Richard Mourdock, a Republican candidate in Indiana running for U.S. Senate. Mourdock, who is backed by the Tea Party, caused a ruckus by saying during a debate Tuesday that pregnancies caused by rapes are "intended" by God.

Romney's campaign distanced itself from Mourdock's statement, but there were calls for the Republican nominee to take further action because he appears in an ad endorsing Mourdock.

Then there was Donald Trump. The reality show star, real-estate developer, and celebrity birther on Wednesday offered $5 million to the charity of Obama's choice if the president makes public his college transcript and U.S. passport.

White House and Obama campaign spokespeople indicated they would not be taking up Trump on his offer.

Title: Al Smith Dinner: Trump and Clinton's Friendly Roast Turns into a Contentious Exchange

Article:

The Alfred E. Smith Memorial Foundation Dinner, traditionally a time for presidential candidates to offer light-hearted jokes about themselves and their opponent, turned into a contentious exchange between Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton and Republican nominee Donald Trump on Thursday.

Trump, who spoke first, seemed to struggle with maintaining a comedic tone throughout his speech. He joked about the politicians who had previously supported him before his presidential campaign, stating, "Suddenly, [they] decided when I ran for president as a Republican that I've always been a no-good, rotten, disgusting scoundrel. And they totally forgot about me."

One of Trump's jokes that resonated was his comment about Clinton's ongoing email server saga. "And even tonight, with all of the heated back and forth between my opponent and me at the debate last night, we have proven that we can actually be civil with each other. In fact, just before taking the dais, Hillary accidentally bumped into me, and she very civilly said, 'Pardon me.'"

Trump also joked about his comment from the final debate in Las Vegas where he called Clinton a "nasty woman." "But this stuff is all relative," he said. "After listening to Hillary rattle on and on and on, I do not think so badly of Rosie O'Donnell anymore."

However, Trump's speech took a more serious tone when he called Clinton corrupt several times, and not in a joking manner. "Hillary believes that it's vital to deceive the people by having one public policy and a totally different policy in private." This remark drew boos from the crowd.

Clinton, known for her ability to laugh off jabs, smiled throughout Trump's speech but let her opponent have it when it was her turn. She ribbed Trump over his recent allegations that the election might be rigged, and that he may not accept the results of the vote. "It's amazing I'm up here after Donald," Clinton said. "I didn't think he'd be OK with a peaceful transition of power."

Clinton mocked Trump for talking over her during the debates, and she mocked Trump's running mate, Indiana Gov. Mike Pence, for defending Trump to no end. She mocked Trump on the way he talks about women's looks, saying he'd rank the Statue of Liberty "a four, maybe a five if she loses the torch and tablet and changes her hair."

The Clinton line that drew the most laughs might have been her take on Trump's debate performance and the drama he provided before it even started. "Sharing a stage with Donald Trump is like, well, nothing really comes to mind," Clinton said. "Donald wanted me drug tested before last night's debate... I am so flattered that Donald thought I used some sort of performance enhancer. Now, actually, I did. It's called preparation."

After pausing for laughter, Clinton added, "And looking back, I've had to listen to Donald for three full debates, and he says I do not have any stamina!"

One needed much stamina to endure the night's sometimes cringe-worthy moments. Though Trump provided almost all of them, Clinton's more traditional speech could not lift the awkward mood of the event. If the Al Smith Dinner in previous years has served as a respite from bitter campaign seasons, this year it may have failed to do so.

There was at least one bright spot, though. Clinton and Trump did shake hands before the event was done, an announcement that was made from the stage, to applause.

Title: Sen. Susan Collins and Sen. Lisa Murkowski Criticize Mitch McConnell's Coordination with White House on Impeachment Trial

Article:

Sen. Susan Collins of Maine and Sen. Lisa Murkowski of Alaska have criticized Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell for his statement that he is in "total coordination" with the White House regarding the ongoing impeachment trial.

In an interview with Maine Public Radio, Sen. Collins expressed her disapproval of senators on both sides of the aisle who have allegedly prejudged the evidence before hearing the presented evidence. She specifically named McConnell and Sen. Elizabeth Warren for their comments.

"It is inappropriate, in my judgment, for senators on either side of the aisle to prejudge the evidence before they have heard what is presented to us, because each of us will take an oath, an oath that I take very seriously, to render impartial justice," Collins said. "And I have heard Democrats like Elizabeth Warren saying that the President should be impeached, found guilty, and removed from office. I've heard the Senate majority leader saying that he's taking his cues from the White House. There are senators on both sides of the aisle, who, to me, are not giving the appearance of and the reality of judging that's in an impartial way."

Earlier this month, Sen. Murkowski expressed her disapproval of McConnell's comments on coordinating strategy with the White House. "When I heard that, I was disturbed," Murkowski told KTUU last week. "We have to take that step back from being hand in glove with the defense, and so I heard what leader McConnell had said, I happened to think that that has further confused the process."

Collins also stated that she is "open" to calling witnesses in the trial, although she said it would be "premature to decide who should be called" until the evidence is presented. Democrats have stepped up their call for witnesses after a New York Times report detailing how Trump's order to put a hold on Ukraine aid was handled within the White House.

Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer said at a news conference on Monday, "Simply put: In our fight to have key documents and witnesses in a Senate impeachment trial, these new revelations are a game-changer." McConnell has stated that the trial should not include witnesses.

Title: Protesters Call for Regulation of Self-Defense Rights; Opponents Vow to Exercise Rights Despite Potential Laws

Article:

Students, teachers, and other Americans are participating in protests across the country, advocating for greater regulation of self-defense rights. The protesters are exercising their free speech rights during the demonstrations, as they should, though some students may be unwillingly participating due to school officials endorsing specific positions.

The protesters' demands for self-defense regulations are based on the belief that individual rights should be subject to popular opinion or debate. However, many libertarians and classical liberals argue that individuals are sovereign beings free to act as they please, so long as they do not cause harm to others. This perspective is rooted in the harm principle, a concept popularized by philosopher John Stuart Mill, who stated that the only purpose for which power can be rightfully exercised over any member of a civilized community, against their will, is to prevent harm to others.

Those who value self-defense rights and individual liberty argue that the potential for causing harm is inherent in the exercise of liberty and is not enough to justify government action. They believe that their rights are not open to discussion, even when they are exercising their rights to call for limiting others.

If the protesters' demands result in legislative action imposing restrictions on gun ownership and self-defense, those who value these rights will not necessarily change their conduct. They argue that laws are not like the law of gravity, and people can choose to abide by them or actively oppose them and sabotage their enforcement.

The willingness of individuals to disobey such laws has a clear history. Residents of Connecticut and New York, for example, have defied requirements to register their so-called "assault weapons." Gun owners in Colorado have ignored mandates that they pass all their person-to-person sales through the background check system. Even in countries with stricter gun laws, such as France and Germany, people own millions of illegal firearms that supporters of restrictions wish they did not have.

Exercising liberty in defiance of restrictive laws is seen as a positive action, as it places limits on the power of the state. The military recognizes this, instructing officers not to give orders that will not be obeyed. People's unwillingness to submit is what made Prohibition fail, and it hobbled the similar ban on marijuana. Even taxes are dependent on people's willingness to pay, as there is always the option to work and do business off the books.

While every tax dodger, dope-smoker, and moonshine-sipper may not explicitly reference John Stuart Mill's harm principle when they scoff at government actions they find intrusive and oppressive, the constituents of political systems seem to instinctively place limits on what they are willing to tolerate from the powers-that-be. This is evident in surveys reporting that, even among people who are supposedly thrilled to be taxed to the hilt, "80 percent of all Danes interviewed for the 2010 study either had or would have engaged in the black market economy." The World Health Organization found that "the United States leads the world in rates of experimenting with marijuana and cocaine despite strict drug laws." This data is a significant factor in the loosening of marijuana laws, as the country gives up on restrictions that many Americans defy.

The protesters' right to voice their opinions is not disputed, as it is one of the rights that is not subject to popular opinion or debate. The author wishes the protesters good weather and a pleasant experience. However, it is important to recognize that, just as the protesters would never try to impose limits on the liberty of others, those who value self-defense rights and individual liberty will never submit to the restrictions that the protesters demand.

Title: China Prepares to Welcome Trump with State Visit-Plus Experience

Article:

China is preparing to welcome U.S. President Donald Trump with a state visit-plus experience, according to Chinese Ambassador to the United States, Cui Tiankai. The visit, starting on Wednesday, will mark Trump's first state visit to China since taking office.

The "plus" aspect of the visit remains unclear, but it is expected that Trump will visit the Forbidden City and participate in an inspection of Chinese troops. The protocol is intended to provide Trump with a grandiose experience, according to Teng Jianqun, head of American Studies at Foreign Ministry think-tank China Institute for International Studies.

Chinese Vice Foreign Minister Zheng Zeguang stated that China would create a good atmosphere for the two presidents, allowing ample time for discussions on important issues. In April, during their last meeting at Trump's Mar-a-Lago estate, the two leaders found common ground, with Trump praising the "good chemistry" of the summit and Xi's political thoughts being enshrined in the Communist Party's constitution.

Trade remains an irritant in U.S.-China relations, with Trump citing it as a one-way street and expressing hopes for better trade terms. On the commercial front, the visit is expected to result in a slew of deals, potentially placating Trump with contract wins rather than addressing long-standing complaints over discriminatory Chinese policies and market access restrictions.

The WeChat account of the ruling Communist Party's official People's Daily marked China's announcement of Trump's visit with a picture of a beaming Trump and the headline "Trump's coming!". Trump is a popular figure in China, admired for his business acumen, and is not the divisive figure he is in the United States and its allies in Europe and elsewhere.

The contrast between the two leaders was set at the start of the year, with Xi delivering a vigorous defense of globalization at the World Economic Forum in Davos, while Trump formally withdrew the United States from the Trans-Pacific Partnership his first week in office. However, Trump has put aside his grievances about China's trade and currency practices to get China behind his strategy of punishing sanctions on North Korea for its escalating missile and nuclear tests.

Trump's 12-day trip to Asia, the longest by a U.S. president in a quarter-century, will give him a chance to reassure friends and allies in the region, who have expressed uncertainty about his "America First" policies. Secretary of State Rex Tillerson has already signaled the limits of Washington's patience with China, criticizing China for its "predatory economics" and "provocative actions in the South China Sea". At last month's party congress, Xi laid out a vision for a prosperous and assertive China taking a bigger place on the global stage.

Title: Obama's Final State of the Union Address: A Reflection on the Speech and Its Historical Significance

Article:

In his final State of the Union address, President Barack Obama delivered a speech that, according to a long-time observer and former White House staffer, failed to inspire or inform the nation about the real state of the union. The observer noted that the speech was disjointed, irrelevant, and disappointing, and that it resembled a political campaign speech rather than a State of the Union address.

The observer recalled the historical significance of the State of the Union address, describing it as an opportunity for a dramatic speech to the nation and the world. The speech is traditionally a recap of what has been accomplished and an agenda for the future. The observer noted that the excitement of the president going to Capitol Hill to address the nation, standing before the other branches of the government, and delivering the State of the Union was a significant part of the drama.

The observer also highlighted the grand entrance of the president into the House of Representatives, where he is often mobbed by members trying to shake his hand or pat his back. The repeated standing and applauding for key phrases that appeal to partisans in his party and the negative responses from the opposition were also mentioned.

The observer noted that the speech was not a reflection of the real state of the union, as it did not set an agenda for Obama's final year or for his legacy. The observer also criticized Obama for failing to explain how the goals he set could be accomplished and for failing to address the Iranian Navy's capture of two US Navy ships that allegedly drifted into Iranian waters on the very day the president delivered his speech.

The observer also noted that the speech was delivered on the same day that Iran fired unguided missiles at the USS Harry S. Truman, an aircraft carrier in the same waters. The observer expressed concern that the president's dismissal of terrorism as a top problem and his continued focus on closing the Guantanamo prison, despite strong objections from the Congress, the military, and law enforcement officers, was a mistake.

The observer also noted that the speech was not remembered as a historic presidency and that the country is desperately looking for new leadership. The observer concluded by stating that the speech will be historically irrelevant.

Title: House GOP Takes Action to Limit Nationwide Injunctions in Federal Courts

Article:

The Trump administration and its Republican allies on Capitol Hill have taken action to address the growing practice of federal judges issuing nationwide injunctions, which has reportedly stymied President Trump's agenda during his tenure. The Department of Justice issued new guidance to government attorneys, stating they should argue vigorously in court against nationwide injunctions. The House Judiciary Committee also approved legislation to curb nationwide injunctions.

The Injunctive Authority Clarification Act, proposed by panel Chairman Bob Goodlatte (R-VA), aims to instruct judges to write rulings that apply only to the individuals, organizations, or entities that are part of the lawsuit in front of them. The bill would limit the scope of nationwide injunctions, which often halt presidential initiatives, programs, or actions.

The federal judiciary operates as an independent branch of government, but Congress retains significant authority under the Constitution to write rules governing federal courts, including questions of procedure, organization, and jurisdiction. It is unclear how the courts would view legislation like that of Mr. Goodlatte, which limits the kinds of rulings they can issue and the scope of how they decide cases.

Chairman Goodlatte, who approved the bill sent through his committee, stated, "The Constitution gives courts the authority to decide cases for the parties before them, not to act as super-legislators for everyone across the country based on a single case." He further added, "I am pleased that the House Judiciary Committee today approved the Injunctive Authority Clarification Act of 2018 to restore the proper balance of power between the branches of government and I look forward to a vote by the full House of Representatives soon."

The Trump White House's initiative to roll back the constitutionally questionable Obama era Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) executive order is another point of contention within the Republican Party and the courts. The Injunctive Authority Clarification Act is part of the ongoing efforts to address the challenges posed by nationwide injunctions in the federal court system.

Title: U.S. Pursuit of Greenland: Historical Context and Controversy

Article:

The United States' recent interest in purchasing Greenland, as suggested by President Donald Trump, has sparked debate and skepticism, particularly from the political left. While it may seem unconventional, the United States has indeed explored the possibility of acquiring Greenland in the past.

In 1946, under President Harry Truman, U.S. Secretary of State James Byrnes discussed the idea of purchasing Greenland with the Danish foreign minister during a United Nations meeting in New York. The proposal did not result in any concrete actions. Prior to this, in 1867, Secretary of State William Seward, who had recently overseen the U.S.'s purchase of Alaska, reportedly considered buying Greenland from the Danes.

Greenland is believed to be rich in natural resources, including iron ore, lead, zinc, diamonds, gold, rare earth elements, uranium, and oil. A significant portion of these resources remains untapped due to the extensive ice coverage in the country, which is rapidly melting due to global warming.

The potential acquisition of Greenland, if driven by indifference to environmental issues and indigenous rights, could be seen as an example of profit-driven perspectives on climate change. Greenland is home to approximately 56,000 people, and the idea of buying an indigenous people's ancestral lands is problematic and reminiscent of colonialism.

It is important to note that private land ownership does not exist in Greenland. In 2017, a sheep farmer in southern Greenland built a new pasture by following local procedures, demonstrating the communal nature of land use in the region. Additionally, Greenland's healthcare industry is nationalized, with both medical care and prescription drugs being free.

Denmark, which runs a budget surplus, has no reason to sell Greenland. The Greenlandic population is unlikely to want to switch their allegiance. Instead, the U.S. would be better off working closely and constructively with European allies, such as Denmark and Norway, to protect U.S. interests in the Arctic. Such cooperation can be more economically beneficial than territorial expansion.

Trump's defenders argue that the evidence of his intentions is circumstantial, but they acknowledge that circumstantial evidence can be strong evidence. The context and circumstances of the situation are likely to become the focus of any investigation. Whether this evidence is sufficient to lead to impeachment or removal remains to be seen.

Title: Bolton's Allegations Cast Shadow Over Trump Impeachment Trial

Article:

Former National Security Adviser John Bolton's claims that President Donald Trump withheld aid to Ukraine until it helped with investigations into Joe Biden are causing controversy in the ongoing impeachment trial. According to a report by The New York Times on Sunday, in his upcoming book, Bolton alleges that Trump told him he did not want to release military aid to Ukraine until that country helped with investigations that could damage Democrats, including former Vice President Joe Biden.

Bolton's lawyer, Charles J. Cooper, provided a copy of the book to the Trump administration on Dec. 30 to be reviewed for classified information. However, Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell reportedly did not have any advance notice that the National Security Council had a copy of Bolton's manuscript for weeks.

McConnell, who has expressed his coordination with the White House on the impeachment trial, is said to be "angry" at the White House over the revelations about Bolton's manuscript, according to The Times. Mere hours before the impeachment trial was set to resume on Monday, McConnell and Sen. Lindsey Graham, R-S.C., privately pressed the president's advisers to explain Bolton's account, which undermines a White House defense of the president and blindsided several GOP senators, according to people familiar with their thinking.

Trump refuted Bolton's account, tweeting out early Monday morning, "I NEVER told John Bolton that the aid to Ukraine was tied to investigations into Democrats, including the Bidens."

CNN's John King said Monday that McConnell, as the "leader in the middle of something incredibly delicate who does not like to be blindsided," has questions for the White House. Behind closed doors for a luncheon Monday, McConnell told his colleagues to "take a deep breath and let's take one step at a time."

Meanwhile, McConnell's fellow Kentucky Republican senator, Rand Paul, suggested in an interview with the Washington Examiner on Monday that Bolton was trying to use the attention he's getting as a potential witness to make more money off his forthcoming book. The state's junior senator called Bolton a "disgruntled, angry man" who should be taken with a grain of salt.

Trump's alleged participation in a quid pro quo with Ukraine is at the center of the impeachment trial that began this month in the Senate, and whether to call witnesses, including Bolton, to testify has been a contentious issue. As Senate majority leader, McConnell has influence over what happens with the trial, and he has expressed skepticism about the need to have additional witness testimony during the proceedings.

Democrats need at least four members of the 53-member Republican majority to vote with them to call witnesses. One possible defector, Sen. Mitt Romney, R-Utah, told reporters Monday that "it's important to be able to hear from John Bolton for us to be able to make an impartial judgment."

Another potential swing vote, Sen. Susan Collins, R-Maine, said in a statement Monday that "the reports about John Bolton's book strengthen the case for witnesses and have prompted a number of conversations among my colleagues."

The impeachment trial's outcome remains uncertain, and the Senate is expected to continue deliberations this week. The allegations made by Bolton and other witnesses could potentially sway the opinions of undecided senators and impact the final verdict.

Title: House Freedom Caucus and Sen. Rand Paul Oppose Obamacare Replacement Bill, Introduce Alternative Legislation

Article:

Members of the House Freedom Caucus, including Sen. Rand Paul (R-Ky.), have denounced the Obamacare replacement bill supported by House Speaker Paul Ryan (R-Wis.) and announced the filing of Paul's own bill, sponsored in the House by Rep. Jim Jordan (R-Ohio).

During a press conference, Paul stated, "There is one thing that has united Republicans in 2010, when we won the House; in 2014, when we won the Senate; and 2016 when we won the White House." He was flanked by members of the House Freedom Caucus, including the caucus chairman Rep. Mark Meadows (R-N.C.) and Jordan, the previous HFC chairman.

Paul emphasized that a clean repeal of the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (PPACA), similar to the bill that every House and Senate Republican voted for in 2015, should not divide Republicans. Jordan stated that to bring down costs and improve medical care, Congress must repeal Obamacare completely.

Jordan explained that the first step is to vote on the 2015 bill. Paul, a former eye surgeon, stated that in 2017, Republicans are united in supporting complete repeal, but they are divided on how, if at all, to replace the 2010 PPACA.

"Conservatives have a replacement plan. House leadership has a replacement plan," said Paul. "Vote on all the replacement plans and let's see what happens." Jordan described the plan supported by Ryan and the House Republican leadership as Obamacare in a different form.

"Then, there is our plan," he said. "It is the one that I think is consistent with what we told the voters we're going to do: Repeal Obamacare and replace it with a market-centered, patient-centered, and doctor-centered plan that actually brings down the cost of insurance."

In 2015, Republicans put a bill on President Barack Obama's desk that repealed Obamacare, got rid of every single tax, and got rid of the mandate, according to Jordan. Obama vetoed that bill, which was sponsored by then-Rep. Tom Price (R-Ga.)—now the Secretary of Health and Human Services.

Comparing what happened in 2015 with the course that Ryan and the Republican leadership have set out on, Jordan stated, "Now, the first thing that Republicans are bringing forward is a piece of legislation that we are going to put on a Republican president's desk, that doesn't repeal it, but keeps Medicaid expansion—and actually expands it—that keeps some of the tax increases. That is not what we promised the American people we would do."

Meadows stated that repealing Obamacare meant repealing all of Obamacare, all of the fees, taxes, and mandates. He added that all Obamacare replacement bills will be subject to scoring by the Congressional Budget Office. "But there is one score that the American people will pay attention to: Does it really lower their health care costs and their premiums? That's the only score that really matters, and if this doesn't do it, we better find something that does," according to Meadows.

Paul told reporters that in the House, the score that counts is 218 votes. If the GOP leadership has 218 votes, then they will pass their bill and move on, he said. If the GOP leadership does not have 218 votes, then they have to find the votes and they will have to talk to conservatives, the senator said.

Vice President Mike Pence added to the day's drama when he met with members of the House Freedom Caucus after having his regular Tuesday lunch with GOP senators. Virginia Republican Rep. David Brat told reporters that the meeting with Pence was very direct and focused because both Pence and Health and Human Services Secretary Tom Price, who was traveling with Pence, are men of the House.

Brat stated he told Price that he needs to convince people on the Hill that regulations on insurance companies will be adjusted to make sense. Case in point, the congressman said: it is not legal for a 25-year-old male to buy a cheap insurance plan that only covers catastrophic illness and injury. "Right now, that kid has to buy a gold-plated that covers every health scenario under the sun."

The White House put out a statement about the meeting: "The Vice President today met with conservative leaders in the House to discuss the failures of Obamacare and the need to repeal and replace that disastrous law. Participants discussed their shared desire for fiscally responsible, market-based reforms that encourage competition and provide individuals and families with the ability to choose the health insurance option that is best for them. The Vice President stressed this is the first step in the process to deliver on the President's promise to the American people and looks forward to House passage of the American Health Care Act."

The American Health Care Act is the name of the bill supported by House GOP leadership.

Title: New York Times, Quinnipiac, and CBS News Poll Shows Obama Leading in Florida, Ohio, and Pennsylvania

Article:

A recent poll conducted by The New York Times, Quinnipiac, and CBS News has shown that President Barack Obama holds an advantage over Mitt Romney in the key battleground states of Florida and Ohio, with a lead of 6 percentage points in each state. In Pennsylvania, the president is leading by 11 percentage points. The margin of sampling error is plus or minus three percentage points in each state.

The poll is part of a series tracking the presidential contest in six states over the next three months. In addition to Ohio, Florida, and Pennsylvania, which have a combined 67 electoral votes, surveys will be taken in Colorado, Wisconsin, and Virginia, which have 32 electoral votes. Four years ago, Mr. Obama won all six states.

Mr. Romney is campaigning in each state, with his strategists viewing the efforts in Pennsylvania and Wisconsin as the most ambitious. These two states, which have voted for the Democratic presidential candidate over the last two decades, are considered firewalls, and an erosion of support would signal trouble for the president.

The poll found that Mr. Obama faces substantial hurdles, most of them rooted in the electorate's deeply pessimistic outlook on the economy. By double-digit margins, voters in each state say his policies would hurt, rather than help, their personal financial situation if he wins re-election, a worrisome sign considering the economy is ranked as voters' chief concern.

Still, more than half of voters in each state also say the administration's actions are either slowly improving the economy or will, if given more time.

"Romney does have business experience, but I wonder if his business experience would benefit the country or might harm it," said Peg Pagano, 72, a retiree in Holland, Pa., in a follow-up interview. "He was in business in order to make a profit. There's nothing wrong with that, but how would that help the country? I feel Obama needs to be given another four years."

In all three states, most women say they prefer Mr. Obama. About half of female voters in Florida back him, while his support is even stronger in Ohio and Pennsylvania, where nearly 6 in 10 women say they favor him. In Ohio, men prefer Mr. Romney, while they are more closely split in Florida and Pennsylvania.

The economy is the top concern in all three states. However, voters in Ohio express more optimism about their own backyard, with 33 percent saying their economy is improving, compared with 23 percent in Florida. Ohio's unemployment rate, 7.2 percent, is the lowest of the three states and below the national rate.

A sliver of voters, 4 percent in each state, say they are undecided between Mr. Obama and Mr. Romney. Only about one in 10 who have picked a candidate say they could change their minds, fewer than some polls showed at this point in previous races.

Mr. Obama has a clear advantage on personal measures, and far more voters say he cares about the needs and problems of people like them. Mr. Romney is seen as being able to do a comparable job on the economy. More voters in Florida say his economic policies would be better for their own financial situations. Among independent voters in the state, the poll found Mr. Romney outpacing Mr. Obama by 14 percentage points when asked who would perform better on the economy.

"We've seen Romney's track record with the Olympics and with his business, and I think that's what really swayed me," said Chris Rench, 47, who recently left his job as an equipment operator from Piqua, Ohio. "And I haven't seen anything in his past that has been questionable. There is nothing to make me doubt his ability to do the things he says he wants to do."

The president drew broad support from voters in each state for a proposal to raise income taxes on people whose household income is more than $250,000. The plan received the backing of 58 percent of likely voters in Florida, 60 percent in Ohio, and 62 percent in Pennsylvania.

Mr. Romney has endured criticism for declining to release more than two years of his tax returns, and at least half the voters, including about half the independent voters, in each state say presidential candidates should release several years of returns.

The state polls were conducted by telephone, both landlines and cellphones, from July 24 through July 30 among 1,177 likely voters in Florida, 1,193 likely voters in Ohio, and 1,168 likely voters in Pennsylvania. The findings cannot be compared with previous surveys because the polls are a measure of people who are likely to vote, rather than those who are simply registered. While the intensity of the race is high, it remains an open question how much the summer campaigning will influence the outcome. Tens of millions of dollars have been invested on television advertising in the states, but most voters say they are not swayed by the commercials.

Title: Evidence Emerges of Russian Military and Intelligence Involvement in Eastern Ukraine Unrest

Article:

The Ukrainian interim government has presented evidence suggesting that Russian military and intelligence forces are instigating the unrest in the eastern part of the country, which has been destabilized since Russia's annexation of Crimea last month. The New York Times reports that photos and descriptions circulated by the Kiev government show that some of the so-called "green men" - gunmen who have seized government buildings and demanded Crimea-style referendums on becoming part of Russia - have been identified in other photos as being among Russian troops.

One of the men identified is Igor Ivanovich Strelkov, a veteran Russian military and intelligence operative. Strelkov is believed to have served Russia undercover both in Crimea and in the city of Slovyansk, one of the centers of the most recent unrest. Last week, Ukrainian authorities released a wanted poster for Mr. Strelkov, accompanied by a pencil sketch of his gaunt face.

The Obama administration has endorsed the Ukrainians' claims, stating that Russia could face new economic sanctions if government buildings currently occupied by demonstrators are not vacated under the terms of an agreement reached Thursday among Russian, Ukrainian, American, and European diplomats. Vice President Joe Biden is scheduled to arrive in Ukraine Monday morning to meet with Ukraine's interim prime minister and president, as well as other officials.

Russian officials, including President Vladimir Putin, have repeatedly denied that Russian forces are involved in the unrest, which began after the February deposition of pro-Russian Ukrainian President Viktor Yanukovych. The separatists themselves claim that their movement is entirely homegrown and in response to what they consider an illegal coup that resulted in Yanukovych's downfall.

The unit accused of operating in eastern Ukraine is known as the GRU, the Russian acronym for the Main Intelligence Department of the Russian General Staff. This elite Russian military intelligence unit has participated in virtually every military conflict in which Moscow has been embroiled in recent decades, including wars in Afghanistan, Chechnya, and Georgia.

In eastern Ukraine, Ukraine's State Security Service alleges that Russian operatives are coordinating pro-Russian militias, helping them identify targets, and carrying out seizures of key installations, such as police and security headquarters, government offices, and communications infrastructure.

Ukrainian security officials say Russian intelligence has spent years building up a network of sleeper agents in eastern Ukraine. One of them, they say, is Igor Bezler, a 49-year-old Crimean native who they claim served in the GRU until 2002, when he moved to the eastern city of Horlivka. There, he worked as a security guard and as head of a funeral company. Last week, after a pro-Russian mob took over the town's police station, a video posted on a local news organization's website showed him parading in fatigues in front of a couple of dozen local police, identifying himself as a lieutenant colonel in the Russian army and telling them they had a new chief. Ukrainian officials allege he was tasked earlier this month with seizing state-security buildings in the Donetsk region, then taking the police station in Horlivka.

The separatists' endgame is unclear. Some talk of federalization within Ukraine; others want independence; yet others dream of a Crimea scenario, energized by Russian President Vladimir Putin's recent mention of Novorossiya (literally, New Russia), a tsarist-era imperial term for what is now southeastern Ukraine. Moscow's goals have also been unclear in comparison to the Crimea campaign, in which Moscow rapidly annexed the peninsula.

Title: Democratic Presidential Candidates Face Challenges in Highlighting Policy Issues Amidst Impeachment Inquiry

Article:

WASHINGTON - The ongoing impeachment inquiry into President Donald Trump has dominated the political landscape, with the Democratic presidential candidates facing challenges in drawing attention to their key policy issues. The impeachment inquiry, initiated over allegations that Trump sought foreign help to smear a political rival, is expected to overshadow the Democratic primary race.

On Tuesday, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi announced the launch of a formal impeachment effort, accusing Trump of seeking foreign help to damage Democratic presidential front-runner Joe Biden. The impeachment inquiry ensures a partisan fight in Congress and on the presidential campaign trail in the coming months.

Trump had pressured Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy in a July 25 phone call to investigate Biden and his son Hunter, who had worked for a company drilling for gas in Ukraine. The impeachment inquiry is likely to energize both the Democratic base and Trump's base, as demonstrated by the Democratic party's fundraising efforts and Trump's re-election campaign's immediate fundraising success following Pelosi's announcement.

Kurt Meyer, Democratic party chairman for three rural Iowa counties north of Des Moines, stated that he expects the impeachment proceedings to energize the Democratic base. "If a highly motivated person drags her mother and her husband and her second cousin twice removed to the polls, then it makes a difference," Meyer said.

However, the impeachment inquiry could also drown out substantive policy discussions among the 19 Democrats running for the party's nomination. "Trump has been the elephant in the room, but the democratic debates so far have been really policy-centered. I think impeachment now takes center stage," said Erin O' Brien, associate professor of political science at University of Massachusetts, Boston.

Biden, who leads polls in the Democratic race, said on Tuesday he would back impeachment if the Republican president fails to comply with congressional requests for information on Ukraine and other matters. Biden leads Trump by about 5 percentage points in a hypothetical general election match-up, according to the Sept. 23-24 ███/Ipsos opinion poll released on Tuesday.

The impeachment inquiry is likely to benefit Biden's Democratic rivals, including U.S. Senators Elizabeth Warren, Bernie Sanders, and Kamala Harris. However, most have so far refused to be drawn into specific questions about Biden and his family, and are likely to stay that way for now.

Democrats should act swiftly to convince voters their actions are necessary and prevent Trump from successfully arguing he is being unfairly prosecuted, said Joel Payne, a Democratic strategist who advised Hillary Clinton's presidential campaign. The impeachment inquiry's impact on the 2020 election remains to be seen, but it is clear that the political landscape has shifted, and the focus on policy issues may be temporarily eclipsed.

Title: Rep. Justin Amash Resigns from House Freedom Caucus, Leaves Mark on Congressional History

Article:

Representative Justin Amash (R-Mich.), a four-term congressman and self-proclaimed "defender of liberty and the Constitution," resigned from the House Freedom Caucus on Monday evening. The conservative group of Republican lawmakers, which Amash co-founded in 2015, has been a significant force in Congress, known for its role in pushing out former House Speaker John Boehner in October 2015.

Amash's departure from the Freedom Caucus had been anticipated for some time. The caucus formally condemned him on May 20 after he called for the impeachment of President Donald Trump, alleging the president had committed "impeachable conduct" during the investigation led by former special counsel Robert Mueller.

Amash, who was part of the wave of tea party Republican lawmakers elected in 2010, co-founded the House Freedom Caucus with nine other freshman Republicans. The group's membership list is not public, but Rep. Mark Meadows (R-N.C.) currently serves as its chairman.

Throughout his tenure in Congress, Amash has been known for his outspoken libertarian views and his transparency, often explaining almost every vote he took, from substantive votes on tax reform to symbolic votes on the naming of post offices.

Amash made headlines in mid-May when he became the first Republican member of Congress to call for Trump's impeachment. In a series of tweets, Amash argued that Trump had obstructed justice during the Mueller investigation. Trump responded with criticism, but Amash has maintained his stance on impeachment.

Amash is also known for his unbroken voting streak in Congress, taking 4,289 consecutive votes before missing one in March 2017 due to a scheduling mishap. The missed vote led him to cry, an event that is not typical in Congress.

There has been speculation about Amash running for president in 2020, either as a libertarian candidate or to challenge Trump in the Republican primary. Columnist Matt Lewis of The Daily Beast wrote on May 29 that it was time to draft Amash for president. Amash has not ruled out the possibility.

Amash's resignation from the House Freedom Caucus was confirmed by his spokesperson, Poppy Nelson, to ███ on Tuesday morning. In a statement to CNN's Haley Byrd, who first reported the departure, Amash said, "I have the highest regard for them, and they're my close friends. I didn't want to be a further distraction for the group." The exact reasons for Amash's resignation remain unclear.

Title: President Obama Urges Congress to Fund Two Years of Free Community College for All Americans

Article:

In a speech at Lake Area Technical Institute's commencement ceremony in Watertown, South Dakota on Friday, President Barack Obama called on Congress to close tax loopholes for millionaires and billionaires and use the savings to offer all Americans a chance at two years of free community college. The President stated that this initiative is in "everyone's interest" as community colleges will play an increasingly vital role in the 21st-century economy.

President Obama has proposed a plan for two years of free community college for everyone, but the plan remains stalled on Capitol Hill. During his address to the graduating class, he expressed his admiration for the graduates, stating, "I didn't come here to inspire you. I came here because you, the graduates, inspire me." He further emphasized that the graduates had chosen to invest in themselves despite living through some of the toughest economic times in the country's history.

The President has spoken at numerous graduation ceremonies during his time in office, including those at Notre Dame, Northwestern University, West Point, and others. He chose to visit the small South Dakota technical school this year to underscore his belief that every American deserves at least some higher education, whether it comes at a major university or a small community college.

"Our budgets should reflect that we care about you, and that means giving everybody in America the chance you've had here," he said. "I want to lower the cost of community college to zero... We can't afford to let striving Americans be priced out of the education they need to get ahead."

The President's proposal for free community college is part of a broader effort to make higher education more accessible and affordable for all Americans. The specifics of the plan, including how the tax loopholes would be closed and how the savings would be allocated, have not been detailed.

Title: WikiLeaks Clarifies: Edward Snowden Has Not Accepted Asylum in Venezuela

Article:

WikiLeaks, the organization that has been providing logistical support to former National Security Agency contractor Edward Snowden, has issued a statement clarifying that Snowden has not yet formally accepted asylum in Venezuela. The statement comes after a brief and tantalizing tip from Russian lawmaker Alexei Pushkov, who suggested that Snowden had decided to go to Venezuela.

In a tweet, WikiLeaks responded to Pushkov's earlier tweet, which was quickly deleted. Pushkov had referenced a report by the Russian TV news program Vesti 24, but later followed his deletion with a second tweet advising readers to contact the news program for more information.

Later on Tuesday, WikiLeaks issued a cryptic tweet stating that the first phase of Snowden's "Flight of Liberty" campaign would be launched on Wednesday, with further details to follow. WikiLeaks, a website that has compiled an archive of classified files on the inner-workings of some governments, has spoken on behalf of Snowden several times regarding the issue of political asylum.

The confusion apparently stemmed from remarks by Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro, who has already offered asylum to Snowden. Maduro, speaking late Monday at a meeting with Panama's president, described the potential asylum for Snowden as the "world's first collective humanitarian asylum" with various countries saying "Come here!"

Maduro stated that Snowden "will have to decide when he flies here, if he finally wants to travel here." His remarks were distributed Tuesday by his office, according to the Associated Press.

Venezuelan Foreign Minister Elias Jaua said Saturday that his country had not yet been in contact with Snowden, who has been unable to travel further due to the U.S. annulling his passport. For Snowden to leave for South America, he would need for Venezuela to issue him travel documents and find a way to get there. The only direct commercial flight from Moscow stops in Havana, Cuba.

The Moscow-Havana flight goes over Europe and the U.S., which could cause complications. Some European countries refused to allow Bolivian President Evo Morales to fly through their airspace on his way home from Moscow last week due to suspicions that Snowden was on his plane.

The presidents of Bolivia and Nicaragua also said over the weekend that Snowden was welcome in their countries. White House spokesman Jay Carney said Tuesday that Russia has not notified the United States about any Snowden departure, and it appears that Tuesday's flap was due to an errant tweet.

Carney stated that the administration wants Snowden to return to the United States, "where he is wanted on felony charges," and that message has been communicated to Russia and other nations that might be willing to receive Snowden. The Obama administration sent an extradition request to Iceland's foreign ministry last week, according to WikiLeaks, citing an Icelandic news report. Iceland, where WikiLeaks has operated, is among about 30 countries Snowden has applied to for asylum. A WikiLeaks spokesman said the preemptive move highlighted the "unprecedented severity" and "pressure and intimidation" that the United States has placed on "friendly countries" in the Snowden case.

Title: California Imposes Tougher COVID-19 Restrictions on Businesses in Response to Surge in Cases

Article:

California Governor Gavin Newsom has imposed stricter restrictions on businesses in response to a surge in coronavirus cases. On Wednesday, Newsom ordered the closure of indoor non-essential businesses in 19 counties across the state, including Los Angeles County and Orange County.

The new restrictions affect bars, dine-in restaurants, indoor movie theaters, and indoor tasting rooms at wineries. Restaurants may remain open for takeout meals. The restrictions will remain in place for at least three weeks, Newsom said.

"I deeply respect people's liberty, their desire to go back to the way things were, but I can not impress upon you more, our actions have an impact on other people," Newsom said.

Newsom recommended that fireworks shows be cancelled, and said parking lots at state beaches in Southern California and the Bay Area will be closed this weekend to limit crowds. The announcement comes just ahead of the July 4 weekend, when Newsom expressed concern about people in coronavirus hot spots ignoring public health guidelines and making the situation worse.

California reported 110 deaths on Wednesday, the most the state has recorded since April, and nearly 6,000 new cases, Newsom said. Hospitalizations have jumped 51 percent in the past two weeks, and ICU admissions are up 47 percent over the same period.

"Please disabuse yourself that somehow, people are no longer dying," Newsom said. "Please do not take your guard down, please do not believe those that somehow want to manipulate the reality that is demonstrable in those lives lost and those families that have been torn apart because of COVID-19."

Newsom allowed local governments to begin reopening in early May. The most recent reopening phase took effect in mid-June and allowed retail stores, bars, dine-in restaurants, gyms, and hair and nail salons to reopen with certain occupancy restrictions.

Newsom said the new closures are being targeted at trouble spots, rather than being imposed statewide. "We're focusing and targeting local parts of the state where we're seeing an increase in community spread and we're seeing an increase in the positivity rate," Newsom said Wednesday. "Not every part of the state is impacted equally, and as a consequence, we are not targeting on a statewide level these rules and regulations, we are focusing in on areas of concern."

California's restrictions come as an increasing number of states have been backtracking their reopenings as coronavirus cases and hospitalization spike just ahead of the July 4 holiday weekend. States like Arizona, Georgia, Texas, and Ohio all reported record numbers of cases on Wednesday. Some records have been broken on a near-daily basis, while others were set at the height of the COVID-19 outbreak in the spring.

Georgia recorded nearly 3,000 new cases on Wednesday, breaking the previous single-day record of 2,225 cases, which was recorded on Sunday. The state has also been increasing testing, and the cumulative positivity rate is currently 9 percent.

In Ohio, the state reported 1,076 new cases of COVID-19 on Wednesday, the first time daily reported coronavirus cases have exceeded 1,000 since April.

Texas again broke its own daily record for new cases, reporting 8,076 new COVID-19 cases on Wednesday.

Arizona on Wednesday also continued to break records, with nearly 5,000 new daily cases reported. Even more concerning, the death rates have also been increasing. Deaths are a lagging indicator, and officials have been citing a low death rate as a way to diminish the impact the virus has had.

Nationally, more than 48,000 new coronavirus cases were reported in the United States on Tuesday, according to data collected by the New York Times.

Title: Gallup Poll: Trump and Obama Tied as Most Admired Man in America

Article:

In a new Gallup poll, former President Barack Obama and current President Donald Trump are tied for the title of the most admired man in America. This marks Trump's first time earning the distinction, while Obama has been named the most admired man 12 times.

The poll, which has been conducted annually since 1948, asked Americans to name the man and woman living anywhere in the world they admire most. Of the people surveyed between Dec. 2 and 15, 18% named both Obama and Trump. The results were predictably split along party lines, with 41% of Democrats naming Obama and 45% of Republicans choosing Trump.

After the two presidents, no other man was mentioned by more than 2% of respondents. The top 10 men this year also included President Jimmy Carter, businessman Elon Musk, Microsoft founder Bill Gates, Pope Francis, Sen. Bernie Sanders, Rep. Adam Schiff, the Dalai Lama, and Warren Buffet.

For the second year in a row, Michelle Obama was named the most admired woman in America. According to Gallup, the sitting president is typically Americans' choice for most admired man, taking the honor in 58 of the 72 prior polls.

Gallup noted in a press release that Trump's job approval rating is currently at 45%, among his best as president. The results come despite Trump becoming the third president in history to be impeached by Congress earlier this month. Coincident with the rise in his job approval rating, the 18% of Americans currently naming Trump as the most admired man is also up, from 13% in 2018 and 14% in 2017.

First lady Melania Trump was voted the second-most admired woman in the world, followed by Oprah Winfrey, Hillary Clinton, and climate change activist Greta Thunberg tied for third place. The remainder of the top 10 women included Queen Elizabeth II, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, Sen. Elizabeth Warren, German Chancellor Angela Merkel, and former US Ambassador to the UN Nikki Haley.

Title: Tea Party Activists Announce Primary Challenges Against Established GOP Senators

Article:

Mississippi state Sen. Chris McDaniel announced on Thursday his intention to challenge U.S. Sen. Thad Cochran in the Republican primary next year. The announcement came a day after Cochran voted to end the 16-day government shutdown and grant President Obama more borrowing authority.

McDaniel's announcement was met with immediate support from outside groups that had rallied against this week's debt and spending agreement. Daniel Horowitz, deputy political director of the Madison Project, stated, "Our country can't afford any more bad votes that stem from old friends and back-room deals. And as witnessed from the recent budget battle against Obamacare, we can't win against Democrats if we don't grow our conservative bench in the Senate."

The past two weeks have seen deep divisions within the GOP on public display. Sens. Ted Cruz of Texas, Mike Lee of Utah, and their allies pushed to withhold all government spending unless President Obama agreed to cancel Obamacare, while party leaders called that a losing strategy and tried to come up with alternatives.

On Thursday, the GOP accepted defeat, passing a bill that gives President Obama a "clean" bill to reopen government through January, and to raise the debt through at least February. A majority of Republicans supported the deal in the Senate, but the situation was reversed in the House, where Cruz allies refused to sign off on a series of plans put forward by GOP leaders to end the stalemate.

Ahead of the vote, each side blamed the other for squandering leverage. President Obama, Democratic leaders, and even many top Republicans said they hoped the tea party side had learned some political and tactical lessons, particularly in fighting a fight that now appears to have been futile from the start.

However, tea party lawmakers say they could have won if all Republicans had stuck together, and the lesson they draw is that they need to oust those who surrendered. Sen. Cruz's battle cry seemed to resonate Thursday across the country with a new generation of tea-party-style candidates who have announced bids to run against veteran GOP lawmakers in 2014.

In South Carolina, Nancy Mace, the first female graduate of The Citadel, lampooned GOP Sen. Lindsey Graham for being the sole Republican in the state's congressional delegation to support the debt deal. Another Graham opponent, state Sen. Lee Bright, also blasted the deal: "We didn't get anything... We surrendered again."

In Tennessee, state Rep. Joe Carr accused Sen. Lamar Alexander of violating conservative principles by voting to raise the debt ceiling without any accompanying spending cuts. And in Louisville, Ky., Matt Bevin, a wealthy businessman running against Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell, praised Sen. Cruz as the new face of the conservative movement and blasted McConnell, who wrote the final debt deal with his Democratic counterpart, Majority Leader Harry Reid.

"This shutdown was completely avoidable if we had real leadership in Washington," Mr. Bevin said in a Web video. "Instead, we have career politicians like Mitch McConnell and Harry Reid that make decisions based on what is political expediency for them, not on principles and not on what is in the best interest of the American people."

Former Alaska Gov. Sarah Palin, the party's 2008 vice president candidate, also weighed in, urging her supporters via Facebook not to "be discouraged by the shenanigans of D.C.'s permanent political class today."

"We're going to shake things up in 2014," Mrs. Palin said. "Rest well tonight, for soon we must focus on important House and Senate races. Let's start with Kentucky—which happens to be awfully close to South Carolina, Tennessee, and Mississippi—from sea to shining sea we will not give up. We've only just begun to fight."

The tea party, though, could face an uphill battle in the 2014 campaign season. A new Pew Research Center poll found the popularity of the tea party—including within Republican ranks—has plummeted in recent months and even more so since 2010 when it helped the GOP take over the House. Now 49 percent of the public has an unfavorable view of the tea party, compared to 30 percent who hold a favorable view.

Jim Manley, a Democratic strategist, said that the budget stalemate may have weakened the tea party within Congress, though it hasn't been eliminated. "What's interesting is that more and more senators have had it with the antics of Sens. Cruz and Lee," Mr. Manley said. "The 'just say no' crowd is down to only 18 in the Senate Republican caucus, a tremendous change from only a few months ago."

Title: U.S. Considering Increased Aid for European Migrant Crisis

Article:

The Obama administration is actively exploring ways to offer additional assistance to Europe as thousands of Syrian refugees and other migrants continue to arrive daily, reaching safe havens in countries like Germany. The migrant crisis has put a strain on infrastructure in Greece, Macedonia, and Hungary, and has highlighted divisions among European Union (EU) countries.

Germany's vice-chancellor suggested on Tuesday that his country could accept at least 500,000 migrants annually, but also called for other EU countries to contribute more. In Hungary, where thousands of migrants were trapped in large camps before neighboring borders were opened, the prime minister is urging the completion of a 13-foot fence at its border with Serbia before the end of this year.

According to NPR's Eleanor Beardsley, Hungary claims that the migrants are primarily fleeing economic hardship and do not require asylum status to protect their lives. Hungarian authorities are reportedly hindering migrants in their journey through southeast Europe towards the West. Romania has stated that migrant quotas are not the solution, while the EU maintains that countries must work together in solidarity to address the crisis.

On Monday, both France and Britain pledged to accept thousands of migrants, with France committing to take in 24,000 and Britain committing to accept 20,000. However, these numbers are significantly lower than the pace set by Germany, which welcomed at least 20,000 migrants over the past weekend. German Chancellor Angela Merkel also announced that Germany is dedicating $6.7 billion to manage the crisis.

Regarding potential U.S. involvement, the White House stated that it is examining a range of approaches to be more responsive to the global refugee crisis, including with regard to refugee resettlement. The administration added that the U.S. has provided over $4 billion in humanitarian assistance since the Syrian crisis began and over $1 billion in assistance this year, making it the single largest donor to the Syrian crisis.

As of 2015, more than 367,000 refugees and migrants have crossed the Mediterranean Sea to seek safety and better prospects in Europe, according to the U.N. Refugee Agency. Of that number, over 244,000 landed in Greece, and at least 121,000 reached Italy. The U.N. agency reported a sharp increase in the number of migrants in August, with nearly 130,000 migrants arriving.

Title: Hillary Clinton's Economic Policy Narrative: A Comparison to Bill Clinton's Administration

Article:

In her bid for the presidency, Hillary Clinton is positioning her economic policy as a continuation of her husband's administration, emphasizing the economic struggles of the American middle class. This strategy contrasts with the Republican narrative that a vote for Clinton is a vote for a third term of Barack Obama's presidency.

Clinton's campaign has been focusing on economic issues such as inequality of opportunity, less mobility, and the gender pay gap. In comments made over the past year, she has portrayed the 1990s as a model for sound economic policies, even when compared with the record of Ronald Reagan, the modern-day Republican Party hero.

In June 2020, Clinton told PBS, "If you want a better future that is going to be reliant on making smart economic policies, compare my husband’s eight years with Ronald Reagan’s eight years—23 million new jobs, more than seven million people lifted out of poverty." In another speech last year, she declared, "The 1990s taught us that even in the face of difficult long-term economic trends, it’s possible through smart policies and sound investments to enjoy broad-based growth and shared prosperity."

The eight years following her husband's presidency, according to Clinton, showed the consequences of bad policy, turning budget surpluses into deficits and "what happens when your only policy prescription is to cut taxes for the wealthy."

The economic conditions during Clinton's campaign in the early 1990s, marked by massive layoffs in manufacturing during the recession of 1991, are arguably better today, with the unemployment rate averaging 6.8 percent in 1991 and 7.5 percent in 1992, compared to 5.5 percent over the past months. However, the national mood is arguably worse, with jobs numbers not adequately accounting for the lower participation rate of American workers, with a smaller percentage of Americans working (nearly 67 percent then versus about 62 percent now). Moreover, wages have barely increased for the vast majority of workers since the early 1990s.

In contrast to the early Republican message that government has impeded the progress of the average American, the Clinton campaign looks to stress how government, in conjunction with individual initiatives and businesses, can help boost opportunities. The implication is that this is what happened throughout the eight years the other Clinton was president.

Between 1993 and 2000, the United States experienced a boom in both employment and economic growth. Gallup polls showed a significant improvement in sentiment about the economy, with just 24 percent expressing satisfaction in 1992 compared with 69 percent in 2000. The prevailing buzz was of an economy firing on all cylinders, boosted by information technologies that were enhancing worker productivity and by a Wall Street and equity boom that saw tens of millions of Americans trading hot-dot stocks that promised not just wealth but connectivity, peace, and happiness.

Title: GOP Plans to Pursue Phase Two of Tax Reform Ahead of Midterms

Article:

WASHINGTON – The Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, enacted just a few months ago, has prompted Republicans to consider phase two of tax reform, with the 2018 midterm elections in mind. The strategy aims to garner more voter support by making permanent the individual tax cuts, potentially forcing Democrats into difficult votes.

U.S. Rep. Mark Walker (R-NC) told ███ News, "We hope to get support from our Democrat friends. In fact, one of the pushbacks we heard from the Democrats was if these tax cuts are so good, why didn't we make them permanent? We've got no problem with that."

Under the current law, individual tax cuts are set to expire in ten years. Republicans were compelled to make them temporary due to budget rules and the lack of Democrat support during the bill's passage. Now, the GOP sees an opportunity to make them permanent before the midterm elections, with the potential consequence of putting Democrats on record against the cuts if they fail to provide the necessary votes.

Walker stated, "I don't know if you would call it support, but at least acknowledgment from some of our Democratic colleagues that tax reform is working in many parts of our country."

GOP lawmakers have signaled they might release parts of phase two of the tax plan on April 15. Walker, a former pastor, told ███ News that this second phase will likely consist of smaller adjustment bills. One of these bills, according to Walker, is the Universal Charitable Giving Act, which would allow families and non-itemizers to deduct charitable donations.

Walker explained that this bill ensures the new tax plan will not negatively affect donations to churches and non-profits. "We want to make sure that those gifts are protected," the North Carolina lawmaker said.

However, Walker does not expect another attempt at repealing the Johnson Amendment through tax reform. He stated, "We believe and hear that it is picking up some energy. At some point, we would like to attach it to something this year."

Lawmakers believe they could begin voting on parts of phase two as early as this month.

Title: Mueller Threatens to Subpoena Trump as Part of Russia Probe

Article:

Special Counsel Robert Mueller has reportedly warned that he could order President Donald Trump to testify as part of an investigation into alleged Russian election meddling. This is believed to be the first time the special counsel has raised the possibility of issuing a subpoena.

According to the Washington Post, Mr. Trump's lawyers were informed during a meeting in March that Mueller's team would consider issuing a subpoena if the president declined to testify. The president's former lawyer, John Dowd, has also confirmed this information.

The potential questions for Trump cover his motivations in dismissing former FBI director James Comey last May and his campaign's contacts with Russia. The president has repeatedly denied collusion, and Russia has also denied the allegations.

Ty Cobb, who has been Mr. Trump's main legal representative in the probe, is stepping down. The White House stated that Cobb had been considering retirement for some time and decided to leave at the end of this month.

The special counsel is investigating Russia's efforts to interfere in the 2016 US election, whether there was any collusion between the Kremlin and Trump's election campaign, and whether the president unlawfully tried to obstruct the inquiry. Mueller was appointed special counsel following Trump's firing of FBI director James Comey last May.

It remains unclear when Mueller will request a meeting with the president. The special counsel's office has remained tight-lipped, but the evolving strategies of the president's legal team are playing out nearly in full view. The US president himself has said he is willing to speak to Mueller, but his enthusiasm has reportedly cooled after the offices of his personal attorney were raided.

Title: Senate Republicans Unveil Police Reform Legislation: The Justice Act

Article:

Senate Republicans have introduced their police reform legislation, titled the Justice Act, which aims to hold officers accountable through an enhanced use-of-force database, restrictions on chokeholds, and the creation of new commissions to study law enforcement and race. The bill was spearheaded by Sen. Tim Scott, the lone African-American GOP senator, in response to the death of George Floyd and nationwide protests for racial justice.

Sen. Scott framed the legislation as a bridge between law enforcement and communities of color, stating, "The answer to the question of which side do you support is 'I support America.' If you support America, you support restoring the confidence that communities of color have in institutions of authority."

The 106-page legislation, called the Just and Unifying Solutions to Invigorate Communities Everywhere (JUSTICE) Act, was unveiled by Sen. Scott, along with Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, Sens. Shelley Moore Capito, John Cornyn, Lindsey Graham, James Lankford, and Ben Sasse.

The bill does not ban chokeholds outright and does not end qualified immunity, which has been criticized by Democrats as not going far enough. Senate Democrats have already unveiled their police reform legislation, the Justice in Policing Act, which includes measures to lower the bar for police officers to face criminal prosecution and create a national database of cops who have committed misconduct.

The GOP legislation would beef up requirements for law enforcement to compile use-of-force reports under a new George Floyd and Walter Scott Notification Act, named for the Minnesota father whose death sparked worldwide protests over police violence, and Scott, the South Carolina man shot by police after a traffic stop in 2015, no relation to the senator. It would also establish the Breonna Taylor Notification Act to track "no-knock" warrants.

The bill encourages agencies to do away with chokeholds or risk losing federal funds and provides funding for training to "de-escalate" situations and establish a "duty to intervene" protocol to prevent excessive force. The Republican package also includes a bipartisan Senate proposal to establish a National Criminal Justice Commission Act and extends funding streams for various federal law enforcement programs, including the COPS program important to states.

The GOP effort seeks to reach across the aisle to Democrats in several ways, including making lynching a federal hate crime and launching a study of the social status of black men and boys. The Republican package also includes a proposal to close a loophole to prohibit federal law enforcement officers from engaging in sexual acts with those being arrested or in custody. The bill also includes tapping the Smithsonian’s National Museum of African American History and Culture to create a law enforcement training curriculum on "the history of racism in the United States."

Title: Former DNC Chair Howard Dean Withdraws, Leaving Rep. Keith Ellison as Frontrunner Amid Controversy

Article:

Former Vermont Governor Howard Dean has withdrawn from the race to lead the Democratic National Committee (DNC), citing time constraints as the reason for his exit. His departure leaves Minnesota Representative Keith Ellison as the frontrunner for the position, but he is currently facing criticism regarding his ability to perform the job while remaining in the House of Representatives.

At a meeting of DNC chair candidates in Denver on Friday, Ellison stated, "I am in the process of deciding this issue of whether I can perform both roles. It has become very apparent that many of you feel very strongly about this. I've loved being in Congress...but I do think that it is more important to build and strengthen the DNC."

Historically, elected officials have chaired the DNC, but some Democrats, including those within the Obama administration, have expressed concerns that leading the party against Donald Trump will be a full-time job. Ellison's position as the first Muslim elected to Congress gives him a symbolically powerful stance against Trump, but his past comments critical of US foreign policy regarding Israel may have weakened his prospects for the DNC post.

The Anti-Defamation League recently raised concerns about Ellison's ability to represent the Democratic Party's traditional support for a strong and secure Israel, citing editorials written by Ellison for his college newspaper. In response, Ellison issued an open letter on Thursday, stating his commitment to Israel's safety and security and his support for a two-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

Ellison was an early favorite for the DNC job, earning endorsements from Vermont Senator Bernie Sanders and Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer, both of whom support a more populist position for the Democratic Party. This made Ellison a natural choice over Dean, who has served as DNC chair before and was an early supporter of Hillary Clinton.

With Dean's departure, Ellison now faces two remaining opponents: South Carolina Democratic Party chairman Jaime Harrison and New Hampshire Democratic Party chairman Ray Buckley. Both candidates agree that the future of the DNC should focus on rebuilding state parties after numerous congressional and gubernatorial losses in the November elections.

"We must become a community organization, working in our neighborhoods with grassroots activists," said Mr. Harrison. Mr. Buckley suggested an alternative leadership strategy, with him handling the nuts and bolts of running the party while Ellison or Harrison serves as the public face of the party. Dean had also called for a new leadership strategy, the "50 state strategy" he championed as chairman in 2004 through 2008.

While Dean's approach proved popular among state party chairs, it did not resonate with younger Democrats, a key constituency at a time when many party officials say that the DNC needs a younger face and new approach to survive going forward. Dean warned against letting the DNC chair race reopen the ideological party divisions exposed in the primaries.

"We can not let this be a proxy fight between Bernie Sanders supporters and Hillary Clinton supporters," Dean, who was a strong Clinton backer, said in a video message announcing his withdrawal. "We have to get rid of this idea that there is a Bernie Democrat or a Hillary Democrat or an Obama Democrat."

The DNC chair will be decided in February, when more than 400 members of the DNC meet to vote on who will lead the party during Trump's presidency.

Title: Pentagon Shifts $3.8 Billion for Border Wall Construction, Sparking Congressional Controversy

Article:

The Trump administration has announced a reallocation of $3.8 billion from weapons programs to fund the construction of the U.S.-Mexico border wall, a move that has upset lawmakers who argue the White House is bypassing their authority.

In a notice delivered to Congress on Thursday, the Pentagon revealed it is transferring $2.2 billion from its base fiscal 2020 budget and $1.6 billion from the Overseas Contingency Operations war fund. These funds will be moved to the Department of Defense's counter-drug fund, which will then be utilized for border wall construction.

According to The Hill, the Department of Homeland Security has identified areas along the southern border as drug smuggling corridors, and has deemed the construction of additional physical barriers and roads necessary to impede drug smuggling activities.

This is not the first time the administration has used executive authority to shift federal funds to the wall, largely due to Democratic lawmakers' opposition to immigration enforcement funding. Thursday's announcement has already drawn criticism from lawmakers who demand the White House seek congressional approval first.

New York Democratic Rep. Nita Lowey, who serves as the House Appropriations Committee chairwoman, and Democratic Rep. Pete Visclosky of Indiana, the chairman of the Appropriations Defense Subcommittee, issued a joint statement, stating, "While some of our Republican colleagues will lament the President’s decision, they enabled this theft by blocking our efforts to stop the President from raiding defense accounts."

Democratic criticism was expected, but one top Republican lawmaker also voiced disapproval of the administration's move on Thursday.

"The re-programming announced today is contrary to Congress’s constitutional authority, and I believe that it requires Congress to take action," Texas GOP Rep. Mac Thornberry, the ranking member of the House Armed Services Committee, said in a statement. Thornberry added that he would be in touch with his colleagues to determine "the appropriate steps to take."

President Donald Trump first declared an emergency at the U.S.-Mexico border in February 2019, allowing him to use executive authority to reallocate federal funds. Congress has twice attempted to rescind the president's emergency declaration, but was unable to overturn his vetoes both times.

The Trump administration has set an ambitious goal of completing 450 border wall miles by the end of 2020, addressing a campaign promise ahead of the November presidential elections.
