Customs and Border Protection (CBP) announced in a document obtained by the ███ News Foundation that the administration built 119 miles of new border wall as of Feb. 7, in places where dilapidated walls existed or where no walls previously existed at all.

Title: Senate Allegations Against Judge Kavanaugh Shift Focus Amidst Confirmation Process

Article:

The confirmation process for Supreme Court nominee Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh has seen a significant shift in the narrative surrounding the allegations against him. Initially, the Democrats were vocal in their opposition, labeling Judge Kavanaugh as a potential rapist and liar. However, after weeks of hearings and an additional FBI investigation, the Democratic allegations have changed focus.

On July 9, the day President Donald Trump announced Judge Kavanaugh as his choice for the court, Democratic Senator Chuck Schumer announced his intention to oppose Kavanaugh's nomination. Breitbart reported that Schumer stated, "I will oppose Judge Kavanaugh's nomination with everything I have because the stakes are simply too high."

In the following weeks, the Democrats' tactics shifted from accusing Judge Kavanaugh of being a serial rapist to questioning his temperament and behavior during his college years. Senator Dianne Feinstein, a key figure in the confirmation process, criticized Judge Kavanaugh's testimony as "aggressive and belligerent."

The New York Times reported a new allegation against Judge Kavanaugh, claiming he once threw ice at a bar during college. The incident, which occurred in September 1985, resulted in Kavanaugh and four other men being questioned by the New Haven Police Department. Kavanaugh was not arrested, but a 21-year-old man accused Kavanaugh of throwing ice on him "for some unknown reason."

The shift in allegations against Judge Kavanaugh has raised questions about the truth and credibility of the initial accusations made by the Democrats. The confirmation process has exposed the tactics used by some politicians and the media to discredit and assassinate the character of an individual for political gain.

As the confirmation process continues, it is essential to remain informed and vigilant, as the actions of the Senate and the media have far-reaching implications for the future of the American judicial system and the lives of its citizens.

Title: Former Defense Secretary Robert Gates Warns of Credibility Problems for Both Presidential Candidates in Foreign Affairs

 Article:

 In a recent op-ed published in The Wall Street Journal, former Defense Secretary Robert Gates has expressed concerns about the foreign affairs credibility of both presidential candidates, Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton.

 Gates, who has served eight U.S. presidents over 50 years, criticized Clinton for her role in advocating for the use of U.S. military to bring about regime change in Libya and her failure to anticipate the ensuing chaos. He also compared her handling of the post-Saddam Iraq situation to the criticism Democrats levied against the Bush 43 administration.

 Regarding Trump, Gates stated that the Republican candidate has a significant credibility problem. He cited Trump's proposals such as building a wall between the U.S. and Mexico, supporting torture of suspected terrorists, and praising Vladimir Putin's dictatorial leadership and Saddam Hussein's nonexistent successes against terrorism.

 Gates evaluated the candidates' positions on various global national security issues, including China, North Korea, Iran, Russia, and international trade. He warned that the new president will likely face an early test of U.S. resolve in the Persian Gulf and Iran's continued regional subversion.

 Although Gates has concerns with both candidates, he believes Clinton fares slightly better than Trump. He urged Clinton to address her trustworthiness, demonstrate her judgment, and provide specific details about her plans for dealing with various global issues.

 Gates, however, deemed Trump "beyond repair" on national security issues, stating that Trump is uninformed about the world, lacks the temperament to lead the country and government, and is unsuited to lead U.S. military personnel.

 The extent to which Clinton addresses these issues, according to Gates, will impact voter decisions, including his own. However, he considers Trump's national security positions as irreparable.

Title: Pennsylvania Resident Fined for Driving During Stay-at-Home Order

Article:

Anita Shaffer, a resident of Pennsylvania, was issued a $200 fine for violating the state's stay-at-home order aimed at containing the spread of COVID-19. According to Shaffer, she went for a leisurely drive on Sunday to get out of the house, but was pulled over by two state police officers as she returned home due to a faulty taillight. The ticket issued to Shaffer states that she violated the state's Disease Control and Prevention Act of 1955 and "failed to abide by the order of the governor and secretary of health issued to control the spread of a communicable disease."

Shaffer told PennLive's Jan Murphy that the officers asked her if she was aware of the stay-at-home act. "I am aware of it, but I didn't know it pertained to just driving," Shaffer said.

The encounter between Shaffer and the police has sparked debate over the enforcement of stay-at-home orders and the balance between public health and civil liberties. Ryan Tarkowski, a spokesman for the state police, explained the encounter as an opportunity for officers to reinforce the necessity of abiding by stay-at-home orders. However, some argue that a single person driving in their own car does not pose a significant risk of spreading the coronavirus.

The incident is not an isolated one. In California, a paddleboarder was arrested last week for violating the state's stay-at-home order, and in New York City, where the COVID-19 outbreak is most severe, police have been arresting people for violating social distancing orders.

The economic impact of stay-at-home orders and mandatory shutdowns has been a topic of discussion, with concerns about the immense economic damage and widespread unemployment. The question of how aggressively shutdown orders should be policed has also been raised, with concerns about the potential for increased risk of spreading disease through aggressive enforcement.

Elizabeth Goitein, director for liberty and national security at the Brennan Center for Justice, a legal policy think tank, suggests that policies should be driven by science, proportionate to the risks involved, and not last any longer than necessary. Goitein worries that ramped-up scrutiny of everyday life could become a new normal that tilts away from freedom.

Police should not have the power to stop and question everyone who leaves their home in apparent contravention of a stay-at-home order. Enforcement should be focused on preventing large public gatherings and actual violations of social distancing guidelines, rather than targeting individuals who are not posing a risk to others.

Shaffer plans to appeal the ticket and fine. In an update, York County District Attorney Dave Sunday has announced his intention to withdraw the citation against Shaffer, stating that prosecution may not be in the public interest due to the specific circumstances of the case.

Title: Former President Obama Criticizes U.S. Gun Laws Abroad, Sparks Controversy

Article:

Former U.S. President Barack Obama, while speaking at a tech conference in Brazil, criticized the lack of gun laws in the United States, particularly regarding the sale of what he referred to as "machine guns." The speech, which was captured on video and later removed from YouTube, sparked controversy as Obama expressed his frustration over the ease of purchasing firearms in the U.S.

During his speech, Obama referenced the Sandy Hook school shooting, stating that he was unable to assure parents that laws would change to prevent the easy purchase of machine guns. However, it is important to note that the Sandy Hook shooter was prevented from purchasing a weapon due to existing U.S. laws, and the shooter ultimately stole the weapons used in the tragedy from his own mother, whom he murdered first.

Allahpundit, a writer for Hot Air, commented that it is unclear what specific regulations Obama is advocating for to prevent such scenarios, apart from a total ban and mass confiscation. Allahpundit also pointed out that Obama's portrayal of the U.S. as lawless was made in a country that has a notoriously high murder rate, approximately six times that of the United States.

It is essential to clarify that weapons are regulated in the United States, with numerous state and federal laws governing their purchase, sale, use, manufacture, and more. The intricate debates over gun laws within the U.S. may not translate well in countries with different systems, but this does not mean they do not exist.

Obama's comments were criticized for being inaccurate and potentially misleading, with some interpreting them as an attempt to criticize America to a foreign audience, a practice that was reportedly a specialty of Obama during his presidency.

Title: Parallels Between HIV and Ebola Outbreaks: Researcher Reflects on History and Lessons Learned

Article:

In an interview with journalist Julia Belluz, Rick Elion, the clinical-research director at the Whitman-Walker Clinic in Washington, D.C., discusses the parallels between the HIV and Ebola outbreaks and the lessons that have been missed in responding to disease outbreaks.

Elion, who has been a long-time HIV researcher, expressed that watching the public's reaction to Ebola today brings him feelings of post-traumatic stress disorder, reminding him of the early days of HIV/AIDS. He noted that, similar to HIV, there is a desire to isolate those suspected of carrying the virus, and fear-based policies are being enacted.

When asked about his thoughts on the public's fear and discussion about Ebola, Elion stated, "It's the same discussion: people want to wall off what they're afraid of." He went on to explain that with HIV, victims were seen with derision and were often blamed for their disease. With Ebola, the victims have been mostly occupational exposures, and the public is more sympathetic, but there is still a desire to isolate Ebola victims.

Elion also discussed the emotional impact of the Ebola epidemic, stating that it brings back memories of HIV and the large number of people who have died from the virus. He emphasized the need to bring humanity into the equation when responding to disease outbreaks, as the longer we do not, the more the disease will flourish.

Regarding isolationist policies such as quarantines and travel bans, Elion stated that these were tried with HIV and did not work. He explained that borders are porous, and people can leave their country and fly another way. He suggested that it is better to keep the borders porous and regulate who is moving, rather than imposing quarantines.

Elion also noted that the quarantine policy is irrational and will impair the ability of help to flow to the affected population. He stated that quarantining afebrile people is counter-productive, as these individuals are not likely to be transmitting the virus.

Title: Bluefin-21 Resumes Search for MH370 as Object of Interest Proven Not to Be Plane Debris

Article:

The autonomous underwater vehicle Bluefin-21 has resumed its mission to search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, which disappeared on March 8, after scanning over 90% of the designated search area. The search for an object found near Augusta, Australia, which was initially considered a potential lead, has been ruled out as debris from the missing plane.

The metal object, which appeared to have rivets on one side, was picked up near Augusta, approximately 1,000 miles away from the suspected crash site. However, detailed pictures of the object were enough to convince investigators that it was not a lead in the search for the missing plane. Authorities have not yet determined the object's origin.

The search for Flight 370, which carried 239 passengers and crew, has been ongoing for 48 days, with no signs of debris found. The search efforts have been complicated by the Indian Ocean being filled with garbage, with other objects spotted in the search turning out to be trash, jellyfish, and fishing gear.

On Thursday, up to 11 military aircraft and 11 ships are set to search for the plane. The Bluefin-21 has begun its 12th mission, continuing to scan the underwater search area set out by investigators.

Malaysian and Australian authorities are already mapping out a long-term strategy for the search, which could last for months or years, if the two-year search for Air France Flight 447 is any guide. If the underwater search comes up empty, it could ground the air search as well.

The next logical step after the underwater search is to "rethink all of the information we have at hand," ocean search specialist Rob McCallum told CNN. An expanded search area might include the last 370 miles of the plane's flight path, perhaps 15 miles on either side. Deep-towed sonar, which provides less resolution than the Bluefin-21 but about 10 times the range, may also be considered.

Investigators would love to find the flight data recorders from Flight 370, a potential treasure trove of information into what happened to the jetliner and the 239 passengers and crew on board. If found, the "black boxes" would likely go to the Australian Transport Safety Board's accident investigation lab. However, the investigation is officially Malaysian, so Malaysia's officials would decide where the boxes would go.

The Malaysian Cabinet has approved the appointment of an international investigation team to look into the disappearance of Flight 370. The names of the team members will be announced next week, and the team will not be looking at the criminal aspects of the investigation, which remain under the Royal Malaysian Police. The main purpose of the team is to evaluate and determine the cause of the accident. Malaysia has completed a preliminary report on the incident but has not released it publicly.

Title: Obama and Boehner Discuss Deficit Reduction Framework, Differences Remain

Article:

In a meeting at the White House on Monday, President Obama and Speaker John Boehner discussed a deficit reduction framework that would raise $1 trillion over 10 years. The details of the plan will be settled next year by Congress's tax-writing committees and the Obama administration.

In response to the initial $1.6 trillion proposal, President Obama reduced his proposal to $1.2 trillion, with $1.22 trillion in spending cuts compared to the Republicans' initial offer of $1.2 trillion in cuts. The White House plan would permanently extend Bush-era tax cuts on household incomes below $400,000, with only the top tax bracket, currently 35 percent, increasing to 39.6 percent.

The White House plan would cut spending by $1.22 trillion over 10 years, with $800 billion in cuts to programs, $122 billion from adopting a new measure of inflation that slows the growth of government benefits, especially Social Security, and $290 billion in savings from lower interest costs on a reduced national debt.

Of the $800 billion in straight cuts, the president said half would come from federal health care programs, $200 billion from other so-called mandatory programs like farm price supports, not subject to Congress's annual spending bills, $100 billion from military spending, and $100 billion from domestic programs under Congress's annual discretion.

To make the plan happen, President Obama proposed fast-track procedures to help Congressional tax writers overhaul the individual and corporate tax code and make changes to other programs.

Senior Republican aides made it clear that differences remain between the two parties. For instance, they say the president is still pressing for $1.3 trillion in higher taxes because the change in the way inflation is calculated would not only slow the growth of spending but also raise more revenue by slowing the rate at which tax brackets rise each year with the cost of living.

They also disagree with the president over counting lower interest payments on the national debt as savings. "A proposal that includes $1.3 trillion in revenue for only $930 billion in spending cuts can not be considered balanced," said another spokesman for Mr. Boehner, using the Republicans' calculation for the president's offer.

The president is also insisting on some protections for what he has called the "most vulnerable populations," which Republican aides said they had not been expecting. The new inflation calculations, for instance, would probably not affect wounded veterans and disabled people on Supplemental Security Income.

Additionally, President Obama is sticking by his request for additional upfront spending on infrastructure and an extension of expiring unemployment benefits. He would also secure some tax and policy changes long sought by both parties but unattainable in the context of smaller budget deals.

To keep the country from returning to fiscal showdowns, Mr. Obama wants the government's borrowing limit to rise high enough to take the issue off the table for two years, although he said that Congress could periodically weigh in and try to override a presidential lifting of the debt ceiling, should it want to.

Senior Republican aides made it clear on Monday night that the plan was not what the speaker had wanted. He had proposed higher income tax rates on income over $1 million. That revenue would be supplemented by reinstating a provision in the tax code—phased out by the Bush-era tax cuts—that automatically limits tax deductions and credits for the affluent. The speaker was also ready to accept a White House proposal from Mr. Obama's first days in office that would limit tax deductions to 28 percent, trimming back deductions for charitable giving and other activities from the top rate paid by the giver, 35 percent currently.

Title: Central American Leaders and Obama Discuss Comprehensive Plan to Address Youth Migrant Surge

Article:

Central American leaders, including the presidents of El Salvador, Honduras, and Guatemala, met with President Barack Obama at the White House on Friday to discuss a comprehensive plan to address the surge of immigrant youth from their countries entering the United States illegally. The meeting was part of an effort to find a solution to the ongoing humanitarian crisis, which has become a contentious issue in the debate over reforming the U.S. immigration system.

The Central American leaders signaled to Obama that they are working on a plan to address the root causes of the migration, including strategies for reducing crime and promoting greater social and economic opportunity. The presidents reiterated their commitment to prevent families and children from undertaking the dangerous journey and to work together to promote safe, legal, and orderly migration.

Obama told the Central American leaders that most of the child migrants crossing the border illegally will not be permitted to stay. Some have been deported already, while most are being allowed to stay temporarily while their immigration status is sorted out. The Obama administration has also discussed a pilot program that would let the United States assess asylum claims in those countries to reduce the number of illegal immigrants.

The administration and Congress have struggled to come to a consensus on how to address the surge that has overwhelmed border and immigration services. Obama has asked Congress for $3.7 billion in emergency funds for border efforts, while Republicans and some Democrats in Congress are resisting that proposal and offering alternatives that would spend less and change immigration policy to deport kids faster.

The House of Representatives is expected to vote on a scaled-down border bill next week that would provide less than $1 billion to address the crisis and modify a 2008 law to make it easier to deport children from Central America who enter the United States illegally. The proposal to alter that law all but ensures the bill will not come to a vote in the Senate, where Democrats are opposed to tagging that change to a funding bill of its own for the border crisis.

The administration is also considering sending National Guard troops to the border, according to a White House official, just days after Texas Gov. Rick Perry said he would do just that in the Rio Grande Valley area. The Pentagon and the Department of Health and Human Services sent a team this week to assess Border Patrol efforts in the Rio Grande Valley. The number of unaccompanied minors seeping through that area has slowed dramatically since last month.

Title: Rep. Al Green Introduces Articles of Impeachment Against President Trump, Citing Disparaging Remarks

Article:

Rep. Al Green (D-TX) has become the first member of Congress to publicly read articles of impeachment against President Donald Trump on the House floor. The president's Twitter account is at the center of the allegations, with Trump's remarks about NFL players, Puerto Ricans, Muslims, LGBTQ people, and former President Barack Obama cited as examples of "crimes and misdemeanors."

Green's proposal, however, is unlikely to gain traction, given the Republican control of both the House and Senate. Even some Democrats have expressed skepticism about the idea of impeaching Trump in the near future.

In a 15-page document, Green argues that Trump should be impeached for tweeting disparaging remarks about various groups. The document, which can be read in full below, does not mention Trump's firing of FBI Director James Comey or the obstruction of justice allegations.

Green contends that the Constitution does not require the commission of a crime for a president to be impeached. Instead, he argues that "high crimes and misdemeanors" referred to in Article II, Section IV consist of actions that may be "denominated political."

Among the "high crimes" Trump is accused of committing are falsely claiming President Obama wiretapped Trump Tower, vowing to ban transgender people from the military, and calling NFL players "sons of bitches."

Green has faced death threats and a barrage of hate mail since first proposing impeachment charges against Trump. Aides say they have received far more feedback over Green's impeachment speech alone than in the rest of this congressional term. Green was in contact with the FBI for his safety.

Most Democrats say it is too early to advance calls for impeachment. In an interview this May, Green acknowledged that his articles of impeachment are unlikely to go anywhere in the Republican-controlled Congress. At the time, he argued that Trump should be impeached for obstructing justice by firing Comey, a charge that does not appear in his articles of impeachment.

Green wrote the document himself after consulting with constitutional scholars, he said. "The Comey firing is something that is still subject to impeachment," Green said. "But the last straw for me was when the president called the NFL men who played football'sons of Bs,'" he added, referring to Trump's use of a racial slur against NFL players.

Title: GOP Leader Kevin McCarthy Questions ABC News Over Alleged Spiking of Jeffrey Epstein Story

Article:

House Republican Leader Kevin McCarthy has sent a letter to ABC News President James Goldston, posing a series of questions regarding the network's reported decision to withhold a story about the late Jeffrey Epstein, a financier who was accused of child trafficking and pedophilia. The letter, obtained exclusively by Megyn Kelly and shared on her Instagram account, lists six specific inquiries, taking an urgent tone due to the nature of the alleged human trafficking operation.

The questions include:
1. Will ABC News provide Congress the interview conducted by Amy Robach, the journalist who reportedly had firsthand information from one of Epstein's accusers, with the victim?
2. What did ABC News learn about Epstein after Robach first presented her story to executives?
3. Who was involved in deciding this story was not of public interest, and what were their reasons for doing so?
4. Can Robach expand on the “outside forces” she mentioned as potentially responsible for the story not running?
5. Was ABC News ever presented with additional evidence on Epstein from the time Robach first brought her investigation to the network and when he was ultimately arrested?
6. Were authorities alerted at any time after Robach presented ABC News executives with her reporting? If so, when and what was provided?

In a series of Project Veritas videos released earlier this month, former ABC News reporter Amy Robach spoke candidly about how the network refused to air her chilling report on Epstein a few years ago. Epstein, who reportedly committed suicide in prison a few months ago, has been accused of pimping young girls and forcing them to have sex with hundreds of men.

McCarthy expressed regret over the situation, stating, "ABC News chose to bury the truth." In a separate development, Kelly interviewed former ABC News producer Ashley Bianco, who was fired by CBS for reportedly leaking the video clip of Robach criticizing ABC News for nixing her Epstein story. Bianco claimed she did not leak the video to Project Veritas, leaving open the question of whether CBS fired the wrong person. According to Project Veritas's James O'Keefe, the real leaker is still at ABC.

ABC News has denied reports that they killed Robach's story.

Title: Congressional Agenda Dominated by Veto Threats as Obama and Democratic Leaders Stake Out Positions

Article:

The 114th Congress, barely a week old, has seen the "V-word" take center stage as President Obama has issued veto threats on three measures, with Democratic leaders vowing to provide the necessary votes to uphold them. Despite calls for cooperation and Republican efforts to line up bipartisan bills for their early agenda, the President's veto threats have been met with resistance from both parties.

House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, a California Democrat, stated on Thursday that her troops will vote to uphold the vetoes. Meanwhile, Senate Democrats launched their first filibuster of the year on the third day of business, a record-breaking move according to an analysis. The filibuster was on legislation to build the Keystone XL pipeline, which has bipartisan support.

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, a Kentucky Republican, stated that they will work through the process to get bipartisan jobs legislation on the President's desk as soon as possible. President Obama has issued a veto threat on the Keystone measure, as well as a bill to repeal Obamacare's 30-hour workweek definition and legislation that includes a two-year delay of Dodd-Frank financial reform regulations.

Sen. Joe Manchin III, a West Virginia Democrat and Keystone supporter, stated on Thursday that he believes enough Democrats could rally behind the project for the Senate to override an Obama veto. However, Pelosi stated that she will muster Democrats in her chamber to uphold the veto on Keystone and the other two issues where President Obama has drawn lines.

Pelosi stated that the President's veto is the key to Democrats' legislative strategy this year. After years of blaming Republicans for blocking Democrats' agenda, Pelosi said that relying on the President to veto bills doesn't make Democrats the "party of 'No.'" Instead, she said, "We want a path to 'Yes,'" aiming for an approach that has integrity and unity.

Pelosi led opposition Wednesday to the Dodd-Frank bill, helping switch dozens of Democrats who voted for a similar measure last year but opposed it this week. As a result, the legislation failed to get the two-thirds vote needed to clear under expedited rules. Pelosi expects Republicans will bring the bill back under regular rules, but Wednesday's vote proves she can sustain an Obama veto on that, too.

The reliance on the veto, and President Obama's eagerness to issue threats, has already poisoned the atmosphere on Capitol Hill. House Speaker John A. Boehner, an Ohio Republican, stated that he expects to raise the issue of vetoes with President Obama when the President hosts congressional leaders at the White House next week.

As Republicans blame Democrats for blocking action, Democrats counter that Republicans are adopting tactics they fought when they were in the minority. The partisan rhetoric and procedural maneuvers have set a contentious tone for the 114th Congress, with both parties digging in their heels and vowing to fight for their respective agendas.

Title: U.S., Allies Accuse Iran of Attacking Oil Tankers Near Strait of Hormuz; Tensions Escalate

Article:

The Trump administration has accused Iran of carrying out attacks on two oil tankers near the Strait of Hormuz last week, stating that it is keeping all options on the table, including military strikes, in response. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo claimed on "Fox News Sunday" that the attacks were conducted with the intent to deny transit through the strait, through which about a fifth of the world's oil is transported daily.

The Pentagon released photographs and a grainy black-and-white video on Thursday, purportedly showing Islamic Revolutionary Guard troops removing an unexploded mine from an oil tanker targeted in the Gulf of Oman. According to U.S. Central Command, American forces in the region witnessed and recorded an Iranian boat approaching the oil tanker Kokuka Courageous and removing an unexploded limpet mine from the side of the vessel.

The U.S. intelligence community has significant evidence to blame Tehran for the attacks, as stated by Mr. Pompeo. Iran has persistently denied such claims. U.S. officials also claim that limpet mines were used in a May attack on four oil tankers, which the Trump administration has also blamed on Iran.

Not all parties are convinced by the U.S. account of the situation. Germany's foreign minister has requested additional evidence before pointing blame on Tehran, stating that the video released by the Pentagon is not enough to draw conclusions. The Japanese owner of one of the tankers has told of his crew's account of the incident and said the ship was hit by a flying object, not a mine.

Saudi Arabia, the world's largest exporter of crude oil, and Britain have joined the U.S. in pointing fingers at Iran. In an interview with Saudi-owned newspaper Asharq al-Awsat, Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman called on other countries to take a "decisive stand" against the attack. Britain plans to send elite military forces to the region in response to the attacks, with Royal Marines scheduled to be deployed to the region in coming weeks and expected to patrol the strait, joining ships stationed at Britain's naval base in Bahrain.

However, the British Defense Ministry downplayed the significance of the move, stating that it is a "pre-planned training deployment and is in no way related to the ongoing situation in the Gulf of Oman." As tensions escalate between Washington and Tehran, Mr. Pompeo maintained that the U.S. does not seek war with Iran but will defend itself if necessary.

Congressional leaders have warned that the administration lacks congressional approval to use military force. Mr. Pompeo on Sunday insisted that the administration "always [ has ] the authorization to defend American interests." Congressional leaders, including House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, have said the White House can not cite the 2001 Authorization for Use of Military Force to strike in the Middle East and have reiterated that only Congress can declare war.

Rep. Adam B. Schiff, California Democrat and chairman of the House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence, said in an appearance on CBS that while he believes Iran is behind the attacks, "congressional approval is necessary to initiate hostilities against Iran." Sen. Tom Cotton, an Arkansas Republican who sits on the Senate intelligence and Armed Services committees, said retaliatory military strikes against Iran would be warranted.

Title: Tensions Rise Between North Korea and South Korea, Israel Launches Airstrikes Against Syria

Article:

North Korean dictator Kim Jong Un has ordered his military units into a "semi-war state" with South Korea following a series of rocket and artillery exchanges on Thursday. The incident marks the most significant such incident in five years, according to The New York Times. Two South Korean soldiers were wounded in a land mine explosion in the demilitarized zone on August 4, for which the South blames the North, as reported by The New York Times.

In response, the South began broadcasting propaganda in the demilitarized zone, a practice that was common but was agreed to stop in 2004. The North has demanded that the South end its loudspeaker propaganda by Saturday afternoon, or else face an attack from the North; the South has rejected the ultimatum.

Meanwhile, Israel launched two rounds of airstrikes against the Syrian military and allied militant groups in Syria on Thursday and Friday, in response to rocket attacks at the Golan Heights. Israel claims that the rocket attack was conducted by the Palestinian militant group Islamic Jihad and coordinated by Iran, which backs the Syrian government in the country's civil war. Syria's government claims five civilians were killed in the second round of strikes, while the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights says they were pro-government fighters. Israel claimed that they were actually Palestinian members of Islamic Jihad, which has so far denied responsibility for the rocket attacks.

The Israeli government is already connecting the rocket attacks to the Iran nuclear deal, with Defense Minister Moshe Yaalon alleging the rocket strikes were a "preview of a richer and more murderous Iran" after sanctions are lifted. The income models of various artists are also making headlines, as well as speculation about the British Labour Party's support for leftist leadership candidate Jeremy Corbyn, and a new apartment development in London featuring a "sky pool" suspended between two buildings with a glass floor. Additionally, there is an increasing number of Bernie Sanders supporters embracing a conspiracy theory in which Black Lives Matter is a Hillary Clinton front meant to destroy Sanders' campaign. Finally, a new video on YouTube explores the evolution of prosthetics from peg legs to biolimbs.

Title: ICE Discretionary Releases of Criminal Immigrants Raise Controversy

Article:

The release of thousands of illegal immigrant criminals by the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) last year, many of whom were deemed the top priority for deportation, has sparked controversy due to new numbers obtained by the House Judiciary Committee Chairman Bob Goodlatte. According to the data, over 17,000 of the criminal aliens released in 2014 were released due to ICE's discretion, representing 57 percent of the releases.

In a statement, ICE stated that it takes release decisions seriously and makes a judgment in each case. The agency pointed out that not all Level 1 criminal aliens are subject to mandatory detention and may be eligible for bond due to mitigating circumstances such as deteriorated health, advanced age, and caretaking responsibilities.

However, nearly all of those released under electronic monitoring broke the terms of their release, according to ICE numbers. In fiscal year 2014, ICE put about 41,000 immigrants through electronic monitoring, and more than 30,000 of them broke the terms of their release—many of them racking up multiple violations.

In a statement to The ███, ICE said violations can include what they deem minor problems, such as someone lacking a strong enough cell signal for voice verification by phone or someone calling in too early or a few minutes late. Low batteries or jostling an electronic bracelet during sports can also cause a monitoring alarm to go off incorrectly, ICE said.

Of the more than 30,000 detainees who broke the conditional terms of their release and monitoring in 2014, only 2,420 were deemed to have been serious enough breaches to rearrest them.

Part of ICE's problem is that it doesn't have enough beds to go out and pick up violators, according to an inspector general's report released earlier this year. Agency officials said they would like to be able to hold those who willfully break the rules, but they haven't requested more beds. Indeed, President Obama's 2016 budget request actually asked for fewer beds to hold detainees next year, arguing that he wants to put more emphasis on the very alternatives that are being violated.

The treatment of those awaiting their deportation proceedings has been controversial for several years. In 2013, the agency released 36,007 convicted criminals who were awaiting the outcome of their deportation cases. Those released had amassed 116 homicide convictions, 15,635 drunken driving convictions, and 9,187 convictions stemming from what ICE labeled involvement with "dangerous drugs."

The total dropped to about 30,000 in 2014—but the seriousness of the offenses increased, with 193 homicide convictions among the detainees and 16,070 drunken driving convictions. There were also 426 sexual assaults and 303 kidnapping convictions, ICE said.

Homeland Security Secretary Jeh Johnson and ICE Director Sarah Saldana said the numbers were unacceptable and imposed new rules requiring releases to be vetted by senior agency officials to make sure they were correct. Both Mr. Johnson and Ms. Saldana also said many of the releases are required and give them little discretion—particularly those made under a 2001 Supreme Court decision known as the Zadvydas case, when the justices ruled that immigrants couldn't generally be detained indefinitely. That means that if a home country won't take someone back, ICE must release them after about six months.

However, the new numbers obtained by Mr. Goodlatte suggest Zadvydas-related releases were fewer than 2,500 in 2014, or only about 8 percent of the total—compared to the 57 percent that ICE admits were completely discretionary. The rest of the releases were divided between cases where an immigration judge ordered bond or where ICE was unable to obtain travel documents but it wasn't considered a mandatory release under the Zadvydas ruling.

Title: Media Narrative Suggests Clinton Lead Over Trump in U.S. Presidential Race

Article:

The media coverage of the ongoing United States presidential race indicates a growing consensus that Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton is favored to win the election, while Republican candidate Donald Trump is facing mounting challenges. This narrative is evident in various news outlets, including the Washington Post, New York Times, Politico, and Fox News.

Headlines such as "Clinton Hopes for a Mandate and Coattails" and "Clinton is in a commanding position in the contest to become the 45th president" suggest a shift in the race's dynamics. The media has also reported on potential cabinet appointments for a Clinton administration and speculated about her policy priorities.

Fox's Karl Rove, a prominent Republican strategist, stated that Trump's chances of winning are slim, with headlines like "ROVE: HE'S TOAST" appearing in publications like the Huffington Post. Reports of Trump's refusal to commit to accepting the election results and his perceived poor performance in the third debate have further fueled the narrative of a struggling Trump campaign.

Polling data also supports the idea that Clinton is leading in the race. According to Politico, if Trump were to win all the remaining battleground states, he would still fall short of the necessary 270 electoral votes to secure the presidency. The six states where Clinton currently leads in the polls are showing signs of becoming swing states, a shift from previous elections.

However, it is important to note that not all polls show Clinton with a significant lead. For instance, the L.A. Times poll and an IBD poll suggest a close race, with Clinton and Trump tied or Trump slightly ahead. The election will ultimately be decided in states such as Florida, Ohio, North Carolina, Colorado, Arizona, and a handful of others.

With less than three weeks remaining until the election, the media's desire for the election to conclude and the public's eagerness for the campaign to end is palpable. However, as Yogi Berra once said, "It ain't over till it's over." The race remains competitive, and the outcome is still uncertain.

Title: U.S. and Romanian Service Members, Civilians Killed in Taliban Suicide Bombing in Kabul

Article:

A suicide bombing carried out by the Taliban in the center of Kabul on Thursday resulted in the death of a U.S. soldier, a Romanian service member, and at least 10 civilians near the American embassy. The incident occurred near the headquarters of Afghanistan's international military force and the American embassy.

The American and Romanian service members were both NATO soldiers, according to the NATO Resolute Support mission. The mission confirmed the two service members were "killed in action," but declined to provide further details or release their names. The American soldier was the fourth killed in the past two weeks in Afghanistan.

The Taliban claimed responsibility for the attack, stating they targeted vehicles of "foreigners" trying to enter the heavily guarded Shashdarak area where Afghan national security authorities have offices. The explosion followed a Taliban attack against a foreign compound late Monday that killed at least 16 people and wounded more than 100, almost all of them local civilians.

The violence continued hours later when the Taliban claimed responsibility for a car bombing outside an Afghan military base in the Logar provincial capital, Puli Alam, with local officials saying four civilians were killed and 11 others wounded. The Afghanistan Independent Human Rights Commission also confirmed that its acting leader in Ghor province, Abdul Samad Amiri, had been kidnapped by the Taliban while traveling and shot dead late on Wednesday.

The U.S. envoy, Zalmay Khalilzad, is in Kabul briefing Afghan leaders on the U.S.-Taliban deal to end nearly 18 years of fighting. The Afghan government has raised serious concerns about the deal, including in new comments on Thursday as the latest Kabul bombing occurred. The agreement was moving with "excessive speed," according to presidential adviser Waheed Omer, who warned of difficult days ahead.

The Taliban, at their strongest since their 2001 defeat by a U.S.-led invasion, have refused to negotiate with the government, calling it a U.S. puppet. The U.S. hopes its deal with the Taliban will bring the militant group to the table for intra-Afghan talks to begin ahead of Afghanistan's presidential election on Sept. 28. The Afghan government has said it shares the concerns raised this week by several former U.S. ambassadors to Afghanistan. They warned that a full U.S. troop withdrawal that moves too quickly and without requiring the Taliban to meet certain conditions, such as reducing violence, could lead to "total civil war" such as the one that engulfed the country in the 1990s after a rapid Soviet pullout and before the Taliban swept into power.

Title: Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein Expected to Depart DOJ in Coming Weeks

Article:

Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein is expected to leave the Department of Justice (DOJ) within weeks, according to reports from CNN and ABC News. President Donald Trump has reportedly been informed of Rosenstein's plans to depart following the confirmation of Attorney General nominee William Barr.

White House press secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders, during a Wednesday interview on Fox News, all but confirmed the move, stating that Rosenstein "has always planned to roughly stay around two years." Sanders added that there is no intention by the president or the White House to push him out, and suggested that Rosenstein is making room for Barr to build his own team.

Barr's confirmation hearings in front of the Senate Judiciary Committee are scheduled for next week. However, sources told The Washington Post that there are no firm plans for Rosenstein's departure or a timeline. NBC News reported that Rosenstein will not leave until Special Counsel Robert Mueller submits his final report.

Rosenstein has been overseeing Mueller's investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election since then-Attorney General Jeff Sessions recused himself from the probe. Trump has frequently criticized the DOJ and the FBI over the investigation, referring to it as a "witch hunt" and accusing the departments of bias against him.

Trump forced the resignation of Sessions in November and appointed Sessions's chief of staff, Matthew Whitaker, as acting attorney general. Whitaker is currently overseeing the Mueller probe, despite past public criticism of the investigation. If confirmed, Barr would take over for Whitaker in overseeing the investigation.

Rosenstein's departure would mark the end of a rocky tenure as deputy attorney general. Speculation swirled late last year that Trump would fire Rosenstein after The New York Times reported that he discussed secretly taping the president and invoking the 25th Amendment to remove Trump from office.

Title: Trump Administration's North Korea Denuclearization Timeline and Recent Developments

Article:

The Trump administration's national security adviser, John R. Bolton, stated on CBS's "Face the Nation" on Sunday that significant steps toward North Korea's denuclearization could be achieved within a year. However, according to private administration officials, Mr. Bolton's view aligns with his pre-administration stance that North Korea will not entirely abandon its nuclear program.

The question remains whether North Korean leader Kim Jong-un is genuinely committed to a change in course or is merely buying time with President Trump, as his predecessors were during their interactions with the past four U.S. presidents.

Recent reports suggest that North Korea continues to advance its nuclear and missile programs, despite its denuclearization pledge. In response, President Trump boasted on Twitter on Tuesday that there have been no rocket launches or nuclear tests in the past eight months, crediting his administration for the peace. He also claimed that without him, the United States would be at war with North Korea.

While there has been a freeze in missile and nuclear tests since November, this does not equate to denuclearization. North Korea retains all its nuclear capabilities and can resume testing at any time. This was previously deemed insufficient by former Secretary of State Rex W. Tillerson because it merely maintained the ability to strike, an intolerable position that President Trump had previously characterized.

The lack of military exercises between the United States and South Korea and the reduced tension between the two countries are evidence of North Korea's success in lowering the heat. The Trump administration's tendency to equate a good meeting with a good outcome is highlighted in this critical national security crisis. This resembles President John F. Kennedy's declaration of the Cold War's resolution after his meeting with Soviet Union's Nikita Khrushchev in 1961, followed by the Cuban missile crisis 16 months later.

In this ongoing situation, it is crucial to distinguish between a temporary freeze and the ultimate goal of denuclearization. The timeline and progress toward this goal remain uncertain, and the international community continues to monitor developments closely.

Title: California's Proposition 8: A Turning Point in the Supreme Court

Article:

Supporters and opponents of California's Proposition 8, the controversial measure banning same-sex marriage, have reached a consensus on one point: Tuesday's Supreme Court hearing marked a significant milestone.

Nowlin Haltom, a real estate agent in Studio City, Los Angeles, expressed his sentiments, "I can't believe we have come this far, frankly." Haltom, who married his partner of 15 years in New York two years ago, has been an active participant in the fight for same-sex marriage rights for a long time.

On the opposing side, Tim Wildmon, president of the American Family Association, stated, "The Supreme Court is considering toying with thousands of years of human history." He argued, "There is nothing in the history of the world culture that supports redefining marriage as an institution between a man and a man or a woman and a woman."

The potential outcomes from Tuesday's arguments range from the case being dismissed to a broad ruling on whether there is a constitutional right for same-sex couples to marry. Rebecca Brown, a constitutional law professor at the University of Southern California's Gould School of law, explained, "They've heard all the arguments, now they will go away and sort through them." A decision is expected by early June.

Haltom, a Vietnam veteran, is hopeful but cautious. He expressed concerns about the implications of the ruling on his own relationship, as his husband would not be entitled to collect Haltom's Social Security check upon his death.

Wildmon, however, suggests that a broad Supreme Court ruling in support of same-sex marriage would contradict the majority opinion in America. Though polls show that more than 50 percent of Americans support same-sex marriage, he notes that 31 states have created legislation defining marriage as being only between a man and a woman.

Paul Linton, special counsel at The Thomas More Society, a national anti-abortion and anti-gay marriage advocacy group in Chicago, indicates that the court might be wary of making a broad ruling. For instance, Justice Anthony Kennedy expressed concerns about heading into "uncharted waters."

Linton expressed his concerns about the potential negative impact of a broad decision, suggesting it could lead to some states calling for a constitutional amendment, which might necessitate Congress to convene a convention. He noted that such a convention has not been used in the history of the United States since the original Constitutional Convention of 1789, but if two-thirds of the states demanded it, it could occur.

Title: Cost Analysis of Various Universal Healthcare Plans in the U.S.

Article:

With the ongoing debate among Democrats regarding the expansion of healthcare access and President Trump's promise of a future "phenomenal" plan, significant changes are expected in the U.S. health care system. The leading Democratic presidential candidates have discussed the merits of Medicare for All during recent debates, but this is just one of several options under consideration.

A study released by a team of researchers from the Urban Institute on Wednesday examines different healthcare reform plans. Among other findings, the report suggests that it is possible to achieve universal healthcare without drastically overhauling the current system or causing federal expenditures to skyrocket.

The study compares the costs of three universal healthcare plans: Medicare for All, an "enhanced" Medicare-for-All plan, and a "lite" Medicare-for-All plan.

1. Medicare for All: The report estimates that Medicare for All would cost $34 trillion over 10 years. This plan would cover everyone in the U.S., including undocumented immigrants, and offer more benefits than the current system, such as dental, vision, hearing, and long-term services and supports. Employer spending on health care would decrease by $955 billion, and household spending would fall by $887 billion. However, $2.7 trillion in additional federal revenue would be needed to finance the new program.

2. "Enhanced" Medicare-for-All plan: This plan, which covers everyone in the U.S. (including undocumented immigrants) and offers more benefits than the current system, would raise national spending on health care by nearly $3 trillion in 2020 and $34 trillion, or $32 trillion after tax offsets, over 10 years. Employer spending on health care would decrease by $955 billion, and household spending would fall by $887 billion, but $2.7 trillion in additional federal revenue would be needed to finance the new program.

3. "Lite" Medicare-for-All plan: This plan, which covers all legal residents in the U.S. but not the 10.8 million undocumented immigrants in the country, would cost roughly $17.6 trillion over 10 years. This plan would reduce national spending on health care by about $209 billion in 2020. Federal spending would increase by $1.5 trillion in the first year, but total health-care spending would fall by about $210 billion as a result of lower provider payment rates and administrative savings.

The study also presents a plan that includes some out-of-pocket expenses based on income and a less generous set of expanded benefits. This plan, which would cover all legal residents in the U.S. but not the 10.8 million undocumented immigrants in the country, would reduce national spending on health care by about $209 billion in 2020. Federal spending would increase by $1.5 trillion in the first year, but total health-care spending would fall by about $210 billion as a result of lower provider payment rates and administrative savings.

Medicare for All is not the only path to universal coverage. One of the plans in the report, involving a mix of private and public health insurance, would cover everyone in the U.S. except for 6.6 million undocumented immigrants. The plan would beef up Obamacare subsidies, expand Medicaid to all states, provide a public option, and cap payment rates. Federal spending would increase by $122.1 billion if implemented next year and by $1.5 trillion over 10 years, but total national health spending would fall by $22.6 billion in 2020.

Sara Collins, a vice president at the Commonwealth Fund, which funded the study, said that the report shows that universal health care coverage "can be reached in different ways" – and, we should add, with very different costs.

Title: Record-Breaking Republican Primary Turnout in Multiple States

Article:

More than 240,000 new Democrats and independents participated in Virginia's Republican presidential primary this week, marking a significant shift in voter demographics. This trend is also observed in other major states, with over 535,000 new Democrats and independents in Texas, 175,000 in Georgia, 172,000 in Tennessee, and 143,000 in Alabama, according to an analysis of exit polling compared to the 2008 race.

Donald Trump, the Republican front-runner, attributes this growth to his campaign efforts. In a statement on Tuesday, Mr. Trump declared, "We have expanded the Republican Party." He claimed that longtime Democrats and independents have switched their allegiance to the Republican Party due to his campaign.

Exit polling data supports Mr. Trump's claim, with nearly 10 million people casting ballots in the 15 primaries and caucuses so far, representing about 4 million more votes than in the same Republican races in 2008. Mr. Trump has won about a third of the votes, building a formidable and durable coalition that spans moderates and evangelicals, draws heavily from self-identified independents, and tilts toward older and less-educated supporters.

The increased Republican turnout is evident in the number of record-breaking contests, with 14 of the 15 Republican contests so far setting records for turnout. In contrast, Democratic turnout has decreased by more than 30% compared to the 2008 elections, with the exception of Colorado's caucuses.

Democrats attribute the difference in turnout to the larger Republican field, which had 12 candidates in Iowa compared to the Democrats' three. In Super Tuesday races, Republicans had five candidates, while the Democrats were down to two: Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders.

White House Press Secretary Josh Earnest noted that when the votes were tallied in states such as Virginia, Hillary Clinton ended up with more support in her two-person race than any of the five Republican candidates did. He suggested that this indicates ample enthusiasm on the Democratic side, particularly in key general election states.

Republican leaders are optimistic about the overall turnout in Virginia, as it could indicate a potential recapture of the state, which President Obama won in 2008 and 2012. John Findlay, executive director of the Virginia Republican Party, stated, "Nearly 240,000 more voters chose to cast a ballot for Republican candidates versus Hillary or Bernie."

The White House, however, suggests that some of the massive Republican turnout is due to hostility toward Donald Trump, implying that he could be a drag on the party if he is the nominee in November. Some voters, like Cori DeFrancis, a 61-year-old consignment shop owner in Atlanta, are searching for an anti-Trump strategy. Ms. DeFrancis supported Sen. Marco Rubio in the Republican primary because she thought he had the best chance of beating Mr. Trump.

Despite concerns about Mr. Trump's brash comments and stance on immigration, he has won Hispanic voters at nearly the same rate as his overall vote total in states with sizable Hispanic populations, such as Nevada and Texas. Mr. Trump's coalition hits the Republican sweet spot, with his strongest support coming from voters who identify as "somewhat conservative," while holding his own among very conservative and moderate voters.

Title: Wisconsin Recall Election: Collective Bargaining Issue Sidelined in Governor Race

Article:

In the upcoming June 5 recall election for Wisconsin's governorship, the contentious issue of collective bargaining rights, which sparked significant protests and a national debate in 2011, has taken a back seat in the campaign. The Democratic candidate, Milwaukee Mayor Tom Barrett, has minimized the issue in speeches, advertisements, and debates, focusing instead on the tactics of incumbent Governor Scott Walker.

During the second televised debate, Barrett acknowledged that he was not the preferred candidate of public unions, a fact he wore as a badge of honor. Barrett defeated the labor movement's preferred candidate, former Dane County Executive Kathleen Falk, in the May primary. Fak had pledged to veto the next state budget unless it restored public employees' collective-bargaining rights. Barrett refused to commit to such a maneuver, although he supports restoring collective-bargaining rights using other tactics.

The decision to downplay the collective-bargaining issue allows Barrett to distance himself from allegations that he is acting on behalf of organized labor and may attract independent voters who are not favorable towards unions. However, this strategy may harm him and other Democrats in their final push to mobilize voters, as the issue could be crucial in a race that might hinge on turnout.

Republican National Committee Chairman Reince Priebus criticized the Democrats for their lack of focus on collective bargaining, calling it a "dead dog loser" for the left. Instead of attacking Walker on labor rights, Barrett has been campaigning on ethical questions surrounding a John Doe criminal probe that has led to the indictment of several former Walker aides. He has also accused the governor of using deceptive political tactics and courting the tea party. Barrett's recent advertisements have focused on the John Doe investigation and job creation.

Title: White House Response to Mass Shootings: Las Vegas and New York City

Article:

In two separate incidents in October 2017, a gunman in Las Vegas and an immigrant from Uzbekistan in New York City caused mass casualties, resulting in 58 deaths in Las Vegas and eight in New York City. The White House's response to these events, particularly in terms of policy discussions, varied significantly.

Following the Las Vegas shooting on October 1, White House Press Secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders stated that the event was a time for consoling the survivors and mourning the deceased. When asked about pursuing tighter gun laws, Sanders emphasized that it was not the appropriate time for political debate but rather a time for national unity. An open and ongoing law enforcement investigation was ongoing, and a motive for the shooting was yet to be determined, making it premature to discuss policy changes.

In contrast, the response to the New York City incident on October 31 was markedly different. On that day, Donald Trump tweeted about ISIS before offering thoughts, condolences, and prayers. He then called for strengthening the already existing Extreme Vetting Program, citing the need to be politically correct but not for this situation.

When asked if the New York City incident was a time when the discussion should not be political but rather a policy discussion, Sanders responded that the day was one of reflection, mourning, and gratitude for those who were saved. She indicated that there would be time for policy discussions in the future but not at that moment.

Interestingly, just a day after the Las Vegas shooting, which resulted in 58 deaths, the White House was focused on mourning and unity, while on November 1, Trump was attacking Sen. Chuck Schumer for sponsoring a bipartisan immigration plan in 1990 and calling for a change to immigration policy. This shift in tone and focus occurred just one day after the New York City incident.

Title: Republican Lawmakers Hesitant to Endorse Trump and Carson Amidst Questions of Electability

Article:

Republican presidential front-runners Donald Trump and Ben Carson have yet to receive endorsements from Capitol Hill lawmakers despite their agendas being supported by most members and popular with voters back home. The hesitation to endorse the two outsider candidates at the front of the race has affected Republican lawmakers of all stripes, from establishment stalwarts to renegade tea partyers.

When pressed about the lack of endorsements, most lawmakers cited it being too early or having too many candidates to choose from, not that Mr. Trump and Mr. Carson are too far outside the mainstream to risk associating themselves with them. However, some Republicans have openly questioned Mr. Trump's ability to reach the White House or perform the job if elected.

Rep. Trent Franks, Arizona Republican and member of the conservative Freedom Caucus that helped force out former Speaker John A. Boehner, stated, "I think Mr. Trump would be hard to elect." Franks, who has endorsed former Arkansas Gov. Mike Huckabee for the Republican presidential nomination, pledged to support Mr. Trump if he wins the nomination.

Rep. John Fleming, another Freedom Caucus member, expressed a concern shared privately by most lawmakers: he doesn't fully trust Mr. Trump. "He uses a lot of broad statements in the way that Barack Obama did, and these things can become fill-in-the-blanks. In other words, you hear what you want to hear, and then you get a surprise down the road," the Louisiana Republican said.

"We just have to be careful. I want to know more about what does Donald Trump want to do with our foreign policy, other than saying that he is a tough negotiator against China and other places. I want to actually know what he intends to do in Afghanistan and Iraq and places like that. I really don't know what he intends to do," he said.

Lawmakers generally handled the affable Mr. Carson more gently. Rep. Peter T. King, New York Republican, said Mr. Trump and Mr. Carson still must "prove themselves" to win more support from elected leaders. "Trump and Carson have to show they know what the job is about, not just be media stars," he said.

Doug Heye, a Washington-based Republican political consultant, said that electability is a major reason lawmakers are not jumping on the Trump or Carson bandwagons—nobody wants to end up behind a loser. "Every historical pattern we know tells us that Trump and Carson are unlikely to win the nomination. That may end up not being the case, but it explains why members have not endorsed," said Heye, who served as a top adviser to former House Majority Leader Eric Cantor and Republican National Committee Chairman Michael S. Steele.

The Carson campaign stated that the retired neurosurgeon deliberately has not solicited endorsements from a single governor, senator, or congressman. "Political endorsements will come in due time. They are not a priority for our campaign attention," said Carson campaign spokesman Doug Watts.

For Mr. Trump, the dearth of endorsements contrasts with his strong push to crack down on illegal immigration and negotiate tougher trade deals with China and other trading partners—stances backed by conservative Republicans in Congress.

Sen. Jeff Sessions, Alabama Republican, has never endorsed a candidate in a presidential primary, but he said that could change. And he disagreed that his colleagues were afraid to endorse Mr. Trump or Mr. Carson. "Most people are a little slow to endorse. We don't have many endorsements for any candidate," he said.

Other GOP contenders have managed to pick up endorsements on Capitol Hill, arguably regardless of their overall electability. Former Hewlett-Packard CEO Carly Fiorina was endorsed by three House members; Mr. Huckabee has received endorsements from two senators and four congressmen; Mr. Rubio got two senators and eight House members; and Mr. Cruz was endorsed by seven House members.

Sen. Rand Paul was endorsed by eight congressmen and Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, a fellow Kentuckian whom Mr. Paul backed in a tough 2014 reelection race. Jeb Bush collected the most endorsements in Congress: three current senators and 23 current House members.

"There's a profound long-term loyalty to the Bushes," said Rep. Kenny Marchant, Texas Republican. He said that many lawmakers could be withholding endorsements from Mr. Trump and Mr. Carson in deference to the Bush family and former Presidents George H.W. Bush and George W. Bush.

Under that scenario, they would begin to flock to one of the front-runners if Jeb Bush drops out of the race. Lingering policy questions and doubts about electability haven't deterred voters who consistently boost Mr. Trump and Mr. Carson to the top of the polls.

Mr. Trump and Mr. Carson were neck and neck at 24 percent and 23 percent, respectively, in a nationwide poll of likely GOP voters that Quinnipiac University released Wednesday. The next-closest candidates were Mr. Rubio with 14 percent, Sen. Ted Cruz of Texas with 13 percent, and former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush with 8 percent, according to the poll.

Rep. Alexander X. Mooney, a first-term West Virginia Republican, said he hadn't endorsed anyone because he is torn between several candidates with whom he has relationships. In a tough seven-way primary election that Mr. Mooney won in 2014, he had Mr. Huckabee campaign for him, former Pennsylvania Sen. Rick Santorum helped his campaign, and Mr. Trump sent him an unsolicited $1,000 check.

"I think part of it is who do you have relationships with. What members of Congress know Ben Carson or Donald Trump personally?" he asked. "There is a reluctance, but, on the other hand, if some of these candidates falter—look at Scott Walker. He went from No. 1 to No. 9 in Iowa and dropped out, " he said. "What's the hurry? Let's let it shake out."

Title: Frustration Mounts Over Lack of Details on Immigration Detainee Release

Article:

State and federal authorities are expressing frustration over the lack of specific details from the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) regarding the release of immigration detainees in preparation for today's sequester. The Department of Homeland Security's response to the announcement that illegal immigrants would be freed from detention centers to save money is only that "hundreds have been released across the country." Lawmakers and local officials in border states are seeking answers about the number of detainees released, the involved detention centers, and the cost savings goal.

Rep. Mike McCaul, who chairs the House Committee on Homeland Security, has demanded answers from ICE Director John Morton by March 6. In a letter to Morton, McCaul expressed concern that the releases were undertaken without notification to the appropriate Congressional oversight committees.

Pinal County, Arizona, Sheriff Paul Babeu also demanded answers from DHS Secretary Janet Napolitano, stating that he was inexplicably kept out of the loop despite being the top law enforcement official in the county where the releases occurred. El Paso and San Diego, both highly active border regions, were informed by ICE officials ahead of the releases.

El Paso Sheriff Richard Wiles said his agency was informed by ICE of their plans, but still did not know how many detainees have been released this week. San Diego County Sheriff William Gore was also made aware of ICE's plans and expressed no concerns over the move.

A forewarning of the current release policy emerged from a letter Napolitano sent to Sen. Barbara Mikulski, D-Md., chairwoman of the Committee on Appropriations, on Jan. 31. In the letter, Napolitano stated that U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) would not be able to sustain current detention and removal operations or maintain the 34,000 detention beds mandated by Congress. This would significantly roll back progress that resulted in record-high removals.

There is also concern about the prospect of cutbacks in Border Patrol agents along the border, which could affect progress made in recent years. Napolitano told Mikulski that U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) would not be able to maintain current staffing levels of Border Patrol Agents and CBP Officers as mandated by Congress. This could increase wait times at airports, affect security between land ports of entry, affect CBP's ability to collect revenue owed to the Federal Government, and slow screening and entry programs for those traveling into the United States.

A freshman Congressman who knows the U.S.-Mexico border firsthand says the recent decision by the Department of Homeland Security to release low-risk detainees may actually be a solution to a festering problem. Rep. Beto O'Rourke (D-Texas) of El Paso, Texas, who sits on the House Committee on Homeland Security with McCaul, told FoxNews.com that there is bi-partisan agreement that there are too many people being detained in ICE facilities that do not belong there. O'Rourke stated that the decision this week by Napolitano to release low-risk detainees as a cost-saving measure may actually be a harbinger for where the federal immigration policy should be heading.

"The detention centers are a horribly broken element of our immigration policy," O'Rourke said. "These people being released are not serious criminals and do not pose a threat to the United States."

Title: Obama's Health Care Reform and the Supreme Court Ruling

Article:

In the aftermath of the Supreme Court's ruling on the Affordable Care Act, also known as "Obamacare," President Barack Obama and his advisers are grappling with the potential loss of the law's universal coverage provision. According to Robert Dallek, a presidential historian, if Obama loses both his legal challenge and his re-election, many will conclude that he "bet on his major reform, and the Supreme Court defeated it, and he lost his hold on the presidency."

During the court's deliberation, Obama and his advisers have moved from denial to a surprising new state, which might be called "Living Without Universal Coverage." Former advisers are emphasizing the law's other aspects, such as subsidies to buy insurance, and some aides argue that losing the mandate could be a political boon, as it would remove Republicans' core complaint against the law.

However, this position is uncomfortable for a deeper reason, one that goes to the core of who Obama wanted to be as president. Earlier in his term, he refused every chance to settle for a more limited health care overhaul, making epic sacrifices to win something far broader.

Before becoming president, critics said that Obama's greatest achievement was his own rise, that he played it safe rather than taking risks for what he really believed. Early in the presidential race, Obama sought advice from historian Doris Kearns Goodwin about Abraham Lincoln, already talking about leaving a legacy and accomplishing vast things.

In the White House, many of his top advisers, including Vice President Joe Biden and his first chief of staff, Rahm Emanuel, counseled Obama against a sweeping health care overhaul. By summer 2009, with the country still stunned by the economic crisis and Republicans falsely raising the specter of death panels, some aides practically begged the president to scale back, take interim steps, and move on to other issues.

Mr. Obama did not relent. He had an economic rationale for stabilizing a dysfunctional health system, but he also "saw what Teddy called the moral issue," Victoria Reggie Kennedy, Senator Edward M. Kennedy's widow, said in an interview, referring to her husband. For those who wondered what Obama really believed in, universal health coverage seemed to be the answer.

As the brutal fight continued, the president sacrificed more and more in its name: an overhaul of energy and environmental laws, greater focus on economic issues, some of his own popularity, and that of House Democrats, who eventually lost their hard-won majority. "Michelle and I are perfectly comfortable if we're only here one term if we feel like we really accomplished something," he told aides.

That declaration sounds different today. Mitt Romney, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, uses "Obamacare" as an epithet and applause line, promising outright repeal if he wins. A few years ago, the health care law seemed a reason for Mr. Obama to risk losing re-election; now, it is a reason he feels he must win re-election.

As he awaits the decision, Mr. Obama has no more knowledge of or influence on it than any of the other lawyers handicapping the odds in Washington bars and boardrooms. The former law professor turned president is scathing about the argument that the mandate violates the Constitution, saying it has no merit whatsoever.

If the court strikes down the mandate and Mr. Obama wins in November, he could face one last version of his perpetual choice on health care: would he settle, learning to live with a sharply edited law? ( Given that Republicans see the bill as a signature piece of big-government overreach, he might have no choice.) Or would he expend yet more precious capital on health care?

Ezekiel Emanuel, Rahm's brother and a former health adviser to the president, predicted the second path. "Too much of the president's legacy—and the good of the country—is tied up with this," he said. The final result on health care will help determine whether Mr. Obama is the game-changing president he aspired to be.

Title: "Bipartisan 'Gang of Eight' Senators Collaborate on Immigration Reform in Washington"

Article:

A bipartisan group of eight senators, known as the "Gang of Eight," have been meeting in private several times a week, alternating between the offices of Senators John McCain (R-Ariz.) and Charles Schumer (D-N.Y.). The group, which includes Marco Rubio (R-Fla.), Dick Durbin (D-Ill.), Jeff Flake (R-Ariz.), Michael Bennet (D-Colo.), and Robert Menendez (D-N.J.), is working to overhaul the nation's complex immigration laws.

The senators are meeting in a collaborative effort, despite including some of the Senate's most prominent personalities and individuals with political challenges. Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.), who is up for re-election next year and facing a potential GOP primary challenge from the right, described the experience as "one of the best experiences I've had." He added, "It's sort of what I came up here to do -- sit down with serious people to solve serious and hard problems."

The group has been meeting for an hour or an hour-and-a-half on days when the Senate is in session. The meetings are held in a confidential manner, with no reporters present, and aides stand or sit in the background. The senators are assiduous about avoiding leaks and are tight-lipped on the details of their discussions.

The legislation the group is working on aims to secure the border, provide a pathway to citizenship for the estimated 11 million illegal immigrants currently in the country, contingent on a secure border first, crack down on employers, and improve legal immigration. Senators have indicated some consensus on elements related to border security and the path to citizenship. However, they are struggling on the question of legal immigration and future workers, and are trading proposals with leaders of the AFL-CIO and Chamber of Commerce to try to reach a deal.

The senators have been working toward a self-imposed March deadline to release their legislation, although it now seems that might slip until they return from a two-week recess the second week of April. They would aim for a vote in the Judiciary Committee soon thereafter, then consideration by the full Senate and from there, the House. Success is far from assured, and the process could fail at any point.

The group came together when Graham phoned Schumer the weekend after the November election. The resounding victory among Latino voters had just sealed Obama's win and underscored to Republicans like McCain and Graham that the GOP needed to act on immigration. Schumer, McCain, and Graham are veterans of past failed attempts on the issue, most prominently in 2007 when legislation backed by then-President George W. Bush failed on the Senate floor.

Schumer later recounted that Graham said, "The band is back, let's do immigration," and told him McCain was on board. "And my heart went pitter patter," Schumer said in telling the anecdote at a breakfast hosted by Politico in January. The senators worked to round up others, with Flake saying Schumer approached him during Congress's lame-duck session. "I said I just always wanted to be part of a gang. I grew up in Snowflake, Ariz., the South side didn't offer much," Flake said. Rubio had been shopping his own immigration proposals that dovetailed with what the senators were working on.

The Gang of Eight began working on drafting principles. They were forced to speed up their timetable when they learned Obama planned to announce his own proposals and they rolled out their blueprint at a packed news conference at the Capitol on Jan. 28. Since then, they've had little to say publicly as they work toward releasing their bill, except to voice cautious optimism that this time they will finally succeed in solving a problem that has bedeviled Washington for decades. "Everybody there wants to get it done and nobody's looking for political points or political advantage," Flake said. "Everybody's looking to get it done, and that makes all the difference."

Title: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo Meets Taliban Officials in Qatar to Discuss Compliance with US-Taliban Agreement

Article:

U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo is meeting Taliban officials in Doha, Qatar, on Monday as part of efforts to salvage a historic deal signed with the armed group in February. The highest-level talks ever between the United States and the Taliban, as described by the U.S. State Department, aim to press the Taliban to continue complying with the agreement.
