According to State Department spokeswoman Morgan Ortagus, Secretary Pompeo will meet with Taliban chief negotiator Mullah Baradar to discuss the agreement signed last month. The meeting is set to take place at Qatar's Al Udeid Air Base, which has served as the host for a year of talks between the United States and the Taliban.

Prior to his meeting with Taliban officials, Pompeo met Afghan President Ashraf Ghani and his longtime rival Abdullah Abdullah in Kabul. Their standoff has stalled the selection of a negotiating team to represent the Afghan government in planned talks with the Taliban.

The U.S.-Taliban agreement, signed in Qatar on February 29, includes a provision for organizing talks between the Afghan leadership and the Taliban to achieve lasting peace in the war-torn country. Formal talks have not yet begun, hampered by disagreement over the release of prisoners, a condition set by the Taliban, and the feud between Ghani and Abdullah.

The February deal also calls for the gradual withdrawal of U.S. and other foreign troops over a 14-month period, with the main focus of U.S. diplomatic efforts being the withdrawal. The first phase of that withdrawal has already begun, though some troop movements have been slowed by the coronavirus pandemic.

In exchange, the Taliban committed not to allow Afghan soil to be used against American security interests and promised to negotiate for the first time with the West-backed Kabul leadership. However, since the Doha agreement was signed, the Taliban have continued to carry out attacks.

Pompeo's visit comes at a time when much global travel has been stalled by the coronavirus pandemic, which has infected over 360,000 and killed more than 15,000 globally. The Taliban and the Afghan government held a "virtual" meeting on prisoner releases on Sunday, officials said.

Title: Donald Trump Threatens Legal Action Against The New York Times, Criticizes Columnist Maureen Dowd

Article:

In a series of tweets on September 17, 2016, Donald Trump, the then-presidential candidate, threatened to sue The New York Times and criticized columnist Maureen Dowd. Trump's tweets followed Dowd's interview on CNN, where she was promoting her new book, "The Year of Voting Dangerously."

Trump tweeted, "My lawyers want to sue the failing @nytimes so badly for irresponsible intent. I said no (for now), but they are watching. Really disgusting." He further stated, "The failing @nytimes has gone nuts that Crooked Hillary is doing so badly. They are willing to say anything."

In another tweet, Trump lacerated Dowd, deriding her as "crazy," "wacky," and "a neurotic dope." He also tweeted that the columnist "hardly knows me," but "makes up things that I never said for her boring interviews and column."

During her interview on CNN, Dowd stated, "I told him that it was wrong that there was violence being incited at his rallies and that reporters were getting roughed up." She added, "And he paused — you're right, he did listen — but then he disagreed and said he thought the violence added a frisson of excitement."

The tweets from Trump and the interview with Dowd on CNN were unavailable for independent verification at the time of this report.

Title: Hillary Clinton Suggests Possibility of Challenging Trump in 2020 Election

Article:

Former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, in a joking manner, suggested on Tuesday that she could potentially run against President Donald Trump in the 2020 presidential election. During an interview with PBS Newshour host Judy Woodruff, Clinton stated, "Maybe there does need to be a rematch. I mean, obviously I can beat him again."

The comment came in response to President Trump's suggestion that Clinton should enter the race to "steal it away from Uber Left Elizabeth Warren." Trump added, "Only one condition, The Crooked one must explain all of her high crimes and misdemeanors including how & why she deleted 33,000 Emails AFTER getting “ C” Subpoena!"

Clinton responded, "Do your job," and in a tweet, she said, "Don’t tempt me. Do your job."

During the interview, Clinton commented on the exchange, stating, "Nothing has been more examined and looked at than my emails. We all know that. He’s either lying or delusional or both... But, seriously, I don’t understand, I don’t think anyone understands, what motivates him other than personal grievance, other than seeking adulation."

Clinton also expressed her confusion about Trump's behavior, stating, "I said during the campaign, there was no other Donald Trump. What you saw was what you were going to get. And I think a lot of Americans understandably thought, oh, no, that can’t possibly be the case. Once he’s in office, he will certainly moderate his behavior. Well, we see, no, he hasn’t."

Clinton has previously stated that she has no plans to run in the 2020 election, but her latest tweet has not helped quell the speculation about her potential entry into the race.

Title: Trump Administration Officials Criticize 'Sanctuary City' Policies, Threaten Legal Action Against California

Article:

Secretary of Homeland Security John Kelly, Attorney General Jeff Sessions, and Sen. Ron Johnson (R-WI) concluded a two-day visit to the U.S.-Mexico border on Friday with a press briefing, emphasizing the Trump administration's commitment to border security and immigration enforcement. The officials stood on an access road on the U.S. side of the border and criticized jurisdictions labeled as'sanctuary cities,' including California.

Secretary Kelly reaffirmed the administration's commitment to a "physical barrier" along the southern border and the importance of stopping human trafficking. He cited drastic reductions in the number of illegal border crossings, which he attributed to the Trump administration's focus on border security and immigration law enforcement.

Attorney General Sessions spoke about the progress made by the Trump administration and warned about the danger of infiltration by gangs like MS-13. He also launched a broadside against sanctuary cities, citing the case of Kate Steinle, an American woman who was shot and killed in San Francisco by an illegal immigrant with seven prior felony convictions who had been deported five times. Sessions accused the city of releasing the shooter from custody despite a federal immigration authorities' detainer request.

Sessions threatened legal action against nine jurisdictions, including California, that have policies potentially violating federal law and receive millions in federal grants. The California State Senate recently passed a "sanctuary state" bill, SB 54, which awaits passage by the State Assembly before proceeding to Governor Jerry Brown's desk.

Johnson, who serves as Chairman of the Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs, praised the Trump administration's support for border patrol and law enforcement. He rejected the argument by sanctuary cities that enforcing immigration law would hurt local policing, describing it as more of an "excuse" than a reason.

Outside the event, about a dozen demonstrators from the Remembrance Project, which commemorates victims killed by illegal aliens, gathered to support the Trump administration's efforts. Vaught Becht of Orange County gave the administration an "A-plus" for its work on immigration and border security thus far.

Title: 7.1-Magnitude Earthquake Strikes Southern California, Causing Damage and Evacuations

Article:

A 7.1-magnitude earthquake hit the town of Ridgecrest, California, on Friday night, marking the second significant earthquake to occur in the area in less than two days. The earthquake, centered 11 miles northeast of Ridgecrest, released 11 times the amount of energy of Thursday's quake, according to CNN Meteorologist Brandon Miller.

The earthquake caused infrastructure damage, cracked streets, and foundation issues in Southern California, sending terrified residents into the streets. Ridgecrest resident Jaye Krona described the earthquake as her "rocking chair gone crazy."

Jason Corona, who co-owns a Mexican restaurant in Ridgecrest, was present during the earthquake. He stated that the quake felt different from previous ones, with bottles falling behind the bar, patrons dropping to the floor, and spilled food making a slippery getaway for frightened guests who sprinted outside.

Since Friday's quake, the region has experienced an average of one aftershock per minute, according to the US Geological Survey (USGS) website. More than 4,700 quakes have occurred since Thursday, said USGS geophysicist John Bellini.

Gas leaks caused structure fires throughout Ridgecrest, residents reported water main breaks, and power and communications were out in some areas, according to Mark Ghilarducci, director of the Governor's Office of Emergency Management. Several injuries were reported, and Kern County Fire Chief David Witt stated that he knew of no fatalities.

In the aftermath of the earthquake, about 130 residents from Bakersfield and Trona were staying in a temporary shelter. Governor Gavin Newsom declared a state of emergency in Kern County on Thursday and in San Bernardino late Friday. Newsom also requested a presidential emergency declaration for assistance, which President Donald Trump approved on Saturday.

Naval Air Weapons Station China Lake, a US weapons testing facility near Ridgecrest, sustained infrastructure damage as a result of the earthquakes on Thursday and Friday. The air station authorized the evacuation of non-essential personnel and dependents.

In the aftermath of the earthquake, there were no major reports of gas leaks or serious injuries in Kern County, but calls came in for ambulance and medical assistance. The San Bernardino County Fire Department reported damage from northwest communities, including homes shifting, foundation cracks, retaining walls down, and one minor injury.

Trona, a town of 2,000 people, does not have power or water, according to San Bernardino County Fire spokesman Jeremy Kern. Both earthquakes disrupted the main water system, and officials are bringing in water to residents and fire teams.

There were two reports of burglary in Ridgecrest, police chief Jed McLaughlin said. In Los Angeles, about 150 miles south of Ridgecrest, residents felt the quakes, but no reports of serious damage were made, according to Mayor Eric Garcetti. The LA County Fire Department reported no major damage, deaths, or serious injuries, but said some wires were down, and power was out in some locations.

The USGS stated that the chance of another magnitude 7 or higher earthquake is 3%, while the chance of a magnitude 3 or higher earthquake hitting the area is more than 99%.

Title: U.S. Secretary of State Pompeo Maintains Pressure on Venezuela, Military Intervention Not Excluded

Article:

Secretary of State Mike Pompeo has urged the Venezuelan government led by President Nicolás Maduro to relent in the face of escalating unrest in the country, stating that all options, including military intervention, remain on the table. In an interview on Fox News Sunday, Pompeo said, "Every option is on the table." He further added that the U.S. is committed to ensuring the voice of the Venezuelan people is heard, democracy prevails, and a brighter future is secured for the people of Venezuela.

The unrest in Venezuela intensified after troops loyal to Maduro obstructed a U.S.-backed effort to deliver foreign aid, resulting in violence along the country's border with Colombia. The troops targeted protesters aligned with opposition leader Juan Guaidó, causing several deaths and hundreds of injuries through the use of tear gas.

The Trump administration, along with several European nations, has supported Guaidó since he declared himself interim president last month. In an effort to appeal to a bloc of Venezuelan-American voters who have fled to Florida due to economic instability in their home country, President Trump held a rally in Miami last week to denounce Maduro and socialism.

Several Democratic presidential candidates have also called on Maduro to cease violence against his own citizens, going as far as labeling Maduro a dictator.

Pompeo confirmed that the U.S. will continue to provide humanitarian assistance to the Venezuelan people and hold Maduro accountable. In a separate interview on CNN's State of the Union, Pompeo stated, "There's more sanctions to be had. More humanitarian assistance that we can provide." He further added, "The Venezuelan people will ultimately, I believe, hold accountable those who have done so much harm to the fundamental, basic rights of the people of Venezuela."

Title: U.S. Increases Special Operations Forces in Syria to Combat Islamic State

Article:

President Obama's announcement on Monday that 250 Special Operations Forces will be deployed to Syria indicates a potential shift in the U.S.'s approach to combating the Islamic State. The move follows the deployment of 50 special operators to Syria last fall as a trial run to assess the effectiveness of U.S. training for Kurdish fighters and Arab Sunnis on the ground.

According to Melissa Dalton, a former intelligence analyst for the Defense Intelligence Agency, the initial deployment aimed to determine if the U.S. could use training to gain traction with local forces. On Monday, Obama stated that the expertise of the Special Operations Forces already in Syria has been crucial in driving Islamic State forces out of key areas.

The decision to increase the number of Special Operations Forces in Syria appears to be an attempt to accelerate the process. As Dalton notes, "there’s been some positive momentum built up, with the idea now being, ‘OK, if we expand that out a bit further – multiply the amount of trainers in the country – then perhaps we can multiply the effects.'"

However, questions remain. With a diplomatic cease-fire faltering, the U.S. seems to be focusing more on a military strategy, despite failing to define a clear end state. Dalton questions, "Where are we building to? Is this the first of many incremental increases – and to what end?"

Some argue that building out the program incrementally makes sense. Nicholas Heras, a Middle East analyst at the Center for a New American Security, states, "incrementalism is the right approach." He believes that the U.S. can empower anti-Islamic State forces in a proven way without becoming embroiled in a Middle East war.

The increased deployment mirrors another decision made last week, with more U.S. troops heading to Iraq in expanded roles. Defense Secretary Ash Carter described these roles as bringing U.S. troops "closer to the action." With Obama expressing a desire to keep the U.S. out of another war in the Middle East, the increase in Syria from 50 to 300 Special Operations Forces is seen as a relatively low-risk move.

In the past, the U.S. has made more grandiose efforts at fighting the Islamic State. Before the U.S. sent over its 50 special operators last fall, it attempted a $500 million effort to train Syrian anti-ISIS forces. However, the result was only "four or five" fighters on the battlefield, according to Gen. Lloyd Austin.

Despite the limited results, the Syrian rebels in the program were reportedly receiving "terrific training," according to Christine Wormuth, the Pentagon's policy chief. The answer was to pivot to the 50 special operators, who have worked on refining their message to potential recruits.

The trainers have also had some success in expanding the number of Syrian Arabs within the Syrian Democratic Forces, according to Heras. This is important in building trust among anti-ISIS forces, as Kurds have been the U.S. forces' most reliable partners, but Syrian Arabs distrust them.

A greater ethnic mix of forces battling ISIS could help in the long run. If these troops can ultimately take back control of their hometowns, they must find a way to live together and govern – a more challenging proposition than winning on the battlefield.

Title: U.S. Senator Jeff Flake Compares President Trump's Media Criticism to Joseph Stalin's Propaganda

Article:

U.S. Senator Jeff Flake (R-AZ) has compared President Donald J. Trump's criticism of the media to the totalitarian dictator Joseph Stalin's propaganda during an interview on ABC News' "This Week."

During a discussion about a series of speeches the soon-to-be-retired Senator will be delivering over the next few weeks, host George Stephanopoulos read an excerpt from one of the speeches.

Stephanopoulos: "We've gotten some excerpts of what you're planning to say, taking on the president's comments about calling the press the enemy of the people. And I just want to read a portion of what we've had. It's a testament to the condition of our democracy that our own president uses words infamously spoken by Joseph Stalin to describe his enemies. It bears noting that so fraught with malice was the phrase 'enemy of the people' that even Nikita Khrushchev forbade its use. And of course, the president has it precisely backward. Despotism is the enemy of the people, the free press is the despot's enemy."

Flake: "Well, what I'm trying to say is, you know, you—you can talk about crowd size and this is pretty innocuous if there's a falsehood. But when you reflexively refer to the press as the enemy of the people or fake news, that has real damage. It has real damage to our standing in the world. And I noted how—how bad it is for a president to—to take what was popularized by Joseph Stalin, the enemy of the people, to refer to the press. And then now, today, you have authoritarians across the world using the term 'fake news' to justify cracking down on their opposition or—or stanch legitimate debate. That's nothing we should be proud of. And so I'm going to talk about how damaging that is. It'll be I think on the same day, probably, Wednesday, that the president is giving out some fake news awards."

According to Cortney, Flake's disdain, put mildly, for Donald Trump is well-documented. Previously on "This Week," Flake has attacked Trump supporters as angry and resentful. The hostility between Flake and Trump started when the discovery of Flake's "secret" book, "Conscience of a Conservative: A Rejection of Destructive Politics and a Return to Principle," in which he criticized Trump's agenda, was made public. Trump mocked the senator at a rally in Phoenix following the discovery.

Title: The Spread of Misinformation in Family Group Chats: A Sociological Perspective

Article:

In times of crisis, people often find solace in sharing information with their family members. During periods of high uncertainty, group discussions can provide a sense of understanding and control over the situation. However, a study by sociologist Emma Spiro, as reported in Science magazine, suggests that these discussions can lead to the dissemination of information that appeals to individuals rather than facts.

Cailin O' Connor, an associate professor of philosophy at UC Irvine, explains that people are more likely to believe misinformation when it comes from those with whom they have close ties. The degree of social and cultural similarity between individuals plays a significant role in the trust placed in the information shared. O' Connor states, "The closer you perceive yourself to [be to] someone... the more you trust the information they're sharing." This dynamic is particularly prevalent in family group chats.

A 2019 study in Science Advances found that people from older generations tend to share misinformation nearly seven times more frequently than younger family members, even when factors such as education and partisan affiliation were taken into account. This trend may be exacerbated in family group chats, as many members may be less familiar with social media and less adept at filtering out misinformation.

Despite recognizing the misinformation shared by family members, addressing it can be challenging due to the close bonds between individuals. A 2019 study found that only 21% of people surveyed in the U.K. reported correcting others who shared false or inaccurate information. O' Connor suggests that this number is likely to be even smaller in family group chats due to the discomfort of disagreeing with loved ones. O' Connor states, "Within families, it can be a powerful force. When someone is saying, ‘Oh, I believe X,’ it pushes others just to accept it rather than to say, ‘Well, you’re wrong about X.’"

In the context of the "Plandemic" video, the article does not provide specific guidance on how to respond. However, the information presented highlights the importance of critical thinking and fact-checking when sharing or receiving information, especially within close-knit family groups.

Title: Atlanta Police Officers Charged in Shooting Death of Rayshard Brooks

Article:

In a news conference on Wednesday, Fulton County District Attorney Paul Howard announced the criminal charges against the officers involved in the shooting death of Rayshard Brooks in Atlanta. Former Atlanta Police Department Officer Garrett Rolfe, who fired the fatal shots, is being charged with felony murder, and former Officer Devin Brosnan, who was also present during the altercation, will be charged with aggravated assault.

The incident occurred on June 12, when officers engaged Rayshard Brooks, 27, who was asleep in the drive-thru of a Wendy's restaurant. The officers woke Brooks, instructed him to park the car in the Wendy's lot, and, after confirming he was not armed, conducted a pat-down search. Brooks was found to be over the legal limit following a breathalyzer test and a field sobriety test.

Brooks cooperated up to this point but attempted to escape when the officers were putting him in handcuffs. A physical altercation ensued, during which both officers attempted to wrestle Brooks to the ground. Brosnan pulled out his Taser, which Brooks was able to take from his hand during the fight. Brooks escaped the officers and took off running with the Taser.

Rolfe pulled out his own stun gun and attempted to stun Brooks, but was apparently unsuccessful. Surveillance footage shows Brooks apparently pointing the Taser at the officers pursuing him, and three shots were fired, with Brooks being shot twice in the back.

Rolfe was fired from the department, and Brosnan was placed on administrative leave. Police Chief Erika Shields resigned from her position after 25 years of service with the department. The Wendy's restaurant, where the shooting occurred, was set on fire in subsequent protests.

During the news conference, District Attorney Paul Howard described Brooks as "calm" and "cordial" during the conversation with officers before the shooting, and that he displayed a "cooperative nature" and "almost jovial" demeanor, despite being "slightly impaired." Howard also stated that the officers' demeanor after the shooting, which included Rolfe kicking Brooks' body, did not reflect any fear or danger from Brooks, but rather "other kinds of emotions."

Title: Yovanovitch Testifies: "Devastated" Over Trump-Zelensky Call Mention

In a hearing on Friday, Marie Yovanovitch, the former U.S. Ambassador to Ukraine, testified that she felt threatened when President Donald Trump brought up her service in Ukraine during a call with President Volodymyr Zelensky. Yovanovitch, who was removed from her post in May, expressed shock and devastation during her testimony before the House Intelligence Committee.

Adam Schiff, the committee's chairman, described the moment as "dramatic," stating, "This wasn’t just testimony about the past, this played out in real time with the president attacking her." He further noted that Yovanovitch's testimony raised the possibility of witness intimidation as a new charge in the ongoing impeachment inquiry.

During the hearing, Yovanovitch testified that Trump's tweet, in which he asserted that she had performed poorly during her career as a U.S. ambassador, was particularly unsettling. Trump's tweet, sent during Yovanovitch's public testimony, claimed that Yovanovitch's assignments had resulted in negative outcomes, citing her initial posting in Somalia and her service in Ukraine.

The impeachment proceedings are set to continue into the afternoon, with major broadcast networks and cable news channels, including ABC, CBS, NBC, CNN, Fox News, C-SPAN, and PBS, pre-empting regular programming to cover the historic event.

Title: Acting Defense Secretary Shanahan Holds Final Decision on $3.6 Billion for Border Wall, Vows to Protect Military Housing Funds

Article:

Acting Defense Secretary Patrick M. Shanahan has stated that he will make the final call on $3.6 billion in military construction funds that President Trump wants to allocate for the construction of a border wall. Shanahan, who took over the position in January, expressed that he has significant discretion in the matter and is not required to use the funds.

The Pentagon chief, who has been thrust into a politically charged battle between border security and military spending, has not committed to providing the full $3.6 billion requested by the White House under the president's national emergency declaration. Upgrades to a U.S. military hospital in Germany, dock repairs at Pearl Harbor, and maintenance at other bases across the country and across all branches of the armed forces could have their funding slashed or eliminated entirely.

White House officials aim to pull approximately $3.6 billion from a pool of roughly $21 billion in unspent military construction funds for the border wall. The remaining $4.4 billion needed for the border barriers will come from funds allocated last week under the bipartisan spending deal, military counternarcotics programs, and a Treasury Department forfeiture program.

Defense Department officials, along with lawmakers of both parties, are resisting the idea of siphoning military construction funds. Shanahan has not committed to the $3.6 billion figure and stated that he needs to review all projects on the table. The Pentagon has a process in place to make decisions regarding the construction budget, and Shanahan emphasized that they do not want to "fumble through" the process.

Shanahan has already ruled out at least one area of the military construction budget: housing for troops and their families. When pressed on the matter, Shanahan offered strong assurances that housing for troops would be protected.

One project reportedly under consideration is a school at Fort Campbell. Lawmakers who support the president's proposed wall and emergency declaration argue that upgrades and operational costs for the school will ultimately be funded, with the students benefiting equally from a stronger border.

Similar projects, such as a child development center at Joint Base Andrews in Maryland, are also reportedly under review. The money at issue comes from "unobligated" funds in defense budgets over the past five years, which have been designated for specific military projects but have yet to have contracts signed or construction or repairs initiated.

While Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-SC) defended the president's strategy, other Republicans argued that their party has spent the past two years fighting for more money for the military. Pulling money from the military budget, they said, would be a mistake and could hurt the readiness and training of American troops.

With the exception of Sen. Lindsey Graham, most Republicans seemed reluctant to defend pulling money from specific military projects even as they backed Mr. Trump's broader goal. The political implications of the situation remain to be seen, as Democrats are using the potential loss of military projects as a means to drive a wedge between the president and Republicans on Capitol Hill.

Title: Democratic Party Faces Ongoing Controversy Over Anti-Semitism Allegations

Article:

The Democratic Party is currently grappling with allegations of anti-Semitism, as freshman Congresswoman Ilhan Omar's comments have sparked controversy and caused leadership headaches. The latest charges of anti-Semitism come amidst a divide within the party over support for Israel.

Rep. Ilhan Omar (D-MN) stated, "I want to talk about the political influence in this country that says it is okay for people to push allegiance to a foreign country," which some interpreted as a centuries-old smear against Israel supporters. This comment led to accusations of anti-Semitism from members of her own party.

Former Sen. Joe Lieberman (D-CT) commented, "Words matter, and when people say words that are biased, bigoted, and hurtful to another group of Americans, they have to be condemned quickly."

The House of Representatives is yet to bring a resolution, aimed at addressing anti-Semitism on Capitol Hill, to the floor. The Democratic leadership had initially planned to do so on Wednesday, but the resolution has been delayed. The resolution is intended as a rebuke of Rep. Omar, who is facing another backlash over anti-Semitic tweets made last weekend.

Kayleigh McEnany, national press secretary for the Trump-Pence reelection campaign, criticized the recurring anti-Semitic remarks by lawmakers like Rep. Omar. McEnany stated, "This is not a one-time thing for Ilhan Omar. There have been multiple remarks. Likewise, we have seen some comments that are similar from Rashida Tlaib and certainly those around her." McEnany suggested that Rep. Omar should be removed from the House Foreign Affairs Committee and that House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-CA) should take action.

There is clear dissension among the Democrats on whether Rep. Omar will be permitted to keep her seat on the House Foreign Affairs Committee. Rep. Pramila Jayapal, the co-chair of the Congressional Progressive Caucus, questioned the need for continuous resolutions addressing the issue, stating, "I'm not sure we need to continue to do this every single time."

Omar, one of two Muslim women in Congress, has declined to apologize for the latest statement. A number of Republican leaders have waded into the controversy, with Rep. Steve Scalise (R-LA) stating, "If they really are serious about addressing the problem, Nancy Pelosi has to remove her from the Foreign Affairs Committee." Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-KY) also commented, "It's unconscionable for any member of the United States Congress, any less a member of the foreign relations committee, to repeatedly traffic in base stereotypes."

Title: Mitt Romney's Shift in Political Stance on Income Inequality Sparks Controversy

Article:

Former Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney's recent advocacy for addressing income inequality has sparked controversy, with critics viewing his sudden change as disingenuous and insincere. Romney, who lost the 2012 presidential election to Barack Obama, has been criticized for his past statements and policies that were perceived as favoring the wealthy.

In a speech on Friday, Romney argued that President Obama's policies have worsened income inequality and increased poverty. He stated, "Under President Obama, the rich have gotten richer, income inequality has gotten worse, and there are more people in poverty than ever before."

However, Romney's critics point to his past statements and policies that were perceived as favoring the wealthy. During the 2012 campaign, Romney made comments such as "corporations are people, my friend," and "I like being able to fire people." He also infamously stated, "I'm not concerned about the very poor."

New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio, who made income inequality the centerpiece of his 2013 mayoral campaign, was astounded by Romney's sudden shift. De Blasio stated, "Doing it in such a ham-handed manner in what appears to be a deathbed conversion is a strange way to suddenly come out of the box with it, and I find it disingenuous, and I think a lot of other people will too."

Stephanie Cutter, Obama's 2012 deputy campaign manager, stated, "A message only works if it's authentic to the messenger. I'm not sure voters will trust that that's the case here."

Romney's advisers have not returned requests for comment regarding the criticism or how he landed on making "American people are struggling to make ends meet" a centerpiece of his official unofficial return.

Democrats have been grappling with the issue of income inequality, with some progressives criticizing President Obama for not being sufficiently committed to addressing the issue. Progressives were upset with Obama for signing off on a change to the Dodd-Frank financial regulation bill sought by banks, and for his nomination of Antonio Weiss, a Wall Street veteran, to a top Treasury Department job.

On Tuesday, President Obama will use his State of the Union address to promote his free community college plan and a series of tax changes that progressives are already embracing as an assault on the "1 percent."

Meanwhile, former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, who is widely expected to run for president in 2016, tweeted on Friday, "Attacking financial reform is risky and wrong. Better for Congress to focus on jobs and wages for middle-class families."

De Blasio believes that Romney's shift towards income inequality shows that the issue has become a defining issue of the 2016 campaign. He stated, "This is on the minds of more and more people around the country, because income inequality is basically the touchstone of what we're dealing with right now. It is very telling that a guy who's trying to find his way back to political relevance will grab onto it."

De Blasio also noted that Romney might be the biggest stretch among the Republicans who could have attached themselves to income inequality. He stated, "It's a fascinating and disingenuous play. But at least it will cause people to talk more about the issues."

Title: Texas Governor Rick Perry Criticizes President Obama's One-Size-Fits-All Approach to Policy Issues

 Article:

 In a recent interview on "Meet the Press," Texas Governor Rick Perry criticized President Barack Obama's approach to policy issues, particularly his implementation of one-size-fits-all solutions. Perry, a Republican, expressed his disapproval of the administration's handling of issues ranging from the death penalty to joblessness.

 Last week's botched execution in Oklahoma, which led to a temporary halt in the process in that state, did not necessarily warrant a nationwide pause, according to Perry. He emphasized that Texas, which has the highest number of executions in the nation with 273 people currently on Death Row, has a different approach to the death penalty compared to other states. Texas uses only one drug for lethal injection, whereas Oklahoma uses a combination of drugs.

 Perry commented on the botched Oklahoma case, stating, "There is an appropriate way to deal with this, and, obviously, something went terribly wrong."

 Moving on to economic matters, Perry highlighted that Texas is not focusing on raising the minimum wage but rather on creating jobs with higher wages. He has been attracting employers from other states to Texas, with 95% of the jobs created in Texas being above minimum wage. Perry argued that the minimum wage discussion is irrelevant when there are no jobs available.

 Perry, who has been traveling the country, also touched upon the theme often repeated by Republicans that minimum-wage jobs are entry-level positions and not intended to support a family.

 Regarding his potential presidential run in 2016, Perry acknowledged the criticism of his 2012 campaign as a failure but expressed the belief that a person's character is more evident when they demonstrate their ability to perform well after a failure.

Title: Democratic Party Faces Internal Divide on Political Identity as Obama's Second Term Concludes

Article:

As President Barack Obama prepares for his second inauguration on Monday, the Democratic Party, which has largely concealed its internal divisions during his tenure due to his commanding popularity, is set to confront a central and unresolved question about its political identity. The question revolves around whether the party will adopt a center-left, Democratic Leadership Council (DLC)-inspired approach or return to a more populist, left-leaning stance that mirrors its electoral coalition.

The entitlement debate, particularly regarding potential Social Security or Medicare benefit cuts for deficit reduction, may provide an immediate answer to this question. "In the short term, that's the flash point," said longtime Democratic consultant Paul Begala.

As moderate Republicans become increasingly scarce, and more centrists find a home in the Democratic coalition, the party must also reconcile its stance on a broader range of economic issues, including Wall Street regulation and public employees' rights. As the 2016 presidential race approaches, and potential candidates begin to maneuver, Democrats must decide whether they want to be identified primarily as the party of Rahm Emanuel or the party of Elizabeth Warren.

"One of the challenges is how we continue to do the right thing while working with a wide coalition of people, both workers and business," said Minnesota Sen. Amy Klobuchar.

For decades, cultural issues divided Democrats internally as they grappled with Republican accusations of extremism on issues such as race, gender, and gay rights. However, due to Bill Clinton's influence and broader cultural shifts in the country, there is now a consensus among Democrats on social issues like abortion rights, same-sex marriage, and immigration reform. While there may be tensions within the party's ranks on Capitol Hill regarding gun control, there is a wide and deep consensus on the issue among the grassroots and in statehouses.

The shift in the party's identity is not so much due to Obama's policy choices as it is the rise of the Obama coalition—a diverse group of youth, minorities, and women. It is unlikely that any serious Democratic White House contender in 2016 would not align with the party on such issues. The Republicans, on the other hand, are now grappling with internal divisions on cultural matters as they strive to appeal to a rapidly changing country.

"The center has moved," said veteran Democratic strategist Mandy Grunwald.

The divide within the Democratic Party primarily revolves around fiscal and class issues, between its populists and its elites, on how to appeal to a broad group of voters while maintaining its commitment to those in need. In essence, the challenge is to represent the interests of its affluent supporters in areas like McLean, Virginia, and Bryn Mawr, Pennsylvania, while staying true to middle-class backers in La Crosse, Wisconsin, and addressing the needs of the poor in Albuquerque and Philadelphia.

"The real struggle within the Democratic Party is where you stand on income inequality and whether the government needs to be a part of fixing that problem," said Rep. Keith Ellison (D-Minn.), co-chairman of the Congressional Progressive Caucus. "The demographics that the Democratic Party must attract are the people who need responsive government."

Title: Harvard University's Admissions Policies Under Scrutiny in Affirmative Action Trial

Article:

In a federal court trial in Boston, Harvard University is defending its admissions policies against allegations of discrimination against Asian-American applicants. The case, brought by Students for Fair Admissions (SFFA), has revealed insights into the Ivy League school's admissions process for the approximately 1,600 students selected annually from about 40,000 applicants.

John Hughes, a lawyer for SFFA, argued that admissions data from Harvard showed a pattern of bias against Asian-Americans, particularly in terms of "personal ratings," a measure of abstract qualities such as leadership skills and friendliness. Hughes stated, "That Asian-Americans get worse personal ratings year after year is pretty strong evidence that racial bias has crept into the system."

Harvard's lawyers conceded that Asian-Americans, on average, received lower personal rating scores in recent years. However, they maintained that this was only one of many factors considered in admissions, and that Asian-Americans, on average, scored higher than other racial groups on some factors.

SFFA's lawyers argued that the plaintiffs had narrowly focused on the personal score to find the "Asian penalty" they were seeking. Seth Waxman, one of Harvard's lawyers, countered this argument. The trial is expected to conclude with a ruling from U.S. District Judge Allison Burroughs between December and March 2019.

Legal experts have suggested that the case could reach the U.S. Supreme Court, potentially allowing the court's conservative majority to bar the use of affirmative action to help minority applicants gain admission to college. In previous rulings on affirmative action, which aims to offset historic patterns of racial discrimination, the Supreme Court has allowed colleges to consider race as one factor among others in assessing applicants.

SFFA alleges that Harvard engaged in "racial balancing," keeping Asian-American admissions at or under 20 percent annually in the years before SFFA sued in 2014. Harvard denies these allegations and claims its approach to promoting student body diversity is in line with Supreme Court precedent.

Edward Blum, an activist involved in other cases challenging the use of race in college admissions, heads SFFA. The U.S. Justice Department launched a related investigation of Harvard after President Donald Trump took office last year, and has backed SFFA's case, stating that Harvard has not seriously considered race-neutral approaches to admissions.

Title: Trump Admits Decision to Fire Comey Unrelated to Justice Department Recommendation

Article:

In a wide-ranging interview with NBC's Lester Holt, President Trump admitted that his decision to fire FBI Director James Comey was not based on the Justice Department's recommendation. Instead, Trump stated, "It was set up a while ago."

Trump criticized Comey, calling him a "showboat" and a "grandstander." He cited the FBI's turmoil and the agency's perceived lack of recovery from its state a year ago. Trump also blamed Democrats for the Russia storyline, stating that the Russia investigation was a "made-up story" and an "excuse by the Democrats for having lost an election that they should have won."

However, Trump denied asking Comey to halt the investigation and expressed a desire for it to be completed by a competent individual at the FBI. Trump maintained that there was no collusion between him, his campaign, and Russia.

Trump fired Comey on Tuesday, citing his handling of the Clinton email investigation as the reason. The White House's official reasoning, based on a review by Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein, was that Comey had mishandled the Clinton email investigation. Vice President Pence has also asserted that Trump's dismissal of Comey was based on Rosenstein's recommendations.

The timing of Comey's firing has raised questions, as it comes as the FBI appears to be ramping up its investigation into Trump associates' ties to Russia. White House spokeswoman Sarah Huckabee Sanders stated that Trump had been considering firing Comey since November.

At Thursday's White House press briefing, Huckabee Sanders said that Comey's testimony before Congress on May 3 was the "last straw" that led to Trump's decision. In that testimony, Comey stated that he was "mildly nauseous" to think that he may have influenced the election by coming forward days before the election to say that he was reopening the Clinton email investigation.

Trump's admission that he called Comey to ask whether he was under FBI investigation has raised ethical questions. Trump also stated that Comey told him twice that he was not under investigation, once on the phone and once during a dinner that was "arranged." Trump initially claimed that Comey had asked for the dinner to ask to stay on as FBI director, but this was later disputed.

Trump also told Holt that he wants to find out if there was Russian meddling in the election and insisted that his campaign and Russia did not collude. The U.S. intelligence community has concluded that Russia meddled in the election, but Trump qualified Russia's involvement with "if" three times in the interview.

The White House claimed Wednesday that low morale at the FBI was a reason behind Comey's dismissal. However, this was disputed by acting FBI Director Andrew McCabe, who stated at a congressional hearing that Comey had the full confidence of the bureau.

Since the election, Comey has publicly confirmed that there was an ongoing FBI investigation into Trump associates and collusion with Russia, and he disputed under oath the president's baseless claim that President Barack Obama ordered his team to be wiretapped.

Title: Partial Government Shutdown Affects National Parks and Services, Volunteers Step In

Article:

The ongoing partial government shutdown, now entering its second weekend with no signs of a compromise, has led to the closure of visitor centers and the absence of park rangers at Joshua Tree National Park in California. The park, known for its rock climbing and camping opportunities, remains open to visitors, but facilities are not being maintained by the National Park Service.

John Lauretig, executive director of the nonprofit Friends of Joshua Tree National Park, stated, "The visitors centers are closed. All the bathrooms are still open, but they're not being maintained right now by the Park Service. So the local community has rallied together and started cleaning the bathrooms and restocking the toilet paper."

As the shutdown continues, volunteers are stepping in to maintain basic facilities, but concerns are growing about the long-term impact. Lauretig questioned, "As the dumpsters fill up and the pit toilets fill up, what kinds of solutions can we make to solve those problems?"

The effects of the shutdown have been minimal so far, with approximately 400,000 critical federal employees continuing to work without pay. However, the longer the shutdown persists, the more widespread the impact will be.

Jacqueline Simon, policy director for the American Federation of Government Employees, the largest union of federal workers, stated, "More things will be shutting down." She explained that some agencies had a little extra funding to continue operations until the end of the year, but that money is running out.

The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) announced plans to halt operations at midnight on Friday, and the Smithsonian museums and the National Zoo will close their doors on January 2. The food stamps program (Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program, or SNAP) and the school lunch program are funded through January but could be affected if the shutdown continues beyond that point.

White House economist Kevin Hassett predicted the shutdown would not cause lasting damage to the U.S. economy, but admitted it could cause a temporary increase in unemployment if hundreds of thousands of federal workers remain idle for several weeks.

Social Security and Medicare payments are still being made, as usual. However, applications for Federal Housing Administration-backed mortgages could be delayed, and FEMA's decision to stop selling flood insurance during the shutdown caused concern in the housing market.

In response to pressure, FEMA backtracked late Friday and announced it would resume selling flood insurance during the shutdown. At Joshua Tree National Park, volunteers are maintaining basic facilities, but the absence of park rangers is a concern for preservationists. Lauretig stated, "There are rare and unique artifacts up there that need to be protected by a fully-staffed National Park Service staff. My concern is right now those one-of-a-kind kind of things in the park are unprotected, unfortunately."

Title: Republican Convention Discord: Grassroots Activists and Establishment Clash Over Party Rules

Article:

In the midst of Tropical Storm Isaac's approach, the Republican National Convention in Tampa, Florida, has been marked by a series of disagreements and clashes between grassroots activists and the party establishment. Drew McKissick, a South Carolina delegate, commented that the postponement of the convention's activities provided an opportunity for everyone to voice their concerns.

The main point of contention is a proposed change in party rules that would give presidential nominees more control over the selection of convention delegates sent by the states. This change, if implemented, would reportedly hinder insurgent challenges like those faced by Mitt Romney during the primaries. A compromise was reached in closed-door talks between Romney aides and conservative activists, with one person involved stating that it would result in a "warm and fuzzy" convention.

Supporters of Representative Ron Paul of Texas expressed frustration over what they perceived as efforts by Romney's aides and supporters to silence their voices in the convention hall. Representative Todd Akin, the Missouri Senate candidate who lost much of the party's support after his comments on "legitimate" rape and pregnancy, was also a topic of discussion, with some Tea Party activists arguing that the "establishment" wing of the party had abandoned him.

The extra day provided by the postponement was seen as beneficial by grassroots conservative activists, who used it to mobilize support for their efforts to quash the proposed rule change. A.J. Spiker, the chairman of the Iowa Republican Party and a supporter of Paul during the primaries, stated, "The leaders of the Republican Party have an obligation to protect grass-roots activists."

The upstart talk extended beyond the fight over the party's nominating procedures, with Herman Cain, a former presidential candidate, telling attendees at a Tea Party "unity rally" on Sunday night, "There were some people who hoped you all wouldn't show up. Y'all fooled them!"

Reince Priebus, the Republican national chairman, gaveled the convention to order and unveiled two national debt clocks, a symbolic barb at government spending under President Obama. However, a group of Ron Paul supporters staged a demonstration in the hall with signs that altered the convention's "We Can Do Better" theme to "Ron Paul Can Do Better."

Jeremy McReynolds, a 25-year-old activist helping to organize Paul's delegates at the convention, stated, "They want to make everyone think that we all are united behind Romney. That's not true." Saul Anuzis, a delegate from Michigan and a Romney supporter, urged those causing "mischief" to settle down and fall in line behind Romney for the good of the party.

The storm also posed a delicate challenge for President Obama, whose efforts to manage the response may have given him a moment to look presidential in Romney's absence, but were also fraught with the risk of appearing to take advantage of a natural disaster at a highly politicized moment. Convention planners stated they had no regrets about their decision to postpone Monday's activities, with any ripples of discord expected to be forgotten by Tuesday night when Ann Romney and Governor Chris Christie of New Jersey are set to speak.

Title: Democrats' Potential Investigations into Trump Administration if They Win Control of Congress

Article:

If Democrats win control of the U.S. House of Representatives or Senate in the November 6 elections, they are poised to launch numerous investigations into various aspects of President Donald Trump's presidency. These investigations could cover a wide range of topics, from Trump's long-elusive tax returns to possible business ties with Russia and conflicts of interest, according to congressional sources.

While the sequencing and scope of these inquiries are still emerging, Democrats are clear about what is not on the agenda: impeachment of Trump, at least until the outcome of Special Counsel Robert Mueller's probe of Russian meddling in the 2016 U.S. elections and possible Trump campaign collusion with Moscow.

If Democrats take control of the House, they would move quickly to obtain Trump's tax returns to look for business ties to Russia and possible conflicts with the Republican president, his family businesses, and U.S. government interests. They may also examine his handling of security clearances and possibly probe his revoking of security clearances from perceived political enemies and his granting of an interim security clearance to an aide who later resigned amid allegations of spousal abuse.

Democratic majorities in the House or Senate would bring more resources for investigations that could derail or delay Trump's agenda, but aides said Democrats will still aim for some bipartisan cooperation to avoid appearing overtly political ahead of the 2020 presidential election.

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, in an interview, warned that Democratic probes could be reminiscent of the late 1990s when the public felt sorry for President Bill Clinton after his impeachment. "It could end up not working well for them, at all," McConnell added.

If Democrats take the House, Representative Elijah Cummings, who is likely to be the chairman of the Committee on Oversight and Government Reform, would lead investigations. During Trump's presidency, Democrats on that committee have sought 64 subpoenas, which Republican committee members have denied. If Democrats win control of the House, those subpoenas would not suddenly be issued all at once, aides said. However, they offer a roadmap of Democrats' intentions.

Cummings would take a "two-lane" approach, examining Trump's businesses and potential conflicts of interests, while also probing "day-to-day" issues such as prescription drug pricing, voter suppression, and questions about citizenship added to the 2020 U.S. Census.

Other committees, such as the House Judiciary Committee, the tax-writing Ways and Means Committee, and the Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence, would also conduct investigations. There is no plan for a special temporary committee, but Democratic leaders would coordinate investigative efforts with the heads of the committees. The committees would spend January organizing, with investigations cranking up as soon as February.

The Ways and Means Committee would use its authority to request Trump's tax returns from Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin. The judiciary and intelligence committees could then use the returns to dig into whether Trump got anything of value from foreigners or had business ties to Russia.

Senate Democrats have a list of Trump-related concerns that runs about 100 pages, according to a document seen by Reuters. Adam Schiff, the top Democrat on the House intelligence panel, has criticized the Republican-controlled Congress for abdicating its oversight duty and being complicit in some of the president's most egregious attacks on democratic institutions. Schiff has stated that Democrats must "restore Congress as an equal branch and check the ambition of an imperial and erratic president."

Title: Trump Campaign Blimp: Fact-Checking Claims of "State-of-the-Art Spy Gadgets" for Data Collection

Article:

In March, a post by America Web Media suggested that the Trump campaign might use "state-of-the-art spy gadgets" to collect data on American citizens through a campaign blimp. This claim, however, is not supported by factual evidence.

Initially, the Trump campaign had planned to send a blimp emblazoned with the Trump-Pence logo over swing states from May to July, as reported by Politico, the Associated Press, Fox News, and other outlets in early March. The blimp was intended to serve a dual purpose: campaigning and collecting voter data.

According to the March reports, the campaign planned to collect voter information through a message on the blimp encouraging those who see it to text the Trump campaign. The campaign would then be able to use the respondents' contact information for donation requests and to send election materials. The America Web Media article's claim of "state-of-the-art spy gadgets" for data collection is not mentioned in these reports.

Since the initial round of reporting, the coronavirus pandemic has led to a significant change in campaigning, and it does not appear that the Trump blimp ever made it beyond the planning stage. The Trump campaign did not respond to a request for comment, and there have been no reports of sightings of the blimp and the campaign has said nothing about it publicly.

The America Web Media article is incorrect in claiming that the Trump blimp would use "state-of-the-art spy gadgets to gather data on the American people." The data collection, as reported in March, would have been entirely voluntary, with individuals choosing to text the campaign and provide their contact information. The aspects of the article that were correct at the time it was first published are, at this point, outdated.

Title: Texas Democrats Face Challenges in "Turn Texas Blue" Campaign as Abortion Issue Divides Latino Voters

Article:

Democrats in Texas are facing challenges in their efforts to "turn Texas blue" as the abortion issue divides Latino voters, a key demographic they are targeting to win over in the state. The Democrats are planning to spend millions of dollars to attract a new generation of Latino voters, but the ongoing abortion debate in Austin may not be an effective strategy for this group.

The abortion fight, which flared up this summer, was seen as an opportunity for Democrats to galvanize new supporters who might stay engaged for the long term. However, the issue is not as appealing to Latino voters, who oppose abortion more strongly than most other voting groups, according to polls.

The Pew Forum on Religion and Public Life found that 53% of Hispanic Catholics believe abortion should be illegal in all or most cases, a higher percentage than all other religious voting groups, including white Catholics, white mainline Protestants, black Protestants, and Jews. A poll by the Wilson Perkins Allen research firm also found a 2-1 "pro-life" margin among Texas Hispanic voters, with 62% describing themselves as pro-life and only 32% calling themselves pro-choice.

Some Democratic strategists argue that the key to winning over Latinos is to avoid focusing too much on any one issue, especially abortion. Matt Angle, a longtime state strategist, suggests that the party's candidates should develop a broader pitch on a range of issues important to Latinos, but one powerful message is the "overreach" by imposing strict health and safety standards that lead to the closure of many health clinics in the state.

Despite the challenges, most Texas Democrats do not think Latinos' anti-abortion views will sink their hopes. James Aldrete, an Austin-based consultant, argues that other polls show Latinos' opposition to abortion is softer than it appears, with 74% of Latinos believing women have the right to make their own decisions without interference from politicians, and a similar percentage saying they would not judge women who decide they are not ready to be parents.

The Democrats have not won a statewide race since 1994, lost control of the Legislature years ago, and President Barack Obama won only 41% of the vote in Texas in 2012. The party has also suffered a series of other humiliations, including Gene Kelly, a perennial candidate who shares the same name as the dancer, winning the nomination to the U.S. Senate. However, most Texas Democrats remain optimistic about their chances of winning over Latino voters.

Title: Trump Campaign Shifts Focus to Elizabeth Warren as She Gains Momentum in Democratic Primary

Article:

The Trump campaign is adjusting its strategy to focus on Massachusetts Senator Elizabeth Warren, who has been gaining momentum in the Democratic primary race. The shift comes as Warren's populist message and disciplined campaign style have raised concerns among Trump advisers about her potential threat in a general election.

According to conversations with more than a half-dozen Trump advisers, the Trump campaign is now deploying opposition research, camera-wielding trackers, and preparing to brand Warren as a liberal extremist. This reassessment reflects the volatility of the Democratic primary and the Trump campaign's response to it.

Initially, the Trump campaign had focused almost exclusively on former Vice President Joe Biden. However, Warren's rise in polls and her perceived ability to win over suburban female voters has prompted the Trump team to take notice. Campaign pollster John McLaughlin has expressed concern that Warren's attacks on Trump could undercut his support from working-class voters who propelled him to the presidency.

In a text message to a colleague, McLaughlin wrote, "Sen. Warren's attacks on President Trump's policies need to be rebutted. We can't just allow her to continue to attack the President in key states like Iowa, New Hampshire, Nevada, and elsewhere."

Biden will still receive a significant share of the campaign's attention. However, Trump aides are less certain that he will be their eventual opponent. The reelection campaign first began taking note of Warren's momentum several weeks ago, when polling showed her gaining substantially on Biden and Sanders. They were startled earlier this month when Tucker Carlson, a host on Trump-friendly Fox News, praised Warren's populist economic agenda.

Other pro-Trump Republican groups are also paying closer attention to Warren. The GOP oppo research shop America Rising has placed Warren in its top tier of Democratic candidates and will prioritize putting trackers on her campaign events. The RNC recently sent out a news release drawing attention to a radio interview in which Warren was pressed on her past claims of Native American ancestry.

The Trump campaign is preparing to dig into Warren's past as a professor and pick apart her laundry list of policy proposals. "There's no question that Elizabeth Warren is on the move, has momentum, and could well end up as our opponent," said Tim Murtaugh, a Trump 2020 spokesman. "We have to make sure voters know about her proposals for government takeover of health care, free health care for illegal immigrants, radical environmental restrictions, and increased taxes—all proposals that will devastate this country."

A Warren spokesperson did not respond to a request for comment.

Warren has been enjoying a renaissance after a painful campaign rollout. Trump attacked her mercilessly after she released a DNA test that attempted to put the controversy over her bloodlines to rest only to reveal she's between 1/64th and 1/1,024th Native American. In the most recent national poll, from Quinnipiac University, Warren was at 15 percent, only slightly behind Sanders for second place. And in polls released this week of California and Nevada—two key states that vote in late February and early March, respectively—Warren leapfrogged Sanders, running behind only Biden.

The latest view inside the Trump campaign is that Warren has a more coherent message and a more passionate liberal following than Biden, whose support they see as soft. "Her politics are where the Democratic party has moved," said Trump campaign adviser Raj Shah. "She's primed to pick up more support as Bernie fades and Biden erodes."

Biden and his supporters, however, are confident the Democratic electorate is more centrist than prognosticators think. Not everyone agrees that going after Warren is the right move. Some Trump aides contend that her liberal positions would make her an easier general election opponent and that they should hold off on attacking her. Others, however, argue that guessing a particular candidate's level of electability is impossible and that the Democratic nominee—no matter who it is—needs to be defined well before next year's convention.

Title: Obamacare Premiums Rise for 2015, but Consumers Have Wider Options and May Find Lower Costs

Article:

Premiums for Obamacare health insurance plans are increasing for 2015, according to multiple experts. Avelere Health, an advisory firm, reports that consumers in the most popular 2014 plan, the cheapest silver tier plan, will pay an average of 10% more for the same policy next year. Pricewaterhouse Coopers, a consulting group, found an average increase of 5.2% when examining premiums for all tier levels by state.

Dan Mendelson, Avelere's CEO, attributes the initial pricing difficulties in 2014 to the exchanges not existing before this year, making it challenging for insurers to price their policies accurately. With a better understanding of the popularity of their offerings and the health status of their newly enrolled, insurers can set more precise premiums for 2015.

However, the increase in premiums does not necessarily mean that consumers will pay more for coverage through the exchanges next year. With more insurers offering plans for 2015, most consumers will have a wider selection in terms of premiums, deductibles, doctor networks, and coverage options, experts said.

It is crucial that consumers browse through all the Obamacare plans available, especially those currently in Obamacare plans. If they do nothing before December 15, they will be automatically re-enrolled and may find themselves paying a lot more for coverage, even if cheaper policies were available.

Even if their policy's premium does not increase, consumers could still experience sticker shock for 2015 if they received a subsidy. The subsidy is based on the price of a benchmark, which is the second-cheapest silver plan being offered in their area that year. The Kaiser Family Foundation, a non-profit health policy research firm, found that the benchmark plan will rise 2% on average.

If the benchmark plan in someone's area carries a lower premium for 2015, the subsidy levels are recalculated. Consumers who do not check out next year's offerings may find their subsidy for 2015 covers a smaller share of their premium, whatever plan they pick.

"Shopping around is an imperative this year," Mendelson said. "In many cases, they'll be able to find a lower-cost option."

Title: Facebook Announces Privacy Tool Overhaul in Response to Criticism and Regulatory Pressure

Article:

Facebook, with over 2.2 billion users worldwide, is implementing changes to its privacy tools in an effort to make navigation easier for users and comply with the European Union's General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), effective May 25. The changes will not alter Facebook's data collection practices or its privacy policies.

The updates, announced on Wednesday, aim to provide users with a more straightforward approach to managing their privacy and security settings. Facebook also intends to offer users a simpler method to access and download the data the company collects on them.

These changes follow the revelation that Cambridge Analytica, a Trump-affiliated consulting firm, obtained data on millions of Facebook users, including information from friends of people who had downloaded a psychological quiz app, despite those friends not providing explicit consent for data sharing. Facebook is also facing criticism for collecting years of contact names, telephone numbers, and call and text histories from Android users. The company has not disclosed the purpose or reason for using such data.

On Monday, the Federal Trade Commission announced an investigation into Facebook's privacy practices. Facebook's chief privacy officer, Erin Egan, stated in a blog post that most of the privacy updates have been in development for some time, but the recent events highlight their importance.

Facebook plans to update its privacy policy and terms of service in the coming weeks, but provided no further details. The company has attempted in the past to simplify its privacy settings, yet the controls remain difficult to find and use for many people.

In response to these concerns, Facebook will consolidate privacy settings into a single, easily accessible location. The company will also provide "clearer explanations" about how its privacy controls work. Chris Cox, Facebook's chief product officer, described the new settings as "the first of many steps" the company is taking to address privacy concerns.

To comply with the GDPR, Facebook is adding a section called "Access Your Information," a secure area for users to manage the data they've shared with the company, including status updates, comments, and search history. This is where users can delete information or download a copy. While the download was already possible, it required some effort to execute. Cox stated that the changes allow users to browse their information in detail without having to download it. For example, users will now be able to look up a post from a specific date in the past.

Cox noted that the changes align with the principles of GDPR, but there is "a bunch of stuff that goes above and beyond that." Facebook also plans to propose updates to its terms of service in the coming weeks and update its privacy policy, but provided no further details.

Title: Disney's Strategic Shift: Launching Disney+ to Strengthen its Media Empire

Article:

Disney, one of the most profitable media firms globally, has ventured into the digital-video service market with the launch of Disney+ on November 12th, 2019. The service, which faced initial technical glitches due to overwhelming demand, marks a significant strategic move for the company.

The decision to invest in Disney+ comes with substantial costs. Disney acquired BAMTech Media, a leading digital-video streaming platform, for approximately $3 billion. The company also spent $85 billion on the purchase of 21st Century Fox and attempted to buy Sky, a British TV giant, but lost out to Comcast. In the coming years, Disney will spend billions more on original series and films for its service, forgo around $4.5 billion in annual profit by withholding content licenses, and invest in new infrastructure.

Despite these significant costs, Disney+ is priced competitively, with a monthly subscription fee of $7 (or less than $6 per month on an annual plan). This low price, compared to Netflix's most popular plan at $13 per month and HBO's service at $15, has led some to question Disney's faith in the offering or its ability to recoup its investment. However, Disney estimates it will break even at 60-90 million subscribers globally.

To attract subscribers and retain existing ones, Disney has implemented several strategies. It offers a three-year subscription for less than $4 per month, partnered with Verizon to provide Disney+ free to 17-18 million subscribers for at least a year, and has announced several other discounts and bundling deals.

The low price and strategic partnerships are tactical moves to compete in a crowded market. In the second quarter of 2020, NBCUniversal (owned by Comcast) will launch its own service, Peacock, while AT&T will release HBO Max, expected to have more than twice the programming budget of today's HBO. Other competitors, such as Jeffrey Katzenberg's Quibi, are also preparing to enter the market.

Beyond short-term tactics, Disney's long-term ambition is to leverage data and direct customer relationships to fortify its entire media empire. For decades, Disney has thrived by cross-monetizing its divisions, but it has lacked a direct relationship with most consumers and their preferences. Through Disney+, the company aims to gather this data, inform decisions about content production, increase the efficacy of marketing and promotion, and sell more Disney-related products and experiences to fans.

This data-driven approach has led some analysts to compare Disney+ with Amazon's Prime Video rather than Netflix. The endgame in the streaming video-on-demand (SVOD) market isn't just video, but entire ecosystems that can generate revenue from various sources, such as theme park passes, cruises, and merchandise.

Title: George Zimmerman Files Lawsuit Alleging Conspiracy in Trayvon Martin Case

Article:

George Zimmerman, the neighborhood watch captain who was acquitted in the 2012 fatal shooting of Trayvon Martin, has filed a lawsuit in Florida alleging a conspiracy to frame him and seeking more than $100 million in damages. The lawsuit, filed Wednesday, accuses civil rights attorney Ben Crump, Trayvon's parents, prosecutors, and state authorities of participating in a plot to swap out a reluctant witness and prepare a witness to deliver false testimony against Zimmerman.

The lawsuit alleges that Trayvon's parents, prosecutors, and state authorities went along with the alleged ruse, knowingly obstructing justice or lying under oath to cover up the witness fraud. The suit's chief allegation is that civil rights attorney Ben Crump helped to swap out Brittany Diamond Eugene, a witness who was reluctant to testify, for her half-sister, Rachel Jeantel.

According to the lawsuit, Jeantel posed as Trayvon's girlfriend during the encounter with Zimmerman, while it was Eugene who was dating Trayvon and on the phone with him during the incident. Jeantel then delivered bogus testimony on the stand at Zimmerman's trial, the lawsuit alleges.

The plan was made final in a 3-minute phone call between Crump and Eugene on March 31, 2012, the lawsuit says. Jeantel, a key prosecution witness, testified that Trayvon told her in the phone call that someone was following him. As Trayvon neared the home of his father's girlfriend, he tried to lose Zimmerman, she testified. Jeantel said she heard him talking to Zimmerman in the background.

"He said, 'Why are you following me for?' And I heard a hard-breathing man say, 'What you doing around here?'" Jeantel testified. Jeantel then heard a bump from Trayvon's headset hitting something and "wet grass sounds." "I start hearing a little bit of Trayvon saying, 'Get off, get off!'" said Jeantel.

Jeantel admitted on the stand to lying several times to Trayvon's family about her age and about her reasons for not attending Trayvon's funeral. Jeantel found herself under the unforgiving light of a nationally televised trial. Viewers criticized her for her dress, her weight, and her speech and her combative manner on the stand.

In a statement issued on behalf of Trayvon's parents and Crump, the lawsuit was described as "an unfounded and reckless lawsuit" and a "shameless attempt to profit off the lives and grief of others." The statement also accused Zimmerman of displaying a "callous disregard for everyone but himself."

CNN is reaching out to others accused in the lawsuit, including Jeantel, who did not immediately return a voicemail and text message seeking comment. The Florida Department of Law Enforcement declined to comment, and Attorney General Ashley Moody, through a spokeswoman, also declined to comment.

The lawsuit alleges malicious prosecution, abuse of process, civil conspiracy, and defamation. It seeks compensatory and actual damages of more than $100,000,000 and leaves open the possibility of an additional claim for punitive damages.

A month after the February 2012 shooting, Sanford Police Chief Bill Lee said Zimmerman was not charged because there were no grounds to disprove his version of the events. Zimmerman said he shot Trayvon in self-defense. Weeks later, amid widespread outrage, a special prosecutor charged Zimmerman with murder. A jury acquitted him of all charges in July 2013.

Zimmerman has been arrested in several alleged domestic incidents but not charged. In November 2013, he was arrested on aggravated assault and misdemeanor counts of domestic violence battery and criminal mischief accusations. But prosecutors said they would not press charges after his girlfriend said she wanted the case dropped. Zimmerman was arrested in January 2015 on the suspected aggravated assault of another girlfriend. Prosecutors did not press charges after the alleged victim backed off her claims. A year later, Zimmerman put the gun that killed Trayvon up for auction.

Trayvon's death spurred a movement and helped give rise to the rallying cry that resonated with many: #BlackLivesMatter. The image of Trayvon wearing a hoodie was iconic. Professional athletes wore hoodies, and protesters repeated the mantra: "I am Trayvon Martin" to express solidarity and outrage.

Title: Encouraging College Students to Study in Diverse Regions: A Proposed Solution for Overcoming Political Polarization

Article:

A college student at a socioeconomically diverse university has highlighted the consequences of the nation's political polarization, with 57% of fellow students coming from the top 20% of family income and predominantly from blue states. The student, who has yet to meet a publicly pro-Trump student on campus, argues that understanding the country's problems requires encountering diverse views and experiences.

The student suggests that national service programs, such as those proposed by politicians like Pete Buttigieg, could help bridge these divides. However, these programs would require a substantial budget and new bureaucracy.

An existing program, study abroad, is proposed as a potential solution. Over the past generation, the number of American college students studying abroad has increased significantly, with about 16% of those earning bachelor's degrees spending part of their time in college abroad.

The student argues that encouraging study "at home" rather than just study "abroad" could help students learn more about the United States. Programs that allow students to spend time at different universities in the U.S. do exist, but they are quite small. The student suggests that these programs should be scaled up significantly to ensure students learn about the diverse types of people and lifestyles that make America great.

The student proposes "study in the U.S." programs as the foundation for other campus initiatives to encourage students to have difficult conversations and interactions in safe and civil settings. This would not only inject different ideas but also make colleges places where young people learn the skills needed to become informed and empathetic citizens in a diverse society.

The student, Isaac Rose-Berman, is a rising sophomore at Brandeis University and an intern at The Flip Side, a free daily newsletter that seeks to bridge the divide between Democrats and Republicans.

Title: 2012 Election Marked as Most Expensive and Smallest in Modern History

Article:

The 2012 election, which concluded on Tuesday, has been labeled as the most expensive and smallest in modern history. The campaign, which began with the first Republican primary debate in 2011, was marked by a series of superlatives, including being the most expensive and, subjectively, the most garish and debased election of the modern era.

Many commentators were captivated by the plot twists, despite their criticism of the campaign. Columnist Maureen Dowd described it as a race that "looked more to the gutter than the stars," while Fred Barnes, in his final election column, titled "Good Riddance."

Gary Hart, the Colorado Democrat who ran twice for president in the 1980s, in a recent interview, condemned a campaign marked by "a dumbing down of the message to elementary rhetoric that does not contain big ideas or challenging ideas."

The core of these complaints lies in a paradox: the 2012 campaign seemed both bloated and all-pervasive, yet miniaturized and ephemeral. The arguments were small, with numerous days dominated by uproars over careless but inconsequential remarks by candidates.
