The debate often played out on cable TV and Twitter, shaping the contest in an unprecedented manner.

The playing field was small, with the Electoral College's usual bias in favor of 10 or so swing states intensified this time by the candidates' relentless focus on mobilizing narrow demographic slivers within those states. The leading actors were small, either content with their diminished stature or powerless to change it.

Barack Obama, who four years ago encouraged people to view him as an epic figure, riding a wave of history, this time encouraged people to view him in life-size terms, as a mortal figure who had done the best he could amid setbacks and disappointments and was at least better than the alternative. Mitt Romney ran mainly as the vessel for anti-Obamaism, and watched helplessly as his biggest career achievements—in business and as Massachusetts governor—turned into partial liabilities.

These 2012 phenomena occurred due to three long-term trends that contributed to making this election historically small. One consistent refrain of Barack Obama, especially in the early days of his administration, was disdain for what he plainly regarded as the frivolous and distracting nature of modern political media and the 24-7 news cycle. In June 2009, Obama boasted to Brian Williams that he did not watch cable television, stating, "I generally don't. Mainly because I don't find most of the cable chatter very persuasive. I've used this analogy before, it feels like WWF wrestling. Everyone's got their role to play."

Title: Trump's Tweets and the Ongoing Russia Investigation: A Constitutional Analysis

Article:

President Donald Trump's tweets over the weekend have reiterated his stance on the ongoing Russia investigation, specifically regarding the 2016 meeting in Trump Tower. In a tweet on August 5, 2018, Trump stated that the meeting was about gathering opposition research, contradicting previous statements that it was primarily about the issue of international adoptions.

In a separate tweet on August 1, Trump called for the investigation to end, labeling it a "rigged witch hunt" and accusing Attorney General Jeff Sessions and Special Counsel Robert Mueller of being biased.

Democrats have labeled Trump's statements as obstruction of justice, but Trump's lawyer, Jay Sekulow, has disputed this characterization. Sekulow stated that the theory of obstruction by tweet is "absurd" and that the question of obstruction would be addressed under Article II of the Constitution, which grants the president executive powers over the government.

While Trump's lawyers have stated that the president is willing to sit down for an interview with the special counsel, they have advised against it, leaving the question of whether to subpoena the president unanswered. Sekulow has stated that a subpoena for live testimony from a president of the United States has never been tested in court and that they would prepare to handle it in court if it were issued.

Senator Marco Rubio (R-FL) has stated that the investigation should continue, as it is in the best interest of the president and the United States for all the truth to come out. Meanwhile, some Democrats have expressed support for impeachment if strong evidence of collusion were to emerge, but others have cautioned against invoking the "I" word prematurely.

The midterm elections in November are approaching, and some Democrats have discussed the possibility of impeachment if they win a majority in the House of Representatives. Former Massachusetts Governor Deval Patrick, a potential 2020 presidential candidate, has stated that if the grounds for impeachment are there, they should proceed. However, he has also emphasized that impeachment should not be the first order of business.

Title: Former FBI Director James Comey Confirms Role in Leaking Memo Detailing Conversation with President Trump

Article:

In a recent testimony, former FBI Director James Comey admitted to orchestrating the leak of a memo detailing his conversation with President Trump, which included the president's request to drop the investigation into the former national security adviser. Comey made this information public through an intermediary after President Trump suggested on Twitter that there might be recordings of their discussions.

Comey, in his testimony, stated, "I woke up in the middle of the night on Monday night, 'cause it didn't dawn on me originally that there might be corroboration for our conversation; there might be a tape.' My judgment was I needed to get that out in the public square so I asked a friend of mine to share the content of the memo with a reporter."

The New York Times published an article about the memo on May 16, and the story was also printed in the newspaper the following day. The article attributed the information to "two people who read the memo" without naming them.

During questioning by Senator Susan Collins (Republican of Maine), Comey did not reveal the friend's name but confirmed that the individual is a professor at Columbia University. On Thursday, Daniel Richman, a law professor at Columbia, confirmed that he was the close friend who served as intermediary.

Title: Supreme Court to Review Injunctions on Travel Ban Executive Order

Article:

The Supreme Court of the United States announced on Monday that it will review the lower court injunctions blocking the enforcement of President Donald Trump's executive order barring travel from six Muslim-majority countries. In a per curiam opinion, the Court partially stayed the injunctions blocking enforcement of executive order 13,780.

The Court's opinion grants the government's applications to stay the injunctions, to the extent the injunctions prevent enforcement of section 2(c) of the executive order against foreign nationals who lack any bona fide relationship with a person or entity in the United States. The injunctions entered by the lower courts in place with respect to respondents and those similarly situated, as specified in this opinion, remain in effect.

The Court's opinion states that the lower court injunctions, even accepting the First Amendment arguments against the order as likely to succeed, went too far. The injunctions also bar enforcement of section 2(c) against foreign nationals abroad who have no connection to the United States at all. Denying entry to such a foreign national does not burden any American party by reason of that party's relationship with the foreign national.

The opinion also announced the Court will consolidate the cases from the U.S. Courts of Appeal for the Ninth and Fourth circuit, Trump v. Hawaii and Trump v. International Refugee Assistance Project, respectively. Both cases found the executive order unenforceable as a likely violation of the U.S. Constitution's First Amendment Establishment Clause because the lower courts held it was motivated by an attempt to disfavor Islam.

The Court had requested additional briefing from the parties in both cases earlier this month, signaling they would hear arguments on the case despite the Court going out of its regular term this week. Arguments are expected to be heard when the Court reconvenes in October. Attorneys from the American Civil Liberties Union and the National Immigration Law Center are expected to face off against a government team now led by acting Solicitor General Jeffery Wall.

The government had argued in the new briefing that the injunctions had delayed the start date for the 90-day order. This would allow the ban, which affects those coming from Iran, Libya, Somalia, Sudan, Syria, and Yemen, to remain valid despite having been issued in March.

A dissent from the per curiam decision, written by Justice Clarence Thomas and joined by Justices Samuel Alito and Neil Gorsuch, would have gone further and stayed the injunctions in their entirety, allowing the travel ban to go fully into effect immediately.

The executive order was the second issued on the matter. The first, Executive Order 13,769, also included Iraq and was immediately the subject of challenges in the courts. The current order was tailored to address the concerns raised in these initial lawsuits but soon was itself enjoined in both the Fourth and Ninth Circuits. Finding a likelihood the plaintiffs would succeed on First Amendment grounds, these courts' decisions to enjoin the orders have heretofore prevented enforcement of the order.

Prevailing arguments in the lower courts have controversially included those based on statements made by the president and his surrogates while on the campaign trail as to his motivation for issuing the ban.

The Trump administration has been determined to defend this version of the travel ban, setting up Monday's opinion and the potential for a Supreme Court hearing on the merits in the fall.

Title: GOP Faces Challenges in Passing Budgets Amid Intra-Party Disputes and Medicare Reform

Article:

Republican leaders are facing difficulties in passing their budget proposals amid an increasingly polarized GOP, with disputes over defense spending and the pace of entitlement cuts. This development was highlighted on Thursday when GOP leaders announced a deal with top Democrats to scrap an 18-year-old tool designed to cut Medicare spending, drawing opposition from conservative groups.

The spending fights will make it challenging for House Speaker John A. Boehner and Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell to assemble a coalition capable of passing a budget. Democrats, who have criticized the twin GOP proposals as "warmed-over stew," are unlikely to offer assistance.

The main sticking point is a dispute over defense spending. With Republicans in control of both chambers, defense hawks argue they must reverse years of cuts to the Pentagon to combat terrorism and maintain control of adversarial countries. However, this would require either politically difficult spending cuts or tax increases, or else the GOP will have to breach the spending caps imposed in a 2011 debt deal with President Obama.

The House Committee on the Budget approved its blueprint on a 22-13 party-line vote after a 24-hour period that underscored the defense rift. Budget Chairman Tom Price's budget cuts $5.5 trillion from spending over 10 years, overhauls Medicare into a voucher-like system, and makes steep cuts to welfare programs.

The Senate Republicans called the House's maneuver a gimmick, although they were not thrilled with their own plan, which included $58 billion in war funds for fiscal 2016 and maintained sequester caps in later years. Sen. Marco Rubio, Florida Republican, said the plan "fails to prioritize our national defense after years of damaging cuts to our nation's military."

In the House, members will debate whether to boost war spending to $96 billion without requiring $20 billion in offsetting savings. Congressional budgets are blueprints without the force of law, but they offer a comprehensive outline of each party's agenda as lawmakers forge actual spending bills.

Coupled with the budget fight is a battle over updating an unpopular Medicare formula that controls payments to doctors. Lawmakers face an end-of-month deadline to avert a 21 percent cut to doctors' Medicare payments, as doctors may leave the program if the cuts are implemented.

On Thursday, congressional leaders said they have a framework for a replacement, which would give doctors a 0.5 percent pay raise each year for five years while streaming programs that evaluate their performance. The House and Senate will debate their budgets on the floor next week, and lawmakers will be soul-searching over whether they can support them.

Title: Senate Efforts to Defund Obamacare Amidst Website Issues

The government-run Obamacare website, healthcare.gov, will temporarily shut down this weekend for maintenance, as it continues to experience technical difficulties. The site, which has been inundated with 8.6 million visitors since its launch, according to officials, has been plagued with issues that prevent users from viewing available health insurance plans.

President Obama, in an interview with The Associated Press, asked for patience as the high volume of visitors has caused the website to malfunction. "The website got overwhelmed by volume," he said, acknowledging the unexpected interest in the program. "The insurance doesn't start until January. So they'll have plenty of time."

House Speaker John Boehner criticized the decision to disable the enrollment site for maintenance, stating that the work demonstrates major flaws with Obamacare. "The news that [the] enrollment system is already going offline confirms that the launch of the president's healthcare law has been an unmitigated disaster," Boehner said in a statement.

Republican lawmakers, including House Majority Leader Eric Cantor, have also expressed concerns about the website's functionality. "A dysfunctional website is the least of that law's problems," Cantor said in a statement.

Insurance agents have also reported difficulties using the troubled website to provide information to their customers. "I am president of the National Association of Health Underwriters, and I could not get on the Web site," Thomas M. Harte, a New Hampshire insurance broker, told The New York Times.

Despite the issues, enrollments have been increasing, according to the Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association. "We are pleased that enrollment for health care coverage through the new marketplaces is picking up," the association said in a statement. "We expect enrollment to continue to increase."

The administration has promised significant improvements to the online consumer experience by Monday, but tech experts suggest that the website's problems extend beyond simple traffic overages. The Obama administration has been criticized for underestimating the level of interest in the program, leading to the website's design and coding issues.

In a statement, Secretary of Health and Human Services Kathleen Sebelius asked for understanding, comparing the website's issues to those experienced by Apple. However, critics argue that the comparison is misleading, as the site's functionality remains questionable.

Title: White House Press Secretary Accuses Media of Lack of Journalistic Curiosity in Michael Flynn Case

Article:

White House Press Secretary Kayleigh McEnany criticized reporters on Friday for what she perceived as a lack of journalistic curiosity in the criminal case surrounding former national security advisor Michael Flynn. During a press briefing, CBS News Radio correspondent Steven Portnoy questioned McEnany about President Trump's recent comments suggesting that people "should be jailed" for the "very obvious crime" committed against Flynn.

In response to Portnoy's inquiry, McEnany referred to the alleged unmasking of Flynn by top Obama administration officials during the transition period between November 2016 and January 2017, a topic President Trump has labeled as "Obamagate." When Portnoy asked for clarification on the nature of this alleged crime, McEnany expressed her appreciation for the question, stating that there has been a lack of media interest in this matter.

McEnany then outlined several actions taken by the Obama administration, including the Democratic National Committee-funded Steele dossier, its involvement in the FISA warrants granted to surveil former Trump campaign advisor Carter Page, and the unmasking of Flynn. She also highlighted an Oval Office meeting that took place just days before Trump's inauguration, during which President Obama, Vice President Joe Biden, and acting Attorney General Sally Yates discussed the unmasking. McEnany emphasized that Yates "learned" about the unmasking from Obama and not from the Justice Department.

McEnany went on to detail the FBI's alleged strategy to "get him to lie" regarding Flynn and the criminal leak of his identity to the press in violation of his Fourth Amendment rights. She expressed concern that these issues have been ignored by the media for an extended period.

When Portnoy asked about the specific crime, McEnany reiterated that the leaking of Flynn's name to the press in January 2017 was the alleged crime.

Later in the briefing, McEnany addressed the media's handling of the coronavirus pandemic, criticizing them for downplaying the virus when pressed on her past rhetoric. She listed instances of alleged mistruths by former officials, such as Andy McCabe leaking to The Wall Street Journal and lying about it, James Clapper lying before Congress, and John Brennan's statements regarding the Steele dossier and the Russia probe.

Portnoy then asked if the individuals McEnany listed were the ones the president thought should be "in jail," but McEnany pushed back, insisting that journalists should investigate the matters she had "laid out." She concluded by stating, "That is, after all, the job of reporters, to answer the very questions that I've laid out, and I hope you guys will take the time to do it."

Title: Republican Establishment Criticizes Trump for Iraq War Remarks, Defends Bush Administration

Article:

In a recent debate, Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump made statements that were largely factual, which led to a response from the Republican Party to criticize him. Trump's comments focused on the Iraq War and the Bush administration's role in the conflict.

Trump stated that the Iraq War was a disaster, that the Bush administration misled the country into invading Iraq, and that the claim that Bush kept the country safe from terrorism is ridiculous because 9/11 happened on his watch.

Jeb Bush, a former governor and brother of the former president, responded by stating that while Trump was building a reality TV show, his brother was building a security apparatus to keep the country safe. Trump countered by reminding the audience that the World Trade Center came down during Bush's reign.

Marco Rubio, another Republican candidate and Trump's primary rival, stepped in to support Bush, stating that it was not George W. Bush, but Bill Clinton who was to blame for 9/11, as he did not kill Osama bin Laden when he had the chance.

The audience responded positively to Rubio's comments, but were displeased when Trump observed that Bush also had the chance to prevent 9/11 and did not listen to the advice of his CIA.

It is unclear whether this exchange helped or hurt Trump, but it did go badly for him in a way that was expected, as he went outside the boundaries of what is considered acceptable for a Republican Party politician to say. In response, the Republican Party and its backers piled on to criticize him.

The Republican Party is a coalition of like-minded people, and when a candidate steps outside their zone of comfort and says things they would not say, they team up to crush them. This is a common occurrence in primary politics, and it was on display in this debate.

Trump's claims that the Bush administration positively knew there were no weapons of mass destruction in Iraq is more dubious, but it is unquestionably true that the sort of WMD programs the White House said existed were not found and that the administration's public presentations of intelligence findings were highly skewed and selective.

Trump's arguments are tame by his standards, and almost banal, as Republicans have wondered how he could be winning by claiming up was down. However, this was exactly how they won in their mid-aughts heyday, by slamming decorated war hero John Kerry for cowardice, claiming to have kept the country safe while presiding over the worst terrorist attack in American history, and responding by invading an unrelated country in order to dismantle a nuclear weapons program that did not exist.

In this debate, the Republican Party establishment finally got its groove back and handed Trump arguably his worst evening of the entire campaign. But they also proved to everyone else that pointing out that Bush was in office on 9/11 is a red line for the GOP establishment in a way that concocting a story about Jersey City Muslims celebrating the attacks was not.

Title: North Korea's Denuclearization: A Matter of Interpretation Ahead of Summit Meetings

Article:

As North Korean leader Kim Jong Un and South Korean President Moon Jae-in prepare to meet next Friday, the topic of denuclearization remains the most ambiguous on the agenda. The term has been discussed extensively in recent weeks, yet there is little agreement on its definition, which could lead to complications during this week's summit and the planned meeting between US President Donald Trump and Kim.

South Korean officials and Chinese state media have reported that Kim is open to discussing denuclearization on the Korean Peninsula. On Thursday, President Moon announced that North Korea had not raised its long-standing demand for the withdrawal of US forces in exchange for giving up nuclear weapons, a concession that was met with skepticism by analysts.

Adam Mount, a senior fellow at the Federation of American Scientists, stated, "North Korea has been saying all the right things... they want this summit to occur and they're doing what it takes to make it happen." However, North Korean state media has yet to address the topic, and Kim's public statements have been vague.

In Beijing on March 27, Kim said, "It is our consistent stand to be committed to denuclearization on the peninsula, in accordance with the will of late President Kim Il Sung and late General Secretary Kim Jong Il," according to Chinese state news agency Xinhua. This statement elicited a positive response from US President Donald Trump, who said there was now a "good chance" of denuclearization by North Korea.

However, are Trump, Kim, and Moon discussing the same thing when it comes to North Korea giving up its nuclear capabilities? Over the past decade, denuclearization in North Korea has only ever meant one thing for the United States and South Korea: complete, verifiable, irreversible dismantlement (CVID) of the North Korean program.

Josh Pollack, senior research associate at the Middlebury Institute of International Studies at Monterey, explained, "It's called CVID—complete, verifiable, irreversible dismantlement of the North Korean program." This language has been used consistently by the United Nations Security Council in its resolutions condemning North Korea as far back as October 2006.

"Irreversible," in the practical sense, aims to ensure that current facilities cannot be reactivated after they've been dismantled, Pollack said. Any denuclearization deal would need to include a series of "verifiable" steps for dismantling North Korea's program, carried out under the eyes of independent observers.

Inspections could be conducted by an international body such as the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA), whose inspectors were previously expelled by North Korea in 2002. For decades, the US and South Korea have pushed for denuclearization in North Korea. In 1991, Pyongyang joined Seoul in signing a "joint declaration of the Denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula." Two years later, North Korea pledged it would dismantle its nuclear program in exchange for international aid.

Still, the US government appears hopeful that the latest round of talks will be different. Trump on Wednesday offered a bullish view, insisting he's positioned to accomplish what his predecessors could not. However, he said he'd be willing to stand up and leave the highly anticipated summit should the meeting fall short of his expectations.

On South Korea's part, Moon denied on Thursday that there was any separation between what the North and the South meant by denuclearization. "I do not think there is any difference in the concept," he said. When North Korean leader Kim Jong Un promised talks on denuclearization in Beijing in March, according to Xinhua, he did not speak of Pyongyang ending its program. He spoke of "denuclearization on the (Korean) Peninsula."

Experts said Pyongyang has long been expected to push for the American military presence across the border to be part of the discussion, a position Pollack said he was not sure had changed despite the South Korean president's remarks. Although the US has not stationed nuclear weapons in South Korea since 1992, Pollack said North Korea considered the US's mere presence on the peninsula a nuclear threat.

"They really are threatened by superior American and South Korean military power; they need nuclear weapons to try and prevent an invasion in their view," Pollack said. "They feel the need to equate their nuclear program with the (US and South Korean) military alliance and claim the military alliance is a nuclear threat, when there's no real grounds for that."

Experts told CNN the confusion over how much each side was willing to give and what their basic goals were for the summits make a positive outcome harder to see. Adam Cathcart, an expert on North Korea at the University of Leeds in the UK, said the hopes of some officials in Washington that Kim would willingly give up his nuclear weapons program were "utopian, really pie in the sky."

Speaking to CNN in March, Cathcart said given the ongoing "disdain" the Trump administration had shown for the Iran deal reached during President Barack Obama's administration, it was hard to see a similar, incremental plan getting support in Washington. The deal removed many of the sanctions on the Iranian government, in exchange for the Middle East country getting rid of the majority of its weapons program and uranium—a key ingredient for nuclear weapons.

The reality, argue analysts, is there simply too much distrust and too little understanding between the two sides to come to an agreement. "They will affirm the principle of denuclearization as they did in 2005," said Pollack. "And the implementation will be drawn up and never happen."

Title: Tsarnaev Brothers Emerging as Suspects in 2011 Waltham Triple Murder

Article:

Forensic evidence may link the Tsarnaev brothers, Tamerlan, 26, and Dzhokhar, 19, to their possible involvement in a 2011 unsolved triple murder in Waltham, Massachusetts. Since the brothers were identified as the suspects in the Boston Marathon bombings, the Middlesex County District Attorney's Office has been investigating the possibility that Tamerlan was behind the fatal stabbings of Brendan Mess, Erik Weissman, and Raphael Teken in Waltham.

The Middlesex County District Attorney's Office is now also looking into whether both Tamerlan and Dzhokhar committed the unsolved murders, according to ABC News, which reported that "mounting evidence" bolstered by "forensic hits" make the brothers strong suspects. The killings of Mess, Weissman, and Teken have remained unsolved since their gruesome murders on Sept. 11, 2011.

At the time, the Middlesex County District Attorney's Office believed the three men knew their killer or killers. Tamerlan identified Mess as his "best friend" to the owner of the martial arts gym where he and Mess worked out, according to the Boston Globe. Attention turned to Tamerlan after family and friends of the victims in the Waltham murders saw pictures of him after the bombings and recalled how he did not attend Mess' funeral and stopped making appearances at the gym, ABC News reports.

The three victims ordered food from Gerry's Italian Kitchen, but a deliverywoman heard no answer from inside the apartment when she rang the bell around 8:45 p.m. on Sept. 11, 2011. The restaurant drew the attention of authorities nine days after the Boston bombings after empty fireworks with the gunpowder taken out were found in a charity bin located in Gerry's parking lot, ABC News reports.

Residents of Waltham and nearby Watertown, Massachusetts, told the network that they remember Tamerlan delivering food, and that he and his brother worked as pizza deliverymen. However, the restaurant denied that either brother worked for Gerry's.

The Middlesex County District Attorney's Office said late last month that it was looking into the possibility that Tamerlan was involved in the triple homicide. "We are definitely going to pursue any new leads," spokeswoman Stephanie Guyotte said.

News that the Tsarnaev brothers are strong suspects in the Waltham triple murders comes the same day it was revealed Tamerlan was buried in Virginia. He died in a firefight with authorities on April 19, four days after the Boston bombings. His brother escaped but was captured later that same day by federal and state authorities in Watertown, where Dzhokhar was found hiding in a boat in the backyard of a home.

Dzhokhar faces two terrorism-related charges in connection with the bombings, which killed three people. He has yet to be charged in the murder of MIT police officer Sean Collier, who was allegedly killed by the brothers shortly before the firefight with authorities on April 18.

Title: FBI Director James Comey Testifies: Clinton's Email Practices "Not Truthful," Putting National Secrets at Risk

Article:

In a highly anticipated testimony before the House Oversight Committee on Thursday, FBI Director James Comey stated that some of Hillary Clinton's claims, made under oath, about her use of a private email server were "not true." This revelation has fueled Republican questions about whether Clinton may have committed a felony by lying under oath.

During the wide-ranging hearing, Comey also asserted that Clinton's email practices put America's secrets at risk and her actions constituted the "definition of carelessness." However, he defended the bureau's decision not to pursue charges, stating, "We have no basis to conclude that [Clinton] lied to the FBI."

Republicans, such as Rep. Trey Gowdy (R-S.C.), questioned Clinton's claims that she sent or received no classified material, and that she used only one device. In response to these claims, Comey stated, "That's not true... There was classified material emailed," and "She used multiple devices." He also noted that "no, we found work-related emails, thousands that were not returned."

Democrats on the committee attempted to argue that Clinton may not have noticed or understood the classified markings in a few emails that bore them, bolstering any claim of plausible deniability. Comey did acknowledge that there is a question over whether Clinton was "sophisticated enough" to understand the significance of a particular classified marking at the time.

Fox News reported that a 2012 email containing a classified code known as a "portion marking" was sent to Clinton's account. During the hearing, Clinton herself was at her Washington home, as her campaign responded to hearing highlights.

Republicans, such as Rep. Mark Meadows (R-N.C.), suggested that Clinton had lied to the American people. House Oversight Committee Chairman Jason Chaffetz (R-Utah) and Rep. Gowdy both suggested a "double standard" was at play in the FBI's decision not to pursue charges.

Comey reiterated that "no reasonable prosecutor would bring this case." He stated that while Clinton showed "great carelessness," he did not see evidence that she and those with whom she corresponded "knew when they did it they were doing something that was against the law."

Comey also denied a double standard was at play, stating that no one at the Department of Justice would have brought such a case against "John Doe or Hillary Clinton" based on the facts.

Democratic committee members criticized the hearing and described the criticism of Comey as political. Rep. Elijah Cummings (D-Md.) stated, "Amazingly, some Republicans who were praising you just days ago... in their eyes you had one job and one job only -- to prosecute Hillary Clinton."

Comey also addressed claims by Romanian hacker "Guccifer" that he breached Clinton's personal server. The hacker, Marcel Lehel Lazar, had told Fox News earlier this year that he easily accessed the server, but Comey stated that when questioned, Guccifer admitted he lied about the breach.

Toward the end of the hearing, Comey would not answer directly when asked whether the FBI is investigating the Clinton Foundation. He also stated that Clinton gave individuals who were not cleared access to classified material, though a campaign spokesman countered that the attorneys who sorted through the emails had "Top Secret-level clearance."

The hearing comes as Republicans turn up the pressure on both Comey and Clinton in the wake of the FBI's recommendation not to pursue charges in the email case. House Speaker Paul Ryan (R-Wis.) has called for Comey to release all of the unclassified findings from the agency's investigation and for Director of National Intelligence James Clapper to deny Clinton access to classified information "for the duration of her candidacy for president."

The Clinton campaign has been repeatedly hitting back at Republicans, with a top spokesman calling the bid to deny her access to classified information a "stunt" and the campaign stating that Republicans had voiced "nothing but confidence" in Comey before his announcement earlier this week.

Comey's decision, and the way he delivered it, infuriated Republicans who felt that the FBI director, in his unusually detailed and critical televised statement Tuesday, had laid out a sufficient basis for prosecution. In a stinging assessment of her email practices as secretary of state, Comey rebuked Clinton and her aides for being "extremely careless" in their handling of classified information. However, he also stated that there was no evidence anyone willfully or intentionally mishandled classified information.

Title: Congressional Leaders Disagree on Obama's Surveillance Reform, Praise NSA Programs

Article:

Congressional leaders have expressed differing opinions regarding President Obama's efforts to overhaul U.S. surveillance programs, with some criticizing the president for not going far enough to protect Americans' privacy, while others argue that certain aspects of the current system are necessary for national security.

On Sunday, the leaders of both the House and Senate intelligence committees pushed back against President Obama's assertion that the government should cede control of Americans' phone records. The president, under pressure to calm the controversy over government spying, suggested on Friday that bulk phone data should be stored outside the government to reduce the risk of abuse. However, Obama did not specify who should control the data, instead directing the Attorney General and Director of National Intelligence to find a solution within 60 days.

Rep. Mike Rogers (R-Mich.), chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, expressed concern about the uncertainty created by the president's decision. "We really needed a decision on Friday, and what we got was lots of uncertainty," Rogers told CBS's "Face the Nation." He added that this new level of uncertainty is already having an impact on the country's ability to protect Americans by finding terrorist threats.

President Obama also announced that he will require a special judge's advance approval before intelligence agencies can examine someone's data and will force analysts to keep their searches closer to suspected terrorists or organizations. However, Sen. Dianne Feinstein (D-Calif.), chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, expressed concern that this could hinder the program's ability to provide instantaneous information to disrupt potential terrorist plots.

Under the surveillance program, the NSA gathers phone numbers called and the length of conversations, but not the content of the calls. The NSA sometimes needs to tap those records to find people linked to suspected terrorists, according to Obama. However, he believes the bulk data should eventually be stored somewhere outside the government's hands. This could mean finding a way for phone companies to store the records, though some companies have balked at the idea, or it could mean creating a third-party entity to hold the records.

Sen. Patrick Leahy (D-Vt.), chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, has proposed ending the NSA's bulk data collection program, putting him at odds with his fellow Democrat Feinstein on the issue. Leahy suggested to Fox News Sunday that the chamber will continue to look at legislation to make its own changes, and the final product will be impacted by Attorney General Eric Holder's testimony on January 29 before the Judiciary Committee.

Leahy expressed concern that Americans have given up too much privacy in exchange for intelligence-gathering on terrorism. "There's still going to be legislation on this," Leahy told Fox News Sunday. However, he suggested he might not fight the president on allowing the NSA's surveillance programs to continue, stating, "I think we have a way that we could do this... But you still have to have some checks and balances, or you have a government that can run amok."

Title: Seven Key Points to Watch in Stormy Daniels' Interview with CBS's "60 Minutes"

Article:

Stormy Daniels, the adult-film actress who alleges an affair with President Donald Trump in 2006, is set to appear on CBS's "60 Minutes" this Sunday, raising questions about what she might reveal. The interview's contents remain a mystery, even to Daniels' lawyer, Michael Avenatti. Here are seven key points to watch for in the interview:

1. Nondisclosure Agreement (NDA) Details: Daniels has never publicly discussed the NDA that allegedly bars her from speaking about her alleged affair with Trump. The existence of such a document was confirmed in a lawsuit filed by Daniels earlier this month, which argues that it is invalid because it was never co-signed by Trump himself. It remains unclear whether Daniels will discuss the details of the agreement in the "60 Minutes" interview.

2. Payment Discussion: Daniels has implied that she was paid $130,000 by Trump's personal attorney, Michael Cohen, weeks before the 2016 presidential election to keep quiet about the alleged affair. Speaking openly about her claims would violate the terms of the disputed NDA, potentially subjecting Daniels to legal penalties.

3. NDA Termination: There is speculation that Daniels could toss out the NDA completely in her "60 Minutes" interview, providing details about her alleged relationship with the president.

4. Evidence of Affair: Avenatti has hinted that video or photographic evidence of Daniels' alleged affair with Trump exists. He has suggested that Daniels may have retained such material, potentially revealing it in the interview.

5. Trump's Knowledge of Payment: The payment made by Cohen is a central point of contention. While Cohen has insisted that the money came from his personal funds and that Trump was never made aware of the transaction, Avenatti has argued otherwise.

6. Motives for Speaking Now: Daniels' lawsuit claims she expressed interest in discussing the alleged affair publicly in 2016 after The Washington Post published a 2005 "Access Hollywood" tape in which Trump could be heard boasting about groping and kissing women without their permission. It remains unclear why Daniels chose to speak about the affair now.

7. Legal Consequences: Trump's legal team has already signaled they are willing to fight Daniels on her claims. They reportedly asked for a temporary restraining order against her last month and have asked to transfer the lawsuit from California state court to a federal court in Los Angeles. The response of Trump and his lawyers to the interview after it airs will be closely watched.

Title: Karl Rove's Remarks on Hillary Clinton's Health Sparks Controversy

Article:

Karl Rove, a prominent Republican strategist, has sparked controversy with his recent comments suggesting that former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton may have suffered a brain injury. Clinton, a potential Democratic presidential candidate, had been hospitalized in December 2012 due to a blood clot following a fall.

In response to Rove's remarks, made at a conference last week, Clinton's husband, former President Bill Clinton, stated, "She works out every week, she's strong, she's doing great. As far as I can tell, she's in better shape than I am. She certainly seems to have more stamina now."

Rove, who is a Fox News Channel contributor, questioned Clinton's health during the conference, citing her wearing glasses after the incident, which are typically used for people with traumatic brain injuries. Clinton's health has been a topic of discussion since the 2012 incident, which prevented her from testifying before Congress about the Benghazi attack.

Clinton's spokesman, Nick Merrill, responded to Rove's comments, stating, "Karl Rove has deceived the country for years, but there are no words for this level of lying. She is 100%."

Rove later defended his comments, stating that it is legitimate to question a potential presidential candidate's health. He clarified that he did not say Clinton had brain damage but had undergone a serious health episode in December 2012.

Clinton's health has been a recurring issue in her political career, with the 2012 incident not being the first time she dealt with blood clots. In 1998, while campaigning for Sen. Chuck Schumer, Clinton suffered a large blood clot behind her right knee and was hospitalized. In 2009, she fractured her right elbow after falling as Secretary of State and was treated at George Washington University Hospital.

Age has often been a campaign issue, with both parties using it to their advantage. In the 1992 presidential race, Bill Clinton's campaign portrayed incumbent George H.W. Bush as old and out of touch. Then-President Ronald Reagan famously turned the issue on its head in 1984 by telling voters during a debate with challenger Walter Mondale that "I am not going to exploit, for political purposes, my opponent's youth and inexperience."

Following Rove's appearance on Fox News, Merrill released a new statement, stating, "From the moment this happened 17 months ago, the Right has politicized her health. First they accused her of faking it, now they've resorted to the other extreme -- and are flat out lying. Even this morning, Karl Rove is still all over the map and is continuing to get the facts wrong. But he does not care, because all he wants to do is inject the issue into the echo chamber, and he's succeeding."

Title: Federal Court Rulings Threaten Trump's Healthcare Agenda, Leaving 2020 Election Outcome Uncertain

Article:

In a series of recent court rulings, President Donald Trump's efforts to dismantle the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as "Obamacare," have faced setbacks. Two federal judges in Washington, D.C. blocked parts of Trump's health care agenda, including work requirements for some low-income people on Medicaid and new small business health plans that do not provide full benefits required by the ACA.

The most significant case, a federal court ruling in Texas last December, declared the ACA unconstitutional and called for its complete dismantling. This ruling is currently on appeal. At the urging of the White House, the Justice Department has stated it will support the Texas judge's position and argue for the complete elimination of the ACA.

However, the litigation process could take months, or even longer, to resolve, and there is no guarantee that Trump will achieve the desired outcomes before the 2020 election. Economist Gail Wilensky, who headed Medicare under former Republican President George H.W. Bush, stated, "Was this a good week for the Trump administration? No."

The ACA's dismantling could create significant challenges if it is struck down entirely. In such a scenario, Congress would face an arduous task of passing a comprehensive health overhaul to replace it, a task that both Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Trump may not be able to agree on. The failed attempt to repeal "Obamacare" in 2017 proved to be toxic for congressional Republicans in the 2018 midterm elections, and they are unlikely to repeat the effort.

Thomas Barker, an attorney with the law firm Foley Hoag, who served as a top lawyer at the federal Health and Human Services department under former Republican President George W. Bush, stated, "It seems to me that you can resolve this issue more narrowly than by striking down the ACA."

The Texas case against the ACA is expected to reach the Supreme Court. Trump has stated that the case "probably ends up in the Supreme Court," and that the Republicans will "end up being the party of health care." However, there is no sign that his administration has a comprehensive health care plan, and there does not seem to be a consensus among Republicans in Congress.

In addition to the Texas case, other health care cases are also facing challenges in lower courts. U.S. District Court Judge Reed O'Connor in Fort Worth, Texas, ruled that the repeal of the ACA's fines for being uninsured knocked the constitutional foundation out from under the entire law. This ruling is being appealed by attorneys general from Democratic-led states to the 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in New Orleans.

U.S. District Court Judge James E. Boasberg in Washington, D.C., last week blocked Medicaid work requirements in Kentucky and Arkansas approved by the Trump administration. The judge questioned whether the requirements were compatible with Medicaid's central purpose of providing "medical assistance" to low-income people.

U.S. District Court Judge John D. Bates last week struck down the administration's health plans for small business and sole proprietors, which allowed less generous benefits than required by the ACA. Bates found that administration regulations creating the plans were "clearly an end-run" around the Obama health law and also ran afoul of other federal laws governing employee benefits.

The administration has stated it disagrees but has not formally announced an appeal. Other challenges facing the administration include regulations that bar federally funded family planning clinics from referring women for abortions and a rule that allows employers with religious and moral objections to opt out of offering free birth control to women workers as a preventive care service.

Title: Republican Gaetz Introduces Legislation to Deport Illegal Aliens During National Emergency Due to Communicable Disease

Article:

Republican Florida Representative Matt Gaetz has introduced legislation, titled the Protect American Nationals During Emergencies by Mitigating the Immigration Crisis Act (PANDEMIC Act), which would require the deportation of all illegal aliens under U.S. custody during a national emergency declared due to a communicable disease.

In a statement shared with Fox News on Wednesday, Gaetz stated, "It is unconscionable that at a time when we should be working together as Americans, Democrats are working to socially engineer our country and advance their legislative priorities." He continued, "The PANDEMIC Act puts Americans first by requiring that all illegal aliens be deported during a pandemic, ensuring our resources are used to benefit and protect American citizens."

The PANDEMIC Act is a response to legislation filed by New Jersey Senator Cory Booker and Washington Representative Pramila Jayapal, both Democrats, which called on federal immigration authorities to release detainees and stop targeting illegal aliens who are believed to not pose a substantial public safety risk.

In March, a group of House Democrats, led by Minnesota Representative Ilhan Omar, requested that Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) freeze all deportations in response to the coronavirus pandemic.

Gaetz referenced the actions taken by the Mexican government, which has nearly repatriated all of the illegal aliens in its custody to prevent migrant detention centers from becoming hotbeds for outbreaks. He stated, "I think we should love our country at least as much as Mexico loves theirs."

The Trump administration has scaled back its immigration enforcement efforts in some ways, with ICE announcing it would focus more on individuals who pose a greater public safety threat, and the agency has released hundreds of immigrants at risk of coronavirus complications. However, the administration has increased enforcement operations in other areas, such as closing the northern and southern borders off to all "non-essential" traffic, immediately turning back illegal entrants, and President Donald Trump has threatened visa sanctions on any country that refuses to accept deportees from the United States.

Title: House Oversight Committee Accuses FBI of Stonewalling Investigation into IRS and Conservative Group

Article:

The House Oversight and Government Reform Committee's chief investigator, Rep. Darrell E. Issa, has accused the FBI of obstructing an inquiry into whether the FBI and the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) targeted the conservative group True the Vote for special scrutiny. Rep. Jim Jordan, another member of the committee, is also involved in the investigation.

The committee has been investigating the IRS for six months, following an internal auditor's report in May that revealed the tax agency inappropriately targeted tea party groups seeking tax-exempt status. The IRS promised to clean up its operations, and Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. ordered the FBI to open a criminal investigation.

However, the FBI has not released any information about its investigation into the IRS, and has reportedly rescinded an offer for an in-person briefing with the assistant director in charge of the investigation. This reversal, after consulting with the Justice Department, suggests political meddling, according to Issa and Jordan.

In their letter to FBI Director James B. Comey Jr., Issa and Jordan warned that if they don't receive the information, they will use "compulsory" means. The FBI has declined to comment, stating it will respond in writing. The Justice Department has referred inquiries about its involvement to the FBI.

Catherine Engelbrecht, an officer in the King Street Patriots, which was seeking status as a 501 (c) (4) social welfare organization, and True the Vote, which was seeking status as a 501 (c) (3) charity, has claimed that she and her husband faced an occupational safety investigation into their company, an IRS audit of their company, repeated rounds of IRS questions about True the Vote's activities, and six inquiries from the FBI about the King Street Patriots.

True The Vote was granted nonprofit status this fall, but the King Street Patriots is still waiting. The group received another round of questions from the IRS in August, according to Cleta Mitchell, an attorney for True the Vote and counsel to the ActRight Legal Foundation.

Issa and Jordan began pressing the FBI for information when former Director Robert S. Mueller III was unable to give any details, just days after Eric H. Holder Jr. assigned the FBI to investigate. The congressmen wanted to be kept in the loop as part of their oversight duties, and sent a letter in September asking for more information on the broad IRS investigation and why the FBI had been looking into True the Vote and the King Street Patriots.

In response, the FBI provided brief details about the broader IRS investigation, but did not mention Catherine Engelbrecht's situation. The FBI stated that Assistant Director Valeria Parlave, who oversees investigations opened by the Washington field office, was in charge, and had 11 special agents and one forensic accountant working for her. The documents Issa is seeking are part of the ongoing investigation and therefore "can not be released at this time."

In a follow-up conversation with committee investigators last month, FBI official Monique Kelso again refused to provide documents but said she would make Ms. Parlave available for a briefing. When the investigators emailed to follow up, one of her colleagues, Kirk Melquist, said he had run the idea by the Justice Department and was awaiting guidance. In a follow-up conversation on November 20, Ms. Kelso rescinded the offer of a briefing.

Issa and Jordan claim that Ms. Kelso denied getting pressure from the Justice Department, but Mr. Melquist wouldn't say one way or the other. The congressmen suggest that senior Department of Justice officials may have inappropriately interfered. They have sent copies of their latest letter to the two top senators on the Senate Judiciary Committee, urging them to give extra scrutiny to Peter Kadzik, one of the Justice Department officials Ms. Kelso informed of the committee's request for a briefing. Kadzik is up for a promotion within the Justice Department, and his nomination must pass Senate scrutiny.

Title: Government Shutdown Negotiations Stall as Shutdown Enters Second Day

Article:

The first day of government shutdown negotiations has proven unproductive, with the U.S. Congress failing to make any significant progress in resolving the impasse. While President Trump met with some Republican lawmakers at the White House, discussions in Congress were largely stalled.

The House of Representatives convened and Speaker Paul D. Ryan immediately adjourned the chamber, preventing any floor action. The Senate held a session for over three hours, but the floor time was largely uneventful. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell concluded the session by announcing that lawmakers would be sent home for Christmas, signaling that the shutdown will persist until at least Thursday.

"It's really simple," McConnell said. "Sixty votes in the Senate, a majority in the House, and President Trump's signature. That's what we need." However, the two sides seem to be growing further apart rather than closer.

President Trump canceled his plans to spend Christmas in Florida, and the first lady returned from her trip ahead of schedule. Senate Minority Leader Charles E. Schumer stated that Mr. Trump must abandon his border wall ambitions before Democrats will agree to reopen the government.

"If you want to open the government, you must abandon the wall, plain and simple," Schumer said on the Senate floor. Democrats believe the president, who has long threatened a government shutdown, will be held accountable by voters.

Mr. Trump, for his part, claimed there was a lot of "fake news" about the shutdown, but did not specify what aspects of the coverage he found objectionable. More than 25 percent of the government that is funded by discretionary spending has run out of funding, with the effects not being felt by most government workers until Wednesday due to the weekend and the upcoming Christmas holidays.

Approximately 800,000 employees are in the departments and agencies that lost funding. Of these, 420,000 are considered essential and must continue working, although they will not be paid until the shutdown ends. The remaining 380,000 employees will be furloughed.

The Senate passed a bill on Friday to ensure that furloughed workers will still be paid for the time they were out of work. This legislation has not yet passed the House, although past major shutdowns have ended with workers being compensated for the time they did not work.

The primary point of contention in negotiations is President Trump's demand for $5 billion in border wall funding. The White House had signaled earlier this week that the president would sign a bill without it, but he reversed his position on Thursday and threatened a veto unless he received the funding. Most Republicans have supported Mr. Trump, while Democrats appear almost unanimous in their opposition to him.

Title: Conservative New York Times Columnist Bret Stephens Deactivates Twitter Account After George Washington University Professor's Comment

Article:

Conservative New York Times columnist Bret Stephens announced the deactivation of his Twitter account on Tuesday, following a comment made by a George Washington University professor, David Karpf. In an email to Karpf and the provost of George Washington University, Stephens expressed his displeasure over Karpf's tweet referring to him as a "bedbug."

The email exchange followed reports of a bedbug outbreak in The New York Times' midtown Manhattan newsroom on Monday. In his email, Stephens wrote, "Someone just pointed out a tweet you wrote about me, calling me a 'bedbug.' I'm often amazed about the things supposedly decent people are prepared to say about other people—people they've never met—on Twitter. I think you've set a new standard."

Stephens then invited Karpf to visit his home, meet his wife and children, and call him a "bedbug" to his face. He continued, "That would take some genuine courage and intellectual integrity on your part. I promise to be courteous no matter what you have to say. Maybe it will make you feel better about yourself."

Karpf shared the email on Twitter, which quickly went viral. In a subsequent tweet, Karpf remarked, "It got 9 likes and 0 retweets. I did not @ him. He does not follow me. He is deeply offended that I called him a metaphorical bedbug."

Karpf's tweet sharing the email received more than 8,000 retweets and over 52,000 likes.

Stephens, who is also an MSNBC contributor, later noted that the offer to Karpf to visit his home was a "standing invitation" and that the professor could also bring his spouse.

The New York Times' Stephens' response to the bedbug comment drew criticism on social media, with some users commenting that he was "roasted" for his reaction. One user wrote, "Dish it out but can't take it." The specifics of the bedbug outbreak at The New York Times' newsroom were not immediately available.

Title: President Obama's Strategy Amid Sequester: Public Engagement and Bipartisan Compromise

Article:

President Barack Obama's strategy to address the sequester, a series of automatic spending cuts, has entered a critical phase as the cuts have taken effect. The president now finds himself in an awkward position, advocating for the cuts' impact to be felt as he and his administration predicted, while also aiming to mitigate their real-world impact.

The sequester, a result of the seemingly endless budget wars, threatens to dominate Obama's second term. Before the cuts began, the president and his top aides were accused of stretching the truth about the impact of the cuts, fueling criticism that the nation can afford budget trims.

The president's strategy for restoring the latest cuts hinges on public engagement and pressure on Congress to reject cuts to government services. In a recent address, Obama stated, "The question is, can the American people help persuade their members of Congress to do the right thing?"

If the public pressure forces the GOP-led House to capitulate, Obama may yet win the war with tea party forces that have significantly influenced his presidency. If he loses this battle, however, he may face perpetual spending crises through the 2014 congressional elections, potentially leading to deeper spending cuts and the exclusion of new tax revenues.

White House economic adviser Gene Sperling stated, "My belief is that as this pain starts to gradually spread to communities affected by military spending, to children who need mental health services, to people who care about our border security, I believe that more Republican colleagues who are concerned about this harm to their constituents will choose bipartisan compromise on revenue-raising tax reform with serious entitlement reform."

Republicans face their own challenges regarding the sequester, both in substance and messaging. House Speaker John Boehner has expressed concerns about the sequester's impact on Defense spending, and today stated he was unsure whether it would "hurt the economy or not."

Other Republicans, including those aligned with the tea party, view the sequester as a step toward fiscal sanity. Rep. Steve Scalise (R-La.) last week called the sequester "a big victory" for the GOP.

The one point Republicans are not willing to compromise on is taxes. This seems to close off avenues for compromise; any plan to replace the sequester, the president is saying, must include ridding the tax code of loopholes that primarily benefit the wealthy.

In his Friday news conference, Obama admitted an extraordinary truth: that he lacks the direct powers to address the current state of affairs in Washington. "What more do you think I should do?" he asked reporters, not entirely rhetorically.

There are no easy answers to that question. With a policy in effect that was designed to be so awful as to force an alternative, all Obama and his critics can do is wait.

Title: Miss Michigan 2019 Stripped of Title over Political Views Dispute

Article:

Miss Michigan 2019 winner Kathy Zhu has been disqualified from participating in any Miss World America (MWA) events due to alleged offensive and insensitive social media posts, according to a letter from MWA's State/National/Chief Director. Zhu, who claims the decision is a result of her conservative political views, shared a copy of the letter on her Twitter account.

The letter states that Zhu violated MWA's rules and conditions regarding good character, citing her refusal to try on a hijab in 2018, a tweet about black-on-black gun violence, and "insensitive" statistical tweets.

In 2018, Zhu reportedly refused to wear an Islamic headscarf during World Hijab Day at her college campus, stating that the hijab is used to oppress women in certain Muslim countries. Townhall.com reports that Zhu also tweeted, "Did you know the majority of black deaths are caused by other blacks? Fix problems within your own community before blaming others."

Zhu defends the tweets, stating, "I am so glad the story got brought into the public eye and the media because this is so much bigger than pageantry. This is about an organization discriminating against people with different opinions. Calling people racist when they’re not. Little attacks like that really diminish the value and truth of the word racism."

Zhu argues that the situation is not just about beauty pageants but about an organization discriminating against individuals with differing opinions. She expressed her gratitude for the support she has received and stated, "There should not just be diversity of skin color, there should be diversity of thought and of mindset, political affiliation, and I’m so glad to be the voice of this right now."

Zhu said she was emotional when she first received the messages from MWA but is thankful for the support she has received. She added, "I hope that other pageant organizations can really learn from this story and situation. Do not discriminate others based on opinions. I will still stand firm, stand my ground, and I’m going to still continue to fight for what I believe in."

Title: Climate Change and Typhoon Haiyan: A Closer Look at the Science and Reality

Article:

The Philippines, in the aftermath of Typhoon Haiyan, has been grappling with the devastating effects of the storm. The country's representative to the United Nations expressed a heartfelt plea for action against climate change, stating, "We can stop this madness. Right now, right here." However, the feasibility of implementing the measures to halt climate change, as desired, is a topic of debate.

Bjorn Lomborg, a Danish author and statistician, has repeatedly emphasized that the cost of implementing the proposed climate change mitigation strategies would be astronomical, potentially causing economic collapse and yielding marginal results at best. In other words, the financial burden of the desired programs is beyond the means of many nations.

Currently, carbon emissions in the United States are at 1994 levels, and emissions have decreased in most parts of the globe due to the economic downturn. Additionally, the global warming trend has stagnated for the past ten years, and some climate scientists predict it could remain paused for another 20 years. The future climate trajectory remains uncertain, making it challenging to attribute a single event, such as Typhoon Haiyan, to global warming.

Furthermore, the occurrence of hurricanes and tornadoes has decreased significantly this year. As of Tuesday morning, no hurricanes had formed in 2023, and tornado activity in 2013 is at record low levels. Heatwaves are also fewer and milder than last year, according to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA). The causes of these weather patterns are attributed to factors such as luck, shifts in the high-altitude jet stream, African winds, and dust.

The question arises as to whether human intervention can control local weather patterns, or if the influence of CO2 on weather events is being overstated. Given the ongoing debate about the settled state of climate science, it is essential to continue learning about our climate and its intricacies.

In conclusion, while the connection between a single trace gas like CO2 and extreme weather events like Typhoon Haiyan is a topic of ongoing research and debate, it is crucial to acknowledge the complexity of climate science and the need for continued study and understanding.

Title: House Republicans Introduce Permanent Tax Cuts Legislation Ahead of Midterm Elections

Article:

House Republicans have announced legislation aimed at making permanent last year's tax cuts, a move intended to highlight the surging economy and the party's role in its growth before the November midterm elections. The three bills, collectively known as Tax Reform 2.0, would make permanent individual tax breaks, boost incentives for retirement savings, and provide more lenient tax treatment for startups and small businesses.

The legislation, if passed, would prevent individual tax breaks from expiring in eight years, while also increasing incentives for retirement savings and offering more favorable tax treatment to startups and small businesses. According to Rep. Kevin Brady, Texas Republican and chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, the new system has led to significant job growth, larger paychecks, and a tax code that benefits families and American businesses.

The bills are expected to face a Democratic filibuster in the Senate, making them more of a political statement than a policy accomplishment. The lack of a budget to protect the legislation from the filibuster increases the likelihood of its failure in the Senate. The Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a left-leaning think tank, estimates that the cuts would add at least $650 billion to the deficit over the next decade, with most of the savings benefiting wealthier Americans.

Democrats have criticized the tax reform, with Rep. Richard E. Neal of Massachusetts, the top Democrat on Ways and Means, stating that the first Republican tax law has not helped workers, as wages are not keeping pace with inflation, health insurance and prescription drug costs are rising, and companies are laying off workers and shipping jobs overseas.

The tax reform is one of the biggest legislative accomplishments of a Congress controlled by Republicans since President Trump took office. The party is counting on the tax cuts to persuade voters to keep them in power. A Quinnipiac University poll released Monday found that 70 percent of respondents said the U.S. economy is "excellent" or "good," matching the poll's record high.

However, President Trump's approval rating stood at just 38 percent in the same poll, dragged down by perceptions of lack of honesty and leadership. Former President Barack Obama has also criticized Trump's handling of the economy, stating that the recovery started during his administration and that the job numbers are similar to those in 2015 and 2016.

Kevin Hassett, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, has defended Trump's economic record, citing increased small-business optimism, business confidence, real sales, real private nonresidential fixed investment, and core capital goods orders and shipments since Trump took office. Despite these positive economic indicators, Trump's approval rating remains low, and he has faced criticism for his handling of various issues, including the economy.

Title: Donald Trump's Management Style in the White House: A Mixed Outcome

Article:

President Donald Trump has adopted a management style in the White House that mirrors his approach to running his family business, characterized by a lack of rigid organization and a small, loyal staff. This style, however, has yielded mixed results, with the resignation of National Security Advisor Michael Flynn and the withdrawal of Labor Department nominee Andrew Puzder from the confirmation process this week.

Trump's business was known for its small staff, according to journalist David Cay Johnston, author of The Making of Donald Trump. "And except for when he was in trouble with his bankers, he was the absolute ruler of his business empire, which is not at all how the White House works," Johnston says.

The president now presides over a vast federal bureaucracy that he and some of his Cabinet nominees are not familiar with. Trump has expressed frustration with the idea that presidential orders can be blocked by a federal judge and has upended longstanding foreign policy doctrine.

David Cay Johnston describes Trump's approach as "seat of the pants." He contends that Trump is not a great negotiator but is skilled at promoting the idea that he is. Trump gained fame as a businessman on the reality TV show The Apprentice.

This week, the Trump administration was tested when Flynn resigned after making false statements about his conversations with the Russian ambassador. Despite knowing about the false statements for more than 3 weeks before Flynn's resignation, spokesman Sean Spicer maintains that the president acted decisively.

Trump seems comfortable with competing personalities and power centers in the White House, which can generate friction and palace intrigue. However, not everyone views this as a negative aspect. Chris Demuth, a veteran of the Reagan White House, suggests that such competition can lead to wiser decisions.

Demuth, now a distinguished fellow at the conservative Hudson Institute, notes that Reagan and Franklin Roosevelt deliberately pitted staff members against each other, often with creative results. He also shares the president's view that unpredictability is a good thing.

However, unpredictability can also create uncertainty, making it difficult for the president to advance his agenda. "Running government is no different than assembling an automobile, making a movie," says journalist Johnston, who launched the news site DCReport.org. "There are lots of different parts that have to be brought together and coordinated with a knowledge of how do you achieve that. Trump does not have those skills."

The administration is less than one month old, and adjustments could still be made. After the botched rollout of the travel ban, for example, the White House chief of staff reportedly drew up a checklist to ensure future initiatives go through the proper channels. Trump, the improviser, often seems impatient with checklists. But as he once said on The Apprentice, it's important to adapt.

"Often times, things go wrong and there's just not much you can do about it," Trump said. "But a really good leader will step up, take responsibility, and really just find the right solution." The question remains whether Trump himself can learn that lesson from his own political apprenticeship.

Title: U.S. Abstains from U.N. Vote on Israel Settlements, Sparks Controversy

Article:

The United States abstained from a United Nations Security Council vote on Friday, allowing a resolution condemning Israel's settlement expansion in the disputed West Bank, including East Jerusalem, to pass. The move has sparked controversy and criticism from U.S. Republicans and Jewish leaders worldwide.

Secretary of State John Kerry defended the Obama administration's decision, stating that the continued Israeli settlement building risks the "two-state solution" between Israelis and Palestinians, who also lay claim to the region. Kerry emphasized that the "two-state solution" is the only way to ensure Israel's future as a Jewish and democratic state, living in peace and security with its neighbors, and freedom and dignity for the Palestinian people.

The resolution, put forward by four nations, was initially withdrawn under pressure from Israel and the incoming Republican President Donald Trump. Trump expressed his disapproval of the move minutes after the vote, tweeting, "Things will be different after Jan. 20."

Israel's Ambassador Danny Danon stated, "It was to be expected that Israel's greatest ally would act in accordance with the values that we share and that they would have vetoed this disgraceful resolution." House Speaker Paul Ryan, R-Wis., blasted the administration for appearing to undermine America's historic Middle East ally.

The resolution was adopted with 14 votes in favor, after U.S. Ambassador Samantha Power abstained. It is the first resolution the Security Council has adopted on Israel and the Palestinians in nearly eight years. The measure calls on Israel to "immediately and completely cease all settlement activity in occupied territories, including East Jerusalem."

As one of the council's five permanent members, the U.S. has veto power and has used it to shield Israel from condemnatory resolutions. However, the Obama administration has long made clear its opposition to Israeli settlement-building in occupied territory, even though it provides Israel with tens of billions of dollars in assistance annually.

Anne Bayefsky, director of the Touro Institute on Human Rights and the Holocaust and president of Human Rights Voices, stated, "The contention that settlements, and not Palestinian terrorism, is the obstacle to peace is false." Bayefsky argued that seven decades of violent Palestinian rejection of a Jewish state prove otherwise.

Title: Pelosi Urges Boehner to Initiate Debate on Military Force Authorization for President Obama

Article:

House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi (D-CA) has called on Speaker John Boehner (R-OH) to initiate a debate in Congress over granting President Barack Obama a new authorization to use military force to combat Islamic militants. During a breakfast with Bloomberg News reporters and editors in New York on Tuesday, Pelosi stated, "Everybody in the country's talking about it except for us."

This month, Congress, in a rare bipartisan vote, passed Obama's plan to arm and train Syrian rebels. This authorization is set to expire in December during the post-election session of Congress. Speaker Boehner has stated that he is willing to call Congress back into session to vote on authorizing broader military action, but it is up to Obama to make the request.

Pelosi expressed her disapproval of waiting for the president to make a request, stating, "No, if you want to have an authorization that has any constraints on the president, you don't wait for him to write it." The debate over the president's power to combat Islamic State extremists in Iraq and Syria is expected to create a divide in both parties and both chambers of Congress.

Democrats, led by Pelosi, strongly oppose using U.S. ground troops to fight Islamic State, while Republicans, particularly in the House, want a more robust response, including possible ground forces. Yesterday, Boehner stated that the U.S. will have "no choice" but to put American troops on the ground if other nations fail to do so.

Pelosi also expressed concern about a congressional debate over raising the nation's borrowing limit, which is set to expire as early as March. "I'm very concerned about the debt ceiling because many Americans don't understand the importance of meeting the nation's borrowing obligations," said Pelosi.

Although this election year is unlikely to yield many new seats for Democrats this year, Pelosi predicted that her party will win a majority in Congress in 2016.

Title: Discontent with Obamacare Exchanges: High Prices and Technical Issues Deter Half of Users from Re-enrolling

Article:

More than half of households that utilized an Obamacare exchange last year have expressed their intention not to use the portal again during the upcoming sign-up period, according to a survey released Monday by Bankrate.com. This less-than-enthusiastic review for the Affordable Care Act (ACA), which is currently embroiled in another high-profile legal battle, comes less than two weeks before open enrollment resumes.

The survey found that about two in five people cited "much higher prices for health plans" on the exchanges this year as their primary concern. This was the most frequently cited issue among those surveyed.

Approximately a quarter of respondents expressed concern that too many people remain uninsured despite the health care law's implementation, and 21 percent cited technological problems that affected the federal Obamacare website and some state-run exchanges during the initial enrollment period.

Despite this gloomy assessment, more than half of those surveyed reported having a positive experience during the previous enrollment, while 43 percent reported a negative experience.

The Obama administration is aiming for the second round of enrollment, from November 15 to February 15, to continue reducing the nation's uninsured rate. To meet congressional scorekeepers' target of 13 million enrollees in 2015, they will need roughly 7 million existing enrollees to renew their plans and nearly 6 million new enrollees.

Those who can afford coverage but fail to obtain it may be subject to a tax penalty unless they qualify for an exemption. If these individuals avoid the exchanges, it may be because they do not qualify for income-based subsidies and will shop in the off-exchange market.

Gerald Kominski, director of the UCLA Center for Health Policy Research, told Bankrate.com, "That's a reasonable alternative because the law regulates those so-called'mirror' policies to where there aren't significant differences. But I don't think there are any huge bargains there."

Eighteen states, on Monday, sought to protect Obamacare subsidies for those who qualify by opposing high-profile lawsuits that claim the subsidies should only flow to states that set up their own exchanges. In a brief to the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia, they wrote, "There is no plausible reason to believe that Congress intended such a draconian result."

Opponents of the ACA argue that the law reserved income-based credits for customers who use an exchange "established by the state." They interpret this to mean the 16 exchanges set up by the states, and only those. However, the Obama administration contends that the law's framers intended the federal government to act as a stand-in for the states that did not want to run their own insurance portals.

The full D.C. Circuit is considering the case after a three-judge panel ruled against the administration earlier this year. On the same day, the Fourth Circuit ruled in favor of the administration, producing a split in the federal appeals courts. The Supreme Court is expected to decide in the coming days whether it will take up the Fourth Circuit case or wait to see if the D.C. Circuit sides with the administration, eliminating the circuit split and potentially reducing the need for high-court review.

Title: U.S.-China Summit in California: Focus on Personal Relationship Sparks Skepticism

Article:

The upcoming summit between President Obama and China's new president, Xi Jinping, in southern California this weekend has sparked skepticism from some who question the importance of personal rapport between world leaders.
