The summit, which will take place at the Sunnylands estate in Rancho Mirage, California, is expected to cover a broad range of topics, including military and corporate cybersecurity, North Korea, territorial disputes in the South China Sea, and US-China trade.

Despite the extensive agenda, some critics, such as Dean Cheng, a research fellow in Chinese political and security affairs at the Heritage Foundation in Washington, remain unimpressed with the summit's emphasis on building a personal relationship between the two leaders. Cheng, who believes that personal dynamics matter little in defending national interests, anticipates little substance from the summit.

However, the Friday and Saturday summit is built on the premise that the dynamics between leaders do matter, especially in the critical and rapidly evolving relationship between the United States and a rising China. Although Obama and Xi have met before, this will be the first summit between the two presidents, with Xi formally assuming China's presidency in March.

The informal and "untested" format of the summit was chosen to allow the two leaders to get to know each other and cover a broad agenda with as much candor as possible. This format is intended to lay the groundwork for US-China relations in the years ahead.

Some China experts, such as Christopher Johnson, a senior adviser and the Freeman Chair in China Studies at the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Washington, see the upside of trying out a new summit format with the Chinese, especially with a leader who has shown signs of being less rigid and more open to free-wheeling discussion than his predecessors.

Even Chinese officials are cautious about expectations for the summit, with no deliverables, or specific agreements or formal steps forward, expected on the issues the two leaders will discuss. However, the Chinese were open to the less structured format with unusually copious time for unscripted dialogue, perhaps in part because Xi is anxious to demonstrate that a maturing China is ready for the "new type of great power relationship" that Xi is calling for the US and China to adopt.

US officials interpret Xi's desire to refashion US-China relations as recognition of the potential pitfalls the two countries face as China asserts itself on the world economic and security stages, and as the US reasserts its role in the Asia-Pacific region.

Obama has said he intends to place a certain amount of emphasis on the cybersecurity issue, especially after the recent Pentagon-commissioned report that warned that Chinese hackers have accessed the designs for dozens of key US weapons systems. The two leaders will also discuss North Korea, with US officials describing Obama as particularly interested in probing recent signs of a growing Chinese willingness to challenge Pyongyang over its security provocations and funding schemes related to its nuclear program.

The US has recently had encouraging discussions with the Chinese on reining in North Korea, US officials say. They point out that these "good discussions" have taken place even as the two countries have aired their disagreements on cybersecurity issues. This ability to pursue encouraging and problematic discussions at the same time is evidence that the US-China relationship is evolving into something more open and developed, these officials say. It's also the kind of evidence that suggests that the two powers may be ready for the "open and serious discussions" Obama and Xi will at least have ample time for in Rancho Mirage.

Title: Supreme Court to Review Louisiana Abortion Law, Potentially Impacting Abortion Rights

Article:

The Supreme Court has agreed to take up a Louisiana abortion case that could impact the state's abortion clinics and potentially reveal the court's stance on abortion rights in the midst of the 2020 presidential campaign. The justices will examine a Louisiana law requiring doctors who perform abortions to have admitting privileges at a nearby hospital.

The court's new term begins on Monday, but arguments in the Louisiana case will not take place until the winter. A decision is likely to come by the end of June, four months before the presidential election.

In February, the Supreme Court temporarily blocked the Louisiana law from taking effect, with Chief Justice John Roberts joining the court's four liberal justices to put it on hold. Justices Neil Gorsuch and Brett Kavanaugh, who have shifted the court to the right, were among the four conservatives who would have allowed the law to take effect.

The Louisiana case and a separate appeal over an Indiana ultrasound requirement for women seeking an abortion, on which the court took no action Friday, were the most significant of hundreds of pending appeals the justices considered when they met in private on Tuesday.

Both cases involve the standard first laid out by the court in 1992 that while states can regulate abortion, they can't do things that place an "undue burden" on a woman's right to an abortion. The regulations are distinct from other state laws making their way through court challenges that would ban abortions early in a pregnancy.

Louisiana abortion providers and a district judge who initially heard the case said one or maybe two of the state's three abortion clinics would have to close under the new law. There would be at most two doctors who could meet its requirements, they said. However, the appeals court in New Orleans rejected those claims, doubting that any clinics would have to close and saying the doctors had not tried hard enough to establish relationships with local hospitals.

In January, the full appeals court voted 9-6 not to get involved in the case, setting up the Supreme Court appeal. The Hope Medical Group clinic in Shreveport, Louisiana, and two doctors whose identities are not revealed said in their appeal that the justices should strike down the law without even holding arguments because the decision so clearly conflicts with the Texas ruling from 2016.

There was no action on a third abortion-related appeal that involves a challenge to a Chicago ordinance that stops protesters from getting within 8 feet (2.4 meters) of people entering abortion clinics and other health care facilities without their consent. Anti-abortion activists had challenged the Chicago law as a violation of their free speech rights. The federal appeals court in Chicago upheld the law, though grudgingly.

The Supreme Court upheld a similar Colorado law in 2000, but in 2014 struck down a Massachusetts provision that set a fixed 35-foot (10.7-meter) buffer zone outside abortion clinics.

Also on Friday, the court agreed to hear an appeal by energy companies and the Trump administration asking the court to overturn an appeals court ruling and reinstate a permit to allow construction of a natural gas pipeline through two national forests, including parts of the Appalachian Trail. The 605-mile (970-kilometer) pipeline would begin in West Virginia and travel through parts of Virginia and North Carolina. The proposed route, which the administration had approved, would include the George Washington and Monongahela National Forests, as well as a right-of-way across the Appalachian Trail.

Title: Primary Elections in Six States Highlighted Ahead of Midterms

Article:

On Tuesday, voters in six states will participate in primary elections, marking one of the most significant primary election days of the year. NPR's political editor, Charlie Mahtesian, provides a preview of the upcoming races.

In the closely watched primary race in Kentucky, Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell is facing a challenge from the right by political newcomer Matt Bevin. McConnell, who represents the Republican establishment, is matched against Bevin, a businessman. Kentucky is notable as the state where Rand Paul made a significant victory in 2010 with Tea Party support.

Senator McConnell has raised $20 million for his campaign, but his approval ratings are not high. McConnell has run a focused and nearly flawless campaign, while Bevin, as a political newcomer, has made some rookie mistakes. Against a seasoned politician like Mitch McConnell, errors are difficult to overcome.

In addition to the Kentucky Senate race, the Georgia and Oregon Republican primaries are other significant Senate races to follow. The Georgia primary features a crowded Republican field, with Democrats expected to nominate Michelle Nunn, the daughter of former senator Sam Nunn, who is widely considered a top-notch candidate. In Oregon, the primary field is smaller, with two candidates: state representative Jason Conger, who went from homelessness to Harvard Law School, and pediatric neurosurgeon Dr. Monica Wehby.

Regarding House elections, incumbents have not yet faced significant challenges, with only a handful of states having held their primaries so far. By the end of June, when more than half of the states will have voted, a clearer picture may emerge.

In Idaho, an election is receiving attention for all the wrong reasons, with a contentious gubernatorial debate featuring two longshot, fringe candidates. The top candidates for governor, incumbent Governor Butch Otter and the state senator challenging him, are engaged in a competitive race, but their contest took a backseat during the debate.

Title: A Closer Look at the Argument Against Aggregate Campaign Contribution Limits

Article:

In a recent contention, Mr. McCutcheon and the Republican National Committee (R.N.C.) argue that aggregate limits on campaign contributions violate the First Amendment by restricting a contributor's opportunity for political expression. However, this argument has been deemed unconvincing.

To illustrate the implausibility of Mr. McCutcheon's claim, consider his example of contributing $1,776 to each of 25 candidates, totaling $44,400, while being able to give $17.76 to every Republican Congressional candidate. This comparison is likened to developers of the One World Trade Center arguing that the First Amendment grants them the constitutional right to build to a specific height.

The R.N.C. and Mr. McCutcheon claim that they are not challenging all contribution limits but only aggregate limits. However, in practice, this distinction is considered insignificant. If the court were to strike down aggregate limits, a contributor could donate up to the maximum amount to every federal candidate and any political action committee (PAC) that contributes to a candidate. The number of PACs that might contribute to a particular candidate is not limited, potentially allowing for a significant increase in donations.

For instance, if there were 10,000 PACs, all likely to contribute to a specific candidate, Mr. McCutcheon could donate up to the maximum of $5,000 to each PAC, totaling $50 million. This would significantly undermine the longstanding, court-approved scheme of campaign contribution limits.

Justice Antonin Scalia, in another context, described this argument as not a "wolf in sheep's clothing," but rather a "wolf that comes as a wolf." The Supreme Court's willingness to entertain this argument may indicate a desire to eliminate all limits on an individual's donations to a political candidate.

Title: Hillary Clinton Steps Down as Secretary of State, Focuses on Empowerment of Women and Girls

Article:

Hillary Rodham Clinton, the former First Lady and current Secretary of State, has stepped down from her position on Friday, sparking speculation about her potential presidential run. In her tenure as Secretary of State, Clinton is reported to have expanded foreign policy to include the impact on regular people, with a particular focus on empowering women and girls.

Clinton has been credited for her efforts in fighting for education and inclusion in politics for women and girls. As Secretary of State, she is believed to have been the first to focus on empowering women and girls, creating the first Office of Global Women's Issues. This office has worked to highlight the plight of women around the world, including the rape of women as a weapon of war, and has fought for the education of girls in emerging countries.

Clinton also included the United States in the Trafficking in Persons report, an annual review of global efforts to eliminate human trafficking, a form of modern slavery that primarily affects women and girls. She stated, "We believe it is important to keep the spotlight on ourselves. Human trafficking is not someone else's problem. Involuntary servitude is not something we can ignore or hope does not exist in our own communities."

In addition, Clinton created the Office of Global Partnerships, with a focus on empowering women, children, the poor, and the helpless. Her efforts have been marked by a balance of firmness and authority, poise and confidence, and goodwill when appropriate.

Clinton's tenure as Secretary of State is noteworthy for her focus on people rather than just treaties. She has been praised for her diplomatic skills, managing relations with heads of state and dealing with crises as if they were routine. Her legacy is not in the praise of diplomats or dictators, but in her focus on the suffering and aspirations of those affected by the treaties, made or unmade.

As Clinton steps down, the focus shifts to her potential presidential run. In the last century, five of the first eight presidents first served their predecessors as Secretary of State. However, it remains to be seen if Clinton will indeed run for president.

Title: Supreme Court to Review Constitutionality of Voting Rights Act Section 5

Article:

The United States Supreme Court has agreed to hear a case challenging the constitutionality of Section 5 of the Voting Rights Act, a landmark civil rights era law. The case, originating from Shelby County, Alabama, questions whether Congress overstepped its bounds when it reauthorized the Voting Rights Act (VRA) in 2006, arguing that federal oversight of polling stations and election rules primarily in the former Confederacy is too broad and potentially discriminatory.

Supporters of state and local election officials argue that the need for federal oversight should be reconsidered in light of President Obama's reelection, as he lost in most of the so-called Section 5 districts and states. The VRA has been used by the US Department of Justice to challenge new voter ID laws in states such as Texas and South Carolina, which were likened to Jim Crow-era "poll taxes" by Attorney General Eric Holder.

The America that elected and reelected Barack Obama, according to Edward Blum of the Project on Fair Representation, the group that brought the Shelby County case, is far different than when the Voting Rights Act was first enacted in 1965. Blum stated, "Congress unwisely reauthorized a bill that is stuck in a Jim Crow-era time warp."

Shelby County seeks to have Section 5 of the Voting Rights Act declared unconstitutional after the Justice Department nullified a local redistricting effort in Calera, Alabama, which attorneys argue played a role in the defeat of the sole black incumbent on the city council.

The Supreme Court's decision to review the case comes after hints earlier this year that some justices saw "serious constitutional problems" with the Voting Rights Act. In a 2009 case, conservative justices questioned whether the law had done its job so well that it now discriminated against Southern white people.

Opponents of the VRA argue that the playing field is now even, and that it's no longer necessary to punish Southern jurisdictions for past sins. They claim that American people have shown at the polls that the playing field is now even, and that it's no longer necessary to target jurisdictions that were identified as discriminatory more than 40 years ago.

Those defending the need for continued federal oversight cite statistics showing that minorities are less likely to have state identification required by new voter ID laws, thus putting an undue burden on specific groups. They also point to the zest with which Republican legislatures in the South focused on voter fraud ahead of the election, despite studies that show voter fraud is rare.

The future of key VRA enforcement provisions is at stake, with many legal experts believing that conservatives on the court are ready to rethink the law's future. The Supreme Court's decision on the case is expected in the coming months.

Title: Slum-Dwellers in Ahmedabad Receive Eviction Notices Ahead of Trump's Visit

Article:

Slum-dwellers in the city of Ahmedabad, Gujarat, have reportedly received eviction notices from municipal authorities as the state prepares to host US President Donald Trump on February 24. The eviction notices come as the area is being prepared for an event called "Kem Chho Trump," which is similar to the "Howdy Modi" extravaganza organized for the Indian prime minister in Houston last September.

Tejabhai Meda, a 36-year-old laborer who earns approximately Rs 300 ( $ 4.2) per day, expressed shock at the eviction notices. He has lived in the slum for the past 22 years. "I don't know what to do," Meda told a local news outlet. "On one side, the government is saying it is helping poor people in constructing new homes, but here we are being evicted from a piece of land."

Meda, along with 44 other families, was asked by the Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) to leave the plot on Monday, but the municipal body has denied issuing such notices. AMC Commissioner Vijay Nehra stated, "The news report is incorrect and misleading. In fact, it can be called mischievous as it tries to link the issue with 'Namaste Trump' event. There are no plans for any forceful evictions in the near future."

However, an AMC official told the same news outlet that the slum dwellers were "encroaching on government land." Kishore Varna, an AMC official, stated, "We have asked them before as well to clear the site, but they refused, saying we should follow due process and give them notices. And when we issued notices now, everybody is linking the issue with Trump's visit."

Mina Jadhav, general secretary of Majdur Adhikar Manch, a trade union working for unorganized workers in Gujarat, linked the eviction to Trump's visit to Ahmedabad. "The BJP government does not want the world to see that poverty exists in Gujarat. They want Trump and others to see only the big buildings, roads, and that everyone here has toilets and homes," she said.

"They (the government) want to hide the poor people living in slums, that is why it has sent the eviction notices to these families and built a wall to shield Trump from noticing another slum," Jadhav added.

The authorities in Ahmedabad expect to spend 800 to 850 million Indian rupees (approximately $11-12 million) on preparations for Trump's visit, according to Reuters, which reported the information from officials. Trump's visit provides him with an opportunity to woo hundreds of thousands of Indian-American voters ahead of the US presidential election in November. Trump is also expected to visit the humble abode of India's independence leader Mahatma Gandhi in Ahmedabad.

Title: Connecticut Gun Seizure Law: A Response to Workplace Shooting Incident

Article:

In the early hours of March 6, 1998, a tragic incident occurred at the Connecticut State Lottery headquarters, where shooter Matthew Beck took the lives of several coworkers before taking his own life in the parking lot upon the arrival of law enforcement. The event prompted a state representative, Mike Lawlor, who later became the Connecticut governor's criminal justice adviser, to investigate the circumstances that led to the rampage.

Lawlor discovered that Beck had a history of suicide attempts and gun ownership. This revelation led to the realization that there was a lack of a procedure for police to intervene in volatile situations, even when warning signs were present. In response, Lawlor and his colleagues enacted a law a year later, known as Connecticut General Statutes Sec. 29-38c, which allows police to seize firearms from individuals who pose an imminent danger to themselves or others, even if no law has been broken.

The law, which went into effect in 1999, allows for a year-long gun seizure and a mental health evaluation. One of the first individuals to have their firearms seized under this law was Bernard Krzynowek, whose sister reported him to the police during an argument. The police warrant states that Krzynowek's sister claimed he was in possession of guns and "was going to kill her and other relatives." The police seized 39 guns from Krzynowek, who kept the guns for sport, hunting, and protection.

Attorney Rachel Baird, who has represented about a dozen people who had their firearms taken under the gun seizure law, believes none of her clients presented any danger. Baird argues that the law, as written, strikes a balance between second amendment rights and community protection, but notes that police and judges sometimes err on the side of caution.

In the first 10 years after its enactment, more than 2,000 guns were seized under the law, with the majority of complaints coming from spouses. Lawlor is not suggesting the law could have prevented the shootings in Newtown, but he believes it has prevented other crimes.

Criminologist James Alan Fox from Northeastern University states that gun laws are not a guarantee against gun violence. Fox suggests that efforts should also be made to connect with isolated individuals, not just to take their guns away, but to help them.

Since the shooting in Newtown, more people in Connecticut have been reaching out to state agencies, expressing concern about others who may have guns. The Connecticut gun seizure law serves as a response to workplace shootings and other potential acts of violence, aiming to protect individuals and communities while balancing the rights of gun owners.

Title: Bipartisan Support Grows for FASTER Act Addressing Food Allergies in the U.S.

Article:

Bipartisan support for the FASTER (Food Allergy Safety, Treatment, Education, and Research) Act, introduced by Rep. Doris Matsui (D-Calif.) in April, has gained significant ground in Congress. The Act aims to address the food allergy epidemic, which affects approximately 10% of the U.S. population, or 32 million Americans.

Since July, the FASTER Act has seen a 115% increase in congressional support, with 44 co-sponsors. This week, the Problem Solvers Caucus, a bipartisan group of 48 lawmakers, fully endorsed the legislation. The caucus is co-chaired by Reps. Josh Gottheimer (D-N.J.) and Tom Reed (R-N.Y.).

Every three minutes, a food allergy reaction sends another American to the emergency room. A recent study supported by Food Allergy Research & Education (FARE) suggests this statistic is increasing, with medical claims for food-allergy induced anaphylaxis having increased nearly 400% nationwide since 2009.

The FASTER Act aims to combat this trend by enabling major research and data collection initiatives that pave the way for new therapies, treatments, and, eventually, a cure. FARE has been working tirelessly over the last year and a half on legislator education, policy refinement, and advocacy.

The Act also addresses the issue of sesame as an allergen, through more stringent labeling and disclosure requirements. A recent study published in JAMA Network Open found that more than 1.5 million Americans are allergic to sesame, a figure five times higher than the previous estimate. Despite its prevalence, sesame is not currently regulated by the Food Allergen Labeling and Consumer Protection Act (FALCPA), the primary federal law governing how allergens are represented on packaged foods. The FASTER Act would require sesame to be clearly listed on food package labels, addressing this dangerous problem and others.

FARE supports the FASTER Act because it aligns with their mission to improve the quality of life and the health of individuals with food allergies and to provide them hope through the promise of new treatments.

While the growing support for this legislation is a step in the right direction, the work is not done. I encourage all Americans to visit the FARE website to learn more about the food allergy epidemic and to write a letter to their representative to co-sponsor the FASTER Act. I also urge our congressional leaders to sign on to support this important legislation if they have not already. Passage of the FASTER Act is not ordinary legislation; it is hope for the entire food allergy community that groundbreaking treatments are out there and, eventually, a cure.

Lisa Gable is the Chief Executive Officer of FARE, the world's leading food allergy advocacy organization and the largest private funder of food allergy research.

Title: Media's Role in the Covington Catholic Controversy: A Call for Caution in Social Media Reporting

Article:

The recent Covington Catholic controversy, involving a group of high school students wearing MAGA hats and their interaction with a Native American elder, has sparked a heated debate, with many questioning the initial reporting by The Washington Post and subsequent social media reactions.

The Washington Post's initial report, published on Saturday, portrayed the students as surrounding and taunting the Native American elder. However, subsequent investigations and videos have revealed a more complex series of events. The story has since unraveled, with many questioning the one-sided account provided by The Washington Post.

The controversy, fueled by social media, has led to a call for caution in news reporting, particularly on platforms like Twitter. The rapid spread of information, often devoid of context and fact-checking, has been criticized for contributing to the initial mischaracterization of the events.

Twitter, in particular, has been singled out as a significant factor in the media debacle. The platform's real-time nature and the ease with which information can be shared have been cited as contributing factors to the spread of misinformation and the rapid formation of public opinion.

Critics argue that Twitter's design encourages snap judgments, viral groupthink, and outrage, often leading to the amplification of the worst aspects of human nature. The platform's role in shaping public opinion and the potential harm it can cause has led some to call for a dramatic reduction in its use by the media.

While the human tendency towards mob mentality and the spread of misinformation is not new, the ease with which it can occur on social media platforms like Twitter has raised concerns. The Covington Catholic controversy serves as a stark reminder of the potential dangers of relying on social media for news and information.

In conclusion, the Covington Catholic controversy highlights the need for caution and fact-checking in social media reporting. The rapid spread of information, often devoid of context and fact-checking, can lead to misinformation and the rapid formation of public opinion. The role of Twitter in shaping public opinion and the potential harm it can cause has led some to call for a dramatic reduction in its use by the media.

Title: Michelle Obama's Unconventional Approach and Future Plans

Article:

Michelle Obama, the former First Lady of the United States, has been known for her candid and unconventional approach to public life. During her time at the University of Chicago, she criticized the institution for its perceived isolation from the black South Side community, an area where she grew up.

In her career, Mrs. Obama's ability to discuss difficult and sensitive issues, such as medical trials on poor black Chicagoans, was one of her strengths. She often defied societal expectations, as seen in her 2004 interview with The Chicago Tribune, where she criticized the traditional order of priorities for men and women.

During her husband's presidential campaign, she spoke out about the importance of communication and reconciliation, urging women to mend broken relationships. In 2007, she addressed a mostly female crowd in South Carolina, encouraging them to reconcile with women in their lives who had been estranged due to various reasons.

As she prepares to leave the White House, Mrs. Obama is reportedly focusing on wrapping up her eight years in office as smoothly as possible. At 53 years old, she aims to reevaluate her life after her tenure as First Lady.

According to longtime aides to the Obamas, Michelle Obama is still determining her public persona post-White House. They suggest that she may follow in the footsteps of Laura Bush, known for her restrained approach, as a means of preserving her popularity and authority.

Mrs. Obama has expressed a desire to step away from the public eye, as it was for Mrs. Bush after her time in the White House. Leaving the spotlight could provide relief, as it allowed Mrs. Bush to simply be after years of hypervigilance.

Given the potential for backlash, especially from prominent Trump supporters, some argue that Mrs. Obama may choose to maintain a calibrated tone to avoid jeopardizing what she has worked to build. Her subtle methods of conveying her viewpoint, such as hints, invitations, art, and clothing, have been effective in the past, and her beliefs have been clear without directly addressing controversial topics.

Title: Supreme Court Justice Anthony Kennedy Temporarily Halts Same-sex Marriage in Idaho, Allows Nevada Marriages to Proceed

Article:

In a surprising turn of events, Supreme Court Justice Anthony Kennedy temporarily halted a federal appeals court ruling that voided same-sex marriage bans in Nevada and Idaho on Wednesday. However, hours later, Kennedy narrowed the stay to the Idaho cases, effectively allowing same-sex marriages to proceed in Nevada.

Acting on an emergency application from Idaho officials, Kennedy issued a one-page order Wednesday morning, staying the ruling by the 9th Circuit U.S. Court of Appeals, which was released Tuesday. Kennedy's order offered no rationale for the stay but instructed those challenging the gay-marriage bans to file a response by Thursday afternoon to Idaho's request.

Before Kennedy acted, it appeared the new 9th Circuit decision would bring the number of states recognizing same-sex marriage to 32 in short order and to 35 if the courts applied the ruling in three other 9th Circuit states that have not permitted gay marriage: Arizona, Alaska, and Montana. However, in the wake of the second order from Kennedy on Wednesday, it appeared that the tally of states allowing same-sex marriage would instead rise to 31.

The second order, which provided no rationale, came after a Nevada group involved in the legal battle there, the Coalition for Protection of Marriage, filed an application asking to have the effect of the 9th Circuit's ruling in Nevada halted (or re-halted). There was no immediate action on that request.

This post has been updated with details of Kennedy's second order and the new application from the Nevada same-sex marriage opponents.

Title: Christine Blasey Ford Agrees to Testify Before Senate Panel, Lawyers Say

Article:

Christine Blasey Ford, the woman who has accused Supreme Court nominee Judge Brett Kavanaugh of sexual assault, has agreed to testify before the Senate Judiciary Committee, her attorneys said Saturday. Bipartisan negotiators have tentatively agreed to work toward a Thursday hearing before the Senate Judiciary Committee with Kavanaugh and Ford, but talks continue on a final agreement, according to multiple congressional sources.

Senate Judiciary Chairman Chuck Grassley, R-Iowa, gave Ford a deadline of 2:30 p.m. on Saturday to decide whether she would testify before the panel next week. If she did not comply, the committee would go ahead with a vote on Kavanaugh's nomination on Monday.

In an email to the committee, lawyers for Ford said that while she has agreed to "provide first-hand knowledge of Kavanaugh's sexual misconduct," they are disappointed "with the leaks and bullying that have tainted the process." The timing and terms of the hearing are still unclear, as negotiations continue between Ford's attorneys and the Senate Judiciary Committee. In a letter, Ford's lawyers said they were "hopeful that we can reach agreement on details."

The email also indicated that Michael R. Bromwich, former inspector general of the Justice Department, has joined Ford's team of lawyers. Bromwich currently represents former FBI Deputy Director Andrew McCabe, who was fired earlier this year.

Ford alleges Kavanaugh groped her and tried to forcibly remove her clothes during a house party in Bethesda, Md., in the early 1980s. Kavanaugh has denied the allegation and said he would appear before the committee next week.

"Brett Kavanaugh has been clear from the beginning—he categorically and unequivocally denies this allegation and is eager to testify publicly to defend his integrity and clear his good name," White House spokesperson Kerri Kupec said in a statement. "On Monday, Brett Kavanaugh met with Committee counsels to answer questions subject to criminal penalties and offered to testify publicly Tuesday morning. Since then, we have heard about different dates, conditions, and ever-changing schedules, but today we appear no closer to a fair hearing. But one thing has remained consistent: Brett Kavanaugh remains ready, willing, and eager to testify as soon as possible."

Politics: Sen. Grassley Gives Kavanaugh Accuser More Time To Consider Options
As the Saturday deadline approached, NBC News reported that Garrett Ventry, a communications aide on the Senate Judiciary Committee who had been helping lead the response to Ford's claim against Kavanaugh, was stepping down after evidence surfaced that he was fired from a previous job partly because of sexual harassment allegations against him. Ventry denied any past "allegations of misconduct," according to NBC News. He told The Washington Post that he resigned "in order to not be a distraction" as Republicans in the Senate continue to work on getting Kavanaugh confirmed. This abrupt resignation is one more point in the chaotic timeline of Kavanaugh's confirmation struggle.

Title: Zelensky Denies Blackmail in Trump Call Amid Impeachment Inquiry

Article:

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky has stated that there was "no blackmail" in a phone call with Donald Trump that is at the center of a possible impeachment inquiry against the Republican president. Speaking to reporters in Kiev on Thursday, Mr. Zelensky said, "This is not corruption, it was just a call."

The call, which prompted a whistleblower complaint and the Democratic impeachment inquiry, took place on July 25. Mr. Trump denies withholding US aid while pressuring Ukraine to investigate political rival Joe Biden. Impeachment is a process by which Congress can vote to oust a president, though it requires support from a majority of both chambers and, as such, is currently thought unlikely to pass the Republican-controlled Senate.

During the call, Mr. Trump asked Mr. Zelensky to investigate Joe Biden, who is a Democratic frontrunner for next year's White House election. His son, Hunter Biden, held a lucrative board position in 2014 with a Ukrainian gas firm, Burisma, that found itself under scrutiny from a former prosecutor general. As US vice-president, Mr. Biden, like other Western officials, put pressure on Ukraine in 2016 to have the prosecutor fired, citing corruption concerns. Ukrainian officials have said there is no evidence of wrongdoing by the Bidens.

A rough transcript of the call released by the White House shows the conversation's content. The whistleblower who filed a complaint over the call reportedly wrote in a memo that a White House official who listened to the phone discussion described it as "crazy" and "frightening." The official was "visibly shaken by what had transpired" in the call, according to the memo.

A poll by Fox News, which is generally supportive of the president, found that 51% of voters are in favor of impeaching Mr. Trump and removing him from office. The results show 85% of Democrats were in favor of impeachment, while 82% of Republicans were against it. Mr. Trump has criticized the poll's results on Twitter, writing, "Whoever their pollster is, they suck."

Later on Thursday, the president is hosting his first rally since the launch of the impeachment inquiry in Minneapolis, Minnesota. Protests are expected against Mr. Trump, who lost the state by a narrow margin to Hillary Clinton in 2016.

The whistleblower whose complaint fueled the impeachment inquiry had a "prior working relationship with a current 2020 Democratic contender" and is a registered Democrat, a source familiar with the matter told CBS News on Thursday. The details of this working relationship or the candidate are unclear. Lawyers representing the anonymous whistleblower said in a statement their client "has never worked for or advised a political candidate, campaign, or party." They also noted that, as a government employee, their client has interacted with candidates from both parties "in their roles as elected officials - not as candidates." The whistleblower's identity has remained a secret, though US media have reported he or she is a CIA officer.

Title: NFIB Small Business Optimism Index Dips in July, Remains in Recession Territory

Article:

In its first index since the Supreme Court's Obamacare ruling in June, the National Federation of Independent Business (NFIB) Small Business Optimism Index took another dip. The July index fell 0.2 points to 91.2, still holding steady in recession territory.

The index fell less than expected, the NFIB stated, and hit its lowest point during the recession in July of 2009 at 86.5. The highest level the index has reached during the recession was in February 2012 at 94.5. Before the recession, the index would often average above 100. The survey was compiled from the responses of 1,803 randomly sampled NFIB members.

NFIB chief economist William Dunkelberg commented, "Congress has recessed without a plan to resolve our calamitous debt/spending cycle or a lasting answer to our dangerous fiscal cliff." He added, "The White House has presented us with some 'fuzzy math,' asserting that only three percent of small businesses will be impacted by planned tax increases. That's not true."

Dunkelberg explained that the denominator in that calculation is wrong—it should be the 6 million employer firms that provide jobs to half the private sector workforce, meaning that more like 15 percent of small businesses can expect higher taxes in January. The lack of meaningful actions to address tax reform in Washington adds to the certainty of sluggish growth for the remainder of 2012, and the uncertainty of what will come in 2013.

With so much media coverage ahead of the Obamacare decision, Dunkelberg said respondents likely had a feeling the law would be upheld, therefore the drop from June to July wasn't as large as originally estimated.

The index found more business owners indicated business conditions to worsen for the next six months, and also believe real sales volumes will be lower in the next three months. Only five percent of business owners believe now is a good time to expand their business, a historically low number.

Fifty-four percent of business owners reported making capital outlays, up 2% over the past six months. Of those that made such expenditures, 38% spent on new equipment, 19% purchased vehicles, and 14% improved or expanded facilities. Those planning to make outlays over the next six months held steady at 21%.

Poor sales was named the top problem for 20% of business owners surveyed. The net percent of small businesses reporting higher nominal sales over the past three months, seasonally adjusted, fell four points to -9%. This was after losing seven points in June's index.

The reported net change in job creation was -0.04%, but was better than June's rate of -0.11%. Before June and July, job creation was rising from December to May and were all either zero or positive. Seasonally adjusted, 10% of businesses added an average of 3.0 workers per firm, while 11% reduced employment by 2.3 workers per firm. The remaining 79% made no net change in employment.

The report found 48% of business owners did attempt to hire in the last three months, and 38% found few or no qualified applicants.

Title: Congresswoman Ilhan Omar Faces Bipartisan Criticism for Remarks on Israel and Alleged Anti-Semitic Slur

Article:

Freshman Congresswoman Ilhan Omar (D-MN) is facing criticism from fellow lawmakers for her comments regarding Israel and its supporters, which some have labeled as an anti-Semitic slur. Omar made the comments at a town hall event with fellow pro-Palestinian advocate Rep. Rashida Tlaib (D-MI).

During the event, Omar stated, "I want to talk about the political influence in this country that says it is ok for people to push for allegiance to a foreign country." Omar's comments were in reference to Israel, marking the second incident of derogatory speech toward the Jewish state and its supporters this month.

In an attempt to defend her comments, Omar said, "A lot of people think because I am Muslim, every comment I make about Israel is anti-Semitic." NBC News reports that she went on to state the criticism prevents a "broader debate" about Israel's treatment of Palestinians.

Rep. Eliot Engel (D-NY), chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee in which Omar serves, condemned her comments, suggesting that Israel demands allegiance from American lawmakers. "I welcome debate in Congress based on the merits of policy, but it's unacceptable and deeply offensive to call into question the loyalty of fellow American citizens because of their political views, including support for the US-Israel relationship," Engel said according to the Washington Examiner.

Engel continued, "We all take the same oath. Worse, Rep. Omar's comments leveled that charge by invoking a vile anti-Semitic slur." He also called on Omar to retract her comments, apologize, and commit to making her case on policy issues without resorting to attacks that have no place in the Foreign Affairs Committee or the House of Representatives.

Rep. Nita Lowey (D-NY), chairwoman of the House Appropriations Committee, also condemned Omar's comments on Twitter. "Lawmakers must be able to debate without prejudice or bigotry," Lowey tweeted. "I am saddened that Rep. Omar continues to mischaracterize support for Israel. I urge her to retract this statement and engage in further dialogue with the Jewish community on why these comments are so hurtful."

Omar defended her comments in a series of tweets, stating, "Our democracy is built on debate, Congresswoman! I should not be expected to have allegiance/pledge support to a foreign country in order to serve my country in Congress or serve on committee." She continued, "I have not mischaracterized our relationship with Israel, I have questioned it and that has been clear from my end."

Omar also criticized her Democratic counterparts in a tweet, stating, "My Americanness is questioned by the President and the @GOP on a daily basis, yet my colleagues remain silent. I know what it means to be American and no one will ever tell me otherwise."

In another tweet, Omar wrote, "Being opposed to Netanyahu and the occupation is not the same as being anti-Semitic. I am grateful to the many Jewish allies who have spoken out and said the same." Omar is currently in the Horn of Africa, and she tweeted about her experiences there, stating, "I fight for peace and justice because only those who experience the pain of war, know the joy of peace."

Title: NBC Fires Matt Lauer Amidst Allegations of Sexual Misconduct

Article:

NBC News has terminated the employment of Matt Lauer, the longtime host of the "Today" show, following allegations of sexual misconduct. According to a report by Page Six, Lauer may have sexually assaulted an NBC employee during the 2014 Sochi Olympics.

An NBC source told Page Six that the employee in question filed a complaint on Monday, stating, "This happened so quickly. She didn't go to the media, she made a complaint to NBC's human resources, and her evidence was so compelling that Matt was fired on Tuesday night." The victim reportedly has evidence suggesting similar incidents with other women, but no such evidence has been made public as of yet.

CNN's Brian Stelter reported that The New York Times and Variety Magazine had been investigating Lauer's behavior for weeks, and in some cases, months before an employee filed a complaint against him. Stelter stated that NBC was aware of these investigations.

Ramin Setoodeh, a writer for Variety, reported knowing of "multiple victims" of Lauer's alleged misconduct. Yashar Ali, a journalist, has been reporting on serious sexual harassment allegations against Lauer for the past two months, with multiple women coming forward privately but fearing public disclosure due to Lauer's power in the media.

Yashar Ali declined to share more details about the allegations but tweeted that Lauer is "one of the worst" he has encountered. Ali claimed that Lauer manipulated women into silence, a practice he allegedly cultivated through relationships with reporters outside NBC. Ali further described Lauer's manipulation as "evil, frightening stuff."

In a series of tweets, Ali called Lauer's behavior "frightening" and "evil," stating that Lauer put fear into the women he allegedly harassed. Ali also claimed that Lauer had relationships with reporters outside NBC, which he cultivated for the purpose of manipulation.

The full extent of the allegations against Matt Lauer remains unclear, as many of the women involved have chosen to remain anonymous due to fear of public backlash and the power Lauer held in the media industry. NBC has not yet released a statement regarding the specific allegations against Lauer.

Title: Supreme Court Upholds Arizona's Controversial Immigration Check Provision, Strikes Down Three Other Provisions

Article:

The Supreme Court on Monday issued a ruling on Arizona's controversial immigration law, striking down three provisions but upholding for now a key provision that requires police officers to check the immigration status of individuals they suspect may be in the country illegally during routine stops.

The provision on mandatory checks during routine stops will now be reviewed by a lower court and may still be subject to challenge. The rest of the ruling definitively strikes down three other provisions in the Arizona law, which made it a crime for immigrants to seek employment without work permits and to not carry their immigration papers, and allowed police to arrest anyone they suspect committed a deportable offense.

The court was unanimous in allowing the immigration checks to go forward, but divided on the rest. The decision now throws into question how other states that had followed Arizona's lead on immigration enforcement will proceed. In Washington, the Obama administration signaled a tough road ahead for those states by suspending a key enforcement program that allowed local officials to partner with federal agents in carrying out immigration law.

The court's decision on Monday prompted a range of reactions from officials in Washington and Arizona. Rep. Jeff Flake, R-Ariz., told Fox News that the ruling was "a bit of a mixed bag." Some Democrats expressed concern about the remaining provision, while others declared outright victory. Sen. Chuck Schumer, D-N.Y., called the ruling "as strong a repudiation of the Arizona law as one could expect."

On the GOP side, a few lawmakers described the decision as disappointing, while keeping pressure on the Obama administration to fix the country's immigration system. Others saw a silver lining. Among them was Arizona Gov. Jan Brewer, who put out an optimistic statement Monday, indicating the state would move to carry out the remaining law, even without the three other planks.

Brewer hailed the decision as a "victory for the rule of law" -- in reference to the one provision that was upheld. "After more than two years of legal challenges, the heart of SB 1070 can now be implemented in accordance with the U.S. Constitution," Brewer said.

President Obama also said he was "pleased" by the ruling. "What this decision makes unmistakably clear is that Congress must act on comprehensive immigration reform," he said. "A patchwork of state laws is not a solution to our broken immigration system -- it's part of the problem."

Brewer said she expects legal challenges to the remaining provision of the law to continue. "Our critics are already preparing new litigation tactics in response to their loss at the Supreme Court, and undoubtedly will allege inequities in the implementation of the law," she said.

Brewer also cautioned her state's police officers against taking the policy too far, saying: "Law enforcement will be held accountable should this statute be misused in a fashion that violates an individual's civil rights."

The federal government had claimed the law encroached on its authority to enforce immigration law. Justice Anthony Kennedy wrote the opinion, which was released Monday, on behalf of the majority. Kennedy was joined by Chief Justice John Roberts and Justices Stephen Breyer, Ruth Bader Ginsburg, and Sonia Sotomayor.

On the immigration checks provision, Kennedy wrote that "uncertainty" over how that policy would be carried out prevented the court from assuming it would conflict with federal law. "As a result, the United States can not prevail in its current challenge," Kennedy wrote.

But he offered words of warning pertaining to the rest of the law. "Arizona may have understandable frustrations with the problems caused by illegal immigration while that process continues, but the State may not pursue policies that undermine federal law," Kennedy wrote. The justice also noted that "discretion in the enforcement of immigration law embraces immediate human concerns," and also "involve (s) policy choices that bear on this Nation's international relations."

He added: "The pervasiveness of federal regulation does not diminish the importance of immigration policy to the States. Arizona bears many of the consequences of unlawful immigration." The Supreme Court is currently wrapping up its term, and the public is still awaiting a landmark decision on the federal health care overhaul, which is expected to be released on Thursday.

Title: Ben Shapiro's Speech at UC Berkeley: A Peaceful Event with Nine Arrests

Article:

Conservative commentator and editor-in-chief at The Daily Wire, Ben Shapiro, delivered a speech on campus thuggery at the University of California, Berkeley, without any reported incidents of fires or rioting. Nine individuals were arrested, but the presence of a concrete barrier and the enforcement of law by police prevented chaos. Police were allowed to use pepper spray for crowd control, a measure that was banned through a city ordinance in 1997. Masks were also banned.

Despite the high security costs, estimated at $600,000, the event did not cause significant disruption. Shapiro, in his speech, highlighted five key points, one of which was that when law enforcement is allowed to perform their duties, Antifa has less influence.

The event, which began at 10 P.M. EST, 7 P.M. PST, saw hundreds of police officers in attendance. These officers arrested individuals carrying weapons or masks, preventing violence in the crowd outside.

Shapiro's speech sparked controversy, with some students reporting emotional distress. One student stated they would be seeking counseling after the event.

Nine individuals were arrested outside the event, with offenses ranging from spitting at a police officer, possessing banned items, and assault, according to the Berkeley Police Department.

In a tweet, political cartoonist Scott Adams suggested that the ban on masks, a tactic used by the KKK, was effective in minimizing violence at the event.

Shapiro, in his speech, addressed the microaggression mentality, political attacks, and the importance of free speech on campus. He also thanked the police and the Young America's Foundation for their support.

In the aftermath of the event, Shapiro considered it a success and expressed gratitude to the Young America's Foundation.

Title: Warren Leads Democratic Primary Field in Wisconsin, According to New Poll

Article:

Senator Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.) has taken the lead in the Democratic primary field in Wisconsin, according to a new poll released on Thursday. The survey, conducted by Change Research on behalf of Crooked Media, a progressive network, found Warren as the top choice of 29 percent of likely Democratic primary voters in the state.

Senator Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) and former Vice President Joe Biden followed closely behind, with 24 percent and 20 percent support, respectively. South Bend, Ind., Mayor Pete Buttigieg and Senator Kamala Harris (D-Calif.) registered 9 percent and 5 percent support, respectively.

The Wisconsin primary is scheduled for April 7, 2020, putting it toward the end of the primary calendar. The state has received increased focus this election cycle due to President Trump's win over Hillary Clinton in the state's last general election.

Thursday's survey predicts a tight race in the 2020 general election, with 45 percent of respondents saying they will probably or definitely vote for Trump and 46 percent saying the same for the eventual Democratic nominee. Change Research polled 1,966 likely voters in Wisconsin between Aug. 9 and 11. That figure includes 626 likely Democratic primary voters. The margin of error for the full sample is 2.2 points.

Title: U.S. Unemployment Rate Drops Unexpectedly in May, Employers Add 2.5 Million Jobs

Article:

The U.S. unemployment rate unexpectedly dropped to 13.3 percent in May, down from a record high in April, indicating the nation's economy is recovering faster than expected from the coronavirus lockdown. The Labor Department reported that employers added a record-breaking 2.5 million jobs in May, while shedding a combined 22.1 million jobs in April and March. This leaves an estimated 21 million Americans currently out of work.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and NASDAQ Composite Index all experienced slight declines following the report's release, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average at $26,989.99 (-1.04%), the S&P 500 at $3,190.14 (-0.53%), and the NASDAQ Composite Index at $10,020.35 (+0.67%).

Economists surveyed by Refinitiv had expected the report, conducted in mid-May, to show that unemployment would rise to 19.8 percent in May and that employers would shed 8 million jobs. If the expectation had been accurate, it would have been the worst figure since the Great Depression.

Tony Bedikian, head of global markets at Citizens Bank, stated, "Barring a second surge of Covid-19, the overall U.S. economy may have turned a corner, as evidenced by the surprise job gains today, even though it still remains to be seen exactly what the new normal will look like."

Larry Kudlow, director of the National Economic Council, expressed the need for long-term measures in the next coronavirus relief package to support the economy.

The jobless rate dropped from 14.7 percent in April, which was the highest level since record-keeping began in 1948. The surprise decline, combined with the surge in jobs, suggests the worst is over for the nation's economy as states ease stay-at-home guidelines and businesses bring back staff.

Leisure and hospitality, the sector hit hardest by the outbreak of the virus, accounted for almost half of the increase, with more than 1.2 million employees returning to their jobs last month. In April, the industry lost a staggering 7.6 million jobs. More than 1.3 million workers returned to food services and drinking places as states gradually allowed businesses deemed nonessential to reopen.

Construction also saw a significant jump in employment last month, with the sector adding 464,000 jobs. Education and health services increased by 424,000, and retail climbed by 368,000.

The number of unemployed Americans who reported being temporarily laid off decreased by 2.7 million in May, representing the majority of the jobs that returned. Among those who said they were not temporarily laid off, the number of permanent job losses continued to increase, rising by 295,000 in May to 2.3 million.

Over the course of the past few weeks, every state has started to navigate reopening their economies. However, the unemployment level, which remains at the highest level since the Depression, is expected to remain elevated as social distancing guidelines remain in place.

Daniel Zhao, a Glassdoor senior economist, stated, "It's important to remember the labor market still faces an unemployment rate at the highest level since the Great Depression with tens of millions of Americans still out of work." He added, "While the labor market may be on the path to recovery, there is still a long way to go until the labor market returns to pre-crisis levels and makes up for lost growth."

Title: Nevada's Early State Advantage for Rand Paul Fades as Competition Intensifies

Article:

In the 2016 presidential race, Nevada, initially considered a stronghold for Senator Rand Paul (R-KY), has seen a shift in the political landscape. The large Republican field has diluted Paul's advantage, with his rivals aggressively contesting the state.

At a recent gathering in Gardnerville, Nevada, it was clear that Paul was not the focus of attention. Ted Cruz, a fellow Republican candidate, stole the show at the Basque Fry, a conservative event attended by four presidential candidates, including Carly Fiorina, Ben Carson, Scott Walker, and Cruz himself. Paul was absent, scheduled for a medical mission to Haiti.

The lack of Paul's presence was noticeable, and his absence was felt among the state's political class. One reason for this is the lingering tensions between supporters of Paul's father, former GOP Rep. Ron Paul, and the state Republican establishment. However, a simpler explanation is the increased competition in the Republican field, which offers anti-establishment and anti-Washington voters multiple viable options.

Mary Burgoon, a board member of the Nevada Federation of Republican Women in Carson City, expressed this sentiment, stating, "I don't know anybody who's going to vote for him. There are a few diehards, but that's it. Why him, when we've got so many others anyway?"

The Basque Fry drew four presidential candidates, and attendees reveled in their 2016 options. The candidates who spoke, including Fiorina, Carson, Walker, and Cruz, were well-received by the crowd.

Rand Paul's concessions to mainstream politics and his departure from his father's uncompromising style have also cost him some support, though the extent of this loss is unclear. Ray Rocha, president of the Republican Men's Club of Northern Nevada, noted, "He's lost some of his father's people, and in my view, Cruz and Walker are taking them away from him."

Paul's campaign, which is still in the process of coming together, is not concerned, according to Richard Bunce, an activist who coordinated Ron Paul's Nevada operation in previous cycles. Bunce stated, "He pulls in standing-room-only crowds in Nevada, so he's a headliner person. He isn't going to be a part of the machine, which is what the event was, and so that was not his crowd."

However, the fact that Paul's effort is still taking shape in a state that was expected to be a stronghold is itself revealing, and his rivals have taken notice. Several other presidential campaigns have already brought on staff, lined up key endorsements, and started to build out field operations. Jeb Bush, Marco Rubio, and other candidates have made strategic moves to gain an edge in Nevada.

Despite the current challenges, some Nevadans recognize that it's a long road to February, and there is still time for change. Nick Phillips, former political director for the Clark County GOP, stated, "There's plenty of time for change around here. But it could be interesting if people don't pay attention."

Title: Mass Exodus of Christians in Islamic World: Unprecedented Displacement and Persecution

Article:

A significant displacement of Christians is currently underway across the Islamic world, with millions of Christians being displaced from one end of the region to another. This mass migration is leading to a resurgence of Christianity's historical presence in the region, as much of the Islamic world, prior to the Islamic conquests, was predominantly Christian.

The U.S. Commission on International Religious Freedom has stated that the exodus of Christians from the region is unprecedented and is increasing year by year. The commission predicts that Christians might disappear altogether from Iraq, Afghanistan, and Egypt in the near future.

Iraq, once home to at least one million Christians in 2003, now has fewer than 400,000 remaining. This decline is attributed to an anti-Christian campaign that began with the U.S. occupation of Iraq, which saw numerous Christian churches bombed, and Christians killed, including through crucifixion and beheading. The 2010 Baghdad church attack, which resulted in nearly 60 Christian worshippers being slaughtered, is a notable example of this ongoing violence.

Similar patterns have emerged in Syria, where entire regions and towns where Christians lived for centuries before the advent of Islam have been emptied. The opposition targets Christians for kidnapping, plundering, and beheadings, all in compliance with mosque calls telling the populace that it is a "sacred duty" to drive Christians away.

In October 2012, the last Christian in the city of Homs, which had a Christian population of some 80,000 before the jihadis came, was murdered. A teenage Syrian girl stated, "We left because they were trying to kill us... because we were Christians... Those who were our neighbors turned against us. At the end, when we ran away, we went through balconies. We did not even dare go out on the street in front of our house."

In Egypt, some 100,000 Christian Copts have fled their homeland following the "Arab Spring." In September 2012, the Sinai's small Christian community was attacked and evicted by Al Qaeda-linked Muslims, according to Reuters. However, even before that, the Coptic Orthodox Church lamented the "repeated incidents of displacement of Copts from their homes, whether by force or threat."

Mali, after an Islamic coup in 2012, saw as many as 200,000 Christians flee. In the north, rebels want to establish an independent Islamist state and drive Christians out. There have been house-to-house searches for Christians who might be in hiding, churches and other Christian property have been looted or destroyed, and people have been tortured into revealing any Christian relatives. At least one pastor was beheaded.

Even in European Bosnia, Christians are leaving en masse "amid mounting discrimination and Islamization." Only 440,000 Catholics remain in the Balkan nation, half the pre-war figure. Problems cited include the construction of dozens of mosques in the Bosnian capital Sarajevo, while no building permissions were given for Christian churches.

In Ethiopia, after a Christian was accused of desecrating a Koran, thousands of Christians were forced to flee their homes when "Muslim extremists set fire to roughly 50 churches and dozens of Christian homes."

In the Ivory Coast—where Christians have been crucified—Islamic rebels have massacred hundreds and displaced tens of thousands of Christians.

In Libya, Islamic rebels forced several Christian religious orders, serving the sick and needy in the country since 1921, to flee.

To anyone following the plight of Christians under Islamic persecution, none of this is surprising. As I document in my new book, "Crucified Again: Exposing Islam's New War on Christians," all around the Islamic world—in nations that do not share the same race, language, culture, or economics, in nations that share only Islam—Christians are being persecuted into extinction. Such is the true face of extremist Islamic resurgence.

Title: Geithner's Alleged Deception: A Look at the 2009 Social Security Claim

Article:

Former U.S. Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner, in a new memoir, has revealed that in 2009, he was asked by a senior adviser to then-President Barack Obama, Dan Pfeiffer, to suggest that Social Security was operating in the black and not a contributing cause of the ballooning federal deficit. This request, according to Geithner, was intended as a "dog whistle to the left" to convey a message to the president's political base, regardless of its truth.

The allegation, if accurate, adds to the growing list of controversies surrounding the Obama administration's honesty. The administration has been criticized for statements made regarding ObamaCare, NSA spying, and the Benghazi incident.

The question of whether government officials can legally lie has been a topic of debate. While the courts have ruled that the remedy for government lying is to vote officials out of office, the legality of such actions remains a contentious issue. The case of Roger Clemens and Martha Stewart, who were prosecuted for petty lies about private matters, contrasts with the lack of prosecution for Clapper and Rice, who allegedly misled the public on significant matters.

The Geithner allegations bring to light the potential consequences of government deception, as it may shatter the social contract between the government and the people, and officials who lie risk becoming a law unto themselves. The full extent of the truth behind Geithner's claims remains to be verified.

Title: Comparison of Clinton Email Scandal and Petraeus' Federal Conviction Unfounded, Says Former Attorney General Mukasey

Article:

Former U.S. Attorney General Michael Mukasey, who oversaw the prosecution of former CIA director David Petraeus, has stated that the comparison between Hillary Clinton's use of a private email server during her tenure as Secretary of State and Petraeus' federal conviction for unauthorized removal and retention of classified information is without merit.

Mukasey, who served as the U.S. attorney for the Western District of North Carolina, highlighted the key element that distinguishes Clinton's email retention practices from Petraeus' actions: Petraeus knowingly engaged in unlawful conduct, which formed the basis of his criminal liability.

The facts of Petraeus' case, as a matter of public record, reveal that during his tenure as the commander of the International Security Assistance Force in Afghanistan, Petraeus recorded handwritten notes in personal journals containing information he knew was classified at the highest levels. These journals contained top-secret and even more sensitive "code word" national defense information, including the identities of covert officers, war strategy, intelligence capabilities, diplomatic discussions, and quotes and deliberative discussions from National Security Council meetings, including discussions with the president of the United States.

Petraeus failed to mark these books as "top secret" and store them in a Secured Compartmented Information Facility. Instead, he allowed his biographer to take possession of the journals for use as source material for his biography. When questioned by the FBI, Petraeus lied to agents in responding that he had neither improperly stored nor improperly provided classified information to his biographer.

Mukasey emphasized that Petraeus' conduct was done "knowingly." That is, when he stored his journals containing "highly classified" information at his home, he did so knowingly, aware that there was classified information in the journals and that they were stored improperly.

In contrast, Clinton is not being investigated for knowingly sending or receiving classified materials improperly. The State Department has confirmed that none of the information that has surfaced on Clinton's server thus far was classified at the time it was sent or received. Additionally, the Justice Department indicated that its inquiry is not a criminal one and that Clinton is not the subject of the inquiry.

Here, the inspector general and the Justice Department are following an established protocol when it is determined that there has been an unauthorized disclosure of classified materials—in this case, potentially due to a potential after-the-fact change in classification. This protocol ensures that any classified information is properly handled going forward.

Reasonable minds may differ about the wisdom of using a personal server to conduct the official business of the State Department. In recent days, Clinton has taken responsibility for using a private server and admitted that using separate accounts would have been a better choice. However, unlike the actions and prosecution of Petraeus, there has been no evidence of criminal conduct.

Anne M. Tompkins, a partner at Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft and former United States attorney for the Western District of North Carolina, has provided this opinion. Tompkins is a donor to Hillary Clinton's presidential campaign. In addition to its own editorials, ███ publishes diverse opinions from outside writers, including its Board of Contributors. To read more columns like this, go to the Opinion front page.

Title: U.S. Election Outcome Won't Settle Major Issues, Economic Growth and Trust in Government Remain Concerns

Article:

The upcoming U.S. election on Tuesday will not likely resolve many of the country's significant issues, as the economy and trust in government remain major concerns. The article points out that the U.S. has experienced one of the longest economic expansions in history since 2009, but the average growth rate of 2 percent is the weakest since 1949. Neither presidential candidate, Hillary Clinton nor Donald Trump, has presented a plan to significantly improve economic growth.

Clinton's proposed tax increases and spending hikes are expected to maintain the economy's current pace, while Trump's plan to add five trillion dollars to the national debt could dampen growth. The article also highlights the candidates' foreign policy positions, stating that neither has articulated a plan to stabilize the U.S. economy, reduce international terrorism, or bring order to hot spots in the Middle East, Eastern Europe, or Asia.

Trust in major American institutions, including the media, religious organizations, labor, business, and the two major political parties, is at or near historic lows. The article notes that millennials, the largest generation, are the most skeptical. The Iraq War, President Obama's health care reform, and government surveillance have contributed to this distrust.

The article also mentions the leak of emails showing Hillary Clinton as two-faced and Donald Trump as a serial scam artist and bully. These revelations are expected to further erode trust in government and politics. The article concludes by stating that until the major parties start governing transparently and nominate candidates who are trusted by the majority of Americans, little is likely to change, and the situation may even worsen.

Title: California's Homelessness Crisis: A National Concern

Article:

California's homelessness issue has become a significant national concern, as the state accounts for a majority of the nation's homeless population growth. According to the latest federal data, the U.S. homeless population has increased by approximately 15,000 people, bringing the total to about 568,000, or 2.7%. However, California's homeless population has seen a more substantial increase, with over 21,000 more individuals without homes, representing a 16.4% rise.

The U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) reported this growth on Friday. The increase in California's homeless population is so significant that it overshadows declines in 29 states, including Washington, Hawaii, Massachusetts, and others with substantial housing pressures.

While the national homeless population remains about 10% lower than it was a decade ago, California's has expanded by more than 22% in the same timeframe. With less than an eighth of the U.S. population, California is home to more than a quarter of the nation's homeless people and more than half of those who are unsheltered.

Moreover, California's homeless population continues to grow, even as overall growth has slowed significantly. The state's Department of Finance estimated that California's population grew only 0.35% over the 12 months ending July 1, the smallest increase since 1900. Several counties, including Marin, Sonoma, Napa, and Santa Cruz, experienced population loss.

HUD Secretary Ben Carson stated that "homelessness in California is at a crisis level and needs to be addressed by local and state leaders with crisis-like urgency." The Trump administration has threatened a crackdown on California's homelessness issue.

California Governor Gavin Newsom and other state officials have been critical of advice from the Trump administration. However, HUD Secretary Carson's assertion that the state's response to homelessness is not commensurate with the human disaster at hand appears to be accurate.

Study after study has demonstrated the strong relationship between housing scarcity and homelessness. The California Legislature has not passed a comprehensive measure to expedite residential development since 2017 and has repeatedly shelved the most significant measure in play, SB50. The San Francisco Board of Supervisors, typifying the approach of too many local governments, voted against the measure for the third time last week.

Beyond legislation to speed development, the state's rampant homelessness calls for reform on the order of the right-to-shelter policy backed by the leaders of Newsom's task force on the issue—though not, so far, by Newsom himself. Anything less will enable more demagoguery and suffering.

This commentary is from The Chronicle's editorial board. Readers are invited to express their views in a letter to the editor via SFChronicle.com/letters.

Title: Americans Donate Stimulus Checks to Charity and Aid Organizations Amid Unemployment Crisis

Article:

In the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic, many Americans are facing financial hardships, with record numbers of job losses and increased unemployment claims. However, some individuals, such as Brooke Young, a Salt Lake City librarian, are using their $1,200 stimulus checks to support charitable causes and aid organizations.

Young donated $200 of her stimulus payment to a mutual aid group that provides groceries for people in need, a group that assists laid-off restaurant workers, the Salt Lake City Tribune, and the local alternative weekly newspaper. Young, who is not swimming in extra cash, expressed feelings of guilt for being financially secure while many are struggling.

In a separate instance, Toi Cudworth, a credit union employee in Texas, donated $950 of her stimulus payment to the San Antonio Food Bank after witnessing the long lines of people seeking food assistance. Cudworth also bought groceries for a neighbor recently laid off from his retail job and plans to help an elderly couple down the street.

Laine Himmelmann, a fundraiser for Habitat for Humanity of Greater Sacramento, donated $100 to her own employer and plans to give another $250 when she receives her stimulus payment. Himmelmann, who works for the organization, noted that they recently laid off 27 of their 30 employees.

Some nonprofits and grassroots groups are actively soliciting stimulus check donations. Cosecha, a national group that helps undocumented immigrants, received over 1,100 pledges for donations from stimulus payments. Wendy Blackwell-Moore, a consultant and married mother of two in Maine, organized an online campaign called Pledge My Stimulus, encouraging people to donate their $1,200 stimulus payments to people in need.

While some high-net-worth individuals may still qualify for stimulus checks due to their assets not being reported on their tax returns, tax preparer Adam Markowitz reported receiving inquiries from clients who wanted to know if they could refuse the payments. Markowitz advised clients to find a way to use the money for the greater good, such as donating to charity or helping those who provide essential services.

Title: Missouri Businesses Reopen Amidst Rising COVID-19 Cases; Governor Lifts Restrictions Despite Criticism

Article:

Missouri's Republican Governor, Mike Parson, chose to ease restrictions on businesses and social gatherings in Liberty, Missouri, despite the state experiencing its largest increase in coronavirus cases on Monday. The decision came six weeks after initial restrictions were imposed.

While some businesses opened their doors, the response was not as enthusiastic as some gun-toting protests against lockdowns and stay-at-home orders in other parts of the country might suggest. Tara Brendle, the owner of Brendle's barber shop, was one of the few who reopened, albeit with precautions such as obliging customers to wait outside and sanitizing equipment between appointments.

Brendle expressed concerns about the resurgence of Covid-19, but felt compelled to reopen due to financial pressures. Lyle Hoover, a customer waiting for his first haircut since the lockdown, believed the pandemic was being exaggerated and that the economy was being manipulated.

Governor Parson's coronavirus policy has been met with criticism, particularly for his decision to tour electrical contractors and hunting and fishing stores without wearing a face mask, and for urging workers to return to their jobs if their employers demand it or risk losing benefits.

Mayors of Missouri's two largest cities, St. Louis and Kansas City, have kept restrictions in place, including the closure of restaurants for sit-down dining, gyms, and non-essential shops. Kansas City's mayor, Quinton Lucas, plans to limit restaurant seating to just 10% capacity or 10 people including employees when they reopen in the middle of the month.

Hammerhand Coffee, a cafe in Liberty's main square, remained closed on Monday, adhering to county guidelines that allow only 25% capacity, which doesn't make sense for a small cafe. The uncertainty about reopening was reflected in the square, where most businesses remained closed, with florists, boutiques, and jewelers still shut. Hueys on the Square restaurant, which had been giving away free boxed meals to families in need, was open with some tables marked "no seating" to keep patrons six feet apart.

Title: Turkish Authorities Pursue Suspect in New Year's Istanbul Nightclub Massacre

Article:

Turkish Deputy Prime Minister Numan Kurtulmus has confirmed that authorities have the fingerprints and a general description of the gunman responsible for the New Year's mass shooting at an Istanbul nightclub. Kurtulmus stated that investigators are close to identifying the suspect. A massive manhunt is currently underway, with Turkish police investigating potential links between the attacker and the cell responsible for the deadly suicide bombing at Istanbul's airport in June 2016.
