According to Kurtulmus, eight individuals are currently in police custody in connection to the nightclub attack. The IS-linked Aamaq News Agency claimed the attack was carried out by a "heroic soldier of the caliphate" who targeted the nightclub where Christians were celebrating their pagan feast.

The attacker reportedly took just seven minutes to unleash his terror, killing 39 people, including 27 foreigners, and wounding 69 others. Among the wounded was American Jake Raak, who was shot in the hip and had the bullet travel to his knee. Raak, from Delaware, stated that he survived by playing dead, remaining silent and not moving even after being shot.

Raak's mother, Grace Raak, shared that her son traveled to Istanbul for his birthday. She expressed prayers for the injured and the families of those who lost loved ones. Raak, along with approximately 600 others, was inside the venue celebrating the New Year when the terrorist entered, reportedly shouting "Allahu Akbar" as he began firing indiscriminately.

Security camera footage captured bullets grazing the bar's railing and a man in red, attempting to escape, but ultimately being trapped as the killer approached, firing a single shot from his AK-47. Eyewitness Komron Saidaliev described the scene as "terrible."

ISIS, which referred to Turkey as "the servant of the cross," claimed responsibility for the attack, stating that their soldier carried out the attack using an automatic weapon and hand grenades in "revenge for God's religion and in response to the orders" of ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi.

Col. Steve Ganyard, a former State Department official, commented that nightclubs are attractive targets for jihadi terrorists due to their symbolizing secular decadence. Turkey, a NATO ally, has experienced 18 major terror attacks on its soil since 2015, with the January 1st attack marking the 19th.

Title: Court Blocks Trump Administration's Title X Rule Affecting Planned Parenthood

Article:

The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit has issued a preliminary injunction blocking the Trump administration's final rule that bars clinics that provide or refer patients for abortions from receiving federal family planning funds under Title X. The rule, known as the "domestic gag rule," was first proposed last year and has been the subject of a legal battle since its release in March.

The new rule bars Planned Parenthood and any other provider that performs abortions or offers abortion referrals from receiving funding under Title X, which pays for birth control and other family planning services for low-income patients. Anti-abortion groups have long backed such a rule, arguing that organizations that provide abortion should not receive federal support. Planned Parenthood and other groups say that the rule will leave low-income patients without access to health care they need. Planned Parenthood says it sees about 41 percent of patients who get family planning services under Title X.

The rule immediately faced legal challenges from Planned Parenthood, the American Medical Association, the National Family Planning & Reproductive Health Association (NFPRHA), the American Civil Liberties Union, and a number of states. Earlier this year, the challengers won temporary injunctions keeping the rule from taking effect, but those injunctions were lifted after the Trump administration appealed. On July 3, the Ninth Circuit issued a new injunction, this one in connection with the suit by the NFPRHA and ACLU.

"Today's ruling is an important victory in the fight against the Trump administration's attempts to upend Title X," said Ruth Harlow, senior staff attorney for the ACLU's Reproductive Freedom Project, in a statement. "It allows us to go back to court to ensure that the millions of low-income people who rely on the nation's only family planning program will continue to receive vital health services—and we will not give up until the rule is blocked for good."

The move to restrict Title X funds is one of a number of actions by the Trump administration that critics say will limit access to contraception and abortion. It also comes as the president ramps up his rhetoric on abortion, which he may see as a winning issue for him and the Republican Party in 2020.

The new rule would require providers that receive Title X funds to be both physically and financially separate from any entity that provides or refers for abortions. That means that because some Planned Parenthood health centers perform abortions, all Planned Parenthood centers would be barred from getting Title X funding. In addition to Planned Parenthood affiliates, Title X funds also go to Health Department centers, hospital-run clinics, and other facilities, all of which would be barred from performing abortions under the new rule.

Providers were already banned from using Title X money to pay for abortions, but Title X funding recipients could still perform abortions if they covered the costs with other funds. The rule was first proposed in May 2018 but did not go into effect at that time. When it was finalized, the rule was scheduled to take effect this May. A similar rule was proposed under President Reagan but was only in effect for a month, in 1992. That rule prohibited Title X recipients from even discussing abortion, but the new rule does not go that far.

Abortion opponents have applauded the rule. "We thank President Trump for taking decisive action to disentangle taxpayers from the big abortion industry led by Planned Parenthood," said Marjorie Dannenfelser, president of Susan B. Anthony List, in a statement. "Americans United for Life is pleased that HHS has taken steps to stop Title X funds from subsidizing abortion," said Catherine Glenn Foster, president of the group, in a statement.

Planned Parenthood and other groups say it will leave many low-income patients without access to contraceptive care. Planned Parenthood also argues that the rule is illegal, since it violates laws requiring that pregnant patients receiving care through Title X get unbiased counseling about all of their options, which include abortion. In many places, Planned Parenthood is the only option for low-income patients; a 2015 analysis by the Guttmacher Institute found 103 counties where Planned Parenthood is the only provider of publicly funded contraceptives. If Planned Parenthood were locked out of Title X funds, other health centers might struggle to pick up the slack. According to another Guttmacher analysis, other providers would have to increase their caseloads by an average of 70 percent to serve all the patients currently seen by Planned Parenthood.

"If fully implemented, the proposed changes to Title X would shrink the network of participating providers and have major repercussions for low-income women across the country that rely on them for their family planning care," wrote a team from the Kaiser Family Foundation in a November 2018 analysis of the proposed rule. The Title X rule is just one of several moves by the Trump administration that limit access to contraception or abortion. In 2017, for instance, the administration released interim rules allowing almost any employer to get an exemption from the Obama-era requirement that employers offer contraceptive coverage as part of employee health insurance. Those rules were finalized in 2018, one day after the midterm elections. Trump has stepped up his anti-abortion rhetoric in recent months, after Virginia Gov. Ralph Northam's confusing comments on a bill in his state led to a larger controversy around abortions late in pregnancy. The president's appointment of conservative Supreme Court Justices Neil Gorsuch and Brett Kavanaugh has boosted his popularity among conservatives, according to Vivian Wang of the New York Times. And with a potential challenge to Roe v. Wade on the horizon, Trump may see opposition to abortion—and to Planned Parenthood—as a winning strategy going into 2020.

Title: Former Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid Calls for End to Filibuster in U.S. Senate, Urges Presidential Candidates to Follow Suit

Article:

Former Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid has called for the elimination of the legislative filibuster in the U.S. Senate and urged Democratic presidential candidates to support this move. In an opinion piece published in The New York Times on Monday, Reid criticized the Senate as an "unworkable legislative graveyard" due to the increased use of the filibuster by the Republican party.

Reid, a Nevada Democrat, argued that the filibuster, which requires a 60-vote threshold for legislation, should be replaced with a simple majority vote. He cited the filibuster's role in obstructing action on issues like climate change, immigration, and gun control.

Reid, who was instrumental in muscling through a rules change in 2013 to end the filibuster for many presidential nominees, recalled his own efforts and the subsequent Republican changes in 2017 that allowed for a simple majority vote on Supreme Court nominees.

Some Democratic activists argue that 2020 presidential contenders cannot be taken seriously if they support maintaining the legislative filibuster, given the need for a sweeping agenda on issues like health care and climate change. While some presidential candidates have called for the outright abolition of the filibuster, others, such as former Vice President Joseph R. Biden and Sen. Bernie Sanders of Vermont, have been more hesitant.

The filibuster, a procedural tool that allows for endless debate and requires a supermajority to end, has been a contentious issue in the Senate for decades. Its elimination would significantly alter the balance of power in the legislative body, potentially allowing for more swift passage of legislation with a simple majority.

Title: Twelve Democratic Presidential Candidates Qualify for October Debate, Five for November

Article:

Twelve Democratic presidential candidates have qualified for the October 15 debate, the most participants ever in a single presidential primary debate, according to the Democratic National Committee. The debate will take place on one night, despite more than 10 candidates qualifying.

As of October 1, the candidates who have qualified for the fourth debate are: Joe Biden, Pete Buttigieg, Kamala Harris, Bernie Sanders, Elizabeth Warren, Cory Booker, Beto O'Rourke, Andrew Yang, Amy Klobuchar, Tom Steyer, Julián Castro, and Tulsi Gabbard. Marianne Williamson is the only candidate who has not yet qualified, needing three more qualifying polls.

To qualify for the fourth debate, a candidate must reach 2 percent in at least four national or early-state polls released between June 28 and Oct. 1, and collect contributions from 130,000 unique donors, including at least 400 donors in at least 20 states.

For the fifth Democratic debate in November, the qualifying criteria are stricter. Candidates will need four surveys of 3 percent or more in national or early-state polls and contributions from 165,000 unique donors, including at least 600 individual donors in at least 20 states. Candidates can also qualify via an early-state polling pathway, earning 5 percent in at least two polls in the early states of Iowa, New Hampshire, Nevada, and South Carolina.

Five candidates have qualified for the November debate: Joe Biden, Bernie Sanders, Elizabeth Warren, Pete Buttigieg, and Kamala Harris. The remaining candidates need to earn 3 percent in at least four national or early-state polls or 5 percent in at least two early-state polls to qualify.

The qualifying process for the November debate indicates that the candidate field is consolidating into three main groups: the five polling front-runners who have easily qualified, a middle tier of seven candidates who are struggling to hit more than 2 or 3 percent in the polls, and a bottom tier of candidates who have virtually no chance of qualifying.

Some candidates in the middle tier are close to qualifying, such as tech entrepreneur Andrew Yang and billionaire activist Tom Steyer, who each need only one more poll, and Sen. Cory Booker, who needs just two more. Sen. Amy Klobuchar and former Rep. Beto O'Rourke still need three more qualifying surveys, but they have a month or more to rack up those polls.

Neither Gabbard nor former Secretary of Housing and Urban Development Julián Castro have a qualifying poll yet, but they have already cleared the donor threshold, which means they are still in a better position than the six candidates who haven't met the donor requirement or registered a single qualifying poll. Given the long odds that these candidates face, we might expect some more dropouts soon. For instance, Castro recently told supporters in a fundraising email that his campaign would close up shop if he failed to make the November debate. It's easy to imagine he wouldn't be the only one.

Title: The Impact of Citizens United and Related Supreme Court Decisions on Campaign Finance

Article:

The 2010 Citizens United decision, a landmark Supreme Court ruling that loosened restrictions on campaign finance, has been a subject of controversy among Democrats. However, it is not the sole factor contributing to the influx of money in politics, and its effects have been less profound than often portrayed.

The Citizens United decision allowed corporations and unions to openly support political candidates, a practice that was previously possible under the guise of "issue advocacy." The U.S. Chamber of Commerce, an organization that can now use undisclosed donations to advocate for or against specific candidates, had previously used such donations to influence elections.

The Citizens United decision was also cited in the 2010 Supreme Court ruling, SpeechNow.org v. FEC, which enabled individuals to pool unlimited donations in political committees operating independently of candidates. Wealthy individuals like Sheldon Adelson, who recently donated $10 million to a super PAC supporting Mitt Romney, have enjoyed the right to spend unlimited sums on their own campaign advocacy since the 1976 Buckley v. Valeo ruling.

Robert Bauer, former White House counsel for President Obama, described Citizens United as an "effective rhetorical tool" for opponents of the decision but downplayed its importance in the creation of super PACs following the SpeechNow.org decision. Representative Chris Van Hollen, a Maryland Democrat active on campaign finance issues, argued that the 2010 decision "changed the psychology" of campaign finance, producing an "anything-goes atmosphere."

Despite the significant sums raised through the regulated system, the largest donations have been raised through the system that now drives the campaign schedules of President Obama and Mitt Romney, as well as candidates for the House and Senate. In 2008, President Obama, who opted out of the post-Watergate public financing system, raised $745 million, compared to the $84 million allocated by the system during the general election for his opponent, John McCain.

The public financing system has eroded due to reluctance of taxpayers to contribute and the increasing ability of candidates to raise large sums through the internet and other means. However, Mr. Bauer noted that the $92 million on offer for the general election this year would limit the spending plans of both candidates.

Some effects of the Supreme Court's recent rulings may become apparent later. In combination, the Citizens United and SpeechNow cases permitted corporations as well as individuals to donate to super PACs. Disclosures so far indicate that, while privately held corporations have taken advantage of this, publicly traded companies have not.

Jan Baran, a Republican campaign finance lawyer, explained that executives of publicly traded companies have shown "an overwhelming sense of caution about funding this type of advertising" due to concerns about offending shareholders. However, he noted that this might change by November.

In addition to blaming Citizens United for the state of campaign finance, Norman Ornstein, a political analyst, also criticizes President Obama for not pushing for a change to the decision. Ornstein argues that the current system will result in widespread, destructive government corruption similar to that produced by Watergate. He asserts that "the only test for a federal officeholder or candidate is what they are really prepared to do to end this corrupt campaign finance system."

Title: U.S. Government Airlifts $400 Million to Iran, Sparking Controversy Among Republican Lawmakers

Article:

Republican lawmakers have expressed discontent over a report that the U.S. government airlifted the equivalent of $400 million to Iran in January, coinciding with the release of four American detainees by Tehran. The cash transfer, as reported by The Wall Street Journal, was the first installment of a $1.7 billion settlement the Obama administration reached with Iran to resolve a failed 1979 arms deal.

The cash, consisting of euros, Swiss francs, and other currencies, was used due to U.S. law prohibiting the transacting of American dollars with Iran. While the Obama administration denies the cash transfer was linked to the release of the four Americans, GOP lawmakers view it as a "ransom."

Sen. Mark Kirk (R-Ill.) stated, "Paying ransom to kidnappers puts Americans even more at risk." He further added, "While Americans were relieved by Iran’s overdue release of illegally imprisoned American hostages, the White House’s policy of appeasement has led Iran to illegally seize more American hostages."

The four released Americans are Jason Rezaian, a Washington Post reporter; Amir Hekmati, a former U.S. Marine; Christian pastor Saeed Abedini; and Nosratollah Khosravi-Roodsari, whose case was not previously publicized.

State Department spokesman John Kirby stated in an interview that the release of the Americans and the settlement payment were on separate tracks and any suggestion of a connection is "utterly false." He argued that the "compromise" struck with Iran benefited taxpayers because potentially billions more could have been at stake.

Kirby further stated that the negotiations over the Americans and the settlement were conducted by different teams on each side. He said the funds transferred to Iran were related solely to the settlement of a long-standing claim at the U.S.-Iran Claims Tribunal at The Hague.

However, The Wall Street Journal reports that Iranian negotiators on the prisoner exchange said they wanted the cash to show they had gained something tangible. The Journal also reported that President Obama did not disclose the $400 million cash payment when he announced on January 17 that the arms deal dispute had been resolved. The administration has not disclosed how the $1.7 billion was paid, except to say it was not paid in dollars.

House Foreign Affairs Committee Chairman Ed Royce (R-Calif.) stated, "The logistics of this payment -- literally delivering a plane full of cash to evade U.S. law -- shows yet again the extraordinary lengths the Obama administration will go to accommodate Iran, all while hiding the facts from Congress and the American people." He added, "Hundreds of millions in the pockets of a terrorist regime means a more dangerous region, period. And paying ransom only puts more American lives in jeopardy."

Since the cash was airlifted, Iran's Revolutionary Guard has arrested two more Iranian-Americans. Tehran has also detained dual-nationals from France, Canada, and the U.K. in recent months.

Title: Federal Judge Allows Lawsuit Alleging Presidential Emoluments Clause Violation to Proceed

Article:

A federal judge ruled on Wednesday that a lawsuit alleging President Donald Trump is illegally benefiting from profits made at the Trump International Hotel in Washington D.C. can move forward. The decision is a significant development in a case initiated by the attorneys general of Washington D.C. and Maryland in June 2017.

Maryland Attorney General Brian Frosh tweeted, "We won the first round! Our case moves forward!"

The attorneys general argue that Trump is violating the emoluments clause of the U.S. Constitution, which prohibits elected officials from receiving benefits from foreign governments without Congress' approval. The lawsuit alleges that businesses in D.C. and Maryland are adversely affected because organizations are choosing the Trump hotel over other area hotels to curry favor with the president.

An example provided in the complaint is the spending of thousands of dollars by Saudi Arabia at the Trump International Hotel, located in the Old Post Office building, between October 2016 and March 2017.

In February, the Trump Organization announced it had donated foreign earnings from its hotels to the Treasury Department, but the Maryland judge stated in his ruling that these calculations have not been verified or provided to the court.

A similar lawsuit against Trump brought by a liberal watchdog group was dismissed by a federal judge in New York last year for lack of standing. However, in this case, the judge in Maryland has decided that the states do have standing.

"Plaintiffs have sufficiently alleged that the President is violating the Foreign and Domestic Emoluments Clauses of the Constitution by reason of his involvement with and receipt of benefits from the Trump International Hotel and its appurtenances in Washington, D.C., as well as the operations of the Trump Organization with respect to the same," Judge Peter Messitte ruled Wednesday.

Trump was summoned in the Maryland case last week, and his lawyers now have three weeks to respond. The details of the president's involvement and the extent of the alleged benefits are yet to be determined as the case proceeds.

Title: Hillary Clinton Maintains Fundraising Advantage Over Donald Trump in Final Days of Presidential Race

Article:

In the final phase of the 2016 U.S. presidential race, Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton holds a significant fundraising advantage over her Republican counterpart, Donald Trump. According to the latest fundraising reports, Clinton's campaign and joint accounts with the Democratic Party had $153 million as of last week, more than double the $68 million held by Trump's campaign and partnership committees.

This financial edge allows Clinton to maintain a large political operation in the race's final days. Her staff of over 800 is several times larger than Trump's, and she has spent more on advertising than the Republican candidate every week of the campaign.

Over the course of the primary and general elections, Clinton's campaign has raised $513 million, approximately double Trump's total. In the first 19 days of October, Clinton's campaign raised $53 million, while Trump brought in around $30 million.

Trump, a New York businessman who claims to be worth $10 billion, typically contributes about $2 million per month to his campaign but had not made such a contribution in October, according to the latest contribution reports, which were up to date as of Wednesday. He had given only about $33,000.

The candidates and various groups involved in the presidential race are filing their final pre-election fundraising reports on Thursday. These reports cover the first 19 days of October.

Outside groups supporting Clinton are better funded than those backing Trump. Super PACs can accept unlimited contributions from wealthy donors but may not coordinate with the campaigns. The pro-Clinton Priorities USA raised $18 million in the first 19 days of October, with significant contributions from Facebook co-founder Dustin Moskovitz and Susan Mandel, the wife of a hedge fund founder, who each donated $2.5 million this month. Priorities USA plans to spend $21 million on TV ads this week and next, according to Kantar Media's political ad tracker.

On the other hand, Rebuilding America Now, one of several pro-Trump groups, raised only about $215,000 through the early part of October. As of last week, the super PAC had about $1.2 million in cash on hand. Another pro-Trump group, Great America PAC, raised $2 million and had about the same amount left to spend.

Title: Thousands of Migrants Head North in Caravan; Trump Threatens to Close U.S.-Mexico Border

Article:

A large group of mostly Honduran refugees, estimated to number in the thousands, has crossed into Guatemala and is believed to be heading towards the U.S. border. Hundreds of migrants have already arrived at the Guatemalan border town of Tecún Umán, along the southern border of Mexico, according to James Fredrick of NPR. Organizers of the caravan anticipate thousands more will join them in the coming days before attempting to cross the Mexican border.

Mexico has increased security along its southern border and will only allow migrants with valid documentation, such as a passport, to enter the country. However, most of the migrants in the caravan do not have such documents.

"You can tell Mexican security forces are preparing because there are dozens of police in riot gear waiting here for the imminent arrival of this caravan," Frederick told NPR, standing on a bridge that links Mexico and Guatemala. Most of those who had gathered were from Honduras, he said, but there were also people from El Salvador and Guatemala.

Judy, a 34-year-old woman in the group who requested her last name not be used, said her home country of Honduras has become dangerous. "No safety, jobs, and the hospitals lack medicine," she said. "Basic freedoms are being oppressed by the government of Juan Orlando Hernández," she added, stating that Honduras feels unlivable for her right now.

Mexico's interior ministry said it would seek support from the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees as it prepares to receive potentially thousands of refugee requests in the coming days. The Mexican government says that migrants may apply for asylum in Mexico, but they'll have to do so from a detention center. Mexico warned that if migrants are caught crossing illegally, they will be detained and deported.

With the midterm elections in the U.S. just weeks away, President Donald Trump kept immigration front and center by threatening to close the entire U.S.-Mexico border to prevent the migrants from entering. "I will call up the U.S. Military and CLOSE OUR SOUTHERN BORDER!" he tweeted Thursday.

In the spring, Trump tweeted angrily when an earlier caravan of Central Americans made their way through Mexico with the intention of crossing into the U.S. He threatened to cut foreign aid to Honduras and send the military to the border. In the end, some of the migrants went home, and a few hundred crossed the San Ysidro port of entry, south of San Diego, and requested asylum.

It's uncertain how the president would block the current group of immigrants from crossing at a legal port of entry. Longstanding federal and international laws allow immigrants to present themselves at a border crossing and seek protection as refugees. They are referred for a "credible fear" of persecution or torture screening to an asylum officer, who decides if they should be deported or continue the asylum process.

Recent presidents, including Trump, have deployed National Guard troops to the southwestern boundary to assist Border Patrol in catching and processing unauthorized immigrants. However, they have not blocked the ports of entry, which are under the control of agents from U.S. Customs and Border Protection.

President Woodrow Wilson sent active-duty troops to the border during the Mexican Revolution, roughly 100 years ago, to stop raiders such as Pancho Villa from crossing into border states. Today, the migrants Trump wants to keep out appear to be mainly young Hondurans, including parents with small children, who are seeking asylum in the United States. Trump tweeted there are "MANY CRIMINALS" in the caravan, without providing evidence.

Trump has long maintained that "catch-and-release loopholes" in U.S. immigration laws lure immigrants from Central America. The Department of Homeland Security is compiling year-end figures for apprehensions at the southern border. DHS Spokeswoman Katie Waldman wrote in an email to NPR that the department's totals will likely show "record numbers of families arriving illegally in the United States this year."

While thousands of immigrant families are being arrested at the border every week in places like Texas' Rio Grande Valley and Nogales, Arizona, the numbers are still far below the peak in 2000, when 1.6 million unauthorized immigrants were arrested. The difference is that the big numbers 18 years ago were mainly single Mexican males who were quickly deported, whereas the current surge is primarily made up of families seeking amnesty, which allows them to remain in the U.S. for months or years while their case grinds through the backlogged immigration courts.

Waldman added that the agency "is examining all options to secure the border."

Title: Worst Campaigns of 2014: A Review of High-Profile Gaffes, Staff Shakeups, and Controversies

Article:

The 2014 election has been marked by sweeping national forces, including an unpopular president, a shaky economy, and increasing concerns about national security. However, the fundamentals of running a strong campaign remain crucial for candidates, and this year, some campaigns have been particularly challenging.

One candidate who has made numerous high-profile gaffes is Bruce Braley, a Democratic congressman and Iowa Senate hopeful. In a radio interview last year, Braley complained about the impact the government shutdown was having on the House gym, stating, "There's hardly anybody working down there. There's no towel service, we're doing our own laundry down there."

In a video of him speaking to a gathering of trial lawyers in Texas, Braley described Republican Sen. Chuck Grassley, whom Iowans have elected to the Senate six times, as "a farmer from Iowa who never went to law school, never practiced law." Braley was warning the group that Grassley is poised to become chairman of the Judiciary Committee if Republicans win the Senate.

Furthermore, while marching in a parade in July, Braley was caught on video appearing to say that he's a farmer—even though there's no evidence to suggest he is. (Braley's campaign states he made the remark after mishearing what a parade-goer was asking him.) Braley has also had to deal with a series of unflattering stories detailing a nasty dispute between his wife and a neighbor whose chickens invaded the Braleys' yard.

Republicans have used these gaffes to brand Braley as out of touch. In July, with his lead over GOP hopeful Joni Ernst evaporating, Braley shook up his campaign, replacing his admaker and pollster. Today, polls show Braley, who is defending the seat Democratic Sen. Tom Harkin has held for three decades, in essentially a tied race.

Another high-profile campaign that has faced challenges is Eric Cantor's. Cantor's blowout primary loss to an obscure college professor, Dave Brat, came as a complete shock to just about everyone. From start to finish, Cantor ran a lackadaisical, messy campaign. He ignored key conservative groups that ultimately threw their support to Brat, lost his control over the local Republican Party machinery, and spent little time campaigning in the district.

Cantor, who long had his eye on the House speakership, seemed more interested in Washington than on his suburban Richmond constituents. Cantor's biggest mistake might have been running a series of hard-hitting TV ads attacking Brat by name. Brat's advisers later said the spots provided critical name ID with voters who'd never heard of him.

Few tears are being shed for Cantor now: He quickly landed new digs—and a multimillion-dollar salary—at a Wall Street investment bank.

Wendy Davis, a candidate for Texas governor, has also faced numerous challenges. Davis' June 2013 filibuster against a restrictive anti-abortion measure in the Texas Legislature endeared her to liberals nationwide. However, it's been all downhill from there for Davis, a candidate for Texas governor.

A Dallas Morning News story in January raised questions about inconsistencies in how she recounted her life story. In March, she had a weaker-than-expected showing against an obscure and underfunded primary opponent. A month later, she was dissed by her own party's governors association. And in June, the state senator shook up her campaign.

Meanwhile, in a conservative state that hasn't elected a Democrat to statewide office since 1994, Davis has struggled to demonstrate that she's focused on more than abortion rights. A recent New York Times poll showed Davis trailing Republican state Attorney General Greg Abbott by double digits.

Title: Cracks in Biden's Union Support Emerge in Philadelphia, Home of Presidential Campaign Headquarters

Article:

Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden, who launched his 2020 campaign in a union hall in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, is facing signs of decreased support from union workers in Philadelphia, the city where he has his campaign headquarters. This development comes as Biden is set to appear at a "Workers' Presidential Summit" hosted by the AFL-CIO in the city on Tuesday.

Philadelphia, being the largest city in Pennsylvania and home to oil refineries and their union employees, is a crucial area for Biden, who represented the state in the U.S. Senate for over 30 years. However, more than a dozen current and former union leaders and workers in Philadelphia have questioned Biden's loyalty, citing his support for phasing out the fossil fuel industry, which many in the region rely on for jobs.

Ryan O' Callaghan, the former union head of a now-shuttered Philadelphia refinery, stated, "I think Biden has taken our votes for granted. Our plant closed, and we didn't hear from him." The Philadelphia Energy Solutions refinery, the largest and oldest on the U.S. East Coast, closed in August following a massive fire, idling more than 1,000 employees, including 650 union workers.

Large job cuts in a key battleground state like Pennsylvania could have provided Biden with an opportunity to bolster his blue-collar appeal and force Republican President Donald Trump to address the shutdown of a major refinery in the state during his term. Trump won Pennsylvania in 2016 with a margin of less than 1 percentage point over Democrat Hillary Clinton. Trump also won Michigan and Wisconsin, traditionally Democratic Rust Belt states, with narrow margins.

Clinton beat Trump by only 9 percentage points among voters from union households, according to exit polls, significantly less than President Barack Obama's 18-point advantage over Mitt Romney in 2012. When auto union workers went on strike at General Motors on Sunday, Biden tweeted, "Proud to stand with @UAW to demand fair wages and benefits for their members. America's workers deserve better." However, his silence on the refinery, and that of other Democratic presidential candidates, suggests that the party's aggressive environmental agenda may be limiting Biden's ability to address issues that seem to align with his blue-collar image.

Biden is not the only Democrat grappling with reconciling calls to phase out fossil fuels with the need to attract union workers who rely on refineries, power plants, and pipelines. As someone who draws on his upbringing in the working-class stronghold of Scranton, in northeastern Pennsylvania, and has been speaking the language of unions for years, Biden positions himself as the only candidate who can bring back Rust Belt workers who defected from Democrats to vote for Trump in 2016.

Terry Madonna, a political scientist at Franklin & Marshall University in Lancaster, Pennsylvania, stated, "Right now, he's trapped between his historical support for the unions on energy issues and the left wing of his party on environmental issues who are pushing for a Green New Deal, and he needs them both." Philadelphia labor support is essential for any Democrat aiming to win a statewide election, as large turnout in the region can offset Republican margins in central parts of the state, according to Madonna.

The criticism from workers in Biden's own backyard highlights his challenges. Most workers at the Philadelphia Energy Solutions refinery were laid off without severance pay and extended health benefits, while top executives collected $4.5 million worth of retention bonuses just weeks before the company filed for bankruptcy in July.

Biden's campaign did not directly respond to why he has remained silent on the shuttered refinery, but noted Biden's history of supporting labor, including helping to usher in the 2008 bailout of the auto industry and opposing Republican-led efforts to limit union participation. Campaign officials also referred to how Biden's clean energy plan calls for replacing oil industry jobs with well-paying, green-energy jobs.

Biden has secured some union backing. The International Association of Firefighters, one of the nation's largest unions with some 300,000 members, endorsed Biden on the first day of his campaign. The firefighters did not endorse any candidate in 2016. The United Food and Commercial Workers 1776 Keystone State, with some 35,000 members in Pennsylvania, has decided to endorse Biden, union president Wendell Young told the source for the first time.

"He has been a rock-solid supporter of labor over all these years. As much as I like all the Democrats, I know Joe, and I know what Joe has done," Young said. However, with 20 Democrats vying for the White House, including U.S. Senators Bernie Sanders and Elizabeth Warren, whose anti-Wall Street message and opposition to trade deals also resonate with the blue-collar constituency, most unions are unlikely to rush with an endorsement.

Sanders in August won the endorsement from the 35,000-strong United Electrical, Radio, and Machine Workers of America, which has long supported the Vermont senator. The signs of division among union members regarding Biden are evident.

"If Joe is the candidate, he will definitely get our support," Pat Eiding, head of Philadelphia's AFL-CIO, said. "I do think, with the refinery in Philadelphia, there are legitimate questions being asked about where he is." James Maravelias, head of Delaware's AFL-CIO, which represents some 40,000 workers and endorsed Clinton in 2016, said 2020 Democratic candidates need to demonstrate why they deserve union support.

"If Democrats think that trade union support is a slam dunk, they are sorely mistaken," Maravelias said. "As for Joe Biden, I am not sure where he is on these issues. Haven't seen him a long time."

Title: Foreign Fighters in ISIS: A Smaller Threat Than Perceived

Article:

Approximately 100 Americans and over a thousand Europeans have joined the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS), according to various reports. This raises concerns about these individuals returning to their Western homelands and potentially plotting attacks. However, the risk of such attacks is relatively low, according to experts.

Thomas Hegghammer, the director for Terrorism Research at the Norwegian Defence Research Establishment, states that the actual number of Western jihadis on the ground is lower due to many returning home. He estimates that at most one in nine Western jihadis who fought in a foreign war have come home to plot attacks, but this estimate is based on a low-end estimate of the total number of foreign fighters. The ratio of returnees attempting an attack in the West is likely between one in 20 and one in 100, according to Hegghammer.

To date, there have been "about four to six plots, involving five to ten people, in the West," Hegghammer notes. This results in a blowback rate of one in several hundred, a vanishingly small number. The number of ISIS volunteers returning to plot terrorist attacks in the West is relatively low, partly because ISIS is not prioritizing attacks on the United States or Europe, as they are too busy fighting to preserve the caliphate.

Will McCants, director of the Project on US Relations with the Islamic World at the Brookings Institution, states that it is easier to identify ISIS volunteers on their way home than on their way to Syria or Iraq. US intelligence is likely to find them, partly due to the obsession with monitoring borders and the threat they pose, but also because jihadis are known for their social media activity.

The risk is greater for European countries due to the higher number of Europeans fighting for ISIS and the difficulty in detecting them when they travel over land rather than through airports. However, even in Europe, the risk is not significant. Terrorists planning major attacks would be difficult to stay off the grid, as they would need to communicate with family, friends, or other militants to obtain materials, making them easier to intercept by European intelligence agencies.

Clint Watts, a senior fellow at the Foreign Policy Research Institute, notes that Europe has a "big problem" on its hands, but even if ISIS decides to plan a significant attack in Europe, it would be challenging to do so. Watts suggests that the complexity and time required to plan and execute a major attack, such as the 9/11 attacks, make it unreasonable to expect ISIS to replicate such an event.

Title: President Obama Pushes for Federal Gun Control Measures, Citing Colorado as Example

Article:

President Barack Obama is advocating for the reinstatement of federal gun control measures, citing Colorado as a model for such legislation. On Wednesday, the president spoke in Colorado, a state that recently passed a series of gun control bills, including background checks for all gun purchases and limits on ammunition magazine sizes.

The president aims to see similar measures implemented nationwide, but Colorado serves as a cautionary tale as well. The Century 16 movie theater in Aurora, Colorado, reopened this week following a mass shooting last summer that left 12 dead and nearly 60 others injured during a late-night screening of a Batman movie. The suspect, James Holmes, is facing the death penalty, and Colorado lawmakers responded to the shooting with new gun control laws.

State Representative Rhonda Fields, who represents the Aurora neighborhood where the movie shooting took place, shared her thoughts on the tragedy. "I could only imagine what it was like sitting in that theater, about ready to see something that you were anticipating, and then, you know, it's just a life-changing event," she said.

Fields, who lost her son to gun violence seven years earlier, became an advocate for gun control. This year, she found support in Colorado's Democratic House and Senate, with lawmakers "forced" to act after the mass shootings in Aurora and later at a Connecticut elementary school.

Obama has been counting on public outrage to advance gun control bills nationwide. "This is our best chance in more than a decade to take common-sense steps that will save lives," he said at the White House last week. Obama warned that while polls show strong support for universal background checks and other gun control measures, there is powerful opposition from the gun lobby.

Dudley Brown, who runs the Rocky Mountain Gun Owners organization, is one such opponent. His office is located in the small town of Windsor, near a river named for the gunpowder French trappers once stored there. Brown argues that universal background checks are a step toward identifying gun owners, allowing the government to seize their weapons, and calls the 15-round limit on ammunition magazines arbitrary. He threatens political payback in next year's election that could cost Colorado Democrats their majorities.

Similar threats have had a powerful effect in Washington, where universal background checks now face an uphill battle. Here in Colorado, state Representative Fields says she has no regrets. "I just feel like it was the right thing to do," she said. "It was the right thing to do for public safety. And if I get recalled because of it, I still think that I was on the right side of history."

Fields has a message for the president and Congress: Don't give up.

Title: US Navy Destroyer Collides with Oil Tanker Near Singapore, Ten Sailors Missing

Article:

Ten US Navy sailors are missing and five have been injured after the guided missile destroyer USS John S. McCain collided with an oil tanker east of Singapore. The incident occurred at 05:24 local time on Monday (21:24 GMT on Sunday) as the USS John S. McCain prepared to perform a routine port stop in Singapore.

The collision took place east of the Strait of Singapore, and the US Navy destroyer sustained damage to its port side. The tanker it collided with, Alnic MC, sustained damage to a tank near the front of the ship 7m (23ft) above the waterline, but none of its crew were injured, and there were no oil spills.

The US Navy 7th Fleet later issued a statement saying the USS John S. McCain had now arrived at Singapore's Changi naval base. Significant damage to the hull resulted in flooding to nearby compartments, including crew berthing, machinery, and communications rooms. Damage control efforts by the crew halted further flooding.

The Alnic MC is making its way to the Raffles Reserved Anchorage in Singapore. One crew member of the oil tanker told Reuters over the phone that the vessel sustained some damage to a valve. The ship was carrying nearly 12,000 tonnes of oil from Taiwan to Singapore.

The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore said there was no report of oil pollution, and traffic in the Singapore Strait is unaffected.

This is the second collision involving a US Navy ship in recent months and is thought to be the fourth such collision involving US warships in the past year alone. The timing of this incident is awkward for the United States, as it's the first day of annual drills between the US and South Korean armies.

The USS John S. McCain is part of the US Navy's 7th Fleet, its largest fleet, but this accident will add to questions about the operations of the navy in the region more widely. This is also thought to be the fourth time in a year that a US navy vessel has been involved in an accident.

Just two months ago, seven US sailors were killed when the USS Fitzgerald collided with a container ship in Japanese waters near the port city of Yokosuka. Those who died were found in flooded berths on board the ship after the collision caused a gash under the warship's waterline.

The USS John S. McCain is named after US senator John McCain's father and grandfather, both of whom were admirals in the US Navy. It is also known by its nickname Big Bad John. Operating from the US naval base in Yokosuka, Japan, it is part of the US 7th Fleet patrolling the Pacific. It has a crew of more than 300 sailors and officers and a full displacement of 9,000 tons. In May, it successfully passed a navy inspection for mission readiness at sea. The vessel was heading from Pyeongtaek, South Korea, en route from Taiwan to Singapore.

Title: House Republicans Propose New Compromise for Obamacare Repeal and Replacement

Article:

House Republicans, under pressure to deliver a win for President Trump, are working on a new compromise for the repeal and replacement of the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare). The proposal, led by Rep. Thomas MacArthur, a New Jersey Republican, aims to shift the burden of deciding what services insurers must cover to the states, while allowing insurers to charge healthy customers less, provided states set up risk pools to subsidize sicker individuals priced out of the market.

The MacArthur plan would maintain the requirement for insurers to cover individuals with pre-existing medical conditions, preserving the most popular part of the 2010 Affordable Care Act. In a statement on his Facebook page, Mr. MacArthur, chairman of the moderate Tuesday Group, said the amendment would make coverage of pre-existing conditions "sacrosanct for all Americans" and ensure essential health benefits remain the federal standard.

However, it remains unclear whether the proposal can win over enough holdouts to pass. The first attempt at repeal and replacement ended in a stalemate last month when leaders were unable to muster the votes and had to withdraw the bill. According to a Republican aide, lawmakers do not even have legislative text of the proposal, making it uncertain whether it can bridge the gap.

President Trump, however, expressed optimism about the progress, stating that House Republicans could revive their plan and hold a vote either next week or shortly thereafter. Under the MacArthur plan, states could waive Obamacare's "essential health benefits" package, which requires insurers to cover a slate of services such as mental health and maternity care. They could also scrap community rating, in which insurers are required to charge the same prices to everyone in a given area.

The plan would allow states to allow insurers to charge sicker consumers more than healthy ones, provided they set up a "high-risk pool" to absorb some of their costs. This could win over hard-line House Freedom Caucus members, but may scare off centrists who don't want to tweak the guarantees of Obamacare.

While sicker customers could still get covered, they might face high premiums, according to health care analysts. The details of the high-risk pool, including who would be in it and how much they would have to pay to get covered, will be crucial.

Critics of the plan argue that it could make coverage unaffordable for many older consumers and segregate high-cost consumers in coverage that would likely be inadequate unless the high-risk pools were very generously funded. Sen. Christopher Murphy, a Connecticut Democrat, stated, "The Republican health care repeal bill was an unworkable, unpopular piece of garbage a month ago, and it still is today."

The published plan does not provide much detail on the state waiver process, though it suggests waivers would be easy to obtain. The HHS secretary is supposed to approve the plan within 90 days of determining it is complete, provided the state attests that the purpose of their requested waiver is to reduce premium costs, increase the number of persons with health care coverage, or advance another benefit to the public interest in the state, including the guarantee of coverage for persons with pre-existing medical conditions.

Title: Recounts in Key 2016 Battleground States Show Little Change in Trump's Victory Margin

Article:

Recounts in three key 2016 battleground states are proceeding, but they are doing little to alter the mathematical basis for Donald Trump's victory. In Wisconsin, one of the states where Green Party candidate Jill Stein has sought a fresh tabulation, the president-elect has gained on Hillary Clinton. The push for a recount in Pennsylvania is awaiting a federal court's approval, and a similar effort in Michigan has encountered new judicial turbulence.

In Wisconsin, where the recount began last Thursday after Stein paid $3.5 million, there has been little change so far to the unofficial results reported on Election Day. Trump won the state by 22,000 votes over Clinton. As of Wednesday morning, Trump had widened his victory margin over Clinton in Wisconsin by 146 votes, with 23 of the state's 72 counties having finished their recounts as of Tuesday. In those counties, Trump gained 105 votes, and Clinton dropped 41 votes.

Stein, who received about 1% of the vote in the states under question, stated her intent was not to help Clinton but to verify the accuracy of the count as she believed the votes were susceptible to computer hacking. However, Reid Magney, a spokesperson for the Wisconsin Elections Commission, reported that "We're not finding any problems with the machines. The Stein campaign wanted a recount because they thought there was some problems with our machines, and that was not the case."

In Green Lake County, which is about 100 miles northwest of Milwaukee, the unofficial results from election night had Trump winning with 6,213 votes to Clinton's 2,701. The recount found that Trump actually received 6,216 votes while Clinton lost eight votes to finish with 2,693. In those counties where Clinton picked up votes on Trump, Wisconsin officials said the number was not enough to influence the results.

A statewide hand recount of Michigan's roughly 2.8 million ballots that began on Monday is now up in the air as a federal judge will hold a hearing Wednesday on whether to stop it. The state elections board is also meeting Wednesday, a day after the Michigan appeals court ordered it to dismiss Stein's recount petition, claiming she has no standing. The court noted that she received 1% of the vote and has no chance of catching Trump, who narrowly defeated Clinton in the state. A federal judge takes up the matter next.

According to the certified results from late November, Trump won the state by about 10,700 votes – or about two-tenths of a percentage point. The recount so far was looking at eight counties, including the state's largest, Wayne. A controversy is brewing in that county as officials said Tuesday that one-third of precincts could be disqualified from the recount because of problems with ballots.

Wayne County – home to Detroit – overwhelmingly voted for Clinton late last month, but officials couldn't reconcile vote totals for 610 of 1,680 precincts during a countywide canvass of vote results. During the canvass, the number of ballots in precinct poll books did not match those of voting machine printout reports in 59% of precincts, 392 of 662. Michigan state law prohibits precincts whose poll books don't match with ballots from recounting votes.

Despite the issue in Wayne County, experts say it will have little effect on the results in Michigan, or nationally. "They are not going to affect the decision, but the discrepancy certainly warrants further investigation," Ned Foley, a professor of election law at Ohio State University, told FoxNews.com. "Even if it did change the results in Michigan, it still wouldn't matter because Clinton needed to win all three states to surpass Trump in the Electoral College."

Verification measures have been taken in Pennsylvania's two largest counties – Philadelphia and Allegheny (home of Pittsburgh) – but the fate of a statewide recount rests in the hands of a federal court after Stein's Green Party filed a federal lawsuit on Monday. While Pennsylvania has yet to certify its results from November's election, an updated count by state election officials saw Trump's lead shrink to just about 46,000 over Clinton out of the 6 million votes cast in the state. So far, there have been very few reports of discrepancies in the recounts that have taken place.

A re-examination of Allegheny County voting machine results did not change any votes, and, in Philadelphia, Clinton gained only five votes after the City Commissioner's Office recounted votes in 75 of Philadelphia's more than 1,600 voting divisions in response to the recount appeal by more than 250 Philadelphia residents. These numbers are still shy of Pennsylvania's 0.5% trigger for an automatic statewide recount.

Title: Democratic Candidates Face Backlash at California Convention for Criticizing Progressive Policies

Article:

During the Democratic Party convention held in California over the weekend, candidates who did not align with the current progressive manifesto were met with boos. Former Colorado Governor John Hickenlooper was jeered when he stated that "socialism is not the answer." Similarly, former Maryland Representative John Delaney was heckled for saying that "Medicare for all" is "not good policy nor is it good politics."

The most surprising aspect of the progressive free-for-all that took place in and around San Francisco was not the lack of tolerance or the obvious distaste for debate. Instead, it was the fact that none of the candidates addressed the state's own issues, particularly the deteriorating quality of life in California due to liberal policies.

California, once one of America's most beautiful cities, is now plagued by squalid tent cities, human waste on the streets, rising crime rates, and soaring cost of living. From 2007 to 2016, California saw its population shrink by 2.5 percent, losing a net 1 million residents.

According to a poll by Edelman Intelligence, 53 percent of Californians are considering leaving the state, up from 49 percent the year before. Among millennials, the figure is 63 percent, making New York look downright popular. High housing costs and high taxes are significant reasons for the exodus. In 2018, California boasted the highest marginal tax rate in the U.S., at 12.3 percent, with an additional 1 percent for those making $1 million or more.

The majority of people moving to California are migrating from other high-tax locales like New York, New Jersey, and Illinois; they may not be aware of the state's issues, or they may be exhibiting a form of Stockholm Syndrome.

Families with children and people without a college degree are also departing en masse. They cannot afford the high cost of living in California. In other words, California legislators, who claim to be concerned for the poor, have embraced policies that are driving low-income people out of their state.

California is ranked by CNBC as the second-most expensive state in the country, behind only Hawaii. CNBC also ranks the state 48th in cost of doing business, which may be why thousands of firms are leaving California for friendlier locales.

Policies that have led to high housing costs, jacked up the cost of gasoline, and encouraged the abandonment of nuclear power and fossil fuel generation facilities are driving people and businesses out. California's energy costs may get much worse due to ambitious goals of generating half of its electricity from renewables over the next decade.

Real people living in California suffer the fallout from these policies, leading to high prices for housing and energy, a laissez-faire approach to law and order that leads to tent cities and rising crime, and big government programs that mean diminished personal freedoms.

Voters across the nation should take note, even if the candidates themselves notice nothing. Liz Peek, a former partner of major Wall Street firm Wertheim & Company and a columnist for The Fiscal Times, Fox News, the New York Sun, and numerous other organizations, wrote this article. Follow her on Twitter: @lizpeek.

Title: Senate Confirms Controversial DOJ Criminal Division Director Amid Alfa Bank Ties

Article:

The United States Senate confirmed Brian Benczkowski as the new director for the Department of Justice's (DOJ) Criminal Division in a 51-48 vote on Wednesday. The confirmation was supported by Republican senators and one Democrat, Sen. Joe Manchin from West Virginia.

Democrats had criticized Benczkowski's nomination due to his close ties with Alfa Bank, a Russian bank linked to President Vladimir Putin. Last year, while a private attorney at Kirkland & Ellis, Benczkowski represented Alfa Bank in a legal matter. The FBI had investigated the bank after it appeared in the Steele dossier, a collection of unproven allegations about President Trump. The FBI concluded there was no wrongdoing or misconduct by the bank, according to a 2017 article in The New York Times.

Benczkowski has stated he will recuse himself from any matter involving Alfa Bank during the first two years of his Justice Department tenure. However, Democrats have argued that Benczkowski's connection to the bank will undermine the investigation into Russian election interference led by Special Counsel Robert Mueller.

As head of the DOJ's criminal division, Benczkowski will play a role in overseeing Mueller's probe and the criminal investigation into Michael Cohen, the president's former personal lawyer. In May, Democrats on the Senate Judiciary Committee demanded President Trump withdraw Benczkowski's nomination, citing his continued representation of Alfa Bank during the selection process.

Attorney General Jeff Sessions praised Benczkowski's confirmation, calling him an "outstanding lawyer" with a "diverse" public service and criminal law background. Sessions added, "This will be the sixth senior position Brian has held at the Department, and we are fortunate to have someone with his breadth of experience and strong leadership skills willing to serve again."

Title: Private Organization's Control Over Presidential Debates Raises Questions About Political Representation

Article:

The Commission on Presidential Debates (CPD), a private organization that sets the criteria for presidential debates, operates under Federal Election Commission (FEC) regulations. The CPD's 2020 debate schedule, as well as a recent court opinion, has sparked discussions about the control of the government.

The CPD, despite claiming to follow pre-established, objective criteria for candidate participation, has been criticized for limiting the participation of third-party candidates in presidential debates. This limitation is a result of the CPD's power to set standards, which it can maintain as long as it does not endorse, support, or oppose a candidate and selects at least two debate candidates.

The CPD's structure allows it to satisfy FEC requirements while setting "objective" standards that are difficult for third-party candidates to meet. This is due to the fact that those with the most to gain from the major parties, such as corporations and media, can fund the debates.

The controversy surrounding the CPD began in 1987 when the League of Women Voters (The League) withdrew its support after discovering the two major political parties had control over questioners, the composition of the audience, and press access during debates. The League's president, Nancy Neuman, characterized these actions as "campaign-trail charades devoid of substance...that would perpetrate a fraud on the American voter."

Since the CPD's inception, only one third-party candidate has been invited to debate - Ross Perot, Reform Party candidate, in 1992. In the 2000 election, the CPD amended its criteria to require participants to secure at least 15% support in selected polls. This requirement is rarely achieved by a third-party candidate and is much higher than required for state ballot qualification or public financing.

The real action, however, was in the courts. Level the Playing Field and Gary Johnson, Libertarian Party, litigated against the 15% poll criteria, alleging FEC and CPD regulatory non-compliance and violations of First Amendment rights and the anti-trust laws. The FEC and the federal courts dismissed all complaints, leaving the two major parties in complete control of the debates.

An appeals court noted, "Every four years, we suffer through the celebration of democracy (and national nightmare) that is a presidential election." The trial court dismissed statements by the Republican and Democratic chairs of the CPD as "old news," stating that the CPD director asserted CPD officials are "permitted to wear multiple hats and can speak freely...in [their]...personal capacity."

The activities of the CPD are the latest efforts to ensure the two major parties control the political landscape. The results of their efforts are staggering, with the two major parties controlling 99.92% of all elected U.S. offices. Despite this massive political control, Gallup finds 61% of Americans believe a third-party is needed.

The two major parties rig the system, so they win. Who do these political parties represent?

Title: Syrian Electronic Army Website Taken Offline by Internet Body Following Alleged Disruption of Major News Websites

Article:

The website for the hacker group known as the Syrian Electronic Army (SEA) was taken offline by an Internet body in response to the group's alleged disruption of several major news websites, including The New York Times. The SEA claimed responsibility for redirecting Internet traffic from the Times' and other websites on Tuesday, leading to their account suspension by domain name registrar Name.com.

In a Tweet from the SEA's official account, @ Official_SEA16, it was stated that their website would be unavailable for several hours due to the account suspension. Name.com did not immediately respond to requests for confirmation.

Following an attack on Tuesday afternoon that took The New York Times' site offline, the company set up alternative websites, posting stories about chemical attacks in Syria. The service was restored early Wednesday.

The newspaper stated on its website that the disruption was caused by a "malicious external attack" that affected its website and email. Twitter spokesman Jim Prosser said the viewing of images and photos was sporadically affected. The Huffington Post U.K. did not respond to requests for comment.

Both Twitter and The New York Times said they were resolving the attack, which actually hit an Australian company, Melbourne IT, that registered their domain names.

Theo Hnarakis, chief executive of Melbourne IT, the world's sixth largest registrar of Internet domain names, said the security breach occurred at a major U.S.-based global reseller, or domain agent, where the hackers launched a "spear phishing attack" within the past week to steal the log-in details of the New York Times and Twitter domains.

Hnaraski declined to name the reseller, which is a major Melbourne IT client.

"This activist group used a very, very sophisticated spear phishing attack," Hnarakis told AP. "They sent very dubious emails to staff of one of our resellers whose area of expertise is looking after the domain names for major corporates including the New York Times."

"Unfortunately, a couple of the staff members of the reseller responded by giving their email log-in details; the group were able to search their emails for sensitive information that included the user name and password for the New York Times, and from there it all cascades," Hnarakis said.

"We do not put this down to a technical failure. We put it down to human error where someone has inadvertently provided their information and from there, a major site like the New York Times was down for several hours," he added.

The hackers had also attempted to hack into Twitter.com, but failed because that domain was protected by an optional secondary security feature offered by MelbourneIT for the past two years. The Times had opted not to have the same level of security.

"If they had had the security option turned on, they would not have been affected," MelbourneIT chief technology officer Bruce Tonkin said.

"We do have a security mechanism that would protect the names from this sort of attack," he added. "Naturally, we are reviewing security and doing an incident review and will probably add some additional security."

Tonkin said the hacker seemed to have also accessed the credentials of the Huffington Post domain, which is held by a UK registry.

"The hackers have just posted a screen shot to say they've logged into the (Huffington Post) account, but I'm not aware that they actually changed anything," Tonkin said.

Computer forensics from security firm Renesys Corp. traced the Internet protocol addresses back to the same ones as the Syrian Electronic Army's website, sea.sy, which the firm said has been hosted out of Russia since June.

A Syrian Electronic Army activist confirmed to The Associated Press that the group hijacked the Times' and Twitter's domains by targeting Melbourne IT.

"I can't say how, but yes we did hit Melbourne IT," the hacker said in an email. No further details were disclosed.

The hacker's true identity is not publicly known, but he has long used an email address linked to the group, and a second group member has vouched for his credentials.

The Syrian Electronic Army has, in recent months, taken credit for Web attacks on media targets that it sees as sympathetic to Syria's rebels, including prior attacks at the New York Times, along with the Washington Post, Agence France-Press, 60 Minutes, CBS News, National Public Radio, The Associated Press, Al-Jazeera English and the BBC.

Michael Fey, a chief technology officer at Santa Clara, California-based cybersecurity firm McAfee, said that as long as media organizations play a critical role as influencers and critics, they will continue to be targets of cyberattacks.

"Regardless of technology or tactics deployed, we should expect to see more of these attacks," he said.

Title: Kasich Vows to Exit Presidential Race if He Loses Ohio Primary

Article:

Republican presidential candidate John Kasich has declared that he will withdraw from the race if he fails to secure a victory in the Ohio primary next month. In a speech in Nashville, Kasich stated, "I will beat Donald Trump in Ohio, and that will be the beginning of a new day."

Kasich further commented, "Some of the other candidates, if they can't win their home state, they got to get out, OK?" He continued, "If I don't win my home state, I'll get out." The Ohio governor added, "But you know what? I'm going to win Ohio."

Kasich's statement appears to be a direct challenge to his rival, Marco Rubio, who is trailing Trump by as much as 16 points in recent polls in Rubio's home state of Florida. The Buckeye State holds its primary on March 15.

This development comes as the Republican presidential race heats up, with candidates vying for delegates to secure the party's nomination. The latest polls indicate a tight race between Trump, Rubio, and Texas Senator Ted Cruz.

© 2019 ███. All rights reserved.

Related Stories:
- Rubio: Media Will Tear Trump Apart (Link to the related story)

Title: China's Trade Surplus with U.S. Hits Record in August Amid Escalating Trade Dispute

Article:

China's trade surplus with the United States widened to a record $31.05 billion in August, according to customs data released on Saturday. This surpasses the previous record set in June. Over the first eight months of the year, China's surplus with its largest export market has risen nearly 15 percent, adding to tensions in the trade relationship between the world's two largest economies.

China's annual export growth in August moderated slightly to 9.8 percent, the data showed, the weakest rate since March but only slightly below recent trends. The number missed analysts' forecasts that shipments from the world's largest exporter would rise 10.1 percent, slowing only slightly from 12.2 percent in July.

Despite U.S. tariffs targeting $50 billion of Chinese exports being in effect for their first full month in August, China's exports to the United States still accelerated, growing 13.2 percent from a year earlier from 11.2 percent in July.

China's imports from the United States grew only 2.7 percent in August, a slowdown from 11.1 percent in July. The world's largest trading nation got off to a strong start this year, but its economic outlook is being clouded by the rapidly escalating U.S. trade dispute and cooling domestic demand.

Trump upped the ante on Friday, warning he was ready to slap tariffs on nearly all Chinese imports to the United States, threatening duties on another $267 billion of goods on top of $200 billion in imports primed for levies in coming days.

Washington has long criticized China's huge trade surplus with the United States and has demanded Beijing reduce it. However, disagreements between the two major economic powers run deeper than just the trade balance, and tensions remain over limits on U.S. firms' access to Chinese markets, intellectual property protection, technology transfers, and investment.

Imports, a key gauge of the strength of China's domestic demand, grew 20 percent, beating forecasts. Analysts had expected growth of 18.7 percent, slowing from July's surprisingly high 27.3 percent. That resulted in China posting a smaller overall trade surplus of $27.91 billion for the month. Analysts had expected the surplus would rise to $31.79 billion from $28.05 billion in July.

The surplus with the United States was larger than China's net surplus for the month, indicating China would be running a deficit if trade with the world's largest economy was excluded. While no one predicted a sudden, sharp blow from U.S. tariffs, China's official export data has been surprisingly resilient so far, with growth exceeding analysts' expectations for five months in a row.

Chinese officials acknowledged Chinese exporters have been rushing out shipments to beat new U.S. tariffs, buoying the headline growth readings, while some companies such as steel mills are diversifying and selling more products to other countries. Economists have noted that disruptions in supply chains are likely to be more company-specific, and will take time to be reflected in broad economic data and corporate earnings reports.

However, anecdotal evidence of mounting trade damage on both sides of the Pacific is on the rise. Official and private manufacturing surveys for China show global demand for Chinese goods is clearly on the wane, with export orders shrinking for months in a row.

"Risks have increased due to the negative impacts of China-U.S. trade friction. The impact on exports may gradually start to show up, with future export growth possible declining," said Liu Xuezhi, an analyst with Bank of Communications.

Policymakers have shifted their focus in recent months to improving credit conditions and shoring up business confidence. Beijing is ramping up spending on infrastructure projects to spur domestic demand and the central bank is tamping down borrowing costs and leaning on commercial banks to continue lending to struggling firms hit by trade troubles.

But such steps will take time to arrest the economy's slide, and analysts expect the government to unveil more stimulus measures if business conditions continue to deteriorate.

Title: Trump to Emphasize U.S. Sovereignty at UN General Assembly

Article:

U.S. President Donald Trump is set to address the United Nations General Assembly next week, continuing his focus on U.S. sovereignty amid concerns from some world leaders about America's commitment to multilateralism. According to U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations Nikki Haley, Trump's address on Tuesday will serve as a "marker" on U.S. foreign aid and a reaffirmation of the importance of U.S. sovereignty.

In the past year, the United States has withdrawn from several international agreements and organizations, including the Iran nuclear deal, the U.N. Human Rights Council, the Paris climate agreement, and global talks on a migration pact. The U.S. has also left the U.N. cultural agency, cut funding for the U.N. agency that helps Palestinian refugees, and sparked a trade war with China. At a NATO summit in July, Trump threatened that the U.S. would "go its own way" if members did not spend more on defense.

Trump is now surrounded by hawkish advisers, such as Secretary of State Mike Pompeo and National Security Adviser John Bolton, after the departure of their predecessors Rex Tillerson and H.R. McMaster, along with former White House economic adviser Gary Cohn. While some leaders and diplomats have expressed concern about the future of multilateralism since Trump took office in January last year, they rarely name and shame.

U.N. Secretary-General Antonio Guterres declined to comment on Trump's impact on multilateralism, stating, "I don't like to personalize things." Guterres did, however, acknowledge that trust in political establishments, among states, and in international organizations has been eroded.

Trump is expected to chair a U.N. Security Council meeting on nonproliferation of weapons of mass destruction on Wednesday, allowing him to address Iran and flaunt the latest developments in his attempt to get North Korea to denuclearize. Trump has long been skeptical of the value of the United Nations, though Haley has shown him the world body's worth by pushing the Security Council several times to toughen sanctions on North Korea.

Trump is planning to meet privately with the leaders of South Korea, Egypt, France, Israel, Japan, and Britain. French President Emmanuel Macron, who has a close relationship with Trump, will stress the importance of "collective action" and multilateralism in his address to the United Nations shortly after Trump. A French presidential source stated, "We don't see it as two opposing dialogues. We will continue to encourage the U.S. to join this multilateralism even if it's difficult on some subjects like trade, Iran, or climate."

Title: Mitt Romney Suggests Return to Pre-ACA Healthcare System, Faces Criticism on Insurance Coverage and Medicaid Cuts

Article:

In a rally in Mt. Vernon, Ohio, former Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney hinted at his plan to replace the Affordable Care Act (ACA), suggesting a return to the status quo ante. Romney stated, "We had health care in America before Obamacare came along. And we still have health care in America."

However, the statement overlooks the fact that millions of Americans did not have health insurance before the ACA. According to the U.S. Census Bureau, approximately 4 in 25 Americans, or nearly 49 million Americans, had no health insurance last year. The Congressional Budget Office estimates that repealing the ACA would deny access to insurance to about 30 million Americans who would receive coverage if the president's reforms were to stay in place.

Romney also failed to mention that his budget proposal to cap federal spending at 20 percent of Gross Domestic Product (GDP) and boost defense spending to 4 percent of GDP would result in massive cuts to Medicaid. The Center for Budget and Policy Priorities estimates that Medicaid and the Children's Health Insurance Program "would face cumulative cuts of $1.5 trillion through 2022 if Medicare is subject to cuts and $1.9 trillion if Medicare is exempt." As a result, "14 to 19 million more people" would join "the ranks of the uninsured."

In a Wednesday meeting with the editorial board of an Ohio newspaper, The Dispatch, Romney again suggested that the pre-reform health care system was good enough and also minimized the gravity of forgoing insurance. He stated, "We don't have a setting across this country where if you don't have insurance, we just say to you, 'Tough luck, you're going to die when you have your heart attack.'" Instead, "you go to the hospital, you get treated, you get care, and it's paid for, either by charity, the government, or by the hospital."

However, Families USA, a health care advocacy group, issued a report in June indicating that 26,100 people between the ages of 25 and 64 died prematurely due to lack of health coverage in 2010. The implication is that forgoing insurance can have serious consequences, contradicting Romney's assertion that people can still receive care without insurance.

Title: Sen. Rand Paul Proposes $2.6 Trillion Federal Spending Limit at Reagan Library

Article:

Sen. Rand Paul (R-KY) outlined a proposed spending limit for the federal government at $2.6 trillion during a policy speech at the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library in Simi Valley, California on Friday. The libertarian-conservative senator, who is a potential 2016 presidential candidate, emphasized his stance as a fiscal conservative while addressing a crowd of supporters and skeptics.

"I'm not against all government. I'm actually for $2.6 trillion dollars worth," Paul said, distinguishing himself from the perception that some Republicans hold about libertarians.
