He aimed to clarify his position as a libertarian-conservative who values the environment and supports common-sense regulations balanced with economic growth and job creation.

Paul also addressed the Republican Party's image problem, stating that the GOP needs to change perceptions in order to win in "bluish" states like California. He argued that Republicans care deeply about the environment but also prioritize job creation and economic growth.

The senator's speech comes as he positions himself as a potential candidate for the 2016 presidential election, seeking to define his political identity and distinguish himself from his father, former Texas Rep. Ron Paul, who had a controversial image among some Republicans.

Title: Senate to Decide on Fast-Track Trade Negotiating Powers Amidst Climate Change Controversy

Article:

The Senate is set to decide on Tuesday whether to grant President Barack Obama fast-track negotiating powers, also known as Trade Promotion Authority (TPA), in a major filibuster showdown. The decision is significant as the TPA is crucial for the president to conclude negotiations on a 12-nation Pacific Rim trade deal.

The debate surrounding the TPA has become a battleground for global warming, with opponents on both sides of the political spectrum expressing concerns. Conservatives argue that the TPA could be used to write a binding climate deal into any agreement, while liberal opponents question the agreement's effectiveness in addressing climate change.

Sen. Jeff Sessions, an Alabama Republican leading conservative opponents, fears that the TPA could provide Obama with the means to impose global warming controls on the U.S. by negotiating stricter greenhouse gas emissions into a binding international agreement and circumventing Congress.

In response, U.S. Trade Representative Michael B.G. Froman has insisted that the administration is not trying to deceive Congress. In a letter this month to Rep. F. James Sensenbrenner Jr., Wisconsin Republican, Mr. Froman ruled out a number of areas where Republicans fear circumvention, including climate change agreements.

However, a bill Republicans are trying to pass as part of the trade package, known as the customs enforcement legislation, adds even more restrictions to the president's powers, including a specific prohibition on negotiating global warming or immigration deals as part of trade agreements.

Democratic trade opponents, on the other hand, fear that these restrictions could hinder the U.S.'s ability to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions. The trade package has been on weak legislative ground for weeks, with opponents voting against worker assistance to poison the entire package.

The Senate will vote Tuesday on heading off a filibuster of the fast-track powers bill, then likely will vote Wednesday on the worker assistance legislation, which has been coupled with a popular set of trade preferences for African countries and Haiti—a bid to entice Democrats.

The fast-track bill could go straight to the president after passage, but the worker assistance would have to go back to the House, where Democrats would be faced with a final decision on whether to further embarrass their party leader. Congress is also likely to vote on beginning a conference committee to hammer out final details on the customs enforcement bill.

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, Kentucky Republican, expressed optimism, stating, "With just a little more trust, a little more cooperation, and simply voting consistently, we'll get there."

Title: President Obama Rates Affordable Care Act an "8," Cites Progress and Ongoing Challenges

Article:

In an interview with ABC News published on Wednesday, former President Barack Obama rated his signature health care law, the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare), an "8" on a scale from 1 to 10. He acknowledged that there is still room for improvement in the 2010 overhaul, which has been a political flashpoint since its passage.

President Obama highlighted the progress made by the Affordable Care Act in reducing the number of uninsured Americans. He stated, "Sixteen million people or more have health insurance that didn't have it before." He also mentioned that the law's cost has been lower than projected, although he expressed disappointment that many states have not expanded the Medicaid program for the poor.

The Affordable Care Act encourages states to extend the federal-state Medicaid program to individuals earning up to 138 percent of the federal poverty level. The federal government covers 100 percent of the expansion's cost from 2014 to 2016, before scaling back its contribution to 90 percent in 2020 and beyond. However, due to the Supreme Court's decision, only 28 states and the District of Columbia have expanded their Medicaid programs.

President Obama criticized this situation, stating, "We're just seeing some stubbornness that's really based on ideology, not on wise public health policy, that is preventing most people in most states from getting the Medicaid that would save the state money in the long term."

The overall health law remains a key target for the Republican-majority Congress, which is aiming to use a budget tool called "reconciliation" to pass a filibuster-proof repeal bill, forcing President Obama to veto their actions. Additionally, the Supreme Court is set to rule by June on whether the administration is unlawfully paying out exchange subsidies to at least 34 states that rely on the federal HealthCare.gov portal. Without these subsidies, the law would be less attractive in those states, potentially providing the GOP with an opportunity to push their own health reforms.

President Obama has expressed a willingness to make changes to his law, having signed some measures and delayed parts of the law, but not the type of Republican-led bills that would scrap its mandates or otherwise weaken it.

Title: U.S. Military Raid on Islamic State Leader Yields Intelligence and Second Raid Resulting in Death of Spokesman

Article:

The U.S. military raid that resulted in the death of Islamic State (IS) founder Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi also produced valuable intelligence concerning the militant group and its top leaders, according to defense officials. The intelligence, which includes data-storage devices and other files, is expected to contribute to the understanding of IS as the U.S. and its allies continue their pursuit of IS leaders and operatives.

In a subsequent operation, a U.S. raid led to the death of IS's top spokesman, Abu al-Hassan al-Muhajir, according to a senior State Department official. The operation was announced by the Kurdish-led Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF), who worked with U.S. troops in fighting IS before President Trump ordered a U.S. withdrawal.

Following the U.S. raid on Saturday, Baghdadi's remains were buried at sea, a U.S. official told The Wall Street Journal, similar to the disposition of the body of al Qaeda leader Osama bin Laden after he was killed in a 2011 U.S. raid in Pakistan.

Gen. Mark Milley, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said at a briefing on Monday that Baghdadi's remains were handled appropriately, without elaborating. Gen. Milley and Defense Secretary Mark Esper, addressing reporters at the Pentagon, said they are working to declassify images of the Saturday raid at Baghdadi's compound and may soon release them to the public.

Many questions about the raid remain unanswered, as officials have not provided details about the 11 children and two adults they said were taken from the Baghdadi compound, or about the three children Mr. Trump said were killed with Baghdadi when he fled into a dead-end tunnel and detonated a suicide vest. Officials have not disclosed how many people were believed killed in the operation or whether any civilian casualties may have resulted.

U.S. warplanes aimed guided bombs at the compound, destroying it after members of the U.S. Army Rangers and Delta Force teams departed, defense officials said. Gen. Milley and Mr. Esper were with Mr. Trump on Saturday, watching the raid as it unfolded on video taken from various angles, an experience the president likened to a movie.

However, Gen. Milley said he was unable to confirm Mr. Trump's assertions that Baghdadi was crying and whimpering as he tried to flee. The video seen at the White House didn't capture the audio of Mr. Baghdadi's voice in the underground tunnel where he eventually died, defense officials said.

Mr. Trump spoke to some of the more than 50 U.S. special-operations team members who took part in the raid, but Gen. Milley did not. A U.S. military dog assisting troops chased Baghdadi into the tunnel and was injured. Gen. Milley and Mr. Esper declined to release the dog's name, citing operational security. However, a defense official identified the dog as a Belgian malinois, a breed frequently used to support military units, and Gen. Milley said the dog was still in the region and would fully recover.

Title: Democratic Candidates Make Last-Minute Push in Iowa Ahead of Caucuses

Article:

On the eve of the Iowa caucuses, Democratic presidential candidates intensified their efforts to rally voters and secure support in the final hours before the contest. Speaking to several hundred supporters in Cedar Rapids on Sunday, Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders declared, "We are the campaign of energy and excitement," and expressed confidence in their position to win on Monday night.

Pete Buttigieg, the 38-year-old former mayor of South Bend, Indiana, emphasized his newcomer status, telling a rally in Coralville that when Democrats have won the White House in the past, "we have done it with someone who is new in national politics."

Former Vice President Joe Biden, highlighting his decades of Washington experience, told voters there is no time for "on-the-job training." Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren urged her supporters to "fight back" if they ever lose hope.

The Democratic race in Iowa is unusually large and jumbled, with four candidates locked in a fight for victory, and others in position to pull off surprisingly strong finishes. Polls show Biden in a close race in Iowa with Sanders, Warren, and Buttigieg. Minnesota Sen. Amy Klobuchar and tech entrepreneur Andrew Yang are also competing aggressively in the state.

The deep disdain for President Donald Trump has put many in the party on edge about the decision. A series of external forces has also heightened the sense of unpredictability in Iowa, including Trump's impeachment trial in the Senate, which kept Warren, Sanders, and Klobuchar in Washington for much of the past week.

New caucus rules have left the campaigns working in overdrive to set expectations before the contest. For the first time, the Iowa Democratic Party will release three sets of results: who voters align with at the start of the night, who they pick after voters supporting nonviable candidates get to make a second choice, and the number of state delegate equivalents each candidate gets.

The new rules were mandated by the Democratic National Committee as part of a package of changes sought by Sanders following his loss to Hillary Clinton in the 2016 presidential primaries. The revisions were designed to make the caucus system more transparent and to ensure that even the lowest-performing candidates get credit for all the votes they receive. However, party officials in Iowa and at the DNC have privately expressed concerns in recent weeks that not just Sanders but multiple campaigns will spin the results in their favor, potentially creating chaos on caucus night.

The Iowa Democratic Party will declare a winner based on the number of state delegates each candidate wins. The AP will also report all three results. Biden's campaign appeared to be trying to lower Iowa expectations, cautioning against reading too much into Monday's results. Biden is hoping to sustain enough enthusiasm and money coming out of Iowa to make it to more diverse states where he hopes to draw strong support from black voters. His campaign is particularly focused on South Carolina, the fourth state on the primary schedule.

Sanders, Warren, and Klobuchar fanned out across the state, trying to make up ground after missing most of the last two weeks of campaigning due to the Senate impeachment trial. In a conference room in Cedar Rapids, Klobuchar appealed to caucus-goers by asking them to think about the voters who won't be caucusing—moderate Republicans, voters who swung from Barack Obama to Trump, and voters who stayed home in 2016.

Many voters are still making last-minute moves. According to a Monmouth University poll in Iowa in late January, 45% of all likely Democratic caucus-goers named a first choice but said they were open to the possibility of supporting another candidate, and another 5% did not indicate a first choice. Indeed, talking to Iowa Democrats can be dizzying. Many can quickly run through what they like—and what worries them—about the candidates in rapid fire, talking themselves in and out of their choices in a matter of minutes.

Title: Ferguson Mayor Maintains No Racial Divide in City Despite Ongoing Tensions

Article:

Ferguson Mayor James Knowles reaffirmed his stance on racial tensions in his city during a Tuesday interview with MSNBC's Tamron Hall, asserting that none of the city's residents believe there is a racial divide in the community.

During the contentious interview, Knowles, who has previously downplayed racial tensions in Ferguson's history, was asked whether his opinions had changed in light of the outcries following the fatal shooting of unarmed African-American 18-year-old Michael Brown on Aug. 9.

"I don't believe that's the case, still. There's not a racial divide in the city of Ferguson," the mayor said.

When asked about the source of this perspective, Hall inquired, "According to whom? Is that your perspective, or do you believe that is the perspective of African-Americans in your community?"

Knowles responded, "That is the perspective of all residents in our city, absolutely."

The mayor also stated that the violent clashes between protesters and police officers since Brown's death have involved a small minority of Ferguson's black community. "There's 22,000 residents in our community. This has affected about a half-mile strip of street in our community," he said of the demonstrations. "The rest of the African-Americans in our community are going about their daily lives, going to our businesses, walking their dogs, going to our neighborhood watch meetings."

Though he acknowledged criticism that Ferguson's police department is disproportionately white, with more than 90 percent of the force being white and blacks making up 63 percent of the city's population, Knowles still maintained that Ferguson was a "model" for Missouri.

Knowles has faced criticism about potential racial issues in his police department. According to official Ferguson police statistics, 86 percent of all stops and 92 percent of all searches in 2013 were of black people. Blacks were also arrested nearly twice as much as whites.

Knowles has previously called allegations that Ferguson has experienced racial tensions through its history "absolutely ridiculous."

Title: House Democrats to Begin Passing Individual Spending Bills Amid Government Shutdown

Article:

House Democrats have announced plans to start passing individual spending bills this week, starting with a bill that funds the Internal Revenue Service (IRS). The move is intended to pressure congressional Republicans and the White House during the ongoing partial government shutdown.

Speaker Nancy Pelosi announced the strategy over the weekend, following the Democrats' passage of a package of bills on Thursday that provides full-year funding for eight affected departments and extends current-year funding for homeland security until September 8.

According to Pelosi, the first individual bill on the agenda is the spending bill that covers the Treasury Department and IRS. "This action is necessary so that the American people can receive their tax refunds on schedule," Pelosi said. "The certainty of the tax returns of hard-working families should no longer be held hostage to the president's reckless demands."

The White House has already rejected the House-passed legislation, stating it falls short on border security. However, passing the bills one-by-one allows Democrats to highlight the potential real-world effects of the partial shutdown, which has now extended beyond two weeks.

Rep. Nita Lowey, chairwoman of the House Appropriations Committee, stated, "Unless Congress acts, the American people will not receive their tax refunds, families will lose food stamps, homebuyers seeking mortgages will remain in limbo, and our National Parks will continue to accumulate garbage and waste."

In addition to the Treasury Department and IRS bill, House Democrats also plan to act on three other individual bills that cover funding for the departments of agriculture, interior, and transportation, among other programs.

During the 2013 government shutdown, House Republicans employed a similar strategy, rolling out smaller, piecemeal bills to re-open shuttered national parks and other programs to try to pressure the Senate, then controlled by Democrats. However, former Sen. Harry Reid, then the majority leader, wouldn't take them up, stating lawmakers shouldn't pick and choose individual departments and that the entire government should be re-opened.

In October 2013, Mr. Reid rejected a question on why Democrats wouldn't take up a bill to fund the National Institutes of Health. "If you can help one child who has cancer, why wouldn't you do it?" asked CNN's Dana Bash. "Why would we want to do that?" replied Mr. Reid, Nevada Democrat. Mr. Reid later tweeted, "Republicans are in such desperate straits that they have literally resorted to accusing me of not caring about kids with cancer. Shameful."

Title: Trump Reaffirms Support for School Safety Measures, Defers Action on Age Limit for Gun Purchases

Article:

President Donald Trump has stated that the issue of raising the minimum age for purchasing certain guns is moving rapidly, but he is currently observing court cases and rulings before taking any action himself. In a tweet on Monday, Trump referred to the age limits as "18 to 21 Age Limits," stating that he is "watching court cases and rulings before acting."

The National Rifle Association (NRA) filed a federal lawsuit last Friday over gun control legislation signed by Florida Governor Rick Scott, which raises the age to buy guns in the state from 18 to 21. Under federal law, licensed firearm dealers cannot sell handguns to individuals under 21 and cannot sell long guns to those under 18. Trump has suggested supporting a raise in the age for long guns to 21.

However, the White House's recent proposals to prevent school shootings did not include a plan to raise the minimum age to buy long guns. The proposals do, however, include a full audit and review of the FBI tip line after warnings about the student who carried out the shooting at a Florida high school last month were not acted upon.

The administration reaffirmed Trump's support for a congressional measure, known as Fix NICS, that aims to help local officials improve efforts to enter data into the National Instant Criminal Background Check System. The administration also supports the STOP School Violence Act, which aims to improve school security and provide some funding for such efforts.

Trump tweeted Monday that "Very strong improvement and strengthening of background checks will be fully backed by White House. Legislation moving forward. Bump Stocks will soon be out. Highly trained expert teachers will be allowed to conceal carry, subject to State Law. Armed guards OK, deterrent!"

The president also reiterated his opposition to schools being designated as gun-free zones, stating, "If schools are mandated to be gun free zones, violence and danger are given an open invitation to enter. Almost all school shootings are in gun free zones. Cowards will only go where there is no deterrent!"

The recommendations were announced nearly a month after the mass shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Florida.

Title: U.S. Vice President Assures Baltic States of U.S. Support in Face of Potential Russian Aggression

Article:

U.S. Vice President Mike Pence has assured the Baltic states of U.S. support if they face aggression from Russia, reaffirming Washington's commitment to NATO's collective defense doctrine. During a meeting with the presidents of Estonia, Latvia, and Lithuania, Pence emphasized the U.S.'s unwavering support for NATO's Article 5, which requires member countries to defend each other if attacked.

Pence's comments come amidst Russia's 2014 annexation of Crimea from Ukraine and President Donald Trump's early lukewarm support for NATO. In May, during a visit to NATO's Brussels headquarters, Trump caused concern among allies by not restating U.S. support for a critical portion of the alliance's charter and instead criticized some members for insufficient defense spending. However, Trump has since stated his support for Article 5.

"A strong and united NATO is more necessary today than at any point since the collapse of communism a quarter-century ago, and no threat looms larger in the Baltic states than the specter of aggression from your unpredictable neighbor to the east," Pence said at a news conference with the three Baltic presidents. "Under President Donald Trump, the United States stands firmly behind our Article 5 pledge of mutual defense. An attack on one of us is an attack on us all."

Russia is scheduled to hold large-scale military maneuvers with its ally Belarus next month. The U.S. army's top general in Europe stated this month that the Zapad war games could be a "Trojan horse," potentially resulting in military equipment being left in Belarus. The general warned that Russia continues to "seek to redraw international borders by force, undermine democracies of sovereign nations, and divide the free nations of Europe, one against another."

Lithuania's President Dalia Grybauskaite told Lithuanian radio that NATO's air-policing missions would be doubled during the Russian-led Zapad exercise. Pence is also due to visit Montenegro, NATO's newest member, and make a stop in Georgia, an aspiring member, which fought a brief war with Russia in 2008.

Title: Unscripted Speech by Clint Eastwood at the Republican National Convention Causes Stir

Article:

The unscripted and seemingly improvised speech delivered by actor Clint Eastwood during the Republican National Convention has become a topic of discussion on social media and cable news, overshadowing the usual post-convention analysis that the Romney campaign had hoped to benefit from. The speech, which was described as "strange," "weird," and "theater of the absurd" by Romney's advisers, left Ann Romney and other top aides unsettled.

In the speech, Eastwood, 82, engaged in a seemingly one-sided conversation with an invisible President Obama, sitting next to him. The speech was a departure from the usual scripted speeches at the convention, with Eastwood misstating the number of unemployed people and making other off-the-cuff remarks.

The Romney campaign had kept Eastwood's role a secret, listing his slot as "to be announced" on the public schedule. As the last night of the convention approached, planners tried to keep the actor's appearance under wraps, hoping it would be a pleasant surprise. However, his name leaked out on the internet, and his speech became a topic of speculation.

Eastwood's speech was scheduled for about five minutes but lasted more than twice as long, throwing off the schedule for Mitt Romney. The actor, who is generally liked and respected in Hollywood, is known for his disdain for teleprompters and chose not to use one during the speech.

The Romney campaign has not commented on the internal decision-making process regarding Eastwood's speech. However, it is known that Eastwood asked for a chair backstage at the last minute and stayed onstage for an extended period, causing a delay in the convention's schedule.

The reaction to Eastwood's speech has been mixed, with some praising it as bold and others criticizing it as a waste of a prime-time slot that could have been used for other speakers or the biographical video of Mitt Romney's life. Eastwood's next film, "Trouble With the Curve," is set for release on September 21.

Eastwood's manager, Leonard Hirshan, said the actor does these things for himself and believes in what he is doing. Hirshan also mentioned that he had heard a chorus of response since the speech, divided evenly between those supportive and those critical.

Title: President Trump Criticizes Rep. Thomas Massie for Threatening to Delay Coronavirus Relief Bill

Article:

In a series of tweets on March 27, 2020, President Donald Trump criticized Representative Thomas Massie (R-KY) for his intention to demand a recorded vote on the $2 trillion coronavirus relief bill. The potential vote could delay the bill's passage, leading to additional costs and potential danger for workers and small businesses.

Trump tweeted, "Looks like a third-rate grandstander named @RepThomasMassie, a Congressman from unfortunately, a truly GREAT State, Kentucky, wants to vote against the new Save Our Workers Bill in Congress. He just wants the publicity. He can’t stop it, only delay, which is both dangerous and costly."

In another tweet, Trump stated, "Workers & small businesses need money now in order to survive. Virus wasn’t their fault. It is “HELL” dealing with the Dems, had to give up some stupid things in order to get the “big picture” done. 90% GREAT! WIN BACK HOUSE, but throw Massie out of Republican Party!"

Representative Ruben Gallego (D-AZ) expressed his displeasure with Massie's actions, stating on Twitter, "I am jumping on the red eye tonight... thanks Massie."

Representative Dean Phillips (D-MN) also criticized Massie, tweeting, "Dear @RepThomasMassie: If you intend to delay passage of the #coronavirus relief bill tomorrow morning, please advise your 428 colleagues RIGHT NOW so we can book flights and expend ~$200,000 in taxpayer money to counter your principled but terribly misguided stunt."

Representative Gil Cisneros (D-CA) added, "Taking a red eye tonight." He continued, "The American people, small businesses, and our healthcare workers need relief now."

The relief bill, Phase Three of Congress's coronavirus relief effort, passed the Senate on Thursday by a vote of 96-0, following several days of contentious debate. The bill was initially focused on targeted relief for individuals and businesses in financial straits due to the coronavirus outbreak, but much of the disagreement centered around House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's liberal wish list, including new environmental measures and millions of dollars in funding for D.C.'s John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts. The House is currently in session debating the relief bill.

Title: Trump Adopts More Presidential Tone in Final Republican Debate Before Crucial Primaries

Article:

In a shift towards a more presidential demeanor, Donald Trump, the Republican frontrunner, displayed a lack of insults, crude remarks, and the characteristic eye-rolling during the final Republican debate before next week's critical round of primaries. The debate, held in Miami, marked a more substantive and dignified performance by all four remaining candidates, helping to restore the Republican brand from the brink following a previous debate's debacle.

The debate's focus on policy, albeit in generalities, raised questions about Trump's knowledge, and he was criticized for his at-times tenuous understanding of certain issues. For instance, when asked about the Common Core education standards, Trump stated, "Education through Washington, D.C. I do not want that," despite Common Core being a state-led program.

Trump also maintained his stance on Islam, stating, "I mean a lot of them [Muslims]. I mean a lot of them," when asked about his comment that Islam hates the United States. This statement drew criticism from fellow candidates, including Sen. Marco Rubio, who emphasized the importance of presidential actions having consequences.

Ohio Gov. John Kasich and Sen. Ted Cruz of Texas also delivered crisp performances, with Kasich focusing on the need for cooperation with Arab Muslim countries to defeat ISIS, and Cruz criticizing the Obama administration's opening to Cuba.

The trajectory of the Republican nomination could be significantly influenced by next Tuesday's primaries, with five states holding primaries, and two of them awarding all delegates to the winner. If Trump wins both Florida and Ohio, he will have a near-lock on the nomination. If he wins one but not the other, he will still be well on his way. If he loses both, the race will be wide open.

Trump's at-times tenuous knowledge of policy has not seemed to deter his supporters, and when he is called out on loose comments during debates, he tends to press forward. In the debate, Trump also backed down on his proposed 45% tariff on Chinese goods, stating it could be less than 45%.

The debate's performance was a demonstration of Trump's negotiating style, which, if he becomes president, may take some getting used to on the world stage. However, this style has proven successful for him in both business and, so far, as a presidential candidate.

In his subdued performance on the debate stage, Trump demonstrated how style can often be more important than substance in the minds of many voters.

Title: Congressional Leaders Meet with Obama Amidst Sequester Crisis; GOP Proposes Alternative Cuts

Article:

As the deadline for $85 billion in spending cuts, known as the sequester, approaches, Congress is scrambling to find a solution. On Wednesday, during a visit to the Capitol, President Obama briefly conversed with Hill leaders, but no significant progress was reported. Congressional leaders are set to meet with Obama at the White House on Friday.

Republicans are skeptical about the meeting, with a senior GOP aide telling CNN that it may be nothing more than a public relations effort by the president.

In response to the impending sequester, Senate Republicans are pushing a proposal that would give the president flexibility to decide where the cuts would occur. Under the GOP plan, Obama would be required to submit a list of replacement cuts to Congress by March 15, and could not cut defense by more than $42.7 billion.

Democrats are concerned that this plan would shift responsibility for the cuts onto the president's shoulders, while some critics consider it an abdication of Congress's power of the purse. Democrats are advocating for replacing much of the sequester with tax revenue from millionaires, eliminating agriculture subsidies, and reducing defense spending after the end of combat operations in Afghanistan next year.

However, Republicans are virtually unified in opposing any new taxes. Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid (D-Nevada) and Minority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Kentucky) are believed to be unable to pull off a deal due to the 60-vote threshold in the 100-member chamber.

Meanwhile, House Speaker John Boehner (R-Ohio) has suspended the use of military aircraft for official travel by House members, as Congress is required to reduce its own expenses.

In a separate development, House Judiciary Committee Chairman Bob Goodlatte (R-Virginia) accused the administration of releasing undocumented workers with criminal records due to the looming cuts. The administration, however, maintains that the decision to release certain undocumented workers was made by career employees without White House input.

Title: House Speaker John Boehner Rules Out House Passage of Senate Immigration Bill, Pursues Own Legislation

Article:

House Speaker John A. Boehner has declared that the House will not pass the Senate's immigration bill, instead opting to debate and pass its own legislation. In a joint statement with top House Republican leaders, they expressed their commitment to addressing the broken immigration system but emphasized the House's intention to produce its own legislation through regular order.

The Republican leaders' statement aims to counter the momentum behind the Senate bill, which passed a bipartisan 13-5 vote in a committee this week. The House GOP's stance is part of a political chess game between Boehner and House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, as a bipartisan group of lawmakers works on a comprehensive immigration deal that includes legal status for illegal immigrants and a rewrite of the legal immigration system.

Rep. Luis V. Gutierrez, an Illinois Democrat and part of the bipartisan group, stated that a bipartisan bill in the House has the best chance of passing and producing a good immigration reform proposal when conferenced with the Senate's bipartisan bill.

Boehner has also given the green light for two committees to work on specific aspects of the immigration bill. The Homeland Security Committee has already approved a border security bill, and the Judiciary Committee is preparing to move on legislation creating an agriculture guest-worker program and another bill to establish a nationwide electronic verification system for businesses to check their workers' legal status.

The House's approach differs from the Senate bill, which rewrites the legal immigration system and extends quick legal status to illegal immigrants with a pathway to citizenship. Democrats argue that citizenship rights are non-negotiable, while Republicans are still grappling with this issue.

Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid has announced that he will put the immigration bill on the Senate floor next month. Key Senate Republicans have stated that they will not attempt to filibuster to block the bill from coming to the Senate floor. There is speculation that if a bill emerges from the Senate, Democrats may call on the House to pass it as well. The House Republican statement appears to be an attempt to shut down this avenue.

The leaders stated, "Enacting policy as consequential and complex as immigration reform demands that both chambers of Congress engage in a robust debate and amendment process."

One issue holding up the bipartisan House negotiations on immigration is the insistence on creating a nationwide electronic verification system to check workers' legal status. Pelosi stated, "If E-Verify is not effectively accomplished in five years, then all of these people revert to the status they have now. I think that's pretty drastic." However, she denied reports that she was insisting on broader health care coverage for illegal immigrants. Pelosi accepted the decision in the 2010 health care law that makes them ineligible.

Title: National Republicans Express Concern Over Mark Sanford's Chances in South Carolina Congressional Race

Article:

Mark Sanford, the former South Carolina governor, secured the Republican nomination for the state's 1st Congressional District on Tuesday, but national Republicans are not celebrating. Many privately concede that Sanford could hand a safe Republican seat to Democrat Elizabeth Colbert Busch.

The affair that derailed Sanford's political career is just one of his liabilities. Fellow GOP politicians do not like him, and he does not appeal to female voters. His campaign is primarily focused on seeking forgiveness for his transgressions from four years ago, which makes it challenging to take the offensive against Colbert Busch.

The concern among national Republicans that Colbert Busch could win the 1st Congressional District seat is so real that they are prepared to invest significant resources to help Sanford, including pouring money into the race. However, Sanford's forces will find it difficult to outraise Colbert Busch, as her brother, Stephen Colbert, is actively fundraising for her campaign.

One national GOP official stated, "This race is by no means a slam dunk for Republicans. If anyone says they know how this race is going to play out, they're kidding themselves."

Operatives from both parties agree that the race is Sanford's to lose. The district is solid Republican territory, and Sanford, despite his flaws, is a skilled retail politician who is widely known. While Colbert Busch's campaign quickly labeled Sanford as untrustworthy and anti-woman on Tuesday night, Sanford framed the general election as a clash of ideologies between a small government conservative and a pro-union liberal.

However, polling already shows Sanford in a tight race, and several warning signs for Sanford cannot be ignored:

* Not a single member of the South Carolina congressional delegation has endorsed Sanford, an indication of his weak standing among his potential Washington colleagues. Two House Republicans backed one of Sanford's primary rivals. GOP leaders are struggling to get the delegation on board now that he has defeated former Charleston County Councilman Curtis Bostic in the runoff.
* Particular attention will be paid to popular Sen. Tim Scott, whose appointment to the Senate triggered the race for his House seat. Scott has remained neutral in the race, but national Republicans will want him to endorse Sanford.
* In 2009, Scott, then a state representative, signed a letter calling on Sanford to resign. The ex-governor opted to serve out his term.
* Sanford's actions "reveal a pattern of poor decision making and questionable leadership," read the letter. "Unless major changes are made, South Carolina will find itself perpetually sidetracked by the disarray that you have brought upon our state."

Title: E.W. Jackson, Virginia's Republican Lieutenant Governor Nominee, Compares Planned Parenthood to the Ku Klux Klan

Article:

E.W. Jackson, the newly-nominated Republican candidate for lieutenant governor of Virginia, has drawn criticism for past comments comparing Planned Parenthood to the Ku Klux Klan and accusing African-Americans of having a "slavish devotion" to the Democratic Party.

In a self-produced video posted on YouTube last year, Jackson, an African-American pastor and attorney from Chesapeake, made the comments in a message to black Christians. He stated, "The Democrat Party has created an unholy alliance between certain so-called civil rights leaders and Planned Parenthood, which has killed unborn black babies by the tens of millions. Planned Parenthood has been far more lethal to black lives than the KKK ever was."

Democrats have seized on these remarks and others in an attempt to tie Jackson to the rest of the Republican ticket in Virginia, particularly conservative gubernatorial nominee Ken Cuccinelli. The two will face Democrat Terry McAuliffe, the former Democratic National Committee chairman, in the November election.

"Extremely divisive rhetoric from Jackson and Cuccinelli reflects the social agenda they would impose on Virginia," McAuliffe campaign spokesman Brennan Bilberry said in a statement. "At a time when Virginians are looking for leaders who focus on jobs, the Tea Party has nominated a ticket whose careers have been defined by a radical social agenda."

Cuccinelli and Jackson were nominated at Saturday's GOP convention in Richmond, where Jackson beat out six other candidates for the number two spot on the ticket. Party activists tapped Mark Obenshain to be their nominee for attorney general.

Jackson, the founder of a nondenominational church, is a former Marine and graduate of Harvard Law School. However, he is rapidly becoming known for a series of controversial statements that have surfaced online following his surprise victory on Saturday. He has publicly questioned President Barack Obama's faith and has been spearheading efforts to recruit black Democrats to the GOP since last year, when he unsuccessfully ran for Senate in Virginia.

In the same video, Jackson said, "Shame on us for allowing ourselves to be sold to the highest bidder. We belong to God." He also stated, "Our ancestors were sold against their will centuries ago, but we're going through the slave market voluntarily today."

As lieutenant governor, Jackson would hold the tie-breaking vote in the currently evenly divided state Senate. Republicans currently hold the lieutenant governorship and control of the 40-seat body. However, with the unpolished Jackson as the GOP nominee, Democrats are now a safe bet to pick up the lieutenant governor's office and control of the senate.

Democrats will decide their nominee in a June 11 primary. The decision to nominate candidates at a convention instead of a primary gave a relatively small group of conservative activists control over the nomination process, causing frustration among establishment Republicans.

Virginia is considered a purple state, currently having a Republican governor, Bob McDonnell, but voting for Obama in the last two presidential elections. Poll numbers so far show neither party with a significant lead in the race, less than six months before Election Day. Because Virginia voters elect the governor and lieutenant governor separately, it's possible that the winners could be from different parties.

Title: Bipartisan Sensitivity and Lack of Progress on Gun Control Following Congressional Shooting

Article:

Following the shooting of several congressional members at a Virginia park baseball diamond, the usual rhythm of gun control debates on Capitol Hill seems to be subsiding. After the Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting in 2012 and the Orlando LGBT Pulse Nightclub shooting in 2016, there were calls for stricter background checks and limitations on ammunition, as well as demands for a vote on purchasing access for people on the no-fly and terror watch lists.

However, in the aftermath of the recent shooting, the tone has been noticeably different. While a few Democrats reverted to familiar gun control talking points, the majority of lawmakers appeared to show sensitivity and refrained from engaging in policy debates with their colleagues. There seems to be a resignation that both parties are entrenched in their positions, and little, if any, progress can be made on the federal level.

Sen. Chris Murphy (D-Conn.), who led filibusters last summer and has been a vocal advocate for stricter gun laws since the Sandy Hook tragedy in his state, expressed dismay and frustration. He wrote on his Facebook page that he was concerned about the country's quick return to "business as usual" after such tragic events.

Former New York congresswoman Carolyn McCarthy, who was one of the most persistent and determined Democrats on the issue during her nine terms in office, also expressed disappointment. McCarthy's husband was fatally shot in 1993 during a shooting rampage on a Long Island Rail Road commuter train outside New York City.

McCarthy argued that discussing policies after a shooting was still seen as politicizing a tragedy, and she lamented that the issue rarely received attention when there was no mass shooting. She suggested that Democrats were less likely to push the issue if they aimed to take back the majority of the House of Representatives in the 2018 midterms.

In contrast, it was Republicans who suggested policy solutions after the shooting. Rep. Roger Williams (R-Texas), who was at the practice during the shooting, suggested that having more people with guns on the scene would have been beneficial. Rep. Tom Garrett (R-Va.) spoke about a bill he introduced in March that would make it easier for people to carry a gun and "allow the most law-abiding among us to defend themselves."

Carolyn McCarthy, despite expressing some satisfaction with the bipartisan approach and the calming of political rhetoric, also sounded disappointed with the lack of progress on the issue. "Towards the end of my career, I thought, 'Could we stop praying for everybody who gets shot or injured and just do something about it?' That is how frustrated you get, and I know most victims feel the same way," she said.

Title: Rep. Chris Collins Suspends Re-election Bid Amid Insider Trading Charges, Remains on November Ballot

Article:

Rep. Chris Collins, a New York Republican congressman, has suspended his re-election bid in the 27th Congressional District due to insider trading charges. The suspension aims to prevent Democrats from electing a pro-impeachment candidate in the district, as stated in a tweet by Collins on Saturday.

Under New York state law, a candidate's name cannot be replaced on a ballot this close to the election unless they die, move out of the state, or are nominated for another office. Collins, who has held the upstate New York seat since 2012, said Democrats are "laser focused" on taking back the House and launching impeachment proceedings against President Donald Trump.

Collins was arrested on insider trading charges and lying to federal agents on Wednesday. He and his co-defendants, including his son Cameron and Stephen Zarsky, the father of Cameron's fiancée, pleaded not guilty when they were arraigned in federal court. Bail for each defendant was set at $500,000, and a status hearing is scheduled for October 11.

Collins is accused of receiving inside information about negative clinical trial tests conducted by Innate Immunotherapeutics, an Australian biotech company with which he has long been associated. He then is accused of passing that information on to his son, prompting the son and others to sell 1.78 million Innate shares before the bad news was made public in June 2017, and the share price plummeted. Those others included Cameron Collins' fiancée, Lauren Zarsky, her mother, Dorothy, and other friends and family members. They avoided losses of $768,600, according to the complaint filed by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Bill Reilich, chairman of the Monroe County GOP, said county leaders in the district are evaluating "several highly qualified individuals" as potential replacement candidates. To comply with state law to remove Collins from the ballot, he could be nominated to a town clerk position in his district, which wouldn't necessarily require him to live within the town. He would likely be nominated on a third-party line to reduce his chances of winning a position he doesn't want to hold.

House Democratic leader Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., said Saturday that Collins' announcement was "insufficient and overdue" and called on House Speaker Paul Ryan to demand Collins' resignation. "No person is above the law, not the President or his first supporter in Congress," Pelosi said in a statement.

Collins, who was the first member of the House to back Trump in the 2016 election and seconded his presidential nomination at the Republican National Convention, said he will "fill out the remaining few months" of his term to support Trump's agenda. Collins has stated that he will "continue to fight the meritless charges" and looks forward to clearing his name of wrongdoing.

Title: Republican Chances of Senate Control Decrease as Democrats Gain Momentum in Key States, According to Nate Silver

Article:

The likelihood of the Republican Party capturing the Senate has significantly diminished, as the fortunes of Democrats in crucial states have improved, according to Nate Silver of FiveThirtyEight.com. The former New York Times statistician currently estimates the Republican odds at 55%, a drop from 64% just two weeks ago.

Silver's detailed statistical model suggests that Democrats now have a stronger chance of winning due to shifts in the Senate races in Colorado and North Carolina, where the party now holds an advantage, a position that was previously held by the Republicans. Silver classifies these two states as "highly competitive purple states," along with Iowa, Michigan, and New Hampshire. All five seats are currently held by Democrats, with the exception of New Hampshire.

Silver points to numerous recent polls showing a surge for North Carolina Sen. Kay Hagan and Colorado Sen. Mark Udall as evidence of the Democrat momentum. He notes that this Democrat surge in purple states has occurred despite a deterioration in the Democrats' position on the generic congressional ballot, which is often considered the best indicator of the nation's mood.

Silver also suggests that the influence of money in these races could be a factor, citing massive financial advantages for the Democrats in North Carolina and Colorado, as well as higher outside spending by Democratic-leaning super PACs.

"Whatever the reason, the GOP's path to a Senate majority is less robust than before," Silver concludes.

Title: Clinton Foundation Announces New Donation Policy Ahead of Potential Email Leaks

Article:

In response to reports suggesting a potential hack of the Clinton Foundation, the embattled organization, led by former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, announced on Thursday that, if Clinton is elected, her foundation will no longer accept foreign and corporate donations at the center of the Clinton Cash scandal.

The new pledge, while a tacit admission of wrongdoing, comes after years of criticism and raises questions about the foundation's past practices. The primary question being, if it would be wrong for Hillary Clinton's foundation to accept foreign cash as president, why wasn't it wrong for her foundation to accept foreign donations from oligarchs and countries with business pending on her desk as Secretary of State?

Furthermore, if Hillary Clinton has been confirmed to have violated her ethics pledge with the Obama administration to disclose all Clinton Foundation donations, why should the American people believe she would now honor a new pledge to forgo foreign and corporate donations?

According to reports by Bloomberg and the Washington Post, Hillary Clinton's foundation has yet to reveal 1,100 foreign donations, and as Clinton Cash revealed, other hidden foreign donations include four totaling $2.35 million from Ian Telfer, the former head of one of the Russian government's uranium companies, Uranium One.

This week, Senate Judiciary Chairman Charles Grassley (R-IA) launched a probe to discover why the Obama Department of Justice blocked multiple FBI field office requests to investigate the Clinton Foundation. The Clinton Cash documentary has now been viewed well over three million times.

However, pressing broader questions remain unanswered, questions national mainstream media have heretofore been afraid to ask Hillary Clinton about the most glaring and vast series of conflicts of interest in modern American politics.

Hillary Clinton has not answered why her State Department approved the transfer of 20% of all U.S. uranium to Russia while not disclosing to the Obama administration that nine investors in that uranium deal funneled $145 million to the Clinton Foundation.

Hillary Clinton has not answered why her brother, Tony Rodham, sat on the board of a company that received a rare "gold exploitation permit" from the Haitian government while she was dispersing billions of U.S. taxpayer dollars in Haiti earthquake disaster relief.

Hillary Clinton has not answered why she hid $2.35 million in Clinton Foundation donations from the head of one of the Russian government's uranium companies.

Hillary Clinton has not answered why she has yet to release the names of the 1,100 foreign Clinton Foundation donors that both Bloomberg and the Washington Post confirm remain secret.

Hillary Clinton has not answered why it was appropriate for Bill Clinton to deliver a $500,000 speech in Moscow paid for by a Kremlin-backed bank while she led the so-called Russian reset as Secretary of State—a Clinton Cash revelation so egregious, that even the progressive New Yorker magazine was left to ponder, "Why was Bill Clinton taking any money from a bank linked to the Kremlin while his wife was Secretary of State?"

Hillary Clinton has not answered why her current campaign chairman, John Podesta, sat on the board of a company alongside Russian officials that received $35 million from Rusnano, Vladimir Putin's funding apparatus.

Hillary Clinton has not answered whether her husband will stop giving paid speeches.

Myriad questions have gone unasked and unanswered about the toxic brew of foreign cash and Hillary Clinton's State Department decisions. Perhaps now, with this stunning new tacit admission of unethical and inappropriate behavior by Hillary Clinton and her foundation, will the mainstream media find the spine to do the hard work of investigative reporting and the courage to demand serious answers.

Title: Philippines Imposes Travel Restrictions on U.S. Lawmakers, Threatens Tighter Entry Rules for U.S. Citizens

Article:

The Philippines has announced a travel ban for two U.S. lawmakers and potential tighter entry restrictions for U.S. citizens in response to potential U.S. sanctions over the detention of Senator Leila de Lima. President Rodrigo Duterte's spokesman, Salvador Panelo, made the announcement during a news conference on Friday.

The U.S. Congress approved a 2020 budget that contains a provision introduced by Senators Richard Durbin and Patrick Leahy against anyone involved in holding de Lima, who was charged with drug offenses in 2017 after she led an investigation into mass killings during Duterte's war on drugs.

In response, Duterte will impose visa requirements on U.S. nationals should any Philippine officials involved in de Lima's incarceration be denied entry to the United States. The Philippines currently grants visa-free entry for up to 30 days to Americans, with nearly 13% of foreign arrivals being U.S. citizens, according to data from the first nine months of 2019.

Panelo stated, "We will not sit idly if they continue to interfere with our processes as a sovereign state." The U.S. embassy in Manila and the State Department did not immediately respond to requests for comment. David Carle, spokesman for Senator Leahy, called the charges against de Lima politically motivated and added, "This is about the right of Filipino citizens - and people everywhere - to freely express their opinions, including opinions that may be critical of government policies that involve the use of excessive force and the denial of due process."

Panelo described travel restrictions over de Lima's detention as "nonsense" because she is not wrongfully imprisoned but detained pending trial for crimes. He stated, "The case of Senator de Lima is not one of persecution but of prosecution."

Duterte has expressed his disdain for the United States and what he considers its hypocrisy and interference, though he admits that most Filipinos and his military have high regard for their country's former colonial ruler. The United States is the Philippines' biggest defense ally, and millions of Filipinos have relatives who are U.S. citizens.

De Lima, a justice minister in a former administration, has won numerous awards from human rights groups, who consider her a prisoner of conscience. She has called for an international investigation into Duterte's war on drugs, in which thousands of people have been killed. Police say those killed were drug dealers who resisted arrest, but activists say many of the killings were murders.

Title: Mitt Romney's Post-Denver Debate Strategy: Six Keys to a Potential Revival

Article:

Mitt Romney's successful debate performance in Denver last week has left him with a significant challenge: maintaining momentum and demonstrating that his victory was not a fluke. To genuinely alter the race's trajectory, Romney must execute a series of strategic moves in the coming days.

1. Consistent Performance: Romney must demonstrate that his Denver performance accurately reflects his abilities and that the weaknesses he exposed in President Barack Obama are not isolated incidents.

2. Obama's Response: The president has expressed dissatisfaction with his own debate performance and is expected to improve at the next debate. A strong Obama debate performance, particularly if contrasted with a merely adequate one by Romney, could bring the race back to its pre-Denver state.

3. Higher Expectations: Romney will be judged by higher expectations, not just as a credible alternative, but as a candidate capable of proposing a forward-looking agenda.

4. Emotional Connection: Romney has been showcasing a more emotive, connected side of himself at rallies since the debate. This not only provides practice for the town hall-style format at Hofstra University but also allows him to connect with voters on a personal level.

5. Preparation: Romney is taking his debate preparation seriously, and this discipline, combined with his recent experience, may make a clear Obama victory unlikely.

6. Perception of a Downward Spiral: A clear Obama loss could invite perceptions of a decline in the incumbent's strength, significantly increasing the odds of a Romney presidency.

In the coming days, Romney's strategy will be crucial in determining the outcome of the presidential race.

Title: Trump Proposes New Immigration Laws: A Look at the Raise Act and Its Potential Impact

Article:

President Donald Trump unveiled a new immigration bill on Wednesday, titled the Reforming American Immigration for Strong Employment (Raise) Act. The legislation, co-sponsored by Republican senators Tom Cotton and David Perdue, aims to reduce the total number of immigrants admitted to the United States by half over a decade and prioritize those who can speak English or are well-educated.

The Raise Act, presented at the White House, would cap the number of refugees admitted annually at 50,000 and eliminate the diversity visa lottery, which currently allocates 50,000 visas a year to residents of countries that do not currently send significant numbers of migrants to the US.

According to an estimate provided by Senator Cotton's office, if passed, the Raise Act would decrease the number of immigrants admitted to the US by 41% in its first year and by 50% over a 10-year-period.

President Trump described the bill as "legislation that would represent the most significant reform to our immigration system in a half century" and as the fulfillment of his campaign promise to create a "merit-based immigration system that protects American workers and taxpayers."

Trump has long been vocal about illegal immigration, making a border wall with Mexico his signature campaign policy. However, he has also advocated for revamping legal immigration. In his February address to Congress, the president called for "reforming our system of legal immigration" and shifting to a merit-based system, citing Canada and Australia as models.

Senator Cotton, from Arkansas, echoed Trump's rhetoric, making a populist case for his legislation. He argued that the current immigration system shows "we're not committed to working-class Americans" and puts "great downward pressure on people who work with their hands and feet." Cotton and Perdue first introduced the bill in February.

Despite Trump's support, the legislation has bipartisan detractors and is unlikely to pass Congress in its current form. While Republicans have long been united on the issue of illegal immigration, legal immigration is far more divisive for them. Many pro-business Republicans have long supported legal immigration, and the new legislation is likely to stoke the divides between this wing of the party and more populist Republicans.

Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina, a frequent critic of Trump, denounced the proposed reduction in legal immigration, stating it would "be devastating to [South Carolina's] economy, which relies on this immigrant workforce."

For the Democrats, Senate minority leader Chuck Schumer told reporters the proposal to cut legal immigration "doesn't make much sense" and said his party would not support the plan. "This is different than illegal immigration," Schumer said. "This creates jobs in America. This helps America, and we think it's a non-starter."

Later, a heated exchange occurred between White House aide Stephen Miller and CNN anchor Jim Acosta during a discussion about the policy. Acosta asked Miller if the proposal would violate the spirit of the poem New Colossus, inscribed at the base of the Statue of Liberty, which includes the line: "Give me your tired, your poor, Your huddled masses yearning to breathe free."

The White House criticized Acosta for his "cosmopolitan bias" and attacked him for asking about what the bill would do to the racial composition of immigrants to the United States by saying: "That is one of the most outrageous, insulting, ignorant and foolish things you've ever said."

Miller later apologized to Acosta before leaving the lectern "if things got heated" but added that the CNN anchor "made some pretty rough insinuations."

Title: Obama's Approval Rating Stays Steady Amidst Controversies, According to New Poll

Article:

Washington (CNN) - President Barack Obama concludes a week marked by controversy with his approval rating remaining steady, according to a new national poll by CNN/ORC International. The poll, released Sunday, indicates that congressional Republicans may not be overplaying their hand in their response to the three ongoing scandals that have dominated the nation's capital over the past week and a half.

The poll, conducted Friday and Saturday, shows that 53% of Americans approve of the job the president is doing, while 45% disapprove. This is a two-point increase from CNN's last poll, conducted in early April. However, CNN Polling Director Keating Holland notes that this difference is within the poll's sampling error, and should not be characterized as a gain for the president.

The poll's findings align with Gallup's, which also indicates a slight rise in Obama's approval rating over the same time period. Both surveys show a very slight upward movement in the president's approval rating over the past week, but within their respective sampling errors.

The poll reveals that more than seven in ten Americans find the Internal Revenue Service's targeting of tea party and other conservative groups applying for tax-exempt status unacceptable. While both parties in Congress and the White House are criticizing the IRS actions, congressional Republicans are portraying the controversy as a case of the federal government gone wild.

However, more than six in ten say that the president's statements about the IRS scandal are completely or mostly true, with 35% not agreeing with Obama's characterizations. Regarding the IRS's actions, 55% say the IRS acted on its own, while 37% say the White House ordered the IRS to target tea party and other conservative groups.

Regarding the September attack in Benghazi, Libya, which resulted in the death of the U.S. ambassador and three other Americans, only 42% are satisfied with the Obama administration's handling of the situation. Fifty-three percent are dissatisfied, but these numbers are virtually unchanged from November.

Republicans have criticized the administration for inadequate security, a botched response, and misleading the public for political gain, as the attack occurred less than two months before the 2012 presidential election. According to the poll, 44% say the administration's statements soon after the attack were an attempt to intentionally mislead the public, while half say those statements reflected what the administration believed had occurred at the time.

However, 59% now say that the U.S. government could have prevented the Benghazi attack, a 11-point increase from November. Additionally, only 37% say that congressional Republicans are overreacting in their handling of the matter, with 59% saying they've reacted appropriately.

The White House has also faced criticism for the Justice Department's secret collection of phone records from the Associated Press as part of a government investigation into classified leaks. According to the poll, 52% say the Justice Department's actions were unacceptable, while 43% disagree.

Americans appear to be taking all three controversies very seriously, with 55% saying the IRS and Benghazi matters are very important to the nation, and 53% saying the same about the AP case.

"More Republicans than Democrats or Independents say these three issues are very important to the nation, but even among Democrats, nearly half say the matters are very serious," Holland adds.

Only 43% say they have a great deal or some confidence in the people who run the federal government. However, 56% say they have a great deal or some confidence in the system of government.

The CNN poll was conducted by ORC International between May 17-18, with 923 adults nationwide questioned by telephone. The survey's sampling error is plus or minus three percentage points.

Title: Republican Debate Elevates Tension Among Candidates Ahead of Super Tuesday

Article:

The final Republican primary debate before Super Tuesday, held on Thursday, displayed a level of hostility and discord not previously seen in the party's debates. The event, moderated by CNN's Wolf Blitzer, featured a significant shift in the dynamic between candidates Marco Rubio, Ted Cruz, and front-runner Donald Trump.

For the first time in ten debates and six months, Rubio and Cruz focused their attacks on Trump, criticizing his record, character, and policy platform. Rubio, in a memorable moment, described Trump's campaign slogan as "Everyone's dumb, he's going to make America great again. Win, win, win."

With nearly half of the delegates needed to secure the nomination at stake, and Trump still leading in most states, it remains uncertain whether the debate's chaotic atmosphere will propel either candidate into the lead. Rubio, armed with a series of comebacks and quick responses to Trump's familiar insults, seemed to employ tactics learned from the Trump Academy of the Dramatic Arts, rolling his eyes, waving his hands, and appearing more human than his previous "Marco Roboto" persona.

Glenn Beck, a Cruz supporter, praised Rubio's performance, reviving hopes that Trump might not run away with the nomination. However, Trump continued to employ the same talking points against Rubio and Cruz, escalating the vitriol. Rubio was now portrayed as a "sweaty-faced choke artist" instead of an inexperienced young man who repeated himself, while Cruz was no longer just a "liar" who allegedly screwed over Ben Carson in Iowa, but a "basket case" and a "crazy zealot." Cruz retaliated by suggesting Trump should "get back on [his] meds."

The debate marked a significant escalation in the Republican primary race, with the candidates' personal attacks and heated exchanges potentially impacting the outcome of Super Tuesday and the overall nomination process.

Title: House Republican Health Care Bill Faces Uncertain Future as Vote Nears

Article:

The Republican-backed health care bill, known as the American Health Care Act (AHCA), is facing uncertainty as it approaches a vote in the House of Representatives. The White House expressed optimism on Friday that the bill would pass, despite speculation that it may not have enough support for an afternoon vote.

White House Press Secretary Sean Spicer confirmed that President Trump and House Speaker Paul Ryan are meeting to discuss the way forward on the bill. According to GOP lawmakers and congressional aides, House Republican leaders are short of the votes needed for the bill to pass.

In an effort to coax support from conservatives, House leaders proposed a fresh amendment that would repeal the requirement that insurers cover 10 specified services like maternity and mental health care. This amendment is in response to demands from conservatives who argue that these conditions drive up premiums.

President Trump met with members of the Freedom Caucus on Thursday in an attempt to win them over. However, the vote was postponed after administration officials fell short. Trump issued an ultimatum on Thursday night, stating that the House should vote on the legislation to begin dismantling ObamaCare on Friday, and if it fails, he is "done with health care" and ready to move on to tax reform.

House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy thinks the vote will wrap up by 4:30 or 5 p.m. ET. If the bill passes, it will be a monumental achievement for Speaker Ryan and Trump. However, if the bill stumbles, recriminations will abound.

The House Rules Committee is expected to prepare the health care bill starting at 7 a.m. ET on Friday. The timing of the vote is uncertain, with McCarthy telling reporters that the House should be "done in the afternoon," but noting that Democrats could delay things.

Meanwhile, Trump met with the Freedom Caucus to try and rally conservatives to the cause. He also tweeted, urging supporters to call their representatives to back the bill. A senior administration official told reporters after the meeting with Trump and the conservative group that there was a deal in the works, but that it was not yet finalized. A source from the Freedom Caucus later said there was not yet a deal.

House Speaker Paul Ryan told reporters after meeting with Republican leaders that they have been promising the American people that they will repeal and replace the broken law for seven and a half years. "Tomorrow we're proceeding," he said.

In appealing to conservatives with concessions that include limiting requirements that plans offer benefits including maternity and substance abuse care, Republican leaders risk scaring off moderates. A plan to cut funding to Planned Parenthood also risks spooking centrist Republicans.

Democrats blasted what they saw as Republicans' amateurish maneuvering. House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi said it was a "rookie's error" to bring the legislation to a vote so early, and urged fellow Democrats to oppose the legislation.

Title: President Trump Welcomes Home Three Americans Released by North Korea

Article:

President Donald Trump welcomed home three American citizens who had been detained by North Korea on Thursday at Joint Base Andrews. The three released prisoners landed at the Maryland military facility at 2:42 a.m., where they were greeted by President Donald Trump, Vice President Mike Pence, their respective wives, and Secretary of State Mike Pompeo.

The three men, identified as Kim Dong Chul, Kim Sang-duk (also known as Tony Kim), and Kim Hak-song, are Korean-Americans. North Korea had accused them of anti-state activities. After arriving, the prisoners were taken to Walter Reed National Military Medical Center in Bethesda, Maryland, for further evaluation and medical treatment.

Secretary of State Mike Pompeo had secured the release of the men during a Wednesday trip to North Korea. He arrived at Andrews minutes earlier on his own plane. The release is seen as a further sign of thawing relations between the U.S. and North Korea, following Kim's pledge last month to suspend missile tests and close a nuclear test site.

However, the release comes amid renewed uncertainty regarding the upcoming summit between Trump and Kim, following Trump's decision earlier this week to withdraw from the Iran nuclear deal. Pompeo's trip to Pyongyang was scheduled to coincide with Trump's decision to remove the U.S. from the Iran agreement.

Plans for a meeting between Trump and Kim mark a significant shift in the relationship between the two leaders, who exchanged threats and insults across the Pacific Ocean last summer. A meeting between a sitting U.S. president and the leader of North Korea would be a historic first. Pompeo's first visit to North Korea over Easter weekend marked the first known meeting between a U.S. official and a North Korean leader since then-Secretary of State Madeleine Albright met with Kim Jong Il, Kim Jong Un's father, in 2000.

"My proudest achievement will be when we denuclearize that entire peninsula," Trump said. "This is what people have been waiting a long time for. I'm very honored to free the three folks. The true honor is going to be if we have a victory in getting rid of nuclear weapons."

Trump predicted that his planned meeting with Kim would be "a very big success" and suggested that his relationship with the North Korean leader is "starting off on a new footing." Asked if he might visit North Korea, Trump responded "it could happen."

"I really think he wants to do something. I think he did this because I really think he wants to do something and bring that country into the real world. I really believe that," Trump said.

The ex-detainees thanked Trump for securing their freedom in a statement released by the State Department on their behalf. One spoke briefly with reporters through a translator, stating that the three prisoners "were treated in many different ways" and that he had been forced to do hard labor but also received medical treatment when he was sick. Their release, he said, is "like a dream we are very, very happy."

"We would like to express our deep appreciation to the United States government, President Trump, Secretary Pompeo, and the people of the United States for bringing us home," the former prisoners said in their statement. "We thank God, and all our families and friends who prayed for us and for our return. God Bless America, the greatest nation in the world."

Title: Tillerson Warns of 'Serious Mistrust' Between U.S. and Russia Over Election Interference

Article:

U.S. Secretary of State Rex Tillerson has warned Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov of "serious mistrust" between the two nations due to Moscow's alleged interference in the 2016 U.S. elections. Tillerson made these remarks on the sidelines of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) meeting in the Philippines.

Tillerson stated that Russia's actions had damaged the relationship, but added it was not "useful to just cut everything off over one single issue." He also mentioned that the U.S. will respond by September 1 to Russia's expulsion of 755 staff from the U.S. embassy in Moscow.

U.S. intelligence agencies believe the Kremlin attempted to help President Donald Trump during the election, a claim Moscow vehemently denies. The tit-for-tat between the two nations escalated after Congress passed sanctions against Russia last month, against President Trump's wishes.

Tillerson told Lavrov that there was now "serious mistrust between our two countries and that we simply have to find some way to deal with that." He also indicated that the two countries may be able to come together to begin discussions on violence in Eastern Ukraine.

The comments by the former CEO of Exxon Mobil come less than a week after President Trump signed into law new legislation that imposes sanctions on Russia for election meddling and military actions in Crimea and Ukraine. The law also prevents Trump from lifting sanctions or returning Russian diplomatic compounds in the U.S. seized by the Obama administration in retaliation for the alleged meddling.

President Trump has failed to singularly point the finger at Moscow for the hacking of Democratic Party emails during the final stages of the election campaign. He has also condemned the investigations, which are also looking at whether his campaign team colluded with Moscow, as a "witch hunt." After signing the bill, Mr. Trump decried it, arguing that it limited his ability to negotiate with Russia.

Title: Central American Migrants Seek U.S. Asylum in Increasing Numbers, Citing Obama's DACA Program

Article:

A surge in Central American families crossing the U.S.-Mexico border and seeking asylum has led to overcrowded detention facilities and the release of some migrants with a promise to report to immigration officials at a later date. Edilberto Lanza Mejia, a 26-year-old Honduran, is one such individual who was released at a bus station in McAllen, Texas, after being detained for five days.

According to The Houston Chronicle, Lanza and his family crossed the border five days prior, but with large groups of 80 to 90 people asking border agents to arrest them daily, the system has been overwhelmed. There is reportedly no space to house everyone until their cases can be adjudicated, so the Border Patrol is releasing them with the expectation that they will voluntarily report to immigration officials weeks later.

Within hours of arriving, Lanza borrowed a cellphone in the bus terminal, and his wife called her sister in North Carolina, who paid for their fare to Greenville. They had tickets for the last bus out that night, leaving at 11:30 p.m.

The Obama administration claims that the influx of families coming to Texas is due to recent violence in Central American countries. However, The Christian Science Monitor reports that the flow of unaccompanied minors crossing the border illegally has been steady for over a decade.

From fiscal year 2012 to 2014, the federal government agency responsible for caring for unaccompanied minors who cross the border illegally dealt with an average of 7,000 to 8,000 cases a year. In fiscal year 2011, the number was 6,560, but it jumped to 13,625 in the following year. This fiscal year, which ends on September 30, 2014, federal officials are estimating that the number could be 80,000.

The increase in unaccompanied minors crossing the border in 2012 coincides with the implementation of the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program, which allows some undocumented immigrants who came to America as minors to defer deportation for two years. Last week, the administration announced guidelines for how these immigrants could defer deportation for a further two years.

The DACA program's arbitrary age and cutoff date limits have been criticized as illogical and morally questionable. When DACA was first announced, PBS NewsHour's Jeffrey Brown pressed President Obama's director of domestic policy, Cecilia Munoz, about the age limit, asking why someone whose age is 31, who has spent many years in the United States and gone to school or had a job or served in the military, would not be eligible. Munoz responded that the cutoff date in the legislation passed by the House of Representatives in 2010 was age 30.

The DREAM Act's age 30 cutoff and the DACA program's arbitrary cutoff dates have been criticized as illogical and morally questionable. Critics argue that there is no moral or logical reason to reward those who entered the country before a certain date and punish those who did not enter soon enough.

Central American migrants appear to be aware of the inconsistencies in U.S. immigration policy, with some viewing the DACA program as a pathway to stay in the United States. A recently detained undocumented immigrant from Guatemala told The Christian Science Monitor last week, "They're saying that women and children are allowed to stay. If you make it, they take you to a shelter and take care of you and let you have permission to stay." A 13-year-old named Robin Tulio told The New York Times, "When you appeal your case, if you say you want to study, they support you."

Texas Gov. Rick Perry has asked President Obama to change his immigration policies, particularly the practice of releasing illegal immigrants into the United States with only a promise to appear in court. A Homeland Security official told The Houston Chronicle, "We need a policy change so we can send these families and children back home instead of turning them loose."

Title: Paul Manafort's Washington Meetings Conflict with Mercury's Previous Claims of No Coordination

Article:
