Recent disclosures filed with the Justice Department reveal that President Donald Trump's former campaign chairman, Paul Manafort, participated in meetings with U.S. government officials connected to the Russia-aligned political party he was representing in 2012 and 2013. These meetings, which had not been previously disclosed, conflict with Mercury's previous claims that it did not coordinate with Manafort.

According to the disclosures, Manafort, in conjunction with Vin Weber, a partner at the lobbying firm Mercury, met with Rep. Dana Rohrabacher (R-Calif.), former Arizona Republican Congressman Jim Kolbe of the International Republican Institute, Paula Dobriansky of the Harvard Kennedy School of Government, and Nadia Diuk of the National Endowment for Democracy. The lobbying effort was on behalf of a Brussels-based think tank that supported Ukraine's Party of Regions, headed at the time by former Ukrainian President Viktor Yanukovych, a Manafort client.

The Brussels think tank, the European Centre for a Modern Ukraine, paid Mercury more than $1.2 million for work between May 2012 and May 2014, according to the disclosures. Manafort spokesman Jason Maloni stated, "One meeting with one lawmaker connected to this topic in a two-year period looks like incidental contact to fair-minded Americans."

Earlier this month, Maloni said Manafort might report his foreign lobbying activities in response to advice from authorities. Manafort, a longtime associate of Trump confidant Roger Stone, was ousted from Trump's campaign in August following revelations by The New York Times about his work in Ukraine.

Mercury partner Michael McKeon stated that Manafort connected his Brussels think tank client to the firm. "Manafort referred the client to us," McKeon said in a statement. "At that time, he was widely recognized for his significant experience in Ukrainian politics and we felt his perspective would be meaningful in those few meetings. That was the extent of his involvement with us."

Weber also accompanied former Ukrainian president Viktor Yushchenko to a meeting with then-Rep. Dan Burton (R-Ind.) in May 2012, according to the disclosures.

Mercury originally reported its lobbying for the think tank to Congress under the Lobbying Disclosure Act, which doesn't require firms to itemize each interaction and expense. However, lobbying for foreign governments and political parties has to be reported to the Justice Department under the Foreign Agents Registration Act.

Mercury said it relied on assurances from the think tank that it wasn't funded or controlled by a foreign political party. "We got it in writing so we could be sure we were doing it right, and relied on our counsel to make the proper determination," McKeon said. While violating the disclosure law is criminal, the office that enforces it usually settles for bringing lobbyists into compliance instead of bringing charges. The other lobbying firm working for the think tank, the Podesta Group, also retroactively filed with the Justice Department earlier this month.

Title: Illinois Democrats Push for Increased Abortion Access, Sparking Protests and Controversy

Article:

Thousands of protestors gathered at the Illinois state capitol in Springfield on Wednesday to voice their opposition to proposed abortion bills, which they refer to as radical new legislation. The bills aim to increase access and provision for abortion, with one bill allowing abortions up until the moment of birth for any reason and the other repealing the requirement for minors to notify their parents.

Democratic Gov. J.B. Pritzker has expressed a plan to make Illinois the most progressive state in the nation for reproductive health care, a move that pro-lifers fear will become a reality. Illinois is already seen as a safe haven for those seeking abortions, especially since a new law allows the state Medicaid program to fund them.

Researchers on both sides of the debate have found that when taxpayers fund abortion, the numbers tend to increase. In 2019, 5,528 women traveled to Illinois from other states to have abortions, a significant increase from the 4,543 women who did so in 2016. The total number of statewide abortions also saw a similar increase, rising to 39,329 in 2017 from 38,382 in 2016.

The repeal of the Parent Notification of Abortion Act of 1995 could lead to an increase in the annual number of abortions. This bill, which passed out of a state Senate committee on Tuesday, will allow minors to make hasty decisions without parental consent to get an abortion.

State Sen. Elgie Sims, Jr. (D-Chicago), the bill's sponsor, stated that the goal of the new bill was to increase "authentic family conversations." However, State Sen. Jason Plummer (R-Edwardsville) argued against the progressive measure at the committee meeting.

"We're talking about the termination of a life, right?" Plummer said. "And so, for there to be maybe a hurdle or two there, I don't think as a society is necessarily the worst thing because... we're talking about the termination of a heartbeat, and that's a significant concern of mine."

The other bill, the Reproductive Health Act, would establish abortion as a fundamental right. The measure includes a mandatory rule for private insurance companies to cover abortion and grants physician-assistants the opportunity to perform abortions.

Rep. Terri Bryant (R-Murphysboro) argues that the bill has nothing to do with reproductive health. "I feel a little bit like I've fallen through the rabbit hole," stated Bryant. "Everything is upside-down, backwards and inside-out in just using the name."

Illinois Right to Life Action reports that the bills would allow unregulated abortion up until the moment of birth for any reason and would strip away all parental rights, along with any requirement of medical certification by staff or facility. If enacted, Illinois would become a third-trimester abortion destination, and no abortion would be subject to state inspection. Since 2011, at least four abortion facilities have shut down due to failed state inspections.

The progressive measures have been introduced by Democrats in both chambers, but only the Senate is seeing success as the measure is stalled in the House.

Title: Trump and Obama's Approaches to Foreign Policy Compared

Article:

In a contrasting approach to foreign policy, Presidents Donald Trump and Barack Obama have taken different tactics in dealing with global conflicts.

President Obama, the 44th president and a Democrat, is known for his efforts to de-escalate the perception of Islam as a terrorist entity. This approach earned him the Nobel Peace Prize, despite the world's ongoing conflicts and the looming threat of a civilizational war, as theorized by Samuel Huntington.

President Trump, the 45th president and an Independent Republican, has defined the enemy more accurately, but has received criticism rather than recognition. His first international trip as president has been met with media focus on trivial matters, such as the fashion choices of his wife, Melania Trump, rather than substantive discussions on American foreign policy.

The media's response to Trump has been criticized for its negative coverage, with little attention given to the substance of American foreign policy. Instead, the media has been accused of undermining the constitutional and democratic order by acting as a court-jester, megaphone, and lap-dog for politicians and civil servants with personal agendas.

Trump was elected in part due to his ability to connect with voters and his commitment to addressing domestic and foreign threats to the union. His priorities have been clear, while his opponents have been criticized for their lack of clarity.

In the Middle East, the article suggests that relying on allies outside Israel is a mistake. The author argues that alliances of convenience, while cold and cynical, are necessary to maintain American power and protect American prosperity and freedoms. The Bush 43 administration recognized this early on, with the "you're either with us or against us" policy in the war on terror. However, the article suggests that the Bushites lost sight of this insight and instead pursued Wilsonian liberal interventionism, which aimed to promote democracy globally.

Trump is now seeking to distance himself from this interventionist approach, with the goal of preserving American power while maintaining order in a world that is "beastly, awful, and evil." The article concludes by expressing hope for Trump's success in his foreign policy tour, particularly in the Middle East, where the president is expected to send a clear message that the U.S. will not tolerate opposition from countries in the region.

Title: YouTube Emerging as Significant Source of Health Information, but Algorithms May Exacerbate Health Literacy Disparities

Article:

A new report from the Health Information National Trends Survey indicates that 75% of Americans turn to the internet first when seeking health or medical information. YouTube, a popular online platform with billions of views daily, has emerged as a significant source of health information. Several public health agencies, such as state health departments, have invested resources in YouTube as a channel for health communication. Patients with chronic health conditions particularly rely on social media, including YouTube videos, to learn more about managing their conditions.

However, video recommendations on such sites could exacerbate preexisting health literacy disparities. A significant fraction of the U.S. population is estimated to have limited health literacy, or the capacity to obtain, process, and understand basic health information. Studies of health literacy, such as the National Assessment of Adult Literacy conducted in 2003, estimated that only 12% of adults had proficient health literacy skills.

A professor of information systems, Anjana Susarla, has researched how social media platforms like YouTube widen such health literacy disparities by steering users toward questionable content. In a study, Susarla examined thousands of videos purporting to be about diabetes and found that the most popular and engaging videos are significantly less likely to have medically valid information.

Users typically encounter videos on health conditions through keyword searches on YouTube. YouTube then provides links to authenticated medical information, such as the top-ranked results. Several of these are produced by reputable health organizations. Recently, YouTube has adjusted how search results are displayed, allowing results to be ranked by "relevance" and providing links to verified medical information.

However, when Susarla recruited physicians to watch the videos and rate them on whether these would be considered valid and understandable from a patient education perspective, they rated YouTube's recommendations poorly. The most popular videos tend to have easily understandable information but are not always medically valid. A study on the most popular videos on COVID-19 likewise found that a quarter of videos did not contain medically valid information.

This is because the algorithms' underlying recommendations on social media platforms are biased toward engagement and popularity. Based on how digital platforms provide information to search queries, a user with greater health literacy is more likely to discover usable medical advice from a reputed health care provider, such as the Mayo Clinic. The same algorithm will steer a less literate user toward fake cures or misleading medical advice.

This could be especially harmful for minority groups. Studies of health literacy in the United States have found that the impact of limited health literacy disproportionately impacts minorities. Correcting algorithmic biases and providing better information to users of technology platforms would go a long way in promoting equity.

For example, a pioneering study by the Gender Shades project examined disparities in identifying gender and skin type across different companies that provide commercial facial recognition software. It concluded that companies were able to make progress in reducing these disparities once issues were pointed out.

According to some estimates, Google receives over a billion health questions every day. Especially those with low health literacy have a substantial risk of encountering medically unsubstantiated information, such as popular myths or active conspiracy theories that are not based on scientific evidence. The World Economic Forum has dubbed health-related misinformation an "infodemic." Digital platforms where anyone can engage also make them vulnerable to misinformation, accentuating disparities in health literacy, as Susarla's work shows.

Social media and search companies have partnered with health organizations such as the Mayo Clinic to provide validated information and reduce the spread of misinformation. To make health information on YouTube more equitable, those who design recommendation algorithms would have to incorporate feedback from clinicians and patients as well as end users.

Title: Senate Republicans Block $84 Billion Tax Cut Bill Over Amendment Dispute

Article:

Senate Republicans on Thursday blocked an $84 billion tax cut bill, marking the second time in less than a week that a procedural impasse over amendments has derailed legislation. The legislation, which aims to revive a series of expired tax breaks, failed to clear a procedural hurdle due to widespread objections from Republicans over the lack of opportunity to propose amendments, including one targeting the Obamacare medical device tax.

The vote was 53-40, with 60 votes needed to advance the measure. The dispute comes just days after a similar impasse scuttled an energy efficiency bill and a vote on the Keystone Pipeline, signaling six more months of gridlock and partisan bickering if Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid and Minority Leader Mitch McConnell cannot forge a working relationship before the November election.

Lawmakers are uncertain about the future of the so-called tax extenders, which would renew a variety of temporary provisions benefiting teachers, commuters, banks, and others. Some Republicans expressed hope for a brief delay, but the party's top tax writer acknowledged the move could postpone the legislation until after this year's midterm elections.

Sen. Orrin Hatch (R-Utah) expressed his support for the Republican stance, stating, "Don't we care a little more about freedom and the right to bring up your amendments and the right to be a participant in the process? We've always had rights around here, and that's what's involved here, that's what the whole thing is about. It's not about trying to stop this bill—it's saying, 'Look, we've had enough of this crap.'"

Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid (D-Nev.) criticized the Republican vote, stating, "Republicans can't take 'yes' for an answer—they just voted against the second bipartisan bill in less than a week. That's what just happened: the Republicans voted against tax cuts. So maybe the Republicans will hear from their friends down on K Street and around the country and maybe they will learn this is pretty important to everybody."

Sen. Mark Kirk of Illinois was the only Republican to side with Democrats. Lawmakers will reportedly use the weekend and the first few days of next week to negotiate an amendment deal. The GOP leadership began whipping their members to vote down the bill on Wednesday, and by Thursday's caucus lunch, Republicans had agreed to oppose Reid.

Republicans expressed little remorse about shooting down a tax cut bill. Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.) stated, "Tax cuts come and go," while Sen. John Cornyn (R-Texas) expressed outrage over being "frozen out of the process." Sen. Dan Coats (R-Ind.) predicted any delay on the bill would be brief, arguing the chamber could still complete work on the bill by Memorial Day. However, if not, Coats suggested it might not make much difference because lawmakers were unlikely to finalize a plan for the tax provisions with the House until a post-election lame-duck session.

Title: Congress Averts Shutdown for Now, December Showdown Looms

Article:

The immediate threat of a government shutdown has subsided, but the possibility of a future standoff is imminent. The U.S. Congress has managed to avoid a shutdown for now, with a short-term funding bill expected to pass this week. However, a more significant funding battle is expected in December, when lawmakers must agree on a new funding bill for the new fiscal year.

The current funding fight, initially centered around Planned Parenthood, dissipated following Speaker John Boehner's surprise resignation announcement on Friday. The House is expected to pass a short-term spending bill this week, which will fund the government through December 11 and not strip funding from Planned Parenthood.

The Senate will lead the charge to prevent a shutdown, with a key procedural vote scheduled for Monday evening on the short-term spending bill. Senate Democratic and GOP leadership aides confirmed that the bill should secure the 60 votes needed to advance. After the Senate's final passage of the stopgap measure, likely by Tuesday night, the House will follow suit, and the bill will be sent to President Barack Obama for his signature, thus averting a second federal government shutdown since 2013.

When asked about the possibility of a shutdown during CBS' "Face the Nation," Speaker Boehner replied, "No." Boehner acknowledged that he would need Democratic support for the bill but added, "I expect my Democrat colleagues want to keep the government open as much as I do."

Instead of focusing on the government funding, House Republicans are redirecting their energy towards investigating allegations that Planned Parenthood profited from fetal tissue sales, stemming from a series of undercover sting videos. The House GOP announced over the weekend that they will establish a select committee to probe these accusations.

In addition, the House will vote on more measures restricting abortion, and draft a reconciliation measure to defund Planned Parenthood. On Tuesday, the House Energy and Commerce Committee will take up a reconciliation bill that bars funding for Planned Parenthood for one year and a public health fund established under Obamacare.

Reconciliation is an appealing procedural tool for the GOP-controlled Congress, as it can bypass a filibuster in the Senate and send a bill directly to Obama. However, the rules for reconciliation in the Senate are more complex, and GOP leaders have not yet indicated whether they will follow suit and use the procedural tool to strip funding from Planned Parenthood.

Some House conservatives were initially dissatisfied with the leadership's strategy when it was unveiled last week, pushing for a funding fight that could lead to a shutdown. However, they have since resigned themselves to the fact that a spending bill without Planned Parenthood restrictions is inevitable.

Democrats are expected to provide the majority of votes to keep the government open beyond Wednesday. Republicans oppose the stopgap measure for reasons beyond the funding for Planned Parenthood, as demonstrated last week when the Senate tried to advance a bill defunding the group, and a group of moderate and conservative Republicans voted against it.

The outcome of the December funding fight is uncertain, but the stage is set for a significant showdown over government spending priorities.

Title: One Million Syrian Children Flee Violence, UN Urges Global Response

Article:

The United Nations (UN) has reported that over one million children, with three-quarters being under the age of 11, have been forced to flee violence in Syria since the conflict began in 2011. This grim figure was released by UN agencies on Friday.

Anthony Lake, the executive director of UNICEF, the UN children's agency, stated, "This one millionth child refugee is not just another number. This is a real child ripped from home, maybe even from a family, facing horrors we can only begin to comprehend."

The release of the statistic coincides with the UN's push for an immediate investigation of an alleged chemical weapons attack near Damascus. The Syrian government has denied the accusation, calling it "illogical and fabricated," according to the BBC. However, unverified footage shows civilians, many of them children, suffering symptoms consistent with nerve agents, and rows of shrouded bodies, as reported by the BBC.

UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon renewed calls for UN inspectors to be allowed to investigate the claims immediately. "I can think of no good reason why any party, either government or opposition forces, would decline this opportunity to get to the truth of the matter," the UN chief said, according to Reuters.

As the situation escalates, the UN is acting quickly, with UN's top disarmament representative, Angela Kane, set to fly to Syria to investigate the suburb where more than a thousand died in what appears to be the largest attack so far in the Syrian conflict. The UN team currently inside Syria is only authorized to investigate three of the 13 sites deemed suspicious before Wednesday's attack.

Syria has become the worst refugee crisis since the genocide in Rwanda in 1994, with over 100,000 people killed since protests against President Bashar al-Assad began in March 2011. Refugees have been fleeing to Lebanon, Jordan, Turkey, Iraq, and Egypt, and increasingly North Africa and Europe.

Children are among the most vulnerable. While 1 million have been forced to flee the violence, the UN says that 2 million others are displaced within the country. "The youth of Syria are losing their homes, their family members, and their futures," said UN High Commissioner for Refugees Antonio Guterres.

Education is a top long-term concern, as these children are part of a so-called "lost generation" that won't easily be able to bring stability to their country in the future. Few have been able to study or receive psychological counseling.

Throughout the region, one of the biggest concerns for Syrian refugee families is finding schooling for their children, who make up 48% of the Syrian refugee population and are unable to attend official schooling in their host countries. The longer children stay out of school, the less likely they are to eventually return, according to a March report from Save the Children. In Jordan, CARE found that more than 60% of school-age children are not attending any classes, despite the availability of free schooling.

On Friday, UNICEF officials urged the international community to respond to the problem, which it says belongs to everybody. "We must all share the shame," said UNICEF's Mr. Lake. "Because while we work to alleviate the suffering of those affected by this crisis, the global community has failed in its responsibility to this child. We should stop and ask ourselves how, in all conscience, we can continue to fail the children of Syria."

However, as Michael Gerson points out in The Washington Post, the response from countries has limits. The article highlights the challenges faced by those trying to help Syrian children who have been forced to leave their homes.

Title: Kurdish Forces Secure Key Highway in Iraq, Aided by U.S. Special Forces

Article:

Kurdish forces, known as the pesh merga, have successfully secured a significant portion of Highway 47 in Iraq, cutting off one of the main supply routes for the Islamic State (ISIS or ISIL). This operation was supported by U.S. Special Forces, who served as advisers to the pesh merga forces, although they remained away from the immediate fighting.

The pesh merga acquired a small number of armored American Humvees, left behind by the Iraqi Army during their rapid offensive last year. However, they faced challenges with another piece of captured American equipment, a heavily armored personnel carrier, which broke down and had to be towed.

The pesh merga's progress was marked by celebratory moments, such as blasting Kurdish music and dancing after reaching the base of Mount Sinjar. Despite these victories, the forces continued their march, with a makeshift meal of bread and canned fish before resuming their journey.

As the pesh merga approached Highway 47, the sound of military jets and the thud of explosions grew closer. These were identified as A-10 attack planes and B-1 heavy bombers, according to the American command.

Approximately two dozen U.S. Special Forces members were deployed, with half of them stationed at the foot of Mount Sinjar as the main headquarters, and the other dozen spread along the long mountain ridge to advise Kurdish airstrike spotters in selecting targets.

General Waisi's Kurdish force, known as the Zeravani Force, spread out to secure a broader area of Highway 47 west of Sinjar. However, other forces working in parallel were engaged in different sections of the highway. By midday, Kurdish officials reported controlling about 22 miles of Highway 47, stretching both east and west of Sinjar, effectively isolating the Islamic State's supply route between Syria and the jihadist-held city of Mosul in Iraq. The exact number of U.S. forces involved in the operation remains unavailable.

Title: Former Republican Lawmakers Urge Congressional Republicans to Oppose President Trump's Emergency Declaration

Article:

A group of former Republican lawmakers has urged Congressional Republicans to block President Trump's emergency declaration in an open letter released on Monday. The letter, first published by Politico, calls on Congress to support a joint resolution ending the national emergency declared by President Trump earlier this month.

Five former Senators and 19 House members signed the letter, expressing their opposition to the national emergency declaration and the potential expansion of executive authority. The former lawmakers, who served between 1967 and 2013, argue that the national emergency declaration sets a dangerous precedent that could be used against Republicans by a future Democratic administration.

In the letter, the former lawmakers write, "We who have signed this letter are no longer Members of Congress but that oath still burns within us." They continue, "That is why we are coming together to urge those of you who are now charged with upholding the authority of the first branch of government to resist efforts to surrender those powers to a president."

President Trump resorted to a national emergency declaration after Republicans on a specially-designated conference committee failed to secure the $5.7 billion he had long demanded for the construction of a border wall as part of a broader spending package. The former lawmakers, in their letter, embrace a common critique of the national emergency declaration, pointing out that the expansion of executive authority could eventually be wielded against Republicans by a Democratic administration.

"What will you do when a president of another party uses the precedent you are establishing to impose policies to which you are unalterably opposed?" they ask. "There is no way around this difficulty: what powers are ceded to a president whose policies you support may also be used by presidents whose policies you abhor."

The House will vote this week on a resolution to end the national emergency, which has thus far received the support of only one Republican, Representative Justin Amash of Michigan.

Title: Trump's Unconventional Approach to Presidency Challenges Traditional Governance Norms

Article:

In a departure from traditional governance dynamics, President Donald Trump has emerged as the most dominant figure in American life despite being the most unpopular first-year president in modern history, according to polls. Michael Beschloss, a presidential historian, notes, "You've got someone who is defining the presidency very differently."

Trump, according to Beschloss, is operating outside the boundaries that have been expected or followed for 200 years, stating, "Trump is essentially saying, 'I'm not going to operate just within the boundaries that the founders might have expected or people might have expected for 200 years. I'm going to operate within the boundaries of what is strictly legal, and I'm going to push those boundaries if I can.'"

William M. Daley, who served as a cabinet secretary under Bill Clinton and as White House chief of staff under Barack Obama, echoes this sentiment, stating, "Everyone else seemed to play within a certain box. But this one is totally outside the box."

Presidents, including Trump, have historically sought to expand the power of their office. Trump, like his predecessor Barack Obama, who made ambitious use of executive power despite opposition in Congress, has turned to his presidential pen to enact sweeping policies. However, Trump has shown a unique resistance to the constraints imposed on the presidency, often lashing out at judges, lawmakers, investigators, and journalists who displease him.

Trump's sense of government is not based on coalition building or a balancing act between equal branches. Instead, he deems what is necessary, and the system should fall in line. In recent days, Trump told The New York Times that he believes he has an "absolute right" to order the Justice Department to open or close investigations into himself or his foes. This assertion of power has sparked concerns about authoritarianism, although Trump, for the most part, has demonstrated more bark than bite.

The question remains whether Trump will follow through on his threats in the next stage of his tenure or whether his attacks will prove ultimately self-defeating. The discussion of "absolute" power and Trump's noted affinity for foreign strongmen have fueled fears of authoritarianism. However, the extent to which Trump will exercise this power remains to be seen.

Title: Veteran Reflects on Service During Vietnam Era and Advocacy for Gold Star Families

Article:

In a poignant reflection, a veteran shares his experiences during the Vietnam War era, highlighting the impact of his service and his subsequent advocacy for Gold Star families. The veteran, who was drafted in 1971 and served in the Army Medical Corps, was initially ordered to Vietnam but was instead sent to Camp Casey in South Korea.

The veteran served in the 2nd Infantry Division's Army Medical Corps, a unique unit with a rich history. The 2nd Infantry Division, 2nd Medical Battalion is the only Army infantry division to have been led by Marine Corps Generals, Major General John A. Lejeune and Brigadier General Charles A. Doyen. The 2nd Infantry Division is also known for their World War I victory at the Battle of Belleau Wood, which earned Marines the nickname 'Devil Dogs.'

The veteran's wartime medical experiences were vastly different from his medical school training. In Korea, he found himself practicing medicine in conditions reminiscent of the American Civil War, with limited tools and resources. Despite the challenges, he worked alongside three other doctors, caring for nearly 10,000 infantrymen.

Memorial Day holds a special significance for the veteran, as he remembers the lives of the two soldiers they saved from extreme heat exhaustion in 1973 and the many fallen comrades. He emphasizes that Memorial Day is a day to honor and remember the sacrifices of those who gave their lives for the country.

In recent years, the veteran has turned his attention to advocating for Gold Star families, the families of the nation's fallen heroes. He authored the Forever GI Bill, a bill that allows eligible veterans to use their GI Bill benefits at any point in their lifetime and makes Fry Scholarship participants eligible for the Yellow Ribbon Program. He also introduced the Fry Scholarship Improvement Act of 2019, a bill that extends eligibility for the Fry Scholarship to surviving spouses and children of deceased National Guard and Reserve members whose deaths are deemed service-connected by VA, but who died while not on active-duty if the death occurred within four years of the servicemember's last discharge.

This Memorial Day, the veteran encourages everyone to honor the fallen by saying a prayer, visiting a VA cemetery, contacting their member of Congress, or volunteering with a Veterans Service Organization (VSO). He mentions several organizations, such as America's Gold Star Families, Tragedy Assistance Program for Survivors, and the Travis Manion Foundation, that focus on honoring our nation's fallen.

The veteran concludes by expressing his gratitude for those who have served and sacrificed for the country and his pride in living in a nation built on those sacrifices. He prays for every life lost fighting for our freedom.

Title: U.S. Lawmakers Reach Principle Agreement on Farm Bill, Ending Months of Partisan Debate

Article:

U.S. lawmakers have reached a principle agreement on the Farm Bill, the top agriculture lawmakers and senators announced on Thursday. The agreement caps months of bitter partisan debate over the legislation that funds $867 billion in food and agriculture programs.

In a joint statement, the chairmen and ranking members of the Senate and House Agriculture Committees stated, "We are pleased to announce that we’ve reached an agreement in principle on the 2018 Farm Bill. We are working to finalize legal and report language as well as CBO scores, but we still have more work to do. We are committed to delivering a new farm bill to America as quickly as possible."

The programs covered by the bill include crop subsidies and support to access export markets, areas essential for American farmers, a key constituency of U.S. President Donald Trump. The latest bill, passed in 2014, expired on Sept. 30 after talks over its replacement broke down.

The agreement is yet to be integrated into the text of the legislation, and lawmakers will have to decide whether it will be voted on as a standalone bill or within a bigger package. Once voted on, the bill goes to the president for final signature. Lawmakers have until the end of the year to finalize the process.

The debate over the Farm Bill has been marked by contentious issues, such as the imposition of stricter work requirements for recipients of food stamps and the impact of trade wars on American farmers. The latest bill's expiration coincided with the imposition of tariffs by the U.S. on key commercial partners, such as China, the top buyer of U.S. farm produce, which has been absent from the market due to these tariffs.

Recently, the main standoff had focused on forestry provisions following the deadly wildfires in California. The details of the agreement regarding these issues are not yet available.

Title: U.S. Defense Secretary's Visit to Iraq Met with Resistance on Mosul Role for Turkey

Article:

U.S. Defense Secretary Ash Carter visited Baghdad on Saturday, aiming to persuade Iraq to allow Turkey to participate in the battle against the Islamic State for Mosul. However, Iraqi Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi declined the offer, stating that Iraqi, Kurdish, and other local forces are capable of handling the battle for Mosul without foreign intervention.

Al-Abadi, through a translator, expressed that Iraqi forces, in coalition with Kurdish peshmerga soldiers, American advisers, and various ethnic minority paramilitary units, can manage the large-scale offensive to recapture Mosul, which was overrun by Islamic State militants in 2014.

The U.S. acknowledges Iraq's sovereignty but seeks to resolve disputes between coalition partners to combat the common enemy, as stated by Carter. He expressed confidence in planning a constructive role for the U.S. in the region.

Carter's visit follows the death of a U.S. service member, the fourth since the U.S. began military operations in the region in August 2014, according to the Associated Press.

Meanwhile, an apparent counter-attack by suspected Islamic State fighters resulted in the death of 80 people and the wounding of 170 others in the oil city of Kirkuk on Friday. Most of the casualties were Kurdish security forces. The attack occurred as Iraqi forces advanced on militant-held Mosul about 100 miles to the northwest.

In another development, hundreds were treated for breathing problems due to a burning sulfur plant set ablaze Thursday in Mishraq, south of Mosul. Residents reported coughing, headaches, and nosebleeds from the gray smoke.

The United Nations Human Rights Office received reports on Friday that hundreds of families were forced out of villages and herded toward Mosul for potential use as human shields by the Islamic State. The U.N. High Commissioner for Human Rights expressed concern over the possibility of the militants using these vulnerable people as human shields or killing them.

The militants forced about 200 families out of Samali and 350 families out of Najalfia on Monday, according to the human rights office. At least 40 civilians were shot dead in one of the villages outside Mosul, under a report the office is investigating.

Title: White House Pushes for Easing Guantanamo Bay Detainee Transfer Restrictions

Article:

The debate over the detention of prisoners at Guantanamo Bay is resurfacing on Capitol Hill as the White House seeks to loosen restrictions on transferring detainees, despite concerns from some lawmakers about the potential risks associated with such actions.

Opponents of swift action on Guantanamo have long warned about the issue of recidivism among former detainees. An official estimate from last year indicated that nearly 28 percent of former detainees were suspected of returning to the battlefield.

Administration officials are hoping to leverage a Senate defense policy bill to advance their long-standing goal of moving detainees out of the Cuba-based prison camp and, eventually, shutting it down. The bill, set for debate in the coming days, would allow them to transfer prisoners who have been cleared for overseas transfer but are still detained, in part due to a complex Pentagon certification process.

The bill would ease those restrictions and lift a ban on bringing suspected terrorist prisoners from Guantanamo to the United States for detention, trial, or emergency medical treatment.

The White House's effort faces strong resistance, with opponents pointing out that some former detainees have re-engaged in terrorist activities after being released from the remote U.S. naval prison in Cuba.

"Why would you want to lower the standard?" asked Sen. Kelly Ayotte (R-NH), who, along with Sen. Saxby Chambliss (R-Ga.), is working on amendments to preserve the current high bar for transfers.

Even if the Senate passes the White House-backed legislation, the House earlier this year approved a measure that further restricts transfers, including an outright ban on sending detainees to Yemen. Yemen is a particular challenge since more than half of the 164 detainees are from there and is home to the world's most active Al Qaeda branch.

Obama himself imposed a ban on Yemeni transfers from Guantanamo after a Nigerian man attempted to blow up a U.S.-bound flight on Christmas 2009 with explosives hidden in his underwear on instructions from Al Qaeda operatives in Yemen. However, Obama lifted that moratorium in his May 23 speech at National Defense University, stating that Guantanamo "has become a symbol around the world for an America that flouts the rule of law."

"I transferred 67 detainees to other countries before Congress imposed restrictions to effectively prevent us from either transferring detainees to other countries or imprisoning them here in the United States. These restrictions make no sense," Obama said. He has vowed to close the prison.

"There is no justification beyond politics for Congress to prevent us from closing a facility that should never have been opened," Obama said.

Purely from an economic point of view, the administration says Guantanamo is too costly. Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel told Congress that annual spending on Guantanamo was $454 million—or about $2.7 million per detainee.

Obama has not publicly discussed Guantanamo in the six months since the speech, but administration officials say he presses Hagel and Secretary of State John Kerry on the matter every week. Obama also has new special envoys for Guantanamo closure at the State Department and Pentagon working full time on the matter.

"Our marching orders are very clear from the president, and in terms of what he wants to do, and that's to close the facility," said envoy Clifford Sloan at the State Department.

Sloan said achieving that goal requires three steps—transferring out those who have been approved, prosecuting others, and making a plan for the remaining detainees accused of participating in dangerous plots who cannot be prosecuted because the evidence against them is inadmissible in a court of law. That's a tall order on a three-year clock, but Sloan vowed, "Step by step, we will get there, and we will close it."

Sloan has been holding meetings across Capitol Hill to push for more flexibility, while Lisa Monaco, Obama's top counterterrorism adviser in the White House, has been calling moderate senators to encourage them to back the Senate bill.

The Senate bill would allow the Pentagon to transfer any detainee the administration no longer considers a threat to the United States, as long as actions are taken to "substantially mitigate the risk" that the detainee would re-engage in terrorism and ensure that the transfer is in the national security interest of the United States.

This summer, the administration sent home two Algerian detainees. Eighty-four others have long been cleared for transfer, and the U.S. government has begun a formal review process of about 45 others previously considered too dangerous to be released to determine if circumstances have changed.

Ayotte argued the Algerian transfers prove the current process is working, and Sen. John McCain (R-Ariz.) agreed that the administration does not need more flexibility. "All they have to do is assure us that they won't re-enter the fight, as numerous ones have, in leadership positions. We can't do that," McCain said.

Chris Anders, senior legislative counsel for the American Civil Liberties Union, which wants to close Guantanamo, acknowledges the issue is always a tough vote for lawmakers but argues there's a growing recognition that Guantanamo can't stay open forever and harms national security.

"What's different this year compared to past years is that the president is ready and willing to use whatever authority Congress gives him to start closing Guantanamo, and particularly to start sending home the majority of detainees who were long ago cleared to be sent back home," Anders said.

Title: Obama's Balanced Approach to Ferguson Draws Mixed Reviews

Article:

President Barack Obama's remarks on the Ferguson, Missouri, situation have received mixed reviews, with some criticizing his approach as subdued and others praising his efforts to maintain a balanced stance. In an interview with ABC's Ann Compton, Obama expressed sympathy for the community's outrage over the killing of Michael Brown while also emphasizing the importance of addressing black crime.

Politico described Obama as "guarded, reserved, and deeply clinical" in his comments on Ferguson. Critics argue that the president did not delve deeply into the pain of the racial divide or the underlying tensions, with Fox's Charles Krauthammer stating that Obama's comments were "instrumental" rather than "emotional."

However, Obama's measured approach may have been a strategic decision, given the volatile nature of the situation in Ferguson, which has seen nightly confrontations with police, numerous arrests, and shootings. Obama's past criticisms, such as his comments on the Trayvon Martin and Henry Louis Gates cases, were criticized for appearing to take sides before all the facts were in.

In his remarks on Ferguson, Obama made an effort to separate lawful dissent from violence, stating, "While I understand the passions and the anger that arise over the death of Michael Brown, giving into that anger by looting or carrying guns, and even attacking the police only serves to raise tensions and stir chaos." He also emphasized the importance of safeguarding constitutional rights, including the right to free speech, assembly, and a free press.

Obama also expressed sympathy for African-Americans, acknowledging the mistrust that exists between local residents and law enforcement in many communities. He stated, "In too many communities, a gulf of mistrust exists between local residents and law enforcement. In too many communities, too many young men of color are left behind and seen only as objects of fear."

Despite this, Obama also emphasized the need to prosecute lawbreakers, regardless of their race or the root causes of their actions. He stated, "There are young black men that commit crime. And we can argue about why that happens because of the poverty they were born into or the lack of opportunity or the school systems that failed them or what have you, but if they commit a crime, then they need to be prosecuted because every community has an interest in public safety."

Overall, Obama's approach to the Ferguson situation has been characterized by a measured and balanced stance, aimed at avoiding inflaming an already volatile situation while expressing sympathy for the community and emphasizing the importance of upholding the law.

Title: Trump's "War on Christmas": A Look at the Controversy Surrounding the Holiday

Article:

In a unique cultural blend, a Hindu-Jewish couple celebrates Christmas, incorporating traditional Christmas elements with their own cultural and religious influences. However, their celebration may face challenges in Donald Trump's America, where the President has vowed to end the perceived "War on Christmas" and promote the holiday more prominently.

Throughout his post-election victory tour, Trump has reiterated his commitment to promoting Christmas and ending the use of "Happy Holidays" in favor of "Merry Christmas." This stance has been met with criticism, as some argue that efforts to exclude other holidays infringes on the separation of church and state.

Trump has publicly criticized businesses perceived as not showing enough Christmas spirit, such as Starbucks, which redesigned its cups to emphasize a generic holiday theme rather than a Christmas one. He has also threatened to evict Starbucks from his hotel and encouraged boycotts of the coffee chain.

If Trump's actions as President escalate, he could potentially use the power of his office to enforce Christmas observance, leading to concerns about potential IRS audits, OSHA citations, and other forms of persecution.

The debate over Christmas observance in public spaces has been a contentious issue, with some arguing that efforts to remove nativity scenes from public squares violate the separation of church and state. However, the First Amendment's primary purpose is to prevent majoritarian oppression, not to eradicate religious expression in public spaces.

Trump's pledge to "Make America Say Merry Christmas Again" has been criticized for potentially turning Christians from victims to victimizers. This could lead to religious minorities feeling pressured to conform to the majority's customs, potentially leading to increased polarization and passive resistance.

The controversy surrounding Christmas observance in America may lead to a reevaluation of cultural defaults and potentially force millions of people, like the Hindu-Jewish couple in the article, to question their role in the cultural landscape. This could lead to a politicization of innocent and unconscious observances, generating anti-Christmas subversion rather than sincere celebration.

In conclusion, the debate over Christmas observance in America is a complex issue with deep cultural and political implications. It is crucial for all parties involved to approach the issue with understanding and respect for the diversity of beliefs and practices that make up American society.

Title: Trump's Continued War on the Media as President-elect

Article:

As President-elect, Donald Trump's antagonism towards the media persists. At a recent meeting with top television executives, Trump criticized the networks for their "outrageous" and "dishonest" coverage, and reportedly told CNN chief Jeff Zucker that "everyone at the network is a liar and you should be ashamed." On the same day, instead of holding a press conference, Trump released a YouTube video updating the public on the White House transition, stating that it had proceeded "very smoothly, efficiently, and effectively."

Presidential animosity towards the press is not a new phenomenon. Presidents have historically expressed frustration with a perceived unsympathetic press corps that misinterprets their words for the news, making it difficult to communicate clearly to the American public. To mitigate this, presidents have reduced the number of press conferences they hold while increasing communication through other means. The emergence of social media has allowed Trump to take this trend to the next level.

However, Trump's war on the media could undermine the media as an effective forum for debate and deliberation. By avoiding engagement with journalists and stifling media critics through public shaming and other strong-arm tactics, Trump will weaken the press's ability to act as a watchdog and critic, as envisioned by the Founders and embodied in the First Amendment. By attacking the media's objectivity and credibility, the Trump administration will weaken public confidence in the public sphere and, by extension, in the entire project of democratic self-governance.

Trump currently enjoys a significant level of support for his assault on the news media. In a post-election Pew survey, for example, just 22 percent of Americans gave the press either an A or B for its campaign coverage, with 59 percent giving it a D or F. A September 2016 Gallup poll found that just 32 percent of the public trust the press a fair amount or a great deal to report news "fully, accurately, and fairly," the lowest figure since Gallup first asked the question in 1976.

The timing of Trump's war on the media is not accidental. The media have become an arena of conflict in the increasingly polarized political system. To those who believe that the media exhibits a liberal bias, Trump is a welcome corrective. Consequently, the recent decline in trust has been driven primarily by Republicans, with just 14 percent of whom now believe the mass media deserves even a fair amount of trust compared to 30 percent of independents and 51 percent of Democrats.

A related trend is the increasing Balkanization of news audiences around competing news sources. For example, a 2014 Pew study showed that 47 percent of "consistent conservatives" name Fox News as their primary (and trusted) source of news about politics, while almost completely avoiding other major news outlets like The New York Times.

Even more concerning is the fact that the trend appears most pronounced among younger Americans, who tend to be somewhat more liberal than their parents. In 2016, just 26 percent of those under the age of 50 trusted the news media compared to 38 percent of those age 50 or older. Nor does the advent of social media help. Just 34 percent of American adults who use the web trust the information they get from social media sources.

How Trump will deal with the media and how the media will respond to Trump remains to be seen. The past 30 years or so do not provide much hope for optimism. The news industry has been pummeled by the fragmentation of the news audience and the emergence of the Internet. In the difficult economic environment they face, news organizations have shown little stomach for increasing hard news budgets or supporting much in the way of investigative journalism. Instead, a good deal of what passes for American journalism today is simply information recycled straight from government sources. There are exceptions, of course, as well as newer, non-traditional sources of news and opinion that provide alternative narratives to the mainstream media accounts. Most encouraging, perhaps, are the emerging signs that Trump's election may lead to a reinvigorated sense of duty on the part of journalists, news organizations, and NGOs. Whether these initial responses add up to an effective counterpoint to Trump's bully pulpit, however, remains to be seen.

Trevor Thrall is a senior fellow for the Cato Institute's Defense and Foreign Policy Department.

Title: Majority of Americans View Political Correctness as a Problem, According to New Survey

Article:

A survey conducted by More in Common, an international research initiative, has found that political correctness (P.C.) is deeply unpopular among the majority of Americans. The survey, which asked respondents questions about race, immigration, sexism, free speech, and other hot-button issues, categorized participants into seven groups: progressive activists, traditional liberals, passive liberals, the apathetic, moderates, traditional conservatives, and devoted conservatives. The two conservative categories constituted 25 percent of the total, while the progressives made up just 8 percent.

The remaining participants, according to the researchers, form an "exhausted majority" whose views are not significantly different from one another, even across racial and gender lines. Yascha Mounk, writing for The Atlantic, notes that "most members of the 'exhausted majority,' and then some, dislike political correctness." The survey found that 80 percent of the general population believe that "political correctness is a problem in our country." This sentiment is shared across all age groups, with 74 percent of people aged 24 to 29 and 79 percent under age 24 expressing similar views.

Mounk observes that "youth is not a good proxy for support of political correctness—and it turns out race is not either." The best proxies for support of political correctness, according to the survey, are education level and income. The most highly educated Americans are more likely to think hate speech is a significant problem, but political correctness is not.

In previous articles for ███, the author has discussed the potential backlash against political correctness and its potential role in Donald Trump's presidential victory. Voters who cited political correctness as a top issue were particularly drawn to Trump's candidacy, and being upset about PC-run-amok was a top indicator of whether a person voted Republican in 2016. Many people who wrote to the author about political correctness expressed that they voted for Trump specifically because they feel the language is moving away from them too quickly, and they don't know how to navigate the newly woke culture.

Mounk suggests that downplaying the concerns of the anti-PC majority could be a detrimental campaign strategy for any would-be Trump challenger. He argues that the gap between the progressive perception and the reality of public views on this issue could harm the influence and readership of publications and political candidates who misrepresent the views of the majority of Americans. In a democracy, it is difficult to win fellow citizens over to one's own side or to build public support to address real injustices when one fundamentally misunderstands how the public sees the world.

Title: Louisiana Governor Bobby Jindal Criticizes President Obama's Handling of Islamic State

Article:

In a critical opinion piece published by Fox News, Louisiana Governor Bobby Jindal has accused President Barack Obama of being "incapable of being the commander-in-chief of the United States of America" in his handling of the Islamic State terrorist group.

Jindal, who is reportedly considering a presidential run in 2016, criticized Obama's refusal to label the conflict as a war against "radical Islam." He argued that the president's reluctance to acknowledge the problem of "radical Islamic terrorism" prevents him from addressing it effectively.

Jindal also took issue with recent comments made by Marie Harf, a spokeswoman for the State Department, who suggested on MSNBC that a lack of job opportunities could be a factor in people joining such groups. Jindal described this as "madness" and argued that killing the enemy is the key to winning a war.

Furthermore, Jindal called for Congress to amend President Obama's request for an Authorization for the Use of Military Force (AUMF) to remove a prohibition on ground troops. He described the current prohibition as a political strategy designed to appease the left and as a check on the next president.

Jindal concluded his piece by calling for President Obama to tell the American people the truth about "radical Islam" and to put political considerations aside in order to defeat the terrorists.

Title: White House Refuses to Dig into IRS-White House Communications Regarding Private Taxpayer Information

Article:

The White House has informed Congress that it will not search its computers for emails that could provide insight into the sharing of private taxpayer information with President Obama's top aides. In a letter last week, White House Chief Counsel W. Neil Eggleston stated that the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) would address the issue once it completes its ongoing document productions, following the resolution of the tea party-targeting scandal.

However, IRS Commissioner John Koskinen's letter from last year did not indicate that the IRS would revisit the email search. Instead, Mr. Koskinen stated that the extensive search, which would have involved combing through 90,000 email accounts, was logistically impossible.

The White House's decision comes despite its past performance of a similar email search, following the loss of thousands of emails from former IRS division chief Lois G. Lerner, a key figure in the tea party targeting scandal. House Committee on Ways and Means Chairman Paul Ryan is investigating whether the laws governing taxpayer information security are effective, which falls under his committee's jurisdiction.

The IRS has been under scrutiny for several years due to scandals such as the targeting of tea party groups and the illegal release of private taxpayer information concerning the National Organization for Marriage. The IRS maintains that the disclosure was accidental and not politically motivated, but it did pay a settlement to the organization.

Some outside pressure groups argue that the IRS's improper behavior extends beyond these incidents, including the disclosure of private taxpayer information to the White House. These groups point to comments by a top White House economic adviser who, in 2010, stated that Koch Industries, the company run by conservative billionaires Charles and David Koch, paid no corporate income taxes.

The IRS's inspector general is currently investigating this issue, but has refused to release documents and is facing a Freedom of Information Act lawsuit over the matter. Both the House and Senate are now investigating IRS and White House communications.

In response to Mr. Ryan's request last week, the White House did not assert any privileges, instead insisting that the IRS would work on it. This contradicts Mr. Koskinen's 2014 letter, which made clear that such a search was not feasible from the IRS's end. The IRS did not respond to a request for comment on whether it had rethought its stance in light of the White House's promise, and the White House did not respond to a request for comment on why its chief counsel had misrepresented the IRS's position as stated in Mr. Koskinen's letter.

In 2014, the IRS admitted to losing some of Ms. Lerner's emails, prompting the Ways and Means Committee to ask the White House if it had any such emails. Mr. Obama's aides complied with that request, even providing three emails that Congress had not asked for.

Official requests for private taxpayer information made by the White House are supposed to be personally signed by the president, and the Joint Committee on Taxation is supposed to be notified of the request. The JCT issues an annual report on all requests for IRS information, and these reports do not show any such requests from the president during President Obama's time in office.

Mark W. Everson, who was commissioner of the IRS under President George W. Bush from 2003 to 2007, said both sides try to observe a strict division. "I can't remember this ever having come up—at least it ever having been brought to my attention," he said. "In my experience, the White House and the service were scrupulous about making sure appropriate independence was maintained between the two."

Mr. Koskinen has told Congress he is working in good faith to restore trust in his agency and to cooperate with lawmakers' investigations, which he says have cost millions of dollars in staff time and additional computer capacity. The tax agency has turned over hundreds of thousands of pages of documents in the tea party investigation, and congressional committees, including Ways and Means, are trying to finalize their reports on the wrongdoing.

Title: Violence Erupts at Guantanamo Bay Prison Following Shift to Individual Cells

Article:

Inmates at the Guantanamo Bay detention facility in Cuba clashed with guards on Saturday after military authorities decided to end communal housing in one of the prison's camps and instead move prisoners into individual cells. At least one detainee was reportedly injured by a rubber bullet during the incident.

The violence began after the facility's commander ordered the move on Saturday morning. According to the U.S. Southern Command, the decision was made due to detainees covering windows and surveillance cameras, limiting guards' ability to monitor them continuously.

The forced transfer was also used as an opportunity to evaluate the health of the prisoners, as dozens of them are currently on a hunger strike. Some detainees resisted with improvised weapons, according to the official statement, and in response, four less-than-lethal rounds were fired. There were no serious injuries to guards or detainees.

The prisoners' weapons included batons, broomsticks, and plastic water bottles, according to multiple reports. The incident occurred in an area of Guantanamo Bay that had evolved into a "medium-security" section since the first inmates were brought there more than 10 years ago.

According to The Miami Herald, a recent visit to the camp showed that the guards "had lost a measure of control" over the inmates. "The captives could be seen systematically disobeying communal camp rules. They covered surveillance cameras in individual cells with cereal boxes," writes Carol Rosenberg. "They refused to admit food carts to the cellblocks." Commanders said they were concerned that, out of view of the guard force, there were stealth hunger strikers who could suddenly die.

Reports of the number of prisoners who are currently on a hunger strike fluctuate, with some news outlets citing the Pentagon's estimate of 43 prisoners out of a total of 166, and others saying the number is more than 60, citing sources in the military and the inmates' defense attorneys.

Last week, the Pentagon named 11 inmates who were being force-fed to prevent them from starving themselves to death. The hunger strike was reportedly prompted by inmates' anger over guards' searching their Qurans and other practices that began after a change in command at the base last summer.

Title: Former GOP Presidential Candidate Jon Huntsman Skips 2012 Republican National Convention

Article:

Former Republican presidential candidate Jon Huntsman has announced that he will not attend the 2012 Republican National Convention, joining a small group of high-profile Republicans who have chosen to skip the event. However, this group does not constitute a formal coalition, as the reasons for their absence appear to serve different political purposes.

Huntsman, the former Utah governor and ambassador to China, stated on Friday that he would not attend the convention, which takes place in Tampa, Florida, from August 27-30, unless the Republican Party focuses on a more inclusive and problem-solving-oriented future for the United States.

The decision comes after Huntsman was reportedly dis-invited from a GOP fundraiser following his suggestion in January, after dropping out of the presidential race, that a third party should enter the race. He later compared the GOP to China's communist party for its response.

Another notable Republican, George Allen, is also among those who have announced they will not attend the convention. Allen's campaign stated on Tuesday that the former Virginia senator and governor is too focused on his close race with Democrat Tim Kaine for the seat of retiring Democratic Sen. Jim Webb. The race has been too close to call since both candidates announced their candidacies.

Allen's critics have attempted to brand him as a Washington insider, which may also explain his decision to distance himself from the national party.

Three other GOP candidates for Senate – Heather Wilson in New Mexico, Rep. Denny Rehberg in Montana, and Linda McMahon in Connecticut – have also stated they will not attend the convention to focus on their respective races.

Huntsman won two delegates for his third-place finish in New Hampshire. He will release these delegates to Mitt Romney, whom he has endorsed. In his announcement, Huntsman reiterated his campaign theme of "Country First."

"I encourage a return to the party we have been in the past, from Lincoln right on through to Reagan, that was always willing to put our country before politics," he said.

Title: Study Warns of Potential Impact of Ocean Acidification on Shark Teeth and Scales

Article:

A new study published in Scientific Reports suggests that ocean warming and acidification could pose a significant threat to sharks, potentially disrupting their role as apex predators and altering marine food webs. The research, led by Lutz Auerswald, a fisheries biologist at Stellenbosch University in South Africa and the nation's Department of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries, indicates that increased acidity in ocean water could cause shark teeth and scales to corrode, compromising their ability to swim, hunt, and feed.

The study's senior author, Auerswald, notes that larger species, such as great white sharks, are already endangered, and this could exacerbate their decline. The idea for the study emerged from a casual conversation between Auerswald and Sarika Singh, an ocean researcher at South Africa's Department of Environmental Affairs, over beers. They pondered the potential impact of more acidic ocean water on shark teeth, given that the high acidity of beer and many carbonated beverages causes human teeth to erode.

While numerous studies have examined the effects of ocean acidification on species that build shells or other calcium-based structures, such as corals and shellfish, only a few studies have looked at how acidification might impact sharks. A single paper has examined the effect of pH on sharks' skin denticles or scales, but its results were limited due to the relatively low carbon dioxide concentration used, compared to the high levels already present in many parts of the world's oceans.

For the new study, Auerswald, Singh, and their colleagues focused on puff adder shy sharks, a small, bottom-dwelling South African species of cat shark that is easily handled and not endangered. The team investigated acidification's effects on the animals' comparatively larger scales, as shark teeth and scales are both made of a calcium phosphate material called dentin, and the researchers expected the effects on teeth to be similar to any impact on the scales.

The researchers captured puff adder shy sharks in a harbor in Cape Town, South Africa, and transported them to a government research aquarium, where the fish acclimated for four months. They divided 13 of the sharks into control and experimental groups. Control animals stayed in an aquarium with a mildly basic pH of 8.1, matching that of the ocean, while the researchers gradually lowered the pH of the experimental animals' water to 7.3, the level that ocean water is predicted to reach by 2300 if carbon dioxide emissions continue. In some areas, including the waters off South Africa and California, the pH can already drop to 7.3 or lower, depending on prevailing currents and winds.

After two months, an electron-microscope analysis revealed that the concentrations of calcium and phosphate in the sharks' denticles were significantly reduced. About 25 percent of the experimental group's scales were damaged, compared with only 9 percent in the control group. "If dissolution is already visible [after just two months], one can only speculate how the sharks would look after a year or more," says Fredrik Jutfelt, a biologist at the Norwegian University of Science and Technology, who was not involved in the latest research but co-authored the only other study of shark scales in acidic conditions. "Increased dissolution of denticles could have serious consequences for sharks for many reasons."

The impacts, however, would likely vary between species. Puff adder shy sharks are sedentary predators that ambush their prey, so corroded scales might not impact their ability to hunt. However, for larger species that swim in open water, such as great white sharks, scales play an important role in hydrodynamics. One study found that shark denticles are responsible for an up to 12 percent increase in swimming speed. Thus, damaged denticles could slow sharks down and make it more difficult for them to catch prey. Scales also protect females from male biting during courtship and help some shark species defend against other predators. Likewise, corrosion to teeth could hit some species harder than others.

Other groups of calcifying organisms, for whom the effects of acidification are more well-studied, show these wide-ranging differences. Auerswald and his colleagues have observed that lobsters are quite resilient in the face of acidification, whereas abalones grow significantly slower, and "their shells look horrible," he says. "A lot of animals have survived even more acidic conditions in the ancient past, but we also know that a lot of species were wiped out," Auerswald says. "One lesson is that you have to test species by species."

Title: Analysis of Stand-Your-Ground Laws and Their Impact on Homicide Rates

Article:

A study by two Georgia State University economists, Chandler B. McClellan and Erdal Tekin, published by the National Bureau of Economic Research, suggests that stand-your-ground laws are associated with a significant increase in homicides among white males. The researchers estimate that between 28 and 33 additional white males are killed each month as a result of these laws.

The study, which analyzed data from at least 24 states that have adopted some variation of a stand-your-ground law since 2005, found a "significant increase in emergency room visits and hospital discharges related to firearm-inflicted injuries." The researchers suggest that increased firearm ownership in states with stand-your-ground laws and the presence of bystanders-turned-victims in public places might account for the increased dangers.

However, the impact of stand-your-ground laws on homicide rates varies among states. Florida, which passed its stand-your-ground law in 2005, experienced a spike in murders and manslaughters, but the trend has since returned to the status quo ante. Other states, such as New Mexico, Louisiana, and Delaware, have shown slight increases in their murder rates, while Texas has seen a decline in its rate after the passage of the law. Other states have either shown slight declines or no change at all.

A chart from McClatchy's interactive tool shows the homicide rates of stand-your-ground states, with Washington D.C.'s murder/manslaughter rate in comparison. D.C., which has some of the strictest gun control regulations in the U.S., has a higher murder rate than any of the stand-your-ground states.

The study's findings challenge the notion that stand-your-ground laws are necessary for public safety. Instead, the researchers suggest that policymakers should focus on addressing the high rate of murders and manslaughters in areas with strict gun control regulations, such as Washington D.C., rather than implementing stand-your-ground laws in states that seem to have a better handle on the situation.

Title: President Trump Praises Puerto Rico Mayor's Change in Tone as Recovery Efforts Continue

Article:

As President Donald Trump visited Puerto Rico on Tuesday to assess the ongoing recovery efforts from Hurricane Maria, he commented on the change in tone from one of the island's most vocal critics, San Juan Mayor Carmen Yulin Cruz.

"Well, I think she's come a long way," the president said of Cruz, who previously clashed with Mr. Trump over the federal response. Cruz, who has described the federal government's response as "killing us with inefficiency," is scheduled to attend a briefing with Mr. Trump in Puerto Rico on Tuesday.

Trump told reporters as he departed the White House that the recovery efforts in Puerto Rico were comparable to those in Texas and Florida, stating, "In Texas and in Florida, we get an A+. And I'll tell you what, I think we've done just as good in Puerto Rico, and it's actually a much tougher situation."

He added, "But now the roads are cleared, communications is starting to come back. We need their truck drivers to start driving trucks."

Hurricane Maria, a Category 4 storm, struck Puerto Rico on September 20, causing widespread destruction, knocking out power, communication, and transportation systems. Nearly two weeks after the storm made landfall, power is still out for 95 percent of electricity customers, and much of the countryside lacks access to life-sustaining basics, including food and fresh water.

Last week, Mr. Trump responded to Cruz with criticism of his own, writing on Twitter, "They want everything to be done for them when it should be a community effort." He also accused the news media, specifically CNN and NBC, of undermining recovery efforts with overly negative reports.

However, the Trump administration's efforts took a hit on Tuesday from Oxfam, an international organization that fights poverty and rarely criticizes wealthy nations such as the U.S. during a crisis. Oxfam America President Abby Maxman issued a statement, saying, "Oxfam has monitored the response in Puerto Rico closely, and we are outraged at the slow and inadequate response the US government has mounted in Puerto Rico. Clean water, food, fuel, electricity, and health care are in desperately short supply and quickly dwindling, and we're hearing excuses and criticism from the administration instead of a cohesive and compassionate response."

Title: Seoul Mayor Park Won-soon Found Dead Amid Criminal Probe and Allegations of Sexual Harassment

Article:

South Korea's longtime mayor of Seoul, Park Won-soon, has been found dead after he was reported missing by his daughter amid a criminal investigation and media reports of alleged sexual harassment. His body was discovered in wooded hills in northern Seoul at around midnight on Friday, more than seven hours after police launched a massive search for him.

Police reported no signs of foul play and did not provide a cause of death. The apparent suicide came after one of Park's former secretaries filed a complaint on Wednesday, alleging the 64-year-old had sexually harassed her, according to the Yonhap news agency. Police confirmed a criminal complaint had been made against Park but did not elaborate on the nature of the allegations.

In a note left on his desk and released by the city government with the permission of his family, Park expressed apologies and requested his body to be cremated and his ashes scattered over his parents' grave. A representative for Park's family issued a statement on their behalf, urging people to avoid spreading "groundless statements."

Park was reported missing by his daughter on Thursday at 5:17 pm, according to the police. Yonhap news agency reported that she also told police he had left a message "like a will." Kim Ji-hyeong, a Seoul Metropolitan Government official, said Park did not come to work on Thursday for unspecified reasons and had canceled all of his schedule, including a meeting with a presidential official at his Seoul City Hall office.

Park left the mayor's official residence at approximately 10:40 am on Thursday, wearing a black hat and a backpack, according to the police, and was identified by a security camera at 10:53 am at the entrance to the Mount Bugak hills. Authorities mobilized about 600 police and fire officers, drones, and tracking dogs to locate him. Choi Ik-su, an officer from the Seoul Metropolitan Police Agency, said rescue dogs found Park's body, and that his bag, cellphone, and business cards had been recovered.

Park, a longtime civic activist and human rights lawyer, was elected Seoul mayor in 2011. He became the city's first mayor to be voted to a third term in June 2018 and was instrumental in its response to the coronavirus pandemic. A member of President Moon Jae-in's liberal Democratic Party, he had been considered a potential presidential candidate in 2022 elections.

Park had mostly maintained his activist colors as mayor, criticizing what he described as the country's growing social and economic inequalities and corrupt ties between large businesses and politicians. As a lawyer in the 1990s, he was credited with winning the country's first sexual harassment conviction. He has also been an outspoken critic of Japan's colonial-era policies towards Korea, including the mobilization of Korean and other women as sex slaves for Japanese soldiers.

In 2018, Park praised women for their courage after a series of women accused powerful politicians and policymakers of sexual wrongdoings amid the #MeToo movement. "The resolve of individual heroines is not enough. I think we need social solidarity," he said at the time.

Park also established himself as a fierce opponent of former conservative President Park Geun-hye and openly supported the millions of people who flooded the city's streets in late 2016 and 2017 calling for her resignation over a corruption scandal.

There was an outpouring of grief from his supporters, some of whom wailed at Seoul National University Hospital as his body was brought in. Prime Minister Chung Sye-kyun expressed condolences during a regular meeting on the government's response to COVID-19 response on Friday, saying, "Mayor Park, who has served Seoul citizens for a decade, was found passed away. I pray that the deceased rest in peace."

Ruling party chief Lee Hae-chan said Park's death was "shocking and regretful," recalling him as an old friend who fought together for democracy during a dictatorship in the 1980s. Reactions to his death were mixed on social media, including both condolences and criticism that he killed himself to avoid punishment.

"Mayor Park, you were an excellent politician," one poster wrote on Daum, the country's second-largest portal site. "But a twist of fate put an end to your journey. I hope you are at ease in heaven."
