Others were more critical of the mayor, accusing him of exploiting his power to harass a subordinate and then taking his own life to "avoid the fallout." "The victim must have had painful times in the run-up to the filing of the complaint," wrote one user. "I hope Park reflects on his misdeeds and atones in the afterlife."

The Seoul city government said a memorial altar will be set up in front of the city hall for citizens to pay their respects.

Title: Trump Administration Proposes Biological Definition of Sex in Title IX Regulations

Article:

The Trump administration is reportedly considering a change in the definition of sex in Title IX regulations, which could potentially limit federal recognition of transgender individuals. The proposed definition would define sex as "a person's status as male or female based on immutable biological traits identifiable by or before birth."

The Obama administration, in April 2014, expanded the definition of sex in Title IX, a federal civil-rights statute banning sex discrimination in federally funded education programs. The Obama administration's definition included gender identity or failure to conform to stereotypical notions of masculinity or femininity. This expansion was done without an act of Congress or a regulatory rulemaking process.

The Obama administration's interpretation led to aggressive mandates for schools across the nation, requiring the use of a transgender student's chosen pronouns and opening bathrooms, locker rooms, overnight accommodations, and some sports teams to students based on their chosen gender identity, not their biological sex.

The Trump administration rolled back Obama-era transgender directives, including the sweeping education mandates, but has not formally responded to the previous administration's expansion of the scope of the statute. According to a story in Sunday's New York Times, the administration may issue formal guidance to return the definition of sex in Title IX to its original, biological meaning.

The proposed change has sparked controversy, with some arguing that it would "deny the humanity" of transgender individuals. However, the change would not affect the constitutional rights of any American, nor would it erase the existence of transgender individuals. Every American is still protected by the Bill of Rights and other constitutional rights, and every single American still enjoys the benefit of every other generally applicable statute.

The claim that the proposed change denies anyone's humanity or existence is a common, inflammatory rhetorical tactic that creates a false choice. The change in regulatory definitions would not deny anyone's humanity or existence, but rather would correct an Obama-administration overreach.

Transgender individuals did not come into existence in April 2014, when the Obama administration altered its interpretation of Title IX. They will not cease to exist if the Trump administration returns to traditional and intended statutory definitions. The rhetoric surrounding this issue is out of control, and members of the Trump administration are simply considering applying conventional rules of statutory construction to correct an Obama-administration overreach.

Title: Democrats Consider Expanding Supreme Court Amidst Controversy Over Court Packing

Article:

In the aftermath of the Merrick Garland situation, discussions regarding the legitimacy and potential expansion of the Supreme Court have arisen. Eric Holder, former Attorney General, has suggested that expanding the number of justices could be a viable option if a Democratic President and Congress are willing to pursue such a change.

The strategy employed by Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, who blocked President Obama's nomination of Merrick Garland, is not without precedent, according to Guy's observations. Two Democratic presidential hopefuls, Sen. Kirsten Gillibrand (D-NY) and South Bend, Indiana mayor Pete Buttigieg, have expressed support for this plan.

In response, Republican legislators are preparing to present amendments to maintain the current number of Supreme Court justices. Rep. Mark Green (R-TN) announced on Tuesday that he will introduce a constitutional amendment to limit the number of justices to 9, the number that has remained consistent since 1869.

Rep. Green stated, "The Supreme Court must remain a fair and impartial branch of government not beholden to party. Schemes to pack the court are dangerous to the Founders' vision of an independent judiciary that serves as a check on both the Executive and Legislative branches of government."

Sen. Marco Rubio (R-FL) has also taken a stand against court packing, citing the potential destabilization of essential institutions as a concern. In a Fox News op-ed, he expressed his intention to lead the charge in the Senate, stating, "Court packing is quickly becoming a litmus test for 2020 Democratic candidates as this ugly, winner-take-all rhetoric gains prominence in progressive circles."

Rubio further explained, "To prevent the delegitimizing of the Supreme Court, I will introduce a constitutional amendment to keep the number of seats at nine. There is nothing magical about the number nine. It is not inherently right just because the number of seats on the Supreme Court remains unchanged since 1869. But there is something inherently good and important about preventing the further destabilization of essential institutions."

The Supreme Court's recent decisions have raised concerns among progressives. On Tuesday, the justices overturned a Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals ruling, granting the Department of Homeland Security legal authority to detain illegal immigrants after they have been through a court hearing.

Title: Clinton Launches National Voter Registration Program for Dreamers

Article:

Hillary Clinton has announced a new voter registration drive, titled "Mi Sueño, Tu Voto/My Dream, Your Vote," aimed at registering sympathetic voters, including undocumented individuals known as Dreamers. The Dreamers themselves are prohibited from voting. The program was launched on the four-year anniversary of the 2012 order that temporarily shielded some young immigrants brought to the country illegally as children from deportation.

The Clinton campaign hopes to use the Dreamers, a powerful political organizing force, to encourage Latino and other households to vote for the Democratic nominee. The program is part of an aggressive effort by Clinton's campaign to woo the record 27.3 million Latinos eligible to vote in 2016.

The program will focus on battleground states such as Colorado, Nevada, North Carolina, and Florida, where Latinos and other immigrants make up an important part of the voting base. Organizers will remind voters that a Trump presidency could end the Dreamer program, which is already at risk after a June Supreme Court decision that effectively killed Obama's efforts to give legal status to some of the 11 million immigrants living in the U.S. illegally.

Trump has promised to revoke Obama's executive orders within the first 100 days of his presidency, calling them the "most unconstitutional actions ever undertaken by a president." Clinton has made revamping the country's immigration system a key plank of her presidential campaign and has vowed to restore and expand Obama's programs, close private sector detention centers, and "take a very hard look at the deportation policies" currently in force.

Last month, Clinton called on Latino voters to help stop what she called GOP rival Donald Trump's efforts to "fan the flames of racial division." The Clinton campaign stated in a full campaign statement on the latest program, per The Washington Examiner, that "Mi Sueno, Tu Voto" aims to organize Dreamers to mobilize their communities and ask voters to consider what is at stake for their families in November. The program will also serve to remind voters of Trump's pledge to eliminate DACA and deport millions of Dreamers and immigrant families.

Title: Microsoft Discloses Cyber Attacks by Iran-Linked Group on US Presidential Campaign, Government Officials, and Journalists

Article:

Microsoft, a leading software company, has announced that a hacking group, allegedly linked to the Iranian government, has carried out a cyber attack against a US presidential campaign, current and former American government officials, journalists covering global politics, and prominent Iranians living outside the country.

In a 30-day period between August and September, the group, known as "Phosphorus" or APT 35, Charming Kitten, and Ajax Security Team, made over 2,700 attempts to identify Microsoft consumers' email accounts and attacked 241 of these accounts, according to the company's blog post.

Four accounts were compromised as a result of these attempts, but they were not associated with the US presidential campaign or current and former US government officials, Microsoft stated. The company has notified the affected customers and worked to secure their accounts.

Hacking to interfere in elections has become a significant concern for governments, particularly after US intelligence agencies concluded that Russia ran an operation to disrupt the American democratic process in 2016, allegedly to help Donald Trump become president.

Microsoft has been tracking Phosphorus since 2013 and, in March, received a court order to take control of 99 websites the group used to carry out attacks. The company stated that the attacks it is disclosing today were not technically sophisticated but attempted to use a significant amount of personal information to identify the accounts of intended targets and in some cases to attempt attacks.

Microsoft's Digital Crimes Unit has taken legal and technical steps to combat Phosphorus attacks. To help secure consumer accounts, Microsoft recommends that all customers enable two-step verification and periodically check their login history.

Title: Bipartisan Congressional Agreement on Russia Sanctions Bill Limits President Trump's Ability to Lift Sanctions

Article:

Leaders of both parties in the United States Congress have reached an agreement on legislation that imposes fresh sanctions on Russia for alleged election meddling. The new legislation significantly restricts President Donald Trump's ability to lift any existing sanctions against Russia.

Throughout his presidency, Trump has expressed a desire for diplomatic flexibility with the Kremlin. However, his tenure has been marked by claims that Russia attempted to influence the 2016 U.S. election. Moscow denies any wrongdoing, but several U.S. investigations are examining whether anyone in the Trump campaign colluded with Russian officials.

The bipartisan agreement in Congress indicates a firm stance against Russia, regardless of Trump's view. If Trump were to veto the bill, he would risk fueling suspicion that he is overly supportive of the Kremlin, according to correspondents. Conversely, if he signs the bill, he would be implementing legislation that his administration is reportedly opposed to.

Senator Ben Cardin, the most senior Democrat on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, stated that the agreement was the result of "intense negotiations." Cardin added, "A nearly united Congress is poised to send President Putin a clear message on behalf of the American people and our allies, and we need President Trump to help us deliver that message."

Chuck Schumer, Senate Democratic leader, said the House of Representatives and the Senate would act on the legislation "promptly, on a broad bipartisan basis." He described a strong sanctions bill as "essential."

The bill also addresses potential future sanctions against Iran and North Korea. It has already passed the Senate, and the House of Representatives is scheduled to vote on it on Tuesday.

The legislation allows for new sanctions against Russia for its 2014 annexation of Crimea, as well as for its alleged meddling in the U.S. election. The U.S. already has sanctions in place against Russian individuals and companies over Crimea. In December, following claims of election hacking, then-President Barack Obama also expelled 35 diplomats and closed two Russian compounds in the U.S.

The Kremlin has demanded the return of the seized compounds and has threatened "specific measures" in retaliation. After high-level talks last week, one Russian official involved said the row had "almost" been resolved. However, the new U.S. bill would make it difficult for President Trump to alter sanctions or return diplomatic properties without the approval of Congress.

During his presidential campaign, Trump hinted he would consider recognizing Crimea as part of Russia and suggested lifting sanctions. In another development, Russia's ambassador to the U.S., Sergei Kislyak, has returned home after completing his nine-year tenure. Kislyak has been linked to several of President Trump's associates and has been named by U.S. media as a key figure in the investigation into alleged election interference. Kislyak's successor has not yet been named.

U.S. authorities continue to investigate possible collusion between the Trump team and Russia, claims Trump has repeatedly denied. In a new twist on Saturday, reports emerged that Trump was considering presidential pardons for family members, aides, and even himself. Presidents have the power to pardon people before guilt is established or even before the person is charged with a crime. Trump tweeted, "While all agree the U.S. President has the complete power to pardon, why think of that when only crime so far is LEAKS against us. FAKE NEWS."

Senator Mark Warner, a Democrat who sits on the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence, described the reports as disturbing, adding, "Pardoning any individuals who may have been involved would be crossing a fundamental line."

Title: Michael Cohen Alleges Trump's Involvement in Hush Payments and Russia Dealings

Article:

Michael Cohen, the former personal attorney to President Donald Trump, has claimed that Trump directed him to pay off adult film star Stormy Daniels and model Karen McDougal, and that he knew these actions were wrong. In an interview with ABC News' George Stephanopoulos, Cohen stated that Trump was aware of the payments' potential impact on the 2016 election.

Cohen, who was once known for his unwavering loyalty to Trump, asserted that all decisions made at the Trump Organization were run through the president, and that he was instructed to make the payments and become involved in these matters. He also expressed his belief that people should not trust Trump's statements, stating, "The man doesn't tell the truth."

Cohen's assertions come after he pleaded guilty to tax fraud and campaign-finance violations in August, and admitted to lying to Congress about the nature and timing of Trump's business dealings with Russia in November. These admissions have raised concerns about Trump's potential impeachment and indictment.

Trump has responded to Cohen's allegations by accusing him of lying to "embarrass the president" and secure a reduced prison sentence. However, Cohen told Stephanopoulos that he had no intention of humiliating Trump and that special counsel Robert Mueller has a "substantial amount of information" to corroborate his assertions about the hush agreements and Russia dealings.

In response to the mounting evidence, Trump's legal team has adjusted its defense. Initially, Trump claimed he had "NOTHING TO DO WITH RUSSIA," but this week, he characterized his dealings with Russia as "peanut stuff" that was "very legal & very cool." After denying the president's knowledge of the hush payments, Trump's lawyer Rudy Giuliani told the Daily Beast that "Nobody got killed, nobody got robbed...This was not a big crime."

Title: Vice President Mike Pence Visits Mayo Clinic Without Mask, Despite Mask Requirement

Article:

Vice President Mike Pence visited the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minnesota, on Tuesday without wearing a mask, despite the facility's requirement for all patients, visitors, and staff to wear face coverings or masks to slow the spread of Covid-19. The Mayo Clinic had informed Pence of its mask policy before the tour.

Pence, who leads President Donald Trump's coronavirus task force, later stated that he did not need to wear a mask because he is tested regularly for the virus and does not have it. The Mayo Clinic, which is renowned for its medical expertise, requires masks to ensure the safety of its patients and staff.

In a pool image, Pence is surrounded by 9 other people, including a patient, all wearing masks during the tour. Pence was the only official who did not wear a mask during the discussion with top doctors, according to a pool report. Federal Food and Drug Administration Commissioner Dr. Stephen Hahn reportedly wore a mask during the tour.

Pence participated in a discussion with top doctors, Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz, and U.S. Rep. Jim Hagedorn, a Republican whose district includes the city of Rochester. The vice president was asked about his decision not to wear a mask during the first question at a news conference at the facility after the tour and discussion.

Pence responded that he is tested for the coronavirus regularly, and everyone around him is also tested. He also stated that wearing a mask does not necessarily protect the wearer from the coronavirus but might prevent the inadvertent conveyance of the virus to a loved one, family member, or friend.

When asked about the signal wearing a mask might send to the American public, Pence did not directly answer the question. However, he reiterated that he is tested "on a regular basis."

A Mayo Clinic spokesman, when asked for comment, said in an email that the clinic shared the masking policy with the vice president's office. The spokesman did not respond to the question about why the facility deleted its tweet about Pence. The Mayo Clinic later posted a new tweet expressing gratitude for Pence's visit.

Pence's aides last week told The New York Times that he did not wear a mask for the same reasons he gave Tuesday. However, the newspaper noted that Pence could contract the virus between his tests, and that the tests are not always accurate.

Title: House to Vote on Immigration Bill: Focus on E-Verify for Controlling Illegal Immigration

Article:

The United States House of Representatives is set to vote on an immigration bill this week, with the aim of addressing the issue of illegal immigration. The bill, sponsored by the House leadership, seeks to find a middle ground between immigration hawks and moderate Republicans.

The bill includes several commendable provisions, such as granting amnesty for individuals who arrived in the U.S. illegally as minors and have maintained law-abiding behavior, reorienting legal immigration towards the recruitment of skilled workers, reducing legal immigration, and allowing children to be held with their parents while their asylum claims are processed.

However, the bill does not mandate the use of E-Verify for new hires, a measure that conservatives are urging to be included. E-Verify is an electronic system that allows employers to confirm the eligibility of their employees to work in the United States.

The Trump administration has been hesitant to prioritize E-Verify, but it is seen as a crucial tool for controlling illegal immigration. Roughly two-fifths of illegal immigrants did not cross the border illegally; they entered the country legally and overstayed their visas. By making it mandatory for employers to verify the legal status of their new hires, it would be more difficult for illegal immigrants to secure employment, reducing the economic incentive that drives most illegal immigration.

The bill's current version does not mandate E-Verify, but conservatives are urging for its inclusion. E-Verify would serve as a deterrent against future illegal immigration, making it harder for existing illegal immigrants to switch jobs, and potentially leading some to leave the country. Additionally, the mandatory implementation of E-Verify would make it easier to prosecute employers who exploit illegal workers and depress wages for lower-income Americans.

Once the flow of illegal immigration is controlled in a sustainable manner, consideration can be given to granting amnesty to those illegal immigrants who have established roots and avoided trouble. The goal is to end the cycle of amnesty inviting more illegal immigration.

The outcome of the House vote is uncertain, as the bill is not expected to survive a filibuster in the Senate. The vote's main purpose is to establish legislators' positions on immigration policy and to influence the ultimate political resolution of the issue.

Title: President Trump Condemns Racism and White Supremacy, Calls for Cultural Change Following Mass Shootings

Article:

In the aftermath of two mass shootings over the weekend, President Donald Trump delivered remarks on Monday, August 5, 2019, condemning the incidents and expressing his condolences. The shootings occurred at a Walmart store in El Paso, Texas, and in Dayton, Ohio.

Trump described the perpetrators as "wicked" and "twisted monsters." He stated that the nation must "condemn racism, bigotry, and white supremacy" and that these "sinister ideologies must be defeated." The president emphasized that hate has no place in America.

While not proposing major gun control legislation, Trump suggested strengthening mental health laws and called for the Department of Justice to propose legislation ensuring that those who commit hate crimes and mass murders face the death penalty. He also proposed "strong background checks," possibly tied to immigration reform.

The president called for a "cultural change" and urged the nation to stop the "glorification of violence in our society," including the "gruesome and grizzly video games" that contribute to the "glorification of violence."

Trump's remarks were delivered before pool reporters and cameras from the Diplomatic Room of the White House, not the Oval Office. Vice President Mike Pence stood at his side. The president did not repeat his earlier suggestion about gun background checks in his formal remarks.

Former President Barack Obama weighed in with a tweet that, while not mentioning Trump by name, reflected scathing criticism of divisive rhetoric. Senate Democratic Leader Chuck Schumer has demanded that Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell call the Senate back from its August recess to consider the bipartisan, House-passed universal background checks bill.

It was unclear how either of the shootings were related to immigration reform, as Trump suggested. The National Rifle Association applauded Trump's call to address the root causes of violence. Trump's acting White House chief of staff Mick Mulvaney rejected claims that the president's harsh rhetoric on immigration played any role in the shootings.

Title: The Economist Takes a Moderate Approach on Climate Change

Article:

In a recent article, The Economist has adopted a more moderate stance on climate change, challenging the long-held belief that the Earth is highly sensitive to changes in carbon dioxide levels. The publication points out that, over the past 15 years, air temperatures at the Earth's surface have remained relatively stable despite a significant increase in greenhouse gas emissions.

Between 2000 and 2010, the world added approximately 100 billion tonnes of carbon to the atmosphere, accounting for a quarter of all CO₂ emissions since 1750. Notably, as James Hansen, the head of NASA's Goddard Institute for Space Studies, observes, "the five-year mean global temperature has been flat for a decade."

Ed Hawkins, of the University of Reading in Britain, notes that surface temperatures since 2005 are already at the low end of the range of projections derived from 20 climate models. If temperatures remain flat, they will fall outside the models' range within a few years.

The article suggests that if temperatures are likely to rise by only 2°C in response to a doubling of carbon emissions, and if the likelihood of a 6°C increase is trivial, the focus might shift from mitigation to adaptation. The author compares this to buying earthquake insurance if one does not live in an earthquake zone, implying that it may be more practical to adapt to the greenhouse-gas emissions rather than attempting to stop them.

The article does not deny the existence of climate change or the need to address environmental issues. However, it questions the notion that humanity's economic growth is directly causing an imminent, irreversible catastrophe that requires immediate action to cut back on growth. The author suggests that a more honest, less emotional approach to the science, the range of possibilities, and the unknown factors, as well as a more inclusive approach to dissenting opinions, may be more effective in recruiting people to the cause in the long run.

Title: Couple Defends Actions as Protesters Demand Mayor's Resignation in St. Louis

Article: A white couple, Mark and Patricia McCloskey, stated on Monday that they pointed guns at protesters outside their home in St. Louis over the weekend due to fear for their lives. The incident occurred on Sunday night as protesters were walking towards the home of Mayor Lyda Krewson (D) to demand her resignation.

According to a local CBS affiliate KMOV, the protesters were on their way to Krewson's home in Portland Place, a gated community, when they passed by the McCloskey residence. The group, reportedly numbering several hundred, had been calling for Krewson's resignation after she recently read activists' personal information on a livestream.

Mark McCloskey told KMOV that they felt threatened, stating, "It was like the storming of the Bastille, the gate came down, and a large crowd of angry, aggressive people poured through. I was terrified that we’d be murdered within seconds. Our house would be burned down, our pets would be killed." He also shared a picture of a gate to the community that he claimed had been broken, but it has not been confirmed whether the gate was damaged by the protesters.

Rasheen Aldridge, who was reportedly one of the leaders of the protest, disputed the couple's claims, stating the protest remained peaceful in nature despite the McCloskeys drawing guns on the demonstrators.

In a statement to KMOV, an attorney representing the McCloskeys, Albert Watkins, defended their actions and said they were not "race related." He added, "In fact, the agitators responsible for the trepidation were white."

Watkins continued, "The Black Lives Matters movement is here to stay, it is the right message, and it is about time. The McCloskeys want to make sure no one thinks less of BLM, its message, and the means it is employing to get its message out because of the actions of a few white individuals who tarnished a peaceful protest."

He reportedly added that the McCloskeys are lawyers whose professional careers have been marked by their long-standing commitment to protecting the civil rights of clients victimized at the hands of law enforcement. This commitment, he said, continues today in the Isaiah Forman case.

Title: House Democrats Pass Anti-Corruption and Voting Rights Bill, Divided Along Party Lines

Article:

The U.S. House of Representatives has passed a sweeping anti-corruption and voting rights bill, known as the "For The People Act" or "H.R.1," on Friday. The legislation, which passed 234-193 along party lines, aims to make voting easier, strengthen ethics rules, and reject a motion to condemn voting by undocumented immigrants.

The 700-page bill proposes designating Election Day as a federal holiday, requiring all states to offer automatic voter registration, restoring voting rights to convicted felons, instituting independent redistricting commissions to combat gerrymandering, and requiring nonprofit organizations to disclose the names of donors who contribute more than $10,000 to rein in dark-money groups.

U.S. Rep. Zoe Lofgren (D-Calif.), who leads the House administration committee that shepherded the legislation, stated, "It’s a power grab for the American people." In contrast, House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy (R-Calif.) said, "This bill is a massive federal government takeover that would undermine the integrity of our elections."

The legislation faces little chance of passing in the Senate, with Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) indicating he will not bring the bill for a vote, effectively killing the bill. Illinois Rep. Rodney Davis (R), the ranking Republican on the House subcommittee on elections, stated before the vote, "This bill is nothing but a bill that is for loading billions of billions of dollars into the coffers of members of Congress."

In a related debate over voter accessibility, House Democrats also voted Friday to defend localities that allow non-citizens to vote in their elections. The vote would have had minimal effect as non-citizens are barred from participating in federal elections. The GOP-backed measure would have added language to "H.R.1 stating that "allowing illegal immigrants the right to vote devalues the franchise and diminishes the voting power of United States citizens."

Rep. John Lewis (D-Ga.), a civil rights movement hero, supported the measure, referencing San Francisco's policy of allowing noncitizens, including undocumented immigrants, to vote in school board elections. Just six Democrats voted against the measure, and one Republican opposed it.

Title: White House Cancels Philadelphia Eagles' Visit Amid Controversy Over National Anthem Protest Misrepresentation

Article:

President Trump announced on Monday that he had canceled a planned visit by the Super Bowl-winning Philadelphia Eagles to the White House, citing the team's alleged disrespect for the national anthem. However, the explanation provided by the President does not align with the facts, as no Eagles players ever stayed in the locker room during the national anthem, nor did any players kneel during the regular season or the playoffs.

The controversy escalated when Fox News aired footage of Eagles players praying before the national anthem, claiming they were protesting. In response, Zach Ertz, a tight end for the Eagles, tweeted that Fox News should be "better than this." Ertz is among the players featured in the Fox News segment, and he and his teammates released a Bible study phone app on humility and surrender this past fall.

Fox News later apologized, acknowledging in a statement to USA Today that no Eagles players ever kneeled in protest during the 2017 season. The White House, in a subsequent statement, alleged that the Philadelphia Eagles "decided to abandon their fans" by not attending the White House celebration.

The controversy over the Eagles' White House visit appears to have backfired on President Trump, including among conservative commentators and GOP members of Congress. Pennsylvania GOP Rep. Ryan Costello tweeted that Trump handled the situation "poorly," while conservative magazine columnist Jonah Goldberg called Trump's statements "deceitful propaganda." RedState contributor Jim Jamitis pointed out the bad optics of excitedly planning a meeting with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un while denigrating NFL players.

In an email, a White House spokesperson asked that an updated statement be included in this article. In the statement, the White House alleges that the Philadelphia Eagles "decided to abandon their fans" by not attending the White House celebration.

Title: Diligent Opposition vs. Hysteria: The Democrats' Struggle to Adjust to Unified Republican Government

 Article:

 The election of Donald Trump has marked a significant shift in the political landscape of the United States, bringing unified Republican government to Washington. However, the Democrats seem to be struggling to adapt to this change, as they have been in power for a decade and their strategy to oppose Trump appears to be ineffective.

 Since 2005, the Democrats have been in control, winning the Congress in 2006 and the White House in 2008. Despite losing the House in 2010 and the Senate in 2014, they still held the White House, a president seemingly immune from criticism, the courts, the bureaucracy, and large portions of the media.

 However, the election of Trump has overturned this understanding, as the Democrats seem not to understand how to deal with Trump and the massive change he is about to bring to the nation's capital. During the general election, they fell for the idea that Trump could be defeated by conventional means, spending hundreds of millions of dollars in negative television advertising and relying on political consultants.

 The Democrats currently control neither the House nor the Senate, yet they act as if they do. Speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi's speech to the 115th House of Representatives was a long-winded recitation of the same liberal agenda that has brought her party to its current low. Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer's pledge to oppose Trump's nominee weeks before inauguration day is a prime example of this misplaced confidence.

 Schumer's strategy of opposing Trump's Supreme Court nominee and prolonging the confirmation process for cabinet officials may force the Senate to change the rules so that Supreme Court vacancies can be approved by a majority vote. This could leave the Democrats vulnerable should another vacancy arise in the next two years.

 The Democrats' blanket opposition to President-elect Trump extends to his appointments at large. Their willingness to stand on a podium beside a sign that reads, "Make America Sick Again," for example, has been criticized for associating not Trump but themselves with illness.

 It remains to be seen how the Democrats will adjust to their new role as the opposition party. However, their hysterics and obnoxious behavior towards Trump may not be the most effective strategy for opposing his policies and appointments.

Title: U.S. Military Had Advance Warning of Iranian Ballistic Missile Attack, Officials Say

Article:

U.S. military officials reported that they had advance warning of an Iranian ballistic missile attack on two bases in Iraq housing U.S. forces on Tuesday night. The attack, which involved more than a dozen short-range ballistic missiles, was intended to cause structural damage, destroy vehicles and equipment, and kill personnel, according to Defense Secretary Mark Esper and Gen. Mark Milley, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

During a briefing with reporters on Wednesday, Milley stated, "I believe based on what I saw and what I know is that they were intended to cause structural damage, destroy vehicles and equipment and aircraft and to kill personnel." He added that U.S. military officials were warned about Iran's pending ballistic missile strike "when the air defense systems went active."

Milley explained that "a little bit of early warning" and "normal defensive procedures" at Al-Assad Air Base prevented American troops from being killed in the missile strike. The attack resulted in the malfunctioning of four missiles, which failed to hit their targets.

According to Esper, the 16 short-range ballistic missiles (originally estimated to be 15) were fired from three locations inside Iran during the attack early Wednesday local time. The missiles were intended as a response to the death of Iranian Quds Force Gen. Qassem Soleimani, who was killed in a U.S.-led drone strike at Baghdad International Airport last week.

Esper stated that between 1,000- to 2,000-pound warheads were sitting on top of the Iranian missiles fired into Iraq. The damage at the bases was largely contained to "tentage, taxiways, the parking lot, damaged helicopter, things like that, nothing I would describe as major," Esper said.

Pentagon officials met with President Trump twice in the past 24 hours following the attack, Esper said. Trump announced earlier Wednesday in a nine-minute address to the nation that he would be imposing even more sanctions on Iran in response to the attack.

Democrats on Capitol Hill have criticized Trump's initial decision to take out Soleimani without first consulting Congress or allies in the region, which has led to escalating tensions in the Middle East. They have since demanded answers from the administration about the alleged imminent threat that sparked the Soleimani attack, and how Trump will de-escalate the tensions with Iran and keep Americans safe.

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi announced plans for the House to vote Thursday on a War Powers Resolution that aims to limit Trump's military action toward Iran. Pelosi stated, "Democrats have'serious, urgent concerns about the administration’s decision to engage in hostilities against Iran and about its lack of strategy moving forward.'"

Lawmakers on both sides of the aisle expressed concerns coming out of Wednesday's Iran briefing about the administration bypassing Congress's approval for military escalations. Esper responded, "Most members of Congress do not have access to the intelligence that I think is the most compelling. That’s simply the nature of the intelligence, and it’s restricted to the Gang of 8."

Title: U.S. Urges Diplomatic Resolution in Ongoing Diplomatic Row Between Saudi Arabia and Canada

Article:

The United States has called for a diplomatic resolution between Saudi Arabia and Canada in a developing diplomatic row over human rights concerns. The dispute, which has been ongoing for a second day, stems from Canada's demand for the release of women's rights activists and others arrested in Saudi Arabia.

State Department spokeswoman Heather Nauert stated that U.S. officials have raised human rights concerns with the Saudis in the past, but emphasized that Riyadh and Ottawa "need to diplomatically resolve this together."

Saudi Arabia, in response to Canada's demand, expelled the Canadian ambassador from Riyadh and froze all new trade deals between the two countries on Sunday. This action followed a tweet by Canada's leading foreign affairs agency, Global Affairs Canada, expressing concern over the detention of Samar Badawi, the sister of a blogger jailed by Saudi authorities.

Critics argue that Riyadh is attempting to assert its international influence and has overreacted to Canada's comment. The value of Saudi-Canadian trade is primarily composed of Saudi exports of petrochemicals, plastics, and other products, with significant exports to Canada from the Canadian unit of U.S. weapons maker General Dynamics Corp.

Ms. Nauert stated that the U.S. is aware of human rights concerns regarding Saudi Arabia but avoided taking a firm position on the Canada-Saudi spat. She noted that the U.S. has a regular dialogue with the Saudi government on human rights and other issues. Ms. Nauert also encouraged the Saudi government to address due process and publicize information on legal cases.

Regarding the specific case between Canada and Saudi Arabia, Ms. Nauert stated that the U.S. has raised the issue with the Saudi government. She asserted that the U.S. respects international recognized freedoms and individual liberty, a stance that has not changed. Ms. Nauert concluded by encouraging both governments to work out their issues together.

Title: Majority of Americans Urge Congress to Delay Looming Spending Cuts

Article:

A new survey conducted by Selzer & Co. and released by Bloomberg News on Thursday indicates that a majority of Americans want Congress to delay the impending forced spending cuts, which are set to take effect next week. The poll shows that 54% of respondents support delaying the cuts, while 40% favor allowing the cuts to proceed.

The across-the-board cuts, totaling $85 billion over the next seven months and $1.2 trillion over the next decade, would significantly reduce federal agency spending. The nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office estimates that these cuts could decrease economic growth by at least 0.6 percentage points and result in a loss of 750,000 jobs.

The potential effects of the cuts on everyday Americans include reduced unemployment benefits, longer security lines at airports, furloughs at federal agencies, delays or closures at national parks, and higher prices for chicken and other products due to cuts to food safety programs.

President Barack Obama and lawmakers on Capitol Hill now face a March 1 deadline to reach a deal to prevent the cuts, which were initially scheduled to take place at the beginning of the year but were postponed for two months due to a scaled-back fiscal cliff bill.

Should Washington find a deficit-reduction agreement to replace the automatic cuts, known as the sequester, 59% of Americans support White House proposals that call for a combination of spending cuts and tax increases, according to the new poll.

In addition, the poll indicates that a majority of Americans (56%) also support overhauling Social Security and Medicare to reduce the deficit, a position shared by Congressional Republicans.

The poll's findings align with a Pew Research and USA Today poll released earlier on Thursday, in which 49% of respondents supported delaying the cuts, while 40% favored their implementation. However, a majority of Americans in both polls expressed a desire to address the federal deficit this year.

The Bloomberg News survey was conducted by Selzer & Co. from February 15-18 with 1,003 U.S. adults via telephone. The poll's sampling error is plus or minus 3.1 percentage points.

Title: President Obama Urges Democrats to Avoid Violence at Political Rallies, Criticizes Trump's Tactics

Article:

In a speech on Friday night, President Barack Obama called on Democrats to refrain from resorting to violence at political rallies, citing an incident at a rally in San Jose this week where anti-Donald Trump demonstrators reportedly assaulted supporters.

"We saw in San Jose these protesters starting to pelt things at Trump supporters," Mr. Obama said at a fundraiser near Biscayne Bay, Florida. "That's not what our democracy is about. That's not what you do. There's no room for violence. There's no place for shouting. There's no room for a politics that fails to at least listen to the other side—even if you vehemently disagree."

The president emphasized the need for Democrats to "remind ourselves of who we are and what is best about American democracy, and not slip into some of the bad habits that currently manifest themselves in the other party."

Mr. Obama also criticized Mr. Trump and his party for using divisive tactics, stating, "Being able to say that it's immigrants or it's gays or it's somebody that is taking something away from you—that's the essence of the message that the Republican nominee is delivering."

The fundraiser was hosted at the home of personal injury lawyer Robert Rubenstein, with ticket prices ranging from $10,000 to $30,000.

In addition to addressing the issue of political violence, Mr. Obama also spoke about the media's role in the election, stating, "Celebrity and fame is such a driver in this culture—and everything's so contested."

The president also gave a plug for Democratic National Committee Chair Debbie Wasserman Schultz, who was in attendance. She is currently facing a primary challenge in her congressional district from Timothy Canova, who is running on a platform of Wall Street reform and has the backing of presidential candidate Sen. Bernie Sanders.

"She's had my back, I want to make sure we have her back," Mr. Obama said.

Title: National Day of Mourning Declared for Former President George H.W. Bush; Funeral Arrangements Detailed

Article:

President Donald Trump has declared Wednesday a national day of mourning for former President George H.W. Bush, who passed away on Friday at the age of 94. The New York Stock Exchange and the Nasdaq Stock Market will be closed on Wednesday, and both markets will observe a moment of silence on Monday.

The former president's body will be flown to Washington on Monday. A short service will take place at the U.S. Capitol, followed by the former president lying in state in the rotunda from 7:30 p.m. Monday to 8:45 a.m. Wednesday. A state funeral will be held Wednesday at 11 a.m. at Washington National Cathedral, after which the former president's body will be flown to Houston.

The former president's body will lie in repose at St. Martin's Episcopal Church from 6:45 p.m. Wednesday to 6 a.m. Thursday. Following a private funeral service at the church, his body will be interred at the George Bush Presidential Library & Museum at Texas A&M University.

Tributes to Mr. Bush poured in from political dignitaries in the U.S. and around the world. Mr. Bush served as U.S. president from 1989 to 1993, during the end of the Cold War and the first Persian Gulf War.

His death was announced late Friday by his son, George W. Bush, who followed in his footsteps to become America's 43rd president in 2001. President Trump said Mr. Bush inspired generations of Americans to public service.

Mr. Bush's funeral could affect plans for a spending bill. Congressional leaders have been discussing the possibility of a one-week spending bill to avoid a partial government shutdown when seven spending bills expire next weekend. While leaders haven't yet made a decision, a short-term spending patch appears more likely in the face of Mr. Bush's funeral proceedings.

On Tuesday, Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer (D, NY) and House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi (D, CA) are expected to meet with President Trump at the White House, where spending negotiations are likely to come up.

President Trump, at the Group of 20 summit in Buenos Aires, canceled a news conference scheduled for Saturday, citing Mr. Bush's death.

Former President Barack Obama said, "While our hearts are heavy today, they are also filled with gratitude." Sen. Jack Reed of Rhode Island, the ranking Democrat on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, cited Mr. Bush's willingness to cross party lines to benefit the country and world.

Tributes from world leaders, including former Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev, German Foreign Minister Heiko Maas, and the emir of Kuwait, highlighted Mr. Bush's contributions to ending the Cold War, reunifying Germany, and aiding Kuwait after an invasion by Iraq in 1990.

Title: Egypt Designates Muslim Brotherhood as Terrorist Organization, Escalating Crackdown

Article:

A public bus was bombed in Cairo on Wednesday, marking a shift in the ongoing series of attacks targeting civilians and security forces in Egypt. This incident followed a police compound bombing in the Nile Delta two days prior. The Egyptian government, backed by the military, has declared the Muslim Brotherhood a terrorist organization, potentially deepening the powerhouse political group's underground status.

The bus bombing in the Cairo district of Nasr City involved a homemade bomb that exploded as a public bus passed by, shattering the windows. At least one more bomb was found nearby, intended to be defused as security forces arrived at the scene, according to Egyptian state TV. No group has claimed responsibility for the attack, but Tuesday's attack on a police compound in Mansoura was claimed by Ansar Bayt al-Maqdis, a militant group based in the Sinai Peninsula.

Tuesday's attack was the deadliest since July, with 16 fatalities, according to the Associated Press. The group claimed responsibility for the attack, stating it was in retaliation for the security forces' crackdown on Islamists following the July military takeover. Ansar Bayt al-Maqdis has also been linked to Al Qaeda and has claimed responsibility for numerous attacks in urban areas, including the attempted assassination of the interior minister in October.

The Egyptian government contends that the Muslim Brotherhood is a national security threat, working with militant groups to orchestrate the campaign of violence, though it has provided no evidence. The Muslim Brotherhood was a popular political force in Egypt, polling ahead of other parties in the country's first free parliamentary elections held in 2012. Since July, the group's top leaders, including former President Mohamed Morsi, have been imprisoned or driven underground. The organization was outlawed in September.

Thousands of members and supporters have been imprisoned, and hundreds have been killed, according to The New York Times. Wednesday's terrorist designation is a significant blow to the 80-year-old Islamist organization. Analysts view it as the most severe crackdown on the movement in decades, potentially outlawing hundreds of social and charity organizations run by Brotherhood members and making it a crime to promote the Brotherhood "by words."

Khalil al-Anani, a senior fellow at the Middle East Institute in Washington who studies the Brotherhood, warned that the government's move could lead Egypt toward "civil conflict." "This is a big miscalculation from the government," he told The New York Times. "It is a massive social movement, whose supporters might retaliate or fight back."

Exiled Muslim Brotherhood leader Ibrahim Munir stated that protests would continue, calling the designation "illegitimate." Reuters warns of the potential for further escalation in Egypt's political landscape.

Title: Senate Republicans Overcome Filibuster to Pass Debt Limit Extension

Article:

Senate Republicans, in a surprising turn of events, managed to pass a House-passed bill to extend the debt limit unconditionally through 2014, overcoming a filibuster on Wednesday evening. The bill, initially expected to face significant opposition, was passed with weeks to spare before the deadline.

However, the bill faced a brief stalemate on the Senate floor, with 58 votes - 55 from Democrats and three from Republicans - two votes short of the 60 required to break a filibuster and no GOP volunteers forthcoming. The delay was due to a collective action problem among Senate Republicans. While the group did not want to vote down the debt limit increase and face market panic, individual Republicans did not want their names associated with its passage.

In a crucial moment, Republican leaders Mitch McConnell and John Cornyn, both in cycle this year, cast their votes to break the filibuster almost simultaneously. This cleared the threshold, and seven more Republicans joined them. Each of these team players seemed willing to provide cover for their colleagues but not if the leaders left them stranded after initiating the fight.

After the bill's passage, the non-Cruz wing of the party expressed gratitude to McConnell for acting with courage and integrity. However, they could not say, but they knew full well, that McConnell and Cornyn had invited this situation upon themselves.

For three years, McConnell has characterized every debt limit increase as a favor President Obama has requested of Congress, a normatively bad thing Republicans would not agree to without some kind of equally partisan quid pro quo. This approach has left McConnell and other GOP leaders without a plausible explanation for their mounting defeats. By McConnell's own standard, he has done Obama's bidding multiple times now, most recently without pocketing even a pretense of a concession.

Senator Ted Cruz declined to comment on whether McConnell should keep his leadership role in the next Congress, citing the decision as one for the voters of Kentucky to make. After the danger had passed, several of the Republicans who helped the debt limit bill clear the filibuster issued press releases boasting of their votes against final passage, a disingenuous distinction for them to draw.

Title: Sylvia Burwell to Face Senate Confirmation Hearings for Healthcare Role Amidst Obamacare Challenges

Article:

President Obama's nominee to replace Kathleen Sebelius, Sylvia Burwell, is set to face tough questions from the Senate Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions Committee today. Burwell, the former White House Budget Director, is expected to be confirmed, but will likely be questioned extensively about the ongoing issues with Obamacare and her plans to address these problems moving forward.

During the announcement of Burwell's nomination last month, President Obama praised her as a "proven manager" who is capable of delivering results. With the challenges ahead, her management skills will be crucial.

Recently, Democrats and the administration have acknowledged issues with Obamacare that need to be addressed rather than repealing the legislation. Today, Burwell will be expected to detail these fixes and explain her plans to work with Congress to implement changes. The confirmation hearings provide Republicans with an opportunity to further scrutinize the new law and ask detailed questions about administration claims.

This week, it was revealed that many of Obamacare's reported eight million enrollees are duplicates, and last week, it was learned that only 67 percent of enrollees have paid their first premium. It will be interesting to see how Burwell defends the program.

Upon her nomination, Burwell expressed her excitement about the opportunity to build on the achievements made by Kathleen Sebelius, President Obama, and others. If confirmed by the Senate, she looks forward to continuing the work of ensuring that children, families, and seniors have the building blocks for healthy and productive lives, whether it's through implementing the Affordable Care Act, supporting affordable childcare, or finding new ways to prevent and treat disease.

Title: FBI Investigates Alleged Plot to Falsely Accuse Special Counsel Robert Mueller

Article:

An apparent attempt to fabricate sexual misconduct allegations against Special Counsel Robert Mueller has reportedly collapsed, and may have led some conservative activists into potential trouble with the FBI.

In a statement, Mueller's spokesperson said, "When we learned last week of allegations that women were offered money to make false claims about the Special Counsel, we immediately referred the matter to the FBI for investigation."

The details of the alleged scheme remain unclear, including its intended target. The incident came to light after pro-Trump Twitter personality Jacob Wohl hinted at such allegations on Monday night, causing concern among journalists who perceived it as a smear campaign.

Key figures involved in the matter appear to be Jacob Wohl, a 20-year-old conservative known for his speedy, sycophantic replies to President Trump's tweets, making implausible and factually dubious claims, and running shady hedge funds. Another individual is Republican lobbyist and conspiracy theorist Jack Burkman, who has a history of making false claims about bombshell political information.

It is unclear if Wohl, Burkman, or both were involved in the plot to drum up these allegations, or if they were merely trolling the media. It is also possible that Wohl may have been deceiving Burkman to some extent.

Investigation into the matter led to the examination of Surefire Intelligence, the supposed private intelligence company investigating these allegations. Wohl was evasive about his involvement in Surefire or the plot in general, while Burkman openly told Hill Reporter that "Surefire is a real company" run by "Jacob Wohl."

Further investigation suggests that Surefire may be essentially Jacob Wohl, with no other individuals involved. It is unclear if Burkman, who insisted that Surefire was "real," is also being deceived, or if he is a willing participant in this scheme.

On Tuesday afternoon, the far-right conspiracist website Gateway Pundit, for which Wohl writes, published a heavily redacted document making a rape allegation against Mueller. The document's author's name was blacked out, but it used a slogan that was also on the Surefire website. After much mockery on Twitter, Gateway Pundit's Jim Hoft took the document down and stated he was "looking into" the "serious allegations against Jacob Wohl."

The FBI is now investigating the matter, as stated by Mueller's spokesperson on Tuesday. If this is merely a trolling attempt, it could be considered a success in drawing attention. However, if the purpose of the scheme was to troll journalists as much as to smear Mueller and the investigation, then the trolls may have achieved their goal.

The midterm elections are approaching, and this incident has reportedly diverted journalistic resources from other topics. Burkman still claims that he will reveal "the first" of Mueller's accusers at a press conference this Thursday. If this press conference follows the pattern of Burkman's previous ones, it will likely be uneventful. However, if the trolls' ultimate goal was to steal the spotlight and change the subject, then their plan may have succeeded.

Title: Alabama Senate Election: Roy Moore Files Lawsuit to Challenge Election Result

Article:

Republican candidate Roy Moore has filed a lawsuit in an attempt to challenge the result of the recent Alabama Senate election, in which he lost to his Democrat rival Doug Jones. The lawsuit was filed on Wednesday, a day before officials certified Mr. Jones as the winner, two weeks after the vote.

Mr. Moore was expected to win the election in the deeply conservative state, but his campaign was marred by allegations of child sexual misconduct. He refused to concede to Mr. Jones, who won narrowly by approximately 20,000 votes.

The lawsuit alleges voting irregularities in 20 precincts and calls for a fraud investigation and a new election. One of the election experts cited in the suit is Richard Charnin, a conspiracy theorist who also claims there was widespread voter fraud against Donald Trump in the presidential election.

In a statement, Mr. Moore's lawyer said the purpose of the complaint was to "preserve evidence of potential election fraud and to postpone the certification of Alabama's Special Election by Secretary of State John Merrill until a thorough investigation of potential election fraud, that improperly altered the outcome of this election."

Secretary of State John Merrill told the Associated Press on Wednesday that Mr. Jones "will be sworn in by Vice-President Pence on 3 January."

Conspiracy theories have spread in online conservative groups since the election, alleging without evidence that black voters were bussed in from other states to vote for Mr. Jones. Mr. Merrill has so far found no evidence of voter fraud, but pledged that his office would investigate any complaint submitted by Mr. Moore.

The election result was a blow to President Trump, who gave Mr. Moore his full-throated support, even as other Republicans distanced themselves following the misconduct allegations. Four women allege that Mr. Moore, then in his early thirties, assaulted, molested, or pursued them when they were teenagers, including sexually touching one when she was 14.

Mr. Moore denies the allegations and says they are politically motivated. His supporters, including his wife Kayla Moore, have promoted unfounded theories that his accusers were paid.

Throughout his political career, Mr. Moore has provoked controversy, suggesting that 9/11 happened because of declining Christian values, calling for Muslims to be barred from office, and strongly opposing gay marriage.

Title: Record Wall Street Contributions to GOP Candidates in Midterm Elections

Article:

In the ongoing 2023 midterm elections, a record 63% of political contributions from employees and corporations in the banking and investment sectors have gone to Republican candidates, according to data from the Center for Responsive Politics. This represents the largest dollar figure ($78 million) and percent for the GOP in any midterm election.

The increased donations are likely due to a strategic calculation that Republicans have a better chance of winning on Tuesday. Dorsey Farr, co-founder of French Wolf & Farr, an investment advisory firm in Atlanta, stated, "You want to be with the winner. A lot of times you'll see companies give to both parties. If they see the tide turning, they'll go with the flow."

The figures do not include money channeled through political action committees, which have become increasingly prevalent in campaign finance in recent years. The boosted election expenditures from the financial world this time around also have to do with the fact that the Democratic Party has intensified its regulatory approach since the financial crisis.

Ray La Raja, a political science professor at the University of Massachusetts - Amherst, explained, "Democrats are just more of the regulatory party. In the past, bankers could work with any party. Now, all things equal, they'd rather work with Republicans."

Beyond strategic calculations, there is also a philosophical element, with many on Wall Street feeling they have been demonized by the current administration. Major banks have paid out unprecedented multi-billion settlements in recent years for their role in the financial meltdown.

In a recent interview with Salon, Senator Elizabeth Warren (D-Massachusetts) criticized the president's economic team for favoring Wall Street over Main Street. Prominent 2016 Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton also faced backlash for comments suggesting corporations and businesses do not create jobs.

Senator Cory Booker (D-New Jersey) was the top recipient of contributions from the investment community this election, having raised almost $1.9 million. Charles Schumer (D-New York), a traditional ally of Wall Street who sits on the Senate Finance Committee, pulled in about $850,000.

La Raja noted, "I'm sure they're not going to piss off a powerful Democrat." However, he also pointed out that Wall Street has not completely abandoned Democrats, as the populist theme will continue to resonate with voters as long as the economic recovery remains sluggish for many Americans.

In contrast, La Raja stated, "If all engines are running and the economy is doing well, populism dies." Despite the increased contributions to Republican candidates, it is unclear whether this trend will translate into electoral victories for the GOP.

Title: Pope Francis Officially Opposes Death Penalty in All Circumstances, Calls for Global Abolition

Article:

Pope Francis has officially changed the teachings of the Catholic Church to oppose the death penalty in all circumstances, the Vatican has announced. The Catechism of the Church, a codified doctrine which sums up the Church's teachings, had previously stated that the death penalty could be used in some cases.

The updated Catechism now states that the death penalty is "inadmissible because it is an attack on the inviolability and dignity of the person." Pope Francis has spoken out against executions in the past, and last October, he had stated that the Church's policy on the death penalty was one area where teaching was not static and could change with modern concerns.

The text of the catechism was first set by Pope John Paul II in October 1992, and earlier stated that the death penalty was "an appropriate response to the gravity of certain crimes and an acceptable, albeit extreme, means of safeguarding the common good." However, the new text argues that today's more effective detention methods protect citizens and "do not definitively deprive the guilty of the possibility of redemption."

The Church will now work with determination for the abolition of the death penalty worldwide, according to a statement from the Holy See. The Catholic Church may base its faith on an unchanging Bible, but that does not stop the institution from updating some of its most important teachings.

Centuries ago, popes called Christians to Holy War, commanded their own armies, and showed little anxiety about the killing of their enemies. In modern times, popes have re-invented themselves as symbols of global peace. But until now, the Church had taught that the death penalty was "an acceptable, albeit extreme means of safeguarding the common good."

Pope Francis, who has made mercy a theme of his papacy, has now decided that this has to change by ruling the death penalty "inadmissible." This may put the Church in direct conflict with conservative Catholics in the US who insist that capital punishment is justified.

Historically, the Church has mostly been unopposed to the death penalty, including into the 20th Century. In 1952, Pope Pius XII said it was not a violation of the universal right to life. Pope John Paul II argued for imprisonment over execution wherever possible, although Joseph Ratzinger, who later became Pope Benedict XVI, wrote that the death penalty could be permissible.

The death penalty is still legal in 53 countries around the world. In the United States, where 22% of the population are Catholic, execution is still legal in 31 states. It is still also legal in Cuba, Dominica, and Uganda - where about half of their populations are Catholic. The only place in Europe where it is still legal is Belarus, which has a sizeable Catholic minority of about 7% of the population. Burkina Faso, Madagascar, and Benin, where significant chunks of the population follow Catholicism, have all outlawed the death penalty in recent years.

Title: Presidential Candidates Distance Themselves from Chick-fil-A Controversy

Article:

In the ongoing 2012 U.S. presidential election, both Barack Obama and Mitt Romney are navigating a cultural divide, with the issue of gay marriage serving as a flashpoint for activists on both sides. The recent controversy surrounding Chick-fil-A, a fast-food chain whose executives have expressed opposition to gay marriage, has become a topic of discussion in the election.

President Obama, who supports gay marriage, has chosen to remain neutral on the issue regarding Chick-fil-A, a private company that operates primarily in red states. The president has been cautious on the issue, focusing on his efforts to dig the country out of the economic hole and avoiding alienating religious conservatives in the black community or blue-collar Democratic whites in key states like Ohio and Virginia.

Mitt Romney, who favors a constitutional amendment forbidding gay marriage, has also avoided discussing the Chick-fil-A controversy. Romney, who has praised Chick-fil-A founder Truett Cathy in the past, has not commented on the issue since May, when his son, Dan, sparked the latest controversy by stating that gay marriage invites "God's judgment."

Both candidates are treading carefully, as stoking the base is crucial for both candidates in the election. Romney, who has been criticized for his evolving stance on gay marriage, has been advised by an adviser to keep the focus on his economic message and avoid distractions.

Ralph Reed, the founder of the Faith and Freedom Coalition, argues that Romney has ground to gain by engaging with the social conservative base on the issue. Reed stated, "The vast majority of the American people, even those who might not agree with Dan Cathy’s personal views, think that it was incorrect for Rahm Emanuel and the mayor of Boston to suggest that they wouldn’t be allowed to get a permit in their city." Reed added, "I think anything for anybody running for office in either party right now would benefit from a trip to a Chick-fil-A franchise."

In summary, both presidential candidates, Barack Obama and Mitt Romney, have chosen to remain silent on the Chick-fil-A controversy, with Obama focusing on avoiding alienating religious conservatives and Romney aiming to keep the focus on his economic message. The issue of gay marriage and its impact on the election remains a topic of discussion among activists on both sides.

Title: U.S. Economy Grows at 3.5% in Q3, Consumer Spending Up 4%

The U.S. economy expanded at a 3.5% annual rate in the third quarter, according to the Commerce Department. This growth rate is slower than the second quarter's 4.2%, but it puts the economy on pace for the fastest annual growth in 13 years.

Private analysts had estimated a 3.4% growth rate in gross domestic product (GDP) for the third quarter. Consumer spending jumped at a 4% rate in the July-September quarter, the fastest in about four years, and topping the 3.8% in the prior three months.

The strong showing reflects the fact that many people are in the job market, according to former White House economist Jared Bernstein. "Lots of people are working and drawing paychecks," he said. "Even if those paychecks are not growing as fast as we might like, that's going to fuel economic growth, and in this report, in fact, the strongest sector was consumer spending."

The travel industry was one sector that benefited from the increased spending. "We set records around Labor Day and Memorial Day this year and Fourth of July in terms of travel," said Elie Maalouf, Americas CEO of IHG, the hotel group that owns Holiday Inn and other chains.

Overall growth may have been affected, in part, by Hurricane Florence, which flooded the Southeast U.S. in September. The Commerce Department said Florence resulted in losses of $37 billion in property and equipment. Earlier, Moody's Analytics estimated the economic cost of the storm at $38 billion to $50 billion. Hurricane Michael, which plowed through the Florida Panhandle and Georgia earlier this month, could affect fourth-quarter GDP.

Last month, the Federal Reserve boosted its growth projection to 3.1% for 2018, but it saw growth slowing to 2.5% next year. The economy has been expanding in the 2% range in the past few years, but growth spiked in the second quarter, boosted by consumer spending and exports. However, exports decreased at a 3.5% pace in the third quarter after jumping 9.3% in the second quarter. Analysts had cautioned that the previous increase in exports was sparked by looming tariffs by China in its ongoing trade war with the United States. So they said that the export boom probably would not be sustained.

With unemployment at nearly 50-year lows, consumers have been confident enough to spend. The Conference Board's measure of consumer confidence rose in September, and retail sales grew 4.7% last month from a year earlier.

However, the housing market is starting to slow, amid higher interest rates. Sales of new homes fell 5.5% in September—the fourth monthly drop in a row—and resales were down 3.4%.

President Trump has been attacking the Federal Reserve for raising interest rates as the economy continues to recover from the Great Recession. Rates on 30-year fixed-rate mortgages are approaching 5%, which may discourage some homebuying.

Title: Four Individuals Charged with Hate Crimes in Alleged Assault Streamed Live on Facebook

Four individuals have been charged with hate crimes, aggravated kidnapping, aggravated unlawful restraint, aggravated battery with a deadly weapon, burglary, robbery, and possession of a stolen motor vehicle, following an assault that was live-streamed on Facebook.

Authorities claim the victim, who has mental health challenges, was tied up, beaten, and cut with a knife by several assailants. The incident led to the victim's hospitalization, and he was found by police on Tuesday evening.

Police Superintendent Eddie Johnson stated at a news conference that the incident was investigated as a hate crime due to the victim's mental capacity, race, and other factors. The Facebook Live stream showing the attack has been deleted, but clips showing multiple people taunting, threatening, and hitting a man who is tied up in a corner have been posted by multiple outlets.

The assailants, who are black, reportedly say "F * * * Donald Trump" and "F * * * white people" on the video. They also force the victim, who is white, to repeat these phrases.

The four suspects were arrested after police were called to a residence near where they found the man and connected the incident and the location. The victim, a resident of a Chicago suburb, spent at least 24 hours in the company of his alleged assailants, one of whom he knew from school. He had been reported missing on Monday.

A GoFundMe account has been set up for the victim, and the website will work with the campaign organizer to ensure all funds raised reach the victim.

Chicago police found the victim in distress on the street before they were aware of the existence of the Facebook live stream. The four suspects' remarks about President-elect Donald Trump are being investigated to determine whether they are "sincere or just stupid ranting and raving."

At Wednesday's news conference, Johnson highlighted the "brazenness" of the assailants for not just carrying out the attack but broadcasting it "for all to see." He expressed his dismay at the incident, stating, "It's sickening. It makes you wonder what would make individuals treat somebody like that."

Title: Rep. Joe Heck Expresses Caution on U.S. Military Intervention in Syria

Article:

Rep. Joe Heck (R-NV), a veteran and physician who served in the Army Reserve with three deployments, including Iraq, has expressed caution regarding the potential U.S. military intervention in Syria. He believes that the U.S. should proceed with caution before entering another Middle Eastern conflict due to concerns about the administration's disjointed foreign policy approach, unintended consequences of military action, lack of clear objectives, and the potential threat to U.S. national security interests.

Heck stated that the atrocities committed by Syrian President Bashar al-Assad's regime are appalling and deserve international condemnation. However, he emphasized the need for a careful examination of the current situation and an understanding of the U.S.'s history in the region. He expressed concerns that a strike in Syria could further complicate the administration's foreign policy approach to the Middle East, as the U.S. has implemented three different strategies in Egypt, Libya, and Syria.

The congressman also raised concerns about the unintended consequences of a "limited" military strike, stating that such action could spark a wider regional conflict that would escalate U.S. involvement. He cited potential attacks against Syrian civilians, retaliation against Israel, and Syrian refugees flooding into neighboring countries as possible consequences.

Furthermore, Heck criticized the administration for failing to clearly articulate the goals, objectives, and potential costs of a military action in Syria. He argued that the U.S. should only use military force when it is willing to "sink the ship" if the warning shot is unheeded, and he expressed doubts about the readiness of the U.S. military and the American people to engage in such action.

Heck also questioned the case for a clear and imminent threat to U.S. national security interests, stating that while evil people will do evil things, the U.S. should not take on a situation that could produce the same result as the continued unrest in Iraq, Afghanistan, and Libya. He emphasized the need for a clear threat to U.S. national security interests and a clear strategy of what the U.S. aims to achieve before engaging in military action.

Title: GOP Faces Internal Disagreement on Immigration Policy Following State of the Union Address

Article:

Following President Obama's State of the Union address, the Republican Party is grappling with a contentious issue regarding immigration policy. The headline "Priebus struggles to explain GOP immigration messages" from Politico refers to Reince Priebus, the Republican Party chairman, who is tasked with clarifying the party's stance on immigration.

The disagreement stems from the responses to the president's speech. Iowa Senator Joni Ernst, in her 10-minute reply, did not address immigration, while Florida Representative Carlos Curbelo, in a Spanish-language version of the GOP response, urged Obama to collaborate with Republicans to create permanent solutions for the immigration system, secure borders, and modernize legal immigration.

In another response, Florida Republican Representative Curt Clawson, in both English and Spanish, called for embracing legal immigrants and those waiting in line legally to pursue their American Dream. This response was not the only point of contention, as Iowa Representative Steve King caused some awkwardness with a rude Twitter slam against Obama for inviting a "deportable" to sit in the House gallery as a guest of the First Lady. The individual, 20-year-old Ana Zamora, was brought to the United States illegally as an infant and benefited from Obama's 2012 executive order that extended legal status to thousands of similarly situated immigrants.

When asked about King's tone, Republican presidential hopeful Senator Marco Rubio responded carefully, stating, "We have to always remind ourselves that we're talking about human beings with hopes and dreams and families."

The clear element of the GOP message on immigration is the lack of a unified stance on the issue. The subject was barely mentioned in the president's address, but the Republican opposition still found themselves in an intramural tangle over it.

While a boisterous battle over policy and principle is a sign of fitness, not feebleness, for a large political party, the current rumble over immigration policy is heartening, especially when the argument focuses on ideals and values and reflects a thoughtful interest in crafting wise, not merely popular, public policy.

In a new monograph from Encounter Books, "Open Immigration: Yea & Nay," Mark Krikorian of the Center for Immigration Studies and Alex Nowrasteh of the Cato Institute provide a brief yet splendid example of how uplifting the debate over immigration can be. Each author lays out his case in prose that is clear, quick, factual, and respectful.

Krikorian, a well-known immigration restrictionist, argues that while mass immigration may have suited the United States in the 19th century, it is harmful in the 21st century. He poses security and economic threats, undermines assimilation, and retards productivity gains by flooding the market with cheap labor. Krikorian proposes slashing the annual influx from 1 million to about 400,000, still higher than any other nation in the world.

Nowrasteh, on the other hand, wants more legal immigration. He argues that America is not being swamped with newcomers—far from it. As a fraction of the population, immigrant inflows are small compared to most developed countries. Every policy generates stresses and strains, he notes, but there is no question that immigration enlarges the US economic pie. "A freer immigration system would not only be economically beneficial to the United States," Nowrasteh argues, "but it would also be consistent with our principles of limited government, free markets, and individual liberty."

These dueling essays are a pleasure to read. Each advocate strengthens his case, paradoxically, by granting that the other side raises serious challenges and attempting to meet them. To be sure, Krikorian and Nowrasteh are not politicians, ravenous for votes and approval ratings. But their debate exemplifies what is possible even on such an incendiary issue.

It's true: Republicans and others on the right, battling it out over immigration, seem awfully fractious and confused these days. For those who take their ideas seriously, that's often how the democratic process works.

Title: Trump's Election Marks a Shift Towards Saying "Merry Christmas" Again, According to Christian Leader

Article:
