A Christian leader, Dr. Richard Land, president of the Southern Evangelical Seminary, has stated that President-elect Donald Trump is fulfilling his promise to make it acceptable to say "Merry Christmas" again in the United States. In an interview with Charisma News, Dr. Land noted a shift in the country's tone since the 2016 election, with many people expressing relief at being able to say "Merry Christmas" without fear of criticism.

During his campaign, Trump often referenced Christmas, tapping into the perceived "War on Christmas" at the highest levels of government, including the White House, during the Obama administration. Now, Trump is following through on his promise. During his "thank you" tour, he frequently mentions "Merry Christmas" in his speeches and is often flanked by two Christmas trees on stage.

In contrast, President Barack Obama's family Christmas card during his eight-year presidency has omitted the phrase "Merry Christmas," instead using the politically correct "Happy Holidays." The Washington Times reported that the message on the Obama family card this season reads, "As our family reflects on our many happy years spent in the White House, we are grateful for the friends we've made, the joy we've shared, and the gifts of kindness we've received. We wish you and your loved ones a joyous holiday season and a wonderful new year."

Christians, who made up a significant portion of Trump's voter base, are reportedly pleased with the change. According to Dr. Land, Trump's presidency will foster a federal government more friendly to traditional Christian beliefs in the public square. He noted that Americans are enjoying their newfound rights to communicate their true beliefs about Christmas.

Dr. Land also stated that this shift is a win for cultural conservatism, which is intertwined with orthodox, traditional Christianity in America, over progressivism and multiculturalism.

Title: Democratic Senators File Unprecedented Brief Attacking Supreme Court Justices' Integrity

Article:

In an unprecedented move, five Democratic members of the United States Senate have filed a legal brief attacking the integrity of the five Republican-appointed justices of the Supreme Court. The brief, filed in the case New York State Rifle and Pistol Association v. the City of New York, alleges that the Court's decisions are politically motivated and threatens political action if the Court does not rule in a manner favorable to the senators' demands.

The brief, which is highly unusual in its tone and content, is not a traditional legal argument but rather a personal attack on the Court itself. The senators, Sheldon Whitehouse, Mazie Hirono, Richard Blumenthal, Richard Durbin, and Kirsten Gillibrand, have accused the Court of being influenced by corporate and Republican interests, and of disregarding "conservative" judicial principles like judicial restraint, originalism, stare decisis, and federalism.

The brief's ostensible purpose is to support the city and state of New York's claims that the case is moot and should be dismissed. However, the true intent of the brief is to cast aspersions on the integrity of the Court. The senators ask the Court to dismiss the case to "stem the growing public belief that its decisions are'motivated mainly by politics.'"

The brief cites the number of 5-4 decisions in which justices appointed by Republican presidents provided all five votes in the majority, and argues that these decisions were influenced by the partisan interests of the Republican Party. The brief does not acknowledge the competing judicial philosophies of the justices or the frequent voting together of Democratic- and Republican-appointed justices.

The senators' brief has been widely criticized as an attack on the independence of the Court and a threat to its integrity. The Supreme Court is not well, and the people know it, the brief suggests, implying that the Court needs to heal itself before the public demands it be "restructured in order to reduce the influence of politics."

It is unclear what political action the senators are threatening, and it is also unclear what the outcome of the case will be. However, the filing of the brief is a significant development in the ongoing debate over the role of politics in the Supreme Court and the integrity of its justices.

Title: Fact-Checking Industry in Overdrive as Trump and Clinton Face Off

Article:

The 2016 U.S. presidential election has put the fact-checking industry into high gear, with both major candidates, Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton, facing numerous allegations of dishonesty. The Associated Press assigned 12 reporters to fact-check a recent speech by Trump, a move that Washington Post media critic Erik Wemple described as "a whole platoon of journalistic talent that could have been doing other things."

Angie Drobnic Holan, editor in chief of the Pulitzer Prize-winning site PolitiFact.com, remains optimistic about the growth of media fact-checking. "Donald Trump is a candidate who has persistent problems with accuracy, and I'm heartened that there's widespread recognition that this is someone who needs to be fact-checked," she says.

Trump supporters, such as Jeffrey Lord, a regular on CNN defending Trump, call media fact-checkers "elitist" and argue that the candidates themselves do a better job of countering each other's assumptions. This "self-policing" concept is compared to having a basketball game with no referees.

The concept of political speech includes out-and-out lies, unintentional falsehoods, exaggerations, and spin. Sorting through the differences can be challenging, as it requires knowing what's inside the speaker's head. Making pie-in-the-sky promises is one thing, but statements of fact that prove false are another, and that's where fact-checkers are having a field day.

PolitiFact has judged 174 statements by Trump so far, finding only 16 to be either true or mostly true. Seventy have been judged false, and another 34 rated "Pants on Fire," referring to claims that are "not only inaccurate but also ridiculous," according to Ms. Holan. With Clinton, PolitiFact has judged 218 statements and rated 112 true or mostly true, 24 false, and three "Pants on Fire."

The question is whether the assessments of PolitiFact and other fact-checkers actually penetrate public consciousness. Holan says that her site's traffic is better than ever, and media organizations are doing fact-checking in part because it's popular with readers. However, Professor Kathleen Hall Jamieson, director of the University of Pennsylvania's Annenberg Public Policy Center, is less sanguine. "Fact-checking has never been more important, more complicated, and less likely to reach its target audience with the desired corrected information," Jamieson says.

Part of the problem is the ever-accelerating news cycle, and another issue is low public opinion of the media. Only 6 percent of Americans have a "great deal of confidence" in the press, according to a survey released in April by the Media Insight Project. Holan of PolitiFact says that when readers accuse her site of partisan bias against Trump, she counters with data that show Republicans who do well on the PolitiFact "Truth-o-Meter," such as Jeb Bush. However, former Governor Bush didn't do very well as a presidential candidate, and voters don't necessarily favor a candidate because he or she is more factual. Moreover, for a slice of the electorate, this cycle reflects a break from politics as usual—and that includes an embrace of candidates who speak to voters without the filter of polls, focus groups, and scripted statements.

Title: Tariffs and Soybeans: Economic and Political Consequences for the GOP

Article:

Tariffs, as a result of the ongoing trade war with China, have both economic and political implications, particularly for the Republican Party in the upcoming midterm elections. The soybean, being the world's top-produced crop in the U.S. and the largest consumer being China, is at the heart of this issue. Last year, China purchased over $14 billion of American-grown soybeans, accounting for 61 percent of total U.S. soybean exports and more than 30 percent of overall U.S. soybean production.

In response to President Donald Trump's decision to impose tariffs on over 1,300 Chinese-made goods last month, China has threatened a 25 percent tariff on soybeans and other American agricultural products. This potential tariff could impact key congressional races across the Midwest, where states like Iowa, Minnesota, Missouri, and North Dakota are significant soybean producers.

The New York Times has dispatched a reporter to Cass County, North Dakota, the nation's top soybean-producing county, to gauge farmers' opinions about Trump's trade skirmishes with China. Robert Runck, a fourth-generation farmer, told the paper that if Trump "doesn't understand what he's doing to the nation by doing what he's doing, he's going to be a one-term president, plain and simple." Runck also stated that tariffs would cost Republican congressman Kevin Cramer, who currently represents North Dakota, some votes. Cramer is running against Sen. Heidi Heitkamp (D–N.D.) in November.

An analysis from the Brookings Institution suggests that Trump's tariffs will do the most damage to the economies of red states, including Iowa, Missouri, Ohio, and Pennsylvania. The potential Chinese tariffs on American agricultural products are expected to cause much of the pain in the Midwest.

Trump's tariffs are part of his campaign promise to revive American steel plants. However, the protectionist policies could harm a much larger group within the president's political coalition, as for every steel-producing job in the country, there are about 46 steel-consuming jobs, many of which are now on shakier ground due to the higher costs created by tariffs.

Republican strategist Karl Rove told the Times that Trump "has little to no understanding of the farm coalition." Trump, a New Yorker who ran hotels and casinos before becoming a TV star, does not have a background that suggests a detailed understanding of the concerns of a North Dakota farmer or an Ohio machine shop worker.

Trump's unwillingness to court rural voters in a traditional manner was one of the things that set him apart during the campaign. However, it remains to be seen whether voters will continue to support a president whose policies make their jobs more difficult or their lifestyle more costly.

Trump won the American heartland in part by promising to end a regulatory war on agricultural and industrial jobs, and he has been following through on that promise. However, he now risks replacing one set of oppressive economic policies with another, putting farmers and manufacturers on the front lines of a trade war. The fact that he's not directly responsible for Chinese tariffs on soybeans might not save Trump, or the rest of his party, from the ire of those who suffer the consequences of these myopic trade policies.

It's a political cliché that people vote with their wallets. This may hold true even for a president who shattered so many other traditional notions of how to get elected.

Title: Clinton Tries to Regroup and Appeal to Democratic Party Establishment as Primary Race Intensifies

Article:

Hillary Clinton, the former U.S. Secretary of State and current Democratic presidential candidate, has been facing scrutiny over her private email account during her tenure as Secretary of State. This, coupled with the rising poll numbers of her primary rival, Bernie Sanders, and the potential entry of Vice President Joe Biden into the race, has led to a shift in Clinton's strategy.

In an effort to regain control of the narrative and appeal to the Democratic Party establishment, Clinton addressed the Democratic National Committee (DNC) in Minneapolis on Friday. She emphasized her lifelong commitment to fighting for families and underdogs and her determination to continue her campaign.

Clinton stated, "I have been fighting for families and underdogs my entire life, and I'm not going to stop now. In fact, I'm just getting warmed up." She also pledged not to take any primary voter or caucusgoer for granted.

However, party leaders are growing concerned that Clinton has not effectively addressed the email controversy, which has created uncertainty and given other candidates an opportunity. Sanders, an independent senator from Vermont, saw a boost in his poll numbers over the weekend, trailing Clinton by only 7 points in an Iowa poll.

Sanders, in a veiled critique of Clinton, argued that the traditional approach to politics is no longer effective in energizing Democratic voters. He attributed the party's losses in the 2014 midterm elections to low voter turnout, particularly among the liberal base.

"We lost because voter turnout was abysmally, embarrassingly low, and millions of working people, young people, and people of color gave up on politics as usual and they stayed home," Sanders said. He further emphasized that the same old approach will not work in generating enthusiasm among voters.

Former Maryland Governor Martin O'Malley also criticized the Democratic establishment, repeating his criticism of the debate schedule and describing it as a "rigged process" and "a cynical move to delay and limit our own party debates."

Vice President Biden did not attend the meeting in Minneapolis, but he has been considering entering the race and has been discussing his decision with his family. In a conference call last week, Biden told DNC members that if he runs, he wants to give the campaign his whole heart and soul.

Ahead of her speech, Clinton released a series of memos highlighting her organizational strength in the four early voting states. She campaigned in Iowa last week with Tom Vilsack, the agriculture secretary and former Iowa governor. Vilsack was asked about the potential awkwardness of endorsing Clinton while Biden is considering a run. He responded, "I love Joe Biden—just like we all do. He's a wonderful man. But campaigns require difficult choices, and I and my wife are supporting Clinton."

Some DNC members have already endorsed Clinton, and it may be too late for Biden in their eyes. Florida committeeman Jon M. Ausman told Politico in Minneapolis, "He doesn't reach out to me for seven f*cking years and then he wants me to help him out? I don't think so. I don't really give a f*ck. I don't care if he gets into the race or not."

By releasing early endorsements, Clinton is attempting to demonstrate her strength and deter a potential Biden entry into the race. According to Mo Elleithee, executive director of Georgetown University's Institute of Politics and Public Service, Elleithee is also the immediate past DNC communications director and worked for Clinton's 2008 campaign, Biden will not have a significant presence in the race if Clinton has secured support from key party members.

"[Biden] will not have oxygen in the room if she has locked people down," Elleithee said. "I think he is probably looking at the field and saying, 'OK, at this late date in the process, can I build the organization? Can I raise the money? And can my message break through?'"

Clinton, when asked about Biden, expressed sympathy for his difficult decision and stated that she wants to give him the space and time to make it. She also acknowledged that she learned some lessons from her primary loss to President Obama in 2008, stating, "I got a lot of votes, but I did not—I did not get enough delegates. And so, I think it's understandable that my focus is going to be on delegates as well as votes this time."

Title: Germanwings Flight 9525: Pilot Locked Out of Cockpit Before Crash, According to New York Times Report

Article:

Investigators probing the crash of Germanwings Flight 9525 have made a startling discovery in an audio recording, according to a report by The New York Times. The report suggests that one of the plane's pilots was locked out of the cockpit before the crash.

A senior military official involved in the investigation told The New York Times that audio from the cockpit voice recorder, one of the plane's black boxes, indicates that one of the pilots was trying to gain entry to the cockpit.

"You can hear he is trying to smash the door down," the official said, describing the audio. "We don't know yet the reason why one of the guys went out," the official added. "But what is sure is that at the very end of the flight, the other pilot is alone and does not open the door."

Lufthansa, the parent company of Germanwings, said it was looking into the report. "We have no information from the bodies investigating the incident that would corroborate the report in The New York Times," spokesman Boris Ogursky said. "We will not participate in speculation, but we will follow up on the matter."

The Times' report is a "terribly shocking revelation," CNN aviation analyst Peter Goelz said. But he and other experts cautioned that it's still unclear what could have been going on inside the cockpit. Possibilities range from a medical emergency to something more nefarious, like a suicide mission.

Officials previously said that they hadn't ruled out terrorism, but it seems unlikely. French authorities revealed earlier Wednesday that they'd been able to access audio from the recorder, even though its external casing was damaged. But they disclosed few details about what the recording actually contained, saying only that there was one audio channel with voices on it that went all the way up to the time of the crash.

Investigators are still trying to piece together what caused the crash. The plane's second black box, the flight data recorder, has not been found yet, but Lufthansa CEO Carsten Spohr said Wednesday that there's a high probability it will be. The mountainous terrain where the Germanwings jet went down is difficult to access.

Teams have begun the daunting task of identifying the victims' bodies, but caution that it could take time to complete. The doomed flight was traveling from Barcelona, Spain, to Dusseldorf, Germany, when it crashed Tuesday in the French Alps.

Title: U.S., Russia Discuss Chemical Weapons in Syria as Peace Talks Loom

Article:

U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry and Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov discussed the potential for a new peace conference in Geneva regarding the Syrian civil war on Friday. The talks revolve around the Syrian government's commitment to relinquish its chemical weapons arsenal.

The discussions took place as United Nations-Arab League envoy Lakhdar Brahimi met with Kerry and Lavrov, while American and Russian chemical weapons experts negotiated technical details crucial to a deal on chemical weapons in a nearby hotel. The looming threat of a limited U.S. military strike against President Bashar Assad's regime hangs over the negotiations.

Brahimi acknowledged the high stakes, stating that the chemical weapons negotiation is significant in itself but also essential for the success of the planned Geneva peace conference. More than 100,000 people have been killed in two years of civil war. On Friday, international group Human Rights Watch accused the Syrian government and militias fighting on its side of carrying out summary executions that killed at least 248 people in two towns in May.

Kerry, flanked by Lavrov and Brahimi, told reporters after an hour-long meeting that the prospects for a second peace conference in Geneva depend on the outcome of the chemical weapons talks, which have been "constructive" so far. Kerry stated that President Barack Obama is committed to a negotiated solution for Syria, and the U.S. is working hard to find common ground to make that happen.

Kerry, Lavrov, and Brahimi agreed to meet around Sept. 28 on the sidelines of the annual U.N. General Assembly high-level meetings in New York. However, the future of peace negotiations depends on the outcome of the weapons talks.

Brahimi also met privately with Kerry on Thursday to explore ways to resume international negotiations last held in Geneva in June 2012, aimed at ending the Syrian civil war.

Lavrov stated that Russia has supported the peace process from the start of the Syrian conflict and discussed with Kerry and Brahimi the Geneva communique from the 2012 meeting on Syria and ways of preparing for a second conference.

When the chemical weapons talks began on Thursday, Kerry rejected a Syrian pledge to begin a "standard process" by turning over information rather than weapons, stating that this was not acceptable.

Syrian National Coalition senior member Salem Al Meslet expressed disappointment that the Kerry and Lavrov meeting on chemical weapons wasn't about punishing Assad. He stated, "They are leaving the murderer and concentrating on the weapons he was using. It is like stabbing somebody with a knife then they take the knife away and he is free."

The talks are the latest in a rapidly moving series of events following the Aug. 21 gas attack on suburbs in Damascus. The U.S. blames Assad for the use of chemical weapons, while Assad denies his government was involved and instead points to the rebels fighting a 2-year-old civil war against it.

President Obama began trying to win support at home and abroad for a punitive military strike on Assad's forces, but put that effort on hold when the Syrian government expressed willingness to turn over weapons to international control. Obama dispatched Kerry to Geneva to hammer out the details of the proposal even as he kept alive the possibility of U.S. military action.

As of Friday, the United Nations is still reviewing Syria's documents submitted to join the international treaty banning chemical weapons to determine if they provide enough information. If accepted as complete, Syria would become a party to the Chemical Weapons Convention 30 days later. Syria's ambassador to the United Nations stated that, as of Thursday when it submitted the documents, his country had become a full member of the treaty, which requires destruction of all chemical weapons.

Assad, in an interview with Russia's Rossiya-24 TV, said his government would start submitting data on its chemical weapons stockpile a month after signing the convention. He also stated that the Russian proposal for securing the weapons could work only if the U.S. halted threats of military action.

At a meeting in Kyrgyzstan on Friday, Russian President Vladimir Putin stated, "I would like to voice hope that this will mark a serious step toward the settlement of the Syrian crisis."

Title: Trump and Sanders Debate Proposal: A Temporary Pause in Campaign Activities

Article:

A potential debate between former President Donald Trump and Senator Bernie Sanders has caused a flurry of speculation, with both candidates expressing interest in a charity debate, only to later clarify that the proposal was made in jest.

During a press conference in Bismarck, North Dakota, on Thursday, Trump reiterated his willingness to debate Sanders for charity, stating, "I'd love to debate Bernie – he's a dream. The problem with debating Bernie is he's going to lose [the Democratic race]... but I'd debate him anyway. We've already had a couple of calls from the networks, so we'll see."

Trump's initial expression of interest in debating Sanders during an appearance on ABC's Jimmy Kimmel Live on Wednesday had been dismissed by his campaign as a joke earlier in the day. Trump's campaign later clarified that the Republican was not serious about the prospect of a debate.

Senator Sanders, who is currently trailing Hillary Clinton in the delegate race to secure the Democratic nomination, responded to Trump's initial proposal with a tweet, stating, "Game on. I look forward to debating Donald Trump in California before the June 7 primary."

Sanders' campaign confirmed they were serious about the opportunity if Trump was, but an aide to Trump clarified on Thursday that the former reality TV star was joking and had no intention to actually debate Sanders.

A debate between candidates from both parties before the conclusion of the nominating process would have been highly unusual and potentially complicated for Clinton, who turned down an invitation from Fox News to debate Sanders earlier this week, citing the need to focus on the looming general election campaign.

A debate during the remainder of the primary season would have been more beneficial to Sanders, offering him another public platform to make his case in what has been a grueling contest against Clinton. The senator has often referred to poll numbers on the stump that show him faring better than Clinton in a hypothetical match-up against Trump, although Clinton has countered that she has spent more than two decades in the public eye, whereas Sanders has yet to be vetted at the national level.

Trump, although evidently unwilling to debate the senator, has made overtures toward Sanders' supporters by echoing their complaints that the establishment is working in Clinton's favor. "The system is rigged against him," Trump told Kimmel, referring to Sanders. "I think it's very unfair."

Sanders and Clinton last faced off on the debate stage on March 9 in Miami. Since then, Clinton has moved significantly closer to securing the nomination but has still lost a series of contests to Sanders along the way.

Sanders has repeatedly charged that the Democratic National Committee, which remains officially neutral in the primary, is aiding Clinton by limiting debates and scheduling them on weekends when there would be less of an audience. The senator's disdain for party leaders escalated last week, when Sanders said he would not reappoint Debbie Wasserman Schultz as chair of the DNC if elected president and endorsed her primary opponent as she seeks re-election to Congress in south Florida.

Simon Rosenberg, a Democratic strategist and founder of the center-left think tank New Democrat Network, wrote in a column this week that the California debate should proceed as initially planned between Clinton and Sanders. "For the DNC to walk away from the debate now, given that Sanders has signaled his desire to proceed, will only confirm the worst suspicions of Sanders partisans," Rosenberg wrote.

Title: The New York Times Endorses Elizabeth Warren and Amy Klobuchar for Democratic Presidential Nomination

The New York Times editorial board has endorsed Senators Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.) and Amy Klobuchar (D-Minn.) for the Democratic nomination for president, marking a break in convention as the first primary contests in Iowa and New Hampshire are set to take place in two weeks.

In the endorsement, the Times stated, "Choosing who should face off against [President] Trump also means acknowledging that Americans are being confronted with three models for how to govern this country, not two." The editorial board further explained, "That’s why we’re endorsing the most effective advocates for each approach. They are Elizabeth Warren and Amy Klobuchar."

The endorsement comes as Warren's campaign faces a new challenge from Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.), whose campaign has recently secured a number of high-profile endorsements from the progressive wing of the Democratic Party, including Reps. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (D-N.Y.) and Pramila Jayapal (D-Wash.).

Warren and Sanders clashed onstage at last week's CNN debate in Des Moines over whether Sanders had told Warren that a woman could not be elected president in the U.S. In their endorsement, the Times wrote that Warren could serve as a vehicle for progressives who worry that Sanders' message is too divisive.

The Times' editors wrote of Klobuchar that the Minnesota senator should take control of the centrist lane currently headed by former Vice President Joe Biden, whom the Times advised should "pass the torch to a new generation of political leaders." Klobuchar, they added, "is the very definition of Midwestern charisma, grit, and sticktoitiveness. Her lengthy tenure in the Senate and bipartisan credentials would make her a deal maker (a real one) and uniter for the wings of the party—and perhaps the nation."

The Times previously endorsed former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, the eventual winner of the Democratic nomination in 2016, before going on to endorse her in the general election as well. The Times ended its endorsement Sunday night with a call for voters to rally behind whichever woman they thought best represented their values: "Ms. Klobuchar and Ms. Warren right now are the Democrats best equipped to lead that debate. May the best woman win."

Title: Wisconsin Allowed to Enforce Voter Identification Law in November Elections, According to Federal Appeals Court

Article:

A three-judge panel of the 7th Circuit U.S. Court of Appeals has unanimously stayed a district court judge's order blocking the enforcement of a new voter identification law in Wisconsin or any similar measure imposing new voter identification requirements. The State of Wisconsin may, if it wishes and if it is appropriate under state law, enforce the photo ID requirement in this November's elections.

The appeals court's order, released Friday afternoon, states, "Having read the briefs and heard oral argument, this court now stays the injunction issued by the district court. The State of Wisconsin may, if it wishes (and if it is appropriate under rules of state law), enforce the photo ID requirement in this November’s elections."

The court added that the district court held the state law invalid and enjoined its implementation, even though it is materially identical to Indiana’s photo ID statute, which the Supreme Court held valid in Crawford v. Marion County Election Board in 2008.

The state had asked the appeals court to lift the district judge's order, arguing that it was overbroad. Civil rights groups challenging the measure could ask for relief from the full bench of the 7th Circuit or from the U.S. Supreme Court.

The appeals court noted that a Wisconsin Supreme Court ruling in July narrowed the new law in ways that made it less likely to have a negative impact on minorities. "This reduces the likelihood of irreparable injury, and it also changes the balance of equities and thus the propriety of federal injunctive relief," the 7th Circuit wrote.

The move is a rebuff to the Obama Administration, which filed an amicus brief in July urging the appeals court to uphold the lower court's ruling. Technically, the appeals court panel did not decide the case Friday, but simply stayed the lower court's order pending a full resolution of the appeal. The appeal was heard by Judges Frank Easterbrook, Diane Sykes, and John Tinder. Easterbrook was appointed by President Ronald Reagan, while Sykes and Tinder were appointed by President George W. Bush.

Title: Trump Announces General H.R. McMaster as National Security Advisor, John R. Bolton to Find New Role

Article:

President Donald Trump has announced that General H.R. McMaster will remain as the National Security Council's chief of staff, following the resignation of Michael Flynn a week ago. McMaster, a retired lieutenant general, was one of four candidates interviewed by Trump on Sunday for the permanent position. The status of K.T. McFarland, the top deputy national security adviser, remains unclear.

In a statement, McMaster expressed gratitude to Trump for the opportunity and expressed his intention to contribute to the national security team. "I'm grateful to you for that opportunity," he told the president, "and I look forward to joining the national security team and doing everything that I can to advance and protect the interests of the American people."

John R. Bolton, a former ambassador to the United Nations under President George W. Bush, was another finalist for the position. Bolton, an outspoken conservative, was previously considered for a high-level post in Trump's administration. Trump praised Bolton on Monday, stating that they had productive meetings and that Bolton had many ideas he agreed with. "We had some really good meetings with him. Knows a lot," the president said. "He had a good number of ideas that I must tell you I agree very much with. So we’ll be talking with John Bolton in a different capacity."

General McMaster has served as the director of the Army Capabilities Integration Center at Fort Eustis in Virginia since 2014. A West Point graduate with a doctorate in military history from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, he commanded a unit that clashed with Iraq's Republican Guard in one of the biggest tank battles of the Persian Gulf war in 1991, earning him the Silver Star.

McMaster came to prominence with his 1997 book, "Dereliction of Duty," which critiqued the Joint Chiefs for not standing up to President Lyndon B. Johnson during the Vietnam War. He cemented his reputation in 2005 during the second Iraq war when he led the Third Armored Cavalry Regiment in regaining control of Tal Afar. The operation was cited as a textbook example in a manual on counterinsurgency doctrine prepared by General Petraeus. Another commander who had a role in drafting that manual was General Mattis, then a Marine general. General Petraeus took a similar approach when he assumed command in Iraq in 2007 with a surge of troops authorized by President George W. Bush.

Title: Federal Court Upholds DACA, Citing Presidential "Racial Animus" as Grounds for Invalidation

Article:

The Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals has upheld the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) policy, ruling that President Donald Trump's administration cannot rescind the program through executive action. The decision, which has been met with controversy, is based on the court's interpretation of the Trump administration's process and reasons for abolishing the policy, as well as allegations of "racial animus."

The court's decision is not a straightforward affirmation of DACA's legality, but rather a complex ruling that criticizes the Trump administration's approach to rescinding the policy. The court found that the administration's reasons for abolishing DACA were defective, as the policy was not issued pursuant to the Administrative Procedures Act, and the litigation risk from a challenge to DACA was not considered a grounds for the action.

In a concurring opinion, Judge John Owens agrees that the Trump administration is barred from rescinding DACA, not for the technical reasons outlined in the majority opinion, but because of alleged "racial animus." In a footnote, the other two judges on the panel write that they agree with Judge Owens' reasoning. This suggests that, according to the judges, Trump's personal biases disqualify him from taking actions that any other president might be permitted to take.

This is not the first time federal judges have used similar reasoning to challenge Trump's policies. In the case of the travel bans on immigration from certain countries, judges found that Trump could not be permitted to implement such bans because they determined that he was biased against certain groups. The U.S. Supreme Court, however, put an end to such psychoanalysis from the bench and let most of the travel ban go into effect.

Under the U.S. Constitution, the president has the authority to exercise the same powers as any other president, regardless of personal opinions about the president's character and behavior. The power of the president is circumscribed by the constitution and federal law, not the opinion of judges about the present occupant. The American people elected Donald Trump president, and he is entitled to exercise the same authority as any other president within the bounds of the constitutional order.

Title: Clinton's Position on Iran's Nuclear Ambitions Remains Consistent

Article:

In a recent conversation, former U.S. Secretary of State Hillary Clinton stated that her stance on Iran's nuclear ambitions has remained consistent, advocating for little to no enrichment for Iran. Clinton, who served as the U.S.'s chief negotiator on the issue during the Obama administration, emphasized that there is no inherent right to enrich uranium, a position she has maintained throughout her political career.

When asked about the perceived shift in her position compared to the current administration's negotiators, Clinton clarified that she does not speak for the current administration but emphasized the importance of sending a clear signal that a deal cannot be reached without stringent restrictions on Iran. She suggested that the preference would be no enrichment, with the potential fallback position being such limited enrichment that Iran would be unable to break out of the agreed-upon limitations.

Clinton acknowledged that there is a debate within Iran about the extent to which they should compromise in order to secure relief from sanctions. She noted that the P5+1 (the five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council, plus Germany) still maintains a unified position, which includes intensive inspections, clear limits on Iran's nuclear facilities, and a strict approach to enrichment.

When asked about the Iranians' unwillingness to pull back and freeze their nuclear program, Clinton expressed uncertainty, suggesting that there may be a political debate within Iran about the potential benefits of a strict nuclear regime in exchange for sanctions relief. She pointed out that Iran is dealing with various domestic and regional challenges, including Syria, Iraq, Lebanon, and potentially Hamas.

Clinton's comments provide insight into her continued opposition to Iran's nuclear ambitions and her belief in the importance of maintaining a firm stance in negotiations with Iran. However, the former Secretary of State also acknowledged the complexity of the situation and the potential for political maneuvering within Iran.

Title: Biden Defends Past Work with Segregationist Senators Amidst Criticism in Democratic Presidential Race

Article:

Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden has refused to apologize for reminiscing on his work with two late senators who were known for their support of racial segregation. The former U.S. vice-president, who is currently leading opinion polls, has faced criticism for his comments regarding his working relationship with Mississippi's James Eastland and Georgia's Herman Talmadge, whom he served alongside in the Senate in the 1970s.

At a fundraiser in New York City, Biden recalled that Talmadge had called him "son" but never "boy," a term racist whites used to address black men during that time. He also stated, "At least there was some civility; we got things done."

Several of Biden's Democratic rivals, including Senator Cory Booker and California Senator Kamala Harris, have criticized his remarks. Harris, who is black, stated that Biden did not seem to understand "the dark history of our country." Booker, also black, called it "so insulting" that Biden had asked him to apologize.

However, Biden defended himself on Wednesday night, telling reporters, "There's not a racist bone in my body; I've been involved in civil rights my whole career." He added, "We, in fact, detested what they stood for in terms of segregation and all the rest."

Anita Dunn, a Biden advisor, told MSNBC that the story was one Biden had told many times. She explained, "The point of the story is that you have to be able to work with people, even if they hold positions repugnant to you, in order to make some progress."

Not all Democratic lawmakers have criticized Biden. House of Representatives majority whip Jim Clyburn, who is African-American, defended Biden, stating, "You do not have to agree with people to work with them." Speaker of the House of Representatives Nancy Pelosi also supported Biden, saying his comments were not what the election was about.

The Democratic candidates will travel to South Carolina this weekend to court support from black voters. Biden will be attending the traditional fish fry picnic, which is hosted by Clyburn. Biden has capitalized on his time as deputy to President Barack Obama, the first-ever black U.S. president, who is still revered among Democrats. Biden launched his campaign in April by condemning President Donald Trump's response to a racist march in Charlottesville, Virginia, in 2017.

Title: U.S. Food Supply Chain Remains Stable Despite Pandemic, but Labor Challenges Persist

Article:

The coronavirus pandemic has caused widespread disruptions to various industries, and the food supply chain is no exception. In the early stages of the pandemic, Americans rushed to stock up on food, leading to temporary shortages in some grocery stores. However, a shortage of food supplies in the U.S. is unlikely in the foreseeable future, as the country still produces more than enough food to meet its needs.

The pandemic, however, has exposed vulnerabilities in the food supply chain, particularly in the labor-intensive sectors that rely on underpaid, overexploited workers. "The worry in the food supply chain was always about activities that were labor-intensive, and where there weren't proper procedures to protect the people doing the work: produce workers, warehouse employees, transport workers, and store employees," said Ananth Iyer, a professor of operations management at Purdue University.

In recent weeks, grocery store workers and farm laborers have started contracting and dying from Covid-19 in increasing numbers. In some places, the disease is already pushing people to a breaking point. This week, a massive meat-processing plant in Minnesota became the latest to shut down after a Covid-19 outbreak among workers. Many employers have continued pressing employees to work in unsafe and exploitative conditions, raising the possibility of more illnesses and shutdowns to come.

The economic impact of the pandemic is likely to land hard on these workers when the pandemic ends. Shifting consumption patterns mean that industries maniacally focused on efficiency will likely slash employment levels. Among the victims could also be food service workers—presently frozen out of jobs amid the shutdown—who could return to an economy where far fewer people are willing to venture outside to eat.

"It's estimated that in the United States, 50 to 55 percent of food consumption normally takes place outside the home, at restaurants, fast food outlets, and entertainment venues," added Iyer. "All of a sudden, that came to a complete halt, and now the question is whether we will even go back to that. If we don't, there will be serious adjustments in the restaurant industry affecting the millions of people who work there."

The agricultural industry looks ready to place the burden onto its most exploited workers by cutting the wages of migrant farm laborers. In this, they have a willing ally in the White House. In the name of supporting farmers, the Trump administration is proposing a new "wage relief" program to allow agricultural firms to cut migrant workers' salaries to save money during the pandemic. The proposal has gone largely under the radar while the country reels from news of Covid-19 deaths and job losses. But it may have serious consequences for what American society looks like when people eventually emerge from quarantine.

"At the moment, the agriculture industry recognizes that the social turmoil caused by the pandemic has created something like a fog of war, in which they can press for lots of things that society normally would have no tolerance for," said Ricardo Salvador, director of the food and environment Program at the Union of Concerned Scientists. "It's a basic principle of economics that if you successfully cut wages at the lowest rung of the economy, it is going to have a ripple effect up through the blue-collar range. To put it another way, if you depress the wages for the poorest people, you depress wages for everyone."

The pandemic is also exposing the massive inefficiency and waste that takes place in a highly centralized industrial food system. Major cities in the U.S. have seen staggering queues in front of food banks, while at the same time, farmers are destroying excess produce, meat, and dairy in other parts of the country. The shock of the pandemic has suddenly made visible the massive inefficiency and waste that takes place in a highly centralized industrial food system. At the same time, some experts say that it is also showing what does work: local networks of farms that are biodiverse and don't run the risk of crashing all at once when something goes wrong.

"We're seeing horror stories of farmers throwing milk away and food being destroyed in fields," said Raj Patel, a research professor at the University of Texas and author of "Stuffed and Starved: The Hidden Battle for the World Food System." "But the reality is that these stories are all coming out of industrial supply chains. Farmers who are part of local networks are not throwing away food; in fact, they are rushing to keep up with demand."

Title: Hillary Clinton's Shift in Stances: A Look at Her Evolution in Key Policy Areas

Article:

Hillary Clinton, who launched her 2020 Democratic presidential campaign on Tuesday, has taken significant policy shifts compared to her 2008 run, as she aims to appeal to the liberal base that has come to dominate the Democratic nomination process.

In 2008, Clinton was against same-sex marriage, a supporter of the Second Amendment, backed her Iraq War vote, and opposed states issuing driver's licenses to illegal immigrants. In contrast, she now supports same-sex couples, advocates for tighter federal gun control measures, has admitted her Iraq War vote was a "mistake," and is an advocate for illegal immigration.

Clinton's stance on free trade has also evolved, having been a supporter, opponent, and then a supporter again, and now opposes the Pacific trade deal she championed as the country's top diplomat. David Axelrod, a Democratic strategist who advised President Obama's bids for the White House, commented on CNN, "This is a classic political decision that you can flip-flop if you flop over to the popular side of an issue."

Senator Bernie Sanders, the Vermont independent challenging Clinton for the Democratic presidential nomination, said he will highlight these policy shifts and trade will be a key example. Sanders opposed trade deals with Mexico, Canada, Central America, and China.

Clinton has been more consistent, though late compared to other Democrats, in her shift on same-sex marriage. In the 2008 campaign, she openly opposed it, offering civil unions as an acceptable compromise of legal protection for same-sex couples. Only after leaving her position as secretary of state, and as the Supreme Court was considering overturning the Defense of Marriage Act, did Clinton change her stance.

In the 2008 campaign, Clinton was steadfast in defending her Iraq War vote, a vote that President Obama hammered her on and contrasted himself to. It wasn't until her 2014 book "Hard Choices" that Clinton says she "got it wrong" on Iraq. This year on the campaign trail, she's gone further, saying her vote was "a mistake."

On guns, Clinton's moves have been more a matter of what she's emphasizing. In 2008, she criticized Obama's statement that rural Pennsylvanians "cling to guns or religion" and portrayed herself as an adherent of the gun culture. Last week, however, in the wake of another mass shooting, Clinton vowed to go further than Obama in taking executive action to limit gun ownership.

On immigration, Clinton is also revising her previous stance. In the 2008 debate, Clinton offered a confusing answer on whether she supported states issuing licenses to illegal immigrants. After the debate, and after then-New York Governor Eliot Spitzer withdrew the proposal because of its unpopularity, Clinton made a statement that she would not support driver's licenses for undocumented people and would press for comprehensive immigration reform. However, as the power of Hispanic voters increases, Clinton has tailored her stance yet again, now supporting states granting driver's licenses to illegal immigrants, according to her campaign.

Title: Progressive and Moderate Democrats Agree on More Than They Disagree, According to Dionne

Article:

In a recent analysis, Dionne, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution and columnist for The Washington Post, suggests that the policy debates in American politics have shifted due to the radicalization of the Republican Party. The Republican Party, according to Dionne, opposes most government actions aimed at solving problems and focuses on cutting taxes for the wealthy and reducing corporate oversight.

As a result, the substantive part of many policy debates now takes place within the Democratic Party, leading to natural tensions between progressives and moderate Democrats. Dionne argues that both sides would be more effective if they were open to learning from each other, rather than engaging in "an unseemly moralism that feeds political superiority complexes."

Progressives argue that over the past half-century, Democratic moderates have allowed conservatives to dictate the terms of political conversation on various issues, including economic growth, criminal justice, family values, and more. Dionne adds that moderates have also focused on designing technocratically elegant policies, rather than creating easily understandable, popular programs.

Moderates, on the other hand, argue that every great progressive victory in American history, such as abolition, women's suffrage, the income tax, labor rights, Social Security, civil rights, Medicare, marriage equality, and more, has required compromise in the service of persuading allies who disagree with progressives on other issues.

Dionne emphasizes that it is not enough for one side to state their case purely and wait for a silent majority to emerge. In the long run, each side is likely to accomplish more if they recognize that the other isn't the enemy. However, in the short run, there is an inescapable dilemma: the party can nominate only one person.

Before the party's nomination, both sides should pause to reflect on the strengths of the other side, according to Dionne. For progressives, this means recognizing that moderate congressional candidates performed better in swing districts in 2018. It also means quietly celebrating the progressivism of candidates like Pete Buttigieg's agenda.

Title: Former President George H.W. Bush to Lie in State at U.S. Capitol, Buried in Texas

Article:

In accordance with presidential tradition, a detailed schedule for the funeral and memorial services of former President George H.W. Bush has been released. The ceremonies will take place in Houston, Washington D.C., Spring, Texas, and College Station, Texas. Bush passed away on Friday at the age of 94.

In honor of the 41st president, President Trump has declared Wednesday a national day of mourning, and has issued an executive order to close federal offices. Trump also announced that one of the Boeing 747s serving as Air Force One will be sent to Houston to transport Bush's casket to Washington D.C.

On Monday, members of both the House and Senate will attend an arrival ceremony at the U.S. Capitol at 4:45 p.m. ET. Bush will lie in state in the rotunda until Wednesday morning.

Family and friends will then gather at the National Cathedral in Washington for an 11 a.m. funeral service on Wednesday.

Bush will be taken to his home of Houston, where he will lie in repose at St. Martin's Episcopal Church in Houston from 7:45 p.m. ET Wednesday until 7 a.m. ET Thursday. The church will also hold a second memorial service for the former president at 11 a.m. ET Thursday.

On Thursday afternoon, a motorcade will take Bush's body to Union Pacific Railroad Westfield Auto Facility. From there, a funeral train will transport Bush to Texas A&M University in College Station, Texas, the site of the George H.W. Bush Presidential Library and Museum, where he will be laid to rest.

Bush will be buried next to his wife and former first lady Barbara Bush, who died in April, and his daughter Pauline Robinson "Robin" Bush, who died in 1953 at the age of 3.

More details about Bush's funeral arrangements are available on a tribute website for the former president. For those who wish to pay their respects, the Bush family has requested that donations be made to the Bush School of Government and Public Service at Texas A&M University to "help ensure that President Bush's legacy of public service with integrity is perpetuated."

Title: Wages Remain Stagnant for Workers Despite Auto Industry Recovery

Article:

The average hourly wage for workers in the United States has barely increased since President Barack Obama took office in 2008, despite the recovery of the General Motors (GM) and Chrysler industries and a decrease in unemployment rates. According to data from the U.S. Department of Labor, the average hourly wage has risen by just 42 cents over the past four years to $23.41, after adjusting for inflation.

Economists attribute this stagnation in wages to high unemployment levels, which allow companies to hire workers at lower wages. Sherry Cooper, chief economist and executive vice president at the BMO Financial Group, stated, "It's unprecedented how modest the wage gains have been over this recovery. It's painful for consumers and detrimental for labor."

The issue of stagnant wages has not gone unnoticed, with Mitt Romney's campaign using the statistic to criticize Obama's statement last week that the "private sector is doing fine." A campaign email sent out on Saturday read, "Maybe he can ask families whose household income dropped $4,300 if they're 'doing fine.'"

The problem is particularly pronounced in the auto industry, which Obama often cites as a success story on the campaign trail. Despite federal intervention and an increase in car sales, wages for workers building vehicles and parts have fallen. The average autoworker earned $21.65 an hour in April, a decrease of about $1.52 after adjusting for inflation, compared to the same point in 2008. This difference amounts to more than $3,000 over the course of a year.

Economists project that it will take years before many Americans receive raises, as unemployment remains high at 8.2 percent. Wages will start rising again when unemployment returns to what economists call its "natural" rate, between 5 percent and 6 percent, the point at which the economy is again running at full capacity.

However, at this stage in the recovery, low salaries reinforce a cycle that makes the economy fragile. Without additional income, consumers are unable to spend or invest in ways that cause gross domestic product to increase by more than about 2.2 percent this year. George Mokrzan, director of economics at Ohio-based Huntington National Bank, stated, "That's why we have modest forecasts, instead of strong forecasts."

Title: Cruz's Third-Place Finish in South Carolina Challenges His Status as Conservative Frontrunner

Article:

Ted Cruz's third-place finish in South Carolina's primary has cast doubt on his status as the preferred candidate among conservative and evangelical voters. In a state where 73% of voters identified as evangelical in exit polls, Cruz, who has long positioned himself as the conservative choice, received 27% of the evangelical vote, trailing both Donald Trump and Marco Rubio.

Penny Nance, the head of Concerned Women for America, expressed that Cruz's third-place finish in South Carolina makes it more difficult for him to argue that he is the front-runner or the unifying figure for the conservative base. "It's going to be more difficult for him to make the argument that he's the front-runner, that he's the guy for everyone to coalesce around," she said.

Timothy Head, the executive director of the Faith and Freedom Coalition, a prominent Christian group, noted that the evangelical vote is not solely based on socially conservative issues. "We're weeks away from seeing an actual coalescence around one candidate," he said.

Despite Cruz's strong support from movement conservative leaders, such as Tony Perkins, the head of the Family Research Council, and James Dobson, the founder of Focus on the Family, Cruz has yet to secure the evangelical vote in a significant manner. Cruz won the evangelical vote in Iowa and placed third in New Hampshire, but his performance in South Carolina indicates that his message may not be resonating with this demographic as effectively as previously thought.

Looking ahead to the upcoming primaries in Nevada and Southern states, Cruz urged conservative and evangelical voters to rally to his campaign once again. "If you are a conservative, this is where you belong, because only one strong conservative is in a position to win this race," he said. "We are the only campaign that has beaten and can beat Donald Trump."

However, the South Carolina results suggest that Cruz's message is not fully translating even with conservative and evangelical primary voters who should be his natural constituency. "Certainly the activist base, the tea party base, those folks really like Ted Cruz and support him, but for the evangelicals who maybe aren't living and breathing...Senate floor fights, people who are evangelicals, social conservatives, there is something about Marco Rubio they like," said Nance.

As March 1 approaches and a dozen states, many of them Southern, heavily evangelical, and similar to South Carolina, vote in primaries, Cruz's campaign has set high expectations for their performance. The Cruz campaign has been organizing in the South earlier and harder than any other campaign and has said they must, and will, have a strong showing.

Rubio and Trump also have paths in states politically similar to South Carolina, and Trump in particular comes in with a head of steam. The Cruz campaign acknowledges that the race is a three-person race headed into March 1, with some cross-over voting expected. As March 1 nears and the race grows more nationalized, the traditional views of the candidates—Cruz as the conservative choice, Rubio as the more moderate one—will come back into play.

Title: WHO Warns Young People to Avoid Socializing Due to Coronavirus Risks

Article:

The World Health Organization (WHO) has issued a warning to young people, emphasizing that they are not immune to the coronavirus and should avoid socializing to protect older, more vulnerable individuals. WHO Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus stated that the choices made by the young can be "the difference between life and death for someone else."

As of the time of this report, over 11,000 patients have died from the Covid-19 respiratory illness worldwide. The coronavirus outbreak was first recorded in China in December, but the center of the pandemic is now Europe.

In Italy, where the virus has claimed more lives than in any other country, the death toll rose by 627 on Friday, reaching a total of 4,032, marking the deadliest day for one country since the outbreak began.

Several countries and regions have taken new measures in response to the pandemic. In the United Kingdom, Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced that cafes, pubs, and restaurants will be closed from Friday night. In the United States, borders with Mexico and Canada will be closed to most traffic, and non-essential businesses have been ordered to shut down in New York State and California. In Spain, the government warned that army patrols would detain people outside without good reason. Bavaria, Germany's second most populous state, has become the first state to impose a lockdown. In France, police have reinforced patrols at Paris railway stations to stop people from taking unnecessary trips. In Indonesia, a state of emergency will be in force in the capital Jakarta from Monday, with bars, cinemas, and many other businesses set to close down.

Speaking at an online news conference from WHO headquarters in Geneva, Mr. Tedros said, "Although older people are hardest hit, younger people are not spared." He added, "I have a message for young people: You are not invincible, this virus could put you in hospital for weeks or even kill you. Even if you don't get sick, the choices you make about where you go could be the difference between life and death for someone else."

Mr. Tedros welcomed developments from the central Chinese city of Wuhan, where the outbreak originated, which reported no new cases on Thursday. He said this provided "hope for the rest of the world that even the most severe situation can be turned around."

Studies have shown that people of all ages can be infected by the virus, but it is especially dangerous for older people and those with underlying illnesses. The average age of those who died from Covid-19 in Italy was 78.5 years. Fewer than 1% of patients under the age of 50 died in China, according to the New York Times. However, it was fatal for nearly 15% of those who were over the age of 80.

The WHO is now recommending "physical distance" instead of "social distancing" to help prevent transmission of the virus, according to Reuters. "We want people to remain connected," said Dr. Maria Kerkhove, a WHO epidemiologist, to the news agency. "So find ways to do that, find ways through the internet and through different social media to remain connected because your mental health going through this (pandemic) is just as important as your physical health."

Title: Millions of Americans Lose Insurance Policies Due to Obamacare, Experts Predict Up to 100 Million More to Follow

Article:

Shortly after the federal Obamacare exchanges launched on October 1, 2013, millions of Americans received policy cancellation notices in the mail. By the end of 2013, more than 5 million people lost their insurance as a result of Obamacare making their plans illegal under the new law.

Healthcare experts estimate that nearly 80-100 million private and employer-provided policies will eventually be cancelled as a result of Obamacare. Stan Veuger of the American Enterprise Institute stated that, in addition to the individual cancellations, "at least half the people on employer plans would by 2014 start losing plans as well." There are approximately 157 million employer health care policy holders.

Avik Roy of the Manhattan Institute added, "the administration estimated that approximately 78 million Americans with employer-sponsored insurance would lose their existing coverage due to the Affordable Care Act."

Last week, an analysis by the American Enterprise Institute, a conservative think tank, showed the administration anticipates half to two-thirds of small businesses would have policies cancelled or be compelled to send workers onto the Obamacare exchanges. They predicted up to 100 million small and large business policies could be cancelled next year.

In a recent interview with Fox News' Bill O'Reilly before the Super Bowl, President Obama refused to admit that promising the American people they could keep their health plans under Obamacare was one of his biggest mistakes. Half of voters believe the president knowingly lied about people being able to keep their plans.

Title: GOP Congressmen Call for Special Counsel Robert Mueller's Resignation from Russia Probe

Article:

Three Republican congressmen, including Rep. Matt Gaetz (R-Fla.), Rep. Andy Biggs (R-Ariz.), and Louie Gohmert (R-Texas), have introduced a resolution calling for the resignation of Special Counsel Robert Mueller from the Russia collusion probe. The resolution was introduced on Friday, citing Mueller's ties to the FBI and its role in controversies involving Russia.

In a statement, Rep. Gaetz stated, "Evidence has emerged that the FBI withheld information from Congress and from the American people about Russian corruption of American uranium companies." Gaetz referred to Mueller's supervision of a bribery probe involving a subsidiary of Russia's Rosatom, which eventually got approval from the U.S. to buy a Canadian mining company, Uranium One, that controlled a significant portion of American uranium reserves.

Rep. Gaetz also pointed to a confidential U.S. witness, whose gag order was lifted by the Justice Department last week, and is now able to provide information to Congress. Gaetz alleged that the Obama administration and Mueller's FBI knowingly kept Congress in the dark about Russia's significant and illegal involvement with American uranium companies.

Rep. Trent Franks (R-Ariz.) and Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Chuck Grassley (R-Iowa) have also called for Mueller's resignation. Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Grassley has called for an independent special counsel to investigate the Obama-era Uranium One deal.

There are currently two pieces of legislation in the Senate with bipartisan sponsorship that would ensure a judicial check on the executive branch's ability to remove a special counsel. Republican Sens. Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.) and Thom Tillis (R-N.C.) are behind the bills, along with Democratic senators.

The proposed resolution comes just days after Mueller's team announced the first charges in their investigation into Russian meddling and potential collusion with Trump campaign officials in the 2016 presidential election. Former Trump campaign chairman Paul Manafort and his associate Rick Gates were indicted on 12 counts, and former Trump foreign policy campaign volunteer George Papadopoulos entered a guilty plea after admitting to making false statements to the FBI.

Title: Graham Questions Rosenstein's Involvement in Mueller Investigation

Article:

Top Republican Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina has inquired whether Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein should recuse himself from the Robert Mueller investigation, citing potential connections to the case. In a letter obtained by Fox News, Graham asked Rosenstein if he considers himself a "potential witness" in the Mueller probe in relation to the dismissal of FBI Director James Comey.

Graham's letter, dated May 31, refers to reports that Mueller's investigation is examining whether President Trump obstructed justice by firing Comey, and the fact that Trump relied on a Rosenstein-authored memo to justify the dismissal.

Rosenstein's role in the matter was further detailed in a New York Times report earlier this week, which discussed a memo written by ousted FBI official Andrew McCabe. Fox News has confirmed that the memo describes a meeting where Rosenstein allegedly claimed Trump had asked him to reference Russia in his recommendation to fire Comey.

However, Rosenstein reportedly declined and instead focused on Comey's handling of the Hillary Clinton email probe. President Trump, in a tweet, denied that he fired Comey due to Russia, stating, "Not that it matters but I never fired James Comey because of Russia!"

A source with knowledge of the investigation told Fox News that Trump had only wanted Rosenstein to mention that Comey was not under investigation in the Russia case. Trump himself, though, has cited the Russia probe in explaining his decision to fire Comey. Any indications that the president was motivated by the Russia investigation to act against Comey could fuel the obstruction of justice component of Mueller's probe.

Asked for comment on Graham's letter, a Department of Justice official confirmed that it had been received. The new pressure on Rosenstein comes as President Trump continues to criticize Attorney General Jeff Sessions for his initial decision to recuse himself from the Russia probe, which led to Rosenstein appointing Mueller after Comey's dismissal. Trump earlier this week expressed a wish that he had chosen another nominee for attorney general.

Title: Kentucky's Criminal Justice Reform Efforts: A Model for the Nation

Article:

Governor Matt Bevin of Kentucky has called for the nation to learn from his state's efforts to reform its criminal justice system, citing the need for a more effective and humane approach. The current state of affairs in the United States' criminal justice system is marked by high incarceration rates, a drug epidemic, and a significant financial burden on taxpayers.

In Kentucky, the governor has advocated for policies that promote redemption and human dignity, arguing that the traditional "lock 'em up and throw away the key" approach has been ineffective and counterproductive. The state has made strides in this area, passing expungement legislation in its latest session, which allows certain nonviolent offenders to wipe their slates clean after serving their sentences and completing a crime-free period.

To further address the issue, the administration has formed a 23-member Criminal Justice Policy Assessment Council. This task force, composed of a diverse group of voices, is conducting a comprehensive review of Kentucky's criminal justice system and recommending reforms aimed at making it more effective and less costly. The task force's recommendations will be presented as legislation before the 2017 session of the Kentucky General Assembly.

Governor Bevin has also joined forces with Governors Nathan Deal of Georgia and Mary Fallin of Oklahoma, both of whom are spearheading criminal justice reforms in their respective states, in a film titled "Changing Laws, Changing Lives." The film showcases their shared vision for a more humane criminal justice system and highlights the different approaches their states have taken to address the issue.

The governor emphasizes that the time for talking is over and that action is needed. By collaborating across state and party lines, the governors hope to develop plans that minimize the cost to taxpayers, maximize public safety, and motivate offenders to turn away from crime. The archaic "tough on crime" rhetoric of the 1980s is becoming a thing of the past, with Kentucky embracing a new style of justice that seeks to rehabilitate offenders rather than simply remove them from society. The governors hope that Congress will be inspired by their efforts and follow their lead in passing similar reforms at the federal level.

Title: Fiscal Cliff Bill Averts Medicare Pay Cuts for Doctors, Eliminates Long-Term Care Program

Article:

The recently passed bill, aimed at averting the nation from plunging over the fiscal cliff, included provisions that affected Medicare and other health care programs. One of the most notable changes was the prevention of a significant pay cut for doctors who treat Medicare patients.

David Blumenthal, president of the American College of Physicians and an internist in Cleveland, stated, "We know that this would really devastate access to seniors, to just cut payment rates by almost 27 percent."

The pay cut, if implemented, would likely drive doctors to stop accepting new Medicare patients and potentially drop existing ones. However, the language in the bill was not what doctors had hoped for, as it only delayed the payment adjustment, which has been a recurring issue since 2002.

In the meantime, hospitals are displeased because the so-called "doc fix" was partially funded by cutting $15 billion in Medicare and Medicaid payments to them over the next 10 years.

Doctors are also concerned about potential cuts to the graduate medical education program when the across-the-board cuts known as the sequester return in eight weeks. This program, which helps fund the training of young doctors, nurses, and other medical professionals, is crucial for the medical workforce in the United States.

Another health care program, the CLASS Act, was eliminated as part of the fiscal cliff deal. Originally part of the 2010 health law, the CLASS Act aimed to provide publicly administered, long-term-care insurance at a modest cost. However, the program faced opposition from Republicans, who viewed it as a potentially unlimited government program that could not pay for itself.

Larry Minnix, president of Leading Age, a group of more than 6,000 nonprofit providers of services to seniors and people with disabilities, stated, "Long-term care, in the broadest sense of it, is responsible for people, including families, the 355 days [a year] they're not in the hospital and the 22 hours a day they're not in the doctor's office."

Medicare has been a significant point of contention in recent budget battles and is expected to come up again in upcoming fights over the delayed budget cuts, raising the debt ceiling, and when last year's temporary spending bills expire, all before the end of March.

Health policy analyst Bob Laszewski stated, "We're going to have three more cliff issues over the next three months." However, he added, "We don't even have a Medicare entitlement fix on the table from either side."

This suggests that the 113th Congress is likely to face challenges in addressing these issues in the coming months.

Title: Collapse of Building in Mexico City's Condesa District: Rescue Efforts Underway

Article:

In the aftermath of a building collapse in Mexico City's fashionable district of Condesa, a massive rescue operation is underway. The neighborhood, known for its vulnerability to earthquakes due to its construction on soft soil, has seen several buildings also collapse. Thousands of people are standing in the streets, avenues, and sidewalks, creating a sense of dread.

On Laredo Street, an eight-story apartment building has fallen into the road, leaving a massive pile of concrete and rubble. Over a hundred people are clearing the debris by hand, passing boulders and twisted steel pipes along a human chain. The sound of shouts and orders fill the air, with a call for silence to listen for any trapped individuals.

Salomón Chertorivski, the secretary of economic development for Mexico City, estimates that at least 10 people may be trapped inside the structure. The operation involves backhoes digging into the building's remains and helicopters overhead. A stretcher was passed up to the top of the heap.

Workers are frantically pulling people from the wreckage. A man is rushing down Amsterdam Street, searching for tools. "Saws, hacksaws—anything to cut wood and metal," he screams. Someone returns with a hacksaw and hands it to him, and he prepares to return to the mound.

The collective spirit of the community fills the disaster site, as neighbors and passersby join the rescue efforts. Moises Escobar, a 25-year-old recent college graduate, witnessed the collapse. "It fell straight down," he said. "There was a lot of smoke and dust."

The rescue operation continues, with the hope of finding and saving those trapped in the debris.

Title: Grocery Workers in 20 States Receive Child Care Benefits Amidst Coronavirus Crisis; Calls for More Protections Grow

Article:

In response to the coronavirus pandemic and its impact on American lifestyles and shopping habits, Minnesota and Vermont have classified grocery clerks as emergency workers, making them eligible for free child care. Since then, more than a dozen states have offered free, subsidized, or income-dependent child care to grocery workers, bringing the total number of states providing this benefit to 20.

As they continue to face increased risk of infection, many grocery workers are advocating for additional protections. At least 41 grocery workers have died from the coronavirus, according to the Washington Post. The United Food and Commercial Workers union, along with major supermarket chains Kroger and Albertsons, have been urging federal and state officials to designate grocery workers as first responders, which would grant them priority access to masks and gloves. They are also calling for mandatory guidelines from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention to enforce sanitation, social distancing, and personal protective equipment in grocery stores.

David Madland, a senior fellow at the Center for American Progress, stated last week that the first-responder status was a step in the right direction but would not be sufficient to keep them safe. "Essential workers need more than just masks and gloves," he said. "They need a broad set of protections to enable them to safely go to work." Madland supports the Essential Workers Bill of Rights, proposed by Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.) and Rep. Ro Khanna (D-Ca.), which would mandate protective equipment, sick leave, child care, health care, and a pay raise for essential employees like grocery workers.

In the absence of federal protections, workers' protections are determined by the companies they work for and state and local governments. Despite the growing recognition of grocery workers as heroes during the coronavirus crisis, only a handful of states have taken action to provide them with protections from the virus.

Some states, including Delaware and Illinois, have issued guidance for grocery stores to limit the number of customers and enforce social distancing in lines. A growing number are requiring shoppers to wear masks. However, only a handful of states, including Connecticut, Rhode Island, New York, New Jersey, and Pennsylvania, are mandating that employers provide grocery workers with personal protective equipment.

Massachusetts has made free, priority coronavirus testing available to grocery workers. California has expanded paid sick time to food sector workers and, along with Nevada and Maryland, has granted grocery workers the right to wash their hands every 30 minutes.

Title: Pro-Life Organization Accuses YouTube and Pinterest of Discrimination Over Anti-Abortion Content

Article:

One of the nation's leading pro-life organizations, Live Action, has taken legal action against YouTube and Pinterest, alleging discrimination against the group's anti-abortion posts on both platforms. In a statement on Friday, Live Action announced that it had sent cease and desist letters to both companies on August 21, demanding they address the allegations or contact their lawyers by August 30.

Live Action claims that YouTube has failed to publish its video ads, breached contracts, and caused financial losses. Pinterest banned Live Action from its platform in June, citing its "pro-life educational and political content" as "pornographic." In their letter, Live Action's lawyers stated that Pinterest's decision was a result of "kneejerk reactions and poorly thought-out pretexts for speech suppression."

YouTube has acknowledged receiving the concerns raised by Live Action and is currently investigating the matter. Pinterest has yet to respond to the group's letter. "Litigation is likely to ensue in this matter," the letters read.

Lila Rose, Live Action's founder and president, expressed her dismay in a statement, stating, "It is truly sad and disheartening that in a society built on the principles of freedom of speech and assembly, companies like YouTube and Pinterest, who clearly benefit from these first principles of American culture, are engaging in not-so-subtle tactics to suppress speech with which they disagree."

Live Action's attorney, Harmeet Dhillon of the Dhillon Law Group, stated, "YouTube and Pinterest are clearly in violation of the law and must remedy this situation." Dhillon added that the evidence in both cases is substantial, ranging from suppression of speech and breach of contract to censorship and banning of Live Action based on false claims.

Last week, Live Action made a similar accusation against Facebook, stating that the social-media platform's fact-checking mechanism labeled as "false" and "inaccurate" the group's claim that "abortion is never medically necessary."
