Rose warned, "Continued efforts to censor Live Action will have tremendous implications, not only for the pro-life movement, but for free speech in America."

Title: Senate Judiciary Committee to Address Key Constitutional Issues in Kavanaugh's Supreme Court Confirmation Hearings

Article:

The Senate Judiciary Committee will hold confirmation hearings this week for Brett Kavanaugh's nomination to serve as an associate justice of the United States Supreme Court. Kavanaugh, a 53-year-old federal judge, is a respected figure in conservative legal circles. However, there are still unanswered questions regarding his jurisprudence. Here are five matters that I would like to hear Kavanaugh address during the Senate Judiciary Committee hearings:

1. Marijuana Legalization and Federal Regulation: With marijuana legal in multiple states, but still federally banned, the Supreme Court has upheld the federal marijuana ban in Gonzales v. Raich (2005). Kavanaugh may be asked about the federal authority to regulate interstate commerce and whether it is broad enough to allow Congress to ban a local activity that is legal under state law and never crosses state lines.

2. Presidential Executive Orders and Judicial Review: In February 2017, the Trump administration argued that President Trump's first executive order banning travelers from certain majority-Muslim countries was beyond the reach of judicial review. Kavanaugh may be asked about his agreement with this stance and the deference federal courts should show to the executive branch when the president claims to be acting in the name of national security.

3. Unenumerated Rights: The Constitution refers to rights that it does not expressly list, such as the right to privacy, the right of parents to educate their children in private schools, and the right to gay marriage. Kavanaugh may be asked about the Supreme Court's justification for securing unenumerated rights from government infringement and whether the Court should overturn its applicable precedents and stop recognizing the unwritten right to privacy.

4. Judicial Restraint and the Affordable Care Act: In his 2011 dissent in Seven-Sky v. Holder, Kavanaugh argued that the federal courts should have abstained from ruling on the constitutional merits of the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (Obamacare). Kavanaugh may be asked to explain his criteria for determining when the judiciary should "afford great respect" to lawmakers and avoid "upending" their "legislative effort."

5. Bulk Metadata Collection and the Fourth Amendment: In 2015, Kavanaugh wrote that the National Security Agency's bulk metadata collection program was "entirely consistent with the Fourth Amendment." Kavanaugh may be asked about his current views on the Fourth Amendment and whether he still believes the federal government's wholesale warrantless collection of every American's telephone record metadata is consistent with the Fourth Amendment.

The American people are eager to hear Kavanaugh's views on these crucial constitutional issues, and the members of the Senate Judiciary Committee should ask him about them during his Supreme Court confirmation hearings this week.

Title: Pro-Choice Caucus of the House Announces Support for Bipartisan Medicare Deal Despite Abortion Funding Ban

Article:

The Democratic leaders of the House's pro-choice caucus announced on Tuesday their intention to support a bipartisan deal aimed at overhauling Medicare payments, despite the inclusion of a long-standing ban on using federal funds for abortion.

Reps. Diana DeGette of Colorado and Louise Slaughter of New York made the statement in an attempt to salvage the Medicare deal, which was struck by House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi and Speaker John A. Boehner, despite Senate Democrats expressing grievances about the so-called Hyde language on abortion and other aspects of the House package.

The pro-choice caucus chairs stated, "The language included in the bipartisan compromise does not further restrict women's access to abortion, and the provisions expire along with funding—just as the current Hyde Amendment does." They further encouraged other members of the pro-choice caucus to support this bipartisan compromise.

The abortion debate centers around a ban on the procedure within funding for community health centers. The abortion issue has already caused a stalemate in a Senate bill aimed at combating human trafficking, and lawmakers from both parties are concerned it will derail the hard-fought struggle to repeal an outdated Medicare formula known as the Sustainable Growth Rate (SGR).

Congress regularly overrides the cuts, but top Democrats and Republicans have stated it's time to scrap them permanently before April 1, when doctors face a 21 percent cut in reimbursements. Rep. Michael Burgess, Texas Republican and lead author of the SGR-repeal bill, said this week, "If someone needs a reason to be against this, I’m sure they can find reasons to be against it. I would rather approach it as, are there reasons to be for it? There’s plenty of reasons to be for it."

Leading women in the House are hoping their counterparts in both chambers see it the same way, even as they reiterated their distaste for the abortion-funding ban. "The Hyde Amendment is a temporary rider that expires every year, and we—along with many women across this country—look forward to the day when it will end," Ms. DeGette and Ms. Slaughter said.

Title: Trump Children Criticized for Business Ties Amidst Biden Scandal Allegations

Article:

In a recent development, Donald Trump Jr. and Eric Trump, children of President Donald Trump, have been criticized for their comments regarding Hunter Biden's business dealings, particularly in Ukraine and China, during their appearances on Fox News. The brothers' comments were seen as hypocritical, given their own extensive international business dealings, which have continued during their father's presidency.

The implication of the conspiracy theory pushed by the Trump brothers is that Hunter Biden's international business dealings created conflicts of interest for the Obama administration's foreign policy. However, there is no evidence to support this claim, and the specific numbers cited by the Trump brothers regarding the amount of money Hunter Biden made in Ukraine and China are dubious.

Since Trump's inauguration, Don Jr. and Eric have been responsible for the Trump Organization, which spans more than 30 countries, about 500 business entities, and generated about $9.5 billion in revenue before he took office. The brothers have sold more than $100 million of the family's real estate since the January 2017 inauguration, including a $3.2 million deal in the Dominican Republic last year that is considered a clear violation of their father's pledge to do no new foreign deals while in office.

In addition to Ukraine, the Trumps have also accused Hunter Biden of cashing in in China. However, a $1.7 billion Trump Organization project in Indonesia received a $500 million infusion from a state-owned Chinese construction company. Ivanka Trump, despite working in the White House, continues to do business in China, and her husband, White House official Jared Kushner, received a massive cash infusion from Qatar.

The news moves fast. To stay updated, follow Aaron Rupar on Twitter, and read more of ███'s policy and politics coverage. In its sixth episode on the impeachment scandal, our podcast explains how Ukraine finds itself at the center of the American political drama, yet President Trump is the least of the country's worries. Looking for a quick way to keep up with the never-ending news cycle? Host Sean Rameswaram will guide you through the most important stories at the end of each day. Subscribe on Apple Podcasts, Spotify, Overcast, or wherever you listen to podcasts.

Title: Trump Seizes Tax-Cut Issue, Promises Simplification and Growth

Article:

President Donald Trump has taken a leading role in advocating for tax cuts, aiming to stimulate economic growth and increase take-home pay for American workers. In a recent speech to the National Association of Manufacturers, Trump stated, "The era of economic surrender is over."

The Trump tax plan includes reducing large and small business tax rates, doubling the standard deduction for middle-income individuals, simplifying the tax code by eliminating unnecessary deductions, repealing the death tax, and ending the alternative minimum tax.

Democrats have criticized the president's plan as a handout to the rich, but Trump has called for a bipartisan approach, citing the tax-cutting policies of past presidents such as John F. Kennedy and Ronald Reagan. He has argued that his plan will make America's economy great again.

The Trump tax plan is currently being refined by key tax-writing committees to pass the Senate with a simple majority of 51 votes. However, there are some key points that require clarification.

One point of contention is the argument that the U.S. is doomed to 2% or less growth, known as "secular stagnation," regardless of tax policy. The article notes that across-the-board tax cuts during the JFK period produced 5% annual growth, and after tax cuts were fully implemented in 1983, real growth averaged 4.6% for the remainder of Reagan's presidency.

Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and National Economic Council Director Gary Cohn have suggested that the 3% growth scenario will pay for the tax cuts, but naysayers refuse to admit that tax-rate incentives matter.

The article provides an example of the incentive effect of the Trump tax plan by comparing the current 35% corporate tax rate to the proposed 20% rate. For every extra dollar of profit, a company keeps 65 cents under the current rate, but under the proposed rate, a private company would keep 80 cents. This represents a significant 23% incentive reward.

The article also highlights the supply-side incentive effect of the Trump plan, including the repatriation of trillions of U.S. company dollars lodged overseas to avoid taxes, as well as 100% expensing write-offs for new investment of any kind.

On the individual side, the doubling of the standard deduction is a key aspect of the Trump plan. This change is expected to put more cash in workers' pockets, simplify the code, and mean that nearly 80% of taxpayers will not have any deductions.

The article concludes by emphasizing the importance of the Republican party winning the tax-cut issue, preferably this year. The article warns that the GOP cannot let archaic process rules prevent good policy and encourages the party to play hardball, citing the bipartisan tax-cutting policies of past presidents such as JFK and Reagan.

Title: Rand Paul's National Security Speech: A Mixed Message and Confusion on National Security Issues

Article:

Senator Rand Paul, a prominent figure in the libertarian movement, delivered his national security stump speech in New York on Friday, outlining his "conservative realism" platform. The speech, while containing positive elements, has been met with criticism for its omissions and perceived inconsistencies.

The speech, in part, marked a shift from Paul's isolationist stance, as he acknowledged the necessity of U.S. engagement in international affairs. However, the absence of key topics such as Israel, border security, immigration, and NSA privacy rights raised questions.

One area where Paul's speech was well-received was his praise for the U.S. military's success in Afghanistan post-9/11, and his criticism of the Obama administration's handling of the Libya intervention.

However, the speech as a whole did not represent a significant departure from Paul's isolationist views or offer a coherent new plan for the right's approach to national security issues. The speech was criticized for its perceived confusion and disingenuousness, particularly in its handling of the global jihadist threat.

In the aftermath of recent jihadist attacks in Canada and New York, many expected a robust and forthright response to the threat that has defined the current age. Instead, Paul's speech offered a more nuanced perspective, stating that the world has a "dignity problem" rather than an "Islam problem."

This focus on dignity issues was met with skepticism, as it seemed to downplay the role of extremist ideology in global terrorism. Paul's argument that U.S. support for unjust regimes contributes to jihadi terrorism was criticized for its potential to negate the responsibility of jihadists and for reinforcing the Obama administration's counterterrorism strategy.

Critics also pointed to Paul's history of conspiracy theories, such as his belief in Alex Jones' one-world government conspiracy theories, as evidence of his unsuitability for presidential material.

Sebastian Gorka, the Matthew C. Horner Distinguished Chair of Military Theory at the Marine Corps University and National Security Affairs Editor for Breitbart.com, was among the critics. Follow him on Twitter at @SebGorka.

Title: Politico Corrects Article on Trump's Alleged Debt to Bank of China

Article:

Politico, an American political news and analysis website, has corrected an article published on April 24, 2020, that initially claimed President Donald Trump currently "owes" millions of dollars to the Bank of China. The publication was forced to edit the article after it was determined that Trump did not currently owe the Bank of China millions of dollars, as the Bank of China had sold the loan related to the property in question weeks after the 2012 loan.

The updated article now reads that Trump "owed" – past tense – money to the Bank of China. It includes an important note from the Bank of China as well.

According to the updated article, the Bank of China participated in a commercial mortgage loan of $950 million to Vornado Realty Trust on November 7, 2012. However, within 22 days, the loan was securitized and sold into the commercial mortgage-backed securities market, a common practice in the industry. The Bank of China has not had any ownership interest in that loan since late November 2012.

The initial headline of the article, which suggested that Trump currently owed millions to the Bank of China, has been updated to reflect this new reporting. The changes were prominently flagged atop the article.

In a statement to ███, a Politico spokesperson defended the report, stating that the Trump Organization is a party to a loan that includes the Bank of China, based on multiple publicly available documents, including a 2017 filing with the city of New York that remains current through 2022. The spokesperson also noted that the Bank of China's NY-based PR representative called after the publication, stating that the Bank had sold that debt shortly after the 2012 deal.

The article still tries to connect Trump's response to the novel coronavirus, suggesting that the Trump campaign has increased its focus on portraying Joe Biden as weak on China amid rising voter disapproval of China, the source of the coronavirus pandemic.

Despite the correction, the article has not been retracted. The spokesperson also noted that finance experts have told Politico that the documents provided to them were complex and didn't necessarily reveal who currently holds that debt, including the Bank of China. The 2017 filing with the city of New York still lists them as a creditor. Politico will continue to report on this story.

Title: Essential Service Workers in Dallas County Continue Operations Amid Shelter-in-Place Order

Article:

As Dallas County enforces a shelter-in-place order, essential service workers such as plumbers, HVAC technicians, and electricians are continuing to enter the homes of residents, relying on customers to maintain safety protocols.

Keresa Richardson, co-owner of Benjamin Franklin Plumbing in Dallas, stated, "Plumbers, historically, protect the health of the nation, and we continue to do so by providing services when everyone else is quarantined. We're still out there doing our job."

Richardson and her husband, J.R., run Lawton Group, a firm that includes Benjamin Franklin Plumbing, Buckaroo Pest Protection, Lawton Mechanical Services, and other companies providing mechanical services. They are requesting that customers inform them if anyone in the home is feeling ill or showing symptoms related to COVID-19 to ensure the safety of their employees.

Jimmy Dale, CEO of Baker Brothers, also emphasized the importance of customers notifying the company if they are sick to avoid potential coronavirus transmission. Dale stated, "The fact that [workers] can spread it to other places and other people... that's the part that really scares them and scares us."

Both companies are taking precautions to minimize the risk of coronavirus transmission. Workers are maintaining six feet of distance from customers, wearing protective gear including face shields and gloves, and disinfecting equipment between every job. Employees at Dallas-Fort Worth-based Berkeys Air Conditioning, Plumbing & Electrical are also adhering to social distancing guidelines and performing touchless payment transactions.

The increased demand for plumbing services due to the shelter-in-place order has led to an uptick in service calls for clogged plumbing, likely due to residents flushing unsuitable items such as baby wipes, paper towels, and Kleenex.

"A lot of times we don't realize we have five people in the house, but you only have two people in at a time," Dale said. "All day long, five people being there kind of creates that."

"We've had a big uptick in drain calls," Dale added. Baker Brothers saw twice as many service requests for clogged plumbing on a typical Monday compared to before the shelter-in-place order.

Plumbing companies are also experiencing an increased demand for toilet paper, with some companies like Benjamin Franklin Plumbing even leaving a roll of complimentary toilet paper at the homes they service. Richardson explained, "With a toilet paper shortage, they are flushing baby wipes, paper towels, Kleenex, whatever they can find to use if they've run out of toilet paper. That clogs the system because those are not meant to disintegrate like toilet paper."

Title: Treasury Department Denies Delay in Stimulus Check Distribution Due to President Trump's Name Addition

Article:

The Washington Post published a story on Tuesday evening claiming that the stimulus checks going out to millions of Americans as a result of the coronavirus crisis are being held up due to the fact that President Donald Trump's name is being affixed to them. However, the Treasury Department has denied any delay and stated that the checks are scheduled to go out on time and exactly as planned.

According to the article from Lisa Rein, the addition of Trump's name to the checks could potentially slow their delivery by a few days. The article also includes a section quoting some career officials claiming this will lead to a delay. The team, working from home, is now racing to implement a programming change that two senior IRS officials said will probably lead to a delay in issuing the first batch of paper checks, which are scheduled to be sent Thursday to the Bureau of the Fiscal Service for printing and issuing. Computer code must be changed to include the president's name, and the system must be tested, these officials said.

However, buried deeper within the piece is confirmation that the checks will not be delayed. A Treasury Department spokeswoman denied any delay and said the plan all along was to issue the checks next week. "Economic Impact Payment checks are scheduled to go out on time and exactly as planned—there is absolutely no delay whatsoever," the spokeswoman said in a written statement. She said this was a faster process than the stimulus checks the George W. Bush administration issued in 2008 to head off a looming recession. "In fact, we expect the first checks to be in the mail early next week, which is well in advance of when the first checks went out in 2008 and well in advance of initial estimates," the statement said.

Multiple Treasury Department officials confirmed to ███ that the claims of a delay are inaccurate. One Treasury Department official confirmed that President Trump's name will appear on the paper checks, adding there will be no delay to make that happen.

Monica Crowley, the Treasury Department spokeswoman, also tweeted this response to the "inaccurate and misleading" Washington Post story on Wednesday:

Treasury spokesperson response to last night's inaccurate and misleading Washington Post story: pic.twitter.com/5K7SNa6PFC

— Monica Crowley (@TreasurySpox) April 15, 2020

Most Americans are getting these cash payments directly deposited into their bank accounts, if they have gotten a tax return in recent years and the IRS has their direct deposit information on file. Some Americans, however, need a paper check to be mailed to them—and the Treasury Department says these checks are going out ahead of schedule even with the addition of President Trump's name on them.

Despite the claims from the Washington Post piece collapsing under scrutiny, many on the left and throughout the media and entertainment establishment have used this story to further attack President Trump. Tweets from legal scholar Laurence Tribe, former Obama administration official Chris Lu, and others can be seen above, accusing the president of delaying the checks for his own vanity and political advantage.

A source familiar with the matter added to ███ that the political attacks on the president and inaccurate claims of a delay in checks going out for this purpose are par for the course for those who hate President Trump. "This is just another attempt by the entrenched, anti-Trump bureaucracy to craft a false narrative about the president's ego when in fact millions of Americans are already seeing their economic impact payments hit their bank accounts," the source said. "The Washington Post is the propaganda arm of the out of touch, rabid, far left and should be lambasted for sowing discord as our nation attempts to navigate this challenging economic climate. Shameful."

Title: GOP and White House Offer Differing Views on Fiscal Cliff Plan

Article:

In a meeting with GOP leaders on Tuesday, Treasury Secretary Timothy Geithner presented a plan to avoid the fiscal cliff, which was described by a top Republican Hill aide as "absurd." An aide to House Speaker John Boehner described the White House's offer as "completely unrealistic" and "a break with reality."

Meanwhile, a top Democratic insider criticized the Republicans, stating, "The Republicans have taken to screaming at us." A 30-minute phone call between Speaker Boehner and President Obama on Wednesday night was reported as "unproductive" and "blunt."

House Speaker John Boehner expressed his frustration at a press conference on Thursday, stating, "No substantive progress has been made over the last two weeks. It's time for the president and Congressional Democrats to tell the American people what spending cuts they're really willing to make."

With the fiscal cliff deadline of December 31 fast approaching, President Obama is taking his case to the public. He is bypassing the ongoing negotiations between both sides and traveling to Hatfield, Pa., where he will tour a toy manufacturing facility and speak to workers. The White House stated that the President will be making the case for action by visiting a business that depends on middle-class consumers, which could be impacted if taxes go up at the end of the year.

The White House and the Speaker's office have provided differing perspectives on the fiscal cliff plan. Boehner's office outlined six reasons why the Obama administration's fiscal cliff offer won't fly:

1. Twice the Taxes: The President's plan to raise the top two tax rates would yield about $800 billion in new tax revenue, but he has now asked for twice that amount.
2. Not Even the Votes in His Own Party: The Senate barely passed a bill with $800 billion in new tax revenue a few months ago (51 votes). There is no chance there are votes in the Senate for anything close to $1.6 trillion.
3. Unbalanced: The President's plan offers four times as much revenue as spending cuts.
4. No Net Spending Cuts: The spending cuts offered in the plan are wiped out by all the new goodies the President is also requesting, such as stimulus, unemployment insurance, payroll, and housing programs.
5. Debt Limit Pipe Dream: Permanently doing away with the debt limit is unrealistic. Raising it to infinity is not.
6. We're Far From Opening Bids: Even as an "opening bid," this offer would be ludicrous. The seven weeks to resolve the issue are almost gone, and this is what the President comes with?

The White House, on the other hand, maintains that the only thing preventing a deal that avoids the fiscal cliff and a tax hike on 98% of Americans is the refusal of Congressional Republicans to ask the wealthiest individuals to pay higher tax rates. The President has already signed into law over $1 trillion in spending cuts, and the White House remains willing to compromise. It's time for Republicans in Washington to join the chorus of voices supporting a balanced approach that asks more from the wealthiest Americans.

Title: Federal Investigation Intensifies in Wake of Orlando Nightclub Shooting

Article:

Federal authorities are intensifying their investigation into the Orlando nightclub shooting that left 49 people dead and 53 injured on Sunday. The probe aims to determine if Omar Mateen, the gunman, acted alone or if others were aware of his deadly plans and potentially aided him.

FBI agents have interviewed Mateen's wife, Noor Salman, who could be charged as an accessory. Salman, who is reportedly cooperating, is under investigation for her knowledge of Mateen's deadly plans. The FBI has declined to comment on the ongoing investigation, but multiple reports indicate that the FBI visited Salman's childhood home in Rodeo, California, on Tuesday.

Investigators are also examining Mateen's radical Islam roots, with two trips to Saudi Arabia in 2011 and 2012 being a focus of interest. These trips were reportedly for the Muslim pilgrimage known as umrah, and experts question whether a working-class Muslim-American would make the pilgrimage twice in two years.

The FBI has taken a computer, camera, and other equipment from Mateen's Fort Pierce condominium, located approximately 120 miles from the shooting site. It remains unclear whether ISIS directed Mateen or merely inspired him, but Fox News reported on Tuesday that Mateen had a complex relationship with American suicide bomber Moner Abu-Salha, who detonated a bomb in Syria in 2014.

Authorities are also investigating Mateen's ties to Dwayne Robertson, a former New York gang leader who resurfaced in Orlando as an imam and is suspected of radicalizing Americans and sending them abroad to commit acts of terror. Robertson denies inciting violent jihad.

Further information from relatives and acquaintances is shedding light on Mateen's personality, revealing an angry and volatile individual with conflicting feelings towards the LGBT community. The massacre is being treated as both an act of terror and a hate crime against the LGBT community, yet Mateen's first wife reportedly believes he was a closeted gay man. Patrons at Pulse, the nightclub where he killed dozens, say he had been seen there frequently, and one reportedly said Mateen had contacted him using a dating app popular with the gay community.

Title: President Obama Responds to Racial Controversy Involving LA Clippers Owner

Article:

In a familiar response to a racially charged event, President Barack Obama addressed comments allegedly made by Donald Sterling, owner of the Los Angeles Clippers basketball team. The comments, which were reportedly made to Sterling's girlfriend, were published by the gossip site TMZ over the weekend.

During a press conference in Malaysia on Sunday, Obama responded to a question about the incident. He referred to the comments as "ignorant" and stated that they "speak for themselves." The president also sought to place the incident in a larger context, noting that while the United States continues to grapple with a legacy of slavery and segregation, it is evolving in a positive direction.

Obama's response to the alleged Sterling comments is not the first time he has addressed a racially charged issue during his presidency. In July 2009, he stepped into the middle of the Gates controversy, responding to a reporter's question about the arrest of Henry Louis Gates Jr., an African-American professor at Harvard University. In 2012, the racially charged killing of Trayvon Martin also prompted comments from Obama.

On policy matters, Obama has been selective in his responses. After the US Supreme Court's recent ruling on affirmative action, in which the court upheld a Michigan referendum banning the practice in admissions to public universities, the White House press secretary issued a nuanced reaction, but Obama himself remained silent. However, the president has been vocal on voting rights, speaking out on voter ID laws and the invalidation of a key part of the Voting Rights Act.

In February, Obama unveiled "My Brother's Keeper," an initiative aimed at helping young men of color avoid the "school to prison pipeline." Some African-American scholars have criticized the initiative for not involving an infusion of federal resources.

Lester Spence, a political scientist at Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore, is one such scholar. He describes Obama as having a "voice in his head" that tells him to avoid discussing race, and decries what he sees as a lack of boldness by Obama.

After the alleged Sterling comments burst into the public arena, Spence wrote a blog post with several observations on the matter. Obama does not merit a mention in the post. Spence says he doesn't necessarily see Obama as having a role in the issue.

Despite this, Obama was asked what he thought, and he responded. Julian Zelizer, a presidential historian at Princeton University, describes Obama's response as a "leadership moment." However, some critics question whether Obama's response was transformative or merely a response to a teachable moment.

Title: Supreme Court to Address Abortion, Gun Rights, and LGBTQ Discrimination in New Term

Article:

The upcoming term of the Supreme Court is expected to be marked by significant decisions on contentious issues that divide American society. Among these issues are abortion, gun rights, gay rights, the separation of church and state, immigration, and presidential power.

In the abortion case, the Supreme Court has agreed to hear arguments in a case that seeks to essentially reverse a 2016 decision that struck down a Texas law making it difficult for abortion clinics to operate. The court's conservative majority, with the retirement of Justice Anthony Kennedy and the appointment of Justice Brett Kavanaugh, is expected to either outright reverse Roe v. Wade or hollow it out.

On gun rights, the court is set to hear the first major test of gun regulations in over 10 years since the justices ruled that there is a constitutional right to own a gun for self-defense in one's home. Court observers attribute the hiatus on gun cases to a closely divided court on which neither the four conservatives nor the four liberals were sure how Justice Kennedy would cast his deciding vote.

In the area of gay rights, the court will hear a case that tests whether employers are free to fire employees because they are gay or transgender. A victory for the LGBTQ community would be significant, as discrimination against gay and trans individuals remains rampant, especially in the private sector.

Immigration cases, particularly the Trump administration's attempt to roll back the Obama administration's program that protects "Dreamers" from deportation, are also on the court's docket.

The court is also set to address questions involving the separation of church and state, with religious rights advocates poised to challenge provisions in most state constitutions that bar direct or indirect aid to religious schools.

In addition, there are cases testing the power of Congress to get information from the executive branch, which is relevant to congressional oversight and potentially to impeachment. President Trump has expressed a desire to stop the ongoing impeachment inquiry, suggesting a possible legal challenge through the courts.

Finally, the court is set to hear a case that could involve the 2020 election, testing the constitutionality of "faithless elector" laws, which impose penalties on Electoral College delegates who refuse to vote for the presidential candidate of their designated party. There have been 167 faithless electors in U.S. history, and in no case has the outcome of an election turned on their vote. However, there is no guarantee that this won't happen in 2020.

Title: Coca-Cola Explores Potential Entry into CBD-Infused Beverage Market

Article:

Coca-Cola (KO) has expressed interest in the growing market for cannabis-infused drinks, specifically CBD, a non-psychoactive component of marijuana, as an ingredient in functional wellness beverages. In a statement on Monday, the company stated it is "closely watching" the growth of CBD. No decisions have been made at this time.

CBD, which does not produce a high for the user, has been used for medical purposes, including easing inflammation, pain, and nausea. Coke's interest was first reported by Bloomberg, which said the company was in talks with Aurora Cannabis, a Canadian cannabis company. Aurora Cannabis has also expressed interest in cannabis drinks. Neither company would comment on a possible deal.

Constellation Brands (STZ), the maker of Corona beer, Svedka vodka, and Casa Noble tequila, announced last month that it is investing an additional $4 billion in the Canadian cannabis company Canopy Growth (CGC). A number of Canadian cannabis companies, including Cronos (CRON) and MedMen Enterprises (MMNFF), now trade on US stock exchanges, and some American companies have taken stakes.

Lagunitas, a craft beer label of brewing giant Heineken (HEINY), already has a drink infused with THC, marijuana's active ingredient, which does produce a high. It can be purchased at marijuana dispensaries in California.

Both cannabis and CBD are still illegal in the United States under federal law, even though a number of states have legalized marijuana. However, the prohibition against CBD is not strictly enforced. There are third-party sellers offering CBD-based products on Amazon (AMZN), for example.

Kris Krane, president of 4Front, a firm that advises companies on the legalities of marijuana and an expert on cannabis law, stated it is unlikely that a major company like Coca-Cola would offer a product infused with CBD in the United States until the federal law changes. He expects Coke would develop the product first for sale in Canada, readying it for the US market once it's legal.

Bonnie Herzog, analyst with Wells Fargo, stated in a note to clients Monday that Coke is positioning itself for the long-term. She said in a note to clients Monday that Coke is positioning itself for the long-term. She estimates that cannabis-infused drinks could become a $50 billion annual market in the United States -- nearly half the size of the $117 billion market for US beer sales.

Both Coke and rival Pepsico have been trying to expand their businesses beyond traditional soft drinks as people drink less soda due to health concerns. Just last week, Coke announced a deal to buy Costa Coffee for $5 billion. Canada is in the process of legalizing recreational use of marijuana. The drug is still illegal under US federal law, although some states have decriminalized it. In June, the US Food and Drug Administration approved the epilepsy treatment Epidiolex, the first cannabis-based drug allowed in the United States. It includes CBD as well.

Title: President Trump's Tweet on Minneapolis Protests Removed by Twitter for Violating Rules on Glorifying Violence

Article:

President Donald Trump's tweet about the ongoing protests in Minneapolis, Minnesota, was removed by Twitter on Friday, May 29, for violating the platform's rules on glorifying violence. The tweet, which was in response to the second night of protests sparked by the death of George Floyd, a Black man who died in police custody, stated, "These THUGS are dishonoring the memory of George Floyd, and I won’t let that happen. Just spoke to Governor Tim Walz and told him that the Military is with him all the way. Any difficulty and we will assume control but, when the looting starts, the shooting starts. Thank you!"

Twitter's statement regarding the removal of the tweet read, "This Tweet violated the Twitter Rules about glorifying violence. However, Twitter has determined that it may be in the public's interest for the Tweet to remain accessible."

The removal of the tweet sparked controversy, with some arguing that it was a clear example of Twitter's alleged bias and selective enforcement of its rules. The White House responded to the removal of the tweet, stating, "The President did not glorify violence. He clearly condemned it."

The protests in Minneapolis have been ongoing since the death of George Floyd, who was arrested for a false document charge and died after a police officer knelt on his neck for nearly ten minutes. All four officers involved in the incident have been fired, and the Department of Justice and the Federal Bureau of Investigation are investigating the incident for civil rights violations.

Minneapolis Mayor Jacob Frey has been criticized for his handling of the situation, with President Trump tweeting, "I can’t stand back & watch this happen to a great American City, Minneapolis. A total lack of leadership. Either the very weak Radical Left Mayor, Jacob Frey, get his act together and bring the City under control, or I will send in the National Guard & get the job done right."

The removal of President Trump's tweet has added fuel to the ongoing debate about the role of social media companies in shaping public discourse and their responsibility to regulate content on their platforms. Twitter has been criticized for its alleged bias and selective enforcement of its rules, particularly in relation to conservative voices. The company has defended its actions, stating that it aims to promote healthy and respectful conversations on its platform.

Title: Border Patrol Union Leader Criticizes National Guard Deployment as 'Colossal Waste of Resources'

Article:

The National Border Patrol Council's president, Brandon Judd, has criticized the deployment of National Guard troops to the Mexican border, stating it has been a "colossal waste of resources." According to the Los Angeles Times, Judd, who leads a union with 15,000 members, initially supported the deployment but has since expressed dissatisfaction with its execution.

Judd argued that the current deployment of troops to the border is not comparable to similar deployments under the Obama or Bush administrations. He stated, "They were allowed to do a lot more than they are under the Trump administration." During previous administrations, troops were permitted to perform tasks such as manning lookout and observation posts, grading roads, and mending fences, which Judd claims freed up Border Patrol agents.

However, Judd and union spokesman Chris Cabrera contend that the troops are now stationed far from the border and are working alongside agents, creating additional work and not freeing up agents for patrols as intended.

A Pentagon official, who remained unnamed, told the LA Times that state governors determine the terms of National Guard troops' usage at the border. The official disagreed with Judd's characterization of the National Guard's usage, stating, "It has not been a significant change under George Bush, Obama, and now Trump. They're different in how they're perceived. They're no different in what they're doing."

Acting Border Patrol Chief Carla Provost argued that the National Guard presence does free up some agents. Typically, pairs of agents operate aerostat blimps to monitor the border remotely, and now troops can replace one person on those teams, freeing up agents to be on the front line.

Homeland Security spokeswoman Katie Waldman stated that the operation is not yet at full capacity, with more troops expected after a third request for assistance was recently approved. President Donald Trump's plan called for 2,000 to 4,000 National Guard troops from nearby states to support Border Patrol operations.

Title: Rescue of Trapped Thai Soccer Team Continues Amidst Monsoon Season Challenges

Article:

The rescue of four young soccer players and their coach from a flooded cave in Thailand's Chiang Rai province is ongoing, with the team still trapped more than 2 miles into the Earth. The rescue operation, which began on Sunday, has been met with global admiration and support.

Eight boys, ages 11-16, and their 25-year-old coach were found in the Tham Luang cave complex on June 23, but heavy rainfall and storms have complicated the rescue efforts. Chiang Rai Governor Narongsak Osottanakorn announced that further rescues would be temporarily halted for 10-20 hours to allow the dive teams to rest and resupply the cave complex with oxygen and other necessary equipment.

The first of the four boys was extracted at 5:40 p.m. local time on Sunday, with the other three following over the next two hours. The boys, who cannot swim, were escorted through the cave by two divers each. The boys were placed in ambulances and given medical assessments before being transported to Chiang Rai Prachanukroh hospital, approximately 30 miles away.

The rescue operation is expected to continue through Monday, with the progress depending on weather conditions and the cave's internal conditions. The boys and their coach entered the cave complex on June 23 for a soccer practice and became trapped when heavy rains flooded some of the narrow tunnels.

An Australian doctor with cave diving experience examined the boys on Sunday and declared them fit for the operation. "Today is D-Day," Narongsak said as the operation began. "The boys are healthy, aware, and ready to come out."

The rescue effort has garnered international attention, with SpaceX CEO Elon Musk expressing admiration for the team's resilience on Twitter. British media have closely followed the events, and the story was the most-read on France's Le Monde and made the front page of China's state-run Xinhua news website.

The boys and their coach have remained calm and reassuring in handwritten notes to their families, with one boy, identified as Tun, writing, "Mom and Dad, please don't worry, I am fine. I've told Yod to get ready to take me out for fried chicken. With love."

Residents of the nearby town of Mae Sai, directly on the border with Myanmar about 7 miles away from the cave entrance, have followed the saga of the boys' disappearance and rescue efforts intently.

Title: Empirical Analysis Reveals Media Bias: A Look at Recent Research on Media Bias in U.S. Media

Article:

In a recent podcast titled "How Biased Is Your Media?", the hosts delve into the debate surrounding media bias in the United States. The podcast, available for download on iTunes, via RSS feed, or through a live media player, features a variety of media practitioners and academic scholars discussing media bias.

One of the key studies mentioned in the podcast is a 2004 paper by Tim Groseclose and Jeff Milyo, which aimed to measure media bias. The paper served as the foundation for Groseclose's book "Left Turn: How Liberal Media Bias Distorts the American Mind."

Groseclose's methodology involved analyzing the think tanks mentioned in media outlets' stories and comparing them to the think tanks referenced by elected officials when speaking on the House or Senate floor. The results showed that most media outlets have a liberal bias, with the Wall Street Journal being the most liberal, even surpassing the New York Times. Fox News was found to be one of the few outlets that lean right.

The following is a list of 20 major media outlets and their positions on the slant scale, with 100 representing the most liberal and zero the most conservative:

1. ABC Good Morning America: 56.1
2. ABC World News Tonight: 61.0
3. CBS Early Show: 66.6
4. CBS Evening News: 73.7
5. CNN NewsNight with Aaron Brown: 56.0
6. Drudge Report: 60.4
7. Fox News Special Report with Brit Hume: 39.7
8. Los Angeles Times: 70.0
9. NBC Nightly News: 61.6
10. NBC Today Show: 64.0
11. New York Times: 73.7
12. Newshour with Jim Lehrer: 55.8
13. Newsweek: 66.3
14. NPR Morning Edition: 66.3
15. Time Magazine: 65.4
16. U.S. News and World Report: 65.8
17. USA Today: 63.4
18. Wall Street Journal: 85.1
19. Washington Post: 66.6
20. Washington Times: 35.4

Another study mentioned in the podcast is a 2010 study by University of Chicago economists Matthew Gentzkow and Jesse Shapiro. They used text analysis to determine the political leanings of newspapers and the reasons behind their biases by looking at common Democratic and Republican phrases in Congress. Further details about this study were not provided in the podcast.

Listeners can find out their own "Political Quotients" (PQ) by taking a quiz available online. The PQ scale, with 100 representing the most liberal and zero the most conservative, was also mentioned in the podcast, but specific details about the scale and its calculation were not provided.

Title: Senate Confirms Tom Price as Health and Human Services Secretary in 2 a.m. Vote

Article:

The United States Senate confirmed Rep. Tom Price (R-Ga.) to serve as secretary of Health and Human Services during a 2 a.m. vote on Friday. The vote was 52-47, with no Democratic senator supporting Price.

Price overcame an initial procedural hurdle on Wednesday evening along party lines. With the Republican Party holding a 52-seat majority in the Senate and only a simple majority required, Democrats do not have the manpower to block any nominees on their own.

Democrats signaled early on that Price would be a top target due to his support for dismantling the Affordable Care Act and overhauling Medicare. Senate Minority Leader Charles Schumer (D-N.Y.) stated, "Make no mistake: In the dark hours of the early morning, with the confirmation of Secretary Price, the Republicans launch the first assault in the war on seniors."

Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) called Price, who has previously backed privatizing Medicare, the "exact opposite" of what President Trump campaigned on. Democrats argue that Price's positions are out of line with Trump's campaign promises, which included not cutting entitlement programs.

Price, who was chairman of the House Budget Committee when nominated, stated late last year that Republicans would move to overhaul Medicare within six to eight months of Trump's inauguration. He also voiced support in 2015 for a proposal to reduce Medicare costs by delivering benefits through a voucher program.

Democrats are expected to use the vote on Price, and his position on Medicare, to target Sens. Dean Heller (Nev.) and Jeff Flake (Ariz.) – two Republicans up for reelection in 2018.

Price faced a rocky confirmation battle, also coming under fire for a growing number of reports about his stock trading as a member of Congress. CNN and Time reported last month that he had invested in health-related companies shortly before introducing or supporting legislation that benefited them. Price denied wrongdoing, adding that he made the investments through a broker.

Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.) – in her first floor speech since she was temporarily banned from speaking on Tuesday night – said Price should be disqualified for "basic ethics." "He should have withdrawn his nomination weeks ago, and if he didn't go voluntarily, the president and his friends in Congress should have quietly but forcefully pushed him out," she said.

The Wall Street Journal also reported last month that he received a 12 percent discount on his purchase of biomedical stock.

Republicans never publicly signaled that they were wavering on Price. They believe getting him confirmed is key to syncing up with the White House on the plan to repeal and replace ObamaCare. Trump and congressional Republicans, as well as House and Senate lawmakers, have at times struggled to get on the same page about a timeline for repealing ObamaCare or how to replace it.

Senate Majority Whip John Cornyn (R-Texas) said Thursday that he hopes confirming Price will speed up the process. "After seven years we've got all kinds of great ideas, but we have to come together behind one," he told reporters.

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) praised Price separately as the "right man" for leading the department. "Price knows more about health care policy than just about anyone. He doesn't just understand health care policy as a policy maker … he also understands it as a practicing physician," he said. "He gets the real-world impact."

Title: Obama and Boehner Remain Silent as Sequester Deadline Approaches

Article:

As the budget deadline of Friday looms, Washington is witnessing a unique standoff between President Barack Obama and House Speaker John Boehner. Unlike previous budget battles, there is no sense of urgency to resolve the issue.

Since Thursday, Obama and Boehner have not communicated, and Boehner and Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid have not met since January 21. However, a meeting has been scheduled for Friday at the White House, involving Obama, Boehner, Reid, Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell, and House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi. This meeting coincides with the day the sequester is set to take effect.

The sequester, a series of across-the-board spending cuts, will indeed proceed as planned, despite previous statements from both Obama and Boehner. The cuts, which Obama had stated would not occur, and Boehner had promised his members would be avoided, will now take place.

Instead of negotiating and inching closer together, the sides are moving further apart. Obama has called for slashing tax loopholes to offset the cuts, while Boehner has suggested closing loopholes as part of tax reform that would lower rates and create jobs.

The Senate is expected to pass a bill this week to increase taxes on high-income earners. If it passes the Senate and the 60-vote threshold, it is unlikely to pass the House. Boehner has stated that the House should not have to pass its sequester replacement bill again before the Senate "gets off their ass" and passes a bill.

The crux of the problem lies in the fact that neither bill would pass the other chamber. Furthermore, the House will depart on Friday, the same day the cuts take effect.

The Republican party finds itself in a state of confusion, grappling with a mix of messaging about Obama crafting the sequester, the cuts being damaging but also deserving praise for finally reducing spending by at least 2 percent.

Boehner and his team believe they are in a favorable position, with Obama advocating for tax increases to mitigate damaging cuts to the Pentagon, while Boehner stands for spending cuts.

This week, Boehner has expressed support for the most significant bipartisan endeavor: tax reform. He has even assigned the leadership's most prized bill title, H.R. 1, to rewriting the Tax Code.

"Dave Camp, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, is continuing a thoughtful and thorough review of the Tax Code with an eye on tax reform," Boehner said at the CUNA convention, according to prepared remarks. "It's time we shift the balance of power from the tax collector to the taxpayer."

Title: Former North Charleston Officer Michael Slager Sentenced to 20 Years for Murder of Walter Scott

Article:

In a Charleston courtroom on Thursday, former North Charleston police officer Michael Slager was sentenced to 20 years in prison for the 2015 murder of Walter Scott, an unarmed black man. The ruling, made by U.S. District Judge David Norton, classified the killing as second-degree murder and obstruction of justice.

Slager, 36, was a patrolman in North Charleston when he pulled over Scott, a father of four, for a broken brake light on April 4, 2015. He pleaded guilty in May to violating Scott's civil rights by using excessive force, a charge that carried a possible lifetime prison sentence. Slager shot at Scott eight times, hitting him five times.

State prosecutors dropped the murder charge in exchange for the federal plea. The case gained national attention due to a bystander's cellphone video of the shooting, which renewed concerns about police treatment of minorities. The footage was a central piece of evidence during the four-day sentencing hearing.

Judge Norton rejected the defense's argument that Slager was provoked or acted in the heat of passion. Slager, dressed in an inmate's gray and white jumpsuit, expressed remorse during the hearing, stating, "I wish I could go back and change events, but I can't and I am very sorry for that."

Scott's relatives and their lawyers hailed the sentence as a historic moment for justice. They called on law enforcement to reconsider the use of deadly force. Before court adjourned, several family members expressed forgiveness towards Slager, but their pain remains. Anthony Scott, Walter Scott's older brother, questioned, "How could someone shoot someone in the back like that as they were running away?"

Title: Romney's Response to Diplomatic Crisis Sparks Controversy, Draws Comparisons to Carter Era

Article:

Mitt Romney's political response to the attacks on American diplomatic posts in Egypt and Libya on Tuesday has sparked controversy, with critics from both the left and right accusing him of attempting to portray President Barack Obama as a successor to former President Jimmy Carter.

In an election that has primarily focused on domestic issues, the foreign-policy crisis has introduced a new element, reminiscent of the Iranian hostage situation that made Carter appear weak and ineffectual during the 1980 presidential elections.

"The 2012 election is similar to 1980, when you had a foreign crisis in the Mideast and a bad economy at home," said Mike Duncan, chairman of American Crossroads and former Republican National Committee Chairman.

Foreign policy had been considered a strong point for President Obama heading into the election. He had wound down the war in Iraq, overseen American efforts to help oust Libyan strongman Moammar Gadhafi, and had approved the daring attack that killed terrorist mastermind Osama bin Laden.

However, the diplomatic post attacks—including another overnight in Yemen—provide images, such as an American ambassador's body being dragged in the street, that could fuel comparisons.

David Lane, founder of the California-based Pastors and Pews, said, "America's 39th president was the last president who created such instability with the U.S. economy and foreign policy: the byproduct was turmoil in the world. Barack Obama, meet Jimmy Carter."

Democrats have rejected the comparison, and President Obama was critical of the way Mr. Romney has handled the situation, saying the Republican candidate has a tendency to "shoot first and aim later."

"As president you can't do that," Mr. Obama told CBS News in an interview the White House read out to reporters traveling with the president on Wednesday.

Some Republicans distanced themselves from Mr. Romney's remarks, which accused the administration of blaming Americans' exercise of free speech rather than the attackers. That criticism was based on a statement issued by the U.S. Embassy in Egypt.

However, other analysts defended Mr. Romney's handling of the situation.

"Romney's condemnation of the apology wasn't embarrassing or too early; it was correct, it was timely, and the only beef commentators have with it is that the White House didn't issue it first," said Danielle Pletka, American Enterprise Institute vice president for foreign- and defense-policy studies.

"The White House still doesn't get it," Ms. Pletka said. "Look no farther than the difference between the Obama and [Secretary of State Hillary Rodham] Clinton statements—Obama equivocates and Clinton condemns."

She noted that Mr. Obama said, "While the United States rejects efforts to denigrate the religious beliefs of others, we must all unequivocally oppose the kind of senseless violence that took the lives of these public servants."

Title: Kerry's Surprising Success as Secretary of State: A Year of Diplomatic Achievements

Article:

In the first year of John Kerry's tenure as Secretary of State, he has been widely regarded as having transcended expectations, making significant progress in restoring diplomacy as a central component of U.S. foreign policy. David Rothkopf, a prominent commentator, suggests that Kerry's legacy will be determined by the outcomes of ongoing negotiations in Iran, Syria, and the Israel-Palestinian conflict.

Kerry's success is particularly noteworthy given the challenges he faced at the beginning of 2013. As a familiar face in politics, Kerry was entering a role traditionally overshadowed by the President, and was tasked with addressing complex and often intractable international issues at a time when U.S. interest in overseas engagement was low.

Despite these challenges, Kerry has been praised for his creativity, tenacity, and courage. He has won widespread acclaim for his efforts to restore diplomacy to the center of U.S. foreign policy, and for his willingness to take risks, such as his tireless travel schedule, mastery of facts, and forceful personality.

Kerry's impact has been felt in several key areas. In the Middle East, he has been credited with making significant strides in the Israel-Palestine peace process, and in Syria, where he brokered a chemical weapons deal. In Iran, Kerry has been instrumental in the ongoing nuclear negotiations.

However, the success of Kerry's initiatives remains uncertain. The outcomes of the Iran deal, the Syria chemical weapons deal, and the Israel-Palestine peace process will determine the lasting impact of Kerry's tenure. The progress made in these areas will be crucial in determining Kerry's legacy and the Obama administration's foreign policy record.

As Rothkopf notes, the challenges ahead are significant. The success of the Iran deal, the pace of disarmament in Syria, and the prospects for peace between Israel and Palestine remain uncertain. The decay in Iraq and the future of Afghanistan, the spread of extremist groups, and the need for modernization of U.S. alliances are among the many challenges that Kerry and the Obama administration must address in the coming years.

In conclusion, while Kerry has had a remarkable year and has been an invaluable asset for the United States, his legacy and that of the President he serves will be determined by the opportunities he has helped create and the outcomes of the negotiations he has initiated. The coming years will be crucial in determining the success of Kerry's diplomatic efforts and the future of U.S. foreign policy.

Title: Trump Administration's Response to Coronavirus Raises Questions on Public Confidence

Article:

The Trump administration's response to the coronavirus has raised concerns about its preparedness and effectiveness, potentially impacting public confidence in President Trump as the risk of a pandemic increases. The administration's approach has given the impression of being in a state of disarray, as demonstrated by last night's coronavirus press conference.

During the briefing, President Trump expressed surprise at the deadliness of the annual flu virus while emphasizing the importance of following public health officials' advice to treat the coronavirus like the flu. However, he downplayed the likelihood of a widespread U.S. outbreak, contradicting statements from public health officials, including the CDC, who have indicated a widespread outbreak is likely.

A new U.S. case, potentially indicating a local transmission and a key indicator of a potential pandemic, was confirmed during the press conference. "This is such a s--tshow. Thank goodness the markets are closed," a former Health and Human Services official who is close to the White House reportedly said during the briefing.

Sources familiar with the decision report that the appointment of Vice President Mike Pence to lead the administration's coronavirus response was made only yesterday. The decision had been a subject of discussion among staff, but it was unclear how many, if any, officials knew about the announcement beforehand. Several people were reportedly shocked, particularly given that Pence is heavily involved in Trump's re-election campaign.

Trump's statements during the press conference were more upbeat compared to what public health officials have been saying, which some attribute to his concern for the stock market. Trump has also reportedly warned Health and Human Services Secretary Alex Azar, as well as other officials, to avoid criticizing China's response to the virus. "They have enough problems without you going out and saying they’re not doing enough," Trump said to Azar, according to a source familiar with their conversation.

Our thought bubble: Trump appears to want the panic over the virus to end as soon as possible to restore normalcy to the markets.

Title: NSA Intelligence-Gathering Programs Under Scrutiny: Details on PRISM and Phone Records Collection

Article:

The Obama administration is facing criticism and questions regarding two secret National Security Agency (NSA) intelligence-gathering programs following leaked documents that revealed details about the collection of phone records and Internet data.

The Guardian newspaper reported that authorities were collecting phone records from millions of individuals. A separate Washington Post report detailed another program, code-named PRISM, which scours major Internet companies such as Google, Facebook, and Apple for data. A former senior NSA official confirmed to Fox News that the PRISM program, started in 2007 by the FBI and NSA, allows them to tap into top U.S. Internet companies to pull audio, video, and other data.

Director of National Intelligence James Clapper issued a statement late Thursday, decrying the leak of the materials and stating that the phone-records monitoring leak could cause harm to the nation's intelligence gathering activities. Clapper also took the rare step of moving to declassify information about the programs as he sought to defend them against criticism.

Clapper stated that the government is "prohibited from indiscriminately sifting through the telephony metadata acquired under the program." He also noted that all information acquired is subject to strict, court-imposed restrictions on review and handling. The court only allows the data to be queried when there is a reasonable suspicion, based on specific facts, that the particular basis for the query is associated with a foreign terrorist organization.

A senior administration official also pushed back, stating that the Guardian and Washington Post articles about the Internet mining refer to collection under a law that "does not allow the targeting of any U.S. citizen or of any person located within the United States." It was not immediately clear how the official defined "targeting."

The PRISM program, according to the Washington Post, accounts for nearly one in seven intelligence reports. The companies that participate in the program, including Microsoft, Yahoo, Google, Facebook, PalTalk, AOL, Skype, YouTube, and Apple, reportedly only comply when legally bound to do so.

According to slides from an internal presentation obtained by the Washington Post, there has been "continued exponential growth in tasking to Facebook and Skype." The Washington Post report also states that with a few clicks and an affirmation that the subject is believed to be engaged in terrorism, espionage, or nuclear proliferation, an analyst obtains full access to Facebook's extensive search and surveillance capabilities. Skype and Google services can also be monitored for various activities.

Google and Facebook have issued statements saying they only comply with data requests in accordance with the law. Both companies emphasize that they do not provide government organizations with direct access to their servers and only provide information when required by law. Microsoft also stated that it only provides customer data after receiving a legally binding order or subpoena.

Title: U.S. and U.N. General Assembly Diverge in Voting Practices, Raising Concerns for Trump Administration

Article:

As President Donald Trump prepares to address the United Nations General Assembly this week, a new State Department report reveals that the world body is out of alignment with U.S. interests in more than two-thirds of votes, potentially raising further concerns within the Trump administration regarding the organization and America's financial commitment to it.

According to the report on voting practices at the U.N. in 2018, the U.S. and the U.N. General Assembly were in agreement only 31% of the time, a decrease from the final year of the Obama administration when they were in agreement 41% of the time. This means that the U.S. voted against 70% of assembly resolutions requiring a vote, more than any other U.N. member state.

The report, which is congressionally mandated, reviewed voting by the 15 members of the U.N. Security Council and 193 members of the General Assembly, and compared countries' voting records with the U.S. An additional section focused on how the world body votes on Israel.

In 2018, former U.S. Ambassador to the U.N. Nikki Haley stated that the U.S. would be "taking names" of countries that vote against U.S. interests, particularly in regard to Israel. Trump also warned that the administration was watching votes, specifically from those that take U.S. money.

The 10 countries that are most out of sync with the U.S. (along with U.S. aid they received in fiscal 2018, according to the USAID website) are: Burundi ($69 million), Syria ($819 million), North Korea ($2.6 million), Turkmenistan ($4.5 million), Venezuela ($25 million), Nicaragua ($30 million), Niger ($573 million), Cuba ($12 million), and Iran (less than $1 million).

Afghanistan, which received about $760 million, only voted with the U.S. 19% of the time. Pakistan, which gets $370 million, voted only 15% of the time with the U.S. Jordan, which gets $1.2 billion, was 21% in alignment with the U.S.

However, the U.S. still enjoys support from some allies. The 10 friendliest records in descending order are: Israel, Micronesia, Canada, Australia, Marshall Islands, Great Britain, Hungary, France, Poland, and the Czech Republic.

In 2018, Haley noted that the U.S. pays for more than a fifth of the U.N. budget, more than the next three highest donor nations combined. She stated at the issuing of the last report on 2017 voting records that "this is not an acceptable return on our investment."

An analysis by the Council on Foreign Relations found that the U.S. government contributed more than $10 billion to the United Nations in 2017 - about $7 billion was voluntary and $3.5 billion was assessed.

Since then, the U.S. has pulled out of a number of U.N. institutions, including the controversial Human Rights Council and the U.N. Social, Cultural and Economic body (UNESCO). It also yanked funding from the U.N. Palestinian refugee agency.

The report also found that the U.N. General Assembly is largely continuing in its anti-Israel slant, adopting 21 anti-Israel resolutions in 2018, the same amount as 2017. The U.S. supported these resolutions just 14% of the time.

It was perhaps with this in mind that new U.N. Ambassador Kelly Craft gave a fiery speech at the U.N. Security Council last week, slamming anti-Israel bias at the body and reasserting U.S. commitment to its ally.

"It is inexcusable that pervasive, anti-Israel bias still exists in the United Nations, and that we continue to witness attempts by some UN Member States to undermine Israel’s standing as a full member of the community of nations," she said. "The United States vigorously opposes all such efforts."

Israel's Ambassador Danny Danon told Fox News that while anti-Israel bias remains, the "needle is moving" in the right direction and pointed to instances such as the U.S.-sponsored resolution condemning Hamas last year. The resolution garnered a simple majority of support in the chamber but did not gain the two-thirds majority needed to pass.

"The resolution against Hamas, for example, is a notable success because, for the first time, a majority of member states supported condemning the group and labeling it a terrorist organization," he told Fox News. "And there are many more successes that are taking place outside of GA and UNSC resolutions, but will begin to influence them in the years to come."

Trump will address the General Assembly on Tuesday, when the issues of both Israel and value for money at the U.N. are likely to be addressed in his speech.

Title: Leaks in Manchester Terror Attack Investigation and White House Leaks Compared

Article:

The National Police Chiefs' Council in Britain has condemned the unauthorized disclosure of potential evidence in the ongoing Manchester terror attack investigation, stating that it constitutes a breach of trust and undermines investigations, as well as the confidence of victims, witnesses, and their families. The disclosure has caused distress for families already suffering from their loss, according to Manchester's top police official, Chief Constable Ian Hopkins.

Earlier reports suggested that the Manchester police had ceased sharing details of the investigation with American counterparts, but this was later clarified after Prime Minister Theresa May received assurances from President Donald Trump. The police have resumed intelligence sharing, though it is unclear if it had actually stopped initially.

Mark Rowley, an assistant commissioner in charge of counterterrorism at Scotland Yard and a member of the Police Chiefs' Council, emphasized that they are working closely with international law enforcement partners, including those in the 'Five Eyes' intelligence alliance, which includes the United States, Britain, New Zealand, Australia, and Canada.

In a separate matter, President Trump's handling of leaks has been inconsistent, with him capitalizing on disclosures during his presidential campaign but expressing frustration with information leaking from his own White House. Details of his conversations with Russian officials, as well as leaders of Mexico, Australia, and the Philippines, have been leaked to the public. Leaked information about a telephone call between Michael T. Flynn, his first national security adviser, and Russia's ambassador led to Flynn's dismissal.

Recent leaks about President Trump's private conversations with and about James B. Comey, the FBI director he fired, have fueled investigations into his associates' ties with Russia. After The Times reported that Trump had asked Comey to halt an investigation into Michael Flynn, the Justice Department felt compelled to appoint a special counsel to take over the Russia investigation.

The article does not provide specific details about the nature of the leaked information in the Manchester terror attack investigation or the White House leaks, as it is unavailable. The article also does not express personal opinions or take a political stance on the matter.

Title: Missouri Governor Plans to Sign Bill Banning Most Abortions After Eight Weeks

Article:

Missouri's Republican Governor, Mike Parson, is expected to sign a bill that would ban most abortions in the state after the eighth week of pregnancy. The bill, which was approved by the Republican-controlled state legislature last week, would enact one of the United States' most restrictive abortion bans.

Governor Parson announced his intention to sign the bill to reporters on Friday, but has not yet set a date for the signing. He has until July 14 to sign the bill, according to local media reports.

Missouri is one of eight states where Republican-controlled legislatures have passed new restrictions on abortion this year. This coordinated campaign is aimed at prompting the conservative-majority U.S. Supreme Court to cut back or overturn the 1973 Roe v. Wade decision that established a woman's right to terminate a pregnancy.

The most restrictive of these bills was signed into law in Alabama last week, banning abortion at all times and in almost all cases, including when the pregnancy resulted from rape or incest, but allowing exceptions when the mother's life is in danger. The Missouri bill also offers no exception for cases of rape or incest.

The American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) has stated it will sue to block Alabama's law from taking effect. Last week, the ACLU joined Planned Parenthood, the women's reproductive healthcare provider, in suing Ohio over its recent six-week abortion ban. Mississippi will defend a new law banning abortion once a fetal heartbeat has been detected in a federal appeals court on Tuesday after the Center for Reproductive Rights sued to block it taking effect.

Abortion is one of the most bitterly contested social issues in the United States. Opponents often cite religious belief in saying that fetuses deserve rights similar to those of infants. Abortion rights advocates say the bans deprive women of equal rights and endanger those who end up seeking riskier, illegal methods to end a pregnancy.

Kentucky, Georgia, Utah, Mississippi, and Arkansas have also passed new restrictions on abortion this year. Conservative lawmakers have been emboldened in their efforts to roll back Roe v. Wade by two judicial appointments by President Donald Trump that have given conservatives a 5-4 majority on the Supreme Court.

The court on Monday took no action on appeals seeking to revive two abortion restrictions enacted in Indiana in 2016.

Title: NATO Members Increase Defense Spending in Response to U.S. Pressure

Article:

NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg appeared on Fox Business Network's "Mornings with Maria" and discussed the increase in defense spending by NATO members in response to President Trump's insistence on fair burden-sharing. Stoltenberg confirmed that the target for defense spending is to be at 2% of GDP by 2024, with many allies already meeting or exceeding this goal.

During the interview, Stoltenberg stated that President Trump and he have a close working relationship due to their shared concerns about terrorism and the importance of fair burden-sharing within the NATO alliance. He also acknowledged that European allies and Canada have increased their defense spending, making NATO stronger.

In July 2018, President Trump expressed frustration with what he perceived as disproportionate financial contributions from NATO members during a speech at the alliance. He stated that prior to his first meeting with NATO leaders, the amount of money being spent by countries was decreasing, but now, it is increasing substantially. Trump also tweeted that all NATO nations must meet their 2% commitment and that it should ultimately go up to 4%.

According to a December 2019 article from Business Insider, NATO agreed in 2014 that each member state would increase their own defense spending to 2% of their respective GDP by 2024. Since 2014, several countries, including Estonia, Romania, Lithuania, Latvia, Poland, and Bulgaria, have reached or exceeded the goal. Other nations such as Turkey, France, and Norway are close to meeting the target. The United States still provides the most, with 3.42% of its GDP spent on defense, according to a NATO report.

Speaking before a joint session of Congress in April 2019, Stoltenberg stated that NATO allies must spend more on defense and that the increase in defense spending is making NATO stronger. He added that the additional funds would allow for investments in new capabilities, including advanced fighter aircraft, attack helicopters, missile defense, and surveillance drones. This, he said, is beneficial for Europe and America.

Title: Virginia Delegate Proposes Bill Mandating Licensing for AR-15 Ownership

Article:

Delegate Mark Levine (D) has introduced a bill in Virginia that would require all AR-15 owners to acquire a state license for ownership. Those who do not comply with this requirement and continue to possess AR-15s would be classified as felons.

The legislation, HB 961, applies to AR-15s and firearms that Democrats refer to as "assault firearms." According to Levine, an "assault firearm" is defined as "a semi-automatic center-fire rifle that expels single or multiple projectiles by action of an explosion of a combustible material with a fixed magazine capacity in excess of 10 rounds."

The bill also outlines certain cosmetic traits that classify a gun as an "assault firearm." These traits include a folding or telescoping stock, a pistol grip that protrudes conspicuously beneath the action of the rifle, a thumbhole stock, a second handgrip or a protruding grip that can be held by the non-trigger hand, a bayonet mount, a grenade launcher, a flare launcher, a silencer, a flash suppressor, a muzzle brake, a muzzle compensator, a threaded barrel capable of accepting a silencer, flash suppressor, muzzle brake, or muzzle compensator, or any characteristic of like kind as enumerated in clauses (i) through (xii).

If Delegate Levine's bill passes the state legislature and is signed into law, current AR-15 owners, and owners of other so-called "assault firearms," will have a grace period in which to acquire a license from the state. According to the bill's summary, "any person who legally owns an assault firearm on July 1, 2020, may retain possession of such assault firearm after January 1, 2021, if such person has obtained a permit from the Department of State Police to possess an assault firearm in accordance with procedures established in the bill."

Title: Gun Control Legislation Faces Challenges in Congress Despite Public Support

Article:

Following President Barack Obama's pledge to push for new gun control laws in the aftermath of the Newtown, Connecticut, massacre, there has been a significant decline in public support for stricter gun laws. According to various polls, support for stricter gun laws has dropped from 57 percent to 47 percent (CBS News), 52 percent to 43 percent (CNN), and 54 percent to 52 percent (ABC News/Washington Post).

Despite the president's efforts, including rallies, using children as props, and holding events with parents of the Newtown victims, the proposed gun control measures, such as the assault weapons ban and limits on magazine size, have faced opposition in Congress. The current focus is on expanding background checks, although any bill that can pass both the Senate and the House will likely be less extensive than what the president or his supporters desire.

The decline in public support for gun control legislation and the challenges in Congress have raised questions about President Obama's legislative acumen and his ability to shape public opinion. Some argue that the president may have overestimated the support for his proposals and failed to consult with key legislators, such as Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, about the plausibility of his proposals.
