This is not the first time President Obama has faced criticism for his legislative strategy and his disconnect with Congress. In 2010, he held a ribbon-cutting ceremony with National Rifle Association (NRA) executive Wayne LaPierre at the Clark County Shooting Park in Las Vegas.

It is worth noting that 90 percent of Americans support universal background checks, a measure that even the NRA supports, albeit with a focus on improving state record-keeping. The ongoing debate highlights the complexities of gun control legislation and the challenges of balancing public safety with Second Amendment rights.

Title: GOP Debate Highlights: Carly Fiorina's Dominant Performance, Rand Paul's Marijuana Comment, and Ben Carson's Vaccine Remarks

Article:

The second Republican presidential debate, featuring 11 candidates, including Carly Fiorina who was moved from the "kids table" debate due to a change in CNN's eligibility criteria, took place for three hours. The discussion covered a wide range of topics, including immigration, vaccinations, and foreign policy.

Carly Fiorina made a strong impact in the first third of the debate, demonstrating her foreign policy knowledge and qualifications. She seamlessly integrated Iran and pro-life issues in one coherent response. Fiorina also displayed tact in her response to Donald Trump's "look at that face" comment from the previous week, stating, "Women all over this country heard very clearly what Mr. Trump said."

One of the most viral moments of the night occurred when Sen. Rand Paul called out Gov. Jeb Bush for his past marijuana use and his reluctance to support marijuana legalization. Bush admitted to smoking marijuana, and an argument over marijuana legalization ensued.

Sen. Marco Rubio had a decent performance, presenting coherent and logical arguments on immigration and immigration reform. Rubio emphasized the need for sensible immigration reform to fix the current system, which he described as "no longer working." He also advocated for a merit-based system.

New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie was more lively and focused than in the first debate. He defended President Bush's invasion of Afghanistan, citing his family's personal experience on September 11, 2001, and his work as a prosecutor.

One of the most perplexing moments of the night came when Dr. Ben Carson and Donald Trump discussed vaccines. When asked to tell Trump to stop stating that vaccines cause autism (they do not), Carson seemed to waffle and did not directly condemn Trump's comments.

Katie, in her analysis, noted that Bush and Gov. Scott Walker did not have many memorable lines, but their tag-team exchange defending George W. Bush's policies was a highlight.

Title: Emmy Awards Ratings Drop to Potential Lowest-Rated Telecast Ever Amid Political Attacks

Article:

The 69th annual Emmy Awards have reported a decline in ratings, with an 8.2 overnight rating among metered market households, a 2.4 percent drop from the 2016 edition. This could potentially make it the lowest-rated Emmy telecast ever, although the final rating is yet to be determined due to Hurricane Irma's impact on six of the 56 markets in Florida.

Media Research Center Vice President Dan Gainor described the Emmys as a "Hollywood bubble show," stating, "Actors and directors get to pretend they are important because they are doing such insightful takes on life in America, when they have zero idea what life in America is for the other 330 million people."

The Emmys were marked by political attacks on President Trump, with host Stephen Colbert's opening monologue through the end of the three-hour program. Alec Baldwin, who won an award for portraying Trump on "Saturday Night Live," used his speech to mock the president for not winning an Emmy during his time hosting "The Apprentice."

Former White House Press Secretary Sean Spicer made an appearance to poke fun at his tenure, but this drew criticism from some viewers, who were upset that CBS allowed the award show to normalize a former member of the Trump administration.

Academy Awards prognosticator Steve Pond described the event as "the most political Emmys show ever," and suggested that voters decided winners based on politics, opting for programs with a political agenda such as "The Handmaid's Tale" and "Atlanta" over less-polarizing shows such as "Stranger Things."

Gainor agreed, stating, "The Emmys celebrate shows that almost no one either watches or cares about." He added, "No ordinary Americans care about ‘The Handmaid’s Tale.’ No ordinary Americans watch ‘Veep.’ The only show the Emmys were honoring that most people even recognize was ‘Saturday Night Live.’"

The Emmys went head-to-head against NBC's "Sunday Night Football," which may have contributed to the viewership decline. However, the awards have now hit new ratings lows for three straight years. Some viewers may prefer the awards show as an escape from politics, while others may not agree with the Hollywood elite's political views.

"Entertainment Tonight" anchor Kevin Frazier stated on "CBS This Morning" that "politics took center stage," with the "recurring punchline" being Donald Trump. The CBS morning show co-hosts seemed to approve, but the dismal rating has not been released yet.

Gainor questioned, "Why would anyone who isn't a die-hard liberal watch?" The Emmys are yet to officially be labeled the lowest-rated Emmys, but the ratings decline suggests a potential trend in viewer disinterest in politically charged award shows.

Title: Senate Defeats Bill for Expanded Background Checks Despite Public Support

Article:

In the aftermath of the Sandy Hook shootings, polls have shown overwhelming public support for expanding background checks on gun sales, with one poll indicating that 9 out of 10 Americans back the idea. However, a bill to implement such checks was defeated in the Senate on Wednesday. President Obama commented on the disconnect, stating, "The American people are trying to figure out how can something have 90 percent support and yet not happen."

The primary explanation for this disconnect is the Senate's procedural rules, which enable a minority to block a majority. The legislation on background checks had the support of 54 out of 100 senators, but it takes 60 votes to overcome a filibuster.

The Senate rulebook was not the only obstacle. There is often a chasm between what the public says it wants and what their legislators actually do. This disconnect is particularly pronounced in the case of gun control proposals, which score well in national opinion polls while facing strong resistance in the South and Mountain West. These regions include states with relatively small populations, which enjoy outsized influence in the Senate due to their equal representation.

Another factor is that issue polls typically include nonvoters as well as voters. However, elected officials focus on the people who actually show up to vote, and their sentiments might differ from those who stay home on Election Day.

Politicians also have to worry about the people who vote in primaries. They need to nurture their ideological bases, or else face defeat at the hands of primary opponents. This tendency has become more pronounced in recent years in the House of Representatives, where red districts have gotten redder and blue districts have gotten bluer.

Intensity also plays a role, as a passionate minority can often outweigh a relatively indifferent majority. Gun control has typically exhibited this pattern: Second Amendment enthusiasts will always get in touch with their lawmakers and vote on the basis of this one issue, while supporters of more gun regulation may answer "yes" to a survey question and then forget about it.

Advocates hoped that the Newtown shootings would change the dynamic – not only by increasing support for gun control but also by making that support more fervent. However, any such effect was bound to fade, though not among those directly affected. In this case, timing worked against gun control, as the shootings occurred while Congress was focusing on the fiscal cliff, followed by the early months of the 113th Congress with a relatively light work schedule.

Presidents have limited ability to drive public opinion and mass political action. Even at the peak of his popularity, President Reagan was able to motivate cards and letters when he was selling something that people already liked (e.g., tax cuts). When he tried to stir Americans on tougher issues (e.g., aid to Nicaraguan rebels), he got nowhere.

Today, presidents work in a much more demanding media environment. Until the 1980s, they could "roadblock" the television networks with an Oval Office address. Now, they have to compete with hundreds of other channels and the Internet. Moreover, their critics and opponents have many more opportunities to respond in real time.

James Madison still rules America. The Framers designed a bicameral legislature and the separation of powers specifically to prevent an automatic translation of public opinion into public policy. Supporters of the system say that it fosters deliberation and ensures the protection of minority rights. Critics say that it prevents the passage of necessary legislation.

At the moment, political progressives are especially disappointed in the system. They should remember, however, that it has enabled them to block conservative ideas that were popular with the general public. If the polls always prevailed, after all, America would have a balanced-budget amendment and a constitutional ban on flag burning. President Obama has frequently taken credit for making tough decisions that were unpopular at the time, implicitly acknowledging that poll numbers do not always translate into righteousness.

Among other things, they need to learn from the other side. The National Rifle Association wins so many battles because of its zeal, its persistence, and its organization. Those who want tougher restrictions on firearms have to stoke the same kind of ardor, matching the NRA letter for letter, email for email, and phone call for phone call.

Getting this level of commitment and organization may be difficult, except perhaps in the immediate aftermath of a tragedy. However, President Obama's political group, Organizing for America (OFA), might have the resources and savvy to succeed, helped along by the efforts of New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg and former Congresswoman Gabrielle Giffords. The OFA insists that it is not a purely partisan organization and will pressure Democrats and Republicans alike. We'll see if it follows through.

Title: Billionaire Michael Bloomberg Endorses Joe Biden, Exits Democratic Presidential Race

Article:

Billionaire media mogul Michael Bloomberg announced his withdrawal from the Democratic presidential race on Wednesday following a disappointing performance in the Super Tuesday primaries. In a message to supporters, he expressed his commitment to defeating President Donald Trump and endorsed former Vice President Joe Biden.

"While I will not be the nominee, I will not walk away from the most important political fight of my life," Bloomberg stated. "I’ve always believed that defeating Donald Trump starts with uniting behind the candidate with the best shot to do it. After yesterday’s vote, it is clear that candidate is my friend and a great American, Joe Biden."

Bloomberg entered the race late and bypassed the first four nominating contests, investing over $500 million of his personal fortune in an advertising campaign, with nearly half of it targeted at Super Tuesday states. He won only one contest, in the U.S. territory American Samoa, earning four nominating delegates.

Biden's campaign saw a surge on Tuesday, resulting in a series of victories that placed him at the forefront of the two-candidate race, as the more traditional liberal alternative to Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont. Bloomberg acknowledged that his presence on the ballot may have dampened the Biden surge.

"Three months ago, I entered the race for President to defeat Donald Trump. Today, I am leaving the race for the same reason: to defeat Donald Trump—because it is clear that staying in would make achieving that goal more difficult," he said.

Similar to other candidates who recently dropped out and endorsed Biden, Bloomberg believes the former vice president has the best chance of beating Trump.

"I’ve known Joe for a very long time. I know his decency, his honesty, and his commitment to the issues that are so important to our country—including gun safety, health care, climate change, and good jobs," he said. "I’ve had the chance to work with Joe on those issues over the years, and Joe has fought for working people his whole life."

With Bloomberg's exit, only two major candidates remain in the race as also-rans behind Biden and Sanders: Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts and Representative Tulsi Gabbard of Hawaii. Former South Bend, Indiana, Mayor Pete Buttigieg and Senator Amy Klobuchar of Minnesota have already endorsed Biden following their own withdrawals from the presidential race.

President Trump took to Twitter to comment on Bloomberg's decision, stating, "I could have told him long ago that he didn’t have what it takes, and he would have saved himself a billion dollars, the real cost. Now he will pour money into Sleepy Joe’s campaign, hoping to save face. It won’t work!" Trump also predicted that "Mini Mike Bloomberg will now FIRE Tim O’Brien, and all of the fools and truly dumb people who got him into this MESS."

Title: Justice Department Reiterates School Obligation to Enroll Undocumented Students, Citing Supreme Court Decision

Article:

Attorney General Eric Holder and Education Secretary Arne Duncan have issued new guidance to school administrators, emphasizing the obligation of public schools to enroll students regardless of their immigration status. The guidance, an update to earlier guidelines issued in 2011, aims to address reports of discrimination against children of undocumented parents.

In a statement released Thursday, Mr. Holder stated that schools must enroll students without discrimination based on race, color, or national origin. He emphasized that the Department of Justice will take action to ensure schools comply with this obligation.

The new guidelines state that schools have the right to establish a student's residency in a district, but they are not required to demand state-issued driver's licenses or Social Security cards to prove a student's legal status. Instead, parents can produce a utility bill or a lease as an alternative.

The guidance is based on the 1982 Supreme Court decision in Plyler v. Doe, which ruled that children of illegal immigrants have a right to a public education. The court struck down a Texas statute that denied funding for education to the children of illegal immigrants and a school district's attempt to charge undocumented persons an annual $1,000 tuition fee for each illegal immigrant student.

Since the initial guidelines were issued in 2011, the Education Department's Office for Civil Rights has received 17 complaints related to enrollment policies. Complaints were from Ohio, Colorado, Louisiana, New Mexico, North Carolina, and Washington, D.C., among others. In addition, there have been a number of undisclosed complaints filed in the Justice Department. In Georgia, the Justice Department evaluated the enrollment policies of over 200 school districts and helped them resolve issues, authorities said.

School boards have historically taken action against illegal immigrants by requiring Social Security numbers or driver's licenses, and employing practices such as proposing separate schools for immigrant students and requiring paperwork designed to identify immigration status. Today, schools in states such as New York, New Jersey, and Arizona routinely inquire into immigration status as part of the enrollment process, according to the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU). In Alabama, public schools must determine the immigration status of children and parents during enrollment and can report the undocumented persons to immigration authorities.

Joanne Lin, ACLU Legislative Counsel, stated in an email, "Today's updated guidance reaffirms the longstanding principle, established by the Supreme Court over 30 years ago, that all children living in our country have a right to equal access to public education. School districts must adhere to this guidance, and meet their constitutional obligations to ensure that no child is locked outside the schoolhouse door."

Title: U.S. and U.N. Pressure Syria Over Alleged Chemical Weapons Attack

Article:

Rebel forces in Syria have accused the regime of President Bashar Assad of using poison gas in an attack near Damascus, potentially killing hundreds of civilians. The Syrian regime has denied the allegations. The White House is attempting to confirm the reports independently but is urging the Syrian government to allow a United Nations (U.N.) chemical weapons inspection team to examine the sites.

The U.N. Security Council held an emergency session to call for a thorough, impartial, and prompt investigation into the chemical weapons use allegations against Syria. The U.N. ambassador of Argentina, the current council president, expressed strong concern about the latest chemical weapons use allegations and the need for clarity on the incident. Russia and China approved the move but blocked a stronger statement on the incident proposed by the United States and its allies.

The death toll from the attack varies, with rebel estimates ranging from the low hundreds to over 1,300. The exact death toll and nature of the attack remain unverified. The reports of chemical weapons use come almost a year after President Obama issued a "red line" to the Syrian regime, stating that the U.S. would ensure that Damascus would suffer "enormous consequences" if chemical weapons were used or prepared for deployment.

When asked about the potential consequences and the limited U.S. response, White House spokesman Josh Earnest stated that the administration has not yet achieved its goal of removing Assad from power. General Martin E. Dempsey, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, wrote a letter this week to a congressman stating that the Pentagon is opposed to even limited action in Syria backing the rebels because it is uncertain that such action would aid those who support American interests.

Lawmakers on Capitol Hill have called for some form of intervention to stop the ongoing Syrian civil war, which has been raging since 2011 and has resulted in over 100,000 deaths, according to U.N. estimates. Some lawmakers argue that the U.S. must act soon to salvage its credibility in the region and tip the balance of power against the Syrian regime.

The Russian Foreign Ministry has suggested that the attack may have been a "provocation" by the rebels. The U.N. chemical weapons investigation team, which arrived in Syria on Sunday, will now have to renegotiate access to the sites of this week's attack if they are to gain access to the locations. The investigation results will help determine whether the Syrian regime has crossed President Obama's "red line" once again.

Title: Hospital Maintenance Workers Face Uncertainty and Risk in Fight Against COVID-19

Article:

Hospital maintenance workers and housekeepers, often unheralded yet vital to keeping hospitals running, are facing uncertainty and risk as they work on the front lines of the novel coronavirus pandemic. These workers, who lack medical training, are struggling with inconsistent guidance from employers regarding personal protective equipment (PPE).

Katina McDavis, a 43-year-old housekeeper at Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago, spends 40 hours a week cleaning hospital rooms. She has spent more than 20 years on the job and has two colleagues who have tested positive for COVID-19. McDavis said that while her employer provides PPE, she often receives conflicting information about when and how to use it.

Anne Igoe, vice president of a Chicago-based branch of the Service Employees International Union, which represents hospital workers, said that hospitals have protocols for keeping housekeepers safe but often fail to communicate them effectively. For example, rooms with COVID-19 patients have at times been mistakenly labeled otherwise, leading housekeepers to enter with insufficient PPE.

Northwestern Memorial said in a statement that it has enough PPE to keep workers safe and provides multiple channels for communication. However, a non-scientific poll by the Service Employees International Union showed that 75% of some 250 respondents, mostly housekeepers and nurse's assistants in Chicago and Indiana, have been told either they do not need PPE or must ask a nurse for it.

Kimberly Hughes, a housekeeper at a Montana hospital, has the chronic inflammatory lung disease COPD, leaving her at higher risk of complications from COVID-19. Hughes said she has been handed a 60-pound bag of laundry from a COVID-19 patient's room and told to hold it away from her body. Hughes, who stands 5'3" and weighs 135 pounds, said she could not.

Fearful of contracting COVID-19, some hospital janitors are refusing to take on certain tasks. At Brookdale University Hospital Medical Center in Brooklyn, a janitor asked a patient to clean her own room, according to her sister. Nurses at New York-Presbyterian Hospital are at times taking out trash themselves to preserve PPE, one nurse said.

To cope with the increased patient loads and demands, a number of hospitals are seeking to hire more housekeepers. Retaining those they hire is another matter. Angel Medrano, a recruiter of hospital housekeeping staff in the San Francisco Bay Area, said a hospital he works with tripled the number of housekeeping staff it required in March. Most of the people his firm has hired are African Americans or Hispanics who have lost their jobs cleaning hotels and offices.

However, around 20 people quit within the first couple of days on the job, mostly over concerns about PPE. The NYU Langone mechanic said he is so worried about getting infected that he is living apart from his wife and three-year-old son until the pandemic ends. His son recently woke up to a nightmare that his mother was taken away in an ambulance. "I worry about how I would take care of my son if I got sick," the boy's mother said. "I worry about how I will explain to him that his daddy probably won't be able to come for his birthday."

Title: Understanding Trump Voters: A Look at the Rationality Behind Support for Donald Trump

Article:

In a recent commencement speech at Rutgers University, former President Barack Obama criticized anti-intellectualism in today's political debate, seemingly alluding to President Donald Trump and his supporters. Obama's speech highlighted the importance of facts, evidence, reason, and logic in policy-making, and expressed concern over the dismissal of experts as elitists when leaders express disdain for facts and repeat falsehoods.

However, the rationale behind Trump supporters' choice may not be as straightforward as Obama's critique suggests. According to a report by The Christian Science Monitor's Patrik Jonsson, Trump followers feel that the candidate has tapped into something deep within them, transcending political reasoning. They see Trump as a leader who can make America great again.

One Trump voter in Georgia told Jonsson, "We need a leader, not an ideologue." In this context, the coherence of Trump's debunked statements, such as his claim about seeing Muslims celebrating on New Jersey rooftops on 9/11, may seem less important to some voters.

Political scientists Eric Oliver of the University of Chicago and Wendy Rahn of the University of Minnesota have found that mistrust of experts is one of the strongest predictors of a Trump voter. Trump supporters are farther over on the "mistrust experts" scale than all other Republicans, according to the researchers. This disbelief in traditional sources of authority is an inherent element of political populism, as they wrote in a March article for The Washington Post's Monkey Cage political blog.

In essence, Trump voters may view themselves as the rational ones in the national political discussion, as opposed to Obama Democrats. This perspective highlights the complexity and nuance behind the support for Trump, suggesting that the rationality behind their choice may not be as illogical as it might seem at first glance.

Title: Ross Perot, Independent Presidential Candidate and Businessman, Dies at 89

Billionaire businessman and independent presidential candidate Ross Perot has passed away at the age of 89, according to a statement from James Fuller, a representative for the Perot family. Perot, who ran for president in 1992 and 1996, died after a five-month battle with leukemia.

In business and life, Ross Perot was a man of integrity and action, according to Fuller's statement. He was described as a true American patriot, a man of rare vision, principle, and deep compassion, who touched the lives of countless people through his unwavering support of the military and veterans and through his charitable endeavors.

Perot is survived by his wife, Margot, his five children, and 16 grandchildren. This 1992 file photo shows presidential hopeful H. Ross Perot at a rally in Austin, Texas.

Perot was an early tech entrepreneur. He started his career in sales at IBM, where he excelled. In 1962, he founded his first company, Electronic Data Systems (EDS), with just $1,000 in savings. More than two decades later, he launched information technology services provider Perot Systems, which was acquired in 2009 by Dell for $3.9 billion.

As a disruptive third-party candidate for president, Perot ran on a platform of fiscal responsibility and protectionism. He won nearly 19% of the vote in the 1992 race—by far the biggest slice of the electorate for a third-party candidate since Theodore Roosevelt's Bull Moose Party in the 1912 election.

Perot stood out from the political crowd for his quirks as much as his business credentials and lack of experience in establishment politics. He was known for his statements such as, "I don't have any experience in running up a $4 trillion debt. I don't have any experience in gridlock government, where nobody takes responsibility for anything and everybody blames everybody else." During the 1992 presidential debate, he famously said that the shifting of U.S. jobs to Mexico created a "giant sucking sound."

Perot participated in all three presidential debates in that election and took a nontraditional campaign route by booking lengthy time slots on network television to lay out his political views. Allan Lichtman, distinguished professor of history at American University, described Perot as "certainly the most influential political force in the late 20th century from outside the regular party system." Lichtman told the Associated Press that he had been tapped to write a biography of Perot, but "quirky Ross Perot, just like he pulled out of the presidential race, he pulled out of the biography."

Perot was a veteran and followed his service with a lifetime commitment to supporting U.S. veterans, especially during the Vietnam War. He was honored in 2009 by then-Veterans Affairs Secretary James Peake for his advocacy efforts.

Title: Democrats' Advantage in Midterm Elections Narrows Amidst Family Separation and Gun Control Debates

Article:

A new CBS poll published on Sunday indicates a narrowing advantage for the Democratic Party over the Republican Party in the upcoming November midterm elections. The poll shows 40 percent of respondents preferring a Democratic-controlled Congress, while 36 percent support Republican control. This is a significant shift from the Democrats' 10-point advantage in a June NBC poll.

The poll was conducted shortly after the peak of the family separation crisis at the Southern border, during which the Trump administration's zero-tolerance policy resulted in the separation of families seeking illegal entry. Despite the significant public outcry against this policy, with 73 percent of Americans opposing the separation of children from parents as a form of deterrence, the Democrats' advantage has diminished.

The CBS poll, which surveyed 2,063 adults with a margin of error of 2.6 percent, also reveals a significant number of Trump supporters who opposed the zero-tolerance policy but did not hold the president responsible. The results suggest voters are compartmentalizing the issue, with many blaming the parents for bringing their children into the U.S. illegally.

Another factor affecting the Democrats' advantage is the gun control debate. According to a Washington Post poll in April, the gap between support for the two parties in House races has narrowed significantly since the gun control debate became a major issue following the school shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Florida in February. Nearly 40 percent of registered voters believe it is extremely important that political candidates share their views on gun control, and the poll suggests neither party holds an advantage in support among the 42 percent of likely voters who want congressional candidates to share their views on the issue.

The CBS poll also found that voters in key states for the Democrats in the midterms, such as Texas, Florida, and Arizona, believe Hispanic illegal and legal immigrants have had a negative effect on their lives. Nearly four in ten say immigrants from Mexico and South America have made life worse, compared to a lower 33 percent among voters across the country. Republicans are particularly likely to say immigrants have negatively impacted their state.

Title: President Obama Faces Historical Barrier in Bid for Re-election

Article:

In the 2012 U.S. presidential race, President Barack Obama is seeking to make history once again, as he aims to become the only president, besides Franklin D. Roosevelt, to be re-elected with unemployment rates as high as they currently are. The Democratic National Convention, held in Charlotte, North Carolina, serves as a platform for Obama to present his case for a second term.

While the historical statistical models suggest a defeat for Obama in November, he enters the race with several key advantages. Incumbency, more room for error, and demographic advantages are some of the factors that give Obama an easier path to 270 Electoral College votes and victory compared to his Republican rival, Mitt Romney.

Incumbency provides the president with an advantage, especially in a close, competitive race. Mitt Romney needs to win Florida and Ohio, and at least two of Virginia, North Carolina, and Wisconsin, to have a realistic shot at 270. On the other hand, Obama enters his convention with several paths to cobble 270 together.

Demographics also play a significant role in the race. As long as the GOP has a crisis with Latino voters, there is a built-in Democratic edge in several key states. New Mexico, not long ago a presidential swing state, is barely mentioned as a potential GOP target. Nevada is a competitive tossup despite the highest unemployment rate among the states and a punishing housing crisis.

The economy is the driving force behind the very different 2012 map and mood. The unemployment rate in February 2009, Obama's first full month in office, was 8.3%. Last month, it was 8.3%. To the Romney campaign, this is proof that Obama's economic policies have failed. The Obama team, in turn, notes that unemployment hit 10% in October 2009, and argues that the president's policies are, albeit slowly, helping pull the economy out of a deep recession he inherited.

In any event, the jobless numbers and other economic data make it all but impossible for the president to make the case that Americans are better off today than they were four years ago. The primary target for Obama is to make the case that his approach is the better, fairer path to sustained recovery. The primary target for his campaign is to appeal to independents and conservative Democrats in battleground states.

The convention also serves as an opportunity to re-energize Obama's 2008 base. The president's appeal to a Colorado college audience, "Don't boo - vote," is a snapshot of the 2012 campaign's approach, understanding it cannot rely on the dynamics that motivated 2008 Obama voters.

The 2016 factor is also noteworthy in Charlotte, with Joe and Jill Biden having busy schedules, and the vice president having a coveted speaking slot. Biden is 69, meaning he would be 73 at the 2016 convention, but he has not ruled out a third try for his party's presidential nomination.

Hillary Clinton will have no Charlotte role, but the convention has no shortage of Clinton loyalists, including her husband, the former president. From there, the focus will be on ambitious next-generation prospects, among them Govs. Martin O'Malley of Maryland, Deval Patrick of Massachusetts, and, for the first time in years, perhaps a Cuomo - New York's governor, Andrew.

To look at a map searching for Democrats of the future, though, is to be reminded of a painful truth for the party gathering in Charlotte: President Obama is their undisputed leader, but the Obama presidency has been a time of deep Democratic decline. The Democrats currently hold 51 Senate seats (plus two independents who align mostly with the Democrats), 190 seats in the House of Representatives (with three vacancies for seats last held by Democrats), and 20 of the 50 governorships.

Title: Sarah Palin Files Defamation Lawsuit Against The New York Times Over Giffords Shooting Allegations

Article:

Sarah Palin, the former Alaska governor and 2008 Republican vice-presidential nominee, has filed a defamation lawsuit against The New York Times, alleging the newspaper falsely implicated her in the 2011 shooting of Democratic Rep. Gabby Giffords, according to documents filed in federal court on Tuesday.

The lawsuit, obtained by ███, states that an editorial published by The New York Times on June 14, 2017, falsely claimed that Palin played a role in inciting the shooting of Giffords by a mentally ill man. The editorial has since been updated, and a correction was added that reads: "An earlier version of this editorial incorrectly stated that a link existed between political incitement and the 2011 shooting of Representative Gabby Giffords. In fact, no such link was established."

The lawsuit alleges that the newspaper "published and promoted its Editorial Board’s column despite knowing that the linchpin of its ‘ sickening pattern’ of politically-incited shootings was the false assertion that Mrs. Palin incited Jared Loughner’s January 8, 2011, shooting rampage at a political event in Tucson, Arizona."

The lawsuit further states that the newspaper "exceeded the bounds of legality, decency, and civility by publishing the false and defamatory column." Palin is seeking a minimum of $75,000 in damages.

The editorial in question claimed that there was a "clear" link between Loughner's attempted assassination of Giffords and a map Palin had created that placed crosshairs over districts that Republicans needed to flip in the 2012 election. However, no such link exists, as CNN's Jake Tapper pointed out in response to the NYT editorial, citing that Loughner's obsession began three years before the Palin map.

After harsh criticism in the media, the NYT finally added a correction to its editorial. The lawsuit states that the newspaper's response to the backlash was insufficient, as it "did not mention Mrs. Palin or acknowledge that Mrs. Palin did not incite a deranged man to commit murder."

Title: Trump Announces Plans for Second Step Act, Focused on Criminal Justice Reform and Reducing Unemployment

Article:

President Donald Trump held a celebratory event at the White House on Monday to highlight the bipartisan First Step Act, a criminal justice reform bill that Congress approved in December. The president announced plans for a "Second Step Act," although he provided few details about what that might entail or when it might be introduced.

"Today I'm announcing that the Second Step Act will be focused on successful reentry and reducing unemployment for Americans with past criminal records, and that's what we're starting," the president said.

The First Step Act, which aims to give prisoners who exhibit good behavior the opportunity to shorten their sentences, particularly for nonviolent drug offenses, and to reduce recidivism, was praised from both the left and the right for its aims. The celebration of the bill comes amid a broader Prison Reform Summit.

In the East Room, the president championed the "bipartisan" nature of the bill and how it's helping people. Among those in the crowd was Attorney General William Barr, who expects to release the full Mueller report by mid-April.

The president welcomed on stage people who had been released earlier because of the First Step Act. One such man said there should be a second step.

The president claimed that since he signed the First Step Act, more than 16,000 inmates have enrolled in drug treatment programs. One beneficiary of the law said that for the law to be fully effective, it needs to be fully funded.

However, the president's proposed budget requests only a sliver of the amount of funding laid out in the legislation. The legislation calls for $75 million a year over five years, but Mr. Trump's proposed budget only provides $14 million, as the Marshall Project first highlighted.

Trump's son-in-law and senior adviser Jared Kushner helped propel the legislation last year, along with nonprofit and other outside groups. Overcoming opposition from a handful of hard-right conservatives like Sen. Tom Cotton, R-Arkansas, the First Step Act was one of the few major legislative accomplishments his administration has achieved thus far.

Title: New York Times Publishes Account of 2012 Benghazi Attack, Sparking Controversy

Article:

The New York Times has published an account of the 2012 Benghazi attack, a controversial event that has been a subject of debate and investigation for several years. The article, written by David Kirkpatrick, the Cairo bureau chief of The New York Times, provides a detailed narrative of the events leading up to and during the attack, which resulted in the death of four Americans, including the U.S. Ambassador to Libya.

The article sheds light on the aftermath of the attack, including the response of the U.S. government and the subsequent investigation. The article suggests that the White House and Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, who was a key figure during the Obama administration, may have downplayed the role of Islamic terrorism in the attack, instead attributing it to a YouTube video that allegedly offended Muslims.

The article has sparked controversy, with some critics arguing that the account is biased and lacks credibility. Rep. Adam Schiff of California, a Democrat on the House Intelligence Committee, has praised the article for providing "valuable insights," but has also noted that the account is "heavily reliant" on sources who may have had a vested interest in the story.

The Benghazi attack remains a contentious issue, with many questioning the response of the U.S. government and the actions of Secretary Clinton during the crisis. The article's publication has reignited the debate and may have implications for Hillary Clinton's presidential campaign.

Title: Over $600,000 Raised for Families of Heroic Men Killed in Portland Train Attack

Article:

More than $600,000 has been collected for the families of three U.S. men who were killed or injured while defending a Muslim teenager and her friend on a train in Portland, Oregon. The deceased are Taliesin Myrddin Namkai-Meche, 23, a recent college graduate, and Ricky John Best, 53, an army veteran and father-of-four. Micah David-Cole Fletcher, 21, is recovering from a knife wound to his neck.

The attack occurred on Friday when the three men intervened after a man launched into a verbal tirade against the teenagers, one of whom was wearing a hijab. The 35-year-old suspect is due in court on Tuesday, charged with two counts of aggravated murder, attempted murder, intimidation, and being a felon in possession of a restricted weapon. The suspect allegedly said "all Muslims should die" during the attack.

The FBI is still uncertain if the suspect, identified as Jeremy Joseph Christian, will face additional charges for a hate crime. Meanwhile, Micah David-Cole Fletcher continues to recover. His mother stated that his neck wound was "a millimeter" from his jugular vein. Fletcher posted a picture from his hospital bed, alongside a poem, on Saturday evening. One of the lines read: "I spat in the eye of hate and lived."

The three men have been praised as "heroes" in their local community, with Destinee Mangum, the 16-year-old who was traveling with her friend, 17, expressing her gratitude. "I just want to say thank you to the people who put their life on the line for me, because they didn't even know me and they lost their lives because of me and my friend and the way we look," she told local channel KPTV.

A vigil was held for Namkai-Meche and Best on Saturday evening, attended by close to 1,000 people. Tributes have also been shared online, with the men being praised by Portland's mayor, Oregon governor Kate Brown, and former presidential candidate Hillary Clinton, who described their deaths as "heartbreaking."

"No one should have to endure this racist abuse," Clinton wrote on Twitter. "No one should have to give their life to stop it." U.S. President Donald Trump has yet to comment on the attack. A tweet by a reporter with the Oregonian newspaper, asking Trump for a comment, has been liked over 4,000 times. Veteran journalist Dan Rather wrote an open letter to Trump, which has been shared over 100,000 times on Facebook, urging the president to address the men's deaths.

"Two Americans have died, leaving family and friends behind," wrote Rather. "They are mourned by millions more who are also deeply worried about what might come next. I hope you can find it worthy of your time to take notice."

Title: Vice Presidential Debate: Pence Expected to Outperform Kaine in Tuesday's Contest

Article:

Tuesday's vice presidential debate in Farmville, Virginia, between Indiana Governor Mike Pence and Virginia Senator Tim Kaine is anticipated to favor Pence, with Pence expected to dominate the debate while concerns about Hillary Clinton's health continue to surface due to her running mate's replacement.

In July, when Clinton and Donald Trump announced their respective running mates, the vice presidential debate was expected to overshadow the presidential bouts, given that Pence and Kaine have more impressive resumes in public life than their respective selectors. Both men have served as governors, with Pence building a solid reputation as a leader on Capitol Hill, while Kaine was one of the Democrats' more respected voices on foreign policy on the Sunday talk show circuit.

However, since then, Pence has been a standout on the campaign trail, while Kaine has struggled to draw crowds, even in swing states where the contest is closest. Kaine's only notable contributions to his side's efforts have been his repeated accusations that Donald Trump is associated with the Ku Klux Klan and his defense of Clinton on her handling of classified information.

In contrast, Pence has been a net positive for the Trump campaign, reassuring the public that Trump will appoint competent people to high posts and be replaced by a capable leader, should the worst happen. By comparison, Kaine has been a net negative for the Clinton campaign. He seems to have been chosen for the sole reason that he would not overshadow Clinton on stage. In fact, when they appear together, she seems more likely to lose. It is difficult to imagine Kaine running the country.

The pattern is unlikely to change on Tuesday. Kaine will be sent on stage with a set of attack lines against Trump to reinforce Clinton's talking points from the last debate. Pence's job will be to look presidential, a task Kaine will make easier for him.

The conventional wisdom is that vice presidential debates do not matter much. However, they can affect a campaign's momentum. In 2008, Alaska Governor Sarah Palin stunned a skeptical media, which expected her to fail, by outperforming then-Senator Joe Biden (D-DE). The result was renewed zeal on the campaign trail for a ticket that appeared to be flagging since the first debate and the disastrous decision of Sen. John McCain (R-AZ) to suspend his campaign during the financial crisis.

In 2012, Biden put Barack Obama's re-election effort back on track after the president was beaten badly by Gov. Mitt Romney in the first debate. Republican vice presidential nominee Paul Ryan, who had prepared well for a genteel battle of wits and policies, was stunned by Biden's antics and outbursts, which seemed clownish but successfully conveyed contempt for Ryan to a national audience.

Pence is expected to give the Trump campaign a boost and force the media to reconsider Clinton's health issues, which remain shrouded in mystery, as well as her judgment, which Trump has repeatedly called into question. This, in turn, will set Trump up for the remaining two debates and, perhaps, for one last, decisive, surge in the polls.

Title: Study Finds Google News Results Skewed Toward Liberal Bias, According to AllSides Report

Article:

A media technology group, AllSides, has released a report claiming that Google News' results are biased towards liberal news outlets. Over a two-week period, AllSides analyzed Google News' homepage and found that news outlets with a left-leaning bias were always at the top of the list.

The study determined that out of 123 individual measurements, 65% of the news links provided were liberal, while only 16% were conservative. This 4-to-1 ratio indicates a significant preference for news media sources from the left. The remaining 20% of the links were considered to be from a middle perspective.

The study highlighted the importance of the positioning of the news, with left-wing news tending to be in the top two results, and right-wing news always appearing below the fold, 12 positions down. AllSides wrote, "The numbers are so significantly strong and consistent in favor of news media sources from the left that the overall conclusion of a leftward bias is well justified."

The study noted that sites like ABC, Buzzfeed, CBS, CNN, NBC, NPR, Politico, Time, The Washington Post, The New York Times, The New Yorker, and Huffington Post were heavily favored, while sites like Breitbart, The Blaze, The Daily Caller, Fox News, and the National Review were almost always below the fold. Even some of the news considered to be in the center wasn't necessarily neutral, as the study included NPR, Bloomberg, Al Jazeera, and BBC.

According to the report, 91% of the 123 measurements indicated at least some preference for news media with a left bias over sources with a right bias. It went even further, stating that 80% of the 123 measurements preferred left-wing news over news from a center source.

AllSides CEO John Gable told USA Today, "Right now, technology overly puts a spotlight on the most popular perspective, or the perspective that most fits you, and that cuts out other perspectives. It reduces an individual's ability to decide for themselves or know the whole story."

Google told USA Today that "search is not used to set a political agenda." The search engine company also denied any bias towards a political ideology.

Title: Bernie Sanders to Urge Unity, Highlight Clinton's Superiority in Key Issues at Democratic National Convention

Article:

Bernie Sanders, the Vermont senator, will address the Democratic National Convention on Monday, urging supporters to consider Hillary Clinton as a superior alternative to the Republican nominee, Donald Trump. The convention, held in Philadelphia, aims to display unity in contrast with the Republican infighting that occurred during their convention in Cleveland last week.

The convention's start was marred by the resignation of Democratic National Committee (DNC) chair Debbie Wasserman Schultz on Sunday, following the revelation of bias against Sanders during the primary contest with Clinton. The DNC emails showed staff members seeking to exploit Sanders' religious beliefs and Wasserman Schultz openly dismissing the notion that he could ever win.

In a statement before the news of Wasserman Schultz's resignation, Sanders' spokesman, Michael Briggs, stated that Sanders would make it clear that Clinton is superior to Trump on key issues such as economics, healthcare, education, and the environment. Sanders himself, in a muted response to the resignation, acknowledged that she had made the right decision but paid tribute to her "years of service."

Since a full-throated endorsement speech two weeks ago in New Hampshire, Sanders has swiftly backed Clinton, claiming to have moved the party's nominee to the left in a series of policy negotiations. In his Monday night speech, Sanders is expected to highlight agreements he reached with Clinton to expand healthcare access and to make public colleges tuition-free for students from families with annual incomes up to $125,000.

Sanders will also criticize Trump for aligning with the Koch brothers and echoing fossil fuel industry claims that climate change is a hoax, despite the scientific consensus that human-induced climate change is causing devastating harm.

Despite some Sanders supporters' anger over the DNC email revelations, the Sanders campaign appears content with the outcome of a rules committee meeting on Saturday that proposed a commission to reduce the number of superdelegates in primary contests. Jeff Weaver, Sanders' campaign manager, described this as a "tremendous victory" for Sanders' fight to democratize the Democratic party and reform the nominating process.

Sanders will use his speech to encourage supporters to continue pushing their agenda outside the mainstream. He will emphasize the ongoing political revolution to transform America and promote a government that represents all, not just the 1%.

"[He] will send a message to the convention and to the 13 million voters who supported him that they have begun a political revolution to transform America and that the revolution – Our Revolution – continues," said Briggs. "Together," Sanders will say, "we continue the fight to create a government which represents all of us, and not just the 1% – a government based on the principles of economic, social, racial, and environmental justice."

Title: Delayed COVID-19 Testing in the U.S.: A Case Study of the Seattle Flu Study

Article:

The United States, home to some of the world's most innovative biotech companies and university research laboratories, was in a prime position to detect and monitor emerging cases of COVID-19 caused by the new coronavirus outbreak. However, a report by The New York Times reveals that officials at the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) hindered the development of diagnostic tests that could have provided an early warning and a head start on controlling the epidemic.

Seattle infectious disease expert Dr. Helen Chu, by January, had collected a large number of nasal swabs from local residents experiencing symptoms as part of a research project on flu. Proposing to test these samples for coronavirus infections, Chu and her team were told by federal and state officials that they could not do so unless their laboratory test was approved by the FDA. The FDA refused to approve Chu's test, citing that her lab was not certified as a clinical laboratory under regulations established by the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services, a process that could take months.

In the meantime, the CDC required that public health officials could only use the diagnostic test designed by the agency. The test, released on February 5, turned out to be flawed. The CDC's insistence on a top-down centralized testing regime greatly slowed down the process of disease detection as the infection rate was accelerating.

Frustrated, Chu and her colleagues began testing on February 25 without government approval. They almost immediately detected a coronavirus infection in a local teenager with no recent travel history. Chu warned local public health officials of her lab's finding, and the teenager's school was closed as a precaution. The teen's diagnosis strongly suggested that the disease had been circulating throughout the western part of Washington for weeks.

Did the FDA and CDC functionaries commend Chu for being proactive? Not at all. Washington state epidemiologist Scott Lindquist recalled, "What they said on that phone call very clearly was cease and desist to Helen Chu. Stop testing." On February 29, the FDA finally agreed to allow biotech companies and academic labs in the U.S. to develop and deploy new tests for the coronavirus that causes COVID-19.

The Seattle Flu Study illustrates how existing regulations and red tape—sometimes designed to protect privacy and health—have impeded the rapid rollout of testing nationally, while other countries ramped up much earlier and faster. Faced with a public health emergency on a scale potentially not seen in a century, the United States has not responded nimbly. Due to red tape, the coronavirus outbreak in the U.S. will be worse than it should have been.

Title: Trump Administration Argues for DACA Program's Invalidity in New Court Filing

Article:

The Trump administration has connected the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program, established during the Obama era, to the surge of children and families crossing the border, in new court documents filed on Friday. Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen stated that a weak stance on enforcing immigration laws sends the wrong message to potential migrants.

In a memo, Secretary Nielsen argued that the government must cancel the DACA program to project a clear, consistent, and transparent enforcement of immigration laws. She stated, "Considering the fact that tens of thousands of minor aliens have illegally crossed or been smuggled across our border in recent years and then have been released into the country owing to loopholes in our laws, it is critically important for DHS to project a message that leaves no doubt regarding the clear, consistent, and transparent enforcement of the immigration laws against all classes and categories of aliens."

The document expands on the justification then-acting Secretary Elaine Duke gave last September when she announced a phaseout of the DACA program. Several federal judges have ruled her phaseout decision was not well-thought-out, and used circular logic that relied on the fear of a legal defeat in the courts to scrap the program.

California Attorney General Xavier Becerra, who won one of those court injunctions halting the Trump phaseout, said the new filing was misguided. "The Trump Administration doubling down on its decision to terminate the DACA program is based on its flawed conclusion that DACA is unlawful," he said.

The Trump administration, in the new memo, argues that the Obama administration stated the program could be revoked at any time when it started DACA in 2012, and was always meant to be temporary. Secretary Nielsen laid out both legal and policy arguments for why DACA is bad policy and bad legally.

She admitted the Dreamers who apply for DACA are "sympathetic" figures, but said that's not enough of a reason for the administration to exercise powers that rightly belong to Congress. The DACA program created a two-year renewable stay of deportation. Those who qualified were also given work permits, entitling them to driver's licenses and some taxpayer benefits.

As of several months ago, more than 800,000 people were approved for the program, and nearly 700,000 were still being protected under it. Secretary Nielsen said there's nothing wrong with granting special relief to Dreamers on a case-by-case basis, but she said DACA was a categorical program that saw applications of people who met the age and education requirements virtually rubber-stamped. She said those sorts of decisions on big programs like that should come from Congress, not the executive branch.

While several judges have ruled the Trump phaseout illegal, Texas and several other states have filed a lawsuit arguing the original DACA program itself is illegal. Should Texas win that case, it could create a bizarre situation where DACA is illegal, but so is getting rid of it.

Title: New York Governor Mario Cuomo's Third Term and Presidential Speculation

Article:

New York Governor Mario Cuomo, once a formidable figure in the state, faced a decline in popularity that emboldened state legislators to challenge him. He attributed the erosion of support to the media's coverage of his response to speculation about a potential presidential run.

In an interview with The Washington Post, Cuomo stated, "You've done everything but call me a liar. You said that I was cute. You said that I misplayed the game. You said that I was really waiting for another scenario. Well, the net result of that is it costs me credibility, because you spent all those months saying I was conning people."

In 1990, despite the economic recession and declining state revenues, Cuomo won a third term. His Republican opponent, Pierre A. Rinfret, a financial consultant and economics adviser to presidents, was not taken seriously even by his own party.

Cuomo's victory was convincing but unsatisfying, as he had performed better against his Democratic opponent four years prior.

Upon returning to Albany to deliver his ninth State of the State address, Cuomo suggested diminished ambitions for his next term. "This is a wonderful year for raw truth," he said. "We don't have any money."

However, Cuomo had one more presidential flirtation left in him. In October 1991, while on a trip to Chicago, he stated he was "looking at" a run. Many of his supporters grew weary of such talk, viewing it as a ruse to reinvigorate his sagging political image. In December of the same year, with presidential campaign plans on hold, he announced again that he would not be a candidate for president.

Years later, Cuomo expressed regret that no one had taken him at his word when he stated he would run for president, had Republicans agreed to his request to pass a budget.

Title: Economic Impact of COVID-19 Control Measures: A Balanced Perspective

Article:

President Donald Trump has expressed concerns that the measures aimed at curbing the spread of COVID-19, such as travel restrictions, business closures, and work-from-home orders, could have a more detrimental impact on the economy than the disease itself. Economists predict that the economic fallout from the pandemic could be as severe as or worse than the Great Recession of 2008-09, which cost the U.S. an estimated $22 trillion.

When evaluating health or safety regulations, government agencies typically consider not only the number of lives saved but the cost of implementing such measures. This approach is justified because finite resources spent on one type of risk reduction might be better utilized elsewhere, potentially saving more lives.

A rough calculation based on the "value of a statistical life" (VSL) used by the Environmental Protection Agency to assess proposed regulations suggests that the cost of COVID-19 deaths in the worst-case scenario, as sketched by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), would be substantial: on the order of $13.6 trillion. However, if the economic projections are accurate, the cost of aggressive COVID-19 control measures will likely be higher.

This comparison assumes that government intervention will be completely successful in preventing those deaths, which is not true, and it uses a VSL that may be excessive in this case, as COVID-19 fatalities are concentrated among the elderly, meaning fewer years of life lost on average. Furthermore, there are valid reasons to believe that the worst-case scenario, which imagines 214 million infections (65% of the population) and 1.7 million deaths, is unrealistic.

The true case fatality rate (CFR) for COVID-19, although likely higher than the CFR for seasonal flu (about 0.1%), is likely to be much lower than the rates suggested by the official numbers, which include only confirmed cases. Since COVID-19 symptoms are typically mild to nonexistent, the actual number of infections is bound to be much higher.

Assistant Secretary for Health Brett Giroir states that the best estimates for the overall mortality rate for COVID-19 are somewhere between 0.1% and 1%. John Ioannidis, an epidemiologist and biostatistician at Stanford University, calculates that "reasonable estimates for the case fatality ratio in the general U.S. population vary from 0.05% to 1%."

The CDC's projection implies a COVID-19 CFR of 0.8%, near the high end of these ranges. The scenario also assumes that voluntary measures to curtail the spread of COVID-19, such as avoiding crowds, limiting social interactions, and paying extra attention to hygiene, have no impact on transmission.

There is a great deal of uncertainty about these projections, and public officials may think they are erring on the side of caution. However, this is true only if one ignores the potentially devastating impact of disrupting economic transactions, shutting down businesses, and depriving millions of people of their livelihoods.

Ioannidis warns that if the CFR for COVID-19 is much lower than many people fear, "locking down the world with potentially tremendous social and financial consequences may be totally irrational." David Katz, founding director of the Yale-Griffin Prevention Research Center, advocates for a more targeted approach that focuses on protecting the people who face the greatest risk, stating he is "deeply concerned that the social, economic, and public health consequences of this near total meltdown of normal life…will be long-lasting and calamitous, possibly graver than the direct toll of the virus itself."

In formulating an appropriate response to COVID-19, there are no easy answers. Wise policy begins by recognizing the trade-offs that politicians have so far been inclined to ignore.

Title: Bipartisan Deal on $2 Trillion Coronavirus Stimulus Package Nears as U.S. Congress Approaches Vote

Article:

Senior Democrats and Republicans have reportedly reached a preliminary agreement on a $2 trillion economic stimulus package aimed at mitigating the economic impact of the ongoing coronavirus pandemic. The deal, if finalized and passed, would mark the third and largest legislative response to the crisis.

On Tuesday, Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell expressed optimism, stating, "At last, I believe, we're on the five-yard line." McConnell, the top Republican in Congress, added, "We are very close." House of Representatives Speaker Nancy Pelosi, the top Democrat in Congress, also expressed optimism, stating, "I think there is a real optimism that we could get something done in the next few hours."

The agreement reportedly includes more oversight provisions for a $500 billion fund to aid hard-hit businesses, resolving a key sticking point. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin confirmed the changes, stating, "There's better oversight."

Democrats had previously blocked the bill twice, citing insufficient funding for states and hospitals, inadequate aid for unemployed Americans, and a lack of oversight for a massive fund to aid big businesses.

As of Tuesday, the coronavirus pandemic has resulted in over 550 deaths and more than 43,800 cases in the United States. The crisis has led to the shuttering of thousands of businesses, the unemployment of millions, and the issuance of stay-at-home orders by state governors affecting about 100 million people, or nearly a third of the nation's population.

If a bipartisan deal is reached, Pelosi's $2.5 trillion counterproposal, which includes $4 billion for states to conduct the November presidential and congressional elections by mail, may become irrelevant.

Details of the emerging bipartisan bill are not yet available, but it is expected to provide financial aid for Americans out of work due to the virus and help for struggling industries such as airlines.

The Republican-majority Senate requires Democratic support to garner the 60 votes necessary to advance most legislation due to their slim 53-47 majority. However, the coronavirus has affected their ranks, giving Democrats additional leverage. Republican Senator Rand Paul has tested positive for coronavirus, and four other Republicans are unable to vote due to exposure to Paul or others with the virus.

Title: Speaker John Boehner Announces Special Committee to Investigate Benghazi Attacks

Article:

Speaker of the House John Boehner announced the creation of a special committee to investigate the 2012 attacks in Benghazi, Libya, which resulted in the death of a U.S. ambassador and three other Americans. The decision was made on Friday, following a week of hints and a standoff between Congress and the White House.

Boehner's announcement highlights his evolution as speaker, with the GOP majority now focusing on oversight rather than negotiating a budget-balancing fiscal deal with President Barack Obama. The move was prompted by a cache of emails obtained by the government watchdog group Judicial Watch under the Freedom of Information Act, which House panels had been unable to receive despite issuing a subpoena.

Boehner's decision to create the panel was a response to what he perceived as either the Obama administration's reluctance to cooperate with Congress or the House committees' inability to obtain the full documents. Rep. Peter Roskam (R-Ill.), the party's chief deputy whip, stated, "The speaker was reluctant to do this, it's not something he was celebrating or anxious to do, even with earlier calls for it. But when the White House is releasing information in discovery in lawsuits that they are not releasing to Congress, that is a very serious breakdown that has to be dealt with."

The House will vote on a resolution to create the committee on Thursday. Boehner has been preparing for this move for some time, consulting with key figures involved in the Benghazi probes, including Rep. Frank Wolf (R-Va.), who had previously proposed his own bill to create a special Benghazi panel. Boehner is expected to appoint Rep. Trey Gowdy (R-S.C.) as the committee's chairman.

The creation of the select committee was a departure from Boehner's usual approach of allowing committees to handle their own work. However, the unavailability of crucial documents and the perceived lack of cooperation from the White House may have influenced his decision. The exact details of the committee's scope and focus are yet to be determined.

Title: Opinion Piece by Paul Waldman Accuses Trump of Destroying America, Sparks Controversy

Article:

In a recent opinion piece for The American Prospect, columnist Paul Waldman criticizes President Donald Trump and his impact on American politics and society. The article, titled "The Impeachment of Donald Trump and the Contamination of Our Emotional Lives," expresses Waldman's view that Trump's presidency has caused widespread dread, despair, and disillusionment.

Waldman argues that the impending impeachment of Trump could bring accountability, but acknowledges that the Senate is unlikely to remove him from office. He also criticizes Trump's tweets, his alleged racism, and his cruelty, citing these as examples of the "unceasing parade of horrors emanating from the Oval Office."

David Limbaugh, a writer, author, and attorney, offers a counterpoint to Waldman's piece, arguing that the columnist's assertions are biased and ignore the Democrats' pursuit of Trump since his candidacy and their handling of the Russia investigation. Limbaugh contends that the Democrats have wasted taxpayers' time and resources on a bogus case and have yet to be held accountable for their actions.

Limbaugh also challenges Waldman's portrayal of Trump as a source of dread and despair, stating that the president's policies have stimulated robust economic growth and invigorated patriotic instincts. He further argues that the left's relentless criticism of Trump is exhausting and that they are projecting their own viciousness and intolerance onto the president and his supporters.

The article concludes with Limbaugh's praise for President Trump's efforts to stand against the extreme left's crusade to transform America and his gratitude for the president's commitment to upholding traditional American values. Limbaugh's piece serves as a response to Waldman's opinion piece, offering a contrasting perspective on the impact of Trump's presidency on American society.

Title: Oregon Senate Republicans Absent to Prevent Cap-and-Trade Legislation, Democrats Accuse Them of Playing Hooky

Article:

Oregon Senate Republicans have left the state to avoid a legislative session that could result in the passage of a cap-and-trade legislation, according to Senate Republican Whip Dennis Linthicum. The legislators' absence is intended to run out the clock on the legislative session, as the state budget is already funded, Mr. Linthicum stated in a press release.

All 11 Senate Republicans have left Oregon, putting them beyond the jurisdiction of state police, according to Mr. Linthicum's spokesman, Jonathan Lockwood. Senator Herman Baertschiger, an Oregon Republican, stated that he would return if Democrats agreed to let the public decide by referring the cap-and-trade plan to the ballot.

Democrats have accused the Senate Republicans of playing hooky. The Oregon Democratic Party posted a "wanted" sign with the names and photos of the Republican legislators, labeling them as "fugitives from justice (and their jobs)!" The Democrats have also tweeted that the Senate Republicans' absence has serious consequences for the state's climate and that they should return to Salem and do their jobs.

If passed, H.B. 2020 would make Oregon the second state, after California, with a cap-and-trade program. The program aims to lower greenhouse-gas emissions 80 percent below 1990 levels by 2050 to combat climate change. However, Republicans argue that the legislation would strangle economic growth and kill jobs, costing the average family of four at least $600 per year.

Oregon Senate President Peter Courtney stated that the Senate Republicans would be fined $500 per day for each day they are absent and a quorum cannot be reached. The Senate Democrats have 18 members, but need 20 members to establish a quorum.

Senate Republicans have been active on social media, tweeting that Governor Kate Brown herself commended House Democrats when they staged a walk-out in 2001. Walkouts are rare but not unheard of, with similar incidents occurring in Wisconsin in 2011 and Texas in 2003. As a state legislator in 1839, Abraham Lincoln famously jumped out a window after the Illinois House Speaker locked the doors of the legislature.

Hundreds of protesters, led by loggers and a convoy of truckers, turned out Wednesday to protest in Salem, alarmed by the cap-and-trade legislation. Senator Baertschiger described the bill as "a monster of a bill" and stated that he would not be part of letting it pass.

Title: Jared Kushner Loses Top-Level Security Clearance, Downgraded to Secret Level

Article:

President Trump's son-in-law, Jared Kushner, has lost the top-level security clearance he had been using on an interim basis to perform his duties within the White House, according to reports on Tuesday. Instead, Kushner will now use a lower level of access to classified information, similar to other White House staffers who had temporary clearances.

Previously, Kushner held a top-secret clearance with access to Special Compartmented Information, known as TS/SCI. Now, he and other officials will utilize a lower clearance level, a secret clearance, which restricts the amount of material they can access. The news was first reported by Politico.

On Tuesday, another story raised new questions about Kushner's future within the White House. The Washington Post reported that foreign officials have discussed potential methods to manipulate Kushner by exploiting his finances, business dealings, or his lack of experience in foreign policy and government.

For now, Kushner is expected to continue working in his unpaid role as a senior adviser to Trump, despite losing this round in a dispute with White House Chief of Staff John Kelly. The two men have reportedly been at odds over access to the president and the nature of their jobs. Trump stated last week that he trusted Kelly to resolve the dispute.

White House Chief of Staff John Kelly stated earlier that he would not comment on any one person's security clearance. However, Kelly did issue a statement regarding Kushner's role within the White House:

"As I told Jared days ago, I have full confidence in his ability to continue performing his duties in his foreign policy portfolio including overseeing our Israeli-Palestinian peace effort and serving as an integral part of our relationship with Mexico," Kelly said.

"Everyone in the White House is grateful for these valuable contributions to furthering the president's agenda. There is no truth to any suggestion otherwise," Kelly also said.

Kelly had set Friday as the deadline to discontinue any top-secret or higher-level interim clearances for individuals whose background investigations had been pending since June 1, 2017, or before.

Kushner's attorney, Abbe Lowell, stated that there is a backlog in the process for securing a permanent clearance. "Mr. Kushner has done more than what is expected of him in this process," Lowell said in a statement provided to NPR.

"Those involved in the process again have confirmed that there are dozens of people at Mr. Kushner's level whose process is delayed. It is not uncommon for these clearance reviews to take this long in a new administration, and the current backlogs are now being addressed. No concerns were raised about Mr. Kushner's application. As General Kelly himself said, the new clearance policy will not affect Mr. Kushner's ability to continue to do the very important work he has been assigned by the president," Lowell continued.

Sen. Richard Blumenthal (D-Conn.) stated that the change in Kushner's access to sensitive information should have occurred months ago. "Downgrading Jared Kushner's security clearance gives new meaning to the term 'overdue,'" Blumenthal said. "Kushner's access to highly sensitive, classified information should have been not just downgraded, but eliminated long ago. There is no reasonable justification for a yearlong policy that allowed people who may have very harmful secrets in their own backgrounds to have access to our nation's secrets."

The resignation of former White House staff secretary Rob Porter had revealed that a number of people on staff had never received full, permanent clearances, meaning they were accessing national security and other secret information even after questions had been raised during background checks about their ability to qualify to do so.

The Porter scandal embarrassed Kelly and the White House after Trump and Republicans had made the handling of secrets such a focus of their 2016 victory over Hillary Clinton, who operated a private email server while she served as secretary of state. Clinton was repeatedly faulted during the campaign about what critics called her slipshod approach to handling sensitive information.

Title: Arkansas Senate Overrides Veto, Advances Abortion Restrictions

Article:

The Arkansas Senate, in a party-line vote, overrode Democratic Governor Mike Beebe's veto of a bill that imposes near-total abortion bans starting from the 20th week of pregnancy. The Senate also advanced a separate bill that would outlaw most abortions from the 12th week, sending it to Governor Beebe for his consideration.

The 20-week bill, which took effect immediately, is based on the contested claim that fetuses can feel pain by the 20th week. Senate President Michael Lamoureux, a Republican from Russellville, supported the override but expressed doubts about the bill's constitutionality.

Minutes after overriding Governor Beebe's veto, the Senate voted 26-8 in favor of the 12-week bill, which would outlaw most abortions starting from the 12th week of pregnancy. The American Civil Liberties Union of Arkansas has already announced its intention to challenge either the 20-week or 12-week bills if they become law, and opponents of the legislation are expected to seek an injunction barring enforcement of the new restrictions pending the outcome of the expected legal challenge.

Governor Beebe has stated that he believes the new law contradicts the U.S. Supreme Court's 1976 Roe v. Wade decision, which legalized abortion until a fetus can viably survive outside of the womb, typically at 22 to 24 weeks. He also expressed concerns about the state wasting money trying to defend the law.

Sen. Bruce Maloch, a Democrat from Magnolia, previously voted for the 20-week ban but voted against the override out of deference to Governor Beebe and the concerns he raised over the measure's constitutionality.

The near-ban of abortions starting from the 20th week of pregnancy is based on the disputed claim that a fetus can feel pain by then. Seven states have enacted similar 20-week restrictions based on the fetal pain argument, according to the Guttmacher Institute, which tracks laws affecting women's health. A similar law in Arizona has been blocked while a federal appeals court reviews a lawsuit challenging it.

The 12-week bill is based on the argument that a fetus should be protected from abortion once its heartbeat can be detected during an abdominal ultrasound. The governor has not stated whether he will veto the bill, but he has expressed constitutional concerns with the measure.

Sen. Jason Rapert, the Republican sponsor of the 12-week ban, stated that Governor Beebe should let the measure go into law without his signature. "I respect his opinions and what he has to do as an individual, but I believe he should honor the vote of the Legislature," Rapert told reporters after the vote.

Title: Trump's Ongoing Response to Ongoing Probes and the Russia Investigation

Article:

President Donald Trump has, for months, expressed discontent towards the ongoing investigations, often unprompted, asserting, "I'm not under investigation." He closely monitors television coverage of the investigations, sometimes recording morning news shows to review them in the evening.

Trump's recent focus on the idea that the investigation has run its course is evident. In a tweet on June 16, 2017, he stated, "after 7 months of investigations & committee hearings about my 'collusion with the Russians,' nobody has been able to show any proof. Sad!"

The source of the "7 months" is unclear, but Trump's point is that the investigation has prolonged long enough.
