Comparing it to the Whitewater investigation, which lasted over four years before evidence of wrongdoing was found, Trump aims to terminate the investigation before Special Counsel Robert Mueller delves too deeply into his financial affairs and before the investigation recruits a significant number of accountants and lawyers to scrutinize his financial records.

Trump has also described the investigation as a "witch hunt" and claimed that others are out to get him. An adviser who has spoken with Trump and his top aides stated, "It's basically all he talks about on the phone."

Trump's surrogates have also been pushing the notion that Mueller is biased, as he has hired individuals who contributed to Hillary Clinton's campaign, and that the investigation is a sham. It is unclear when Trump may declare the investigation over, but he has been reported to be considering devoting half the FBI's resources to monitoring the other half for potential leaks.

Despite concerns about the political implications, Trump's actions suggest that he is not weighing the consequences or looking down the road. He wants Mueller removed from the investigation, and there is only so long his staff will hold him back.

Title: Eric Cantor Loses Primary Election in Virginia's 7th Congressional District

Article:

In a surprising turn of events, Representative Eric Cantor (R-VA), the sitting Majority Leader of the House, has lost his primary election to Professor Dave Brat (R-VA) in Virginia's 7th Congressional District. The election result was described by elections expert Sean Trende as the "biggest House upset" he has ever seen.

Despite a significant spending advantage in the last seven weeks, with Cantor outspending Brat by $993,000 to $76,000, Cantor was unable to secure a victory in a race that was widely expected to be a comfortable win. A recent poll had shown a potential tightening of the race, but Cantor still led by double digits.

The defeat of Cantor, who was not perceived to be taking his primary challenge seriously, was due in part to discontent within the solidly Republican, suburban Richmond 7th Congressional District. Brat exposed this discontent by attacking Cantor on his votes to raise the debt ceiling and end the government shutdown, as well as his support for some immigration reforms.

At a May meeting of Republican activists in the district, Cantor was booed, and an ally he campaigned for was ousted as the local party chairman in favor of a tea party favorite.

As of the time of this report, it is unclear if there is a Democratic candidate running in Virginia's 7th Congressional District. The lack of information on this matter is not promising if there is a Democratic candidate.

This unexpected election result has effectively ended any chance of Immigration Reform in the near future, according to political analyst Chuck Todd. The full implications of this election result are still being assessed.

Title: Deadly Train Accident Kills 16 Migrant Workers in Western India

Article:

A freight train in the western Indian state of Maharashtra has run over a group of migrant workers sleeping on the tracks, resulting in the deaths of at least 16 individuals and injuries to two others, according to officials. The incident occurred as tens of thousands of laborers have been walking home from major Indian cities after losing their jobs due to a lockdown imposed to curb the spread of the coronavirus pandemic.

The Railways Ministry stated that the driver of the train attempted to stop in time but was unable to do so. An inquiry has been ordered in response to the incident. The state government reported the death toll and the number of injured in a statement.

The laborers were reportedly employed by a steel company and were walking towards their village in the neighboring state of Madhya Pradesh. A police officer stated, "They had been walking all night; they were exhausted and fell asleep on the tracks."

Under the lockdown, public transport has been suspended, leaving migrant workers heading home to walk long distances to reach their destinations. The opposition and activists have criticized the government for arranging planes to bring back Indians from overseas while leaving migrant workers stranded in big cities with limited access to food and cash.

Prime Minister Narendra Modi expressed his "anguish at the loss of lives" in the accident and stated that "all possible assistance required is being provided." Rahul Gandhi, the leader of the main opposition Congress party, expressed his "shock at the deaths of migrant workers" and stated, "We should be ashamed of how we treat our nation-builders."

Over the past week, some state governments have organized trains and buses to bring back migrant workers. Many are walking great distances in the blistering heat through fields and forests to get home. India's railway network is one of the largest in the world and carries about 23 million passengers a day. Accidents are common, with most being attributed to poor maintenance and human error. A 2012 government report described the loss of 15,000 passengers to rail accidents every year in India as a "massacre."

Title: Health and Human Services Secretary Acknowledges Potential Premium Increases in Affordable Care Act

Article:

Health and Human Services Secretary Kathleen Sebelius has admitted that the Affordable Care Act, also known as ObamaCare, may not be as affordable as initially perceived. This acknowledgment comes as insurers prepare to release rates for health plans starting on January 1, 2014, when key provisions of the health law take effect.

Sebelius' remarks suggest that individuals purchasing new insurance policies could experience premium increases due to requirements in the health-care law. She noted that the law mandates improved benefits and equal treatment for all customers, regardless of their medical claims.

The secretary's comments are among the first direct statements from federal officials acknowledging that people with less comprehensive health plans may face higher premiums for more generous plans. Sebelius stated, "These folks will be moving into a really fully insured product for the first time, and so there may be a higher cost associated with getting into that market."

However, she also emphasized that subsidies will be available for many lower-income Americans to help them afford the increased costs of coverage.

A survey of more than 600 doctors found that six in ten physicians (62 percent) believe many of their colleagues will retire earlier than planned in the next 1 to 3 years. Additionally, 55 percent of surveyed doctors anticipate others will scale back hours due to changes in the medical profession.

The survey also indicated that physicians and hospitals may become more integrated in the coming years, with about two-thirds of respondents believing that physicians and hospitals will become more integrated. In the last two years, 31 percent of respondents moved into a larger practice. Nearly eight in ten believe midlevel providers will play a larger role in directing primary care.

Furthermore, biomedical or medical device engineering firms are reportedly laying off workers who develop crucial medical products due to the costs associated with the medical device tax in ObamaCare. The more money these companies pay to the government, the less they have available for research and development.

In summary, the Health and Human Services Secretary's acknowledgment of potential premium increases in the Affordable Care Act comes as insurers prepare to release rates for health plans starting in 2014. The survey of physicians indicates a pessimistic outlook on the future of medicine, with many anticipating early retirement, reduced hours, and increased integration of physicians and hospitals. Additionally, the medical device tax in ObamaCare has reportedly led to job losses in the medical device industry.

Title: Canada Rejoins USMCA Trade Agreement After Intense Negotiations

Article:

Canada has re-entered a revised North American free trade agreement with the United States and Mexico following weeks of intense, high-stress negotiations that approached a midnight deadline. In a joint statement, U.S. Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer and Canadian Foreign Affairs Minister Chrystia Freeland stated that the agreement "will strengthen the middle class, and create good, well-paying jobs and new opportunities for the nearly half billion people who call North America home."

The new deal, reached just before the midnight deadline imposed by the U.S., will be known as the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA). It replaces the 24-year-old North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA), which President Donald Trump had previously referred to as a "job-killing disaster."

Trump, on Monday morning, called it a "great deal," tweeting that it "solves the many deficiencies and mistakes in NAFTA, greatly opens markets to our Farmers and Manufacturers, reduces Trade Barriers to the U.S. and will bring all three Great Nations together in competition with the rest of the world."

The agreement reached on Sunday grants U.S. farmers greater access to the Canadian dairy market. However, it maintains a NAFTA dispute-resolution process that the U.S. wanted to eliminate and offers Canada protection if Trump proceeds with plans to impose tariffs on cars, trucks, and auto parts imported into the United States.

"It's a good day for Canada," Prime Minister Justin Trudeau said as he left his office. Trudeau stated he would have more to say on Monday.

"We celebrate a trilateral deal. The door closes on trade fragmentation in the region," Jesus Seade, trade negotiator for Mexico's incoming president, said via Twitter. Representatives for the government of Mexican president-elect Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador have called a press conference to discuss details of the trade deal on Monday.

Canada, the United States' second-largest trading partner, was excluded when the U.S. and Mexico reached an agreement last month to revamp the North American Free Trade Agreement. The Trump administration officially notified Congress of the U.S.-Mexico trade agreement on Aug. 31. This started a 90-day clock that would allow outgoing Mexican President Enrique Pena Nieto to sign the new pact before he leaves office on Dec. 1.

Trump threatened to proceed with a revamped NAFTA, with or without Canada. It was unclear, however, whether Trump had the authority from Congress to pursue a revamped NAFTA with only Mexico.

Some lawmakers immediately expressed relief that Canada had been reinstated in the regional trading bloc. "I am pleased that the Trump administration was able to strike a deal to modernize NAFTA with both Mexico and Canada," said Senate Finance Chairman Orrin Hatch, R-Utah. "NAFTA is a proven success."

NAFTA dismantled most trade barriers between the United States, Canada, and Mexico, leading to a surge in trade between the three countries. However, Trump and other critics argued that it encouraged manufacturers to move south of the border to take advantage of low-wage Mexican wages, costing American jobs.

Trump campaigned on a promise to rewrite NAFTA - or get rid of it. Talks on a rewrite began more than a year ago. To appease Trump, Mexico agreed in August to provisions that would require 40 percent to 45 percent of a car to be built in countries where auto workers earn at least $16 an hour to qualify for NAFTA's duty-free benefits.

It was surprising that the United States found it easier to cut a deal with Mexico than with Canada, a longtime ally with a high-wage economy similar to America's. "When this got started, Canada was the teacher's pet and Mexico was the problem child," said Michael Camunez, president of Monarch Global Strategies and former U.S. Commerce Department official.

However, relations between Ottawa and Washington soured. In the aftermath of a disastrous G-7 summit in Quebec in June, Trump called Trudeau "weak" and "dishonest." The two countries rely economically on each other. Canada is by far the No. 1 destination for U.S. exports, and the U.S. market accounts for 75 percent of what Canada sells abroad.

Title: Cruz Wins Majority of North Dakota Delegates, but Binding Status Remains Uncertain

Article:

Ted Cruz claimed a majority of delegates in North Dakota on Sunday, though the delegates are not bound to him, leaving their loyalty uncertain. The state selected 25 national delegates, with 18 of those on a list of preferred delegates that Cruz circulated, marking a clear win for the Texas senator.

The delegates met Sunday evening, just as the convention ended, and selected State Party Chairman Kelly Armstrong to be chair of their convention delegation. Republican National Committeeman Curly Haugland and RNC Committeewoman Sandy Boehler were chosen to serve on the powerful convention rules committee.

Party leaders made up many of the slots, including Governor Jack Dalrymple, First Lady Betsy Dalrymple, Attorney General Wayne Stenehjem, and top party donors. However, party activists won a good number of slots as well.

Delegates who said they were supporting Cruz on Sunday were adamant in their support. Rick Becker, who ran a close race for the Republican nomination for governor at the convention, said, "I don't want to hold out making a decision in order to be wooed by candidates." He added, "I'm always standing by principle, as boring as that might be. I know I'm going to support Cruz. I can't fathom what would occur."

With the delegates formally unbound and free to make their own decisions at the national convention, it would be impossible to declare North Dakota's results a clear win for any of the three campaigns. However, the race was on Sunday evening to do just that anyway. The Cruz campaign sought to portray the results as an unequivocal win.

"I'm thrilled to have the vote of confidence of Republican voters in North Dakota who delivered such a resounding victory today," Cruz said in a statement. "As I met them over the weekend, North Dakota Republicans recognized that I am the only candidate who can move this country forward by protecting freedom and liberty."

Even though none of the 17 national delegates contacted by CNN said they were voting for Kasich, the Ohio governor's campaign claimed a victory of sorts Sunday evening. Top Kasich strategist John Weaver tweeted, "Cruz strong arm tactics fail in ND, where he lost key floor vote & helped elect delegates who will vote @johnkasich in Cleveland. #NDGOP16."

Former candidate Ben Carson rallied more than 1,600 state delegates for Trump Sunday morning, with a speech focused heavily on faith and his efforts to teach Trump religion and spirituality. Behind the scenes, he lobbied North Dakota Republican brass one-on-one. Ahead of Sunday's speech, he pulled Haugland into a private meeting and also met privately with former Governor Ed Schafer the night before.

As the delegates packed into this Fargo hockey arena for the final day of their state convention, the Trump, Cruz, and Kasich campaigns worked furiously to identify supporters. Republicans were scheduled to vote for 25 national delegates from a list of 74 nominated delegates.

However, North Dakota's unique delegate selection process, which lets delegates vote for whichever candidate they prefer at the national convention, led to much battling between the campaigns. North Dakota's lone congressman, Rep. Kevin Cramer, endorsed Trump Sunday, shortly before North Dakota Republicans began selecting the delegates to the national convention.

Because the delegates will be unbound, they are not formally committed to any campaign. However, that did not stop the campaigns from working to set expectations so they could claim victory. Trump adviser Barry Bennett told CNN that "a plurality" on the list of 25 preferred were leaning toward Trump after a strong lobbying effort from Cramer, who Bennett called the Trump operation's "Sherpa" over the course of the hectic weekend.

"We'll be drinking champagne here all day," Bennett said, if the slate of 25 delegates picked by party leaders earlier this weekend passes in the convention. Of the 25 people the party leaders put forward, 16 were chosen, and nine new delegates were selected.

Still, as is the case on the ground in states around the country, Cruz's campaign has had a strong presence in and around the convention. In addition to Cruz's speech on Saturday, Carly Fiorina, the former presidential candidate and top Cruz surrogate, has been meeting publicly and privately with potential delegates since Friday.

As many as 10 of the delegates on the preferred list have indicated some or solid public support for Cruz. Kasich's delegate wranglers were equally optimistic Saturday after reviewing the list of party picks, saying they saw at least 20 on their who could be swayed to their side.

In the end, however, the decisions will not be known until the delegates place their vote on the first ballot at the national convention in Cleveland.

Title: Sequestration Cuts Affect Military Tuition Assistance and Veterans' Programs

Article:

The $85 billion in sequestration cuts, which took effect at the beginning of March, will not spare soldiers, veterans, or other federal programs designed to support servicemen and women. The Pentagon, as well as other federal agencies, have announced cuts to programs such as tuition assistance and housing assistance for homeless veterans.

Under a federal housing program run by the Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD), roughly 100,000 Americans, including homeless and formerly homeless veterans, will lose assistance due to the sequester. The program provides state grants to help veterans secure housing. HUD spokespersons have stated that local officials will determine which projects will not be renewed under the program, and they are also concerned about the impact of the cuts on the elderly and children.

Active duty military personnel will also feel the impact of sequestration. The Army announced on Friday that it will no longer accept applications for its Tuition Assistance program, which provides soldiers with up to $4,500 annually to take courses at accredited schools toward high school and college diplomas. The Army could not provide a specific amount on how much the cuts would save, but 201,000 soldiers used the program in fiscal 2012 at a cost of $373 million. The Air Force, Marines, and Coast Guard have also announced suspensions of their programs.

Pete Hegseth, chief executive of Concerned Veterans for America, stated that Washington needs to examine its spending and cut the waste. However, he said, officials have gone after "low hanging fruit" such as military tuition assistance because special interest groups have protected big items like weapons systems.

Congress allowed the drastic, across-the-board cuts in 2011 after failing to reach a deal on a more measured approach to fixing Washington's fiscal problems. The cuts, which will equal roughly $1.2 trillion over 10 years, kicked in on March 1. The Department of Veterans Affairs is spared from the cuts, but cuts elsewhere in the federal budget will nevertheless affect veterans.

A Labor Department program that provides employment-related assistance for veterans is also being cut. An agency spokesman stated on Monday that tens of thousands of veterans under the VETS job-training program will no longer receive assistance. He also stated that reaching a more exact number is difficult because the cuts were made in overlapping budgets, and the full impact will be felt over the next couple of months. However, he confirmed that 33,000 fewer veterans will be served under a state grant program known as Jobs for Veterans.

Meanwhile, Americans have expressed concerns about the federal government's spending amid the cuts to veterans and others, including $250 million in aid to Egypt and an essentially untouchable, $400 billion program to build F-35 fighter jets before testing is complete. A spokesman for Republican Rep. Buck McKeon, chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, stated that McKeon has warned of such consequences for the past 18 months and continues to try to upend the sequester. "No one has rung the alarm bell more than Chairman McKeon," said spokesman Claude Chafin. He also stated that McKeon's objective now is to use House Budget Committee Chairman Rep. Paul Ryan's new budget to end sequester, "not delay, not reverse, it needs to stop."

Title: Americans' Unawareness of Economic Policies and Immigration: A Look at the Perspective of Jonette Christian

Article:

Jonette Christian, head of Mainers for a Sensible Immigration Policy, has expressed concerns about the impact of free trade agreements, deregulation of banking, and immigration on the American economy and society. In an article, Christian argues that these policies were not initiated by the American people but were imposed on them, often without their knowledge or consent.

According to Christian, free trade agreements have led to the loss of American manufacturing jobs, the outsourcing of businesses, and a shift in the nation's identity from makers to consumers. Similarly, deregulation of banking, which led to the 2008 Great Recession, was not a choice made by the American people.

Moreover, Christian contends that the quadrupling of the U.S. population due to immigration, as reported by the Migration Policy Institute, was not a decision made by the American people. She questions whether the American people ever asked Congress to increase immigration levels, suggesting that the influx of immigrants was not a response to a demand from the American public.

Christian refers to this trio of policies - free trade, deregulation, and immigration - as the "globalist's trifecta." She argues that these policies were sold to Congress as a means to stimulate economic growth, and while they did lead to economic growth, they also resulted in winners and losers. The winners, primarily bankers and investors, grew rich, while wages for working Americans stagnated, good jobs disappeared, and the middle class shrank.

Christian criticizes the globalist trifecta for shaping political discourse, convincing both parties that America requires an incessant influx of foreign labor. She points out that even in Maine, this trifecta is influencing political debates.

The Partnership for a New American Economy, a coalition of billionaires, corporate CEOs, and their politicians, is a particular focus of Christian's criticism. She accuses the Partnership of using data and studies to promote the need for increased immigration, often without providing links or considering costs or labor impacts. Christian alleges that Maine editorial writers frequently cite data from the Partnership's website to support the "Maine needs immigrants" narrative.

In conclusion, Christian calls for Americans to think for themselves and question the economic policies that have been imposed on them. She suggests that if employers want to benefit from doing business in America, they should offer livable wages, rather than relying on foreign workers to undercut domestic wages.

Title: New Polls Show Tightening Presidential Race in Swing States

Article:

A new CBS News/New York Times/Quinnipiac University poll has revealed a tightening presidential race in three crucial swing states. The poll shows President Barack Obama's lead in Florida narrowing to three points, down from a six-point advantage at the end of July. In Ohio, Obama still leads Mitt Romney by six points, while in Wisconsin, the race is virtually tied, with a two-point difference between the two candidates.

The poll results indicate that Republican nominee Mitt Romney is closing the gap in these battleground states. However, it's important to note that these polls are based on samples that some analysts argue are flawed.

Ed Morrissey, a political blogger, points out the partisan splits in the samples. In Florida, the poll sample is Democratic-leaning by 6 percentage points, while the mean Florida electorate from 2008 and 2010 was only Democratic-leaning by 1.5 percentage points. In Ohio, the poll sample is Democratic-leaning by 8 percentage points, while the mean '08/'10 hybrid Buckeye State electorate was Democratic-leaning by 3.5 percentage points. In Wisconsin, the poll sample is Democratic-leaning by 4 percentage points, while the state's combined electorate was Democratic-leaning by 2.5 percentage points.

Another significant finding from the poll's internals is the under-sampling of 2008 McCain voters in the Florida and Ohio surveys. The new poll's Florida respondents voted for Obama over McCain by a nine-point margin, while the actual election result was Obama by three points. The poll's Ohio respondents backed Obama by 13 points, while the actual election result was Obama by four-and-a-half points.

A recent USA Today/Gallup poll shows a record number of Americans identifying as independents. Romney holds a "clear edge" on the economy and a larger lead on deficits, while Obama leads on several other issues. More voters say Obama is attacking Romney unfairly than vice versa, the GOP has an enthusiasm advantage, and the generic Congressional ballot is exactly tied. Romney leads men by eight points, while Obama leads women by the same margin.

Title: Congress Returns to Work Amid Election-Year Politics and Limited Agenda

Article:

Congress resumed work on Monday with the upcoming election year shaping an already limited legislative agenda. Republicans have vowed to focus on various aspects of President Barack Obama's health care law, viewing the law's problem-plagued rollout as a political advantage as the GOP aims to maintain its House majority and capture control of the Democratic-led Senate.

House Majority Leader Eric Cantor (R-Va.) announced that the first order of business in the House would be legislation addressing the security of personal data, part of the Republican's effort to protect citizens from the potential harmful effects of Obamacare. In a memo to House Republicans, Cantor promised further steps to curb the healthcare law, including increased transparency in enrollment data disclosure and efforts to ultimately repeal and replace the law with patient-focused reforms.

Republicans also pledged closer scrutiny of the administration's enrollment numbers in the health care program. Meanwhile, Democrats will push for a federal minimum wage increase from $7.25 an hour and the extension of unemployment benefits, attempting to portray the party as more concerned with the less fortunate and focused on addressing income inequality.

Rep. Steny Hoyer (D-Md.), the second-ranking Democrat in the House, emphasized the urgency of extending federal benefits for an estimated 1.3 million Americans whose payments stopped on Dec. 28, stating, "It's about real people, people with families struggling to put food on the table, to make ends meet, including... 200,000 military veterans who are among these folks who are losing their benefits."

Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid (D-Nev.) has scheduled a vote Monday night on legislation by Sens. Jack Reed (D-R.I.) and Dean Heller (R-Nev.) to extend jobless benefits for three months. President Barack Obama, in his weekly radio and Internet address, urged Congress to restore this "vital economic security" for job-seekers.

Rancor marked the first session of the 113th Congress, with few bills passed and sent to the president. The combination of divided government and the upcoming elections is expected to pose an obstacle to major legislation in the second session, counting down to November when all 435 House seats and 35 Senate seats will be on the ballot.

Congress must address several significant unfinished business items before delving into political votes and extended breaks for campaigning. The Senate is set to vote Monday on President Obama's nomination of Janet Yellen to become the head of the Federal Reserve. If confirmed, Yellen would be the first woman to hold the powerful post, replacing Ben Bernanke.

Lawmakers face a Jan. 15 deadline to agree on a spending bill to keep the government running and avoid a partial shutdown that occurred last fall. Passage of legislation in December scaling back the automatic, across-the-board cuts gave the House and Senate Appropriations Committees time to draft a massive, trillion-dollar-plus measure to run the government through September. A short-term measure is likely this month to allow the government to continue operating.

The GOP-controlled House and Democratic-led Senate spent a significant portion of last year wrangling over renewing the nation's farm bill after passing separate, competing versions of the five-year, roughly $500 billion measure. In dispute are crop subsidies and the extent to which the $80 billion-a-year food stamp program should be cut, with the House slashing $4 billion and the Senate $400 million annually. Lawmakers are pressing for a compromise that can win approval from both chambers.

Twenty-six senators have signed on to a new Iran sanctions bill that President Obama opposes while his administration negotiates with the Iranian government over its nuclear program. Proponents of the legislation are seeking to gain the support of further senators when Congress reconvenes, with the hope of securing a full Senate vote this month.

Although the issue may not be an immediate legislative priority for returning lawmakers, it could become a major point of discussion as advocates and opponents of fresh penalties make their cases. Reid spared the administration a vote in December, but this month he may not be able to hold off proponents of tough sanctions.

The majority leader did promise Sen. Kirsten Gillibrand (D-N.Y.) a vote on her legislation to give victims of rape and sexual assault in the military an independent route outside the chain of command for prosecuting attackers. Her solution would take the decision from commanders and give it to seasoned military lawyers. The top echelon of the military, the Democratic chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, and other Senate Democrats and Republicans oppose her plan. Reid backs it, as do several top conservatives such as Sens. Ted Cruz (R-Texas) and Rand Paul (R-Ky.). However, Gillibrand is still short of the 60-vote, filibuster-proof threshold.

Unclear is whether the House will tackle major legislation to overhaul immigration laws. Advocates remain hopeful, buoyed by Speaker John Boehner's hire of a Senate aide who worked on bipartisan immigration legislation for Sen. John McCain (R-Ariz.) and Boehner's willingness to stand up to outside conservative groups and tea partyers over the budget. Boehner and Obama have discussed a piecemeal approach after the comprehensive Senate measure stalled in the House. However, some House Republicans still resist any legislation, fearing it would lead to negotiations with the Senate and a final bill that includes a path to citizenship for the 11 million immigrants living in the country illegally.

Title: JPMorgan Chase & Co. and Other Banks Targeted in Coordinated Cyber Attack by Russian Hackers

Article:

Investigations have revealed that Russian hackers have launched a coordinated assault on JPMorgan Chase & Co. and at least four other banks this month, resulting in the loss of gigabytes of customer data. One of the banks has linked the breach to Russian state-sponsored hackers, according to one of the people familiar with the investigation. The FBI is investigating whether the attack could be in retaliation for U.S.-imposed sanctions on Russia.

The attack led to the theft of account information that could be used to drain funds, as well as the theft of sensitive information from employee computers. The incidents occurred at a low point in relations between the U.S. and Russia, with Russian troops continuing to mass on the Ukrainian border despite U.S. and European sanctions.

JPMorgan, the biggest U.S. bank, said it has taken additional steps to safeguard sensitive and confidential information. The company will contact any customers that might have been affected, though it hasn't seen unusual levels of fraud. The absence of fraud would lend support to the theory that the hack had a political motive, according to a U.S. official and another person briefed by law enforcement.

Investigators have determined that the attacks were routed through computers in Latin America and other regions via servers used by Russian hackers. The hackers took advantage of a type of software flaw known as a zero-day in at least one of the bank's websites, according to one of the people familiar with the investigation. They then plowed through layers of elaborate security to steal the data, which security specialists said appeared far beyond the capability of ordinary criminal hackers.

The sophistication of the attack and technical indicators extracted from the banks' computers provide some evidence of a government link. However, the trail is murky enough that cybercriminals from Russia or elsewhere in Eastern Europe could be behind the assaults. Other federal agencies, including the National Security Agency, are aiding the investigation.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation is working with the U.S. Secret Service to determine the scope of "recently reported cyber attacks against several American financial institutions." The absence of fraud would lend support to the theory that the hack had a political motive, the government official said.

U.S. and European sanctions have altered the way banks are interacting with Russian entities, triggering the ire of Russian officials. In April, JPMorgan was singled out for criticism when it blocked a payment from a Russian embassy to the affiliate of a U.S.-sanctioned bank. Russia's foreign ministry called the move by New York-based JPMorgan "illegal and absurd." The U.S. bank was widely criticized by Russian commentators.

It couldn't be determined whether this month's data thefts resulted in any financial losses for consumers. The people familiar with the hacks didn't specify whether the stolen information included credit-card numbers or other easily sold financial data.

JPMorgan Chief Executive Officer Jamie Dimon has warned shareholders in annual letters that hackers' efforts to breach the bank's computers were growing more frequent, sophisticated, and dangerous. The bank expects to boost annual spending on cybersecurity by 25 percent to about $250 million by the end of the year from 2013 levels.

"We're making good progress on these and other efforts, but cyberattacks are growing every day in strength and velocity across the globe," Dimon said in that letter. "It is going to be a continual and likely never-ending battle to stay ahead of it -- and, unfortunately, not every battle will be won."

JPMorgan fell 35 cents to $59.24 in New York trading as of 1:45 p.m. The shares have risen 1.3 percent this year. Banks must disclose when customer data is breached, a process that can take days or weeks. Companies often don't immediately know what information was taken or who was affected. If a theft leads to losses, consumers have more protections than corporations.

Title: Obama Nominates Three Judges to Fill Vacancies on D.C. Circuit Court

Article:

President Obama announced the nomination of three top lawyers to fill vacancies on the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit on Tuesday. The nominees are Patricia Ann Millett, Cornelia "Nina" T.L. Pillard, and Robert Leon Wilkins.

The nominations come amid political pressure from both sides on the issue of vacant federal court seats, particularly those in the D.C. Circuit. Democrats have urged Obama to move more aggressively with nominations, while Republicans argue that the D.C. Circuit does not need more judges and are promoting a plan to shift seats to other circuits.

In his Rose Garden announcement, Obama criticized Senate Republicans for blocking his judicial nominees, labeling their motives as political and noting that when they do reach the Senate floor, they are confirmed with bipartisan support. Obama claimed that his judicial nominees have waited three times longer to receive confirmation votes than those of his Republican predecessor.

Obama also acknowledged that Democrats, too, held up judicial nominations when he was in the Senate. However, he emphasized that the current situation is unprecedented and called for an end to the political obstruction.

Federal court nominations, which are made for life, represent an important part of a president's legacy. By moving three names at once, the president is signaling that he is ready to use political capital on the matter. Critics of the president accused him of moving now to create a distraction from the troubles plaguing various federal agencies and departments, including the Internal Revenue Service and Justice Department.

The nominees, all graduates of Harvard Law School, are as follows:

* Patricia Ann Millett, who runs the Supreme Court practice at the law firm Akin Gump Strauss Hauer & Feld in Washington, D.C., and has argued 32 cases before the US Supreme Court – until recently, Obama said, a record for a female lawyer. She also served nine years, during both Democratic and Republican administrations, as an assistant to the solicitor general at the Justice Department.
* Cornelia "Nina" T.L. Pillard, a law professor at Georgetown University in Washington. She has served twice in the Justice Department and was an attorney for the NAACP Legal Defense and Education Fund. Obama cited as "landmark successes" her defense before the Supreme Court of the Family and Medical Leave Act and the opening of the Virginia Military Institute to female students.
* Robert Leon Wilkins, who is African-American, is a judge on the federal D.C. District Court, confirmed without opposition in 2010. Before that, Judge Wilkins spent eight years in private practice, and a decade as a public defender in Washington, D.C.

One aspect of the nominees that shows no diversity is their common legal alma mater. Like Obama, they are all graduates of Harvard Law School.

Last month, Obama won the first confirmation of a judge to the D.C. Circuit of his presidency, when Sri Srinivasan was approved 97 to 0 by the Senate. In his remarks Tuesday, Obama pointed to "mounting public pressure" and "vocal bipartisan support" as helping Judge Srinivasan win confirmation. However, he also noted the experience of another D.C. Circuit nominee, Caitlin Halligan, who faced multiple filibusters over 2-1/2 years and eventually withdrew in March.

The D.C. Circuit holds a special place in the pantheon of federal appellate courts, as it hears cases of national and international significance. The court considers the constitutionality of federal regulations and the actions of federal agencies, and is often the last word in cases, since most do not reach the US Supreme Court. The D.C. Circuit is also a steppingstone to the high court.

However, Sen. Charles Grassley (R) of Iowa, the top Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee, wants to shrink the D.C. Circuit, saying its caseload does not justify 11 seats. He has introduced legislation that would shift two of the court's seats to other circuits and eliminate one seat altogether.

Obama laughed with exasperation at the claim that he is trying to "pack the court."

"We're not adding seats here," he said. "We're trying to fill seats that are already existing."

With the addition of Srinivasan, the D.C. Circuit now has four Democratic appointees and four Republican appointees. However, among the court's six "senior judges" – formerly full-time judges who still hear cases – five are Republican appointees. So for both parties, the current vacancies have clear political import.

Senate majority leader Harry Reid (D) of Nevada has suggested he may move this summer to change the rules on filibusters – from a requirement of 60 votes to end debate to a simple majority – on judicial and executive branch nominations. Such a move, known as the "nuclear option," would add an explosive new level of partisan angst to the Washington scene.

Title: Equifax to Pay Up to $700 Million in Settlement Over 2017 Data Breach

Article:

Equifax, the consumer reporting agency based in Atlanta, has agreed to pay up to $700 million to settle claims from the U.S. government, states, and consumers over a 2017 data breach that exposed the personal information of nearly 150 million people. The settlement, which includes a $425 million monetary relief for consumers, a $100 million civil money penalty, and other relief, is expected to be approved by the federal district court in the Northern District of Georgia.

The breach, one of the largest ever to threaten private information, was not detected by Equifax for more than six weeks. The compromised data included Social Security numbers, birth dates, addresses, driver license numbers, credit card numbers, and in some cases, data from passports.

Affected consumers may be eligible to receive monetary compensation by filing one or more claims for conditions such as money spent on credit monitoring or identity theft protection after the breach and the cost of freezing or unfreezing credit reports at any consumer reporting agency. All impacted consumers would be eligible to receive at least 10 years of free credit-monitoring and seven years of free identity-restoration services.

Starting on Dec. 31 and extending for seven years, all U.S. consumers may request up to six free copies of their Equifax credit report during any 12-month period. If consumers choose not to enroll in the free credit monitoring product available through the settlement, they may seek up to $125 as a reimbursement for the cost of a credit-monitoring product of their choice. Consumers must submit a claim to receive free credit monitoring or cash reimbursements.

FTC Chairman Joe Simons stated, "Companies that profit from personal information have an extra responsibility to protect and secure that data." He added, "Equifax failed to take basic steps that may have prevented the breach that affected approximately 147 million consumers. This settlement requires that the company take steps to improve its data security going forward, and will ensure that consumers harmed by this breach can receive help protecting themselves from identity theft and fraud."

Equifax had earlier this year set aside around $700 million to cover anticipated settlements and fines. The company's shares dipped slightly before the opening bell following the announcement on Monday.

Title: Obama Administration Argues for Military Action Against Syrian Regime as Vote Nears

Article:

The Obama administration has begun to make its case for military action against Syrian President Bashar Assad's regime, as votes in the House and Senate approach. In a speech at the New America Foundation, National Security Adviser Susan Rice outlined the administration's position, emphasizing the need to hold Assad accountable for using chemical weapons against his own people and the potential impact on American security if such actions are ignored.

Rice argued that failing to respond to the use of chemical weapons could embolden terrorists and other nations with weapons of mass destruction, such as North Korea and an aspiring nuclear Iran. She stated that not responding could indicate the United States is not prepared to use the full range of tools necessary to maintain national security.

Rice's comments were part of the administration's last-ditch effort to garner support for military action in Syria. Later on Monday, President Obama is scheduled to give interviews to six major news outlets, each focused on Syria. On Tuesday night, Mr. Obama will address the nation from the White House.

Behind the scenes, administration officials are lobbying lawmakers to support House and Senate resolutions authorizing "limited" action against the Assad government. In her nearly 40-minute speech, Rice referred to her experiences at the United Nations in explaining why international action on the Syrian crisis is unlikely, leaving the U.S. in a position to take the lead or allow Assad to go unpunished.

With United Nations action off the table, the U.S. is attempting to build its own coalition, which currently includes France and several other nations. However, the administration is facing growing opposition on Capitol Hill, with several senators stating they will oppose a military force resolution. Some senators, such as Democratic Sen. Heidi Heitkamp of North Dakota, are urging the administration to pursue a diplomatic solution. Other senators, such as Tennessee Republican Lamar Alexander, have expressed concerns about the potential escalation of U.S. involvement, leading to ground forces and, ultimately, American casualties.

Rice attempted to address these and other concerns, stating that the U.S. will not take sides in sectarian struggles or impose its will on the democratic development of other nations. However, she emphasized that the U.S. will stand up for certain principles, including the prohibition of chemical weapons use.

Title: American Corporations and National Identity: A Changing Landscape

Article:

In the aftermath of the Pearl Harbor attack, President Franklin Roosevelt summoned the heads of American industry to Washington, initiating an unprecedented war production effort. Major U.S. companies such as Ford, General Motors, Boeing, and 3M responded by transforming their production lines to meet the nation's war needs. The U.S. eventually reached a production capacity of 100,000 warplanes per year, a feat initially deemed impossible by the Germans.

Recent questions have been raised about the loyalty of American corporations in the current globalized economy, with some companies seemingly prioritizing global interests over national ones. The Daily Caller News Foundation posed the question of corporate American identity to 19 major U.S. companies, but only General Motors and JPMorgan Chase were willing to identify as American institutions.

Billionaire tech investor Peter Thiel has accused Google of "seemingly treasonous" behavior, citing the company's development of a censored search engine for the Chinese government, Project Dragonfly, and its refusal to work with the U.S. military. Google's actions have sparked concerns about the loyalty of U.S.-based corporations with global operations.

Corporations have significant influence in Washington, with dedicated offices lobbying for their interests and funding influential trade associations, think tanks, and lobbyists. This influence extends to former congressional representatives, with over two-thirds of those who retired or lost their seats in the last election cycle now working as corporate lobbyists, marking a record level.

The question remains about the sustainability of this corporate influence in the American political landscape. As corporations grow more global in their operations and priorities, some argue that the interests of American citizens may be at risk. The balance between corporate and national interests is a topic of ongoing debate.

Title: Project Veritas' Claim of CBS News Staging COVID-19 Testing Line Met with Denial from CBS and Cherry Health

Article:

Right-wing activist group Project Veritas published an article on May 6, claiming that a CBS News crew orchestrated a staged COVID-19 testing line at the Cherry Medical Center in Grand Rapids, Michigan. The story quickly spread on Twitter and was picked up by outlets including the Wall Street Journal, The Daily Beast, and entertainment news website Deadline.

In a video accompanying the Project Veritas article, Project Veritas founder James O' Keefe states that an insider from a Grand Rapids medical center claimed CBS News created a fake testing line, diverting doctors and medical personnel away from treating patients to stage the event for CBS News and their national morning show.

However, CBS issued a statement denying any involvement in orchestrating the line, placing the blame on Cherry Health. The statement, included in the original article, states, "CBS News did not stage anything at the Cherry Health facility... Any suggestion to the contrary is 100% false."

The statement was framed as a "BREAKING" update by O' Keefe, who claimed the statement came in response to the article. However, the statement was delivered to Project Veritas on May 5, a day before publication.

The insider's identity and role at the facility were not revealed by Project Veritas, but in his interview with O' Keefe, the insider reveals that he grew suspicious after witnessing the alleged staging, but had no direct knowledge of who was responsible. Only one person in the hidden footage mentions CBS, saying "apparently the news crew wanted more people in the line." The basis for this claim is never explored, and other employees of Cherry Health were caught on camera putting the blame not on CBS but on Cherry Health's director of quality and information.

A representative from CBS reiterated the statement provided to Project Veritas when contacted by ███ Fact Check. In a statement provided to ███ Fact Check by a representative of Cherry Health Medical Center via email, Cherry Health CEO Tasha Blackman concurred that, to her knowledge, "CBS This Morning did not stage any part of their visit to our site." Blackman also denied that she had instructed staff to get into the line, but when asked if that was true of other members of Cherry Health's leadership team as well, Blackman stated:

"I was not aware of any staging that took place. Cherry Health has had a process of pre-screening individuals for COVID-19 testing. On the day of the CBS interview we had 34 prescreened individuals that came for testing. I was not asked for help on any staging, nor was I aware that any staging activities were going on. The only requests we had were tied to the number of patients being tested that day and the PPE supply that we had in place."

It seems some staging took place at Cherry Health during filming for the CBS news segment, but given the statements by the parties involved and O' Keefe's history of misleadingly editing videos, Project Veritas' presentation of events deserves a healthy dose of skepticism.

Title: Federal Immigration Authorities Implement Deportation Halt, Ignoring Eligibility Rules in Some Cases

Article:

Federal immigration authorities have begun granting tentative legal status to some illegal immigrants under President Obama's deportation halt, with some cases reportedly being approved despite not meeting the administration's eligibility criteria. According to Rep. Lamar Smith, the Chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, illegal immigrants who have been in the U.S. for less than five years have had their deportations canceled, contrary to the five-year mark listed by President Obama and Homeland Security Secretary Janet A. Napolitano as one of the criteria.

The documents obtained by Rep. Smith detail how U.S. Customs and Immigration Enforcement (ICE) officers are instructed to actively search for illegal immigrants who may be eligible for their cases to be dropped. These illegal immigrants would then be granted tentative status.

"President Obama is granting amnesty to illegal immigrants behind Americans' backs," Mr. Smith said. He also stated that, although administration officials told congressional offices that it would take 60 days to implement the president's amnesty plan, internal ICE documents show that illegal immigrants have already benefited from it, even though there are no standards in place.

U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS), the agency that will judge most of these cases, has not yet put in place a more formal process for illegal immigrants to proactively head off deportation. ICE will handle a relatively small share of the eventual cases, and their review is easier because the agency already began using broad prosecutorial discretion last year.

Last month, President Obama and Ms. Napolitano announced they would unilaterally halt deportations for illegal immigrants who would have qualified for the Dream Act, legislation that never passed Congress but would have granted a path to citizenship to many illegal immigrants age 30 and younger. To avoid deportation under the new rules, illegal immigrants would have to have been brought to the U.S. by age 16, graduated high school or earned an equivalency degree, not been convicted of major crimes, and been in the U.S. for at least five years.

Those granted a stay of deportation are given permission to work in the U.S., which could lead to hundreds of thousands of new, legal workers entering the economy. The program has come under fire from both sides, with some immigrant-rights activists expressing concerns about the lack of assurances and critics questioning the broad scope of the program and the documentation required.

ICE has halted deportations for illegal immigrants the agency knows have been in the U.S. for less than five years, according to Rep. Smith. ICE spokeswoman Gillian Christensen stated that the agency has broad authority to halt deportations on a case-by-case basis, even when illegal immigrants fall short of the new standards, especially in "humanitarian" cases in which the people in question were brought to the U.S. as children.

ICE officers are already trained in what documents to ask for and how to evaluate them as part of their jobs, according to Ms. Christensen. Acceptable documents they can request include passports, visas, school or medical records, and leases. Part of President Obama's dilemma on immigration is that the U.S. has the resources to deport about 400,000 illegal immigrants a year, which means it has to live up to that level. The latest statistics showed a backsliding this year, with about 49 percent of all illegal immigrants deported in fiscal year 2012 not having criminal records, up from about 44 percent last year.

Title: FDA Warns Against Purchasing Hand Sanitizer Products from Eskbiochem Due to Methanol Contamination

Article:

The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has issued a warning on June 19 advising consumers not to purchase hand sanitizer products from the Mexico-based manufacturer Eskbiochem. The warning stems from the FDA's discovery of methanol, or wood alcohol, in these products. Methanol can be harmful when ingested or absorbed through the skin, and it can be fatal in large quantities.

"Methanol is not an acceptable ingredient for hand sanitizers and should not be used due to its toxic effects," the FDA cautions in its letter.

As the demand for hand sanitizers remains high amidst the resurgence of the coronavirus pandemic, the recent health warning is particularly concerning. With many people struggling to find their usual hand sanitizer online or in stores, they may turn to new brands that may not have previously manufactured hand sanitizer.

The FDA's testing revealed high methanol concentrations in two Eskbiochem hand sanitizer products, Lavar Gel and CleanCare No Germ. Lavar Gel contains more than 80% methanol and no ethyl alcohol, the main FDA-approved ingredient for use in hand sanitizers. CleanCare No Germ contains nearly 30% methanol, the FDA found. As of June 23, the FDA reports no cases of harmful health effects associated with the Eskbiochem hand sanitizers, but urges caution nonetheless.

If you have used a hand sanitizer with methanol in the last few months, the FDA advises that you throw it out. The FDA also advises seeking medical treatment immediately if you've been exposed to methanol, as intervention is required to reverse the toxic effects of methanol poisoning.

Everyone exposed to methanol is at risk for methanol poisoning, but young children are especially susceptible, the FDA says.

The information contained in this article is for educational and informational purposes only and is not intended as health or medical advice. Always consult a physician or other qualified health provider regarding any questions you may have about a medical condition or health objectives.

Title: U.S. Markets Plunge in Historic Drop Amid Coronavirus Concerns

Article:

Stocks experienced another significant drop on Thursday, following President Donald Trump's address and the Federal Reserve's actions, as concerns over the economic impact of the coronavirus persisted. The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed 2,352.60 points lower, or 9.99%, at 21,200.62. This marked the worst drop since the 1987 "Black Monday" market crash, during which the index fell by more than 22%.

The S&P 500 also plummeted 9.5% to 2,480.64, joining the Dow in a bear market. The S&P 500 also had its worst day since 1987. The Nasdaq Composite closed 9.4% lower at 7,201.80.

Kathy Entwistle, senior vice president of wealth management at UBS, commented on the market's volatility, stating, "The coronavirus is scary, and people don't know what to expect. It's like the tsunami is coming. We know it's going to hit any day, and nobody knows what the outcome is going to be."

The Federal Reserve announced it would ramp up its overnight funding operations to more than $500 billion on Thursday and offer more repo operations totaling $1 trillion on Friday. The Fed also expanded the types of securities it would purchase with reserves. However, stocks quickly traded back towards their session lows as investors awaited more aggressive measures to support the economy and target the virus outbreak directly.

Thursday's sell-off was so severe that trading was halted briefly after the open for 15 minutes as markets hit the mandated "circuit-breaker" threshold used by U.S. exchanges. Despite the halt, the Dow went on to notch its fifth-worst decline in its history, according to FactSet. Even the worst one-day drop of the 2008 financial crisis did not reach this magnitude.

Not much was immune to the financial market plunge. Small-cap benchmark the Russell 2000 index cratered by 11%. Gold fell, oil plunged, credit market spreads widened significantly, and even U.S. Treasurys, a reliable safe haven earlier in the sell-off, ended Thursday lower.

Mohamed El-Erian, chief economic adviser at Allianz, stated on CNBC's "Squawk Box," "We are going into a global recession. After what's been happening the last few days, we are going to see a spread of economic sudden stops." He added, "The trouble with economic sudden stops is it's not easy to restart an economy." El-Erian believes the selling won't stop until the bear market hits down 30%.

In his address, Trump announced travel from Europe will be suspended for 30 days as part of the government's response to the coronavirus outbreak. Trump also said the administration would provide financial relief for workers who are ill, caring for others due to the virus, or are quarantined.

However, these measures were not enough for investors, who were looking for a more targeted fiscal response to address the issue of slower economic growth stemming from the coronavirus. Ernie Tedeschi, policy economist for Evercore ISI, wrote in a note, "President Trump in an extraordinary Oval Office address did not offer up major new ideas on stimulus and only said he'd propose a vague payroll tax holiday to Congress without strongly standing up for any firm size/magnitude." He added, "This effectively kicks the issue to Congress."

Cruise line shares dropped sharply. Royal Caribbean closed 31.8% lower while Carnival and Norwegian Cruise Line slid 15% and 20.7%, respectively. Airline shares such as United, Delta, and American all fell more than 21%.

The S&P 500 officially closed in a bear market on Thursday, down more than 26% from its record high set just last month. The Dow ended its historic 11-year bull market run a day earlier on Wednesday. A bear market marks a 20% decline from all-time highs.

Title: Lawrence Summers Withdraws from Consideration for Federal Reserve Chair Position

Article:

Lawrence Summers, a leading contender for the position of Federal Reserve Chairman, has withdrawn his name from consideration, the White House announced Sunday. In a statement, President Barack Obama accepted Summers' decision.

"Larry was a critical member of my team as we faced down the worst economic crisis since the Great Depression, and it was in no small part because of his expertise, wisdom, and leadership that we wrestled the economy back to growth and made the kind of progress we are seeing today," Obama said. As director of the National Economic Council, Summers oversaw the administration's response to the economic and financial crisis early in Obama's first term.

However, Summers faced opposition from some Democrats, including members of the Senate Banking Committee. Summers alluded to the opposition to his candidacy in a letter he sent to Obama Sunday to formally withdraw from consideration.

"I have reluctantly concluded that any possible confirmation process for me would be acrimonious and would not serve the interests of the Federal Reserve, the administration, or ultimately, the interests of the nation's ongoing economic recovery," he wrote.

Summers' ascent to the top of the list to succeed Bernanke rankled some of the president's liberal supporters. He was seen as having been too cozy with Wall Street and was criticized for controversial comments he made about women and math and science.

Shaunna Thomas, co-founder of the women's rights group UltraViolet, welcomed Summers' withdrawal, saying she hopes it serves as "a reminder to all that sexism has no place anywhere in society and certainly not in the highest levels of our government." Thomas called on Obama to nominate current Fed vice chairwoman Janet Yellen, another candidate on Obama's short list, to take over Bernanke's job.

Obama vigorously defended Summers in recent weeks, both in public comments and in closed-door meetings with lawmakers.

"I will always be grateful to Larry for his tireless work and service on behalf of his country, and I look forward to continuing to seek his guidance and counsel in the future," Obama said Sunday.

Summers' decision could make Yellen the leading candidate to replace Bernanke. Yellen, who became a member of the Fed's board of governors in 1994, would be the first woman to run the Fed. Obama is expected to announce his nomination as early as this month. Bernanke's term ends Jan. 31, 2014.

Title: North Korea Bars South Korean Workers from Joint Industrial Park

Article:

North Korea has barred South Korean workers from entering the Kaesong industrial complex, a jointly run factory park located just over the heavily fortified border, in the latest escalation of tensions between the two Koreas. The move comes a day after North Korea announced plans to restart its long-shuttered plutonium reactor and a uranium enrichment plant, facilities that could potentially produce fuel for nuclear weapons.

The Kaesong industrial park, which started producing goods in 2004, has been an unusual point of cooperation in an otherwise hostile relationship between the Koreas. The continued operation of the park, even during periods of high tension, has reassured foreign multinationals that another Korean War is unlikely and their investments in prosperous, dynamic South Korea are safe.

The North's rising rhetoric over the past few weeks has been met by a display of U.S. military strength, including flights of nuclear-capable bombers and stealth jets during the annual South Korean-U.S. military drills. North Korea claims these drills are invasion preparations.

Hong Soon-jik, a North Korea researcher at the Seoul-based Hyundai Research Institute, described the Kaesong industrial park as "the last stronghold of detente between the Koreas." He warned that tension between the Koreas could escalate further over Kaesong, as Seoul may respond with its own punitive measures, and Pyongyang will then retaliate with another move.

It is unclear how long North Korea will prevent South Koreans from entering the industrial park, which provides jobs for more than 50,000 North Koreans. The last major disruption at the park amid tensions over U.S.-South Korean military drills in 2009 lasted just three days.

Seoul's Unification Ministry spokesman Kim Hyung-suk said Pyongyang was allowing South Koreans to return home from Kaesong. Some 33 workers of about 860 South Koreans at Kaesong returned on Wednesday, but Kim said about 480 South Koreans who had planned to travel to the park on Wednesday were being refused entry.

Trucks streamed back into South Korea through its Paju border checkpoint in the morning, just minutes after heading through it, after being refused entry into the North.

Pyongyang threatened last week to shut down the park, which is run with North Korean labor and South Korean know-how. It expressed anger over South Korean media reports that said North Korea had not yet shut the park because it is a source of crucial hard currency for the impoverished country.

About 120 South Korean companies operate factories in Kaesong, which produced $470 million of goods such as clocks, clothing, and shoes last year that are trucked back to the South for export to other countries. The industrial park is crucial for the small businesses that operate there to take advantage of North Korea's low wages but not important for the South Korean economy overall.

It has more significance to cash-strapped North Korea, as, according to the South Korean government, wages for North Korean workers totaled some $81 million last year. This has underscored the risks that North Korea's brinkmanship will result in a miscalculation that leads to an even more dangerous polarization of the Korean peninsula.

Barring entry to South Koreans is a "slap in the face" after the South Korean government recently extended medical aid to the North, said Lee Choon-kun, a North Korea researcher at the Korea Economic Research Institute, a Seoul-based think tank. "I see this as a start for more provocative actions," he said.

"The North has made too many threats not to stop short of any real action," said a senior South Korean government official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, saying he was not authorized to speak publicly to the media.

Title: Comparative Analysis of U.S. Spending on Social Programs, Military, and Safety

Article:

The United States stands out in comparison to its peer nations in terms of spending on social programs, military, and safety. The U.S. dedicates 18.7% of its annual output to social programs, contrasted with 31.2% by France and 25.1% by Germany. The U.S. spends 0.6% of its GDP on benefits for families with children, which is one-sixth of what Sweden spends and one-third the rich-country average.

In health care, the U.S. spends more than its peers, but the system is described as "broken, patchy, and inequitable," leaving people without care and causing financial hardship for those who receive it.

In contrast, the U.S. spends twice as much on military expenditure as Europe, and more on domestic public-safety programs than most of its peer nations. The U.S. incarcerates millions, with an incarceration rate significantly higher than other NATO countries. If Massachusetts, the state with the lowest incarceration rate, were a country, it would imprison more people than all but nine other nations, including Turkmenistan.

Despite these high spending levels, the U.S. does not appear to be safer than its peers. Violent crime rates have decreased in recent decades, but the U.S. still has a higher murder rate than the average among Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) member countries and approximately four times the rate in Canada. The number of rapes, adjusted for population size, is four times higher than in Denmark. Robberies are more than twice as common as they are in Poland. Gun violence is prevalent, with firearm-related injuries and deaths among children considered a "major clinical and public health crisis." Additionally, Americans experience a disproportionate amount of violence from police officers. A Guardian investigation revealed that police shot dead 55 people in 24 years in England and Wales, while there were more fatal police shootings in the U.S. in the first 24 days of 2015.

In terms of social welfare, the U.S. spends roughly double on police, prisons, and courts compared to food stamps, welfare, and income supplements. At the federal level, the U.S. spends twice as much on the Pentagon as on assistance programs and eight times as much on defense as on education. Notable expenditures include the costs of the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, estimated to be around $6 trillion, and annual policing costs of $100 billion.

Proposed solutions to address issues such as homelessness, universal prekindergarten, reducing the racial wealth gap, and eliminating poverty among families with children are estimated to cost $20 billion, $26 billion, $60 billion, and $70 billion per year, respectively. However, these proposals often fail to secure funding.

Annual per-person spending in the U.S. is $31,286 on each incarcerated person and $12,201 on every primary and secondary school student.

Title: Allegations of Misrepresentation and Consequences of the 2003 Iraq War

Article:

The 2003 Iraq War, initiated by the United States under the administration of George W. Bush, has been a subject of intense debate and controversy. Allegations have been made that the primary reasons for the invasion may not have been as stated, and that the U.S. government may have misled the American people, Congress, the United Nations, and other nations.

One of the central claims is that the invasion was not driven by the presence of weapons of mass destruction (WMD) in Iraq, but rather by the desire to depose Saddam Hussein due to his attempted assassination of former President George H.W. Bush, and to secure oil resources or control. It is also suggested that the Bush administration knowingly lied about the threat posed by Saddam Hussein to the Middle East, the U.S., and the world, and that he was, in fact, a stabilizing force in the region.

Furthermore, the invasion has been accused of violating the principles of the Just War, a concept rooted in Judeo-Christian teachings and international law for over 500 and 100 years, respectively. The war is estimated to have resulted in the deaths of 4,500 American troops, 650,000 Iraqi civilians, and injuries to 40,000 American troops. It also displaced 2 million Iraqis and caused over $100 billion in property damage.

The aftermath of the invasion has been marked by the rise of violent extremist groups, such as al-Qaeda and the Islamic State (ISIS), which some argue were drawn to Iraq as a result of the American invasion. The invasion is also said to have exacerbated the longstanding religious and ethnic tensions in the Middle East, particularly between the Sunni and Shia branches of Islam, and between Sunnis, Shia, and the Kurds.

Moreover, the Iraqi military, which was thought to have been defeated or dispersed, has reportedly been infiltrated by ISIS members, who brought their American-made and American-paid-for military equipment and training with them. This has led to concerns about the effectiveness and loyalty of the U.S.-trained Iraqi military.

In the years following the invasion, American troops have been training new Iraqi and Afghan armies. However, some of these trainees have reportedly joined the ISIS resistance, raising questions about the long-term effectiveness of the U.S. training efforts.

These allegations and their consequences continue to be a topic of discussion and debate, with some calling for a reevaluation of U.S. foreign policy and military intervention.

Title: Sotomayor Calls for Greater Diversity on Supreme Court

Article:

U.S. Supreme Court Justice Sonia Sotomayor has emphasized the need for greater diversity in the nation's highest court, speaking during a talk at Brooklyn Law School. Sotomayor, the court's first Latina justice, stated that a more diverse Supreme Court would provide a more comprehensive understanding of various perspectives.

During her speech, Sotomayor did not mention the nomination of Judge Merrick Garland, a highly respected candidate but one who would not add racial, religious, or educational diversity to the high court. However, she expressed the importance of having a more diverse Supreme Court and in the legal profession.

Sotomayor commented on the current makeup of the court, stating, "I, for one, do think there is a disadvantage from having (five) Catholics, three Jews, everyone from an Ivy League school, [and] no one who practiced criminal defense law outside white-collar settings."

Sotomayor's remarks come in the context of a nomination in a unique situation, as the vacancy left by the death of conservative Justice Antonin Scalia in January has not been filled. With the opportunity for Democratic President Barack Obama to fill a seat that could shift the court's ideological balance, Senate Republicans have stated they will not consider confirming anyone before the November presidential election.

In the past, Sotomayor and some of her colleagues have expressed the belief that the high court could benefit from more diversity. However, her remarks on diversity on Friday are significant in the context of the current nomination process.

Since the nomination of Merrick Garland, the chief judge of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, some liberal groups had hoped Obama would nominate another woman or minority. Garland, who is white, Jewish, and has an Ivy League background, is a former prosecutor with a career in the capital and a centrist reputation.

Sotomayor did not mention Garland or touch on the nomination. In response to diversity-related questions from Brooklyn Law students, she stated that varied backgrounds help justices "educate each other to be better listeners and better thinkers because we understand things from experience."

Sotomayor recounted a 2009 oral argument in which Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg suggested that her all-male colleagues had incorrectly equated a strip-search of a middle-school girl to changing for gym class in a locker room because they had "never been a 13-year-old girl." The court ultimately ruled, 8-1, that the search was unconstitutional.

Sotomayor emphasized that decisions depend on the law, not personal viewpoints or experiences. "But a different perspective can permit you to more fully understand the arguments that are before you and help you articulate your position in a way that everyone will understand," she said.

Title: U.S. President Trump Threatens Auto Tariffs, Disrupts G7 Consensus on Trade

Article:

U.S. President Donald Trump's decision to withdraw from the joint communique of the Group of Seven (G7) summit in Canada has disrupted the fragile consensus reached on the trade dispute between the U.S. and its top allies. Trump's tweets, criticizing Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, have escalated the trade tensions.

In his tweets, Trump accused Trudeau of being dishonest and weak, stating that the U.S. tariffs on steel and aluminum imports are in response to Canada's 270% tariff on dairy products. In his press conference, Trudeau had spoken of retaliatory measures Canada would take next month in response to Trump's tariffs.

Germany and France have continued to support the "jointly agreed communique" despite Trump's decision to back away. France and Europe have stated that anyone departing from the commitments made at the summit would be showing their "incoherence and inconsistency."

Trump's actions have been seen as an attempt to disrupt the status quo, following his decisions to pull out of the global climate accord, the international nuclear deal with Iran, and threats to scrap the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA).

The communique, which appeared to have papered over the cracks that have surfaced in the G7, stated that the leaders of the United States, Canada, Britain, France, Italy, Germany, and Japan agreed on the need for "free, fair, and mutually beneficial trade" and the importance of fighting protectionism.

Trump's reversal, announced while he was en route to Singapore for a meeting with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, has left his G7 partners scrambling. Trump's counterparts in the G7 had sought this week to find some semblance of consensus with Washington on trade and other key issues that have formed the basis of the 42-year-old grouping of industrialized nations.

Trump's tariffs are part of his "America First" agenda, aimed at protecting U.S. industry and workers from unfair international competition. The prospect of Trump moving toward an even greater protectionist trade policy is likely to chill financial markets worried about tit-for-tat escalation that could lead to a full-blown global trade war.

Trump has announced tariffs of up to $150 billion on Chinese goods over U.S. complaints of Beijing's trade practices and its alleged theft of U.S. technology. Canada, Mexico, and the EU are also moving ahead with their own levies on U.S. goods. Tariffs on U.S. imports of cars and auto parts could devastate the Canadian auto industry, which is highly integrated with the U.S. sector, and potentially damage Japan and Germany.

The Trump administration announced two weeks ago that it would investigate whether auto imports hurt U.S. national security, the first step toward tariffs similar to the ones he imposed on steel and aluminum imports last week. Earlier on Saturday, Trump told reporters it would be "very easy" to make the case for tariffs on auto imports using the rationale that they threaten national security.

Such a move could make it nearly impossible to renegotiate the terms of the 1994 NAFTA pact between the United States, Canada, and Mexico. On Saturday, Trump repeated his desire to have a sunset clause in an updated NAFTA deal, a demand Trudeau rejected again.

Title: Senate Republicans Face Potential Hypocrisy in Confirming Trump's Supreme Court Nominee

Article:

NBC's Chuck Todd, in a series of tweets on Wednesday, suggested that some Senate Republicans may face a challenge in justifying the confirmation of President Donald Trump's Supreme Court nominee during an election year, following their previous blockade of former President Barack Obama's nominee in 2016 for the same reason.

Todd tweeted, "Will be interesting to see how some GOP senators rationalize the idea that it's suddenly now ok to debate an open SCOTUS seat in an election year. They may fully pull that hypocrisy muscle."

In 2016, Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell led the effort to block the nomination of Obama's final Supreme Court pick, Merrick Garland, arguing that the seat opened up too late in Obama's term and stating that "the American people should have a voice in the selection of their next Supreme Court Justice."

Todd commented that McConnell will have to make a case that midterm elections matter less than presidential elections to confirm Trump's nominee ahead of the midterm elections, adding that it "truly is an insult to voters."

Trump announced on Wednesday that he will pick a nominee from a previously released list of candidates, and McConnell stated that the Senate will vote on Trump's pick this fall. Several Senate Democrats have already pushed back against McConnell's announcement, calling it hypocritical and arguing that the chamber should wait until after the 2018 midterm elections to vote on any Supreme Court nominee.
