Democrats cannot block Trump's forthcoming pick without help from Republicans, who hold a slim 51-seat majority in the Senate. Republicans "went nuclear" and eliminated a 60-vote procedural hurdle when they confirmed Trump's first Supreme Court nominee, Justice Neil Gorsuch.

Title: Violent Protests Erupt in Charlotte Following Police Shooting of Keith Lamont Scott

Article:

Another night of violent protests erupted in Charlotte, North Carolina, following the shooting of Keith Lamont Scott, a black man who was fatally shot by a black police officer. The Charlotte Police Department reported that a gun was recovered at the scene, but Scott's family claims he did not possess a gun, but a book.

Charlotte Police Chief Kerr Putney stated, "Mr. Scott exited his vehicle, armed with a handgun... as the officers continued to yell at him to drop it." The officer who shot Scott, Brentley Vinson, was not wearing a body camera, but three other officers on the scene were. The Charlotte Police Department has not released the footage, citing it as evidence in the ongoing investigation.

The violent demonstrations on Wednesday night resulted in injuries. One man is currently on life-support after being shot in the head by another civilian, and the Charlotte Police Department reported that four of its officers were injured. In addition, journalists found themselves under attack. A CNN reporter was pushed to the ground on live television, and protestors attempted to throw another reporter into a bonfire but were stopped by police.

North Carolina's governor has declared a state of emergency, calling in the National Guard and state police to help restore order. The shooting in Charlotte and a separate incident in Tulsa, Oklahoma, have prompted statements from both presidential candidates, Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton.

Trump, who has expressed support for the police and law and order, stated, "I am very, very troubled by the shooting in Oklahoma and called for a national expansion of the policy of'stop-and-frisk.'" Clinton, on the other hand, has made curbing gun violence and police brutality a central part of her campaign. She said, "It's unbearable and it needs to become intolerable."

With the latest police shooting controversies and the recent terrorist attacks in New York, New Jersey, and Minnesota, these issues are now guaranteed to be on the front burner for Monday's first presidential debate between Clinton and Trump.

Title: NBC's Decision to Interview Alex Jones Sparks Outrage and Boycott Threats

Article:

In a controversial move, NBC host Megyn Kelly has granted conspiracy theorist Alex Jones a platform to question the authenticity of the Sandy Hook Elementary School massacre in one of the first sit-down interviews of her new Sunday night show. The decision has sparked outrage on social media, with calls for a boycott and advertisers pulling ads from NBC.

The backlash follows a teaser for the show, which is set to air this Sunday, showing Kelly interviewing Jones. The parents of the children who were slain at Sandy Hook have been targeted by Jones, who has long claimed that the massacre was a hoax.

In a statement, Kelly defended the interview, stating that her goal was to "shine a light" on an increasingly important media figure. An NBC executive also defended the program, asserting that there was value in having Jones sit down for an interview.

However, many critics argue that a serious sit-down interview is an inappropriate format for covering Jones, given his history of spreading false information and conspiracy theories. They argue that the interview risks validating Jones and disseminating his claims, which have had real-world consequences, including inciting violence and undermining institutions such as the media, science, and government.

Jones' claims include allegations that 9/11 was an "inside job," that the Sandy Hook massacre was designed to push for gun control, and that there is a secret fungus epidemic spreading across the country. The president of the United States has also praised Jones and perpetuated falsehoods that originated on his show.

The parents of the Sandy Hook victims have been targeted by "Sandy Hook truthers" spurred on by Jones, and a woman who claimed Sandy Hook was a hoax was recently sentenced to five months in prison for threatening the father of a Sandy Hook victim.

In April, Jones was entangled in a legal skirmish over his claims that Chobani yogurt company's practice of hiring refugees has brought "migrant rapists" and tuberculosis to areas near their factories. The company is now suing Jones for what it says are "false" and "defamatory" reports.

Families of the Sandy Hook victims have expressed their anger over the interview, with Nelba Márquez-Greene, whose daughter Ana Grace was killed in the massacre, tweeting, "Every week. 5 years later. Still harassed by truthers. You do NOT give crazy a platform. You're better than this @ nbc."

Critics argue that NBC could have used the interview as an opportunity to debunk Jones' claims and provide context for viewers on how he has gained such a large following. Instead, they argue, the interview may serve to legitimize Jones and his falsehoods.

Title: Amazon Halts Police Use of Facial Recognition Technology for a Year, Citing Lack of Regulation

Article:

In a blog post on Wednesday, Amazon announced a one-year moratorium on police use of its facial recognition technology, Amazon Rekognition, while awaiting federal regulation of the surveillance tool. The decision follows years of pressure from police reform advocates and privacy activists, including the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU), over concerns about racial bias and potential misuse.

Nicole Ozer, technology and civil liberties director of the ACLU of Northern California, responded to Amazon's announcement, stating, "Face recognition technology gives governments the unprecedented power to spy on us wherever we go. It fuels police abuse." She called for a halt to the technology, emphasizing, "This surveillance technology must be stopped."

Amazon has advocated for stronger regulations to govern the ethical use of facial recognition technology, noting that Congress appears to be ready to take on this challenge. The company stated, "We hope this one-year moratorium might give Congress enough time to implement appropriate rules, and we stand ready to help if requested."

Liz O' Sullivan, a privacy activist and founder of Arthur AI, described the announcement as a "victory for activists and academics" who have been pushing for stricter regulation of facial recognition for years. However, she noted that it was an "admission that the entire system of surveillance is flawed, biased, and has racial implications."

The one-year moratorium on police use of Amazon Rekognition does not include organizations that work closely with law enforcement to identify victims of child sexual exploitation and human trafficking, such as nonprofit Thorn, the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children, and Marinus Analytics.

In July 2018, the ACLU conducted a test of Amazon Rekognition and found it incorrectly matched 28 members of Congress, identifying them as other people who had been arrested for a crime. At the time, Amazon attributed the high number of false positives to the ACLU setting the "confidence rate" in the system lower than the recommended level.

The announcement follows a similar pledge from IBM, with CEO Arvind Krishna writing a letter to Congress on Monday, stating that the company would no longer develop or research facial recognition technology. Krishna expressed opposition to the use of facial recognition technology for "mass surveillance, racial profiling, violations of basic human rights and freedoms." He called for a national dialogue on the employment of facial recognition technology by domestic law enforcement agencies.

Title: Trump-Russia Connections Raise Questions as Election Nears

Article:

GOP nominee Donald Trump has continued to deny any connections with Russia or its leader, President Vladimir Putin, but questions about such ties have arisen due to an increasingly tangled web of connections between Trump and key players in his campaign, particularly chairman Paul Manafort, with Russia over the years.

The Guardian, a major British newspaper, reported on Saturday that Trump himself added fuel to the growing fire this week when he urged Russia to find and turn over more than 30,000 emails missing from Hillary Clinton's private email server, and then by insisting in a Fox News interview that he was being sarcastic.

However, a law enforcement official has told The New York Times that the "same adversary" that hacked the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee's emails has also hacked Clinton's campaign computer system. "These are sophisticated actors," the official told the Times. "We can't say 100% that Mr. Putin had a hand in any of this, but this kind of meddling in other countries’ affairs is part of Russia’s toolkit," Alina Polyakova, deputy director of the Dinu Patriciu Eurasia Center at the Atlantic Council, told The Guardian.

Trump foreign policy adviser Joseph Schmitz, however, denied a connection between Trump and Putin, but noted it's important to remember that "we had to negotiate with Joseph Stalin when we had a common enemy called Hitler. Bill Clinton went on vacation in Russia when he was a Rhodes scholar; that’s a fact. If anyone is in bed with Russia, it’s the Clintons."

CNN's Drew Griffin on Saturday also examined Trump's ties with Russia, including a revelation that Trump had trademarked several combinations of namesake properties in that country. Meanwhile, Clinton's campaign servers were allegedly attacked by a group known as "Fancy Bear," which is connected to Russia's military intelligence service, also linked to the hack on the Democratic National Committee and leading to the resignation of DNC Chair Debbie Wasserman Schultz.

The speculation is also growing after the Republican platform, approved at the Cleveland convention, removes a call to arm Ukraine against Russia, a move several Republicans have also decried. Ohio Sen. Rob Portman called the change "deeply troubling," while party operative Charlie Black added that the change was "unusual."

The Guardian also notes that Trump's ties with Russia go back as far as 1987, when it was still the Soviet Union. More recently, in 2013, Trump traveled to Moscow to meet with Putin to discuss airing his Miss Universe beauty pageant from there. Moscow billionaire Aras Agalarov, who was a liaison between Trump and Putin, told The Washington Post that Putin cancelled the meeting at the last minute, sending Trump a note and a traditional gift of a lacquered box.

Trump also collected $14 million from Agalarov and other business figures for bringing the pageant to Crocus City Hall, which the Russian billionaire owns, notes The Guardian. Trump also met with Russian pop stars, including rapper Timati and Philipp Kirkorov, who he first met in 1994 when the singer was performing at the Trump Taj Mahal in Atlantic City. He also spent time there with Trump in 1999 and 2013, and tells The Guardian they did not talk about politics, but "about the beauty of Russian and American women."

Trump also sold his six-acre Palm Beach mansion property in 2008 for $95 million to Russian fertilizer billionaire Dmitry Rybolovlev. In the infamous Panama Papers leaks, Rybolovlev has hidden more than $2 billion in paintings by artists such as Picasso through offshore law firms from his wife before their divorce.

Conservative columnist George Will, who opposes Trump's election, on Friday wrote an extensive opinion piece for The Washington Post linking Trump with Putin, who he says is "etching with acid a picture of America as ignorant, narcissistic and, especially, unreliable." Trump validates every component of this indictment, even saying that the U.S. commitment to NATO's foundational principle—an attack on one member is an attack on all—is not categorical.

Title: Vice President Biden Acknowledges Potential Shortfall in Obamacare Enrollment Target

Article:

Vice President Joe Biden has admitted that the Obama administration may not meet its initial enrollment target for the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare). This acknowledgment comes as the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office (CBO) has predicted similar numbers in its latest budget outlook.

During an unscheduled stop in Minneapolis, Biden stated, "We may not get to seven [million people enrolled], we may get to five or six, and that's a hell of a start." The CBO had previously lowered its prediction for the first-year enrollment from 7 million to 6 million due to technical issues with the government's online insurance exchange, HealthCare.gov.

Health policy expert Larry Levitt, a senior vice president at the independent Kaiser Family Foundation, explained that the lower figure is unlikely to significantly impact the health care law as a whole. He stated, "The overall enrollment number is essentially an arbitrary figure that comes from CBO's original projections of what they thought the bill would do."

Total enrollment is important for the law's success in its central goal of increasing the number of insured Americans. However, according to Levitt, the health of the people enrolling is more crucial to the law's viability. He emphasized, "What's much more important in the first years is they get the right mix of enrollees so the insurance market is stable."

The success of the administration in recruiting a diverse group of enrollees will become clear over the summer, as insurance companies begin submitting their rates for 2015. If premiums for 2015 increase, it will indicate that the customers who enrolled are sicker than expected. Conversely, steady or decreasing premiums would suggest that the customers who signed up in 2013 and 2014 met the insurers' expectations.

The impact of lower total enrollment on the broader goal of expanding health coverage may be challenging to calculate. Under the new law, access to insurance is not limited to the exchange. Millions have already been enrolled through state Medicaid offices, and countless others have purchased insurance off the exchange.

Later this year, population surveys will provide information on the number of uninsured individuals, but this data may not reflect the entire six-month open-enrollment period. In the spring, insurance companies will begin filing quarterly reports to state regulators detailing how many people they insure, and organizations like Kaiser will aggregate that data to create a nationwide picture.

Levitt, however, points out that even this data may be problematic. "We'll probably have a data brawl over these numbers for the rest of the year," Levitt said. "We'll be able to see how many more people are insured, how many fewer people are uninsured. What's not knowable is what would've happened in the absence of the Affordable Care Act."

Title: NRA Faces Cooling Public Opinion as Senators Experience Backlash Over Gun Control Vote

Article:

Former President Bill Clinton, during a lecture on public service at Georgetown University, compared the National Rifle Association (NRA) to a hot stove that has deterred politicians from supporting gun control legislation for the past 30 years. Clinton's remarks come as new surveys suggest the public is growing disillusioned with the NRA.

The parable, in Clinton's words, suggests that politicians, like a cat that has been burned on the NRA's "hot stove," are reluctant to take a stance against the powerful gun lobby. However, the political landscape may be shifting as several senators who voted against background checks have seen a decline in their approval ratings.

Alaska Sen. Lisa Murkowski's overall approval rating dropped 8% from February to April, while Ohio Sen. Rob Portman's rating decreased by 9% since October. Nevada Sen. Dean Heller's rating also dropped 3% since October/November. This trend is particularly concerning for the NRA, as it is occurring in traditionally pro-gun rights states.

The growing disapproval of the NRA's stance on gun control is further complicated by the public's discontent with the Republican Party on other hot-button issues, such as immigration reform, marriage equality, reproductive rights, Wall Street reform, and more. The combination of these factors has left today's Republican politicians in a precarious position on gun control.

This week, New Hampshire Republican Sen. Kelly Ayotte, who voted against background checks, faced the new political reality head-on during a town hall meeting. Erica Lafferty, whose mother, Dawn Hochsprung, was among the first victims of the Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting, confronted Ayotte, asking, "You had mentioned that day the burden on owners of gun stores that the expanded background checks would harm. I am just wondering why the burden of my mother being gunned down in the halls of her elementary school isn't more important than that."

Ayotte defended her vote, but the questions posed by Lafferty and others like her are likely to persist. The future of gun control legislation on the national stage remains uncertain, but the growing public disapproval of the NRA and the backlash experienced by senators who oppose gun control may encourage some politicians to reconsider their positions.

In the past, the NRA has been successful in buying elections and influencing politicians through massive spending and grassroots campaigns. However, the tide may be turning, and the heat may finally be on the NRA for a change. For senators who voted against background checks, it appears they have jumped out of the frying pan and into the fire.

Title: Hong Kong District Council Elections and U.S. Congressional Bills: A Turning Point for Hong Kong and U.S.-China Relations

Article:

Hong Kong's pro-democracy movement scored a landslide victory in the city's district council elections on Sunday, with democratic candidates securing almost 90% of the 452 district council seats. The election results have been interpreted as a repudiation of Chinese rule and a clear message of support for the pro-democracy movement.

The election victory comes amid months of unrest in the semi-autonomous Chinese city, with pro-democracy demonstrations and violent clashes between protesters and police. The election results have been seen as a rejection of China's claims that the protests are rooted in Western manipulation and a select few troublemakers.

In response to the unrest, the U.S. Congress has approved two bills aimed at supporting human rights in Hong Kong. The bills, which now go to President Donald Trump for his signature, request the State Department to annually evaluate whether Hong Kong is upholding the rule of law and protecting rights enumerated in various documents.

The election results and the passage of the U.S. bills have been welcomed by both sides, with pro-democracy activists urging President Trump to sign the bills into law. The U.S. has long been a supporter of Hong Kong's unique status, including an independent judicial system and a free-market economy, and the bills are seen as a way to ensure that Hong Kong continues to enjoy special treatment from the U.S.

However, some have cautioned that the district council elections do not have a major hand in putting together policy, and the real test will come during next year's Legislative Council election. The district council has an actual role in determining policy, and it is during this election that Hongkongers could send an even bigger message to Beijing.

The election results and the passage of the U.S. bills have also been seen as a test of U.S.-China relations, with some arguing that a veto by President Trump would betray America's values and be a show of weakness to China. Others argue that the signing of the bill would demonstrate an indomitable American will that Beijing has not previously encountered and which it must now accept in all its dealings with the U.S.

The election results and the passage of the U.S. bills have also been seen as a turning point for Hong Kong, with some arguing that the city's next leader may have less license to chip away at Hong Kong's semi-autonomy. The pro-democracy camp's victory in the district council elections has been seen as a fresh opportunity to cultivate the city's democratic spirit and lay a solid foundation for the future.

In conclusion, the election results and the passage of the U.S. bills have been seen as a significant development in Hong Kong's struggle for democracy and human rights. The election results have been interpreted as a clear message of support for the pro-democracy movement, while the passage of the U.S. bills has been seen as a show of support from the U.S. for Hong Kong's unique status and its struggle for democracy and human rights. The real test will come during next year's Legislative Council election, when Hongkongers could send an even bigger message to Beijing.

Title: Russian Influence on Bulgaria's Shale Gas Exploration

Article:

Russia's influence in Bulgaria, a European country with historical, linguistic, and cultural ties to Russia, has been evident in the country's decision to prioritize Russian interests over domestic shale gas exploration. In 2011, Bulgaria faced a significant challenge to the construction of the South Stream gas pipeline, a project initiated by Russian President Vladimir Putin, which aimed to bypass Ukraine and reduce Russia's dependence on transit routes through the country.

According to Bojan Stoyanov, a former Bulgarian Energy Ministry official who served as deputy energy minister in 2013, a Russian parliament member, identified as a special emissary of Putin, offered what Stoyanov understood to be a tacit bribe to secure support for South Stream.

The South Stream project, estimated to cost over $40 billion, faced opposition in Bulgaria due to geological surveys suggesting the presence of significant natural gas reserves within the country. These reserves could potentially make Bulgaria self-sufficient in natural gas for years and overshadow the advantages of the South Stream pipeline.

Bulgaria, once a Soviet ally, has historically relied on Russia for 90% of its gas, with a route that has left the country vulnerable to pricing disputes between Moscow and Kiev. In 2009, a two-week gas shutoff from Russia during the winter left Bulgarians without heat.

In 2011, Bulgaria's prime minister, Boiko Borisov, granted Chevron a permit to explore for shale gas. However, a well-organized campaign emerged to halt shale gas exploration, partially fueled by supporters of the far-right Ataka party, one of several far-right parties that Putin has cultivated in Europe.

Volen Siderov, the chairman of Ataka, denied receiving direct funds from Moscow. The appeal of these far-right parties extends beyond ideology, as seen in France, where the leader of the far-right National Front, Marine Le Pen, acknowledged receiving a loan of 9 million euros from a Kremlin-linked bank.

Title: Asimov's 1959 Essay on Creativity: A Timeless Approach to Spurring Innovation

Article:

In 1959, renowned author and biochemistry professor Isaac Asimov penned an essay on the formation of ideas and creativity, which was later discovered by his friend, scientist Arthur Obermayer, and published by MIT Technology Review in 2014. The essay was written as a contribution to a research group funded by the Advanced Research Projects Agency (ARPA) to develop creative approaches for a ballistic missile defense system. Asimov eventually left the group due to his reluctance to handle classified or secret information, but the essay on creativity remains relevant to this day.

Asimov, who wrote and edited over 500 works, including science fiction novels, delved into the essentials of creativity by examining the process through which Charles Darwin and Alfred Wallace developed the theory of evolution via natural selection. Asimov emphasized the importance of making connections between seemingly unrelated ideas, which he referred to as "cross-connections."

"What is needed is not only people with a good background in a particular field, but also people capable of making a connection between item 1 and item 2 which might not ordinarily seem connected," Asimov wrote.

Asimov attributed the ability to make cross-connections to certain personality and societal factors. "Making the cross-connection requires a certain daring," he explained. "It must, for any cross-connection that does not require daring, be performed at once by many and develops not as a 'new idea,' but as a mere 'corollary of an old idea.'"

Asimov also discussed the role of isolation in fostering creativity, but he also wrote at length about how to cultivate creativity in groups. He suggested that a group of five individuals, in a relaxed and permissive environment, would be the ideal human petri dish for creativity.

"But how to persuade creative people to do so? First and foremost, there must be ease, relaxation, and a general sense of permissiveness," Asimov wrote. "The world in general disapproves of creativity, and to be creative in public is particularly bad."

Asimov's ideas seem ahead of their time, as they predate radical changes in office structures, the culture of start-ups, and the mass marketing of innovation. Yet, his essay was published at the exact right moment, serving as a timely reminder of the need for true, daring new connections and a call to be informed and eccentric.

Title: West Virginia Supreme Court Justice Robin Jean Davis Resigns Amid Impeachment, Spending Scandal

Article:

Justice Robin Jean Davis of the West Virginia Supreme Court of Appeals resigned early Tuesday, following the state House of Delegates' adoption of articles of impeachment against every justice serving on the court. Her resignation marks the conclusion of two decades on the bench, which has been marred by scandal.

At a Tuesday press conference in Charleston, West Virginia, Davis stated, "We judges weigh evidence as part of our jobs. Unfortunately, the evidence clearly shows that the preconceived, result-driven mania among the majority party members in the legislature can not result in a just and fair outcome."

Davis, along with three of her colleagues, was impeached in the state legislature late Monday. Chief Justice Margaret Workman and Justices Allen Loughry and Elizabeth Walker will now stand trial in the state senate. The fifth member of the court, Menis Ketchum, resigned on July 27 and is expected to plead guilty to two corruption charges in federal court on Aug. 29.

The impeachment articles allege the justices failed to effectively administer the state courts, approved compensation for senior judges in excess of statutory limits, and abused state resources through lavish renovations to their chambers and unauthorized use of state vehicles for personal travel.

GOP Gov. Jim Justice will appoint successors to any justice removed from office following the Senate trial. Local media and state auditors discovered the justices cumulatively spent over $1 million on furniture and aesthetic upgrades for their state offices—Davis spent some $500,000, according to the impeachment articles, including $23,000 for design services and $20,000 for a sectional carpet.

Davis' profligate spending is just the latest iteration of her long history of ethical quandaries. In 2002, The Wall Street Journal reported Davis participated in a case from which her husband, a successful plaintiffs lawyer, stood to benefit financially. A legal ethics expert who taught Davis and her husband at the West Virginia University College of Law said the justice should have recused herself from the matter.

In August 2016, ███ News Foundation reported Davis sold her family's private jet to an attorney named Michael Fuller. Two years after the sale, Fuller defended a $95-million judgment before the West Virginia Supreme Court. Despite the possible conflict, Davis wrote an opinion for the court preserving a significant portion of that award.

TheDCNF uncovered evidence in March 2017 that a Florida-based corporate entity funneled thousands of dollars to her 2012 reelection campaign through an illegal straw donation scheme at the behest of the same attorney to whom Davis sold her plane. The West Virginia secretary of state opened an investigation, though charges were never brought because the statute of limitations expired.

Still, a defiant Davis cast her service as honorable Tuesday, and accused state Republicans of concocting a plot to pack the court with conservatives. "The people of West Virginia have honored me in three separate elections by placing their confidence in me as a justice of the West Virginia Supreme Court of Appeals," she said. "I have returned their faith by serving honorably for almost 22 years."

"I encourage each of you to watch this legislative process very carefully and to vote in November," she added.

Title: Iran-Six Powers Nuclear Talks Extended as Deadline Passes, Progress Made but Challenges Remain

Article:

The nuclear talks between Iran and six world powers, including the United States, have been extended indefinitely after the deadline passed on Tuesday, casting doubt on the possibility of reaching a final deal to prevent Iran from developing nuclear weapons in exchange for the lifting of international sanctions.

In the early hours of Wednesday, there were signs of progress toward building a framework outlining elements of a final nuclear deal to be reached by June 30. State Department spokeswoman Marie Harf stated, "We've made enough progress in the last days to merit staying until Wednesday. There are several difficult issues still remaining." Iranian Foreign Minister Javad Zarif also indicated that work would resume on Wednesday.

Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov said the sides reached an agreement in principle, according to his spokeswoman. The parties would try to finalize a text later on Wednesday, she added. However, people involved in the talks have said many tough details would still be left over even if a framework agreement is reached.

The two big sticking points were the timetable for lifting United Nations Security Council sanctions on Iran and the question of what nuclear work Tehran would be permitted to do in the final years of an agreement. Late Tuesday night, diplomats said some inroads had been made but differences on these points remained.

The Obama administration was forced to accede to the third delay in less than a year in the talks, stoking new criticism from Congress about the direction of the White House Iran policy. The deadline has been seized on by U.S. lawmakers who have warned that they would push for fresh sanctions legislation on Iran if a framework agreement isn't reached on time.

Many lawmakers, both Republicans and Democrats, believe the terms of the deal won't go far enough in preventing Iran from developing nuclear weapons. Senate Republicans are pushing legislation in April that would give Congress the power to approve, amend, or kill any deal announced by the Obama administration.

The talks have encountered few successes since they began in early 2014. Negotiators failed to meet two deadlines in July and November last year, setting Tuesday as the final day to reach a framework of an agreement and the end of June as the deadline for a comprehensive deal. President Barack Obama in February said he saw little point to any further delays.

An Iranian diplomat told state-run television on Tuesday that some progress had been made on the sanctions issues. "We don't want an agreement at any price. We want to guarantee the Iranian people's honor and rights...Our goal is this. Time won't stop us," said the senior negotiator, Hamid Baeedinejad.

The U.S. and its European partners at the talks have long said Iran would only win phased sanctions relief with some U.N. restrictions on nuclear-related trade remaining in place. However, Iran was pushing for sanctions relief up front. Iran was also doubling down on its insistence that after 10 years, it would have no tight restrictions on its nuclear program, including its research work, Western diplomats said. U.S. and European officials have said some of those constraints must stay in place.

After an official said French Foreign Minister Laurent Fabius could leave early Wednesday morning, a senior U.S. official said there was no discussion of giving Iran an immediate ultimatum to make concessions or end the diplomacy. The Obama administration has made an Iranian nuclear agreement its main foreign-policy goal, hoping both to stop Iran from becoming a nuclear power and thaw the deeply hostile relationship between the two countries since the 1979 Iranian revolution.

However, over the past 18 months, as the diplomacy heated up, the U.S. and its partners have dropped a number of conditions they once set for a deal. As the diplomacy has dragged on, skepticism has risen in Washington and elsewhere that a strong deal can be reached. Critics of the diplomacy say the U.S. and other powers have accepted terms that will embolden Iran in regional power struggles and do little over time to prevent the country from developing nuclear weapons. Fueling that debate will be the many questions an agreement will leave unanswered.

U.S. officials have said the deal is a good compromise, which will meet its central goal of blocking any of Iran's paths to an atomic weapon. Western officials say they believe they can achieve their central demand that Iran will be at least a year away from amassing enough nuclear fuel for a bomb for at least a decade.

Missing Tuesday's deadline has no automatic consequences for the talks. The interim agreement reached in November 2013 remains in effect until the end of June. At various points in the past decade, the negotiations have appeared on the brink of collapse, raising the prospect of a military conflict with Iran. While diplomats had appeared confident earlier in the day that a deal could be reached Tuesday, officials described discussions as hard-going as the talks dragged on. A German delegation official said the negotiations had been very tough.

Title: Hillary Clinton Recalibrates 2016 Presidential Campaign Stances

Article:

One week into her 2016 presidential campaign, Hillary Rodham Clinton has begun to adjust her 2008 campaign positions and is seeking to find a balance that appeals to both the Democratic primary and general election.

On same-sex marriage, Mrs. Clinton now supports the legal recognition of same-sex marriages and wants the Supreme Court to overturn state laws defining marriage as the union of a man and a woman. This stance mirrors President Obama's evolution on the issue, who also opposed gay marriage in the 2008 campaign but has since re-evaluated his position.

In terms of immigration, Mrs. Clinton supports driver's licenses for illegal immigrants, a position she held during her last presidential campaign.

Regarding the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP), Mrs. Clinton has distanced herself from President Obama, stating that she is not sold on the TPP, which the president is negotiating. Her campaign has expressed interest in addressing issues such as currency manipulation, labor rights, environmental protection, health, transparency, and opportunities for small businesses to export overseas.

Campaigning in Iowa, Mrs. Clinton has also begun to draw more narrow distinctions with the president. For instance, she has expressed an openness to allowing health insurance to be sold across state lines, a policy that was not included in President Obama's massive health care overhaul.

Republican hopefuls and potential Democratic nomination opponents have criticized these perceived political shifts, with the Republican National Committee stating that "nothing is authentic in Clinton World."

Sen. Joe Manchin III, a West Virginia Democrat, and Virginia Gov. Terry McAuliffe, a Clinton backer, have defended Mrs. Clinton's authenticity, praising her warmth, compassion, toughness, and positive agenda.

Meanwhile, potential Democratic nomination opponents have struggled for recognition as they hit the talk shows, with hosts repeatedly asking them to draw distinctions. For the most part, they have declined to attack, instead leaving it to voters to sort out the Democratic field.

Title: Ongoing Investigations and Allegations of Russian Interference in U.S. Elections

Article:

In the past year, several allegations of Russian interference in the 2016 U.S. presidential election have surfaced, leading to various investigations and inquiries. One of these allegations involves Donald Trump Jr., who met with a Russian lawyer, Natalia Veselnitskaya, in June 2016. Trump Jr. was reportedly seeking damaging information about Hillary Clinton's campaign.

Veselnitskaya has denied working for the Kremlin to lobby for favorable Russian treatment. However, she has been connected with several Russian-related lobbying groups in the past. Trump Jr.'s meeting with Veselnitskaya follows a series of events involving Russian collusion charges, including the resignation of National Security Adviser Michael Flynn and former Trump campaign manager Paul Manafort due to their contacts with the Russians and questionable business interests, respectively.

Several intelligence officials from the Obama administration, including former CIA director John Brennan, former FBI director James Comey, and former director of national intelligence James Clapper, have asserted that they found no evidence of Russian collusion with the Trump campaign to rig the election. However, former FBI head Robert Mueller is currently overseeing the probe into possible Russian meddling as a special counsel, and there are several other Russia-related investigations being conducted by various agencies and congressional committees.

One of the ongoing investigations involves the unmasking of Trump campaign officials' names in surveillance files and their potential illegal leak to the press. Additionally, some Republican and Clinton campaign operatives hired former British spy and opposition researcher Christopher Steele to compile a dossier on Donald Trump that included Russia-related allegations. Steele's firm may have had contacts with Russian lawyer Natalia Veselnitskaya.

The so-called Steele dossier was leaked, and the website BuzzFeed published the entire file despite admitting that they could not verify any of the accusations. Other allegations include the Clinton campaign's ties to Russian interests, such as the donation of funds to the Clinton Foundation and generous speaking honoraria to former president Bill Clinton. The U.S. government also approved the sale of a large amount of North American uranium deposits to Russian interests in a controversial deal.

The Russian government has lost nearly half of its oil revenue due to the innovative American ability to frack gas and oil, which has crashed world energy prices. Russian president Vladimir Putin is reportedly eager to stop American energy exploration and production, and there are ongoing investigations into whether the Russians funneled cash into American anti-fracking groups such as Sea Change.

The ongoing investigations and allegations of Russian interference in the 2016 U.S. presidential election have led to a series of resignations, investigations, and inquiries. The picture that emerges is one of a Russian government eager to do anything possible to hurt the U.S., using a disinformation campaign, spreading Kremlin cash, and playing a gullible and often unprofessional U.S. media. The ongoing investigations have also diverted attention from other global issues, such as North Korea's missile tests, Iran's nuclear program, and the Syrian conflict.

Title: Atlanta School District Faces Largest Standardized Test Cheating Scandal in U.S. History

Article:

The Atlanta Public Schools district has been embroiled in the largest standardized education testing cheating scandal in American history. Thirty-five teachers and administrators were given until noon today to surrender to police in connection with the scandal. This is just the first round of potential defendants in a case where educators allegedly prioritized test scores over actual education, leaving students behind in the process.

According to CBS, investigators claim that the Atlanta school district orchestrated a culture of cheating to benefit those at the top. Nearly 200 educators admitted to tampering with students' standardized tests and correcting answers to inflate scores. Some teachers reportedly held pizza parties to erase wrong answers and circle in the correct ones, while one principal allegedly handled altered tests wearing gloves to avoid leaving fingerprints.

At one middle school, 86 percent of eighth-graders scored proficient in math, compared to 24 percent the year before. Prosecutors say that this progress was a criminal mirage. "The four primary crimes that are charged in the indictment are the statements and writings, false swearings, theft by taking, and influencing witnesses," Fulton County District Attorney Paul L. Howard, Jr. said.

Beverly Hall, Atlanta's retired school superintendent, is among those indicted. Her system's turnaround won her national fame, awards, and over $500,000 in performance bonuses. However, investigators claim she pressured teachers and principals to cheat, and punished those who refused.

One of the victims of this alleged cheating is Nybria Collins, a 15-year-old student who is reading at a fifth-grade level. Despite failing her classes, she kept passing the standardized tests, leaving her mother to question what was happening at the public school. Instead of being prepared to succeed in adulthood, these "educators" left Nybria to fail for a lifetime while they held pizza parties to cover up their incompetence.

The indictments involve racketeering charges, which carry a maximum 20-year prison sentence. Compared to the length of the damage they did to students like Nybria, that seems lenient.

The scandal may lead to a closer examination of school choice, at least in Atlanta.

Title: Justice Kennedy's Retirement Speculation Swirls as He Nears 81st Birthday

Article:

Rumors of the impending retirement of Supreme Court Justice Anthony Kennedy have been circulating for months, with the 80-year-old justice neither confirming nor denying the speculation. The speculation has been fueled by the recent gathering of dozens of Kennedy's former law clerks in Washington, D.C., with some questioning if it would be their last chance to meet with him while he is still on the bench.

At a private dinner with the former clerks on Saturday night, Kennedy made a lighthearted comment about an expected announcement, saying, "The 'bar will be open after dinner.' However, sources close to Kennedy suggest that he is seriously considering retirement, although the timing remains unclear.

Justice Kennedy's departure would significantly alter the balance of the Supreme Court, offering President Donald Trump an opportunity to further reshape the court. Trump's first nominee, Justice Neil Gorsuch, a former Kennedy clerk, joined the court earlier this year.

Throughout his tenure, Kennedy has often been the deciding vote in high-profile cases that have captured the nation's attention. To liberals, Kennedy is a hero for his landmark opinion in Obergefell v. Hodges, which paved the way for same-sex marriage in 2015. To abortion rights supporters, Kennedy voted to reaffirm the core holding of Roe v. Wade in 1992.

However, Kennedy has also sided with the conservative justices on several issues, such as striking down election spending limits for corporations and unions in Citizens United v. FEC and siding with the GOP candidate in the 2000 presidential election.

In terms of a replacement, Kennedy might find comfort in the list of 20 judges Trump has pledged to consider for future Supreme Court vacancies. The timing of Kennedy's retirement could be a factor, as a replacement nominated during a mid-term election year could further politicize an already contentious confirmation process.

On the other hand, Kennedy may be concerned about the politicization of the confirmation process and could choose to remain on the bench until the political climate becomes less contentious. Retiring at 81 would not be significantly different than retiring at 80, and Kennedy would have the opportunity to serve alongside Justice Gorsuch and take up a case on the next term's docket concerning partisan gerrymandering.

Title: Obama's Approval Rating Drops to 47.9 Percent in 18th Quarter, According to Gallup Poll

Article:

U.S. President Barack Obama's approval rating has decreased to 47.9 percent, marking the second consecutive quarter of decline, according to a Gallup poll. The survey, conducted among 45,000 American adults between April 20 and July 19, reveals that Obama's best quarterly approval average was 63 percent when he first took office as president. Since then, the approval rating has dropped to a low of 41 percent in his 11th quarter, during a time when Obama was facing Congress over the debt limit.

The release of these numbers coincides with the president's upcoming series of economic speeches, beginning on Wednesday at Knox College in Illinois. Obama is also expected to push for further action on immigration reform, an issue that has been stalled in the GOP-led House of Representatives despite the Democratic-led Senate having already passed a comprehensive immigration reform bill. Overhauling the immigration system is one of Obama's top priorities for his second term, and he aims to achieve significant progress by the end of 2013 or early 2014 to avoid becoming a lame-duck president.

It is worth noting that this decline in approval ratings is not unique to Obama. Several other second-term presidents have experienced similar drops, with some having worse numbers. According to Gallup data, George W. Bush's 18th quarter approval was 47.3 percent, and Richard Nixon's was 44 percent. The picture was far more favorable for presidents Ronald Reagan, with 58.7 percent, Bill Clinton with 56.3 percent, and Dwight Eisenhower with 63.6 percent.

Gallup stated that historically, presidents' approval ratings tend to decline in their 19th quarters in office. Nixon saw a steep decline due to the Watergate scandal, while Reagan and Clinton received high numbers because they "presided over robust economies at that point in their presidencies."

Title: Congress Approves Temporary Increase in Debt Ceiling, Averting Government Default

Article:

Congress passed legislation on Thursday that allows the government to borrow additional funds to meet its financial obligations, thereby avoiding a potential first-ever government default. The bill, which was passed by a vote of 64-34 in the Democratic-controlled Senate, now heads to President Obama for his signature. The Republican-led House passed the legislation last week.

The legislation temporarily suspends the $16.4 trillion limit on federal borrowing, allowing the government to borrow approximately $450 billion to cover interest payments, Social Security benefits, and government salaries. The deadline for Congress to act again to prevent default is estimated to be August, according to calculations by the Bipartisan Policy Center. Without the bill, the Treasury Department warned that the government could default on its obligations as early as mid-February.

Senator Max Baucus (D-Mont.) stated, "Failure to pass this bill will set off an unpredictable financial panic that would plunge not only the United States, but much of the world, back into recession." He added, "Every single American would feel the economic impact."

The short-term increase in the borrowing limit was proposed by House Republicans, who aimed to re-sequence a series of upcoming budget battles, removing the threat of a potentially devastating government default and instead setting up a clash in March over automatic across-the-board spending cuts set to affect the Pentagon and many domestic programs.

The across-the-board cuts, postponed by the recent "fiscal cliff" deal, are the result of the failure of a 2011 deficit supercommittee to reach an agreement. The panel was established by the hard-fought 2011 increase in the debt limit.

Democrats agreed to the debt increase without contingencies for matching budget cuts, as long-demanded by House Speaker John Boehner (R-Ohio). Senate Republicans offered several amendments, but all failed on party-line votes. Any amendments to the bill would have required the House to vote again.

Senator Pat Toomey (R-Pa.) proposed an amendment to ensure that in the case of a cash crunch, the government would use available tax revenue to ensure that bondholders, Social Security recipients, and the military receive their payments. Senator Rob Portman (R-Ohio) sought to require that any immediate increase in the debt limit be paired with commensurate cuts to spending, which could be spread out over 10 years.

The legislation also includes a "no budget, no pay" provision, which would withhold pay for House and Senate members if the chamber in which they serve fails to pass a budget plan. This provision was seen as a move to pressure the Democratic-controlled Senate, which has not passed a budget blueprint since 2009.

Lawmakers are now focusing on the across-the-board cuts, which would reduce $85 billion from this year's budget after being delayed from January 1 until March 1 and reduced by $24 billion due to the recently enacted tax bill. Defense hawks are particularly concerned, as the Pentagon cuts would allegedly devastate military readiness and cause disruption in defense contracting. The cuts, referred to as a "sequester" in Washington-speak, were never intended to take effect but were instead aimed at driving the two sides to a large budget agreement.

Republicans and Obama now appear to be on a collision course over how to replace the across-the-board cuts. Obama and his Democratic allies insist that additional revenues be part of the solution, while Republicans argue that further tax increases are off the table after the 10-year, $600 billion-plus increase in taxes on wealthier earners forced upon Republicans by Obama earlier this month.

Title: Rick Santorum's Waning Political Relevance Tied to Stance on Gay Rights

Article:

As the announcement of Rand Paul's presidential campaign gains attention, the political irrelevancy of another potential candidate, former Senator Rick Santorum (R-PA), has come to light. This is despite Santorum's near victory in the Republican nomination race against Mitt Romney in 2012.

In recent news, Santorum expressed support for Indiana's "Religious Freedom Restoration Act," a controversial law that allows businesses to discriminate against gay customers. This stance, in contrast to the general opposition from Democrats, independents, and the business community, has further highlighted Santorum's stance on gay rights.

For the past 40 years, the heir apparent to the Republican presidential nomination has been the runner-up from previous years' primaries. If this trend were still in effect, former Senator Rick Santorum would likely be among the frontrunners. Instead, he trails in the single digits, a position he has maintained since the beginning of this election cycle's polling. According to the Polling Report, he has not reached 4 percent in over a year.

The reason for Santorum's low standing is attributed to his strong opposition to gay rights. While this might have been enough to make him a strong contender in the GOP primaries a decade ago, today's Americans are increasingly in favor of full legal equality for the gay community. This shift in public opinion has significantly impacted Santorum's chances at the presidency, despite his other political weaknesses, such as his landslide loss in the Pennsylvania Senate race in 2006.

Furthermore, Republicans are less religiously-minded in their politics than they have been in the past. While many conservatives still express support for using religion to shape government policies, a growing number perceive religion as losing its influence in American life. This shift in religious beliefs and practices has contributed to Santorum's declining political relevance.

The Christian Right, a historically significant force in American politics, has also seen a decline in its influence. While Christianity has been politicized since the early days of the republic, the Christian Right as we know it today is characterized by its religiously-tinted patriotism and conservative stances on issues like gay rights, the drug wars, opposition to the '60s counterculture, reproductive choice, and the separation of church and state.

Although Christianity remains a factor in American politics, the days when a candidate like Rick Santorum can play a dominant role in Republican Party politics may be coming to an end. The Christian Right's grip on the GOP has weakened over the past two presidential elections, as candidates like John McCain and Mitt Romney have focused less on their religiosity in their campaigns and religious conservatives have lost touchstone cultural battles on issues like marijuana legalization and gay marriage.

In conclusion, Rick Santorum's stance on gay rights and the changing political landscape have contributed to his waning political relevance. The Christian Right, a historically significant force in American politics, has seen a decline in its influence, and the days when a candidate like Santorum can play a dominant role in Republican Party politics may be coming to an end.

Title: Presidential Candidates' Climate Change and Economic Policies

Article:

In the ongoing 2016 U.S. Presidential race, both candidates, Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump, have outlined their plans regarding climate change and economic policies in coal-producing regions.

Hillary Clinton has proposed a plan to invest in job creation and economic development in coal communities. She emphasizes the historical role of these regions in powering the nation and aims to prevent their decline. Clinton also intends to honor the Paris Climate Agreement's pledge, aiming to reduce emissions up to 30 percent below 2005 levels by 2025. She seeks to collaborate with Canada and Mexico to negotiate a North American Climate Compact, aiming to reduce emissions and accelerate the clean energy transition across the continent.

Donald Trump, on the other hand, does not consider global warming as the most pressing threat to the nation. He criticizes Clinton's climate plan, stating it could cost the U.S. economy $5 trillion. Trump also points out that China, the world's largest polluter, continues to increase its emissions for at least 14 more years. He argues that manufacturing products in the U.S. is environmentally superior due to higher environmental standards compared to countries like China.

Regarding income inequality, Hillary Clinton states that many hardworking Americans face disadvantages. She aims to ensure that no one who works hard should live in poverty or worry about retiring with dignity. Further details about her plan to reduce income inequality were not provided in the source text.

Title: Senate's Acquittal of President Trump Reflects Malapportioned Senate, Not Popular Vindication

Article:

In a 52-48 vote, the U.S. Senate acquitted President Donald Trump on charges of abuse of power, and in a 53-47 vote, on obstruction of Congress charges. However, a closer examination of the Senate's configuration reveals that the majority of senators voting to keep Trump in office is a result of the Senate's malapportioned system that systemically advantages Republicans.

The Senate, with its structure that grants equal representation to each state regardless of population, means that a less populous state like Wyoming, with a population of approximately 570,000, has the same representation as California, with a population of over 39 million. Democrats control a majority of Senate seats (26-24) representing the most populous half of the states. However, Republicans hold a majority in the Senate as a whole due to their 29-21 lead in the least populous half of the states. This means that the current Republican Senate "majority" represents about 15 million fewer people than the Democratic "minority."

On the first article of impeachment, abuse of power, Republican Sen. Mitt Romney joined every member of the Democratic caucus to vote for removal. This means that the senators voting to convict represent about 170 million individuals, 18 million more people than the bloc of senators who voted to acquit.

To derive these numbers, a two-column spreadsheet was created, with columns labeled "acquit" and "convict." In each state where both senators voted to acquit, the full population of the state was allocated to the "acquit" column. Similarly, in states where both senators voted to convict, the full population of the state was allocated to the "convict" column. In states where the two senators split their vote, half the state's population was allocated to one column and half to the other.

In total, the senators voting to acquit represent about 152 million individuals, while senators voting to convict represent about 170 million individuals. As a practical matter, Trump likely would remain in office even in a fairly apportioned Senate, as the Constitution requires a two-thirds majority of the members present for conviction.

Nevertheless, it is worth noting that senators representing about 53% of the nation voted to remove Trump from office, a far different narrative than the raw vote in the Senate suggests.

Title: Charleston Church Shooting Suspect Dylann Roof Captured in North Carolina

Article:

Dylann Roof, a 21-year-old man, has been apprehended in Shelby, North Carolina, following a manhunt in connection with the shooting deaths of nine individuals at a historically black church in Charleston, South Carolina. The arrest occurred during a traffic stop, as authorities were alerted to suspicious activity, according to authorities.

Charleston Police Chief Greg Mullen described Roof as the suspect who "obviously committed a tragic, heinous crime last night in the city of Charleston." He credited "unparalleled cooperation" between law enforcement agencies for the quick arrest. Roof was taken into custody without incident.

Earlier Thursday, police released photographs of the young, white man suspected of being the gunman who shot and killed nine people at a historic black church during a Wednesday night prayer meeting. The FBI was searching for Dylann Roof Thursday morning, noting he is 5-foot-9, approximately 120 pounds, and may be driving a black 2000 Hyundai Elantra sedan.

Roof has been arrested twice as an adult, once for a drug-related offense and another for a trespassing charge. He was out on bond at the time of the shooting rampage, according to court records.

The Justice Department's Civil Rights Division, the FBI, and the U.S. Attorney's Office for the District of South Carolina are opening a hate crime investigation into the shooting.

The suspect joined the prayer group inside the church for an hour before opening fire at about 9 p.m. Wednesday, according to Chief Mullen. The deadly attack at Emmanuel AME church, one of the oldest black churches in the country, shook Charleston and sent shockwaves across the country.

Speaking on the floor of the U.S. House, Rep. Jeff Duncan, a South Carolina Republican, asked lawmakers to pray for the 180-year-old Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church and those impacted by the shooting.

Republican presidential candidate Jeb Bush canceled a campaign event Thursday morning in Charleston due to the shooting. Sen. Lindsey Graham, another 2016 GOP presidential candidate, canceled scheduled campaign stops in Philadelphia and New Hampshire this weekend to return home.

Sen. Tim Scott said on Thursday that he wanted "swift justice" for those who were killed during the shooting. The South Carolina Republican made the comments after catching a flight from Washington, D.C., to his home state Thursday morning.

The Rev. Al Sharpton, who has been a fixture at scenes of racial unrest, said he was likely heading to Charleston. Tips had already come in from across the country, according to Chief Mullen, who urged people to phone in tips to a hotline: 1-800-CALL-FBI.

Title: Five Concerns for Libertarians in the New Year

Article:

As the year 2016 draws to a close, many individuals are eager to usher in the new year. However, before popping the champagne, it is crucial to consider five areas of concern for libertarians in 2017.

1. Marijuana Legalization: With most Americans supporting the legalization of marijuana, 2017 could pose challenges for pro-legalization advocates. President-elect Donald Trump has expressed that the issue should be left to the states, but he has appointed anti-marijuana lawmakers to key positions in his cabinet. Notably, Senator Jeff Sessions of Alabama, who has been tapped as Attorney General, has long opposed legalization and has criticized the Obama administration and the Department of Justice for not enforcing federal marijuana laws.

2. National Debt: As Donald Trump prepares to take office, he will inherit a debt that has nearly doubled under President Obama. In early 2017, the national debt is set to hit a staggering $20 trillion. Estimates from the Committee for a Responsible Budget suggest that Trump's policy proposals will add another $5.3 trillion over the next four years.

3. Free Markets and Globalization: While globalization and free trade have historically lifted millions out of poverty and raised living standards across the United States, 2017 enters with both Democrats and Republicans questioning the fundamental value of free markets. The new administration has promised to intervene in the affairs of private companies, and President Trump has openly threatened a costly trade war with China.

4. Fake News: Hillary Clinton recently referred to fake news as an "epidemic" at a public event, stating that the trend "can have real-world consequences." In response, Facebook is testing new plug-ins to limit misinformation and partnering with fact-checking groups to root out false news items, causing concerns of censorship on the popular social media platform.

5. Surveillance Powers: Under a Trump administration, the FBI, NSA, and CIA are likely to see expanded surveillance powers. Some of these changes are already happening, with a new rule approved this fall allowing federal agents with a single search warrant to hack millions of Americans' computers or smartphones at once. Additionally, the United Kingdom recently approved the Investigatory Powers bill, which grants the UK's global surveillance program authorities to create a new government database that will store the web history of every citizen in the country.

Produced and written by Alexis Garcia. Music by Letter Box.

Title: Trump and Macron Exchange Words on ISIS Fighters and NATO in London

Article:

In a tense exchange on Tuesday in London, President Donald Trump and French President Emmanuel Macron engaged in a heated discussion regarding ISIS fighters and NATO. The exchange occurred just hours after Trump criticized Macron's rebuke of NATO.

During the exchange, Trump asked Macron if he would like "some nice ISIS fighters" and joked about Macron's response, which urged Trump to "be serious" and called for a broader push against ISIS. Trump later took another swipe at Macron, calling his response "one of the greatest non-answers I've ever heard."

The exchange came hours after Trump criticized Macron's comments about the NATO alliance, referring to it as a "very dangerous statement" and stating that the U.S. "has not spoken to the president about that." Trump also noted that France, which was invaded twice during both World Wars, "needs NATO more than anyone."

Macron's remarks came weeks after Turkey, a member of NATO, invaded northern Syria. Macron had previously stated that the U.S.'s decision to withdraw troops from northeastern Syria marked the "brain death" of NATO.

In a separate issue, Macron recently imposed a French digital services tax on American companies, including Facebook, Google, and Twitter. The White House has announced that the tax will be met with tariffs of up to 100% on $2.4 billion worth of French products such as cheese, yogurt, sparkling wine, and makeup. Trump has expressed disapproval of the tax, stating, "I'm not so in love with Facebook, Google, or Twitter, but I don't want France taxing American companies."

The exchange between Trump and Macron occurred as Trump is set to meet with NATO members during a two-day summit in London. Trump would not confirm if he will meet with Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdoğan. Turkish media in late November quoted Erdoğan's adviser saying the country was considering dropping out of NATO.

Title: U.S. Withdrawal from WHO Could Impact Global Response to Future Pandemics

Article:

The withdrawal of the United States from the World Health Organization (WHO) by former President Donald Trump has raised concerns about the nation's readiness to respond to future pandemics. The move, which is still legally questionable, has led to a potential disengagement of U.S. officials and experts from international institutions, potentially encouraging other nations to follow suit.

Loyce Pace, the president of the Global Health Council, stated that this disengagement could harm the WHO at a time when it is most needed and further diminish America's already damaged international standing. The U.S., which has mishandled its own COVID-19 outbreak, bought up world stocks of important drugs, and withdrawn from global alliances, may receive less support or warnings in case of a new crisis.

In a positive scenario, a second virus could be contained due to increased global vigilance. The new pathogen would find it harder to spread in an alert world, be rapidly detected, and potentially fizzle out due to cautious citizens. The same tests used for diagnosing COVID-19 could be adapted to cover the new pathogen, and if the new pathogen is a flu strain, existing vaccines could be tweaked to protect against it.

However, in countries like the U.S., Brazil, Russia, and India, which have struggled with COVID-19, a second respiratory virus could go unnoticed due to resources being redirected to combat the ongoing pandemic. According to Lauren Sauer, who works on disaster preparedness at Johns Hopkins Medicine, resources like swabs, storage tubes, healthcare workers, and public-health experts are either running out or burning out. A second respiratory virus would further tax the same resources that the U.S. has failed to adequately marshal for COVID-19.

Title: The Decline of San Francisco: A Comparative Study of the City's Transformation

Article:

The transformation of San Francisco, once known for its breathtaking views, delectable food, and cool jazz, has been stark. The city, now infamous for its homeless population and unsanitary conditions, has been compared to Bombay, with some of the dirtiest slums in America.

Lee Edwards, a Distinguished Fellow in Conservative Thought at The Heritage Foundation, recounts his experiences in San Francisco, having first visited the city in 1964 as a member of Barry Goldwater's political team. Back then, the city was a vibrant hub, with its streets and hills freely roamed. Today, one must watch their step to avoid human feces and open displays of drug use in Union Square.

The city's shift is not only visible in its streets but also in its societal values. In the 1960s, the city was home to conservative ideals, with the prevalence of "The Conscience of a Conservative" and opposition to marijuana legalization. Today, California is known for its marijuana cultivation and a shift in societal values, with the nuclear family disappearing, gay rights taking precedence, and socialism gaining traction.

Edwards attributes this shift to the influence of political philosophers such as John Rawls, who argues that there is no absolute right or wrong, and that the purpose of government is to rectify every injustice. This contrasts with the Founding Fathers' vision of a system of checks and balances to limit the role of government.

The government Rawls envisions, according to Edwards, is empowered to enforce a theory without any institutional restraints. This, he says, is a departure from the principles outlined in the Declaration of Independence and the Constitution, which rely on self-evident truths accumulated through 2,500 years of Western civilization.

Edwards, after witnessing the decline of San Francisco, found hope in Dallas, a city known for its clean streets, optimistic residents, and shining skyscrapers. The young professionals he met in Dallas were excited about the future, offering a contrast to the despair felt in San Francisco.

Edwards concludes that the decline of San Francisco serves as a reminder of the importance of freedom and individual responsibility, quoting Milton Friedman on the significance of what one does with that freedom. The future, he suggests, lies in the hands of the citizens of San Francisco, who must resolve to take back their city.

Title: Study Suggests Moral Disapproval as Primary Reason for Same-Sex Marriage Bans

Article:

Indiana University sociologist Brian Powell's research suggests that moral disapproval of homosexuality is the primary reason for bans on same-sex marriage, as opposed to public policy considerations. In a survey published recently in the sociological journal Social Currents, Powell found that the majority of opposition to same-sex marriage is rooted in religious beliefs.

One response that reflected the majority of opposition was, "Because I don't believe God intended them to be that way." Powell acknowledges that people have a right to their beliefs and values, but he argues that if public opinion drives public policy, the real motivation for banning same-sex marriage is moral disapproval over homosexuality.

This finding could present a challenge for supporters of traditional marriage, as moral disapproval does not make a valid legal case. In fact, same-sex marriage proponents argue that such a case would be unconstitutional.

The longstanding courtroom debate over same-sex marriage has begun to address a particular legal term: "animus." Animus is the notion that a law has no compelling public interest and is driven merely by a moral disapproval so strong that it causes harm to a group that's viewed as inferior. In the case of same-sex marriage, proponents argue that harm is denying gays and lesbians the basic right to marry.

IU law professor Steve Sanders, who is co-counsel on an amicus brief from the Human Rights Campaign, argues that state bans on same-sex marriage are unconstitutional because they're based on animus. The brief will be filed in the Supreme Court same-sex marriage case, which is poised to become the definitive ruling on the issue.

However, those fighting same-sex marriage adamantly disagree that their stance is fueled by animus. Such an argument, they say, places blame on every person who supported same-sex marriage bans as having evil intent.

If animus motivated Indiana's former same-sex marriage ban, said Curt Smith of the Indiana Family Institute, "that means that the 150 legislators—a majority of whom supported it—and former Gov. Frank O'Bannon had to have hatred for gays in their hearts when they voted for and supported that bill. I just think that's a wrong analysis, but it's also a tremendous discredit to the men and women who serve in the legislature and our governor."

Instead, Smith points to specific public policy considerations, such as the benefits of traditional marriages for couples, society, and children. However, proponents of same-sex marriage argue that the public policy arguments are flimsy at best.

For example, one such public policy argument is that marriage promotes "responsible procreation" and thus limits the number of children born accidentally. But since same-sex couples cannot naturally reproduce, they were excluded from the definition of marriage.

Judge Richard Posner addressed this in the recent 7th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals majority opinion that maintained same-sex marriage bans were unconstitutional in states including Indiana and Wisconsin. Posner wrote that if responsible procreation were a real justification for banning same-sex marriages, the state also would not allow people who are infertile to marry. He added that the policy argument "is so full of holes that it can not be taken seriously." He concluded that the states failed to show a valid policy interest for discriminatory bans on same-sex marriage.

Sanders, the IU law professor, explained further: If states merely want to "protect marriage" by denying same-sex couples from wedding, then why also refuse to recognize gay marriages from other states, prohibit civil unions, and deny domestic partnership benefits?

"To do something like that," Sanders said, "begins to feel like it's more motivated out of spite than any sort of sensible public policy."

But if that sounds like animus, not everyone—or court decision—concurs. The 6th Circuit Court of Appeals, which oversees states including Ohio, did not agree that animus existed in its evaluation of same-sex marriage bans. The court upheld such bans, a decision out of chorus with other circuits that propelled the issue to be heard this summer in the U.S. Supreme Court.

"For most people," read the 6th Circuit majority opinion authored by Judge Jeffrey Sutton, "whether for or against the amendment, the truth of why they did what they did is assuredly complicated, making it impossible to pin down any one consideration, as opposed to a rough aggregation of factors, as motivating them."

Sutton also refused to impugn traditional marriage supporters for wanting to uphold what has been a longtime social norm that has only recently been thrown into flux. He accepted policy arguments for responsible procreation as a valid, rational basis for state bans while acknowledging flaws. And even if he did not find animus, he was careful to note that allowing same-sex marriage seemed inevitable.

Still, he wrote that should be a decision left up not to the courts, but to the democracy— "as fellow citizens seeking to resolve a new social issue in a fair-minded way."

Powell's sociology research notes that public opinion on same-sex marriage has been changing, and he gives a nod to some interesting questions that could tendril off the concept of animus as the debate moves forward. What happens to public opinion if same-sex couples gain more legal rights? Or, Powell wrote, will it subside fears and animosity toward same-sex couples?

Title: Norway's Paternity Leave Policy and Its Impact on Gender Wage Gap

Article:

Norway's implementation of mandatory paternity leave in the early 1990s, a first in Europe, has been credited with significantly reducing the gender wage gap in the country. In 1991, working women in Norway made about 20 percent less than men, according to data from the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD). By 2010, this gap had shrunk to 8.3 percent.

The policy, which initially offered four weeks of mandatory paternity leave and has since been extended to 10 weeks, has had a cultural and economic impact. Fathers taking several months off to care for their children is now commonplace in Norway. This shift in cultural attitudes, coupled with the economic benefits, has contributed to the reduction in the gender wage gap.

While holding up Norway's policy as a solution for social issues in the United States may be problematic due to differences in size, social progressiveness, and government structure, advocates for gender equality are using the example to support the idea that supporting women at home is crucial for their success in the workplace. They argue that increased investment in child care could help shrink the pay gap, with the added benefit of growing the economy.

According to an analysis from the left-leaning Economic Policy Institute, access to affordable child care could help increase the participation of women in the labor force, thereby growing the economy by an estimated $210 billion each year.

The gender wage gap in the United States is a persistent issue. Women in the American workforce make 79 cents for every dollar a white man makes, and the gap is wider for women of color, with black women earning 60 cents and Latino women earning 55 cents for every dollar a white man earns. This wage disparity costs American women a combined $500 billion annually, according to a report released Tuesday by the National Partnership for Women & Families.

If the gap were eliminated, on average, "a working woman in the United States would have enough money for approximately 83 more weeks of food for her family, seven more months of mortgage and utilities payments, 11 more months of rent, or nine more years of birth control," the report reads.

The wage disparity between men and women has barely changed over the past two decades, and there has been small but promising movement on family leave and paid time off. A January poll found that 80 percent of likely voters, including 94 percent of Democrats, 80 percent of Independents, and 65 percent of Republicans, characterized things like equal pay, paid time off, and affordable child care as "good for our nation."

Three states, Rhode Island, California, and New York, as well as cities like Washington, D.C., and San Francisco, have introduced their own paid-leave rules. Major tech companies, from Twitter to Netflix to Etsy, have been introducing increasingly competitive and inclusive paid-leave allowances for employees.

However, there are still obstacles to overcome. Only 13 percent of US workers have access to any paid leave at all, and "if you look at the states with the populations most in need, against those that have taken action, there’s a pretty substantial mismatch," says Vicki Shabo, vice president of the National Partnership for Women & Families. "The states that need it are not inclined to make their own laws, and that’s why federal action is needed."

Investments in child care are also important in addressing equality, but they present challenges. In 33 states, outside infant care costs more than in-state college tuition. Paying for care for two children costs more than rent in most of the country, and it's a cost that even the highly competitive tech industry has yet to address. However, Shabo emphasizes that these investments contribute to workplace retention and help women stay employed, reducing turnover costs.

Title: Critics Accuse The New York Times of Hypocrisy Over Hiring of Sarah Jeong

Article:

Critics are accusing The New York Times of a "hypocritical double standard" following the newspaper's hiring of tech writer Sarah Jeong. The controversy stems from several derogatory tweets Jeong posted, primarily in 2014, that are now under scrutiny.

Jeong's tweets included comments such as expressing joy at being "cruel to old white men" and using the "CancelWhitePeople" hashtag. The Times, in a statement on Thursday, defended Jeong, attributing her offensive comments to a young Asian woman "imitating the rhetoric" of her own online harassers.
