Conservative columnist Daniella Greenbaum, who recently resigned from her job as a columnist at Business Insider, has criticized the situation. Greenbaum stated, "The issue at hand here is not about whether Jeong's tweets were racist or not." Instead, Greenbaum argues that the hypocrisy is the real issue.

Greenbaum, a young columnist who has garnered attention similar to Jeong, was censored by her liberal colleagues after publishing a piece defending Scarlett Johansson for playing a transgender man. Johansson later backed away from the role.

Greenbaum has noticed that many in the media industry have rushed to defend Jeong, while allegedly not extending the same courtesy to those who hold conservative views. Greenbaum said, "The New York Times, and much of the media chose to believe that she was kidding, or to posit that even if she wasn't kidding, her misguided beliefs are not reason enough to fire her."

High-powered liberal media members such as HuffPost Editor-in-Chief Lydia Polgreen and leadership at The Verge, where Jeong currently works, have defended her rhetoric. Greenbaum described this as an "enormous, hypocritical double standard that is entirely unjust" in the media industry.

Greenbaum also expressed skepticism about how Jeong would react if a conservative were in a similar situation, stating, "Let's see how Jeong reacts next time a conservative finds themselves in a similar situation. Something tells me she won't speak out on their behalf."

Media Research Center analyst Kristine Marsh wrote that the Times' statement justifying Jeong's tweets was "laughable." Social media users have also expressed their disapproval of the Times' decision on Twitter.

The New York Times has continued to support Jeong, stating in their announcement of her hiring that she was a subject of frequent online harassment and that her journalism and being a young Asian woman were factors in their decision.

Title: Romney Claims He Paid a Minimum Tax Rate of 13% Over the Past Decade

Article:

Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney has disclosed that he paid a minimum tax rate of 13% over the past ten years. During an appearance in South Carolina, Romney stated, "I never paid less than 13%" in taxes over the past decade.

The statement was made in response to demands, primarily from Democrats but also from some Republicans, for Romney to release several years of his tax returns. He has already released his 2010 tax returns, which showed an effective federal tax rate of 13.9%. Romney has promised to release his 2011 returns before the election.

Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid of Nevada has claimed that an unnamed source told him Romney paid no taxes over the past decade. In response, Romney said, "I did go back and look at my taxes and over the past 10 years I never paid less than 13%. I think the most recent year is 13.6 or something like that. So I paid taxes every single year. Harry Reid's charge is totally false."

The Obama campaign spokeswoman, Lis Smith, responded with a statement, "Since there is substantial reason to doubt his claims, we have a simple message for him: prove it... Given Mitt Romney's secrecy about his returns... he has forfeited the right to have us take him just at his word."

Romney is not legally required to release more tax records. However, his wealth (estimated at $230 million), the campaign's emphasis on economic issues and tax rates, and recent political history suggest that the calls for Romney to release more tax records will continue.

Since 1980, only one party nominee or presumptive nominee other than Romney has released fewer than six years of returns, according to PolitiFact. That was Republican John McCain, who released two years of returns in 2008.

"The fascination with taxes I paid I find to be very small-minded compared to the broad issues that we face," Romney said Thursday.

In an interview with NBC conducted during the Olympics but scheduled to air later on Thursday, Romney's wife, Ann, also addressed the issue, stating, "We have been very transparent to what's legally required of us." She added, "There's going to be no more tax releases given."

Title: Justice Department Faces Criticism Over IRS Targeting Scandal Investigation

Article:

The Justice Department is facing mounting criticism from conservatives over the ongoing investigation into the IRS targeting scandal, with some calling the probe a "sham." Officials have stated that, while the FBI investigation is still ongoing, criminal charges are not expected at this point.

Jenny Beth Martin, co-founder of the Tea Party Patriots, described the news as "absolutely outrageous." She questioned the motives behind the lack of criminal charges, stating, "Why are they protecting the IRS? Why aren't they getting to the bottom of it? If they do not truly do a real investigation of this, there are always going to be doubts, and it is not good for the trust between the governors and the governed."

Martin suggested that the administration is attempting to sweep the scandal under the rug and that there is a cover-up. She said, "They wanted to silence us, and they have done what they can to silence us. We're not going away, but they've done everything they can to make it difficult for us, if not impossible at times, to exercise our First Amendment rights."

The controversy arises after it was revealed that the woman leading the FBI probe is a President Obama donor. Republicans have unsuccessfully urged the Justice Department to remove her from the case.

The developments have fueled claims of a lack of accountability in the administration over the scandal. The toughest action President Obama took was last May, when he announced Acting IRS Commissioner Steven Miller resigned at the administration's request following revelations that the agency singled out conservative groups for additional scrutiny as they sought tax-exempt status. However, a source told Fox News at the time that Miller was set to resign the following month anyway. Other lower-level officials have faced discipline or left the administration, though the circumstances were unclear.

Jay Sekulow, chief counsel with the American Center for Law and Justice, which is representing Tea Party groups, called the investigation a "sham." He stated, "To reach a conclusion that no criminal charges will be filed against those responsible for this illegal targeting scheme without interviewing any of our clients -- the real victims in this ordeal -- is absolutely absurd."

Sen. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah, questioned how sources could be discussing the likelihood of criminal charges in the first place when the probe is not even finished. He said, "These are serious matters - but to make this decision before the investigation is completed seems entirely out of order and inappropriate."

The Wall Street Journal first reported that criminal charges are unlikely, unless investigators discover evidence that dramatically changes their viewpoint. Sources separately told Fox News that the investigation is still ongoing, but that they've turned up no evidence yet to support criminal charges.

Title: Hannity Accuses Media, Clinton Campaign of Conspiracy and Propaganda

Article:

Radio host Sean Hannity, in a statement made on his show Wednesday, claimed that recent revelations from WikiLeaks about Hillary Clinton's campaign confirm long-held conspiracy theories. The allegations include Clinton's knowledge of Saudi Arabia and Qatar funding ISIS, her support for a hemispheric common market, open trade, and open borders, left-wing activists plotting a "Catholic Spring" and infiltrating the Catholic Church, and the media colluding to release debate questions ahead of time.

Hannity accused CNN, the New York Times, CNBC, and the Boston Globe of conspiring to propagandize the public and posing as objective journalists. He compared this alleged media manipulation to Soviet Union propaganda, stating, "This is like Communism in the Soviet Union propaganda... It’s really sad but it's also true and it's also reality and it's also the world you live in."

Hannity further alleged that Clinton's dream of a hemispheric common market, open trade, and open borders was revealed in one of her speeches. He also claimed that the Clinton campaign wanted to face Donald Trump in the general election.

Regarding polls, Hannity disputed the notion that he disbelieves polls or only cites online polling after Trump wins the debate. He argued that the current polls are inaccurate due to extensive coverage of the Access Hollywood tapes and the delayed release of the tapes by NBC, as reported by TMZ. Hannity asserted that the polls do not reflect Trump's debate performance, the latest WikiLeaks drops, or the media's alleged manipulation of information.

Title: Biden Leads Trump by 9 Points in Six Key Senate Battlegrounds, According to New Poll

Article:

Former Vice President Joe Biden has opened up a 9-point lead over President Donald Trump in six states where Republican senators face difficult reelection battles this fall, according to a new poll by Hart Research Associates. The survey finds Biden at 50 percent and Trump at 41 percent among voters sampled in Arizona, Colorado, Iowa, Maine, Montana, and North Carolina.

Trump won four of these states in 2016, with the exception of Maine and Colorado. All six states feature vulnerable GOP incumbents: Sens. Martha McSally (Ariz.), Cory Gardner (Colo.), Joni Ernst (Iowa), Susan Collins (Maine), Steve Daines (Mont.), and Thom Tillis (N.C.).

The poll found the Democratic challengers leading the Republican incumbents by a margin of 46 to 41. Republicans currently hold 53 seats in the Senate, meaning Democrats need to flip four to win back a majority.

The poll was conducted to measure voter appetites for mail balloting during the coronavirus pandemic. Trump and some Republicans have been resistant to the idea, warning mail voting is susceptible to fraud. The poll found broad support for voting by mail, with 85 percent of voters in the six battlegrounds saying there should be a mail option because of the pandemic.

Eighty-three percent of voters said they support congressional action to expand access to mail balloting, including 67 percent of Trump supporters. There is near-universal support for mail balloting among Democrats.

Fifty-six percent of voters who said they plan to support the GOP senator up for reelection said the incumbent should support a vote-by-mail option. If the GOP senator opposed legislation to expand mail-in balloting, 62 percent of voters said they would view the decision unfavorably, and 90 percent said they believe the decision would have been driven by politics.

Fifty-nine percent of voters overall said they do not believe that mail-in balloting is subject to fraud or corruption. The Hart Research survey was conducted on behalf of the Democracy For All 2021 Action campaign. The survey of 805 likely voters in the six states has a 3.5 percentage point margin of error.

Title: Conservative Students Face Harassment and Violence at UC Berkeley

Article:

In recent years, the University of California, Berkeley (UC Berkeley) has been the site of numerous incidents involving violence and intimidation, with a particular focus on conservative students and organizations. One such student, a member of the Berkeley College Republicans (BCR), recounts being harassed, stalked, chased, punched, and spat on during their time at the university.

In early 2017, the student was chased by a mob of masked, black-clad individuals, members of a fringe political faction known as "Antifa" (short for "anti-fascist"). The incident occurred during a planned talk by Milo Yiannopoulos, which administrators canceled for safety reasons. Police made only one arrest that night.

The student, who was 20 years old at the time and a junior, was a member of the BCR. Despite expecting a strong reaction from fellow students for hosting a conservative speaker, the student had never anticipated having to flee from a mob intent on silencing them, as the mob's stated goal was to "shut down" the event "By Any Means Necessary."

In the aftermath of the incident, the student and the BCR were criticized, not for the violent acts of Antifa, but for staging the violence to lay the groundwork for a crackdown on universities and their federal funding, as suggested by well-regarded political figures such as Gavin Newsom, the lieutenant governor of California, and former United States secretary of labor Robert Reich.

The UC Berkeley school paper, the Daily Californian, published several opinion pieces justifying the use of violence to shut down events, with one headline stating, "Violence Helped Ensure Safety for Students."

The student's experiences at UC Berkeley are not isolated incidents. Members of the BCR have been subjected to vicious attacks, harassment, and "doxing" incidents, with their contact information publicly revealed. The university's inaction has emboldened agitators to escalate their harassment, free of any consequences.

In fact, on several occasions, the university has collaborated with these leftists to shut down BCR events through bureaucratic maneuvering. In 2017, three of the BCR's speakers, including the student's mentioned above, were canceled in this manner: Ann Coulter, David Horowitz, and Milo Yiannopoulos.

In late 2017, the BCR managed to host their first successful event in months, with conservative commentator Ben Shapiro. However, to ensure Shapiro's safety, UC Berkeley police closed off the campus and adjacent roads. Several leftist protesters attempting to disrupt the event were arrested that night.

The BCR took Berkeley to court, and in their lawsuit, now backed by the Department of Justice, the judge agreed that Berkeley's speech policies were unconstitutional.

To combat the suppression of free speech on campus without resorting to lawsuits, the student encourages donors to major universities, such as UC Berkeley, to follow the lead of Dilbert creator and UC Berkeley alumnus Scott Adams and cease giving financial support to universities that do not respect free expression. Adams, who received his MBA from UC Berkeley, stated that he would "possibly try to club [him] to death" if he walked on campus due to his political views not aligning with the campus majority.

The anti-free-speech philosophy that is prevalent at UC Berkeley is not unique to the university. It lies at the heart of modern universities and is taught every day by professors at major American universities. Nor is Berkeley the only offender, although it may be one of the worst. American universities receive millions in donations from parents and alumni each year, and these donations are a significant portion of their financial support. If donors speak out, universities will take notice.

Should these trends continue, universities will transform into violent echo chambers where intellectualism expires, and Marxist dogma goes unchallenged. Gone are the days where students challenged mainstream ideas in the pursuit of truth, and "Ignorance is strength" will be the new motto of American universities.

Title: Republican Governors Leverage Medicaid Expansion to Pursue State-Specific Healthcare Changes

Article:

Republican governors, historically critical of the Affordable Care Act, or Obamacare, are utilizing the law as a means to implement changes in their states' Medicaid programs. This shift in strategy comes as a result of the federal government's desire for states to expand Medicaid coverage, which has created leverage for conservative governors to push for greater autonomy in Medicaid spending and structure.

Governors such as John Kasich of Ohio, Rick Scott of Florida, and Chris Christie of New Jersey, who have previously rejected parts of the Affordable Care Act, are now considering the expansion on their terms. Instead of enrolling new Medicaid enrollees into the existing system, these governors aim to purchase private health insurance plans for the low-income population using Obamacare funds and, in some cases, the Obamacare health insurance exchanges.

The specifics of these arrangements are still under negotiation with the Department of Health and Human Services, but discussions continue, with both sides hopeful for a breakthrough on the so-called "private option." The outcome remains uncertain, with the possibility that these governors may not receive the flexibility they seek, leading them to either reluctantly expand Medicaid or opt out.

The shift in strategy is evident in the case of Pennsylvania. Republican Governor Tom Corbett, a longtime critic of the Affordable Care Act, recently met with HHS Secretary Kathleen Sebelius to negotiate a deal amidst dwindling approval ratings and increasing bipartisan pressure at home to address the influx of Obamacare funds available to states that expand Medicaid.

This change in strategy has been preceded by a series of high-profile Republican defections on expansion, as well as more nuanced moves by states like Ohio, Tennessee, and Arkansas to provide private health insurance coverage using Medicaid expansion dollars. Arkansas' proposal, tentatively endorsed by HHS, to carry out the full Medicaid expansion via private health insurers in the Obamacare exchanges, has encouraged other states, including Republican governors in Indiana, Oklahoma, and Nebraska, to propose similar solutions.

In summary, Republican governors are leveraging the Medicaid expansion under the Affordable Care Act to push for greater autonomy in their states' healthcare systems, with the potential for private insurance plans to replace traditional Medicaid coverage for low-income populations. The specifics of these arrangements are still under negotiation, and the outcome remains uncertain.

Title: Clinton and Warren Criticize Sanders' Campaign Culture and Alleged Sexism

Article:

Hillary Clinton, the 2016 Democratic presidential nominee, has criticized her former Senate colleague and 2020 rival, Sen. Bernie Sanders, for his campaign culture and alleged sexism. In an interview with The Hollywood Reporter, Clinton accused Sanders of running a misogynistic campaign and described him as a political phony whose achievements are nonexistent and who lacks the temperament to be president.

Clinton's comments come after Sen. Elizabeth Warren, D-Mass., confronted Sanders during the last debate over his alleged statement that a woman could not win the presidency. Warren accused Sanders of lying, and he, in turn, accused Warren of lying.

Clinton's assessment of Sanders is that he fits nicely into her Trumpian "basket of deplorables." The New York Times put Clinton's attack on Page 1, reflecting the significance of her remarks.

The bad blood between Bernie and two leading women in the Democratic Party calls to mind the battle between Nelson Rockefeller and Barry Goldwater, which did not end well for the Republican Party in 1964. While the eventual GOP nominee, Goldwater, lost in a 44-state landslide to Lyndon Johnson, the liberal Republican establishment that Rockefeller led would never again be able to nominate one of its own.

It is difficult to see how this acrimony inside the Democratic Party—over the character, record, ideology, and alleged sexism of Sen. Bernie Sanders—ends well for the Democrats. Already, Bernie's backers believe the DNC "rigged" the nomination in 2016 by feigning neutrality while secretly aiding Clinton. If Sanders now fails in the first primaries and loses his last chance for the Democratic nomination because of the Clinton-Warren's attacks, it is difficult to see how Bernie's backers enthusiastically support Warren.

As for Bernie backing Biden, the raison d'etre of the liberal-radical wing of the party to whom Sanders is a hero is that the Democratic establishment consistently sells out progressive values. Sanders' crowd consists of true believers, a trademark of whom is militancy. Such folks often prefer defeat behind a principled leader to victory for a corporatist Democrat they regard as the enemy within.

Assume Bernie defeats Warren in Iowa, bests Biden in New Hampshire, and then goes on to win the nomination. Would women, a majority of whom vote Democratic, and who are indispensable to party victory, surge to the polls to install a president whom Hillary Clinton and Elizabeth Warren describe as a sexist who ruined their own presidential hopes? Would Democratic women come out to vote for a candidate who was responsible, in two successive presidential elections, for keeping the glass ceiling firmly intact over the heads of the Democratic Party's leading female candidates?

Ten days before the Iowa caucuses, the great unifier of the Democratic Party remains Donald Trump. But now, with Iowa, New Hampshire, Nevada, and South Carolina dead ahead, the Democrats' focus is becoming: Who should replace Trump? The rival claims of the constituent elements inside the party are rising to the fore. And what they reveal is a Democratic Party that is a coalition of groups that seem to be dividing along the lines of ideology, politics, race, class, and culture.

Consider the most loyal of Democratic constituents in presidential elections: African Americans. They are 13% of the electorate but a fourth of the national Democratic vote. Yet, of the six candidates for the nomination on stage in the last debate, not one was African American. Not one was Hispanic or Asian. The lone outsider rising in the polls is another white man, a multibillionaire who is willing to spend a billion dollars to buy the presidential nomination of the party of the common man.

Title: U.S. Acknowledges Cash Payment to Iran Was Used as Leverage for Prisoner Release

Article:

The Obama administration has confirmed that a $400 million cash payment to Iran in January was used as leverage to secure the release of American prisoners, sparking criticism that the transaction amounted to a ransom payment. State Department spokesman John Kirby confirmed that the U.S. withheld possession of the cash until a plane carrying the freed Americans had departed from Tehran.

During a State Department news briefing, Mr. Kirby stated, "If you're asking me was there a connection in that regard, at the endgame, I'm not going to deny that." He added, "We took advantage of leverage that we felt we could have to make sure that they got out safely and efficiently."

The revelation follows a report in The Wall Street Journal detailing that an Iranian cargo plane was not permitted by the U.S. to leave Geneva with $400 million in euros, Swiss francs, and other currencies stacked on shipping pallets until the Americans had left Tehran. The exchange took place on Jan. 17.

Administration officials, including President Barack Obama, have maintained that the cash payment was not a ransom because the $400 million was money the U.S. owed Iran to settle a failed arms deal from more than three decades ago.

Republican lawmakers, however, have criticized the handling of the payment and the timing of the Americans' release. U.S. Sen. Ben Sasse (R-NE) stated, "If it quacks like a duck, it's a duck. If a cash payment is contingent on a hostage release, it's a ransom. The truth matters, and the president owes the American people an explanation."

Sen. Tom Cotton (R-AR) added, "The latest reports about the cash payment also send a message to extremists that 'the United States will pay cold, hard cash for hostages.'"

Republican leaders in Congress have announced plans to hold hearings on the cash transfer in September. House Speaker Paul Ryan stated Thursday, "The president owes the American people a full accounting of his actions and the dangerous precedent he has set."

Mr. Kirby reiterated that the payment did not constitute ransom. "We don't pay ransom," he said. Instead, he portrayed the cash as a useful tool, stating, "It would have been foolish, imprudent, irresponsible for us not to try to maintain maximum leverage."

U.S. officials also maintain that the prisoner release and the arms-deal settlement were negotiated through separate diplomatic channels, and deny that the two were linked. The White House announced in January that the U.S. would pay Iran $400 million in the first installment of a $1.7 billion settlement the U.S. and Iran reached to resolve a legal dispute over the failed arms deal. Administration officials did not disclose at the time that the $400 million had already been paid in cash to Iran and refused to answer questions about how and when the payment took place. The administration stated that the legal dispute could have cost the U.S. some $10 billion without January's settlement.

Title: Fox News' Tucker Carlson Faces Criticism for Denying Existence of White Supremacy Problem in America

Article:

Fox News host Tucker Carlson is facing criticism for his claim that America's white supremacy problem is a "hoax." In a monologue on Tuesday, Carlson dismissed the threat, stating it is "not a real problem in America."

This statement came after the El Paso shooting, where the suspect's racist views and potential radicalization factors were under scrutiny. News outlets have pointed out that the anti-immigrant language in the manifesto published before the attack mirrors language often used on far-right-wing talk shows and websites.

Carlson's comments sparked widespread condemnation, including from his own colleague, liberal Fox News contributor Mo Elleithee, who tweeted, "You know who else believes white supremacy is not a real problem? White supremacists."

The Anti-Defamation League (ADL) conducted an audit in 2017, finding that white supremacist murders in the US "more than doubled," with far-right extremist groups and white supremacists responsible for 59% of all extremist-related fatalities in the US that year. They were responsible for 20% of these fatalities the year before.

Far-right extremists are also responsible for most of the ideological killings in America in the last 10 years, according to data from the ADL, which tracks extremist activity. White supremacists are also actively recruiting new members, with white supremacist groups posting more propaganda on college campuses for the third year in a row.

FBI Director Christopher Wray warned in July that domestic terrorism threats are on the rise, and the FBI takes white supremacist hate crimes "extremely seriously."

Carlson's punditry on "Tucker Carlson Tonight" frequently focuses on immigration and depicts immigrants as dangerous criminals. He rejects multiculturalism and portrays it as a threat to "Western civilization."

Washington Post reporter and CNN contributor Wesley Lowery stated on Sunday's "Reliable Sources" that "white supremacy is the ideology that has killed more Americans than any other terroristic ideology in the history of America."

In the wake of the El Paso massacre, white supremacy is receiving renewed attention. The Los Angeles Times published an editorial on Wednesday titled, "As the El Paso massacre showed once again, white supremacy is the poison in our well."

At the same time, discussions on MSNBC suggest there is "no distance" between the anti-immigration rhetoric in the El Paso shooter's manifesto and commentary from Fox News opinion hosts like Tucker Carlson, Laura Ingraham, and Brian Kilmeade.

It is important to note that the Dayton shooter's extreme left-wing views are not being compared to the El Paso shooter's white supremacist views, as there is no evidence that the Dayton shooter's politics were a factor in his actions. This is a crucial distinction.

Title: Tensions Escalate as Gowdy Urges DOJ to "Finish It the Hell Up" Amid Russia Probe

Article:

In a heated hearing on Thursday, Republican Rep. Trey Gowdy of South Carolina criticized Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein for the ongoing Russia collusion probe, urging the Department of Justice (DOJ) to "finish it the hell up because this country is being torn apart." The hearing, held by the House Judiciary Committee, saw a series of tense exchanges between Republicans and the DOJ over the handling of the Russia probe and the Hillary Clinton email investigation.

The day's events were marked by a resolution approved by the House, insisting the DOJ comply with congressional subpoenas for documents related to the Russia case. Rep. Jim Jordan, R-Ohio, referenced this resolution during the hearing, challenging Rosenstein over his compliance.

Earlier in the hearing, Gowdy expressed frustration over the protracted Russia investigation, suggesting that despite numerous charges against individuals tied to the Trump campaign, the investigation has not found evidence of presidential wrongdoing. "We've seen the bias, we need to see the evidence," Gowdy said. "If you have evidence of wrongdoing by any member of the Trump campaign, present it to the damn grand jury. If you have evidence that this president acted inappropriately, present it to the American people."

Rosenstein, who oversees the special counsel's Russia probe, sought to defuse tensions, vowing to hold wrongdoers accountable in the wake of the inspector general report and defending the response to congressional requests for documents related to the Russia investigation. However, he was grilled repeatedly by House Republicans over various issues, including the department's role in Trump campaign surveillance, alleged stonewalling of congressional document requests, and the damning watchdog report on FBI conduct during the Clinton email probe.

Rosenstein denied allegations from Jordan that he had FBI agent Peter Strzok avoid answering certain questions during a closed-door appearance before the committee the previous day. He also could not discuss classified information in an open setting when asked what the DOJ and FBI did to surveil the Trump campaign, including the reported work of an informant apparently in contact with members of that campaign in 2016.

Rosenstein further rebuffed GOP suggestions that he recuse himself from the Russia probe, repeatedly denying allegations first reported by Fox News that he once threatened to subpoena GOP committee members and declined to comment about his role in approving a surveillance application for a Trump adviser. Rosenstein would not say whether he read the application, but stressed he's "confident" about his conduct and sees it as "highly, highly unlikely" that the inspector general would find wrongdoing on his part as part of an ongoing review.

The hearing also addressed the DOJ inspector general's findings on the Clinton email case, with Rosenstein stating that it showed some FBI officials "deviated from important principles." He added, "We need to correct errors, hold wrongdoers accountable, and deter future violations."

Rosenstein and FBI Director Christopher Wray have been criticized for months by Republicans on Capitol Hill who have suggested that the agencies are stonewalling congressional committees' requests for documents related to the beginning of the Russia investigation. However, Democrats have pushed back against those requests, with Democratic leaders sending a letter to Rosenstein and Wray on Tuesday, expressing concern that the agencies are disclosing sensitive information.

Last week, the Justice Department gave House Republicans some of the documents they sought related to the Russia investigation and the Clinton email probe after lawmakers threatened to hold officials in contempt of Congress for stonewalling requests.

Title: House Republicans Plan to Attach GOP Priorities to Debt Ceiling Bill

Article:

House Republicans have announced their intention to attach a list of Republican priorities to the upcoming debt ceiling bill, including a delay of the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare. The bill is expected to include provisions for major tax reforms, changes to entitlement programs like Medicare and Social Security, and measures such as the Keystone pipeline and increased offshore energy production.

During a meeting on Thursday, House Speaker John Boehner and other top leaders outlined a wish list of items they plan to attach to the debt ceiling legislation. House Majority Leader Eric Cantor announced on the House floor that the increase will also contain "important pro-growth economic policies, health care and non-health care reforms in addition to a one-year delay in Obamacare."

The strategy aims to keep the Republican party united, following a week of internal disputes about the strategy to deal with the government funding bill. The goal is to focus on the debt ceiling fight and maintain a unified front among Republicans.

The debt ceiling bill is expected to include provisions for major tax reforms, changes to entitlement programs, and measures like the Keystone pipeline and increased offshore energy production. The bill will reportedly be modeled on a budget, but will not include specific changes to the tax code. Instead, it will give instructions to both the House and Senate to pass tax reform by a specific deadline.

GOP aides declined to specify the changes to entitlement programs that will be included in the bill, but congressional Republicans have pushed for changes to the way Social Security benefits are adjusted for inflation, effectively lowering annual increases for Social Security recipients.

The measure will also include approval of the Keystone pipeline and increased offshore energy production, which GOP members argue would boost job creation. The bill will also reportedly include several provisions to roll back regulations on coal plants and other industries.

President Barack Obama and Senate Democrats have stated they will not negotiate on a measure to authorize additional borrowing authority for the Treasury Department, which is projected to run out sometime in October or early November. They argue that Congress should not risk the nation's credit limit with another down-to-the-wire brawl over major policy issues like health care and taxes.

Obama and Boehner spoke on Friday, an aide to the speaker said. The aide reported that the president called the speaker to say he would not negotiate with him on the debt limit. The aide also stated that the speaker was disappointed but told the president that the two chambers of Congress will chart the path ahead.

House Republicans say Obama himself agreed to add other measures to reduce the deficit in the last major negotiation over the debt limit. However, Senate Democrats argue that delaying Obamacare for a year and rolling back Obama administration regulations are non-starters, and not the debate they want to have on a must-pass bill.

The strategy to attach a host of major policy items to the debt ceiling bill is designed to keep the Republican party unified, at least temporarily. However, the addition of controversial items to the bill only increases the threat of a default, and ensures that Capitol Hill will be tied up for the next several weeks, if not months, with partisan fighting that could ripple through the financial markets.

Title: Michigan Poll Shows Democratic Frontrunners Leading Trump in Key 2020 Battleground State

Article:

In a recent poll of Michigan voters, two Democratic presidential candidates, former Vice President Joe Biden and U.S. Senator Bernie Sanders, are leading President Donald Trump by 12 percentage points if the election were to take place today. The poll, conducted by Lansing, Michigan-based Glengariff Group, shows 36% of likely voters in Michigan would vote for Trump, while 48% would vote for Biden and 44% would vote for Sanders.

Michigan, which has not voted for a Republican as president since 1988, surprised political observers in 2016 by backing Trump and helping him secure the White House. Winning Michigan is crucial to Trump's reelection path, along with the states of Wisconsin and Pennsylvania, which have similar voting patterns.

The survey of 600 Michigan voters was conducted by live phone interviews and has a margin of error of 4 percentage points. It was published by The Detroit News and local news station WDIV-TV.

In a separate poll conducted by Quinnipiac University in early May, Biden led Trump by 11 percentage points in Pennsylvania.

Trump's campaign has acknowledged the potential weakness in these states, which have significant manufacturing and agriculture sectors that have been affected by the president's trade wars. As Democrats must first navigate a crowded primary field before focusing on the general election, Republicans are optimistic they have time to invest in states like Michigan and Pennsylvania and ultimately gain an advantage.

The Michigan poll also compared Trump against three other Democratic presidential hopefuls: South Bend, Indiana Mayor Pete Buttigieg, and U.S. Senators Elizabeth Warren and Kamala Harris. All three also outperformed Trump in the poll, although by smaller margins than Sanders and Biden.

Title: Trump's Visit to Mississippi Civil Rights Museum Met with Protests from African-American Leaders

Article:

U.S. President Donald Trump visited Mississippi on Saturday to attend the opening of the Mississippi Civil Rights Museum, but his visit was met with protests from top African-American leaders who stayed away due to their disagreement with his policies and record on race relations.

During his visit, Trump toured the museum and delivered brief remarks, paying tribute to African-Americans who fought against institutionalized racism, including Medgar Evers, the civil rights activist who was murdered outside his home in Jackson in 1963.

In his prepared remarks, Trump said, "We want our country to be a place where every child from every background can grow up free from fear, innocent of hatred and surrounded by love, opportunity, and hope."

Referring to Evers and other civil rights leaders showcased in the museum, Trump stated, "Today we strive to be worthy of their sacrifice. We pray for inspiration from their example."

Trump acknowledged Evers' wife Myrlie and brother Charles in the audience.

U.S. Representative John Lewis of Georgia, a Democrat who marched with Martin Luther King Jr. in the 1960s, stated on Thursday that he would not go to the museum opening because of Trump's presence.

"President Trump's attendance and his hurtful policies are an insult to the people portrayed in this civil rights museum," Lewis said in a statement with Mississippi Democratic U.S. Representative Bennie Thompson, who also declined to attend.

The two men also cited Trump's "disparaging comments about women, the disabled, immigrants, and National Football League players" and said the president had shown disrespect to those who fought for civil rights in Mississippi.

The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People also took issue with Trump's attendance.

However, U.S. Housing and Urban Development Secretary Ben Carson, who is black and ran against Trump in the early 2016 Republican presidential primaries before dropping out, accompanied the president on his tour of the museum.

Trump, a Republican, has had a complicated record on race relations. He was a leading proponent of the false theory that Democratic President Barack Obama, the first black U.S. president, was not born in the United States. Obama was born in Hawaii, a U.S. state.

In August, Trump unleashed a firestorm of criticism, including from Republicans and a top adviser in his administration, for saying that both left- and right-wing protesters were at fault for violence at a white supremacist-led rally in Charlottesville, Virginia, where one woman died.

White House spokesman Raj Shah said on Friday ahead of the visit that the civil rights movement was about fighting intolerance, hatred, and bigotry, and that Trump intended to honor the leaders of that struggle.

The White House called the decision by Lewis and Thompson not to attend "unfortunate."

Trump concluded his remarks by saying, "Today we pay solemn tribute to our heroes of the past and dedicate ourselves to building a future of freedom, equality, justice, and peace."

Title: Nationwide School Walkout Against Gun Violence Marks Columbine Anniversary

Article:

Schoolchildren across the United States participated in a nationwide walkout on Friday morning to demonstrate against gun violence, marking the 19th anniversary of the Columbine High School massacre in Colorado. The event, known as the National School Walkout, was initiated by Connecticut high school student Lane Murdock following the Parkland shooting in Florida.

In an unrelated incident, a student at Forest High School in Ocala, Florida, was shot in the ankle before the walkout. Only one person, a 17-year-old student, was injured, and a suspect is in custody. The suspect was initially identified as a student, but authorities later clarified that he was not a current student at the school.

Students at Forest High School, which had planned an in-school "civic demonstration" instead of a walkout, were taken to a nearby church to meet their parents. Around 11:00 local time, officers responded to reports of a gunman at another school in Marion County, but later said those reports were false. All schools in the district were placed on "Code Red" lockdown as a precaution.

The goal of Friday's demonstration, which involved more than 2,000 schools, was to raise awareness of gun violence and to combat political inaction. Student Lane Murdock launched the National School Walkout campaign in the wake of the Parkland shooting in Florida. The protest started as a petition on the website change.org, with more than 250,000 people signing it.

Participants on Friday also held 13 seconds of silence, in honor of the 13 victims of the Columbine shooting. The sample walkout agenda from the campaign states that the students will not return to school but instead will "make calls to their Senators' offices and flood social media with calls for reform."

US students already staged a national walkout on March 14, one month after 17 people were murdered at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Florida. One student in North Carolina, who was the lone protester in March, posted a selfie outside his school with dozens of classmates on Friday.

On April 20, 1999, two teenage students murdered 12 of their classmates and one teacher at Columbine High School before killing themselves. Twenty-four more people were injured in the attack, mostly by gunfire. As well as guns, the pair used nearly 100 explosive devices, including a bomb placed in the school's cafeteria that did not detonate.

The shooting caused a national outcry, leading to changes in police tactics and investigations into violent video games and bullying. Actors Robert DeNiro and Julianne Moore penned absence letters for students to explain why they were participating. Students who survived the Florida shooting have actively advocated for an end to gun violence, with many backing legislative changes to control the sale of guns.

On Thursday, students from the Colorado school district where Columbine High School is located held a "Vote for Our Lives" rally adjacent to the scene of the massacre. About 60 students from Parkland, Florida, attended, as well as students who survived a 2013 shooting at nearby Arapahoe High School.

Title: North Korea Removes and Executes Former Second-in-Command Jang Song Thaek

Article:

North Korea's state media announced on Friday that Jang Song Thaek, a close ally and former mentor to leader Kim Jong Un, has been executed. The announcement comes after Pyongyang announced Jang's removal from all his posts due to allegations of corruption, drug use, gambling, womanizing, and leading a "dissolute and depraved life."

Jang, considered the second most powerful official in North Korea, was instrumental in helping Kim Jong Un consolidate power following the death of his father, Kim Jong Il, two years ago. Jang's execution is the latest in a series of personnel reshuffles conducted by Kim Jang in an apparent effort to bolster his power.

Reports suggest that one of Jang's aides has sought asylum in South Korea. The unidentified aide, who managed funds for Jang, is being protected by South Korean officials in a secret location in China, according to cable news network YTN and the Kyunghyang Shinmun newspaper, citing sources familiar with the matter.

Jang was removed from all his posts and expelled from the ruling Workers' Party during a meeting of its politburo on Sunday, as reported by the North's official KCNA news agency. Kim Jong Un attended and "guided" the meeting, it said. North Korean state television showed a still photograph of Jang being hauled away by uniformed guards from a large conference hall as it reported on the politburo meeting.

Kim's uncle has also been airbrushed out of pictures and video footage, and experts say his name is no longer searchable on the KCNA database. "Jang and his followers committed criminal acts baffling imagination and they did tremendous harm to our party and revolution," KCNA said, without specifying if Jang had been detained or charged with any crime.

The report did not refer to Jang's aide, whose defection, if confirmed, would be the most serious for North Korea in 15 years. The decision to remove Jang was widely reported in North Korea's media, including on the front page of the official Rodong Sinmun newspaper on Monday, in contrast to the dismissal of officials in the past which were almost never reported.

The Rodong Sinmun carried a picture of what it said was the politburo meeting. Jang and Kim Kyong Hui, Jang's wife and aunt to the young leader, were among 17 politburo members. Neither could be seen in the photo. However, Kim's aunt, the daughter of the North's founding leader Kim Il Sung, was not in trouble, a source with close ties to Pyongyang told Reuters.

Last week, a South Korean official said Jang was likely alive and in no immediate physical danger, as was his wife. South Korea's National Intelligence Service last week said it believed Jang had been relieved of his posts in November. It also said two of Jang's close associates were executed recently for corruption.

Pyongyang is undergoing its biggest leadership upheaval since the death in 2011 of former leader Kim Jong Il, the younger Kim's father. Among Jang's senior party and military posts, he was vice chairman of the country's top military body, the National Defense Commission. Jang had close ties to China and visited Beijing in 2012 on behalf of Kim. He was also head of the North Korean side of a joint project managing a special economic zone with Beijing.

In listing reasons why Jang was dismissed, KNCA said, "Jang pretended to uphold the party and leader but was engrossed in such factional acts (such) as dreaming different dreams and involving himself in double-dealing behind the scene." "Affected by the capitalist way of living, Jang committed irregularities and corruption and led a dissolute and depraved life," KNCA added.

Information from The Associated Press and Reuters was used in this report.

Title: North Korea's Kim Jong Un Affirms Nuclear Deterrent, Promotes Sister and Key Officials

Article:

North Korean leader Kim Jong Un has reaffirmed the country's nuclear weapons as a "powerful deterrent" that safeguards its sovereignty, state media reported on Sunday. The statement came hours after U.S. President Donald Trump suggested that only one thing would work in dealing with the isolated nation.

In a speech to the Central Committee of the ruling Workers' Party on Saturday, Kim addressed the "complicated international situation." He stated that North Korea's nuclear weapons are a "powerful deterrent firmly safeguarding the peace and security in the Korean peninsula and Northeast Asia," referring to the "protracted nuclear threats of the U.S. imperialists."

Recent weeks have seen North Korea launch two missiles over Japan and conduct its sixth nuclear test. The country may be advancing toward its goal of developing a nuclear-tipped missile capable of reaching the U.S. mainland. According to a Russian lawmaker who recently visited Pyongyang, North Korea is preparing to test-launch such a missile.

Trump has previously stated that the U.S. would "totally destroy" North Korea if necessary to protect itself and its allies. The situation, Kim Jong Un said in the speech, proves North Korea's policy of "byungjin," meaning the parallel development of nuclear weapons and the economy, is "absolutely right."

Kim also noted that the national economy has grown despite escalating sanctions imposed by the U.N. Security Council to curb Pyongyang's nuclear and missile program. The meeting also handled personnel changes within North Korea's secretive and opaque ruling center of power, state media reported.

Kim Jong Un's sister, Kim Yo Jong, was made an alternate member of the politburo, the top decision-making body over which Kim Jong Un presides. Her new position indicates the 28-year-old has become a replacement for Kim Jong Un's aunt, Kim Kyong Hui, who was a key decision-maker when former leader Kim Jong Il was alive.

Michael Madden, a North Korea expert at Johns Hopkins University's 38 North website, stated, "It shows that her portfolio and writ is far more substantive than previously believed and it is a further consolidation of the Kim family's power."

In January, the U.S. Treasury blacklisted Kim Yo Jong, along with other North Korean officials, over "severe human rights abuses." Kim Jong Sik and Ri Pyong Chol, two of the three men behind Kim's banned rocket program, were also promoted.

State media announced that several other high-ranking cadres were promoted to the Central Committee in what the South Korean unification ministry said could be an attempt by North Korea to navigate a way through its increasing isolation.

"The large-scale personnel reshuffle reflects that Kim Jong Un is taking the current situation seriously, and that he's looking for a breakthrough by promoting a new generation of politicians," the ministry said in a statement.

North Korea's foreign minister, Ri Yong Ho, who named Donald Trump "President Evil" in a bombastic speech to the U.N. General Assembly last month, was promoted to a full vote-carrying member of the politburo. Madden stated, "Ri can now be safely identified as one of North Korea's top policy makers."

"Even if he has informal or off the record meetings, Ri's interlocutors can be assured that whatever proposals they proffer will be taken directly to the top," he said.

Title: Trump Lowers Expectations Ahead of North Korea Summit as Negotiations Remain Stalled

Article:

President Donald Trump is one week away from his second summit with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, and he is attempting to lower expectations in advance. The meeting, set to take place in Vietnam at the end of February, aims to strike a deal to dismantle North Korea's nuclear program, a goal that has proven challenging.

After months of negotiations, both sides are at an impasse. The United States has demanded that North Korea offer a full, detailed list of its nuclear inventory before sanctions are lifted, while North Korea insists that sanctions should be lifted before it provides the full list and begins to downgrade its nuclear capabilities.

In an effort to manage expectations, Trump has used numerous public opportunities to downplay the urgency of the situation. On Tuesday, he told reporters in the Oval Office, "We’re in no rush whatsoever... As long as there’s no testing, I’m in no rush. If there’s testing, that’s another deal."

Experts suggest that Trump's comments are not entirely accurate. North Korea has not conducted a nuclear test since September 2017 or a missile test since November of that year, but it has a history of long gaps between tests. The country has completed six nuclear tests in total, only one of which took place during the Trump administration.

Frank Aum, a North Korea expert at the US Institute of Peace in Washington, stated, "This only reinforces the perception among some that Trump either doesn’t understand the threat or is cynically approaching the North Korea issue from a political rather than security perspective."

On Wednesday, Trump told reporters in the Oval Office that the Hanoi summit likely won't be the last time he meets with Kim, indicating that a comprehensive deal to end North Korea's nuclear program may not be reached next week. Trump did add that he believed Pyongyang would eventually dismantle its nuclear arsenal, however.

Aum suggests that Trump is creating negotiating leverage by giving the impression that he is not desperate to achieve North Korea's denuclearization. Trump's strategy appears to be one of patience, as he waits for North Korea to take steps towards denuclearization without testing its weapons.

Bridget Coggins, a North Korea expert at the University of California Santa Barbara, stated that "quick denuclearization is impractical." Kim Jong Un believes that a credible nuclear program is essential for the survival of his regime, as it serves as a deterrent against invasion from the United States. Therefore, Kim has no incentive to give up his arsenal and expose himself to attack.

The four-part plan agreed upon by Trump and Kim in their first summit in Singapore includes establishing new US-North Korea relations, building a lasting and stable peace regime on the Korean Peninsula, working towards complete denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula, and recovering POW/MIA remains, including the immediate repatriation of those already identified.

Experts suggest that the next meeting may focus more on relationship building rather than ending nuclear programs, as "denuclearization" is only mentioned in the third step of the plan. The first two steps are primarily about improving ties between the US, North Korea, and South Korea. There is also disagreement about what "denuclearization" means, with the US interpreting it as the end of North Korea's nuclear program, and North Korea interpreting it as the withdrawal of US protection from South Korea.

It is possible that Trump is signaling that, as long as North Korea does not test any more weapons, the US will commit to working through the four-step plan. The next meeting may be more about relationship building than ending nuclear programs. Coggins states, "There isn’t trust between the two governments and they’re working to change the relationship, but the pressure for real substantive progress is there too."

Title: U.S. Stocks Rebound as China Indicates No Immediate Response to Latest Tariffs

Article:

U.S. stocks experienced significant gains on Thursday, following indications from China that it was not in a rush to respond to the latest round of tariffs imposed by the U.S. The Dow Jones Industrial Average (DJIA) advanced 326.15 points, or 1.3%, to close at 26,362.25. The S&P 500 index (SPX) rose 36.64 points, or 1.3%, to finish at 2,924.58, while the Nasdaq Composite Index (COMP) added 116.51 points, or 1.5%, to close at 7,973.39.

This week's rebound has significantly reduced month-to-date losses for the major indexes. The S&P 500 and Dow are down 1.9% and 1.55%, respectively, while the Nasdaq is off 2.5%. The S&P 500 and Dow are each less than 4% below all-time closing highs set in July, while the Nasdaq remains around 4.2% below its peak.

A spokesman for China's commerce ministry was quoted in news reports as saying the country would not immediately respond to the latest round of tariff increases announced by President Donald Trump on Friday. The spokesman, Gao Feng, said, "The question that should be discussed now is about removing the new tariffs to prevent escalation." He also mentioned that both sides were discussing a planned meeting next month of trade negotiators.

David Madden, market analyst at CMC Markets UK, stated in a note, "The largely hopeful tones of the update from China has lifted market sentiment, and that sparked buying this morning." He added, "U.S.-China relations have been volatile recently, but for now, there is a sense that things are heading in the right direction, and that has coaxed some traders back into the market."

Investors also considered a series of economic reports, including a revision of second-quarter GDP growth that showed the U.S. economy growing at a 2% annual rate rather than the previously reported 2.1%. The revised numbers also showed the U.S. consumer playing an even larger role in economic growth than before, as personal consumption accounted for 3.1 percentage points of growth, versus the initially reported 2.9.

New applications for jobless benefits rose by 4,000 to a seasonally adjusted 215,000 during the week ended Aug. 24, slightly above economist expectations of 214,000, according to a poll.

Stocks have pulled back in August in sometimes volatile trade as the U.S.-China trade war escalated with rounds of tit-for-tat tariff escalations and increasingly harsh rhetoric on both sides, which has also been blamed for heightening worries over the global economic outlook and stoking fears of a possible U.S. recession.

Analysts also pointed to the calendar as a reason for higher equity prices in recent days, as investors rebalance their portfolios heading into September. "There's a lot of evidence of month-end book squaring, as a lot of the worst performing sectors month-to-date outperformed yesterday, despite the lack of a discernible positive catalyst," wrote Tom Essaye, president of the Sevens Report, in a Thursday note to clients.

Pending home sales fell by 2.5% in July, according to the National Association of Realtors, versus a decline of 0.3% expected by economists polled by ███. The July goods trade deficit shrunk to $72.3 billion from $74.2 billion a month earlier, lower than the $75 billion consensus.

Shares of Best Buy Co. Inc. (BBY) tumbled 8% after the retailer reported second-quarter revenue that fell short of analyst expectations, though it beat earnings-per-share forecasts. Shares of Dollar General Corp. (DG) added 10.7% after the discount retailer handily beat analyst estimates for sales and profits in the second quarter, while raising its outlook for the full-year 2019.

Tech Data Corp.'s (TECD) stock rose 15.7% after reporting fiscal third-quarter results. Shares of Dollar Tree Inc. (DLTR) declined 1.9% after the retailer beat sales estimates for the second quarter but fell short of profit expectations and issued full-year earnings guidance below analyst forecasts.

The yield on the 10-year U.S. Treasury note (TMUBMUSD10Y) rose 3.5 basis points to 1.5%. In commodities markets, the price of crude oil (US: CLV19) rose 1.3% to $56.52 per barrel, while the price of gold (GCZ19) ended the day 0.9% lower at $1,534.6 per ounce. The value of the U.S. dollar, meanwhile, ticked 0.3% higher, according to the dollar index (DXY).

In Asia overnight, stocks traded mostly lower; the China CSI 300 (000300) fell 0.3%, while the Nikkei 225 (NIK) lost 0.1%. Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index (HSI) rose 0.3%, and European stocks rallied Thursday, with the Stoxx Europe 600 (SXXP) closing 1% higher.

Title: Senate Leaders Reach Agreement to Vote on Bipartisan Bills to End Government Shutdown

Article:

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell and Minority Leader Chuck Schumer have reached an agreement to vote on two bills aimed at ending the ongoing government shutdown on Thursday. One bill will be the immigration proposal President Donald Trump unveiled on Saturday, while the other is a clean continuing resolution that would reopen the government until February 8.

The clean continuing resolution, which the House has already passed, would be a viable option for Democrats, ensuring federal workers would not miss another payday. The immigration proposal, however, is considered a non-starter for Democrats due to its controversial provisions. The bill would need 60 votes to advance.

The outcome of this week's vote could mark a breakthrough in ending the shutdown, or it may represent another round of negotiations in the ongoing shutdown saga. If the short-term bill passes with enough Republican support, President Trump would receive a bill to fund the government without any wall funding, which would be a significant victory for Democrats. Conversely, if Trump opposes the proposal and discourages Senate Republicans from voting for it, the shutdown may continue.

Senate Majority Leader McConnell requested the president to develop compromise legislation, as he needed something to present on the Senate floor. Additionally, centrist Democrats in the House, representing red or purple districts, have urged House Speaker Nancy Pelosi to at least promise the president a vote on his homeland security request, including border wall funding, after the government reopens.

Although the Senate may not be able to end the shutdown on Thursday, the machinery necessary to eventually resolve the impasse is now in motion. The pressure from anxious Senate Republicans and anxious House Democrats is starting to build, signaling potential progress in ending the government shutdown.

Title: Former Trump Campaign Manager Accused of Obstruction in House Hearing

Article:

In a heated hearing on Tuesday, Corey Lewandowski, a close ally of President Donald Trump, was accused of obstructing information during a House Judiciary Committee hearing regarding the Russia investigation. The hearing, which marked the beginning of an "aggressive series" of impeachment hearings, saw Lewandowski confirm that the president had asked him to intervene in the Russia investigation.

House Judiciary Chair Jerrold Nadler criticized Lewandowski's behavior, stating, "It is a part of a pattern by a White House desperate not to reveal the truth." Nadler added, "The president's lawyers are sitting behind you right now to make sure that you do not answer us."

Lewandowski, who is considering running for the US Senate in New Hampshire, followed White House orders not to discuss conversations with the president beyond what was already public in the former special counsel Robert Mueller's report. During the five-hour session, Lewandowski was defiant, demanding a copy of the Mueller report and reading from it.

The hearing was marked by a series of procedural votes initiated by Republicans, causing disarray. During a bathroom break, Lewandowski took the opportunity to tweet a link to his new Super Pac. Trump praised Lewandowski's testimony, tweeting that his opening statement was "beautiful."

The hearing highlighted a central dilemma for the Judiciary Committee all year as it investigates and potentially tries to impeach Trump. Democrats have been pressured by their base to move quickly to remove Trump from office, but the White House has blocked the committee's oversight requests at almost every turn, declining to provide new documents or allow aides and associates to testify.

Lewandowski was a central figure in Mueller's report, which described two episodes in which Trump asked Lewandowski to tell the former Attorney General Jeff Sessions to curtail Mueller's investigation and fire Sessions if he refused to meet with Lewandowski. Lewandowski never delivered the message, instead delegating the task to the White House aide Rick Dearborn, who declined to comply, according to the report.

Under questioning, Lewandowski acknowledged he might have lied in a cable interview when he said he didn't remember the president asking him to get involved with Sessions. He stated, "I have no obligation to be honest with the media because they are just as dishonest as everybody else."

Two other witnesses who were subpoenaed alongside Lewandowski, Dearborn and the former White House aide Rob Porter, did not appear, on orders from the White House. Democrats are challenging the White House's position in court, arguing that former aides are not "absolutely immune" from testifying.

Title: Global Adaptation of Religious Observances During COVID-19 Pandemic

Article:

In the wake of the global COVID-19 pandemic, families and communities worldwide are modifying their religious observances during significant religious events such as Passover and Holy Week.

Notably, authorities are intensifying their efforts to enforce social distancing measures during the Easter weekend, as officials report that these measures are contributing to a flattening of the COVID-19 curve in critical regions across the United States and Europe.

The adaptations to religious practices are a response to the unprecedented situation, with many religious institutions turning to virtual services and drive-in church services to maintain religious observance while adhering to social distancing guidelines.

The situation remains fluid, with many details and specifics varying depending on the region and local authorities' guidelines. However, the global community's resilience and adaptability in the face of this pandemic are evident in the creative ways religious observances are being maintained.

As the situation continues to evolve, it is essential to prioritize public health and safety while respecting religious freedom and traditions.

Title: Senate's Vote on Patriot Act Provisions Results in Program's Temporary Expiration

Article:

The federal government's controversial program for gathering Americans' phone records expired at midnight on Sunday, marking a significant setback for the program's advocates, including Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell and Senator Rand Paul, who has made ending the data gathering program his signature issue. The expiration of the program and other anti-terrorism surveillance provisions under the Patriot Act was expected to be only temporary, but it represents McConnell's first serious defeat as majority leader.

In the wee hours of May 24 and again in an unusual Senate session on Sunday, Paul used parliamentary rules to disrupt floor action on the issue. A vote on a House compromise known as the USA Freedom Act is not expected until later this week. The House bill passed overwhelmingly and has President Obama's support. It leaves the job of data gathering to phone companies rather than the government, and requires the government to get a search warrant to access it.

McConnell worked hard to build opposition to the House bill, which he has criticized as a hurdle to intelligence gathering. However, he lost supporters as senators coalesced around the House bill, 77 to 17, in a procedural vote to advance the bill on Sunday. The leader had wanted to simply extend the provisions of the Patriot Act, but Paul, eight days ago and on Sunday, blocked even short-term extensions.

Republicans blamed Paul rather than the leader for the expiration. "I'm sure we're not going to let the whole program lapse, but because Senator Paul is taking advantage of the rules of the Senate, [we] will delay and there will be an interim period where the nation is less secure," said Sen. John McCain (R) of Arizona, on Sunday.

Democrats see things differently. Minority Leader Harry Reid of Nevada faulted McConnell, blaming him for a "manufactured crisis" by waiting to bring up the Patriot Act provisions until just before the Senate's Memorial Day recess—a week before their expiration. When he was majority leader, Reid also used deadlines to forge consensus. However, Reid "would never have stacked this many bills together against a deadline without a clear path forward," his spokesman, Adam Jentleson, said in an email.

Sen. Susan Collins (R) of Maine expressed concern about the program's expiration, stating, "It's difficult to know...Perhaps we should have stayed in last week rather than going on recess until the issue was resolved." However, she also noted that when McConnell offered short-term extensions to work out compromise legislation just before the recess, "I don't think it was anticipated" that Paul and some Democratic allies would object.

Now, she said, "all of us are extremely concerned about the program going dark at a time when the terrorist threat is very high and coming at us from so many different directions."

Title: Indian Detainees in Assam Fear Coronavirus Outbreak in Overcrowded Detention Centers

 Article:

 In the northeastern state of Assam, India, families of more than 800 undocumented migrants being held indefinitely in six detention centers are worried about the safety of their loved ones amid the global coronavirus pandemic. One such family is that of Gulbahar Begum, a 28-year-old woman from Marigaon district, who travels nearly 145km to Tezpur detention center to meet her 69-year-old father, Gul Mohammad.

 Mohammad, declared an "illegal immigrant" by the Foreigners Tribunal, a quasi-judicial court in Assam, has been in jail since 2017 due to insufficient documents to prove his citizenship. Over the past three weeks, Gulbahar has been waging a legal battle to free her father. She is concerned about his health, as he has various health issues, including a kidney ailment, and his left leg often swells up.

 The National Register of Citizens (NRC), which was published last year, left nearly 1.9 million people, many of them Muslims, stateless. They face either deportation or detention in camps such as the one in which Mohammad is detained. Several rights organizations have accused the ruling Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) of using the NRC as a tool to target and disenfranchise the Muslim population, an allegation the Hindu nationalist party denies.

 Family members of those detained fear a potential coronavirus outbreak due to overcrowding in the detention centers, which makes physical distancing nearly impossible. Most centers lack proper hygiene and medical care for the detainees, exacerbating the chances of a viral transmission.

 Botu Miya, a 40-year-old man from Cachar district, is distressed as he fears his wife, Banesa Begum, being held in Silchar detention center, might contract the coronavirus. Banesa, a 45-year-old daily wage laborer, was first marked as a "doubtful voter" for not producing the requisite proof of Indian citizenship and later labeled an undocumented migrant.

 Since 1997, nearly 143,000 people have been marked as "doubtful voters" (or D-voters) in Assam, and their voting rights were taken away by the government. These individuals were referred to Foreigners' Tribunals, facing charges of being "undocumented" migrants mainly from Bangladesh. Some of them are currently languishing in detention centers.

 Manvendra Pratap Singh, deputy commissioner of Sonitpur district, however, said all necessary measures were in place to ensure the safety of every inmate. "We have stopped taking in new inmates. Everyone is being screened by the doctors on a regular basis, and there does not seem to be any such possibility of a coronavirus outbreak," Singh told ███.

 Some families are making desperate attempts to secure bail from the courts before the virus turns into a disaster inside the detention centers. Anura Begum, a 31-year-old woman from Gobradhana village in Baksa district, has collected all the documents, including the bond amount to bail out her husband, Kadam Ali, lodged in the Goalpara center. However, courts across the state suspended functioning last month following the coronavirus outbreak.

 "Just before the lockdown, I had submitted documents for his bail. The officials rejected them and asked me to furnish additional documents," Begum told ███. "But now courts are closed, and I don't know what will happen to him."

 Similarly, Hazrat Ali, a 22-year-old man from Shaatbhoridhuk village in Barpeta district, is also waiting for the courts to open so that he can get his father, Hanif Ali, out on bail. "Each passing day brings new tragedy for us. All I want is him to be home," Ali told ███.

 Human rights organizations have demanded the release of the detainees amid the escalating coronavirus pandemic. Amnesty International India, in a statement on Monday, called for the immediate release of inmates declared foreigners. "Assam government must recognize that the detainees in overcrowded detention centers face a heightened risk of infection and must do everything to protect them, starting with their immediate release," Amnesty's executive director Avinash Kumar said in the statement.

 On Tuesday, India's Supreme Court heard a petition filed by one of the detainees, Raju Bala Das, and issued notices to both the Assam and federal governments. Das's petition had sought the release of people who have spent more than two years in detention. The top court also heard pleas by the Justice and Liberty Initiative, a non-profit group, which called for their release on humanitarian grounds.

 "The government has deported just five 'foreigners' in the last seven years. It is because of the fact that most of those in the camps are Indian citizens. They should be immediately released," the group's founder Aman Wadud told ███. "And this is the best time to correct the historical mistake."

 The Supreme Court will next hear both the pleas on April 13. For Gulbahar, imprisonment amid the coronavirus pandemic is like a death sentence for her father. With each passing day, she says her hope of seeing him alive is fading. "I think I would never see him alive," she said. "And the government has to take responsibility for his death."

Title: Trump Condemns Syrian Chemical Attack, Signals Potential U.S. Response

Article:

President Donald Trump has condemned the chemical attack in Syria that has been attributed to President Bashar Assad, signaling a shift in Trump's approach towards the Syrian leader. During a Rose Garden news conference on Wednesday with Jordan's King Abdullah, Trump stated, "It crossed a lot of lines for me."

The attack, which has reportedly resulted in at least 72 deaths, has had a significant impact on Trump's stance towards Syria, according to the president. "It's very, very possible that my attitude toward Syria and Assad has changed very much," Trump said.

Trump's criticism of the Obama administration's approach towards Syria was reiterated during the conference, with the president stating that the attack had a "big impact" on him. However, when pressed on how the U.S. would respond, Trump remained vague, stating he did not want to reveal his hand and would remain flexible.

Trump's comments on the Syrian conflict have been at odds with his past statements, as he previously argued the U.S. should not involve itself in the conflict. NPR's Tamara Keith reported on Tuesday that Trump's blame of former President Barack Obama for not acting after Assad crossed the "red line" was inconsistent with Trump's previous positions.

Trump also criticized the Obama administration's approach to the Syrian conflict, stating, "I think the Obama administration had a responsibility to solve the crisis a long time ago." He added, "And when he did not cross that line in making the threat, I think that set us back a long ways not only in Syria, but in many other parts of the world because it was a blank threat."

United Nations Ambassador Nikki Haley also suggested the possibility of U.S. intervention in Syria's ongoing civil war, strongly condemning the attacks and blaming Russia for its support of the Assad regime. Haley questioned, "How many more children have to die before Russia cares?"

Trump has historically praised Russian President Vladimir Putin, signaling a willingness to collaborate with Russia in combating terrorism amid ongoing investigations into Russian efforts to influence the U.S. election last year and potential ties between Trump's presidential campaign and Russia. In an interview with the New York Times before the news conference, Trump began to cast blame towards Putin, marking another shift in his stance. "I think it's a very sad day for Russia because they're aligned, and in this case, all information points to Syria that they did this," Trump told the Times. "Why they did this, who knows? That's a level, first of all, they were not supposed to have this."

Title: Small Business Health Exchanges Face Challenges in Implementation

Article:

The Obama administration is facing challenges in implementing the Small Business Health Options Program (SHOP) exchanges, a key component of the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare). The exchanges, designed to make it easier for small businesses to purchase health coverage, are facing issues with insurer participation, particularly in some states.

According to Politico, early looks at insurance offerings on the Obamacare exchanges show that insurers are not signing up in large numbers to sell on the SHOP exchanges. In some states, only one insurer has signed up for the SHOP exchanges, which are supposed to foster competition and make it easier for small businesses to purchase coverage.

The Obama administration is still trying to recruit insurers to states where there has been little interest in the exchanges. However, some health law advocates believe that the administration has prioritized standing up the individual exchanges, where they hope premium tax credits will be a big draw for millions to sign up for coverage next year.

In Washington state and North Carolina, for instance, only a single insurer has signed up to offer insurance through the small-business exchanges. In Mississippi, no insurers have signed up for the SHOP exchange, while only one insurer has signed up for their individual exchange.

Furthermore, a delayed program that was supposed to help provide small-business employees with a greater array of choice in health plans isn't expected to get out of the gate until after 2015 in the federally-run state exchanges. This delay will not help the Obama administration follow through on the key selling point that these exchanges would be helpful to small businesses in increasing competition and lowering costs.

Title: USA Freedom Act Clears House Judiciary Committee, Faces Uncertain Future in Senate

Article:

The USA Freedom Act, a bipartisan legislation sponsored by an unusual coalition of conservative Republicans and liberal Democrats, has passed the House Judiciary Committee with overwhelming support from both parties. The bill, which is expected to be approved by the full House, aims to reform the government's bulk data collection practices, particularly those authorized under Section 215 of the Patriot Act.

The measure faces a more uncertain future in the Senate, where a similar bill failed by two votes to overcome a filibuster last year. The legal authority for domestic bulk data collection is set to expire on June 1, creating a deadline that is likely to prompt Congress to take action to avoid letting the program disappear altogether.

The bulk collection program, revealed by Edward Snowden in 2013, generated significant criticism due to its wide-reaching data collection methods. Under the program, major phone companies were forced, under a secret court order, to pour their data directly into government computers. However, the data received was only "metadata" - phone numbers called, as well as the duration and time of calls, but not the content of the conversations.

Under the new legislation, the government would no longer be allowed to maintain a database of that information. Instead, they would be limited to obtaining data from telecommunications companies when there is a "reasonable, articulable suspicion" that a "specific selection term" used to request data is associated with international terrorism.

According to an analysis by the Electronic Frontier Foundation, a civil liberties advocacy group, the bill "should end" the bulk collection of "everyone's phone records." However, the NSA could still search for records beyond telephone data with fewer restrictions.
