The bill would not address warrantless collection of Americans' international calls and emails under Section 702 of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act amendments of 2008.

The future of the bulk collection program may have been sealed in December 2013, when a panel of experts appointed by President Obama found that the program had been of minimal intelligence value and ran considerable risks of invading privacy.

Title: Terrorist Attack at Berlin Christmas Market Kills 12, Injures 48

Article:

A suspected terrorist drove a truck into a Christmas market in Berlin on Monday night, resulting in the deaths of 12 individuals and injuries to 48 others, some critically. The incident occurred at the popular Christkindlmarkt, or Christmas market, which has historical roots dating back to 1434 in Dresden's Striezelmarkt.

The attack has struck at the heart of German tradition, with the Christmas market symbolizing a powerful influence on German sentiment. Despite being dismissed as kitschy by some and overly commercial in some instances, the Christmas market remains a cherished part of German culture, characterized by twinkling white lights, a capella music, and wooden ornaments handcrafted by local artisans.

In an interview three years ago, a vendor named Roland Schweizer, who sold iced gingerbread cookies and sugared almonds at a Christmas market in Stuttgart, expressed the sentiment shared by many Germans: "Without the Christmas market, there is no Christmas. This is worth preserving."

Berlin police tweeted early Tuesday that the truck driver intentionally veered into the crowd, in what is believed to be a terrorist attack. The evening attack occurred at Breitscheidplatz, near the Kaiser Wilhelm memorial church that lay in ruins after World War II.

Germany's Interior Minister Thomas de Maiziere stated that the man they arrested in connection to the attack is from Pakistan and entered Germany on December 31, 2015, coming to Berlin in February. It is possible he entered the country as part of a wave of more than a million refugees and migrants seeking asylum in Europe. However, Berlin police say the suspect denies any role, and they urge Germans to remain vigilant as the perpetrator may still be at large.

The attack follows a turbulent year for Europe, with the terrorist attack in Nice, France, in July, where a man drove a 19-ton truck into a crowd gathering for a fireworks display on Bastille Day, resulting in 86 deaths. Germany had been spared such a large-scale attack, although four separate incidents this summer became known as "black July."

The yearning for a calmer time is powerful, and the allure of the Christmas market reflects this longing. Stephen Nissenbaum, author of "The Battle for Christmas," told the Associated Press that this type of longing has always underpinned the "Christmas spirit." People have always looked back at the magical hold Christmas had over them as children or generally to a time they perceive as simpler.

One longtime producer of Christmas markets in Germany could not be reached for comment. Hitting a Christmas market is powerfully symbolic for Germans, just as attacking Bastille Day festivities was for the French or hitting cafes for Parisians, as terrorists did on November 13, 2015.

François-Bernard Huyghe, a senior researcher at the French Institute for International and Strategic Affairs in Paris, states that terrorists, although it has not been confirmed in this case who is behind the attack in Berlin, are not necessarily hitting these places as symbols of a nation. "They want to kill as many people as they can. It is very logical that they would choose very crowded places when people are celebrating, like Bastille Day or Christmas, or it could be football or a rock concert," he says.

Terrorists have also targeted religion in Europe, killing a priest in Normandy this summer and targeting a kosher supermarket in Paris in January 2015. An attack on Christmas is perceived not in overtly religious terms but as an attack on a way of life. Millions are drawn to Germany's markets each year, so popular they are now reproduced around Europe and even the United States.

The US State Department issued a warning in November that terrorists in Europe were focusing "on the upcoming holiday season and associated events, including outdoor markets." Last week, officials said a 12-year-old boy attempted to set off a bomb at another market in Ludwigshafen. Markets in Germany have been shut down for the day out of respect for the victims, but are expected to reopen for the rest of the season under much heavier security – in Germany, France, and beyond.

Title: Trump Delays Decision on Firing Attorney General Jeff Sessions Until After November Elections

Article:

President Donald Trump has postponed his decision regarding the dismissal of Attorney General Jeff Sessions until at least after the November congressional elections, according to a statement made by Trump in an interview with Bloomberg News on Thursday. Trump expressed his desire for Sessions to perform well in his current position, but declined to comment on whether he would keep Sessions beyond November.

Trump has publicly criticized Sessions for months, and reportedly told one Republican lawmaker that he wanted to fire him before the midterm elections. However, top Republican lawmakers have urged Sessions to resist pressure to resign and have encouraged Trump to hold off on any decision for the time being.

Trump's statement on Sessions came after the president consulted advisers earlier this week about the potential political backlash from firing Sessions. Trump reportedly told one person that he did not believe there would be significant backlash. Inside the White House, senior officials provided Trump with legal and political reasons for not removing Sessions, but advisers were unsure earlier this week about Trump's ultimate decision.

One factor contributing to Trump's decision to keep Sessions for the coming months is the lack of a clear replacement. White House officials and others Trump has spoken to about firing Sessions said the president has not inquired about potential successors.

Tensions between Trump and Sessions have escalated due to Sessions' decision to recuse himself from the investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 elections. This investigation is examining possible collusion between the Trump campaign and Russia, as well as possible obstruction of justice. Trump has denied any wrongdoing and has called the probe a "witch hunt." Russia has also denied any involvement.

Last week, Trump issued a series of attacks on Sessions, suggesting that Sessions is allowing the special counsel's Russia investigation to proceed while permitting "real corruption" to go "untouched." In response, Sessions issued a rare public statement defending his leadership of the Justice Department. "While I am attorney general, the actions of the Department of Justice will not be improperly influenced by political considerations," he said.

The tweets put renewed pressure on Sessions, who is in a delicate position of both fending off attacks from Trump while implementing the president's tough-on-crime policies.

Title: AP Photo of Mitt Romney Sparks Controversy Over Journalistic Ethics

Article:

A photograph of Mitt Romney, a seemingly astonished schoolgirl standing behind him, has sparked a debate over journalistic ethics following its publication by The Associated Press (AP) on Monday. The image, which has since circulated widely on the internet, has been the subject of criticism for its perceived humorous and potentially disrespectful portrayal of the Republican presidential candidate.

Steve Manuel, senior lecturer at Penn State's College of Communications and an award-winning photojournalist, stated that the AP must have been aware of the image's potential perception when it was published. "In this photo, while it may appear funny, AP knows exactly what viewers are thinking," he wrote in an email. "It's not legitimate news. AP knows that viewers are going to chuckle and imagine what the little girl is seeing, and it makes Gov. Romney appear a bit foolish. That is not the purpose or mission of photojournalism."

Tim Graham, media analysis director at the Media Research Center, shared similar sentiments, stating, "It's unbelievable. It honestly looks like a little girl is gaping at Romney from behind." He further noted that the image coincided with a story with a decidedly anti-Romney tone.

The AP piece, which ran concurrently with the photograph, focused on Romney's decision to skip a Nickelodeon-sponsored "Kids Pick the President" special, an event that President Obama had agreed to participate in. The story was largely a platform for show producer Linda Ellerbee to express her disapproval of the Republican nominee.

Stephen Ward, director of the Center for Journalism Ethics at the University of Wisconsin-Madison, noted that the photo, in itself, was not particularly offensive but could be exploited. He suggested that the AP may have entered a "gray area" with this image, as it was not altered or manipulated in any apparent way. However, the National Press Photographers Association code of ethics offers guidance, stating, "Treat all subjects with respect and dignity" and "Be complete and provide context when photographing or recording subjects."

The controversy surrounding the photograph has raised questions about the role of journalism in political campaigns and the ethical implications of publishing images that may be perceived as disrespectful or humorous at the expense of a political candidate.

Title: Trump Discusses Republican Leaders' Endorsement and Party Unity

Article:

In a recent interview, Donald Trump, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, has expressed confidence that he will receive the support of most Republican leaders despite some refusal to endorse him. Trump stated, "I'm going to get millions and millions of votes more than the Republicans would have gotten," during an interview on NBC's Meet the Press.

Trump's comments come as House Speaker Paul Ryan, who is scheduled to meet with Trump on Thursday, has expressed doubts about Trump's conservatism, leading to his reluctance to endorse the nominee-in-waiting. In an interview on ABC's This Week, Trump described himself as a "very different" kind of candidate, suggesting that party unity may not be as crucial due to new Republicans.

Traditional party unity has been a topic of discussion, with some Republican leaders, including 2012 Republican nominee Mitt Romney, former 2016 GOP hopefuls Jeb Bush, and Lindsey Graham, expressing doubts about Trump's temperament, conservatism, and comments about women and Hispanics.

Trump's critics have been vocal in their opposition. Bush, in a Facebook post on Friday, stated that Trump lacks "temperament or strength of character" to be president, and that he has not displayed a respect for the Constitution. Romney has denounced Trump as a "phony" and a "fraud," while Graham has expressed skepticism about finding a conservative agenda with Trump.

In response, Trump has accused Romney of being "ungrateful" for his support in 2012, suggesting that Romney "choked" on his chance to beat President Obama. Trump also noted that Bush and Graham are upset that he beat them during the nomination fight, and that they have broken their pledge to support the nominee.

Trump has also been critical of Ryan, stating that he was "blindsided" by Ryan's reluctance to endorse. Ryan, however, has expressed a desire to back the nominee but is not yet ready to do so.

Democrats, particularly Hillary Clinton, the likely Democratic presidential nominee, are reportedly enjoying the Republican in-fighting. Clinton told CBS' Face the Nation that she is reaching out to voters who want a candidate running on issues. Trump, on the other hand, is confident that most Republicans will back his candidacy, stating, "The party's come together. I have tremendous numbers of endorsements."

Title: U.S. Intelligence Community to Brief President-elect Trump on Russian Hacking Report

Article:

President-elect Donald Trump is expected to receive a briefing on Friday regarding a report prepared by the U.S. intelligence community on Russian hacking activities during the presidential election. The report, which was ordered by President Obama in December, has been prepared by the CIA, FBI, and NSA. Director of National Intelligence James Clapper announced on Thursday that an unclassified version of the report will be made public early next week.

In his testimony before the Senate Armed Services Committee on Thursday, Clapper previewed some of the report's findings, stating that hacking was only part of Russia's cyber activities during the election. He also mentioned that classical propaganda, disinformation, and fake news were also involved.

Four intelligence chiefs, including Clapper, CIA Director John Brennan, FBI Director James Comey, and National Security Agency Director Adm. Mike Rogers, will brief Mr. Trump on the report on Friday at Trump Tower in New York.

For several weeks, the president-elect has questioned the U.S. intelligence community's integrity and its assessment that Russia not only launched cyberattacks against the U.S. to sow doubt in the election but to sway the outcome in favor of Mr. Trump. Since the final weeks of the campaign, he has also doubted that Russia was responsible for the cyberattacks against the Democratic National Committee (DNC), other political groups, and Hillary Clinton's campaign chairman John Podesta.

On Wednesday, Mr. Trump posted a tweet indicating he is still not convinced Russia is to blame for the cyberattacks against the DNC, other political groups, and John Podesta. He claimed on New Year's Eve that he had information no one else had on Russian hacking and that he would reveal it publicly this week, but he has not yet followed through on that statement.

A number of Republicans in Congress, such as Rep. Michael McCaul, R-Texas, chairman of the Homeland Security Committee, are adamant about the need for the new administration to develop a more clear-cut cyber policy and to punish Russia for its actions. McCaul expressed confidence in the intelligence on Thursday, stating that the evidence he was briefed on in both classified and unclassified settings "was very clear," and he said that it was clear the attacks were "nation-state based."

Sen. John McCain, R-Arizona, and other Republicans warned at his committee's hearing that Russia must suffer the consequences. "Every American should be alarmed by Russia's attacks on our nation," said McCain. Later in the day, he told reporters that the Trump administration should work with Congress to craft a cyber policy.

Clapper, Rogers, and undersecretary of defense for intelligence, Marcel Lettre, issued a joint statement on Thursday, warning that Russia is a "full-scope cyber actor." They stated that only Russia's senior-most officials could have authorized the recent election-focused data thefts and disclosures, based on the scope and sensitivity of the targets. Russia has also used cyber tactics and techniques to seek to influence public opinion across Europe and Eurasia, they added.

Last week, the Obama administration announced a new series of sanctions against Russian intelligence agents and entities that the U.S. says were responsible for hacks into the DNC and other servers. In addition to the targeted sanctions, 35 Russian operatives were expelled from the U.S. in retaliation.

Sen. Lindsey Graham, R-South Carolina, said those actions weren't good enough and had some advice for the president-elect: "When you listen to these people [in the intelligence community], you can be skeptical, but you have to understand they're the best among us."

"I think what Obama did was throw a pill. I'm ready to throw a rock," Graham said. "If we don't throw rocks, we're going to make a huge mistake."

Over the next week, Sen. Ben Cardin, D-Maryland, the top Democrat on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, plans to roll out legislation containing tougher sanctions against Russia.

"That hearing today gave a great boost to sanctions," McCain said. Clapper's testimony and Rogers' testimony this morning helps that process along and resolved any doubts as to what the intelligence part of our government thinks."

Meanwhile, Mr. Trump appeared to side this week with WikiLeaks' Julian Assange, who again denied that their source for hacked emails was not the Russian government. Several lawmakers slammed Mr. Trump for questioning the integrity of the intelligence community. Sen. Claire McCaskill, D-Missouri, asked Clapper, "Who benefits from a president-elect trashing the intelligence community?"

"I think there is an important distinction here between healthy skepticism," Clapper said. "... I think there's a difference between skepticism and disparagement."

Speaker Paul Ryan, R-Wisconsin, had positive, but qualified words for the intelligence community. "I do have faith that our men and women in the intelligence community are doing an incredible job, sacrificing for our country," he told reporters Thursday. "But there's always room for improvement."

On the question of whether Russians meddled in the presidential election, though, Ryan firmly believes the intelligence. "Did the Russians hack us? Yes. Is it right for any country to meddle in our elections? No," he said on "The Jerry Bader Show."

Title: White House Honors Evangelical Leaders, Discusses Religious Freedom and Midterm Elections

Article:

In a unique turn of events, the White House hosted an evening celebration on Monday, not for a foreign head of state, but for evangelical leaders. President Donald Trump, in his address, acknowledged the gathering as a celebration of America's faith and its believers.

Among the faith leaders present were Rev. Franklin Graham and Pastor Paula White. The president also took a moment to express gratitude for the late Sen. John McCain's (R-AZ) service to the country.

"Our hearts and prayers are going to the family of Sen. John McCain... and we very much appreciate everything Sen. McCain has done for our country," Trump said.

The president then shifted the focus to the dinner's purpose: honoring America's faith and freedom. He emphasized his administration's efforts to combat religious persecution, citing the release of hostages from North Korea, including an American pastor, and the ongoing efforts to free Pastor Brunson from Turkey.

Trump urged people of faith to vote in the midterms to continue the progress. This sentiment was echoed by Pastor Robert Jeffress, a staunch supporter of the president.

"They are facing the possibility of a Democrat Congress that, if they take control of the legislature, will either impeach this president from office or at least paralyze him while he is in office," Pastor Jeffress said.

The event served as a show of appreciation for the role evangelicals played in propelling Trump into office in 2016 and a pledge to protect their rights to continue their work.

"The support you've given me has been incredible, but I really don't feel guilty because I have given you a lot back," Trump said.

Ralph Reed, from the Faith & Freedom Coalition, weighed in, stating, "The president just wanted to celebrate, and what our churches and houses of worship do every day – to provide spiritual direction to the lost, heal the broken-hearted, to save marriages and lives – that goes every day in America."

Title: Lessons Learned: The Financial and Social Consequences of Public White Supremacy

Article:

The aftermath of the "Unite the Right" rally in Charlottesville, Virginia, has highlighted the financial and social repercussions of publicly espousing white supremacist views. In the week following the event, several companies, including Cloudflare, have terminated their services for white supremacist websites, such as The Daily Stormer.

In a recent piece at National Review, Kevin Williamson discusses the ideology of white supremacists, suggesting that they lack a coherent set of demands or a well-developed ideological position, but are instead seeking identity and purpose in the wrong places. This theory reflects the experiences of the author, who grew up in a town where the Confederate flag was displayed casually and unabashedly.

The author recalls a high school classmate who identified as a neo-Nazi, but was unable to provide a cogent explanation for his prejudices. In the early 2000s, the author worked construction with a Klansman who struggled financially and showed up to job sites hungover. These individuals, the author notes, were born into less than ideal circumstances, but their circumstances were not orchestrated by people of color or other minority groups.

In May 2012, the FBI arrested some of the author's former high school classmates as they trained with American Front, a white supremacist group. The author expresses empathy for people of color who may have felt threatened by the group's activities in their community.

Despite their public displays of white supremacy, the author argues that many of these individuals are simply sore losers, people who have not achieved their goals due to circumstances beyond their control. The author suggests that most people, regardless of their prejudices, understand the importance of caution and courtesy in order to succeed in society.

The author concludes by stating that the "dapper" echelons of the alt-right, with their education and supposed historical acumen, have also learned this valuable lesson: being awful in public will not lead them to the places they aspire to be.

Title: Greece's Finance Minister Resigns as EU Leaders Meet to Address Bailout Crisis

Article:

Greece and its European Union partners are navigating the aftermath of a referendum in which the country rejected a German-led bailout plan. The vote has set in motion a series of events that could potentially lead to renegotiating the bailout terms or Greece's exit from the EU.

Eurogroup President Jeroen Dijsselbloem described the vote as "regrettable for the future of Greece," and called an emergency meeting on Tuesday. The European Union leaders expect Greece to put forth a new proposal soon.

The first concrete consequence of the vote was the resignation of Greek Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis on Monday. In a statement, Varoufakis expressed hope that his resignation would aid Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras in negotiating more favorable terms for Greece.

Varoufakis, who called the vote "splendid" and the "historic" moment when Greece "rose up against debt bondage," also indicated that he would wear the creditors' loathing with pride.

Greece has appointed Euclid Tsakalotos as its new finance minister. Tsakalotos, who has been a key negotiator in the drawn-out talks between the Greek government and creditors, is expected to maintain a more reserved public persona compared to Varoufakis, but may not take a softer approach in substance during the new bailout talks.

European Commission Vice President Valdis Dombrovskis stated that while they respect the "democratic choice of the Greek people," the no vote "widens the gap between Greece and Eurozone countries." He also explained that the European Commission cannot negotiate new terms with Greece without a mandate from eurogroup countries.

Dombrovskis emphasized that the eurozone is not in danger, and concluded that "the place of Greece is, and remains, in Europe." He urged all sides to work together responsibly for the sake of the Greek people.

Title: Mississippi Senate Candidate Cindy Hyde-Smith Attended Segregation Academy, Praised Confederate Soldier

Article:

In the run-up to a tense Senate runoff election in Mississippi, Republican candidate Cindy Hyde-Smith has faced renewed scrutiny over her past associations and comments. Reports from the Jackson Free Press, an independent newspaper in Mississippi, and CNN have brought attention to Hyde-Smith's attendance at a segregation academy and her praise for a Confederate soldier's efforts.

The Jackson Free Press reported that Hyde-Smith attended Lawrence County Academy, a school founded in 1970, the year many Mississippi public high schools integrated. The newspaper reported that the school was created for parents who did not want to send their children to schools with black students. The Free Press included photos from the school's yearbook, including a group photo of the cheerleading squad, of which Hyde-Smith was a member. The photo shows the school's mascot dressed in what appears to be a Confederate uniform holding a Confederate flag.

Hyde-Smith's campaign spokeswoman, Melissa Scallan, responded to the report, stating, "In their latest attempt to help Mike Espy, the gotcha liberal media has taken leave of their senses. They have stooped to a new low, attacking her entire family and trying to destroy her personally instead of focusing on the clear differences on the issues between Cindy Hyde-Smith and her far-left opponent."

Another report, from CNN, delved into Hyde-Smith's work as a legislator and found she once praised a Confederate soldier for his work to "defend his homeland." According to CNN, as a state senator in 2007, Hyde-Smith co-sponsored a resolution that honored Effie Lucille Nicholson Pharr, whose father was a soldier in Robert E. Lee's army. The resolution stated that her father "fought to defend his homeland and contributed to the rebuilding of the country."

Democratic candidate Mike Espy has repeatedly pointed to Hyde-Smith's comments while campaigning. Hyde-Smith apologized for the "hanging" comments during a debate earlier this week and dubbed the voting suppression comments a "joke." The continued reports have garnered national attention to the runoff race, which is expected to see a higher-than-average turnout. President Donald Trump is planning multiple rallies next week ahead of the election to help secure another Republican seat in the Senate after large losses in the House allowed Democrats to gain control.

Title: Trump Faces Challenges in First Month as President

Article:

President Donald Trump is encountering significant obstacles in his first month in office, as the complexities of the Washington political landscape present hurdles that cannot be easily overcome by a business executive. The vast government machine, composed of courts, bureaucracy, and Congress, can emerge as a threat at any point.

In the past week, political pressure has led to the dismissal of Trump's national security adviser and the withdrawal of one of his Cabinet nominees. The president is also facing persistent and growing questions about his campaign's ties to Russia, with some fellow Republicans in Congress expressing concerns. Legislative victories are proving elusive as congressional Republicans struggle to unify behind policy measures, and Democrats form a solid bloc of opposition.

The transition from candidate to president is challenging for most young administrations. Presidents such as Jimmy Carter and Bill Clinton experienced rocky opening weeks as their campaign idealism collided with Washington reality. However, Trump's first month in office is noteworthy due to the self-inflicted wounds that have arisen, from the rushed rollout of his travel ban to his frequent Twitter distractions.

The turmoil surrounding the new administration could undermine a central tenet of Trump's pitch to voters: that he is a non-politician uniquely positioned to make deals and get Washington working again. Trump's inaugural speech in Cleveland stated, "Nobody knows the system better than me, which is why I alone can fix it."

Trump began his presidency by adhering to these beliefs, unleashing a series of executive orders demonstrating a determination to wield firm executive power. However, the backlash was swift as the checks on presidential power soon activated. The federal court halted Trump's controversial executive order banning immigration from seven majority-Muslim countries. Despite GOP majorities in Congress, Trump is not making much progress on his legislative agenda.

Opposition is growing in the Senate to paying for his border wall now that Mexico has refused to fund it, according to CNN's Manu Raju. Democrats have frustrated the President by delaying confirmation of Cabinet nominees.

"That's all they're doing is delaying," Trump said during an extraordinary White House press conference last week. "And you look at (Senate Democratic leader) Chuck Schumer and the mess that he's got over there, and they have nothing going."

A leaky federal government and intelligence community with which Trump is locked in a perpetual state of war are also resisting his attempts to exert control over his administration. White House Chief of Staff Reince Priebus denied Sunday that there was dysfunction in the President's inner circle.

"The truth is that we do not have problems in the West Wing," Priebus said on NBC's "Meet the Press." "The amount of drama and spin that you read about mostly in the Washington daily gossip rags is unbelievable stuff. And it just is not true."

Amid the negative headlines, Trump is attempting to speak directly to the American people. He delivered a speech Friday touting his jobs agenda at a Boeing factory in South Carolina and a campaign-style rally over the weekend in Florida. He is scheduled to deliver an address to a joint session of Congress later this month, providing one of the strongest venues available to project presidential strength.

However, Trump's early stumbles have overshadowed some areas where he could otherwise claim success. Well-choreographed visits from the leaders of Britain, Israel, Canada, and Japan followed a host of executive orders that began to dismantle Obamacare and federal regulations and open the way for cross-continental pipelines, as well as Trump's withdrawal from the Trans Pacific Partnership trade deal. His unveiling of Neil Gorsuch as his nominee for the open Supreme Court seat was one of the most flawless moments of his presidency.

Controversy can develop in unexpected directions in Washington and exhaust a White House staff in a way that can be detrimental to a presidency. Trump is not the first President to come into power with a team that does not seem to quite measure up to Washington's demands.

"I think every administration goes through that," said Trent Lott, a former Republican Senate Majority leader, in an interview. "I was here through Carter, when a bunch of Georgians who thought they were the smartest guys in town arrived and they were going to fix everything."

"When (Ronald) Reagan came to town, he brought a bunch of Californians, idealistic ideologues who found out pretty quick that they needed help from Jim Baker," Lott said.

Through trial and error, Clinton and Reagan learned to work the inside game in Washington to advance what were sometimes seen as outsider political aims. However, Trump's attempts to fight back against the restrictions all presidents face could be complicated by another factor: his idiosyncratic character and political style, which were an undoubted asset when he reinvented the rules of the presidential campaign but have not yet proven effective in governing.

His constant feuds with enemies, sometimes on Twitter, cast doubt on his temperament, as do his unpredictable eruptions and struggles to stop gloating about his election win. His press conference and weekend rallies helped keep his loyal supporters happy and boosted his own morale. However, it seems unlikely that he meaningfully advanced his political agenda.

GOP majorities on Capitol Hill should ensure that big-ticket issues like tax cuts and Wall Street reform get done and that Trump can bill them as the kind of "wins" he promised would dazzle Washington. And if any politician can get away with such polarizing tactics, it's Trump.

"The President's campaign essentially changed the laws of physics last year," said Bill Lacy, director of the Dole Institute of Politics at the University of Kansas.

"All the so-called experts have been wrong consistently," Lacy said, adding that Trump had changed the way presidents are viewed along with the usual codes of behavior in the White House and Washington. "Traditionally, a President could not do that and get away with it. With this president, that remains to be seen."

Title: House GOP Blocks Immigration Measures on National Defense Authorization Act

Article:

The House Republican leadership has formally blocked a pair of immigration-related measures from being voted on in the National Defense Authorization Act (NDAA), a critical defense policy bill, on early Wednesday. This latest development deals another blow to the prospects of immigration legislation this year.

The Republican-led House Rules Committee, which adheres to the wishes of leadership, declined to include the ENLIST Act, a bill authored by Rep. Jeff Denham (R-Calif.) that provides a path to green cards for immigrants who came to the U.S. as children if they serve in the military, among the amendments to be considered on the NDAA.

Rep. Denham expressed his disappointment over the decision, stating, "I am disappointed that my ENLIST amendment was not ruled in order this year. I will continue to push for a vote on the stand-alone bill so that undocumented young people who want to perform the ultimate act of patriotism will have that opportunity and be able to earn legal status through their sacrifice."

Another immigration measure, from Rep. Joaquin Castro (D-Texas), that would allow young immigrants who have been granted a reprieve from deportations by the Obama administration to enroll in U.S. military academies was also blocked from a vote.

Rep. Castro expressed his disappointment in a statement, saying, "I'm disappointed that expanding opportunity to all of our students to the U.S. military academies is not allowed to be part of the discussion about our nation's defense readiness." He plans to introduce the measure as a standalone bill with Rep. Ileana Ros-Lehtinen (R-Fla.).

Speaker John Boehner (R-Ohio) stated on Tuesday that including Rep. Denham's legislation, known as the ENLIST Act, on a must-pass bill such as the NDAA was "inappropriate," although he noted that Republican leaders have supported the measure in the past. Boehner added that there are talks about allowing the bill to get a stand-alone vote on the House floor.

More than 300 amendments were filed to the NDAA, and 162 of them will be considered on the legislation, a sweeping annual measure that sets policy for the Pentagon.

Title: U.S. Mission in Syria: A Shift from ISIS to Regime Change and Iran, and the Ongoing Debate

Article:

The United States' involvement in Syria has been marked by a shift in objectives, with the initial aim of defeating the Islamic State (ISIS) evolving into a focus on fighting Iran and promoting regime change in Damascus. The withdrawal of American troops from Syria has sparked confusion, with some viewing it as a necessary move to protect the Kurds from NATO ally Turkey, while others accuse President Donald Trump of handing a victory to Iran or giving a gift to Russian President Vladimir Putin.

The presence of a small American force of 4,000 troops in certain regions of Northern Syria is pursuing a limited objective, primarily focused on fighting ISIS. However, the mission's scope and objectives have been a subject of debate, with some viewing it as a modest endeavor, while others see it as a crucial component of the global liberal order.

The term "mission creep" has been used to describe the shift in military objectives that results in a long-term commitment. The U.S. mission in Syria, however, is mission creep itself, with objectives and rationale evolving over time. Initially, the focus was on supporting "moderate" Syrians in their civil war against the Assad regime, but this shifted as ISIS emerged in eastern Syria and western Iraq.

The U.S. has been accused of concocting elaborate theories about the codependence and cooperation of ISIS and the Assad regime. The Free Syrian Army, initially held out as a beacon of hope, quickly disintegrated, suggesting it was little more than a branding exercise.

Public support for greater U.S. involvement in Syria, driven by the beheadings of Americans and terror attacks across Europe, has provided a legal imprimatur for the U.S.'s actions under the 2001 Authorized Use of Military Force. However, the mission's objectives have often been at odds with the public-approved goal of defeating ISIS, as hawks and the foreign-policy establishment have sought to confront Shia governments in Damascus and Tehran.

New plans for American involvement in Syria have been proposed every six months or so, but they all share the same objective as the 2012 plan: defeating ISIS, toppling Assad, and hurting Iran. In 2015, Frederick Kagan suggested inserting 40,000 to 50,000 troops to create a safe zone in Syria, with the ultimate goal of forcing Assad out of power.

In 2018, then-Secretary of State Rex Tillerson outlined a way forward in Syria, with five key end states: reducing Iran's influence, creating conditions for refugees to return, ensuring Syria is free of weapons of mass destruction, transitioning away from Assad's leadership, and preventing the return of ISIS and al-Qaeda. Tillerson promised to achieve these goals with a minimum of troop commitments.

However, many refugees have already returned to Syria as Assad recaptured territory, and the zones of conflict have changed. Strengthening long-lasting government authority seems to be the swiftest way to reduce the capacity of ISIS locally, rather than continuing low-grade war in ad hoc alliances with non-state actors.

The disparity between the mission the public approved—defeating ISIS—and the mission that Washington's interventionists wanted—ousting Assad and hurting Iran—lasted until Trump announced his policy. This explains the hollow arguments for staying in Syria now that the caliphate has been destroyed. Some, like my colleague David French, merely want to deny ISIS any safe haven. However, many hawks want to stay because they want more chances to make their case for regime change and anti-Iranian military action in Syria. Their mission was mission creep. Six years is enough.

Title: Abortion Laws in New York and Alabama Spark Controversy: A Look at the New York and Alabama Abortion Laws and the Ongoing Debate

Article:

Protests outside the Alabama State Capitol have been ongoing, demonstrating against the state's new abortion law, enacted on May 15, 2019. The controversy surrounding abortion laws has been a topic of discussion in the United States, with recent comments made by President Trump and other political figures.

In early January, Kathy Tran, a Democratic Virginia delegate, introduced legislation to liberalize abortion in her state. During a colloquy with a Republican lawmaker, Tran's bill would have legalized abortions through the 40th week of pregnancy, including during labor. Following backlash, Tran clarified that she misspoke, as this would have violated infanticide laws.

In response to Tran's bill, Virginia Governor Ralph Northam, a pediatric neurologist by training, explained that in cases where a fetus was not viable, the infant would be delivered, resuscitated if desired, and a discussion would ensue between the physician and the mother. Northam never said anything about "executing" babies, but his comments have been a point of contention.

Tran's bill didn't pass, but it was part of a trend in liberal states to loosen abortion laws even further. Earlier in January, Democratic New York Governor Andrew Cuomo had signed similar legislation. The media's response to New York's law was relatively muted, while the reaction to Alabama's law has been more intense.

Polling on abortion is notoriously complex, with many Americans holding conflicting views on the issue. According to Gallup, 60 percent of Americans support abortion rights in the first trimester, but only 13 percent do in the third trimester.

The Alabama law, which is considered near-total, is unconstitutional under current precedent. The law's sponsors deliberately passed an unconstitutional law in the hope that the Supreme Court's new conservative majority would overturn Roe v. Wade and Planned Parenthood v. Casey, the landmark cases that established abortion rights in the United States.

New York's Democratic lawmakers weren't trying to test Roe or Casey, but to create a post-Roe abortion "sanctuary" in case the court does reverse Roe. The underlying political reality is that most Americans want a compromise, but the parties are more responsive to the activists and donors. As a result, Democrats have abandoned their "safe, legal, and rare" rhetoric, while Republicans are downplaying a "culture of life."

The debate over abortion laws is a polarized and polarizing issue, with each party seeking to cast the other as extreme. Republicans highlight rare late-term abortions, while Democrats focus on the also-rare cases of 12-year-olds impregnated by their rapist fathers. Overturning Roe and allowing states to pass laws that reflect majority opinion might not defuse the political passion, but at some point, we are likely to find out.

Title: Memorial Day Calls for National Unity Amidst COVID-19 Crisis

Article:

The ongoing COVID-19 pandemic has caused a significant impact on the United States, leading to a surge in unemployment, business closures, and deaths. As the country commemorates Memorial Day, the need for national unity in response to this external threat has become more apparent.

According to recent data, approximately 35 million people have filed for unemployment benefits, with millions more not accounted for. Hundreds of thousands of small businesses have closed, and major retailers like JC Penney and J. Crew are declaring bankruptcy. Manufacturing plants, such as Ford, have reopened only to close again due to worker infections. Major industries like the airlines are surviving primarily due to government and Federal Reserve assistance.

The human toll of the virus is substantial, with over 90,000 deaths and tens of thousands more weakened or crippled. However, the casualties extend beyond the virus's direct impact. Homeowners and renters struggle to pay mortgages and rent, graduates are unable to keep up with student loans, small businesses exhaust their reserves and lay off employees, front-line workers face constant stress and infection risk, and states and localities face plummeting revenues and rising costs, leading to layoffs and service cuts.

People are understandably scared, worried, and angry due to dashed plans and hopes caused by the pandemic. At this time, as in wartime, the government must act to organize the collective response to the crisis, provide medical and protective gear, develop testing and tracing strategies, distribute health resources, and galvanize an all-out effort for a remedy. The government must also limit the damage, keeping families in their homes, small businesses open, and workers employed.

Recent statements by Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell and Senator Lindsey Graham have raised concerns about the urgency to aid states and localities and extend supplemental unemployment benefits. McConnell has suggested that states could go bankrupt, and the crisis is largely due to "blue-state" mismanagement. Graham stated that any extension of unemployment benefits would occur only "over our dead bodies."

The casualties are not partisan; they affect Republicans and Democrats, small business owners and small farmers, meat packers, and more. They disproportionately impact middle- and low-income families, the poor, the elderly, and the sick. They are found in red states and blue states.

McConnell acknowledges the non-partisan nature of the casualties and the response must be the same. Let us hope he uses this Memorial Day break to develop a response of the necessary scale to meet the crisis. Let us hope that he moves from obstruction to negotiation, figuring out the compromises needed to move legislation through the Senate.

Most Americans agree that aiding the unemployed and supporting small business owners is not controversial. Some conservative Senate Republicans have joined with progressive House Democrats to champion a paycheck guarantee program that would support small business owners to pay their employees even when their businesses are locked down. This would enable workers to keep their benefits, get their pay, and owners to sustain their teams.

This is not a blue or red program; it is common sense. Similarly, most Americans would agree that everyone should have access to treatment and testing without financial worry, that the post office should not be bankrupted, and that voting should be safe in the fall. Voting by mail is not a partisan agenda; it is a safety agenda.

This is a time when leaders must emerge, move beyond their comfort zone, and offer bold responses to a stark crisis. This is not a moment for posturing; it is a time for patriotism, for solidarity, for action. Let us hope that Memorial Day celebrations may help our leaders remember this challenge.

Title: Islamic State Launches Offensive on Ramadi, Iraq

Article:

Islamic State militants have launched a fierce attack on the city of Ramadi, located in the Sunni-dominated Anbar Province, 70 miles west of Baghdad. The assault marks a setback for the Iraqi military's ongoing offensive in the region.

Sunni tribal leaders, who have been holding out in the city, reportedly expressed their shortage of weapons and ammunition, and are under intense pressure from the extremist group, according to Sterling Jensen, an assistant professor at the United Arab Emirates' National Defense College in Abu Dhabi. Jensen maintains close contact with tribal leaders.

Iraqi Defense Ministry spokesman, Brig. Gen. Tahseen Ibrahim, acknowledged that the militants have gained a foothold in some areas of Anbar Province, as reported by the Associated Press. He stated that reinforcements have been dispatched to the province, and the situation is under control, with the standoff expected to be resolved in the coming hours.

U.S. Central Command reported that the Iraqi government remains in control of Ramadi, the provincial capital. The fighting in Anbar is a key test for Iraq's military's goal to push the militants out of the country. Iraq's leaders decided to make a push in Anbar, located along the main roads linking Baghdad to the Syrian border, before launching an offensive into Mosul, Iraq's second-largest city.

Some residents of Anbar have sided with the Islamic State militants due to their shared Sunni identity and feelings of alienation from Iraq's Shiite-dominated government. Other tribes have fought against the militants, complaining of insufficient support from Baghdad's central government.

Washington has encouraged the Iraqi government to provide the Sunni tribes with arms and other support to carry out the fight against the extremists. "Baghdad is not speaking realistically about what's happening and what it claims to be doing for Sunni fighters," Jensen said.

Iraqi Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi expressed concern on Wednesday about the conflict in Yemen, stating that his government is "uneasy" about U.S. military support for Saudi Arabia, which is carrying out airstrikes against Shiite rebels there. Al-Abadi told reporters the conflict "has all the potential to become a sectarian war."

Title: House Speaker Nancy Pelosi Accuses President Trump of Coordinated Effort to Subvert 2016 Election, Questions Ties with Putin

Article:

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) did not back down from her attacks on President Donald Trump after they agreed to end the partial government shutdown, instead she hit him with a bizarre conspiracy theory. The Democratic leader made the accusations from her social media account on Friday.

"Roger Stone's indictment makes clear there was a deliberate, coordinated effort by top Trump campaign officials to subvert the will of the American people during the 2016 Election," she tweeted.

Pelosi was referring to the indictment and arrest Friday morning of one of the president's oldest friends and former campaign aides, Roger Stone. He was arrested at his home and charged with lying to Congress about being an intermediary between WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange and the Trump campaign.

Pelosi then asked if Russian Federation President Vladimir Putin was extorting President Trump.

"@realDonaldTrump's continued efforts to undermine Special Counsel Mueller's investigation raises the questions: 'What does Putin have on @realDonaldTrump, politically, personally or financially?'" she asked rhetorically.

She then implied that the president was attempting to weaken NATO, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, in order to help Putin's foreign policy schemes.

"Why has the Trump Administration continued to discuss pulling the U.S. out of NATO, which would be a massive victory for Putin?"

The speculation that Trump is doing the bidding of Putin because of some compromising information held against him has been made by many of the most virulent of the president's critics. Trump has denied all allegations of this sort.

Pelosi added in a statement, "Lying to Congress and witness tampering constitute grave crimes."

"All who commit these illegal acts should be held accountable to the fullest extent of the law," she said. "We can not allow any effort to intimidate witnesses or prevent them from appearing before Congress."

Title: Gun Violence Hearing: Tax Attorney Argues for Women's Right to Bear Arms for Self-Defense

Article:

In a Senate gun violence hearing on Tuesday, tax attorney Gayle Trotter, the sole female member of the five-person panel, advocated for women's right to own firearms for self-defense. Trotter argued that guns serve as an equalizer in violent situations, particularly for women facing larger, stronger male attackers.

"For women, the ability to arm ourselves for our protection is even more consequential than for men because guns are the great equalizer in a violent confrontation," Trotter stated. "We protect women by safeguarding our Second Amendment rights. Every woman deserves a fighting chance."

However, it is essential to clarify that Trotter's statement emphasizes the need for self-defense, not advocating for women to engage in combat.

In June, Trotter published an op-ed that appeared to criticize the idea of allowing women to serve in combat, but in reality, it questioned the role of women in the military in general. Trotter argued that young, single women recruited to serve in the military often become pregnant, which she suggested could disrupt their military service.

"Many young single women are specifically recruited to serve in our military," Trotter wrote. "When you mix young women with fit young men, pregnancies are to be expected."

Trotter further argued that a woman's role as a mother was more important than a position in the military. She questioned the principles of women's liberation, suggesting that confining mothers to leave their children behind while serving in the military would infringe upon their freedom.

"Do the principles of women's 'liberation' embrace jailing mothers for refusing to leave their kids behind with strangers?" Trotter asked rhetorically. "If a woman is not free to care for her child, what kind of liberation does she have?"

Critics seeking to maintain the ban on women in combat have argued that women are inherently less fit than their male counterparts. Trotter's testimony today echoed this argument, equating women with mothers.

"If we ban these types of assault weapons, you are putting women at a great disadvantage, more so than men, because they do not have the same type of physical strength and opportunity to defend themselves in a hand-to-hand struggle," Trotter told members of the Senate. "And they're not criminals; they're moms. They're young women. And they're not used to violent confrontations."

Trotter did not mention the biological or emotional problems former presidential candidates Rick Santorum and Newt Gingrich referenced in their arguments against women in combat.

Title: Assaults on U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement Agents Reach Decade High in 2017

Article:

Assaults on U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) agents and Border Patrol agents have seen a significant increase in recent years, according to government data. In 2017, the number of assaults on ICE agents and officers reached 48, tying the highest recorded since the beginning of the decade, while assaults on Border Patrol agents surged to 856, marking a decade high.

The report, released by the Department of Homeland Security's inspector general, indicates a renewed danger, particularly on the southwest border. The most frequent method of attack was projectiles, such as large rocks, which accounted for half of all assaults. Other weapons used include bombs, clubs, knives, guns, and laser pointers.

Most injuries were minor and did not require treatment, the audit found. Customs and Border Protection recorded 1,089 assaults in 2010, which dropped through 2014, with just 381 assaults. However, the number of assaults began to rise again, reaching 856 in 2017.

In 2017, there were 28 assaults per every 10,000 apprehensions. In the interior, ICE agents and officers saw 48 assaults in 2017, tying 2010 as the highest in records going back to the beginning of the decade.

ICE officers and Border Patrol agents have reported an increasing willingness on the part of migrants to resort to violence in recent years. One of the assaults recorded in 2017 involved Lester Sadict Cruz-Garcia, an immigrant from Honduras who was arrested by police in New York on a domestic assault charge. Despite a request by ICE that he be held, police released him into the community.

When ICE officers attempted to apprehend Cruz-Garcia, he struggled and kicked, attempting to get away. He was eventually handcuffed but bit one of the officers on the arm. The officer was taken to a hospital and prescribed antibiotics. Cruz-Garcia was sentenced in June to 364 days in jail.

In another incident in 2017, ICE officers in Massachusetts were trying to deport Mohammed Kenneh to Liberia. Kenneh knocked one officer to the ground and used the handcuffs around his wrists to ensnare the officer's hand, refusing to let go. The officer had to be taken to the emergency room.

Prosecutors often refuse to bring charges or win cases against the perpetrators, the audit found. The new numbers could even be underselling the problem, investigators said, because the government doesn't do a good job of tracking incidents, and agents and officers don't always report them properly.

Title: Tech Giants Apple and Google Collaborate on Contact Tracing Technology for COVID-19

Article:

In an attempt to aid in containing the COVID-19 pandemic, tech giants Apple and Google have joined forces to develop software for contact tracing. The software aims to alert individuals who have come into close proximity with people who have contracted the virus.

Contact tracing is considered a valuable tool in public health efforts to contain the spread of COVID-19. Various leading public health authorities, universities, and NGOs worldwide are working on opt-in contact tracing technology. To further this initiative, Apple and Google will launch a comprehensive solution that includes application programming interfaces (APIs) and operating system-level technology to facilitate contact tracing.

The plan is to implement this solution in two stages while prioritizing user privacy. In May, both companies will release APIs that enable interoperability between Android and iOS devices using apps from public health authorities. These official apps will be available for users to download via their respective app stores. In the coming months, Apple and Google will work to enable a broader Bluetooth-based contact tracing platform by integrating this functionality into the underlying platforms. This more robust solution would allow more individuals to participate, if they choose to opt in, as well as enable interaction with a broader ecosystem of apps and government health authorities.

Privacy, transparency, and consent are of utmost importance in this effort, and both companies look forward to building this functionality in consultation with interested stakeholders. They will openly publish information about their work for others to analyze.

However, Hot Air's Allahpundit has expressed skepticism about the ability for people to truly "opt out" of data mining. In a blog post, Allahpundit wrote, "If I understand that correctly, they’re going to roll this out quickly by first providing it as an app available for download—called Contact Tracing, neatly enough. Then, in stage two, they’re going to build it right into the iOS and Android operating systems while providing some sort of option to opt out."

Allahpundit questions the thoroughness of the "opt out" and suggests that the movements of opt-outs might still be tracked. He also raises concerns about the potential for the default setting on contact tracing to be set to turn it on and force users to turn it off.

Allahpundit notes that Apple and Google's app appears to function similarly to a program instituted by Germany to combat the virus, which broadcasts different IDs every 30 minutes as someone goes about their day. If a person tests positive for coronavirus, then it would trace which IDs came into contact with the temporary IDs of the coronavirus-positive person and send them an alert that they may have interacted with someone who had COVID-19.

However, as Allahpundit points out, this requires widespread testing for the virus, something that is not yet available.

Title: Senate Passes Tax Overhaul Bill, Moving Closer to Major Legislative Victory

Article:

The United States Senate has passed a sweeping tax overhaul bill worth approximately $1.4 trillion, moving one step closer to President Donald Trump's first significant legislative victory and potential tax cuts for many Americans. The vote, which took place early Saturday morning, was 51-49, with Republican Bob Corker of Tennessee being the sole member of the GOP to side with the Democrats in opposition.

Following the vote, President Trump tweeted his reaction, stating, "We are one step closer to delivering MASSIVE tax cuts for working families across America." He also thanked Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell and Senate Finance Committee Chairman Orrin Hatch for guiding the bill through the Senate. House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., responded by calling the legislation a "betrayal of the American middle class."

The bill is not yet finalized, as the Senate and House have passed similar tax reform plans. Negotiators from both chambers will begin meeting on Monday to agree on a single piece of legislation that both chambers must approve before it is sent to the president for his signature.

The Senate bill eliminates federal deductions for state and local income and sales taxes but allows deductions of up to $10,000 in local property taxes. The legislation originally eliminated federal deduction for all state and local taxes, but the property tax exemption was later added at the insistence of Sen. Susan Collins, R-Maine.

Like the House bill, the Senate bill nearly doubles the standard deduction level to $12,000 for individuals (up from $6,350) and $24,000 for couples (up from $12,700). The Senate bill retains the current limit for the home mortgage interest deduction to interest paid on the first $1 million of the loan. The Senate version also preserves the deduction for medical expenses not covered by insurance, but ends deductions for moving expenses and tax preparation.

The Senate bill allows owners of so-called "pass-through" businesses to deduct 23 percent of their earnings, and then pay at their personal income tax rate on the remainder. The Senate bill also keeps seven tax brackets, but reduces them to 10, 12, 22, 24, 32, 35, and 38.5 percent. The House measure condenses seven brackets to four: 12, 25, 35, and 39.6 percent.

The Senate and House bills both eliminate the $4,050 personal tax exemption. The changes will not have any impact on your taxes for 2017, which are due to the IRS by April 17, 2018 (you get an extra 48 hours to file because the traditional April 15 due date falls on a Sunday). The differences in the bills will be hashed out in the coming days, with the House expected to vote on a motion to go to conference on the tax bills on Monday evening. The Senate is expected to vote on a similar measure soon after. Congress is scheduled to adjourn for its Christmas break on Dec. 15, but House Speaker Paul Ryan has said he will keep the House in session beyond that date if necessary to get tax reform passed.

Title: Senate's Second-Ranking Democrat Confirms Sebelius to Testify on ObamaCare Website Issues

Article:

In response to the problem-plagued Healthcare.gov website, Senator Dick Durbin (D-Ill.), the Senate's second-ranking Democrat, announced on Sunday that Health and Human Services Secretary Kathleen Sebelius will testify before Congress. The House Energy and Commerce Committee has requested Sebelius to testify on Thursday regarding the website's issues, which have been marked by crashes, slow responses, and other glitches since its launch on October 1.

Sebelius has yet to respond publicly to the House Energy and Commerce Committee's request, but her refusal to testify has sparked calls for her resignation. Florida Republican Senator Marco Rubio expressed reluctance to call for an immediate dismissal but criticized Sebelius for not agreeing to testify, stating that her refusal has undermined her credibility.

House investigators are seeking to determine whether officials involved in the website were aware of or concealed problems, as they repeatedly claimed the site was "on track" to launch. Though the White House reported that 476,000 people have applied online for health insurance, officials have yet to disclose the number of people who have purchased a policy.

Missouri Republican Senator Roy Blunt stated that Sebelius' position appears "unsustainable," and that she will have to testify. The House investigators' focus on Secretary Sebelius intensified after she appeared on Comedy Central's "The Daily Show with Jon Stewart" last week to discuss the website. Michigan Republican Fred Upton, the Commerce committee chairman, has repeatedly stated, "Secretary Sebelius had time for Jon Stewart, and we expect her to have time for Congress."

Title: Judge Delays Sentencing for Michael Flynn, Former National Security Adviser, for Lying to FBI

Article:

A U.S. District Judge Emmet Sullivan criticized Michael Flynn, former national security adviser to President Donald Trump, for lying to FBI agents during an investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 election. The judge delayed sentencing Flynn until he has completed his cooperation with prosecutors.

During the hearing, Judge Sullivan stated that Flynn had arguably betrayed his country by operating as an undeclared lobbyist for Turkey while working on Trump's campaign team and preparing to be his White House national security adviser. Flynn pleaded guilty to lying to FBI agents about his December 2016 conversations with Sergei Kislyak, then Russia's ambassador in Washington, about U.S. sanctions imposed on Moscow by the administration of Trump's Democratic predecessor Barack Obama.

Special Counsel Robert Mueller, leading the investigation into possible collusion between Trump's campaign and Russia, had asked the judge not to sentence Flynn to prison because he had already provided "substantial" cooperation over the course of many interviews. Lying to the FBI carries a statutory maximum sentence of five years in prison, and Flynn's plea agreement stated that he was eligible for a sentence of between zero and six months.

Judge Sullivan sternly told Flynn his actions were abhorrent, noting that Flynn had also lied to senior White House officials, who in turn misled the public. The judge said he had read additional facts about Flynn's behavior that have not been made public. At one point, Sullivan asked prosecutors if Flynn could have been charged with treason, although the judge later said he had not been suggesting such a charge was warranted.

"Arguably, you sold your country out," Sullivan told Flynn. "I'm not hiding my disgust, my disdain for this criminal offense."

Flynn, dressed in a suit and tie, showed little emotion throughout the hearing, and spoke calmly when he confirmed his guilty plea and answered questions from the judge. Judge Sullivan appeared ready to sentence Flynn to prison but then gave him the option of a delay in his sentencing so he could fully cooperate with any pending investigations and bolster his case for leniency. The judge told Flynn he could not promise that he would not eventually sentence him to serve prison time.

Flynn accepted that offer. Sullivan did not set a new date for sentencing but asked Mueller's team and Flynn's attorney to give him a status report by March 13. Sullivan later imposed travel restrictions on Flynn, ordering him to surrender his passport and to obtain court permission before traveling outside the Washington area. The curbs are typical for people released on their own recognizance, the judge said.

Prosecutors said Flynn had already provided most of the cooperation he could, but it was possible he might be able to help investigators further. Flynn's attorney said his client is cooperating with federal prosecutors in a case against Bijan Rafiekian, his former business partner who has been charged with unregistered lobbying for Turkey. Rafiekian pleaded not guilty on Tuesday to those charges in federal court in Alexandria, Virginia. Flynn is expected to testify.

Prosecutors have said Rafiekian and Flynn lobbied to have Washington extradite a Muslim cleric who lives in the United States and is accused by Turkey's government of backing a 2016 coup attempt. Flynn has not been charged in that case.

Former U.S. national security adviser Michael Flynn departs after his sentencing was delayed at U.S. District Court in Washington, U.S., December 18, 2018. (Photo by Joshua Roberts)

Flynn was a high-profile adviser to Trump's campaign team. At the Republican Party's national convention in 2016, Flynn led Trump's supporters in cries of "Lock her up!" directed against Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton. A group of protesters, including some who chanted "Lock him up," gathered outside the courthouse on Tuesday, along with a large inflatable rat fashioned to look like Trump. Several Flynn supporters also were there, cheering as he entered and exited. One held a sign that read, "Michael Flynn is a hero."

Flynn became national security adviser when Trump took office in January 2017, but lasted only 24 days before being fired. He told FBI investigators on Jan. 24, 2017, that he had not discussed the U.S. sanctions with Kislyak when in fact he had, according to his plea agreement. Trump has said he fired Flynn because he also lied to Vice President Mike Pence about the contacts with Kislyak.

Trump has said Flynn did not break the law and has voiced support for him, raising speculation the Republican president might pardon him. "Good luck today in court to General Michael Flynn. Will be interesting to see what he has to say, despite tremendous pressure being put on him, about Russian Collusion in our great and, obviously, highly successful political campaign. There was no Collusion!" Trump wrote on Twitter on Tuesday morning.

After the hearing, White House spokeswoman Sarah Sanders told reporters the FBI had "ambushed" Flynn in the way agents questioned him, but said his "activities" at the center of the case "don't have anything to do with the president" and disputed that Flynn had committed treason. In contrast, Trump has called his former long-time personal lawyer Michael Cohen, who has pleaded guilty to separate charges, a "rat."

Mueller's investigation into Russia's role in the 2016 election and whether Trump has unlawfully sought to obstruct the probe has cast a shadow over his presidency. Several former Trump aides have pleaded guilty in Mueller's probe, but Flynn was the first former Trump White House official to do so. Mueller also has charged a series of Russian individuals and entities.

Trump has called Mueller's investigation a "witch hunt" and has denied collusion with Moscow. Russia has denied meddling in the election, contrary to the conclusion of U.S. intelligence agencies that have said Moscow used hacking and propaganda to try to sow discord in the United States and boost Trump's chances against Clinton.

Title: Death Toll in California Wildfires Reaches 42, With 228 Missing

Article:

Thirteen more bodies have been recovered in California, bringing the death toll in the state's deadliest wildfire to 42, officials say. The remains were found in and around the largely incinerated town of Paradise, in the north of the state. At least 228 people are missing as the Camp Fire continues to rage. Nearly 7,200 structures have been destroyed, and another 15,500 are at risk.

The fire has now surpassed the 1933 Griffith Park disaster that killed 31. Speaking at a news conference on Monday evening, Butte County Sheriff Kory Honea confirmed the number of dead and the official number of missing.

In the south of the state, other wildfires are menacing lives and property. The Woolsey Fire has so far killed two people, damaging beach resorts, including Malibu. More than 300,000 locals have been forced to flee their homes across California.

President Donald Trump has declared a "major disaster" in the state, making federal aid available to affected residents. Paradise and its surrounding areas bore the brunt of the Camp Fire - the largest blaze - which started in nearby forest on Thursday. Some bodies were found in gutted cars that were overrun by the fast-moving fire, as residents scrambled to evacuate.

Sorrell Bobrink, a Paradise resident who managed to drive away with her child, told BBC World Service radio she had first been woken up and alerted by a phone call from a friend. Describing the scene as "exactly like any apocalyptic movie I have ever seen," she said she had not known if she was driving towards death or out of harm's way as the sky blackened.

"I had to drive through the fire - it was awful. It was probably the most awful experience I will have in my life," she told the Newsday programme. "It was traumatising, we will be traumatised for a long time. My whole community was traumatised - I can't watch the videos anymore because I actually went through it."

Many of the victims are believed to be elderly residents or people with mobility issues who would find evacuating more difficult. Forensic experts are stepping up their search in the ruins of Paradise, but officials warn that finding the bodies could take weeks. Cadaver dogs are being brought in by local police to try and locate the dead, and two mobile army morgues will be used to help identify them.

The fire has burned more than 111,000 acres (45,000 hectares) and is nearly 25% contained, fire officials say. The separate Woolsey Fire started on Thursday near Thousand Oaks, about 40 miles (64km) north-west of central Los Angeles. It has consumed at least 85,500 acres and destroyed at least 177 buildings, officials say. It is only 10% contained. The smaller Hill Fire, nearby, has scorched 4,530 acres and is 75% contained. Luxury homes in Malibu and other beach communities are among the properties destroyed. The nearby city of Calabasas, home to well-known celebrities, remains under a mandatory evacuation order.

Historically, California's "wildfire season" started in summer and ran into early autumn, but experts have warned that the risk is now year-round. The California Public Utilities Commission is investigating what sparked the latest blazes - amid reports electrical companies may have suffered malfunctions near the sources shortly before the fires began. Low humidity, warm Santa Ana winds, and dry ground after a rain-free month have produced a prime fire-spreading environment.

The state's 40 million-strong population also helps explain the fires' deadliness. That number is almost double what it was in the 1970s, and people are living closer to at-risk forest areas. And then there is climate change. Recent years have produced record-breaking temperatures, earlier springs, and less reliable rainfall. Citing the role of a warming climate, Governor Jerry Brown declared: "This is not the new normal, this is the new abnormal."

Thousands of firefighters, some from across the US, have been brought in to help battle the blazes.

Title: Congressional Leaders Discuss Impeachment Proceedings and Mueller Report

Article:

In a series of interviews, several high-profile figures have discussed the potential for impeachment proceedings based on the findings of the Mueller report.

Senator Elizabeth Warren, a Democratic presidential candidate, stated, "I believe we have very good reason to believe that an investigation has been conducted, which has produced evidence that tells us that this president and his administration engaged in obstruction of justice. I believe Congress should take the steps towards impeachment."

Warren further argued, "If any other human being in this country had done what's documented in the Mueller report, they would be arrested and put in jail. If there is going to be any accountability, that accountability has to come from the Congress, and the tool that we are given for that accountability is the impeachment process."

When asked about the current timing of impeachment discussions, Warren responded, "No." When asked why, she stated, "I think right now, we should continue this investigation. I think Mueller should come before and testify. I don't think we should be having that conversation."

Senator Bernie Sanders, another Democratic presidential candidate, expressed a similar viewpoint, stating, "I think it would be perfectly reasonable for Congress to open up those proceedings, and it's clear that Bob Mueller, in his report, left that in the hands of Congress."

Sanders continued, "I think the American people are going to have a chance to decide this at the ballot box in November 2020, and perhaps that's the best way for us to resolve these outstanding questions."

When asked about impeachment, Senator Amy Klobuchar, also a Democratic presidential candidate, stated, "The impeachment proceedings are up to the House. They're going to have to make that decision. I am in the Senate, and I believe that we are the jury. So, if the House brings the impeachment proceedings before us, we will deal with them."

It is important to note that these statements represent the opinions of the individuals interviewed and do not necessarily reflect the official position of their respective political parties or the United States government. The impeachment process is a complex and lengthy one, and the outcome remains uncertain at this time.

Title: Police Reform Necessary to Prevent Future Riots, According to Journalist

Article:

The destruction of property during the rioting in Minneapolis has been compared to the actions of younger boys in the past, who would destroy glass to earn money for small purchases. This visceral appeal to destroy, often seen in riots, is not exclusive to any race or class, as demonstrated by the willingness of children in wealthy, white areas to destroy property given the opportunity.

The author argues that the time to stop a riot is before it happens, through prevention measures. One of the most obvious preventive measures is consistent, top-to-bottom police reform. The author criticizes the police for their failure to police themselves, citing the case of George Floyd's death at the hands of a Minneapolis police officer, Derek Chauvin, as evidence of systemic cultural rot within the police department.

The author argues that the Minneapolis police union should reconsider whether dues should be used to hire lawyers for bad cops, as the four fired officers are currently being represented by expensive lawyers. The author also questions why the community has tolerated a police department with poor relations between police and citizens of color, and why only one in every 100 citizen complaints leads to disciplinary action.

The author concludes by stating that the public must demand police reform, but it is ultimately up to the police to root out the bad cops in their midst and prevent future riots. The failure to address police misconduct and systemic cultural issues within police departments will only lead to more anarchy and violence.

Title: Sen. Dianne Feinstein Clashes with Youth Activists over Green New Deal

Article:

In a heated exchange on Friday, Sen. Dianne Feinstein (D-CA) clashed with a group of youth activists over the Green New Deal, a 10-year plan to address climate change. The confrontation took place as moderate Democrats grapple with the Green New Deal, a proposal championed by progressive members such as Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (D-NY).

During the meeting, Sen. Feinstein expressed her reservations about the Green New Deal, stating, "There's no way to pay for it." She also criticized the resolution, saying, "That resolution will not pass the Senate."

When a girl urged her to vote yes anyway, Sen. Feinstein replied, "I may do that... but it's not a good resolution."

In a statement Friday night, Sen. Feinstein said, "I always welcome the opportunity to hear from Californians who feel passionately about this issue and it remains a top priority of mine." She also mentioned that she presented the group with her draft resolution addressing climate change, which she plans to introduce soon.

The conversation grew heated, particularly when Sen. Feinstein dismissed the group's request due to their tone and youth. A young woman told Sen. Feinstein, "I'm looking at the faces of the people who will be living with these consequences" of climate change. Sen. Feinstein responded, "I've been doing this for 30 years. I know what I'm doing."

When asked about her age, a girl replied that politicians should listen to the people they represent. Sen. Feinstein, who was re-elected in 2018 with a large margin, responded, "I've gotten elected. I just ran. I was elected by almost a million-vote plurality, and I know what I'm doing."

Later in the meeting, a young woman stressed the need for a climate plan with "bold, transformative action," to which Sen. Feinstein replied, "Well, you know better than I do."

As the meeting concluded, a woman urged the children to read a letter aloud. Once most of the children exited, several women remained and calmly chatted with Sen. Feinstein. One of them expressed the importance of voting to support the deal, even though it "isn't something that's aimed at passing right now." A 16-year-old inquired about internship opportunities in Sen. Feinstein's office.

The article does not provide further details about the specifics of the Green New Deal or the draft resolution presented by Sen. Feinstein. The exchange between Sen.
