Feinstein and the youth activists highlights the ongoing debate among Democrats regarding the best approach to address climate change and the role of youth activism in shaping policy.

Title: Analysis of Speeches at the 2012 DNC: A Review of Sandra Fluke, Jim Sinegal, Elizabeth Warren, and Bill Clinton's Addresses

Article:

The second night of the 2012 Democratic National Convention (DNC) in Charlotte, North Carolina, concluded with a speech from former President Bill Clinton. The evening's speeches, prior to Clinton's address, were met with mixed reviews.

Sandra Fluke, a recent law graduate, delivered a speech that focused on birth control and abortion. Her speech was criticized for its surly and self-pitying tone, as well as her demand for the federal government to compel Catholic schools to pay for her birth control. Fluke's speech was deemed unseemly and crass by some, with comparisons to her 15 minutes of fame.

Jim Sinegal, the former CEO of Costco, spoke about the benefits of Democratic policies for businesses. His speech was considered dull and unmemorable, with no meaningful analysis to offer.

Elizabeth Warren, a Harvard Law professor, led the class warfare fight, emphasizing the rigged system and the need for increased government investment in various sectors. Her delivery was slightly improved, and she remembered to smile, but her message was still characteristic and reprehensible.

Bill Clinton delivered the most effective sales pitch for a "four more years" of the Obama administration, according to some. Clinton's speech focused on the challenges Obama faced upon taking office, his accomplishments, and the need for more time to continue improving the economy. Clinton's speech was considered compelling, but some criticized him for straying from the script and overstaying his welcome.

The media has been eager to move past the floor debacle of the DNC, with some suggesting that Clinton's performance salvaged the lackluster 10pm hour and session. Clinton's star power and strong endorsement certainly helped Obama, but the rest of the night was met with less enthusiasm.

Title: FBI Investigation of Hillary Clinton's Email Practices May Lead to Indictment for Espionage

Article:

The ongoing investigation by the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) into Hillary Clinton's email practices during her tenure as Secretary of State has raised concerns about her handling of state secrets. The FBI's discovery of a Special Access Program (SAP) email on Clinton's private server, as well as the alleged cutting and pasting of state secrets onto her server and BlackBerry, could potentially lead to an indictment for espionage.

The FBI is currently investigating two broad categories of Clinton's legal woes: her failure to safeguard state secrets and her potential use of her position to financially benefit her husband's charitable foundation. The following details the state secrets aspect of the investigation.

An SAP-denominated email, the most sensitive category of state secrets, was found on Clinton's private server. SAP emails are so sensitive that they cannot be received or opened accidentally. Clinton, who received all her governmental emails through her husband's server, could only have received or viewed the SAP email after inputting certain codes.

The presence of the SAP-denominated email on her private server, whether opened or not, indicates a criminal indifference to her legal obligation to maintain the safety of all state secrets entrusted to her care. Clinton's suggested digital ineptitude, which she has used as a potential defense, is not a valid argument in this sensitive area of the law.

Failure to safeguard state secrets is a crime that does not require proof of intent. Plausible deniability, an attempted defense, is not available in this case, as it constitutes an admission of negligence and, therefore, an admission of guilt, not a denial.

Clinton signed an oath under penalty of perjury on Jan. 22, 2009, acknowledging that she had received a full FBI briefing on the lawful care and keeping of state secrets. Her briefing and oath specified that the obligation to safeguard state secrets is absolute and that negligence can lead to prosecution.

Typical data protected by the SAP denomination includes the names of moles (spies working for multiple governments), their American handlers, the existence of black ops (illegal programs the U.S. government carries out), codes needed to access state secrets, and ongoing intelligence-gathering projects.

The crime occurs when SAPs are exposed by residing in a nonsecure venue; it does not matter for prosecution purposes whether they fall into the wrong hands. Clinton's persistent mocking of the seriousness of these issues is seen as the moral equivalent of taunting alligators before crossing a stream.

Shortly after the presence of the SAP-denominated email was made known, the State Department released another email Clinton failed to erase, wherein she instructed her subordinates to take state secrets from a secure venue, cut and paste and summarize them, and send them to her on her nonsecure venue. Such an endeavor, if carried out, is a felony—masking and then not safeguarding state secrets.

Furthermore, a little-known 2013 speech by one of Clinton's former subordinates recently surfaced, revealing that Clinton and her staff regularly engaged in digital conversations about state secrets on their BlackBerries. This is not criminal if the BlackBerries were government-issued and secured. Clinton's was neither.

The article concludes by questioning the state of the rule of law in America, as the FBI's investigation and potential indictment of Clinton will soon reveal the answer.

Title: Romney Kicks Off Six-State Bus Tour in Pennsylvania, Responds to Obama's Immigration Announcement

Article:

Mitt Romney, the Republican presidential candidate, embarked on a six-state bus tour on Saturday, focusing on connecting with undecided voters in battleground states. The tour, which began in New Hampshire on Friday, includes stops in Pennsylvania, Ohio, Wisconsin, Michigan, and Iowa.

In Pennsylvania, Romney visited the Weatherly Casting and Machine Company to deliver a message emphasizing his commitment to creating jobs and restoring the American Dream. He highlighted a local entrepreneur who started a business with a second mortgage and now employs about 110 people.

"Let's put America back to work again with those kinds of dreams," Romney said. "I'm optimistic about the future."

The second stop in Pennsylvania, at an Agway convenience store in Quakertown, was relocated due to a counter rally organized by former Democratic Governor Ed Rendell. Romney's response to the change was that his surrogate, Rendell, had stated they could win Pennsylvania, and they were happy to be there.

The tour's final stop in Pennsylvania will be an old iron furnace in Cornwall, now a national historic landmark.

During the tour, Romney was compelled to address President Obama's announcement to suspend deportation for hundreds of thousands of young, illegal immigrants. He stated that an executive order makes reaching a long-term solution more difficult but, if elected, his administration would strive to find a long-term solution.

Romney's response to the immigration issue was softer than his stance during the GOP primary campaign, where he called the DREAM Act a "handout" and vowed to veto it if elected president.

The bus tour, which involves flying to the next state each night and traveling from town to town during the day, is Romney's first traditional campaign. He is joined by former Minnesota Governor Tim Pawlenty and will be joined by Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker when the tour reaches Wisconsin, both of whom are considered potential vice presidential candidates.

No Republican has won Pennsylvania since 1988. In 2008, Republican nominee John McCain won two of the counties Romney plans to visit. The last time Romney was in Pennsylvania, he was campaigning with Senator Marco Rubio (R-FL) and discussing the Cuban-American's ideas for legislation that would allow some illegal immigrants to stay in the country to work.

Romney faces pressure to appeal to Hispanic voters, who are crucial in battleground states like Nevada and Colorado, but risks alienating his conservative base if he abandons his previously tough stances.

Title: Walmart Enters Healthcare Market with Transparent Pricing Model

Article:

Retail giant Walmart has ventured into the healthcare market with the opening of its first in-store clinic, Walmart Health, in Dallas, Georgia. The new facility offers primary medical, dental, vision, and mental health care services. While Walmart has not announced plans for a national rollout, the Georgia clinic appears to be a pilot for a new approach to providing basic healthcare to Americans.

One of the notable aspects of the Walmart Health clinic is the transparent pricing model. The company has published a pricing list, detailing costs for services such as basic check-ups ($30, or $20 for children), flu tests ($20), and routine vision exams ($40). The clinic will be staffed by medical professionals capable of handling a range of healthcare services, from immunizations to counseling sessions, lab testing, and X-rays.

Walmart, which is already one of the country's largest pharmacies, has previously offered basic healthcare services in 19 stores through smaller clinics. These clinics average about 1,500 square feet, while the new Walmart Health location in Georgia spans over 10,000 square feet, according to Forbes.

The move is another example of private-sector innovation in healthcare, with CVS and Walgreens also offering small-scale clinics in some retail locations. Both companies plan to expand these services in the coming years. If Walmart enters the healthcare provider market, it could increase competition and convenience.

Elise Amez-Droz, a health care policy associate at the Mercatus Center, a think tank based at George Mason University, commented, "Walmart Health is proof that the private sector can deliver high-quality, transparently priced health care services without government intervention. The best way to cater to our varying needs is to let patients have the final say in their health care decisions, shopping for better value, and reaping the benefits in the form of better care and savings."

Access to care is an often overlooked aspect of the national healthcare debate, which primarily focuses on providing insurance rather than healthcare itself. While insurance is crucial, it is ineffective if there are no providers nearby. The new Walmart Health clinics could help address this issue, as approximately 90% of the U.S. population lives within 10 miles of a Walmart store.

The pricing model Walmart is implementing could disrupt conventional healthcare pricing. Although the retail chain will accept most major insurance plans, as it does in its pharmacies and existing, smaller clinics, the low, transparent prices will enable many customers to pay out-of-pocket for basic care. This could potentially reduce the opacity in healthcare prices, which is largely due to third parties, such as insurance companies, serving as intermediaries between consumers and providers. This lack of transparency encourages the inflation of healthcare costs and overconsumption of healthcare services.

A single Walmart health clinic in the Atlanta suburbs will not resolve the major issues in the American healthcare system. However, the innovative approach and potential cost savings offered by Walmart Health could lead to improvements in the future.

Title: Sessions to Testify Before Senate Intelligence Committee Amidst Ongoing Controversy

Article:

Former Republican Senator Jeff Sessions will testify before the Senate Intelligence Committee on Tuesday, setting up another media frenzy at the Capitol Hill just days after James Comey's explosive testimony. Comey's remarks last week, including potential discussions about a third meeting between Sessions and a top Russian official, are threatening to further entangle the Attorney General in the controversy surrounding potential contacts between the Trump campaign and Moscow.

Ahead of Sessions' testimony, the White House has sent mixed signals about the level of cooperation Sessions will offer lawmakers. White House counselor Kellyanne Conway stated that Sessions is willing to cooperate and share what he knows, while press secretary Sean Spicer declined to rule out Sessions invoking executive privilege during his testimony, stating, "I think it depends on the scope of the questions."

The controversy stems from Comey's claims during a closed-door meeting with the Senate Intelligence Committee that Sessions may have had an undisclosed third meeting with Russian Ambassador Sergey Kislyak. If a third meeting took place, it would contradict Sessions' previous assertion that he only met twice with the Russian official during the presidential campaign.

Sessions wrote in a letter to the Senate Judiciary Committee, "I do not recall any discussions with the Russian ambassador, or any other representative of the Russian government, regarding the political campaign on these occasions or any other occasions."

The Justice Department has denied that the two talked, stating, "The then-senator did not have any private or side conversations with any Russian officials at the Mayflower Hotel."

Sessions will also face questions over when he decided to recuse himself from the investigation into Russian election meddling, which includes a review of potential ties between the Trump campaign and Moscow to influence the race's outcome. Comey told lawmakers that the FBI expected Sessions to step back from the investigation even before his recusal on March 2.

Sessions' decision to recuse himself from the probe reportedly strained his relationship with President Trump, and senators will likely ask Sessions about reports that he offered to resign. Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein told lawmakers during a closed-door meeting that he first learned Trump planned to fire Comey during a May 8 meeting with Sessions and the president.

Sessions and Rosenstein also discussed replacing Comey during a meeting last year, months before Comey was fired. "In one of my first meetings with then-Senator Jeff Sessions last winter, we discussed the need for new leadership at the FBI," Rosenstein told lawmakers, according to his released remarks.

Democrats argue Sessions would have violated his pledge to recuse himself from the Russia probe if he was involved in Comey's firing. They are expected to ask the attorney general if he knew the president wanted to fire Comey, in part because of the Russia investigation, as Trump has stated publicly.

Sessions' testimony will provide insight into the ongoing investigation and the role he played in the events that have transpired since the 2016 presidential campaign. The testimony will be closely watched by both parties, as Sessions' credibility and involvement in the Russia probe remain under scrutiny.

Title: Obama Addresses 2016 Election and Political Polarization at Joint Press Conference with Justin Trudeau

Article:

In a joint press conference with Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau at the White House on Thursday, President Barack Obama made extended comments regarding the 2016 election and the unprecedented political polarization.

"I have been blamed by the Republicans for a lot of things," the president said. "But to be blamed for their primaries and who they are selecting is... novel."

He further stated, "I’m not going to validate some notion that the Republican crackup that’s been taking place is a consequence of actions that I’ve taken."

The president also addressed the accusations that his administration has contributed to the rise of a provocative candidate like Donald Trump. "It's not as if there's a massive difference between Mr. Trump's position on immigration and Mr. Cruz's," he said. "Mr. Trump may be more provocative in terms of how he sighs, but they're not that different."

When asked about his critics pointing to the polarized political climate as under his administration as contributing to the rise of such a candidate, President Obama responded, "I have been blamed by the Republicans for a lot of things, but to be blamed for their primaries and who they are selecting, that is taking place in their primary is... novel."

He also expressed regret over the degree to which polarization and the nasty tone of politics have accelerated over the course of his seven and a half years in office. He acknowledged that Republican political elites, information outlets, social media, television stations, and talk radio have been feeding the Republican base for the last seven years, a notion that everything he does is to be opposed.

President Obama also clarified that he does not feel any responsibility for the protectionist rhetoric from some Democratic candidates. He did not provide a timeline for when he may make a presidential endorsement.

Title: Acting Attorney General Matthew Whitaker and Chairman Jerrold Nadler Engage in Contentious Exchange During House Hearing

Article:

In a tense and contentious House hearing on Friday, Acting Attorney General Matthew Whitaker and Democratic Chairman Jerrold Nadler of New York exchanged sharp words, with Whitaker attempting to call time on Nadler after a series of questions regarding Special Counsel Robert Mueller's Russia probe.

The heated exchange occurred after Nadler expressed his desire for Whitaker to appear for a private deposition following the hearing and asked Whitaker whether he had been "asked to approve any requests or action" for the special counsel.

Whitaker, who was met with gasps from the onlookers, responded, "Mr. Chairman, I see that your five minutes is up, so... I am here voluntarily. We have agreed to five-minute rounds."

Nadler, who momentarily smiled at the response, repeated his question, and Whitaker ultimately responded, "I have not interfered in any way with the special counsel's investigation."

The hearing, which was marked by bickering among Whitaker and Democratic lawmakers, as well as among members of the committee, over whether Whitaker was properly answering questions, saw Whitaker tussle with Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee of Texas when she pressed on whether he had appeared before the committee for an oversight hearing.

While the answer, eventually, was that he had not, the congresswoman objected when Whitaker would not answer with a "yes or no." When she asked the chairman if her time had been restored, Whitaker responded, "I don't know whether your time's been restored or not."

"Mr. Attorney General, we're not joking here, and your humor is not acceptable," the congresswoman responded.

The fiery back and forth follows a dramatic political prelude to the hearing itself, complete with threats by Nadler to subpoena the witness and threats by the DOJ to boycott. Democrats are acutely focused on Whitaker's oversight of the Mueller probe, in his acting AG status while awaiting confirmation of President Trump's attorney general pick William Barr.

"There has been no change in the overall management of the special counsel investigation," Whitaker testified Friday, saying that he never offered any "promises or commitments" regarding the Mueller or any other investigation.

Nadler pressed Whitaker over whether he had shared information about the investigation with Trump, or any White House officials.

"I do not intend today to talk about my private conversations, but to answer your question, I did not talk to the president about the status of the investigation," Whitaker answered. "Consistent with what I've already said, I have not talked about the special counsel's investigation with any White House officials."

Whitaker did not directly answer several of Nadler's other questions, resulting in the chairman requesting that the acting attorney general return to the committee at a later date.

"I've given you a fair opportunity so that we could avoid this fight in the first place, but you don't appear to have done any of that," Nadler said, referring to Whitaker's preparations, while saying, "I do not believe issuing a subpoena here would correct the problem." Nadler explained that the committee would "attempt to reach an accommodation with the department to receive answers," so Whitaker can return for "deposition before the committee, under oath."

Nadler said that, at that point, he expects "clean answers or proper assertion of privilege claimed by the president."

Meanwhile, the top Republican on the committee blasted the hearing as a "dog and pony show."

"This hearing is a character assassination on Acting Attorney General Whitaker, all pure political theater, to go after the president," Ranking Member Doug Collins, R-Ga, said in his opening statement while urging the committee to adjourn.

A vote was then taken on whether to abruptly end the hearing. The measure did not pass, and the hearing began as scheduled.

The hearing follows an intense back and forth between the Justice Department and the Judiciary Committee a day earlier. The Judiciary Committee voted Thursday to give Nadler the authority to issue a subpoena if necessary, despite Whitaker having already agreed to appear before the panel voluntarily.

Nadler made clear early Thursday that he did not want to have to subpoena Whitaker, but said a "series of troubling events" suggested it would be better for him to be prepared with that authority, just in case he decided not to show up for the hearing.

But Whitaker then warned he would not show up unless lawmakers dropped the threat.

MUELLER DEPUTY BRIEFED ON ANTI-TRUMP DOSSIER RESEARCH MONTHS BEFORE 2016 ELECTION: TESTIMONY

The hearing Friday comes as the Senate is close to confirming Trump's nominee for attorney general. The Senate Judiciary Committee on Thursday voted, along party lines, to advance Barr's nomination to the full Senate for confirmation.

The president fired his first attorney general, Jeff Sessions, the day after the 2018 midterm elections. Prior to Whitaker's appointment as acting attorney general, Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein oversaw the Russia investigation.

Nadler and other Democrats have criticized Whitaker for not recusing himself from the Mueller probe, as Sessions did due to his involvement with the Trump campaign in 2016, as Whitaker had made public comments criticizing the investigation.

The hearing is the committee's first major oversight hearing looking at the Justice Department of this Congress. Whitaker told reporters last week that Mueller's probe was "close to being completed," the first official sign that the investigation may be nearing an end. His comments, though, were a departure for the Justice Department, which rarely comments on the status of investigations. Whitaker, though, said he had been "fully briefed" on the probe.

Title: Supreme Court Upholds Bladensburg Peace Cross, Citing Community Devotion and Historical Significance

Article:

In a 7-2 ruling on Thursday, the Supreme Court of the United States upheld the Bladensburg Peace Cross, a 40-foot Latin cross that stands on public park land in Maryland. The court determined that the cross, which has been a war memorial and an expression of community grief for soldiers lost in World War I, does not violate the First Amendment's Establishment Clause.

The Bladensburg Cross, erected by the American Legion, has been a symbol of religious freedom controversy, with both sides of the church-state divide questioning the justices' decision. In the case American Legion v. American Humanist Association, the court ruled that the cross passes constitutional muster, and removing it would show unconstitutional "hostility" towards religion.

Justice Samuel A. Alito, who wrote the key opinion, stated that the Religion Clauses of the Constitution aim to foster a harmonious society where people of all beliefs can coexist. He argued that the presence of the Bladensburg Cross on the land where it has stood for nearly a century is consistent with that aim.

The cross was designed to mirror the crosses that stood on the graves of the troops who died during the Great War, and the names of 49 soldiers are engraved at the base of the cross. The 1961 acquisition of the land where the cross stands by the Maryland-National Capital Park and Planning Commission created the church-state clash that the cross' opponents raised with the Supreme Court.

Justice Stephen G. Breyer, who agreed with the main ruling, stated that the case would have been different if there was evidence that the American Legion erected the cross to disparage or disrespect people of faiths other than Christianity. However, he noted that there was no such evidence.

The ruling overturns the decision by the 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, which rejected the cross in a 2-1 decision. The court's decision is a significant victory for religious liberty advocates, who view it as a landmark ruling that ends the "weaponizing" of the Establishment Clause to attack religious symbols in public.

However, the ruling leaves hundreds of other religion-themed memorials across the country to be fought over one by one, as the justices were unable to come to any consensus about how to approach them. The court's decision also marks the latest blow to the "Lemon test," the Supreme Court's 1971 framework for deciding religion-state entanglements.

Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, joined by Justice Sonia Sotomayor, dissented, stating that the Peace Cross is impossible to view as anything other than the chief symbol of Christianity and leaving it on public land "elevates" that religion above all others. She suggested moving the cross to another location to solve the religious entanglement.

The American Humanist Association, which lost the case, took solace in the court's limited ruling, stating that it feared the justices would overturn the Lemon test and pave the way for even broader religious displays by government. The park commission that owns the land said it was "gratified" to have prevailed, stating that the cross is an important reminder of honor, bravery, and sacrifice.

Title: Study Reveals Tendency of Significant Supreme Court Cases to Land at the End of the Term

Article:

A new study published in The Duke Law Journal has found that the Supreme Court of the United States tends to decide significant cases towards the end of its term, particularly in June. The study, which considered 7,219 cases from 1946 to 2013, aimed to provide empirical evidence for a phenomenon that is widely observed but difficult to prove.

The study, led by Professor Lee Epstein of Washington University in St. Louis, used several measures to define and identify significant cases. These measures included front-page coverage in The New York Times, the number of friend-of-the-court briefs filed, and the frequency of the decision's citation in later Supreme Court opinions.

The results of the study confirmed that significant decisions were disproportionately likely to be handed down in late June. More than 30% of the court's decisions are issued in June, and more than half of those decisions are made in the last week of the month.

Geoffrey R. Stone, a law professor at the University of Chicago who served as a clerk to Justice William J. Brennan Jr., stated, "I can't think of an instance, certainly during my term, that the court sat on an opinion when it was done." Deanne E. Maynard, a lawyer with Morrison & Foerster who served as a law clerk to Justices Lewis F. Powell Jr. and Stephen G. Breyer, echoed this sentiment, stating, "The court uses as much time as they have to decide the really important cases."

The study's findings suggest that the end-of-term crunch for big cases may be due to human nature, as the court attempts to decide the most important cases before the summer recess. However, the study's authors acknowledge that the question of whether big cases are disproportionately likely to come late requires an objective definition of significance, which can be challenging to establish.

Title: Trump Threatens Iran with Severe Consequences in Late-Night Tweet

Article:

In a late-night tweet on Sunday, President Donald Trump issued a warning to Iran, stating, "Iran must never, ever threaten the United States again." The tweet, sent at 11:24 p.m. Eastern Time, came in response to Iranian President Hassan Rouhani's remarks suggesting that "war with Iran is the mother of all wars."

The tweet, written in all capital letters, continued, "WE ARE NO LONGER A COUNTRY THAT WILL STAND FOR YOUR DEMENTED WORDS OF VIOLENCE & DEATH. BE CAUTIOUS!" The message was directed at Rouhani.

On Monday, White House Press Secretary Sarah Sanders defended the president's tweet, stating that Trump was not inciting a confrontation and that Iran was the one "inciting anything." National Security Advisor John Bolton also supported Trump's statement, saying, "President Trump told me that if Iran does anything at all to the negative, they will pay a price like few countries have ever paid before."

Iranian government officials responded cautiously to Trump's tweet. Gholamhossein Gharibpour, the head of the voluntary Basij paramilitary force, described Trump's words as "psychological warfare." Foaz Izadi, a prominent commentator close to the establishment, suggested that Trump's tweet was aimed at addressing his domestic base in the U.S.

Tensions between the U.S. and Iran have escalated since Trump withdrew the U.S. from the Iran nuclear deal earlier this year. The move unraveled a signature foreign policy achievement of the Obama administration and threatened to destabilize Iran's denuclearization program.

In his remarks, Rouhani warned Trump, saying, "Mr. Trump, don't play with the lion's tail, this would only lead to regret." He also stated, "America should know that peace with Iran is the mother of all peace, and war with Iran is the mother of all wars."

U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo also criticized Iran in a speech at the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library and Museum in California. He accused Iran's political, judicial, and military leaders of widespread corruption and human rights abuses. Pompeo also accused several Iranian leaders, including Ayatollahs, of participating in illicit trading and amassing vast wealth.

The U.S. is preparing to reimpose economic sanctions on Tehran, with the first sanctions expected to hit on August 4. The Trump administration has stated that it aims to cut off funds to Iran, focusing on reimposing sanctions on its banking and energy sectors.

Title: Millennial Incomes Stagnant in Four Major Employment Sectors, According to Young Invincibles Report

Article:

A report by the advocacy group Young Invincibles, using Census data, reveals that salaries for young adults have decreased in four of the top five biggest employment sectors for individuals aged 25 to 34. The sectors experiencing a decline include retail (down 9.9 percent), leisure and hospitality (down 14.65 percent), manufacturing (down 2.87 percent), and professional and business services (down 4.28 percent). The only exception is the health care industry, which has seen essentially stagnant yearly pay (up just 0.10 percent).

The report's authors note that the group is measuring annual, not hourly, pay, making it difficult to interpret the statistics with depth. They did not know whether young adult incomes were falling because workers were making less per hour or because they were working fewer hours in total. The authors suggest that the decrease in income is more likely due to the latter, given the post-recession rise of joblessness and part-time employment.

In comparison to the median young adult income of $30,759, which is its lowest in inflation-adjusted terms since 1995, the income levels of millennials are similar to those of Generation X. However, millennials are shouldering more debt due to student loans compared to previous generations.

The report also analyzed wages from 18-to-24-year-olds, but it seems pointless to look at wages of the prime college-age demographic without distinguishing between full- and part-time workers. The report's findings suggest that millennials are not exceptionally poorly paid compared to young adults who came before them, but they are stretching the same wages to pay off a bigger heap of loans.

Title: U.S. on Alert for Potential North Korean Missile Launch, Threatening Denuclearization Negotiations

Article:

U.S. officials are on high alert for signs of a possible missile launch from North Korea in the coming days, which officials have referred to as a "Christmas gift." A significant launch or nuclear test would mark a breach of North Korea's self-imposed moratorium on missile launches and tests, and it would pose a significant challenge to President Trump's foreign policy goal of getting North Korea back to the negotiating table to eliminate its nuclear weapons.

Earlier this month, the North conducted what U.S. officials say was an engine test, which experts believe may have involved an engine for a long-range missile. Anthony Wier, a former State Department official who tracks nuclear disarmament for the Friends Committee on National Legislation, stated, "North Korea has been advancing. It has been building new capabilities. As long as that continues, they gain new capabilities to try new missiles to threaten us and our allies in new ways."

North Korea warned of a possible "Christmas gift" in early December, stating that the Trump administration was running out of time on nuclear negotiations, and it was up to the U.S. to choose what "Christmas gift" it gets from Pyongyang.

Victor Cha, a Korea expert at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, said a review of the possible launch sites in North Korea shows they are "basically ready to go." Defense Secretary Mark Esper told reporters earlier this week that the U.S. has heard all the talk of a possible upcoming test around Christmas.

Army Gen. Mark Milley, the chairman of the U.S. Joint Chiefs of Staff, told reporters on Friday that the U.S., Japan, and South Korea are ready to defend against any move by the North. "We always maintain very high levels of readiness," he said.

At a meeting in Singapore in June 2018, Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un issued a joint statement that the North "commits to work toward complete denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula." However, negotiations stalled in February after the U.S. rejected North Korea's demands for broad sanctions relief in exchange for a partial surrender of the North's nuclear capabilities.

According to the U.S. military, North Korea has launched more than 20 missiles this year, including new types of missiles and a submarine-launched ballistic missile, in violation of U.N. Security Council resolutions. In 2017, North Korea conducted a torrent of missile tests, including flying two intermediate-range missiles over Japan and threatening to fire those weapons toward the U.S. territory of Guam. It also tested three developmental ICBMs, including the Hwasong-15 that demonstrated the potential range to reach deep into the U.S. mainland.

However, those ICBM tests showed no clear sign the North had perfected the technology needed to ensure a warhead could survive atmospheric re-entry. Experts said North Korea needed additional flight tests to determine the reliability and accuracy of its ICBMs and establish a capable re-entry protection system.

James Carafano, a senior fellow at the Heritage Foundation, stated, "The U.S. and North Korea have a chance to break the logjam." Defense Secretary Esper, who has visited Korea twice this year since being sworn in as defense chief, said the U.S. now has a team on the Korean peninsula that has asked the North for meetings. At the same time, he said the U.S. military remains at a high level of readiness.

A key discussion point has been the reduction in U.S. military exercises with South Korea, a move by the Trump administration to appease North Korea and woo them to the negotiating table for denuclearization talks. The U.S. has about 28,000 troops in South Korea.

Title: China Imposes Tariffs on US Imports, Including Pork and Wine, in Response to US Steel and Aluminum Tariffs

Article:

China has implemented tariffs of up to 25% on 128 US imports, such as pork and wine, following US President Donald Trump's imposition of duties on foreign steel and aluminum imports in March. The tariffs, affecting approximately $3 billion (£2.1 billion) of imports, took effect on Monday.

Beijing stated that the move was to safeguard China's interests and counterbalance losses caused by new US tariffs. China had previously expressed that it did not want a trade war but would not stand idly by if its economy was affected. Mr. Trump, however, has maintained that "trade wars are good" and that the US should "easily" win one.

The US authorities have already announced plans for further targeted tariffs on tens of billions of dollars of Chinese imports, reportedly in response to unfair trading practices in China that affect US companies. This development, however, raises the possibility of further action in what has become a tit-for-tat trade battle.

The initial trigger for this trade dispute was China's alleged theft of foreign intellectual property. According to Washington, if international companies wish to operate in China, they must surrender their intellectual property, thereby transferring technology, such as German high-speed rail technology, to Chinese engineers.

With China's retaliatory tariffs now in place, there are concerns that launching a potential tariff war may not be the solution to the problem. Some argue that China has been getting away with this practice for years, and tough measures were necessary to force change. Others, however, express worry that a trade war is not the way to address the issue.

The overall imbalance in US-China trade, with a large Chinese surplus, means China is potentially more exposed during a trade war than the US. For this reason, Beijing will likely seek a way out of this escalating tariff standoff.

China's initial tariffs are relatively mild but are in response to the first round of US tariffs, with a second round already announced. There are many more American companies to be affected, and other nations, particularly those in Europe and Asia, could soon find themselves involved in this conflict.

US scrap aluminum and frozen pork will be subject to a 25% additional tariff, in addition to existing duties. Several other American foods, including nuts, fresh and dried fruit, ginseng, and wine, will be hit by a 15% increase. Rolled steel bars will also see a 15% rise in duties.

China described the new tariffs as a retaliatory measure in response to Mr. Trump's decision to raise duties on steel and aluminum imports. On March 22, the US announced plans to impose duties on up to $60 billion of Chinese imports and limit its investment in the US, in retaliation for years of alleged intellectual property theft. The White House stated it was acting to counter unfair competition from China's state-led economy.

It remains to be seen if China will follow its opening gambit with stronger measures. In theory, Beijing could tax US tech companies like Apple, for example. Such a move could force US tech giants to raise their prices to compensate.

Title: Former President Obama Calls for Calm in Ferguson, Missouri, After Shooting Incident

Article:

Former U.S. President Barack Obama has urged calm in Ferguson, Missouri, following the shooting of a black teenager by police that has led to two nights of unrest. In a statement, Obama described the death of Michael Brown as heartbreaking and called for reflection and understanding.

Over the past two nights, dozens of arrests were made, shops were looted, and tear gas was used by police in the St. Louis suburb. However, on Tuesday night, anger turned to reflection at a community forum. Missouri Governor Jay Nixon, speaking at a packed crowd at Christ the King United Church of Christ, described the shooting as reopening an old wound.

Ferguson's mayor and police chief attended the meeting and were greeted with applause. Earlier, the Reverend Al Sharpton, a civil rights activist, appealed for peace, stating that becoming violent in Michael Brown's name betrays the gentle giant he was. Sharpton was flanked by Brown's parents during his address.

Police have stated that Brown was shot several times after a struggle in a police car, but witnesses have reported that the unarmed Brown was shot while he had his arms raised. The identity of the officer who shot and killed Brown remains undisclosed due to death threats on social media, according to police.

Protests during the day on Tuesday were peaceful but tense, but they followed a night of unrest where police used tear gas and rubber bullets to disperse a large crowd in Ferguson the night before. Thirty-two people were arrested on Sunday night after people looted shops, vandalized cars and stores, and set a building alight.

The FBI is investigating the shooting, and U.S. Attorney General Eric Holder has stated that the case deserves a "fulsome review." The justice department has also sent its community relations team to the area.

Title: The Origins and Evolution of Labor Day: A Historical Perspective

Article:

Labor Day, celebrated on the first Monday in September, is a unique American holiday, distinct from other national holidays in both its origins and its cultural significance. Unlike holidays such as Washington's Birthday (now known as Presidents Day), Independence Day, Thanksgiving, and Memorial Day, Labor Day did not become a national holiday until 1895.

One of the most notable aspects of Labor Day is its transformation into a symbolic end of summer and the beginning of fall. Prior to the 1890s, summer would end when the weather changed, sometimes as late as mid-October or early November. However, most warm-weather institutions, such as community swimming pools, now conclude their season on Labor Day, regardless of whether the best summer weather still lies ahead. The day after Labor Day also used to mark the first day of the school year, but many states now open their school doors in August.

The primary advocate for Labor Day was Peter J. McGuire, a figure not widely recognized outside of historians' homes. McGuire, the son of Irish immigrants, made his mark as a carpenter and became a leading force behind the trade's unionization. On August 8, 1881, 36 delegates representing carpenters in 11 states came together to form the United Brotherhood of Carpenters, with McGuire serving as the principal administrator. The organization grew from a few members to 70,000 strong by the end of the century.

McGuire proposed a special day for all workers to advance the cause of unionism, aiming to break up the long holiday-barren period from July 4 to Thanksgiving. The day would provide workers with leisure time and offer unions the opportunity to increase their numbers and visibility through parades and demonstrations. McGuire's idea was supported by the UBC, which organized the first Labor Day in New York City on September 5, 1882.

The establishment of a national Labor Day was initially slow to materialize. Oregon made Labor Day the first Saturday in June in 1887, while cities such as Baltimore, Boston, Philadelphia, Pittsburgh, Chicago, Detroit, Cincinnati, and Kansas City celebrated their first Labor Days in 1889. Southern cities were conspicuous non-celebrators. It was clear that only a national holiday would serve the interests of McGuire and his followers.

An unexpected economic collapse in 1893, leading to a bitter railway strike in Pullman, Illinois, accelerated the push for a national Labor Day. In Pullman, the head of the Pullman Palace Car Company had built a model town for his employees in 1880. When the economic downturn occurred, wages were cut, but rents remained constant. After lengthy negotiations, the workers, assisted by the American Railway Union and its leader, Eugene V. Debs, went on strike in May 1894. A month later, the union initiated a boycott of Pullman cars on all American trains. The railroads retaliated by firing union members, and the strike spread to trains across 27 states. The federal government eventually dispatched troops, and Debs was convicted of violating an injunction issued by the attorney general, serving six months in jail in 1895.

With the Pullman strike and public concerns about additional labor strife, legislation establishing a national Labor Day was rushed through both houses of Congress and signed by President Grover Cleveland in 1894. The immediate beneficiaries were the large number of workers who preferred a day off to the principle of unionism.

In another twist, neither McGuire nor Debs would become rallying leaders for workers on subsequent Labor Days. McGuire's ideas for a loose federation of unions within the United Brotherhood of Carpenters clashed with the rank and file, and in 1901, he was ousted on what was generally thought to be trumped-up charges of embezzling union funds. Debs, a Socialist Party candidate for president in five elections, spent additional time in jail for having violated the Espionage Act during World War I.

Finally, union leaders in the years after the first national Labor Day were unsuccessful in making the holiday their special day. For it was "labor" day, not a "union" day, the monopoly of no single group. The farmer labored, as did the merchant, physician, lawyer, and clerk. There would always be far more of these sorts than there would be workers carrying union cards.

Title: President Trump Expresses Dissatisfaction with Media Coverage Ahead of 100-Day Mark

Article:

President Donald Trump, in a Friday morning tweet, expressed his dissatisfaction with the national media's coverage of his administration's accomplishments, stating, "No matter how much I accomplish during the ridiculous standard of the first 100 days, & it has been a lot (including S.C.), media will kill!"

The White House's apparent preparation for media scrutiny as the 100-day benchmark approaches was not explicitly clear. The first 100 days of a first-term president is often used to measure success and set a roadmap for future policy issues. This practice dates back to President Franklin D. Roosevelt, who signed 76 pieces of legislation, including 15 major overhauls and new programs, during the depths of the Great Depression in 1933.

White House spokesman Sean Spicer stated, "It's very clear that he's committed to the conservative principles and agenda that he outlined in the campaign." Since then, the first 100 days has been a test of a new president's productivity, though none have come close to matching FDR's achievements.

During his campaign, President Trump had promised significant changes in his first 100 days, including cracking down on illegal immigration, a complete tax overhaul, and the repeal and replace of the Affordable Care Act (ObamaCare). In an October 2016 rally, he stated, "You're going to have such great healthcare at a tiny fraction of the cost and it's going to be so easy."

Regarding his "big beautiful wall" with Mexico, Trump stated in 2015, "So simple. So simple." However, expectations were high given Trump's promises and the fact he had a Republican-led Congress, but so far, the two branches have not always been on the same page.

On Wednesday, White House Press Secretary Sean Spicer defended the Trump administration's accomplishments in the first 90 days. Spicer told ███' "The First 100 Days," "It's very clear that he's committed to the conservative principles and agenda that he outlined in the campaign." The specifics of these accomplishments were not detailed in the provided text.

Title: Shooting at YouTube Headquarters: Suspect's Father Claims Daughter's Discontent with YouTube's Monetization Policies

Article:

The suspect identified by police as Nasim Aghdam, 39, of Southern California, who shot three people at YouTube headquarters in San Bruno, California before taking her own life, was reportedly displeased with the company due to its alleged unfair treatment and censorship of her content, according to her father, Ismail Aghdam.

Ismail Aghdam stated that he reported his daughter missing on Monday after she did not respond to phone calls for two days. He claimed that the family received a call from Mountain View police around 2 a.m. Tuesday, informing them that they had found Nasim sleeping in a car. He warned the police that she might be headed to YouTube due to her dislike for the company.

Mountain View Police spokeswoman Katie Nelson confirmed that officers located a woman by the same name asleep in a Mountain View parking lot Tuesday morning. However, Nelson did not respond to a question about whether police were warned Aghdam might go to YouTube.

Nasim Aghdam reportedly maintained a personal website alleging that YouTube compensated her unfairly and censored her views. Authorities are still investigating Aghdam's motive, and there are no indications she knew the victims.

In online postings last month, Aghdam alleged that YouTube tries to "censor and suppress people who speak the truth." She also claimed, "YouTube stopped everything, and now she has no income."

A website reportedly belonging to Aghdam contains several screenshots purportedly showing Aghdam's YouTube user account page. The screenshots suggest that at least one of Aghdam's YouTube accounts had been "de-monetized," meaning that she was not earning significant revenue from her uploads to the site.

The company "de-monetizes" some channels for reasons including inappropriate material or having fewer than 1,000 subscribers. Text superimposed on one of the screenshots reads, "My Revenue for 300,000 Views Is $ 0.10?????"

The website also espouses veganism, and includes videos apparently showing animals being skinned and cooked alive. Aghdam's YouTube videos had been removed from the site by Tuesday evening for violating the company's terms of service. Her personal website remained online.

Ismail Aghdam told NBC that YouTube "stopped everything, and now she has no income."

The shooting spree left YouTube employees terrified, huddled inside, calling 911, as officers and federal agents swarmed the company's suburban campus sandwiched between two interstates just south of San Francisco.

YouTube employee Dianna Arnspiger said she was on the building's second floor when she heard gunshots, ran to a window, and saw the shooter on a patio outside. She described the woman as wearing glasses and a scarf and using a "big huge pistol."

"It was a woman and she was firing her gun. And I just said, 'Shooter!', and everybody started running," Arnspiger said.

She and others hid in a conference room for an hour while another employee repeatedly called 911 for updates.

Title: Megyn Kelly Challenges Trump Spokesperson Katrina Pierson on Candidate's Policy Flip-Flops

Article:

Megyn Kelly, host of The Kelly File on Fox News, confronted Donald Trump spokesperson Katrina Pierson regarding the Republican presidential candidate's frequent policy and position reversals. The discussion centered on Trump's inconsistency when addressing women-related issues.

Kelly questioned Pierson about Trump's evolving stances on various topics, such as the war in Afghanistan, Obamacare, and abortion. She asked Pierson to explain her candidate's inconsistency, to which Pierson responded by attributing Trump's off-the-cuff comments to his appeal as a non-scripted politician.

When pressed about Trump's comments on abortion, Kelly asked why he had stated that women should be punished for having an illegal abortion if abortion were made illegal, and then later claimed he misspoke. Pierson attempted to clarify Trump's position by stating that he had provided a statement indicating he did not want to punish women for having an illegal abortion.

Kelly pointed out that Trump currently has a 73 percent disapproval rate with women, and questioned how he could perform better in an election with such a high disapproval rating compared to Mitt Romney's 51 percent disapproval rate in the 2012 election. Pierson responded by suggesting that there is a full-scale anti-Trump movement and that the mainstream media is working against Trump's campaign.

It is unavailable whether Pierson directly addressed Kelly's question about Trump's inconsistency and the potential impact of his high disapproval rate with women on his election prospects.

Title: NPR's Limited Coverage of State Department's Conclusion of Hillary Clinton's Email Investigation

Article:

The State Department recently concluded its investigation, initiated in 2016, into former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton's emails. According to an Associated Press report, the investigation found "no persuasive evidence of systemic, deliberate mishandling of classified information." However, 38 current or former employees were found to have sent classified information, some of which ended up in Clinton's personal email.

While the investigation was a significant development in the long-running saga, it received limited coverage from National Public Radio (NPR). A reader pointed out to NPR's Public Editor's office that there is no digital story or newsmagazine report about this development on NPR.org. The story was only covered in six newscasts on Friday, October 18, and Saturday, October 19, during off-hours. Newscast transcripts are not archived online.

Newsroom leaders explained that the decision to cover the story only in newscasts was due to the crush of other important news and an exceedingly stretched staff. Edith Chapin, NPR's vice president and executive editor, stated, "It was a combination of things: timing and stretched resources, and in the scheme of all the news of late, it just didn't rise up to our re-allocating resources."

Sarah Gilbert, NPR's vice president for news programming, added that the week's news agenda was dominated by the acting White House Chief of Staff Mick Mulvaney's admission and retraction of a quid pro quo on Ukraine, the Doral G7 announcement and reversal, and the crisis in Syria. In this context, newscast coverage of the 9-page State Department report was deemed adequate.

While the other stories were important and arguably far more newsworthy, given the ongoing impeachment inquiry against the president, the State Department finding may have felt anti-climactic, as the FBI had already closed its own investigation into Clinton's use of a private email server in 2016, stating there was no criminal act. NPR covered that at the time.

The individuals most affected by the new development are the senders of the now-classified emails. However, as recently as September 30, NPR had prominent reports in both Morning Edition and All Things Considered about the State Department's revival of the probe, contacting about 150 current or former employees whose emails had ended up in Clinton's private email. The net effect of that action, and NPR's reporting on it, was to keep alive an issue that President Trump has used to stir up his supporters against Clinton in particular and Democrats in general.

The end of the State Department's investigation marks a final period on the Clinton email saga that received significant attention in the lead-up to the 2016 election. NPR has an obligation to provide closure after three years, and since there is no other report in the NPR online archive, this article will have to serve as the final word on the matter.

Title: Sen. Marco Rubio Guides President Trump's Cuba Policy, Fosters Pragmatic Relationship

Article:

Senator Marco Rubio, a Republican from Florida, has found a pragmatic relationship with President Donald Trump, despite their contentious history. This relationship was on display on June 16, as Rubio accompanied Trump on Air Force One to Miami for an important announcement regarding Cuba policy.

Rubio, who once called Trump a "con artist" and was dubbed "little" by the president, has put aside their differences to collaborate on Cuba, China, and Venezuela policy. Trump expressed his gratitude to Rubio during his June announcement, calling him "a man who has really become a friend of mine."

Rubio's role in shaping the Cuba policy is significant, as he has been instrumental in crafting the new approach to the Castro regime. This opportunity also allowed Rubio to personally pitch Florida's most ambitious public works project.

The two have managed to find common ground despite their past disagreements, which were evident during the 2016 campaign. Rubio endorsed Trump after his exit from the presidential race, but did not appear with Trump during Florida visits during the general election campaign.

During a June Intelligence Committee hearing featuring former FBI Director James Comey, Rubio questioned the volume of leaks stemming from the agency's probe into Russian meddling with the 2016 election. Rubio's aggressive questioning drew criticism, but he defended his actions, stating that he asked questions directly from Comey's written statement.

Rubio has grown to enjoy his role in the Senate after declaring his frustration with the job during his presidential campaign. He has returned to the Senate after pledging not to seek a second term, and seems to have a new appreciation for the position. A key reason for his optimism is his alliance with Trump in the Oval Office.

Brian Ballard, a Tallahassee-based lobbyist who supported Rubio for president before becoming Trump's state finance chairman, attributes the two men's relationship to their genuine affection for each other. "When the election goes the right way, it cures a lot of things," he said.

Rubio has not gone out of his way to publicly criticize the president, choosing instead to focus on policy and the success of his Florida-related issues and foreign affairs with Trump in the White House. "If I have an opportunity to influence the administration's policy in a positive direction, I'm going to seek that out," he said.

Rubio has been a frequent visitor to the White House, dining or meeting with Trump or Vice President Pence several times. On Tuesday, he and two other lawmakers met with Pence to discuss geopolitics in the Western Hemisphere in advance of the vice president's trip to the region.

Political science professor Susan MacManus of the University of South Florida in Tampa believes Rubio's relationship with Trump is more issue-focused than power-focused, making it easier to have "gives and takes." MacManus also noted that Rubio has not expressed any interest in running for president in 2020, choosing instead to focus on his service in the Senate.

Title: U.S.-Israeli Relations Strain as Israel-Hamas Conflict Enters Third Week

Article:

The relationship between the United States and Israel has experienced a series of significant strains during the past few months, with the ongoing Israeli operation against Hamas in the Gaza Strip exacerbating the situation. The latest signs of tension emerged on Sunday, following a call between President Barack Obama and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, during which the growing concern over Palestinian civilian deaths, Israeli lives lost, and the deteriorating humanitarian situation in Gaza was expressed.

The White House statement, released after the call, emphasized the need for an immediate, unconditional humanitarian cease-fire to end the hostilities and pave the way for a permanent resolution. The statement also referenced Secretary of State John Kerry's efforts to broker a cease-fire between Israel and Hamas, which have been met with criticism from some Israeli officials.

The current tensions can be traced back to several factors. On the U.S. side, there is lingering frustration with Israel's response to previous attempts by Mr. Kerry to broker a broader peace deal with the Palestinians, which stalled just before the discovery of the bodies of three Israeli teenagers, believed to have been killed by Palestinians. This event set off a chain of events that led to the current wave of fighting and rocket attacks.

On the Israeli side, officials have expressed concerns about the weakness of Palestinian Authority leader Mahmoud Abbas in the West Bank and the extremism of Hamas leaders in the Gaza Strip, leading them to believe they have no viable partner for peace. Some Israeli officials have also viewed the American push for peace as a grandstanding move by Mr. Kerry.

Another factor contributing to the strained relations is the ongoing talks between the U.S. and five international powers and Iran over the Iranian nuclear program. As the negotiations move closer to an agreement that would allow Iran to maintain its uranium enrichment capacity, Israeli discomfort has grown. The extension of the talks for four more months has further increased Israeli unease.

Initially, the U.S. publicly supported Israel's right to respond when rockets were fired at its cities from Gaza. However, as Israel transitioned from an aerial offensive to a ground incursion, American and Israeli analyses began to diverge. U.S. officials grew concerned that the high number of Palestinian casualties could fuel long-term anger in the Gaza Strip and West Bank, potentially jeopardizing the U.S.'s long-term quest for peace.

As the diplomatic dance between the U.S. and Israel continues, both sides remain focused on their respective concerns. Israel views Hamas as a problem, but considers Iran's nuclear program an existential threat. The resumption of nuclear talks with Iran is imminent, and this issue is likely to contribute to further tensions between the two nations.

Title: U.S. Government Proposes Expanded Social Media Information Collection for Visa Applicants

Article:

The U.S. Department of State has proposed a new policy to collect social media identities from nearly all individuals seeking entry into the United States via visas. The proposal, if approved by the Office of Management and Budget (OMB), would require most immigrant and non-immigrant visa applicants to list all social media identities they have used in the past five years.

According to the proposal, this information will be used for vetting and identifying applicants. The new measures would affect approximately 14.7 million people annually.

The proposal supports President Donald Trump's campaign promise to implement "extreme vetting" of foreigners entering the United States to prevent terrorism. Previously, under rules instituted last May, consular officials were instructed to collect social media identifiers only when they deemed such information necessary to confirm identity or conduct more rigorous national security vetting.

The American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) has expressed concern, stating that the move could have a "chilling" effect on freedom of speech and association. Hina Shamsi, director of the ACLU's National Security Project, said in a statement, "People will now have to wonder if what they say online will be misconstrued or misunderstood by a government official."

The ACLU also expressed concern about the potential for the Trump administration to define the term "terrorist activities" in a vague and overly broad manner, which could lead to discriminatory visa denials without enhancing national security.

If approved, the measures would also require applicants to submit five years of previously used telephone numbers, email addresses, and their international travel history. They will be asked if they have been deported or removed from any country and whether family members have been involved in terrorist activities, the department said.

The department stated that it does not intend to routinely ask most diplomatic and official visa applicants for the additional information.

The new proposal was published in the Federal Register on Friday, and the public has 60 days to comment on the revised procedures before the OMB approves or rejects them.

Title: US-Russia Syria Peace Conference Prospects Dim as Assad Expresses Confidence in Receiving Russian Missiles

Article:

The prospects for a US-Russia jointly sponsored Syria peace conference in Geneva, initially planned for this month, have dimmed following recent events. These events include a defiant interview by Syrian President Bashar al-Assad on Hezbollah television, in which he expressed confidence in receiving sophisticated Russian anti-aircraft missiles, and a key Syrian opposition group's insistence on not attending the proposed conference.

Despite the setbacks, the US continues to view a Syria peace conference as a key goal, a critical element of the Obama administration's "two-track" Syria policy, which involves seeking a political settlement to the conflict while supporting the opposition fighting against Assad.

Some regional experts suggest that the US is playing into Russia's game plan of forestalling a more robust US intervention in Syria by agreeing to co-sponsor peace talks that appear to have little chance of success. The US has rejected this notion, with State Department spokeswoman Jen Psaki stating, "We expect to be able to move forward on a conference."

Senior US diplomats will meet next week in Geneva with Russian and UN officials to continue planning for the conference. Some officials speculate that what was originally envisioned for May could now slip into July.

Regarding Russia's delivery of sophisticated weaponry to Assad while working with the US and the United Nations on a peace conference, Psaki said, "I don't want to speculate on what their motivations are." However, she added that Russia has accepted the need for a "political transition" in Syria since the first Geneva conference on Syria a year ago, and the US continues to see Russia as a "partner" in the diplomatic process due to its ability to bring the Assad regime to the table.

Critics of the White House argue that the administration is allowing the US to be played by the Russians, whose main interest they say is to avoid the kind of decisive intervention the US and other Western powers undertook in Libya in 2011.

Sen. John McCain (R-AZ), who recently visited rebel-held Syrian territory, has stated that the rebels are running out of arms and ammunition and are facing growing numbers of Hezbollah and Iranian fighters supporting Assad. Senator McCain has long advocated arming the rebels and imposing a no-fly zone over parts of Syria.

The increasing deadly conflict in Syria, with a death toll on a path to cross the 100,000 threshold next month, is likely to amplify calls for President Obama to intervene more directly in the conflict. If a negotiated settlement proves elusive, pressure will grow for lethal measures.

Syria's main opposition group, the National Coalition, announced Thursday in Geneva that it would not take part in any negotiations as long as Lebanon-based Hezbollah and Iran are in Syria fighting for the Assad regime. George Sabra, the National Coalition's acting chairman, stated, "It is difficult to continue when Syrians are constantly being hammered by the Assad regime with the help of outside forces."

This week's setbacks to a diplomatic solution to Syria's increasingly deadly conflict will likely amplify calls for President Obama to intervene more directly in the conflict. If the conflict proves not to be "ripe" for a negotiated settlement, they add, pressure will grow for lethal measures.

Title: Former Obama White House Counsel Greg Craig Goes on Trial for Alleged False Statements Regarding Ukraine Work

Article:

Former Obama White House counsel Greg Craig will go on trial on Monday, charged with making false statements related to his work on behalf of Ukrainian interests. The trial, which will take place in the District of Columbia, stems from the investigation conducted by former special counsel Robert Mueller.

Craig, a prominent attorney in Democratic political circles who has worked for two Democratic presidents, was indicted in April on two counts of providing false statements to the Justice Department regarding his Ukraine work. A judge dismissed one of these counts last week, but Craig will still face trial on the remaining count.

The case against Craig, who has pleaded not guilty, emerged from Mueller's Russia probe. During its investigation, Mueller's team uncovered evidence of alleged wrongdoing by Craig, which they referred to the U.S. Attorney's Office for the District of Columbia for prosecution.

The case is one of several that have emerged from the Mueller inquiry and allege violations of the Foreign Agents Registration Act (FARA). FARA requires individuals doing political or public relations work in the U.S. on behalf of a foreign entity to disclose this fact. It is illegal to willfully not register or to provide false or misleading statements to the Justice Department's FARA unit.

In Craig's case, prosecutors allege that he withheld information that he should have provided to the department and provided other information that he knew was incorrect in connection with his work for the Ukrainian government. Craig's lawyers, William W. Taylor III and William J. Murphy of the law firm Zuckerman Spaeder, have denied that Craig broke the law. In a statement at the time of the indictment, they called the government's prosecution "a misguided abuse of prosecutorial discretion."

The case against Craig dates back to work he and his law firm, Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, did for Ukraine's pro-Russian government in 2012. Paul Manafort, who was advising the government in Kiev at the time, helped hire Craig and Skadden to draw up a report on the government's prosecution of former Prime Minister Yulia Tymoshenko.

Manafort, who later became Trump's campaign chairman in 2016 before resigning amid questions about his Ukraine work, was later convicted in a bank and tax fraud trial in Virginia brought by Mueller's team. Internationally, the case against Tymoshenko was viewed as a politically motivated sham pushed by her rival, then-President Viktor Yanukovych.

After being brought on board, Skadden drew up a report that validated the Tymoshenko prosecution. Craig then allegedly briefed journalists to shape early international coverage of the report. Craig and Skadden, however, did not register their activities with the Justice Department.

Prosecutors say Craig did not register his work with the Justice Department in order to avoid disclosing that Craig and Skadden had been paid $4 million for the work. Publicizing that fact would have undermined the perceived independence and credibility of the report, prosecutors say.

Early this year, Skadden reached a settlement of its own with the Justice Department, allowing it to avoid prosecution. It agreed to register under FARA and pay about $4.6 million. Craig's trial is expected to last 2 1/2 weeks, with jury selection beginning on Monday.

Title: Giuliani Clarifies Statement on Hush Money Payment to Stormy Daniels

Article:

WASHINGTON - Former New York Mayor Rudy Giuliani, a recent addition to President Donald Trump's legal team, issued a statement on Friday clarifying his remarks regarding the $130,000 payment made to adult-film star Stormy Daniels before the 2016 election. Giuliani stated that the payment was not a violation of election law, as it was made to resolve a personal matter to protect the President's family.

In a series of media interviews this week, Giuliani had suggested that the payment, made by President Trump's personal lawyer Michael Cohen, could have potentially violated federal election law by concealing a campaign contribution. However, in his statement, Giuliani stated, "The payment was made to resolve a personal and false allegation in order to protect the President’s family. It would have been done in any event, whether he was a candidate or not."

Giuliani's comments come after President Trump seemed to distance himself from Giuliani's statements, stating that the former federal prosecutor "really has his heart into it" but needs to "get his facts straight." Trump added that Giuliani would "get his facts straight" but did not specify the statements to which he was referring.

In a TV interview on Thursday, Giuliani had stated that if Stormy Daniels' claim of an affair had come up in a debate between Trump and his Democratic opponent, Hillary Clinton, Cohen "made it go away. He did his job."

Giuliani revealed on Wednesday that Trump had repaid Cohen for the $130,000 the lawyer had provided to Daniels. Trump previously had denied knowing about the payment.

In his statement on Friday, Giuliani stated, "My references to timing were not describing my understanding of the President’s knowledge, but instead, my understanding of these matters." However, he did not provide specifics.

Giuliani also addressed the controversy surrounding his statement on James Comey's firing, stating that it was "undisputed" that Trump had the constitutional power to fire Comey and that doing so has turned out to be "plainly in the best interests of our nation."

President Trump, facing legal troubles on several fronts, indicated a willingness to be interviewed in Special Counsel Robert Mueller's investigation but only if he knew he would be treated fairly. Trump is under investigation for potential collusion between his campaign and Russia and for whether he has unlawfully sought to obstruct the investigation.

During a pretrial hearing in Virginia on Mueller's charges against Trump's former campaign chairman, Paul Manafort, U.S. District Judge T.S. Ellis III openly questioned whether the special counsel had exceeded his prosecutorial powers by bringing the case.

Title: Obama and McConnell Agree on Cooperation, but Differences Remain

Article:

President Barack Obama and incoming Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell have agreed to work together, with both leaders expressing a desire to find areas of agreement on issues such as trade and tax reform. However, the two leaders have made it clear that they do not see eye-to-eye on many other issues, including immigration reform, the Affordable Care Act, and the minimum wage.

During a press conference on Wednesday, Obama and McConnell discussed their plans for cooperation, with Obama stating that he is willing to "drink Kentucky bourbon" with McConnell and work to improve their relationship with congressional Republicans. McConnell, for his part, declared that any executive actions by Obama on immigration reform would be "like waving a red flag in front of a bull," while Obama made it clear that he will move forward with executive action on immigration reform, as Congress has not passed a bill on the issue.

On the issue of the Affordable Care Act, McConnell called the law a "huge legislative mistake" and vowed to continue fighting it, while Obama insisted that a minimum wage increase will still be a priority for his administration. McConnell also promised to move ahead on the Keystone pipeline, another nonstarter for the president.

In response to the sweeping Republican victories in the midterm elections, both Obama and McConnell acknowledged the need for cooperation, but it remains unclear how much actual cooperation will occur. McConnell has stated that there will be no government shutdown or default on the national debt, but he also indicated that the Senate will send Obama bills that he is likely to veto.

Republican leaders have called for the party to work with Obama to get things done, while conservative activists within the party are pushing for the repeal of Obamacare and other nonstarters. Republican policy experts suggest that the party will have to manage this balance by putting out its own governing agenda, working with Obama where possible, and taking the bigger fights to the voters in 2016.

The Republican Party is also facing internal tensions, with conservative activists pushing for big fights with Obama and the GOP Senate doing everything it can to repeal Obamacare, fight regulations, and hold the line against immigration reform. It remains to be seen how the Republican Party will navigate these internal tensions and balance cooperation with Obama with the demands of their conservative base.

Title: Sen. Jeff Flake Open to Changing Stance on Expanding Gun Background Checks

Article:

Republican Senator Jeff Flake has expressed his willingness to reconsider his opposition to expanding background checks for firearm purchases, provided that changes are made to a provision in the current Senate bill regarding internet sales. Flake voted against the bill due to concerns about the cost and inconvenience of the background check requirement for internet sales, particularly in rural areas where guns are often exchanged among friends.

Flake stated that under the current measure, a casual sale initiated through a text, email, or social media post would be considered a commercial sale, making it inconvenient and costly for rural residents. He admitted that the bill's chief sponsor, Senator Joe Manchin (D-West Virginia), may not be able to alter the language to satisfy his concerns, but Flake expressed hope that they can find a solution.

The legislation, if passed, would have expanded the requirement for background checks on internet sales and private sales at gun shows. However, a Senate Democratic leadership aide stated on Monday that they do not anticipate or expect a deal on background checks to be reached in time for the bill to be reconsidered during this work period, which ends before Memorial Day weekend.

Senator Flake, a first-term senator, has been a target of gun control group protests during the recent congressional recess. One such group, Mayors Against Illegal Guns, sent a woman whose son was a victim of the Aurora movie massacre to try to meet with Flake in his Phoenix office.

Flake, who is close with former Congresswoman Gabby Giffords, who, along with her husband, had been lobbying Flake to support expanding background checks, was publicly criticized by them following his vote against the measure. Some Republicans opposed the measure out of fear that expanding background checks would lead to a national gun registry, but Flake stated that this is not his concern.

"I know that is not what this bill does, just the opposite," Flake said. During last week's congressional recess, Flake was the target of gun control group protests. Despite facing criticism and being labeled as the most unpopular senator in the country in a Democratic polling firm's survey, Flake stated that he received positive feedback from his constituents for opposing the background check measure as it was written.

"I'm comfortable with where I am, pond scum or not," he said with a smile.

Title: Bipartisan Efforts to Avert Sequestration Cuts and Pursue Budget Deal

Article:

Top Democrats and Republicans have been trading blame for the $85 billion in sequestration cuts that took effect on Friday, but both parties have expressed a willingness to negotiate a comprehensive budget deal. The federal budget standoff, which began on Friday, has opened an opportunity for a "big deal" that addresses politically sensitive issues such as entitlement reform and tax code overhaul, which have eluded Washington for the past two years.

Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-SC) stated on CBS' "Face the Nation" that a "big deal" could be achieved with leadership.
