He expressed his unwillingness to engage in small deals and reiterated that he would not accept tax rate hikes to resolve the sequestration issue. However, he is open to a major agreement that would raise approximately $600 billion in revenue by closing tax loopholes and eliminating deductions. This revenue could then be used to reform Medicare and other entitlement programs.

Sen. Richard J. Durbin (D-IL), the second-ranking Democrat in the Senate, also expressed optimism about the opportunity to find a sensible solution. He stated that both parties must agree on how to finish the fiscal year, creating an opportunity for leaders to collaborate and find a lasting solution.

The deadline for achieving such a deal is at the end of March, as the resolution funding federal government operations expires then. This means another showdown, this time to avoid a Washington shutdown, is imminent.

Both parties have until the end of March to achieve a deal, and if they fail to do so, Congress will have to approve another short-term spending plan by March 27 or face a government shutdown. Another debate over the debt ceiling is also expected in May.

Top Republicans in the House and Senate have reiterated their opposition to further tax increases. House Speaker John A. Boehner (R-OH) stated that the White House should not expect any more concessions on taxes after the New Year's deal to avoid the so-called fiscal cliff. Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-KY) echoed these sentiments, stating that no Republican is willing to raise a dime in taxes to turn off the sequester.

The top Republican lawmakers made these comments after the White House indicated a willingness to go around the GOP leadership in the House and Senate. National Economic Council Director Gene Sperling, who appeared on multiple Sunday morning shows, stated that the president spent part of Saturday calling lawmakers directly in an attempt to break the sequestration logjam and find a deal.

The White House has criticized the Republican Party for its unwillingness to compromise on the revenue question. National Economic Council Director Gene Sperling refuted the notion that congressional Republicans scored a political victory with sequestration and the administration's inability to stop it. He stated that the only "win," if it can be called that, is for those on the Republican side who are willing to let all the harm be inflicted so they can stand by the principle that there should not be one dime of deficit reduction that should ever come from closing loopholes or deductions.

Title: Wisconsin Recall Election Breaks Fundraising Records, Exceeding $70 Million

Article:

The ongoing gubernatorial recall election in Wisconsin is breaking fundraising records, with a projected final tally of $70 million to $80 million. This surpasses the previous record of $37 million set just 18 months ago when Republican Governor Scott Walker was first elected.

Mike McCabe, who runs Wisconsin Democracy Campaign, a nonpartisan campaign watchdog group, predicts this range for the race's final tally. The money raised in the recall already far exceeds the state's previous record.

The disparity in fundraising between the two candidates is significant. Democrat Tom Barrett has raised just under $4 million, while Walker has raised $30.5 million. This gap can be attributed in part to a quirk in the election law that allows public officials targeted for a recall in Wisconsin to raise unlimited sums of money until the recall is formally set. In Walker's case, this was in March.

A large portion of Walker's donations in the last month came from outside Wisconsin, amounting to 70% of his contributions. This influx of out-of-state donations, both large and small, has been a notable trend in the recall.

Individual contributions only tell part of the story of big bucks in Wisconsin's recall. Outside groups supporting both candidates have flooded the state with some $25 million. These groups, such as Planned Parenthood, the National Rifle Association, and labor unions, look like a who's who of Washington special interests.

Labor unions, which have a significant stake in the recall due to the backlash against Walker's actions regarding collective bargaining rights for public employees, have given $8 million in traceable donations to help Barrett. It's likely unions have given much more to Democratic groups not required to disclose their donors.

The Republican Governors Association is another significant contributor, providing at least $9 million, including $1 million from GOP high roller David Koch. These groups register and advertise with names that appear to be homegrown, but many are actually national unions or Washington-based special interests.

There are also stealth super PACs whose donors are anonymous, contributing $8.5 million. The Wisconsin Democracy Campaign lists eight such groups on its website, most of which are right-leaning groups trying to help Walker. One, Greater Wisconsin Committee, is trying to help push Walker out.

"Elections are being poisoned here, but the people of Wisconsin can't know who is paying for most of the poison," McCabe said.

Despite the massive amounts of money raised and spent on the recall election, it is an open question whether it will make a real difference. Wisconsin's electorate is so polarized that public and party polls suggest most people's minds are already made up. However, both parties agree that the extra campaign cash does help where it matters most: identifying voters and making sure they get to the polls on Election Day.

Title: House Speaker John Boehner Allows Debt Ceiling Vote Without Conditions, Sperling Hopes for Consensus on Default Tactics

Article:

Gene Sperling, director of President Obama's National Economic Council, expressed hope on Tuesday that the tactic of using government default or the full faith and credit of the United States as a bargaining chip in budget debates is no longer on the table. The hope stems from House Speaker John Boehner's decision to allow a vote to increase the government's borrowing cap without attaching conditions sought by some Republican legislators.

During a breakfast meeting with reporters, Sperling, who is set to leave the White House next month, expressed his hope that the country has reached a consensus on this matter. He stated, "We as a country have now reached a consensus that... the tactic of threatening default or threatening the full faith and credit of the United States for budget debates is over, off the table, and never to happen again."

Boehner's decision to allow a vote on the debt ceiling, as soon as Tuesday evening, without any legislative strings attached, is a reversal from his plan announced Monday evening. The previous plan linked raising the debt ceiling to reversing a measure that cut pension benefits to younger military retirees. Now, Boehner stated, "We'll let the Democrats put the votes up. We'll put a minimum number of [GOP] votes up to get it passed."

The change in plan came after conservative House Republicans expressed dissatisfaction with the linkage in Boehner's initial plan. Repealing the pension measure would have cost $7 billion over the coming decade, according to the Congressional Budget Office. Representative Mo Brooks (R-AL) told The Associated Press, "Right now we've got a debt-ceiling bill that increases spending, which is diametrically 180 degrees opposite of what we were battling over just two years ago – where the question was how much in spending cuts we were going to get."

The Obama administration is "supportive of efforts to grandfather current recipients" of the pension benefits, Sperling said. However, the White House is opposed to using the debt limit as a "ransom" to pass it, he added.

Sperling, who is the first person to serve two presidents as director of the National Economic Council, compared his service in the Clinton and Obama administrations, stressing the differences in the Republican Party then and now. "In the Clinton administration, what was often most difficult was having [to go up against] a unified and strong opposition," Sperling said. "This time around, you learn the challenges of having a divided opposition when you want to get things done." Even when parts of the opposition leadership today want to reach a budget agreement, "it is hard for them to stay at the table because [their members] are not unified enough to stay at the table and finish an agreement."

Material from The Associated Press was used in this report.

Title: North Carolina Governor Blames Congress for Lack of Federal Civil Rights Laws, Cites Inconsistency in State and Local Policies

Article:

North Carolina Governor Pat McCrory, under fire for signing a bill that requires transgender residents to use bathrooms corresponding to their sex at birth, has blamed Congress for not updating the nation's civil rights laws. In an interview with TIME, the Republican governor stated that the patchwork of non-discrimination laws at state and local levels is inconsistent, and the Civil Rights Act could resolve contradictions over discrimination in schools, businesses, and government buildings.

McCrory, who is facing a tough re-election bid this November, also vowed to continue his fight against President Barack Obama's orders that schools allow transgender students to pick their own restrooms or face a cutoff of federal dollars. "As a country, Congress needs to step up and clarify the Civil Rights Act, which hasn't been updated for decades," McCrory said by phone on Wednesday. "A lot of things have changed since then, including the Supreme Court decision on gay marriage. There's been dramatic change."

Congress is considering a comprehensive non-discrimination law that would add protections to LGBT Americans. The Equality Act has attracted supporters from both parties, but it's unlikely to make its way to the President's desk before he leaves office early next year. McCrory said he is aware of that legislation but didn't know enough about it to endorse it. However, he said it's time for Congress to do something on the issue of discrimination. "Congress has been sitting on the sidelines," he said. "Every city and state and town has its own non-discrimination ordinances that are very inconsistent."

McCrory signed legislation that undid one of those local policies. Charlotte, N.C., was among the last major American cities to adopt such a measure—decades after Minneapolis passed the first one in 1975. Some in the GOP are left scratching their heads over why these are controversial. "Non-discrimination laws belong at the federal level and they have not been updated," McCrory said.

LGBT rights advocates have been tough on McCrory and the Republican-led legislature, urging them to scrap a law that, by some estimates, has cost the state's economy $500 million. Corporate America is lined up against the measure, too, and have recruited conservative mega-attorney Ted Olsen to write a friends-of-the-court brief on their behalf.

McCrory said the Left started this fight, and have proved effective opponents. He met recently with the president of the nation's largest LGBT group, the Human Rights Campaign (HRC), and came away calling him "Machiavellian." "Chad [Griffin] was extremely assertive and told me exactly what the campaign was going to entail. He has followed through," McCrory said. "He said he was going to make North Carolina the epicenter of the transgender bathroom rights issue. He was going to bring activists from outside to protest, he was going to bring teams to North Carolina to coordinate protest."

Griffin has, and it has found some success. "From across the country, the response has been yes, we're with you," Griffin said of the corporate allies. That has left McCrory dangling. "He's found himself on a very lonely island when it comes to defining a legacy based on bathrooms," Griffin said.

Entertainers have announced boycotts until the law is changed, and some Mayors and Governors have banned official travel to North Carolina. McCrory called it hypocrisy, and cited a transgender American Airlines employee, Candis Cox-Daniels, whom he met. McCrory later posited how she would fare in New York state, where Gov. Andrew Cuomo has banned most state employees from going to North Carolina.

"New York does not allow Candis Cox to change her birth certificate. North Carolina does," McCrory said. "Our laws are stronger than New York's laws." That is little consolation to Cox-Daniels, who is telecommuting to her job at the Raleigh-Durham International Airport. Her corporate counsel has advised her not to go to her workplace because it falls under the law that would require her to use the men's room. And North Carolina's birth certificate policy is only available to those who can prove they have had reassignment surgery, which can be medically dangerous, costly, and unnecessary.

"This was not an issue that I had even heard of. We did not seek out this issue," McCrory said. "The HRC, I give them credit. They are more powerful than the NRA." But with Obama's orders, this now should move beyond a question of North Carolina, the Governor said. "The President has the power to enforce the law, under our Constitution, but he does not have the authority to make or interpret the law," he said. "It's now a national issue that impacts every business in the United States, every university in the United States, every K-12 school in the United States. This goes way beyond North Carolina."

"The Right is often criticized—and rightly so—for wanting to getting involved in the bedrooms," he added. "The Left is wanting to get involved in locker rooms, showers, and bathrooms. It was working pretty well when we were just dealing with it.... I don't think government should tell the private sector what their locker room, shower room, and bathroom policies should be." But that is, however, what the North Carolina law did for its public buildings. "There is selective outrage by the corporate media and entertainment elite," he said. "There is a lot of learning and a lot of confusion and complexities that both sides aren't talking about."

Title: Churches Adapt to Coronavirus: Bible Verses, Live Streaming, and Precautionary Measures

Article:

In response to the growing concern over the spread of the coronavirus, some Christians are turning to Bible verses such as 2 Timothy 1:7 to alleviate the mounting panic. The verse reads, "For God has not given us a spirit of fear, but of power and of love and of a sound mind."

Aside from spiritual solace, houses of worship are implementing practical solutions to limit the potential spread of COVID-19 within faith communities. For instance, DC officials are urging parishioners who attend Christ Church Georgetown to self-quarantine after its lead preacher tested positive for coronavirus. The church had already suspended services and activities as a precaution. The preacher, the Rev. Timothy Cole, remains hospitalized in stable condition in a Washington-area hospital, while his wife and two kids are in self-quarantine.

In a preventive measure, the Holy See has opted for live streaming masses to show solidarity with those affected by the virus. Pope Francis delivered mass via video on Monday, and the live stream was intended to demonstrate unity with those suffering from the virus. The Vatican also discouraged large crowds from gathering in St. Peter's Square over the weekend, with Pope Francis briefly appearing at the iconic window to wave to the sparse crowd.

France, neighboring Italy, now has the second most coronavirus cases in Europe. In response, the government announced it will ban gatherings exceeding 1,000 people, which could potentially affect Paris Christian Center, which welcomed fifteen new converts at its weekend service. Dorothée Rajiah, senior pastor of Paris Christian Center, told ███ News contributing correspondent Chuck Holton, "Many churches have decided to close their services." If the government asks them to shut down their service, they are ready to stream from their website and YouTube.

In Greenwood Village, Colorado, parishioners at St. Peter Lutheran Church have replaced traditional handshakes with elbow and fist bumps during the Passing of the Peace. Pastor Dave Risendal of St. Peter Lutheran stated, "We're trying to be careful to make sure our communion servers have their hands well clean and that people know how to be careful and thoughtful when they receive the bread and the wine."

Last week, the Church of the Nativity—the site where many Christians believe Jesus was born—shut its doors as a precaution. Meanwhile, after temporarily shuttering Islam's holiest site, Saudi Arabia re-opened the Grand Mosque in Mecca for Muslim pilgrims over the weekend.

Title: Supreme Court's Decision on Same-Sex Marriage: Impact on Religious Liberty and Potential Civil Disobedience

Article:

The United States Supreme Court has declared that same-sex couples have a constitutional right to marry in all 50 states, following the historical decision on marriage. The ruling, which has already been upheld in 36 states and the District of Columbia, will no longer allow the remaining 14 states to maintain their traditional definitions of marriage.

In response to the ruling, Christian leaders have expressed a range of emotions, including love, concern, and warnings of civil disobedience. Former governor and presidential candidate Mike Huckabee described the ruling as "an out-of-control act of unconstitutional judicial tyranny." Bob Vander Plaats, a conservative activist in Iowa, stated that the court "succumbed to demands to invent a new constitutional 'right' never imagined by our Founders."

The impact of the gay marriage ruling on religious liberty is a topic of concern for many Christian leaders. Austin Nimocks, Senior Legal Counsel at the Alliance Defending Freedom, shared his perspective on the matter. Rev. Albert Mohler, the president of the Southern Baptist Theological Seminary, urged followers to "speak the truth in love and to speak love in truth."

Many faith leaders believe the Supreme Court ruling recognizing gay marriage will put religious liberty at risk. Jim Campbell, Senior Legal Counsel at the Alliance Defending Freedom, stated, "The Supreme Court has stripped all Americans of our freedom to debate and decide marriage policy through the democratic process. The freedom to democratically address the most pressing social issues of the day is the heart of liberty."

In the weeks before the ruling, the Southern Baptist Convention partnered with the Alliance Defending Freedom to provide guidance for churches and other faith-based institutions called Protecting Your Ministry. Dr. Russell Moore, president of the Ethics & Religious Liberty Commission of the Southern Baptist Convention, discussed the booklet in an interview with ███ News earlier this month.

Rev. Samuel Rodriguez stated that the decision "serves as a de facto and legal catalyst for the marginalization of Americans who embrace a biblical worldview." Mat Staver, founder and chairman of Liberty Counsel, has already called for civil disobedience in response to such a ruling. Other individuals and organizations are studying the ruling to determine the best ways to respond.

Title: May's Brexit Deal: A Closer Look at the Controversial Agreement and Its Implications

Article:

British Prime Minister Theresa May announced the terms of Britain's departure from the European Union (EU) in the House of Commons earlier this week, following months of negotiations. The deal, which spans over 500 pages, has been met with mixed reactions, with few having read it in full.

The agreement confirms earlier leaks, stating that after leaving the EU, Britain will continue to be subject to EU rules and regulations, but will have no say or vote in their creation. This has raised concerns among Brexit supporters, as it appears to contradict the "red lines" set by Prime Minister May last year.

Red Lines vs. Deal:

1. Red Line: Britain will leave the single market and its regulations.
   Deal: Britain will sign on to a "common rulebook" of regulations, which will be the EU single-market rulebook.

2. Red Line: Britain will leave the Customs Union to negotiate free-trade deals with non-EU countries.
   Deal: Britain will remain in a customs union with the EU, making it impossible to negotiate free-trade deals with other countries.

3. Red Line: Britain will be out of the jurisdiction of the European Court of Justice (ECJ).
   Deal: Britain will be subject to ECJ jurisdiction on regulation and trade matters, and U.K. courts will take account of its rulings.

Prime Minister May maintains that she has achieved the Brexit deal she wanted, despite the apparent contradictions. However, this claim has been met with criticism from Brexit supporters, who argue that the deal amounts to an outright betrayal.

The deal's opponents, including former Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson and Jacob Rees-Mogg, are calling for a vote of no confidence in May, as they believe that if the leader won't change the deal, they must change the leader.

Supporters of the deal, often referred to as "covert Remainers," argue that it is the best achievable Brexit, even potentially leading to a second referendum and the maintenance of EU membership. They accept that the deal may be unsatisfactory but argue that Brexit is an impossible "fantasy."

The Northern Irish Democratic Unionists, whose support gives the May government its parliamentary majority, have also expressed opposition to the deal, as it places a border within the U.K. to avoid one between the U.K. and the Republic of Ireland. This threatens the Union—not the European Union but the Union of Great Britain and Northern Ireland.

Prime Minister May and her loyalist supporters now face three linked challenges: a possible leadership vote, a possible parliamentary defeat on the EU-U.K. deal, and a possible election to resolve the Brexit issue. The crisis has led to several cabinet ministers resigning, and at least half the required 48 letters for a vote of confidence have been publicly submitted.

The outcome of this political crisis remains uncertain, but it is clear that the deal has sparked significant controversy and division within the Conservative Party and the British government. The Tories may need to choose a new leader to forge a new policy and achieve a real Brexit. At present, they are sleepwalking into vassalage, as the deal appears to contradict the will of the British people as expressed in the 2016 referendum.

Title: Louisiana Election Results: John Bel Edwards Defeats David Vitter, Shifts Political Landscape in Deep South

Article:

In a significant shift in the political landscape of the conservative Deep South, State Rep. John Bel Edwards has defeated Republican U.S. Sen. David Vitter in Saturday's election. Edwards will be the only Democratic governor in the Deep South, where Republicans dominate politically.

The election night parties of the candidates provided a clear indication of the outcome. Sen. David Vitter was based at a hotel near the airport, while John Bel Edwards lodged in the historic Monteleone Hotel in the French Quarter. A brass band led a second line through the packed ballroom, with revelers waving yellow campaign hankies, signaling Edwards' victory.

Democrats have much to celebrate in a state where they have been shut out of statewide elected office. Edwards attributes this change to his supporters who, he says, "were willing to believe that we could confound the conventional wisdom that this victory just couldn't happen."

Initially, Republican Sen. David Vitter was the presumed frontrunner. By last night, he was conceding defeat and preparing for an exit from the U.S. Senate. Vitter stated, "I'm only going to be doing that for one more year though this term," referring to his Senate tenure. He had decided to pursue new challenges outside the Senate regardless of the election outcome, citing he had reached his personal term limit.

Vitter's ties to a Washington D.C. prostitute in 2007 were a recurring issue in the governor's race. At the time, he confessed to a "serious sin," and then handily won re-election to the Senate in 2010. However, the governor's race was different, with Edwards and his supporters attacking Vitter's character at every turn with harsh language, labeling him a liar and a stain on Louisiana.

Vitter also had to overcome voters' frustration with the current Republican Governor, Bobby Jindal, who is term-limited. Louisiana's other Republican Sen. Bill Cassidy supported Vitter, but some other GOP officeholders backed Edwards. Cassidy acknowledges that this division within the Republican party hurt Vitter's campaign.

"Clearly Republicans were fractured, and there was a multimillion-dollar superPAC attacking David. For whatever reason, their attacks had a bite," he says.

State Rep. Kenny Havard is among those who broke GOP ranks to endorse Edwards. He views the election as a message that voters are tired of ultra-partisan politics. "We've got people on the fringe of each party, you know they rule the party. And probably 80 percent of us are stuck in the middle with nowhere to go. So I think the people of Louisiana spoke tonight and spoke with a loud voice," Havard said.

Edwards, a veteran and West Point graduate, stakes out some conservative turf—he's anti-abortion and pro-gun rights. However, he also plans to expand Medicaid and push for a higher minimum wage, issues popular with Louisiana Democrats. Edwards promised last night to be a governor for "all the people." With one final punch, he added, "I will never embarrass you."

Title: Boston Marathon Bombing Suspect's Interrogation and Charges Remain Unclear

Article:

The surviving Boston Marathon bombing suspect, Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, has yet to provide law enforcement authorities with substantial information due to medical issues, as he has been in and out of consciousness since his apprehension on Friday evening, according to The Wall Street Journal. Meanwhile, new circumstantial evidence suggests that his older brother, Tamerlan Tsarnaev, may have radicalized Dzhokhar and influenced him into the alleged bomb plot. Tamerlan was killed in the brothers' getaway attempt on Friday.

In January, Tamerlan Tsarnaev interrupted a speaker at a Cambridge mosque who compared the prophet Muhammad and the Reverend Martin Luther King Jr., according to The Boston Globe. The elder Tsarnaev brother called the speaker at the Islamic Society of Boston mosque a nonbeliever, a "kaffir," and accused him of contaminating people's minds. The congregation did not agree and "shouted him out of the mosque," Yusufi Vali, a spokesman for the mosque, told the Globe.

Younger brother Dzhokhar may be unable to communicate with investigators even after recovery, as he sustained a wound to the throat area. It is unclear whether the wound was the result of police gunfire or was self-inflicted as part of a failed suicide attempt. Authorities indicated that the federal High Value Detainee Interrogation team was standing by to question the surviving Tsarnaev in writing if possible.

Mr. Tsarnaev could be charged at any time. As legal expert Robert Chesney notes on the "Lawfare" blog, law enforcement faces no shortage of possible crimes to use in its indictment. Charges could be state or federal. "Many if not most will be ordinary violent-crimes charges rather than terrorism-specific ones – though they'll be no less potent for that," writes Mr. Chesney.

The most serious charge Tsarnaev might face is federal: use of a weapon of mass destruction in killing. It can carry the death penalty. However, the "Use of Weapons of Mass Destruction" statute carries four conditions, one of which must be met for it to apply. The first two conditions, which generally hold that the alleged attack affects mail delivery or property used in interstate or foreign commerce, may not be applicable. The third, which holds that the perpetrator of the attack travels across state or national boundaries in furtherance of the crime, might fit. So might the fourth, which says that the offense must "affect interstate or foreign commerce" itself.

Another federal terrorism statute that can carry a capital charge and may be applicable is titled "Acts of Terrorism Transcending National Boundaries." If authorities believe some element of the plot began overseas, they could invoke this law. It is possible they suspect just that, given that the elder Tsarnaev traveled to Russia for six months in 2011, where he may have met with radical Islamists or received some terrorist training.

Other federal terrorism laws that Dzhokhar Tsarnaev might face charges from include a statute dealing with the bombing of public places and another prohibiting material support for terror acts.

There is some question as to whether Tsarnaev's trial might be moved outside Massachusetts, on the grounds that any jury pool would be tainted against him. After all, Timothy McVeigh's trial for the Oklahoma City bombing was moved to Colorado for that reason. State authorities are likely to file their own charges against the terror suspect, meaning that at some point he is quite likely to face a Bay State jury.

On Monday, civil libertarians continued to criticize the Obama administration for its decision to delay reading Tsarnaev his Miranda rights so that it can ask initial questions under a public safety exception to the law. Given the weight of evidence against Tsarnaev, this action is unlikely to have any practical effect on his future trial, note experts. Authorities have so much video, so many tapes, and lots of physical evidence, including explosives, that they would not need to use Tsarnaev's initial statements in any trial, and thus would not need to risk the statements being excluded on legal grounds.

Title: Orlando Mass Killing Fits Pattern of Homegrown Terrorism, According to Peter Bergen

Article:

Peter Bergen, CNN's national security analyst, a vice president at New America, and a professor of practice at Arizona State University, has written that the mass killing in Orlando this weekend fits a grim pattern of homegrown terrorism in the United States.

Since the 9/11 attacks, every lethal terrorist attack on U.S. soil has been carried out by American citizens or legal permanent residents, operating either as lone wolves or in pairs, with no formal connections or training from terrorist organizations such as al Qaeda or ISIS.

Many Americans may think that terrorist attacks in the United States are carried out by foreigners, rather than by U.S. citizens. However, Omar Mateen, who on Sunday carried out the deadliest terrorist attack in the United States since 9/11, is an American citizen born in New York to parents who immigrated from Afghanistan.

Since 9/11, a plot which was directed by al Qaeda from Afghanistan and involved only foreign operatives has been the exception, rather than the rule. The real terror threat in the United States has been American citizens or legal permanent residents such as the Tsarnaev brothers, who carried out the Boston Marathon bombings in 2013, and Nidal Hasan, the U.S. Army major who killed 13 at Fort Hood, Texas, four years earlier.

In other ways, Mateen is also typical of jihadist terrorists in the United States. He was on the radar of the FBI as a possible militant, just as Tamerlan Tsarnaev, who was investigated by the bureau because of a tip from the Russian government in 2011 that he might be a militant.

Title: Wisconsin Governor Recall Vote: A Battle for Home Turf and Statewide Expansion

Article:

Wisconsin residents are casting their votes today in the historic recall election for the state's governor, with potential implications beyond the state's borders. The focus of this election is primarily on the 3 million-plus registered voters within Wisconsin, rather than the broader political implications for 2012.

The recall election is, in many ways, a replay of the 2010 gubernatorial election, which Republican Scott Walker won by approximately 125,000 votes among over 2 million cast. Democratic challenger Tom Barrett, the mayor of Milwaukee since 2004, is aiming to translate his mayoral popularity into a stronger showing than his 2010 performance, particularly in his home county and metro area.

In 2010, Barrett won his own city proper in a landslide, enabling him to carry Milwaukee County by a little over 80,000 votes. However, Walker, who was the chief elected official for Milwaukee County at the time, countered the city's vote and kept the countywide margin close to where it had been in 2006, when Democratic Governor Jim Doyle was re-elected.

In 2006, Doyle rode the Milwaukee County vote to a narrow win for the overall Milwaukee metro area, superseding the usual Republican blowout in the suburban-exurban counties of Waukesha, Washington, and Ozaukee to the west and north. In 2010, with turnout down dramatically in the city of Milwaukee, Barrett found that the vote in surrounding counties had grown insurmountable.

Meanwhile, the vote was going heavily against him in the rest of the metro. Waukesha County alone favored Walker by about 82,000 votes, slightly more than the margin by which Barrett won Milwaukee County. Ozaukee and Washington came piling on, going for Walker by a combined ratio approaching 3-to-1, putting the Republican nearly 50,000 votes ahead for the four-county metro area.

For his part, Walker was running up big margins in the traditional Republican enclaves in the eastern half of the state, from Walworth in the south to Dodge, Fond du Lac, and Winnebago in the east-central part of the state. He had little trouble winning the swing county of Brown, which includes the city of Green Bay.

In Tuesday's recall, Barrett needs to get much closer to Obama's numbers in the Milwaukee metro, find a way to squeeze even more votes out of Dane and widen his winning margin in outstate counties such as Eau Claire. It would also help if he could flip counties he lost in 2010, including southeastern Racine and Kenosha near the Illinois state line.

This tall order explains why even the late polls showing the race getting closer are not shaking the confidence of the governor and his backers. The votes to be counted Tuesday night are likely to follow traditional partisan patterns that have been discernible in the state since the emergence of its modern Democratic Party in the years after World War II.

Title: U.S.-Led Coalition's Progress Against Islamic State Challenged by Political and Military Concerns

Article:

Secretary of State John F. Kerry declared on Sunday that the U.S.-led coalition, working with Arab partners, has made significant progress in the fight against Islamic State terrorists, taking back wide swaths of territory and eliminating top commanders. However, this rosy outlook is met with skepticism from Kurdish leaders and Republican critics who question the U.S. leadership's strategy and commitment.

Kerry stated that the coalition has made substantial progress, citing the retaking of territory and the elimination of key Islamic State commanders. He expressed confidence in the coalition's victory, stating, "I absolutely do [believe they are winning]...And I think the evidence is not in my saying it, but it’s in the facts of what is happening."

However, Kurdish leaders involved in the ground combat have expressed concerns about the lack of a clear strategy to rout the extremists. U.S. lawmakers from both parties have also voiced concerns about the U.S. not doing enough to support their allies without deploying American troops.

The disconnect between the U.S. administration's assessment and that of those on the ground highlights the challenges the administration faces in navigating real-life battles abroad and political ones at home. The Islamic State's jihadist-inspired violence, including the brutal immolation of a Jordanian pilot and the suspected killing of American hostage Kayla Mueller, has fueled fears over the tangible and philosophical threats of radical Islam.

In the midst of this turmoil, political tensions are running high in Washington, with members of both parties warning about the growing threat of homegrown terrorism. The Department of Homeland Security's funding is set to run out on February 27 due to a stalemate over President Obama's executive amnesty for certain illegal immigrants. Homeland Security Secretary Jeh Johnson has urged for a fully funded department to ensure public safety.

While some Republicans express concern about picking the wrong fight, hard-liners argue that the DHS can maintain the country's safety during a partial shutdown. Others criticize the administration for not setting clear goals and for failing to define the enemy as radical Islamist extremism.

In addition to the ongoing conflict in the Middle East and the domestic political tensions, the U.S. is also facing challenges in Ukraine, where the administration is being urged to arm the Kiev government, which is battling Russian-backed separatists in the eastern part of the country. Attempts at a truce have faltered, and the administration has been reluctant to disclose what assistance they will provide to Ukrainian loyalists.

Republican senators, including Sen. John McCain and Sen. Ted Cruz, have expressed concerns about the administration's foreign policy, with Cruz suggesting that diplomacy may not be enough and that the U.S. needs to arm Kurdish peshmerga fighters on the front lines. The administration maintains that it has already supplied the peshmerga with ammunition, weapons, and other resources.

The battle against the Islamic State ultimately needs to be waged by the Iraqi army, although they are not yet prepared to fight, according to Kerry. He emphasized that the coalition believes everything, including the governing process in Iraq, is moving in the right direction.

Title: Same-sex Marriage and Religious Liberty: A Balancing Act

Article:

The debate over same-sex marriage has a strong religious component, as highlighted by Marc Stern, a prominent legal scholar and former president of the American Jewish Congress. Stern argues that the government should not favor one religious view over another on the issue of gay marriage.

In the context of the ongoing debate, Stern raises questions such as whether recognizing gay marriage infringes upon religious liberty. The debate involves interpreting biblical passages, reconciling ancient texts with modern theological understanding, and considering the importance of love and human autonomy as religious values.

Stern emphasizes that the U.S. Supreme Court should not be tasked with determining the religious stance on same-sex marriage. Religious groups are divided on this issue, with some supporting and others opposing same-sex marriage. Even if a religious viewpoint were clear, it should not influence the constitutional requirement for states or the federal government to recognize same-sex marriage.

Stern argues that neither the court nor government should referee religious disputes. Under the Constitution, religious groups are free to advocate for their differing visions of morality and compete in the marketplace of ideas. Winners and losers are determined by individual and congregational beliefs, not by government bodies.

Citizens opposed to same-sex marriage cannot demand that the government refuse recognition to such marriages to avoid offending their religious sensibilities.

Religious liberty, as Stern points out, does not grant anyone the right to deny others the "right to live the most intimate portions of their lives according to their own deepest convictions." However, when government recognizes same-sex marriage, it creates new challenges for the liberties of religious believers.

These challenges extend to questions such as whether religious leaders must provide religious marriage counseling to same-sex couples, whether religious colleges must provide housing to same-sex couples, or whether churches and synagogues must employ spouses in same-sex marriages. Resolving these conflicts will not be easy, and Stern suggests that in some instances, the rights of same-sex couples will unavoidably trump religious liberty rights. Conversely, in other cases, religious liberty will trump, and same-sex couples may have to accept that not everyone accepts their relationships as legitimate.

Stern concludes by stating that same-sex couples should not be denied the right to civil marriage, but they should not, without good reason, be allowed to force dissenting religious organizations to recognize or facilitate their marriages.

Title: Texas Gubernatorial Candidate Wendy Davis' Ad Sparks Controversy Over Attack on Paraplegic Opponent Greg Abbott

Article:

In the ongoing Texas gubernatorial race, Democratic candidate Wendy Davis has released a controversial ad that focuses on her Republican opponent, Greg Abbott, and the accident that left him in a wheelchair. The ad, titled "Justice," has sparked criticism from both political opponents and media personalities.

The 30-second spot, released on Friday, notes that Abbott received millions of dollars in a lawsuit after his accident in 1984, but accuses him of not siding with victims like himself during his time in the state Supreme Court or as the Texas attorney general.

MSNBC's "Morning Joe" co-host Mika Brzezinski expressed her disapproval of the ad during a discussion on Monday, stating, "I cringed watching that." She further commented that the ad goes against Davis' "brand" and her positive message.

Despite the criticism, Davis has defended the ad, stating that Abbott has tried to block cases similar to his own. She told CNN affiliate KSAT in San Antonio over the weekend, "He rightfully had an opportunity to access the justice system when he was at the receiving end of a tragic accident, but ever since he's been actively fighting to close that door and deny access to others who have been wronged and who deserve to have their day in court."

Davis' pollster, Joel Benenson, also defended the ad, stating that it is effective and aligns with their campaign strategy. However, Republican strategists argue that the ad is backfiring, with Abbott's camp releasing a video on Monday about the mounting complaints on Davis' ad, stating that she is "unfit to be governor."

Associate professor at Columbia University, Dorian Warren, told "The Morning Joe" show that the ad is a "huge blunder," as Davis, who is losing to Abbott by double digits in state and national polls, is trying to attract voters. Warren stated, "What Wendy Davis needs is to increase voter turnout. Negative ads depress voter turnout. She needs many new voters to come out, and this will not motivate her voters to come out."

Abbott himself has expressed his disapproval of the ad, stating that it is "offensive" and "shows the tenor of the campaign." He also expects the strategy to backfire, stating, "It's her choice if she wants to attack a guy in a wheelchair. I don't think it's going to sell too well."

Texas GOP Sen. John Cornyn and Sen. Ted Cruz have also expressed their disapproval of the ad, with Cornyn stating that it is "way over the line" and calling on Davis to apologize and pull down the ad. The ad has also drawn criticism from Texas Republican lawmakers and media strategists, with some comparing it unfavorably to Todd Akin's controversial comments during the 2012 Missouri Senate race.

Title: U.S. Military Deployment to Southern Border Aims to Assist, Not Stop, Migrant Caravan

Article:

The United States Department of Defense has ordered 800 soldiers to the southern border to assist with the influx of migrants from Central America, as a caravan of approximately 10,000 individuals, primarily from Honduras, makes its way towards the United States. The military presence is not intended to stop the caravan but to support Customs and Border Protection, Immigration and Customs Enforcement, Health and Human Services, and other authorities as they process the newcomers.

The caravan, organized by the group Pueblo Sin Fronteras, is a challenge to national sovereignty, as it represents an unauthorized march towards the U.S. border. The group's goal, in part, is to undermine the concept of sovereignty, as they bear the flag of their homeland rather than the country they seek to enter.

The military's role is to provide logistical and administrative support, not to enforce immigration laws. The government's ability to turn back the tide of illegal immigration is limited due to the same rule of law that incentivizes and protects the illegal immigrants within the caravan.

Congress, however, has the authority to address the issue by closing the loopholes that have facilitated recent illegal migration. These loopholes include provisions of the 2008 Trafficking Victims Protection Reauthorization Act, the 1997 Flores settlement, and the "credible fear" standard for asylum requests.

The character of illegal immigration has changed in recent years. While the population of Mexicans living illegally in the United States has declined, the overall figure has stabilized due to rising living standards in Mexico and improved immigration enforcement. The new illegal immigration is primarily families fleeing violence and instability in Central America, rather than single males seeking economic opportunities in the United States.

The changing nature of illegal immigration was first evident in the child migration crisis of 2014, and the election of Donald Trump has not significantly reduced illegal border crossings. The first caravan of this year is just one example of the ongoing issue.

The humanitarian instinct is a powerful force in American immigration policy, but it has unintentionally contributed to a mounting crisis that benefits no nation. The desire to help strangers has led to inadequate responses to the issue, and calls for congressional action are growing louder.

Amending the 2008 law to accelerate repatriations, addressing Flores in legislation that permits indefinite detention of family units, and tightening asylum standards are among the solutions being proposed. Providing more funding for resources to speed up legal proceedings and announcing a clear, unequivocal stance on immigration policy may help address the issue more effectively.

In addition, the construction of a border wall remains a contentious topic in the ongoing debate on immigration policy. Regardless of one's stance on the wall, it is clear that the current situation requires a comprehensive, congressionally-led solution.

Title: Obama Aims to Shift Discourse and Present Vision for Second Term in Acceptance Speech

Article:

In his acceptance speech for the Democratic Party's renomination, President Barack Obama will seek to transition from a message of hope and change to one of progress and accomplishment. However, due to an anticipated jobs report the following day showing U.S. unemployment above 8 percent for the 43rd consecutive month, Obama will avoid sounding triumphant.

Martin Medhurst, a professor of political science and rhetoric at Baylor University, explains, "In an acceptance situation, you want to paint a bright picture of all the wonderful things that have happened over the past four years." While good things have indeed occurred during Obama's term, the economic situation makes it challenging for him to present a particularly bright picture.

Aside from criticizing his opponent, Republican Mitt Romney, Obama's main tasks include convincing voters that another four years in office will lead to further achievements. Minneapolis Mayor R.T. Rybak, a vice chairman of the Democratic National Committee, points to several accomplishments Obama is likely to highlight: bailing out the domestic auto industry, expanding health coverage for millions of Americans, reshaping the student loan business, ending the war in Iraq, winding down the war in Afghanistan, and authorizing the mission that killed Osama bin Laden.

Rybak asserts, "He's delivered and is going to deliver a lot more than Mitt Romney can ever dream of doing." Attacks on Romney's platform will be a recurring theme in Obama's speech, as he seeks to frame the election as a choice rather than a referendum on his own record.

George C. Edwards III, a presidential scholar at Texas A&M University, suggests that Obama will argue that a Romney administration would jeopardize the middle class. Obama will also draw parallels with Franklin D. Roosevelt's 1936 renomination acceptance speech, portraying himself as an advocate for the middle class while depicting Romney as favoring the wealthy.

Raising the stakes by painting a dire picture of a Romney presidency may help energize the Democratic base, which has been less enthusiastic about this election compared to Obama's 2008 campaign. David Woodard, a Republican consultant and professor at Clemson University, states, "He's been president for four years, and I'm not sure the average person right now could answer the question, 'What does Barack Obama want to do in a second term that would have a better result?'"

The theme of the Democratic National Convention has been "Forward." Obama will need to answer the question, "Forward to what?" Michael Waldman, a former speechwriter for President Bill Clinton and president of the Brennan Center for Justice at New York University's law school, explains, "The challenge for Obama is that he needs to put out, much more than he has, a strong vision for what he wants to do in a second term."

This vision should not be an idealized vision of what Obama would do if Democrats had complete control, but rather, a realistic depiction of what people could expect from him if elected for a second term.

Title: Unpopular Candidates: A Look at the 2016 Presidential Race

Article:

The current state of the 2016 presidential race, as summarized by a recent headline in the Los Angeles Times, poses a question: "A Trump-Clinton general election poses a question: Which one does America hate less?" The two presumptive candidates, Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump, are generally disliked by most voters, consistently recording negative favorability ratings this year.

Donald Trump, the Republican candidate, has been successful in the primaries, winning 27 delegates in the Republican primary in Washington state on May 24th. However, he is the most unpopular candidate overall in recent times. According to YouGov's latest poll, he is viewed unfavorably across various demographic groups, including gender, age, race, and income. Clinton, while receiving more favorable ratings, is only viewed favorably by blacks and Hispanics in these categories.

The protracted primaries and party squabbles have not helped the candidates' images. Candidates often become more popular once they secure the nomination, as happened with John Kerry in 2004, and their image changes from contender to victor. This is not always the case, as Mitt Romney was viewed unfavorably throughout most of his run in 2012, only receiving a small boost once he won the Republican nomination. In September that year, two months before the election, he still had a negative favorability rating in Gallup polling, the only presidential candidate from either party to gain that distinction at that stage of campaigning since at least 1988.

This year will be different, as the race will feature not one but two unpopular candidates. Just a third of Americans have a favorable view of Donald Trump. Clinton does slightly better at 40%, but she might take heart from her husband's campaign. Bill Clinton had a negative favorability rating throughout the spring and early summer of 1992, but it jumped from 41% to 62% when the Democratic National Convention got underway. Clinton will be looking for a similar boost, contingent on Bernie Sanders' campaign, at the Democratic National Convention in Philadelphia in July.

Title: Multiple Police Officers Shot in Three States in Single Day

Article:

A series of shootings targeting police officers occurred in three states on Sunday, resulting in the death of a 20-year veteran San Antonio police detective and injuries to several other officers. The shootings, which appear to be unconnected, involved law enforcement officers sitting unsuspectingly in their patrol cars, either waiting in traffic or after pulling vehicles over for traffic stops.

In San Antonio, Texas, a man is suspected of executing Detective Benjamin Marconi, 50, at 11:45 a.m. local time. The suspect is believed to have staked out police headquarters just hours before the shooting and briefly gained access to a vestibule of the building before quickly leaving. The man is being sought by police and is described as driving a 2009-2012 black Mitsubishi Galant with black rims.

San Antonio authorities have released video surveillance footage showing the suspect outside police headquarters. He is seen speaking to a clerk on an intercom before being let in to a vestibule, but he only stayed a short time before leaving. The suspect asked a question, but the content of the conversation remains undisclosed.

Four hours later, the man is suspected of killing Marconi as he sat in his patrol car across from police headquarters, writing a traffic ticket. A vehicle thought to be driven by the suspect pulled up behind Marconi, and a man got out and shot Marconi twice in the head. The final shot was fired as the assailant reached inside Marconi's passenger window to shoot the father of two at close range.

In St. Louis, Missouri, a sergeant was shot twice in the face at 7:30 p.m. Sunday night and is expected to survive, although he is hospitalized in critical condition. The 46-year-old officer, whose name has not been released, is a married father of three and a 20-year veteran of the force.

In Sanibel, Florida, an officer was shot and injured during a similar incident when a person fired at the officer as he sat in his patrol car after finishing a traffic stop just before 8 p.m. Other officers fired back at the suspect, who was eventually taken into custody.

In Gladstone, Missouri, an officer sustained non-life-threatening injuries during a struggle with a man in his late teens who had fled from a traffic stop. During the tussle, the man revealed a handgun, shots were fired, and the teen was killed.

The shootings come less than five months after a gunman killed five officers in Dallas who were working a protest about the fatal police shootings of black men in Minnesota and Louisiana. It was the deadliest day for American law enforcement since September 11, 2001.

Ten days after the Dallas attack, a man wearing a ski mask and armed with two rifles and a pistol killed three officers near a gas station and convenience store in Baton Rouge, Louisiana. Earlier this month, two Des Moines, Iowa-area police officers were fatally shot in separate ambush-style attacks while sitting in their patrol cars.

In 2016, 56 state, county, and local officers have been shot while on duty.

Title: Secret Service Expands Protective Detail for Trump Administration Members, Affecting New York Field Office

Article:

The United States Secret Service is providing round-the-clock protective details to the spouses and children of President Donald Trump's adult children, as well as several top aides, including Reince Priebus, H.R. McMaster, and Kellyanne Conway, at the president's request. This expansion of the protective detail, beyond the top officials and immediate family required by statute, is expected to ease slightly this summer with the expected cessation of regular protection for former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and his wife, as well as President Obama's eldest daughter.

With several of the new protectees residing in New York, the Secret Service may eventually establish a fully staffed branch of the presidential protection division in the city, relocating agents from across the country. However, for now, as it awaits a potential move to Washington by First Lady Melania Trump and President Trump's youngest son, Barron, the agency is flying agents in from around the country, a less common practice for a routine nonelection detail. This arrangement necessitates the agency's payment for hotel rooms, transportation, and living expenses at Manhattan prices, according to the officials.

The Secret Service is also renting space inside Trump Tower for offices and temporary sleeping quarters, two officials said, though the details of the transaction have not been made public. The New York field office appears to have been particularly hard hit, with a third of the agents involved in protection on a given day. This has diminished the kind of protective intelligence, financial crime, and cybercrime cases that normally make up the bulk of their work, according to a former agency official briefed on its staffing. Such investigative work is seen within the agency as crucial to not only building agents' skills and combating crime, but also sharpening their protection abilities.

James F. Tomsheck, who left the agency in 2006 after 23 years, stated, "Essentially the Secret Service is in a campaign mode all of the time right now. It will greatly degrade the quality of life for most agents in the Secret Service, because of increased travel, protracted periods of time away from family."

Title: Kamala Harris' Proposed Equal Pay Policy Under Scrutiny for Methodology and Potential Burdens

Article:

Democratic Senator Kamala Harris, a presidential hopeful, has proposed a plan titled "Holding Corporations Accountable for Pay Inequality in America." The plan aims to achieve "equal pay for equal work," but the methodology used to calculate the pay gap has come under scrutiny.

In her report, Harris claims that women who work full-time are paid, on average, 80 cents for every dollar paid to men. However, this calculation is based on median earnings for all workers who work 35 hours or more a week for the full year. This methodology does not compare women with men who perform the same jobs, work the same number of hours, and have the same education.

Economist Claudia Goldin's work, whose research is widely recognized on the left, has shown that when measured properly, the remaining small pay gap is not primarily the result of discrimination. Instead, Goldin finds that women demand "temporal flexibility," which refers to anything that leads to a desire for more time. This can include caring for children or aging parents, which requires more flexibility in the workplace, leading to differences in job selection for women and men.

The proposal suggests that employers with more than 100 workers would have to prove to a federal bureaucrat that they are not paying women less than men for work of equal value. If they fail to do so, they would have to pay the government "1% of their profits for every 1% wage gap they allow to persist."

Critics argue that this policy would create a bureaucratic nightmare, requiring businesses to prove that their employees are paid according to their performance reviews and tasks. The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, which Harris would task with the certification, would need to add several hundred bureaucrats to its current staff of 2,300 employees to certify everyone in a timely fashion.

Labor attorneys could potentially benefit from the new litigation resulting from disagreements between the commission and businesses. The proposal could also lead to employers reducing the number of women they employ or scaling back on flexibility to minimize wage gaps, potentially infringing on workers' rights to temporal flexibility.

While it is common for candidates on the campaign trail to propose controversial policies, this proposal has raised concerns about its methodology and potential burdens on businesses and the workforce.

Title: TIME Magazine Disputes Trump's Claim of Being Offered "Person of the Year" 2017

Article:

TIME Magazine has refuted President Donald Trump's claim that he was likely to be named the magazine's 2017 "Person of the Year." The magazine has opened an unofficial public poll for readers to vote on who should receive the honor. Trump was named "Person of the Year" in 2016.

In a tweet on Friday, TIME Magazine stated that Trump's assertion about being offered the title was incorrect. "The President is incorrect about how we choose Person of the Year," the magazine tweeted. "TIME does not comment on our choice until publication, which is December 6."

Earlier in the day, Trump tweeted that he had declined the offer after the magazine reached out to him, citing editorial obligations. "Time Magazine called to say that I was PROBABLY going to be named 'Man (Person) of the Year,' like last year," Trump said in his tweet. "But I would have to agree to an interview and a major photo shoot. I said probably is no good and took a pass. Thanks anyway!"

Alan Murray, chief content officer of Time Inc., also disputed Trump's claims, tweeting Friday night, "Amazing. Not a speck of truth here."

Trump, who won the award in 2016, took issue with the magazine's coverage that year, as the magazine published his picture on the cover with the title "PRESIDENT OF THE DIVIDED STATES OF AMERICA."

In the unofficial public poll, Trump is currently tied for third place at 5% of the vote, along with the hashtag "#MeToo" and "The Dreamers" – undocumented immigrants who were brought to the US. As of this post, Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia is ranked No. 1 with 21% of the vote.

Title: Trump Approved of Uighur Muslim Concentration Camps in China, According to Bolton's Memoir

Article:

Former National Security Advisor John Bolton's upcoming memoir, "The Room Where It Happened," claims that President Donald Trump expressed approval of a concentration camp for Uighur Muslims in China during a private meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping. The meeting took place during the 2019 G20 meeting in Japan, according to Bolton's book.

In the private meeting, which was attended only by the leaders and their interpreters, Xi reportedly explained to Trump why he was constructing concentration camps in Xinjiang. The interpreter added that Trump said Xi should proceed with building the camps, which Trump believed was the right thing to do, according to the book.

Bolton also wrote that Matthew Pottinger, a retired US Marine and the current deputy national security adviser, told him that Trump made a similar statement during his November 2017 trip to China.

The Chinese Communist Party has been criticized for constructing large concentration camps in Xinjiang, where millions of ethnic minority Uighur Muslims are believed to be detained under the guise of a counterterrorism campaign. Inside the camps, approximately 2 million to 3 million Uighur Muslims are under surveillance and subject to mandatory "reeducation" training.

The camps have been criticized by the White House, and lawmakers from both parties have condemned the practice. Trump recently signed a bipartisan bill, the Uyghur Human Rights Policy Act, which calls for sanctions against officials involved with the camps.

The Chinese Communist Party has denied the mistreatment of Uighur Muslims and claims that the allegations "blatantly smear China's counterterrorism and deradicalization measures and seriously interfere in China's internal affairs."

Bolton's book has caused a stir in Washington and the political sphere. In the memoir, Bolton accuses the House of Representatives of "impeachment malpractice" and claims that Trump engaged in far more objectionable conduct than what he was impeached for.

The book also describes Trump's efforts to persuade Xi to purchase US agricultural products to help him win reelection in 2020. According to Bolton, Trump emphasized the importance of farmers and increased Chinese purchases of soybeans and wheat in the electoral outcome.

Bolton's book is set to be released on June 23.

Title: Trump's National Security Strategy Emphasizes Economic Prosperity, Trade, and Tax Reform

Article:

In a speech on Monday, President Trump outlined a new national security strategy that places U.S. economic issues at the center of U.S. foreign policy. The strategy, which is the first comprehensive update of U.S. foreign policy since 2015, is built on four pillars: protecting the American people at home, promoting economic prosperity, preserving peace through a strong military, and advancing American interests abroad.

The strategy aims to balance competing objectives, emphasizing political and economic competition with countries like Russia and China, while also enlisting their help with security challenges like North Korea's nuclear program. Trump stated, "While we seek such opportunities of cooperation, we will stand up for ourselves, and we will stand up for our country like we have never stood up before."

In his speech, Trump criticized his predecessors, particularly President Barack Obama, for negotiating "disastrous trade deals," neglecting the North Korea crisis, making a "bad nuclear deal" with Iran, and allowing the Islamic State to gain a foothold in Iraq and Syria. The strategy is characterized by economic nationalism, with Trump boasting low unemployment numbers and a soaring stock market.

The strategy places more emphasis on the business climate than on climate change, a key focus of Obama's last national security strategy document. The strategy states that the United States will counter "an anti-growth energy agenda that is detrimental to U.S. economic and energy security interests." The strategy also places an emphasis on cyber-security, although it reduces the extent of Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election to just a couple of lines in the written report.

Trump described Russia and China as "revisionist powers" intent on changing the global status quo by illegitimately seizing territory. China's unique economic and military clout makes it what the report calls a "strategic competitor." However, the strategy does not rule out cooperation with these countries when their interests align.

In other areas, Trump attempts to expand the concept of national security as encompassing fair trade, tax reform, and deregulation. The strategy also promotes the idea of a "national security innovation base," a term coined by Trump trade adviser Peter Navarro to describe the technology and other intellectual property that gives the United States a strategic and economic advantage in the world.

Title: Empathy and Compassion: A Study on Interpersonal Relations and the Impact of Personal Encounters

Article:

A study conducted by sociologist Richard LaPiere in 1934, documented in the journal American Journal of Sociology, provides insight into the human tendency to exhibit more compassion and empathy towards others in personal encounters compared to abstract situations. The study involved a Chinese couple traveling across the United States, where they were met with unexpectedly minimal instances of racism, despite the prevalent overt racism against Chinese people during that time.

In the experiment, the couple was denied service only once at 251 hotels and restaurants. However, the most surprising finding was that, after the study, only one establishment indicated a willingness to serve "members of the Chinese race." Ninety-two percent of the establishments stated they would not serve Chinese people, with the remaining respondents uncertain.

This study suggests that people may be more hostile towards others in abstract, theoretical situations than in personal, face-to-face interactions. This phenomenon can be observed in various aspects of society, such as the increased endorsement of gay rights when individuals realize they have gay relatives or colleagues.

To foster more compassion and empathy in America today, the article suggests adopting a proactive approach. Individuals are encouraged to emulate figures like Tommy Gunn and Hawk Newsome, inviting those perceived as "other" into their personal or professional spheres. Engaging in open dialogue and sharing personal experiences can help break down barriers and promote understanding.

The article further proposes a national movement of American renewal, celebrating leaders who venture into unfamiliar territory and supporting institutions dedicated to respectful ideological discourse. Additionally, it encourages supporting news outlets that combat anonymous hatred, even if it may not be financially profitable.

While the idea of such a movement may seem radical, the study and the rally in Washington, as depicted in a YouTube video, offer evidence that it may indeed be possible to foster more compassion and empathy in society.

Title: Parents Encouraged to Inquire About School Safety Plans After Georgia Elementary School Shooting

Article:

In the aftermath of a recent shooting at an elementary school in Decatur, Georgia, parents are being urged to take a proactive approach when it comes to their children's school safety plans. The incident, which occurred barely over a week into the new school year, involved a gunman armed with an assault rifle. Fortunately, the gunman was apprehended before any injuries or fatalities occurred.

To ensure the safety of their children, parents should ask their school administrators the following questions:

1. Does the school have a crisis response plan customized for its campus?
2. Does the school regularly practice basic school safety drills such as lockdowns, shelter-in-place, and evacuations?
3. What should parents do in case of an emergency at the school?
4. Have both staff and students received training on what to do during an active shooter incident?
5. Has the school partnered with its local law enforcement agency to practice emergency response procedures?

It is crucial for schools to have a crisis response plan tailored to their unique characteristics, demographics, and personnel. Regular practice of safety drills is essential to a strong school safety plan, with most school safety experts advising campuses to practice such drills at least once per semester.

Parents should also be informed of their role during a school crisis, including whom to contact, where to go, and what to do upon arrival. Many school districts require proper identification for parents to pick up their child during a nontraditional release, such as an evacuation.

In addition to administrators and teachers knowing what to do during a school crisis, it is equally important for students to be trained in survival techniques. Parents should inquire about the training provided to staff and students, as well as any materials offered for additional practice at home.

Collaboration between schools and local law enforcement agencies is also essential for comprehensive school safety plans. When school and law enforcement plans are not in sync, important procedures that could save lives may be overlooked.

Parents are encouraged to take the necessary measures to ensure their child's school is prepared and equipped to handle emergencies, such as shootings, in the safest and most effective manner possible.

Title: Gallup Study Highlights Millennial Job Expectations and Engagement Levels

Article:

A recent study by polling firm Gallup suggests that the job expectations and engagement levels of millennials differ significantly from previous generations. The study, which surveyed workers from various generations, found that millennials are less engaged in their jobs, with 55 percent reporting they are "checked out" and lack passion and energy for their work. This is in contrast to 29 percent of millennials who report active engagement, the lowest figure among the four generations tracked in the survey.

The study attributes the job-hopping tendency among millennials to their emphasis on finding fulfilling work rather than just high-paying jobs. Millennials prioritize opportunities to learn and grow, quality of management, interest in the type of work, and opportunities for advancement over income when looking for a new job. Eighty-seven percent of millennials said personal development is an important characteristic in a job, and fewer millennials than other generations said they would pursue a different line of work for a raise.

The study also found that millennials have a higher turnover rate, with 21 percent changing jobs last year, and 60 percent saying they are currently open to a change in employment. This is three times more than non-millennials. The increased emphasis on jobs with meaning and the potential for personal development comes as the younger generation eschews conventional societal institutions, such as family and the church.

The Gallup survey found that just 27 percent of millennials are married, compared to 36 percent of Gen Xers, 48 percent of baby boomers, and 65 percent of traditionalists who were married at that stage in their lives. Additionally, the survey notes that just 55 percent of millennials report having interest in religion, compared to 65 percent of Gen Xers, 70 percent of baby boomers, and 75 percent of traditionalists.

Greg Jao, vice president of campus engagement for InterVarsity Christian Fellowship, suggests that the capricious employment habits of young people entering the workforce can be interpreted as a winding search for meaning. He believes that millennials are looking for people who help provide meaning and coherence to their experiences. Mr. Jao also points to the ascendance of activism on college campuses as a similar attempt by young people to belong to groups that transmit a sense of purpose greater than oneself.

Title: Key Players in Government Shutdown Remain Divided on Budget and Immigration Issues

Article:

Three days after a debate over federal spending and immigration policy led to a government shutdown, key battles between Democrats and Republicans remained unresolved on Tuesday. The compromise, which ended the shutdown and returned hundreds of thousands of federal employees to work after they were furloughed on Monday, comes at a time of profound political polarization in Washington, when trust across the aisle is in short supply.

On Monday, President Donald Trump signed a short-term spending measure after Senate Democrats agreed on legislation to fund the government for three weeks, in exchange for a commitment to vote on ensuring protection for Dreamers, young undocumented migrants who were brought to the US as children.

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell reiterated on Tuesday that he intended to allow debate on immigration legislation that would protect Dreamers. The offer was conditional on the government remaining open, a tactical move to ward off another shutdown in three weeks.

Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer parried criticism on Tuesday, insisting that the Democratic leadership was "pleased" by the outcome of what was an audacious gambit to force Republicans' hand on immigration. He told reporters that Democrats were "a lot better off today when it comes to the cause of Dreamers than we were four or five days ago."

However, even if the Senate does act, there is no guarantee the House Republican leadership will follow. The deal was enough to win support from 33 Senate Democrats, who joined 48 Republicans to reopen the government on Monday night. Sixteen progressive Democrats voted against the measure, including Senator Kamala Harris of California, who said it would be "foolhardy" to trust McConnell.

The path to a bipartisan immigration solution that satisfies Democrats' desire for Dreamer protections, Republicans' requirement for increased border security, and Trump's demand for a wall seemed as distant as ever on Tuesday. An inchoate effort to restart negotiations was underway in the Senate without clear direction or leadership. Several senators on Tuesday said the current state of negotiations was unmoored from an earlier bipartisan effort that paired increased border security and tighter controls on immigration with a Dream Act, legislation that would offer a conditional path to citizenship for certain undocumented people.

Title: California Schools Prepare for Potential Coronavirus Outbreaks, Review Emergency Plans

Article:

Education officials in California are reviewing and updating emergency plans in response to the potential spread of the new coronavirus. Federal officials have urged schools to start considering contingency plans for local outbreaks, as the virus has been detected in countries outside China, indicating that containment efforts have been breached and it is likely to spread in the United States.

On Wednesday, a Solano County resident tested positive for the virus, marking the first case in the country from an unknown source. In response, the Fairfield-Suisin Unified School District, located in Solano County, has increased disinfection efforts, recommending daily cleaning of commonly shared surfaces to prevent the spread of the virus.

Dr. Nancy Messonnier, director of the National Center for Immunization and Respiratory Diseases, stated that as the virus is likely to spread across communities, closing schools, holding classes in smaller groups, or remote education via the internet are all possibilities. She emphasized the need for individuals and families to start thinking about these scenarios now.

In a 2017 advisory regarding a flu pandemic, the Center for Disease Control suggested that closing schools before flu becomes widespread in schools and communities can help slow the spread of disease. Schools might also close if many staff and students are sick and regular school functions cannot be maintained.

Parents are encouraged to consider what to do if schools are closed or classes are held remotely in their community. Messonnier advised families to think about childcare arrangements if schools or daycares close. She also noted that many children in China are attending school remotely, but most schools in the Bay Area or across the country would not be able to conduct classes online due to a lack of computer or internet access for many students.

School districts are required to have emergency plans for earthquakes, fires, active shooters, and other critical events. In recent years, pandemic flu plans for communicable diseases like the coronavirus have been added to these emergency plans. For example, the pandemic influenza plan in Tulare County includes county guidance to close a school if more than 30% of students are ill.

State and county officials have been providing guidance to California school districts about how to deal with a potential outbreak. San Francisco schools spokeswoman Laura Dudnick stated that they are planning for how to manage in the case of an exposure at a school. The state Department of Education has already advised schools to bar travelers from mainland China from school grounds for 14 days.

In Contra Costa County, three people who have tested positive for coronavirus are currently being monitored in hospitals. However, there is no evidence that the virus is circulating in the county. Contra Costa County Office of Education spokesman Terry Koehne stated that they are working on a plan with health services to respond if any of their schools are at risk of becoming impacted.

The California Department of Education is monitoring the situation and working closely with agency partners to determine the best steps to be prepared. Any decisions to close schools as a result of the coronavirus would be made by individual county health agencies and school districts.
