Title: Potential Record-Breaking Gender Voting Gap in 2016 Presidential Election

Article:

The upcoming 2016 presidential election could witness a significant gender voting gap, potentially the largest in at least 60 years. Since 1996, women have consistently voted more heavily for Democratic candidates in presidential elections, with the most substantial gap occurring in 2000, when Al Gore received a 10-point advantage among women, while George W. Bush received an 11-point lead among men, resulting in a 21-point total gap.

Recent national polls suggest that the gender gap in this year's election could be even wider. An average of three recent polls indicates that women favor Hillary Clinton by approximately 13 points, while men prefer Donald Trump by 12 points, totaling a 25-point gap.

While it may seem logical that this kind of gender gap is occurring in the first election featuring a female major-party presidential candidate, it is not necessarily due to women flocking to Clinton. Instead, research indicates that party identification plays a more significant role in voting decisions. In fact, Clinton may not win women by as large a margin as her husband did in 1996.

Another factor contributing to the gender gap is not so much Clinton attracting women as Trump repelling them. Trump's overt sexism and comments about assaulting women have turned off even conservative white evangelical women, while his campaign's overtly masculine image may help explain his appeal to men.

Neither gender is a monolithic voting bloc, with various fissures dividing either group (single women vote more Democratic than married women, for example, and white-collar white men are less Republican than blue-collar white men). However, 2016 could be unusual among white women, as they swung Democratic only once since the 1960s, in 1996. This year, polls suggest white women could swing Democratic for the first time in 20 years, though they currently lean slightly Republican.

While whites make up nearly three-quarters of the electorate, their choices will help drive the broader gender gap depicted in the first chart. However, it appears less likely that the white gender gap will be as historic as the one seen nationwide, across all races.

Title: South Korean President Moon Jae-in Suggests President Trump for Nobel Peace Prize

Article:

South Korean President Moon Jae-in has suggested that U.S. President Donald Trump should receive the Nobel Peace Prize for his role in facilitating talks aimed at denuclearizing the Korean peninsula and potentially ending the Korean War. Moon's comments came following a message from Lee Hee-ho, the widow of late South Korean President Kim Dae-jung, who suggested Moon himself should win the prize for his work with North Korea.

Moon made the comments during a meeting with senior secretaries, according to a Korean official who briefed the media. "President Trump should win the Nobel Peace Prize," Moon reportedly said. "What we need is only peace."

The suggestion for Trump's Nobel Peace Prize nomination comes just days after Moon met with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un for a summit at the Peace House in Panmunjom. Trump also continued to play an active role on Monday, floating the possibility of holding his expected summit with Kim at the same location.

During the summit, the Korean leaders announced their commitment to achieving a "nuclear-free Korean Peninsula" and expressed hope to officially end the 1950-53 Korean War by the end of the year. However, it is not yet clear whether this will happen.

The leaders also agreed to suspend loudspeaker propaganda broadcasts and dismantle broadcasting equipment along the heavily-armed border, as well as to stop flying propaganda leaflets across their border. Kim also promised Moon that he "won't interrupt" his "early morning sleep anymore," referring to missile tests.

During the summit, the Korean leaders agreed to jointly push for talks with the United States and potentially China to officially end the war. They also agreed to stop all hostile acts over "land, sea, and air" that cause military clashes and tensions.

The date for Trump's expected summit with Kim has not yet been scheduled. Last week, Trump criticized the Obama administration for allowing the situation in North Korea to escalate, while calling former Secretary of State John Kerry the "worst negotiator" he'd "ever seen."

Earlier this year, Moon applauded Trump, noting he "deserves big credit for bringing about the inter-Korean talks." Trump has imposed what his administration describes as "the heaviest sanctions ever imposed on a country" on North Korea, crippling the DPRK's economy. The Treasury Department aims to cut off sources of revenue and fuel used to boost the country's nuclear program and military.

Title: Senate Democrats Request Explanation of Potential Conflicts of Interest for Whitaker and Benczkowski

Article:

Senate Democrats have requested an explanation from the Justice Department regarding potential conflicts of interest involving Acting Attorney General Matthew Whitaker and Assistant Attorney General Brian Benczkowski. The letter, signed by a group of 11 Democratic senators, focuses on more than $1.2 million in compensation received by Whitaker from an organization that has sued Democratic lawmakers in the past, and Benczkowski's history working on behalf of a Russian bank.

The senators, including Sheldon Whitehouse (D-R.I.), Dianne Feinstein (D-Calif.), Patrick Leahy (D-Vt.), Dick Durbin (D-Ill.), Ron Wyden (D-Ore.), Amy Klobuchar (D-Minn.), Chris Coons (D-Del.), Richard Blumenthal (D-Conn.), Mazie Hirono (D-Hawaii), Cory Booker (D-N.J.), and Kamala Harris (D-Calif.), expressed ethical concerns, particularly regarding special counsel Robert Mueller's investigation into Russian meddling in the 2016 election.

The senators stated that previous DOJ responses to requests for information on these officials were heavily redacted. They noted that some of these requests were renewed because the DOJ had either failed to respond or provided incomplete responses to prior congressional requests. The senators urged the DOJ to provide prompt, complete, and public responses to the issues they raised to maintain public trust in an impartial DOJ.

Whitaker assumed the top job at the Justice Department after President Donald Trump pushed out Attorney General Jeff Sessions in early November. Trump had been angry with Sessions for recusing himself from overseeing Mueller's investigation. Whitaker has not recused himself from the investigation, though he promised House Democrats that he would not tamper with its integrity.

As a private lawyer, Benczkowski represented Alfa Bank, whose owners have been identified by the Treasury Department as oligarchs with close ties to the Russian government, according to the letter. Senate Democrats criticized Benczkowski's nomination and confirmation, though he said at the time he would recuse himself from any investigations related to the bank.

Title: St. Louis Police Officer's Association Calls for NFL Discipline Over Rams Players' "Hands Up, Don't Shoot" Display

Article:

The St. Louis Police Officer's Association (SLPOA) has requested the National Football League (NFL) to discipline the St. Louis Rams players who participated in "hands up, don't shoot" displays during Sunday's game. The SLPOA considers the displays as "tasteless, offensive, and inflammatory."

In a statement, the SLPOA stated that five Rams players, including Jared Cook, Kenny Britt, Stedman Bailey, Chris Givens, and Tavon Austin from the team's receiving corps, as well as rookie running back Tre Mason, made the gesture during pregame introductions and after scoring a touchdown, respectively.

The Rams defeated the Oakland Raiders 52-0 at the Edward Jones Dome in St. Louis on Sunday. The team has denied any prior knowledge of the on-field demonstrations.

Last week, a grand jury declined to indict Darren Wilson, the Ferguson police officer involved in the shooting of Michael Brown, a teenager who was involved in a convenience-store robbery prior to his death. The decision led to riots, looting, and violence in Ferguson, Missouri. Wilson resigned from the Ferguson police force over the weekend.

Jeff Roorda, a representative of the SLPOA, noted, "Our officers have been working 12-hour shifts for over a week. They had days off including Thanksgiving cancelled so that they could defend this community from those on the streets that perpetuate this myth that Michael Brown was executed by a brother police officer and then, as the players and their fans sit safely in their dome under the watchful protection of hundreds of St. Louis's finest, they take to the turf to call a now-exonerated officer a murderer. That is way out-of-bounds, to put it in football parlance."

Title: Trump's Proposed Wall Along U.S.-Mexico Border Faces Skepticism from Border Residents

Article:

BROWNSVILLE, Texas — The proposal to build a wall along the U.S.-Mexico border, a key component of Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump's campaign, has faced skepticism from residents in this southernmost U.S. city. The current fence, erected in 2009 through the 2006 Secure Fence Act, has been largely ineffective in stemming the flow of undocumented immigrants and drugs, according to residents, community leaders, and border patrol officials.

Bonnie Elbert, a politically conservative resident whose family has tended citrus farms in the area since the 1920s, questions the feasibility of a new wall. "The one we have doesn't really work," Elbert said, driving through Loop Farms, more than 700 acres of orange and grapefruit orchards. "What makes them think a new one will?"

The current fence, which is nearly continuous along the border with Arizona, New Mexico, and California, due to long stretches of federal land, is chopped up into multiple sections in Texas due to the state's border with Mexico being mostly private property. Donald Trump has suggested building only about 1,000 miles of the proposed wall, citing natural barriers.

However, the current fence has sparked costly legal fights with property owners, disrupted communities that straddle the border, and proven largely ineffective in preventing illegal crossings, according to residents, community leaders, and border patrol officials. Whoever pays for it, a newer, bigger wall would waste more money and be just as futile in preventing illegal crossings, Brownsville Mayor Tony Martinez said.

Border Patrol union has endorsed Trump due to his focus on border security and immigration reform. Chris Cabrera, a McAllen-based border patrol agent and vice president of the local chapter of the National Border Patrol Council, the agents' union, noted that the concept of building a bigger wall without other measures, such as increased manpower and technology, is ill-informed.

The security fence project also ran into a litany of private property lawsuits and environmental opposition that ran up costs and led to delays, said Denise Gilman, director of the Immigration Clinic at the University of Texas-Austin School of Law, who has studied the fence's impact on the border. Most of the land along the Texas border is privately owned, making it much harder for the federal government to acquire and build on, she said.

The current wall snakes through the Rio Grande Valley just south of Highway 281, at times cutting right through residents' lawns, and through old town Brownsville, where some of the city's most historic buildings sit. The fence has broken up the continuity and goodwill between Brownsville and Matamoros, its sister city across the river in Mexico, and created an eyesore that rankles most locals. Across the river, Mexicans call it "El Berlin," alluding to the 27-mile concrete wall that once divided East and West Berlin during the Cold War.

Title: Historical Hostility Towards Hillary Clinton: A Look at the Roots of Public Disapproval

Article:

A sense of untrustworthiness has long been associated with Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton, but the origins of this hostility run deeper than the current election cycle. There exists a dedicated group of individuals who, despite not personally knowing Clinton, hold strong negative sentiments towards her. Whether these individuals constitute a "vast right-wing conspiracy" as Clinton described in 1998 or simply represent a large conservative demographic, their existence and influence is undeniable.

Clinton's unfavorability rating may not match that of her Republican counterpart, Donald Trump, but she has attracted criticism from both the left and the right throughout the 2016 election. Polls have consistently cited the public's lack of trust in Clinton, while Trump has rallied his supporters with the "Crooked Hillary" epithet.

The 2016 election has seen attacks on Clinton related to her links to Wall Street, her missing emails, and her supposed responsibility for the security failures that contributed to the attack on the Benghazi consulate. However, the roots of hostility towards Clinton go much further back.

Craig Shirley, a Ronald Reagan biographer and historian who spent decades as a conservative political consultant, noted that when Hillary Clinton arrived in Washington D.C. as First Lady, she came with a reputation as a "militant feminist, difficult to deal with." Shirley explained that she faced hostility in Arkansas politics and media when Bill Clinton was first elected governor, due to her keeping her maiden name.

Shirley attributed Clinton's perceived manner, persona, voice, and smirk as potential reasons for the hostility she faced. He suggested that people do not like to be talked down to, and Clinton has a habit of speaking condescendingly to people.

Elaine Kamarck, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution who served in Bill Clinton's administration, offered a different perspective. She argued that people's dislike of Hillary Clinton is not her own fault, but rather a product of societal expectations and media portrayals. Kamarck suggested that Clinton reminds people of their mothers or schoolteachers they did not like, and that there is an element of misogyny in this dislike.

Kamarck noted that it is rare for men who do not conform to conventional standards of attractiveness to be on television or pursue political careers, while women are more likely to be granted visibility when they are younger and meet traditional beauty standards. She added that the world is accustomed to viewing old men as strong and wise, while old women are not.

In conclusion, the hostility towards Hillary Clinton has a long and complex history, rooted in societal expectations, media portrayals, and personal interactions. While the specific reasons for this hostility may vary, the consistent theme is a lack of trust and likability towards Clinton, which has persisted throughout her political career.

Title: Grand Jury Convened in Russia Election Meddling Investigation Signals Expansion of Mueller Probe

Article:

Special counsel Robert Mueller has requested a grand jury in Washington, D.C., to investigate Russia's interference in the 2016 election, signaling a significant expansion of the probe into potential collusion between the Trump campaign and Russia. This development indicates that the investigation has moved from investigating potential collusion to potentially charging individuals with crimes.

The call for a grand jury is typically made to enable prosecutors to subpoena documents, ensure witnesses testify under oath, and formally charge someone with a crime if they deem it necessary. The move to involve a grand jury suggests that there is still much more to investigate over the next few months.

CNN reports that the special counsel has found the financial ties between Trump associates and Russia to be among the most fruitful areas of investigation. Since taking over the probe in May, Mueller has hired 16 lawyers with expertise in multiple areas including cybercrime, white-collar crime, and financial crime.

Stephen Vladeck, a law professor at the University of Texas, told the Wall Street Journal, "This is yet a further sign that there is a long-term, large-scale series of prosecutions being contemplated and being pursued by the special counsel." Vladeck added, "This suggests that the investigation is bigger and wider than Flynn, perhaps substantially so."

The growing inquiry poses another problem for President Trump: it becomes increasingly difficult for him to dismiss Mueller. As the investigation intensifies, it would appear unwise for Trump to ask Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein to remove Mueller without "good cause." If Trump were to attempt to relieve Mueller of his duties now, it could be perceived as a reaction to the growing probe, as there is yet no indication of Mueller's ineptitude in his role.

Republicans have warned Trump that firing Mueller could be detrimental to his presidency. Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-SC) told NBC News, "Any effort to go after Mueller could be the beginning of the end of the Trump presidency, unless Mueller did something wrong."

The future course of action for Trump remains uncertain, but it is likely that he will not be pleased about more people scrutinizing his finances, associates, and family.

Title: Economic Underperformance and Job Growth in the Lead-up to the 2012 Presidential Election

Article:

As the 2012 Presidential Election approaches, the incumbent President Barack Obama is facing a challenging economic landscape. The economy is not meeting job growth expectations, with recent months showing underperformance compared to forecasts. This trend, which has been consistent since the first Friday of each month, has created a political stalemate.

The Labor Department releases a monthly jobs report on the first Friday of each month. These reports are often used by both parties to support their respective economic policies. In the June report, the U.S. economy created more than 80,000 jobs, a figure that President Obama described as a "step in the right direction." However, Republican candidate Mitt Romney, on a break from his vacation, called the June numbers a "kick in the gut."

The jobs reports, while politically charged, do not provide significant new insights about the economy. The data suggest that the economy is not in recession, but it is also not creating jobs at a rate that would significantly lower the unemployment rate, which has been above 8 percent for 41 consecutive months.

Economist Heidi Shierholz of the liberal Economic Policy Institute states, "We are not in — nor are we slipping into — another recession, but neither are we getting the kind of job growth that will bring down the unemployment rate. In other words, the labor market is treading water."

Historically, high unemployment rates have been associated with incumbents losing their re-election bids. Since 1960, there have been four presidential elections featuring incumbents with unemployment rates above 7 percent: 1976, 1980, 1984, and 1992. Only in 1984 did the incumbent, Ronald Reagan, manage to secure another term.

However, it is crucial to consider other factors that may have played significant roles in past elections. For instance, President Gerald Ford was hurt by his pardon of Richard Nixon in 1976, while President Jimmy Carter faced a primary challenge by Sen. Ted Kennedy in 1980. In 1992, H. Ross Perot's third-party bid pulled votes away from President George H.W. Bush, allowing Bill Clinton to win with just 43 percent of the popular vote.

In conclusion, the lackluster economic growth and job creation are significant factors propelling Mitt Romney's candidacy. Romney has made the economy's underwhelming performance, which he blames on Obama, the central argument for his case for a change in the White House. The slowdown of economies in Europe and China suggests the situation may worsen for the U.S. economy before it improves.

President Obama, however, has shown a resilience and political acumen that has often left his opponents questioning their assumptions. Whether he will be able to defy political gravity and secure another term remains to be seen.

Title: Obamacare's Third Year of Open Enrollment Faces Challenges with Rising Premiums, Cancellations, and Limited Options

Article:

The third year of Obamacare's open enrollment began on Sunday, with a revamped website featuring fresh photos and high-tech features. However, the actual insurance offerings under President Barack Obama's signature healthcare law have faced challenges, with premiums rising, cancellations mounting, and choices decreasing.

Premiums are increasing significantly in many states. In Alaska, premiums will be nearly 40 percent higher next year, while people buying insurance on the Minnesota exchange will pay anywhere from 14 to 49 percent more. Premiums are just one part of the high-cost story; many plans are also raising deductibles, co-pays, and other out-of-pocket costs.

One of the most significant changes from the 2010 promise of "If you like your health care plan, you can keep it" is the new advice for people to "shop around" to avoid brutal rate increases. Switching insurance plans each year may result in slightly lower rate increases, but for some people, their old plan will not be available at any price.

More than half a million people insured by one of the health co-ops that have shut down in 11 states over the past few months will not have their plans available. In some states, plans are changing dramatically, even if the company remains. A patient may find that her longtime doctor will no longer be a part of her plan's network, or that the hospital nearest to her home is no longer included by her insurance.

In some states, the number of options is becoming increasingly limited. According to the Kaiser Family Foundation, people living in 14 of Nevada's 16 counties will have only one or two companies to pick from. In Wyoming, with the failure of WINHealth, residents will have only one option.

Insurance through Obamacare is largely coming down to a simple choice of "take it or leave it." More and more Americans are leaving it. The only people who are consistently signing up are those who receive subsidies from Washington. According to the IRS, 90 percent of people who received government insurance subsidies last year got the wrong amount.

To avoid an all-out panic over low enrollment, the administration is trying to lower expectations. It has lowered the bar for success to around 10 million people enrolled for 2016, which is half of the 21 million people the non-partisan Congressional Budget Office says should be covered next year. It is also essentially flat compared to the 9.9 million who were enrolled in June.

Senator John Barrasso (R-WY), chairman of the Republican Policy Committee and a physician, has stated that Obamacare is failing because too many people want nothing to do with it. As the costs continue to rise, more people receive cancellation notices, and the exchanges offer fewer choices, the collapse will only continue. We may look back at this past Sunday as the beginning of the end.

Title: Far-Left Groups Involved in Escalating Political Violence in the U.S.

Article:

In the aftermath of the violent clashes at a white nationalist rally in Charlottesville, media attention has focused on self-described "anti-fascists" (or "antifa") who were present at the rally. These far-left actors have been involved in escalating political violence in the United States, according to various reports and statements from the groups themselves.

Many establishment political figures have compared these "anti-fascists" to American soldiers on D-Day, but their own statements indicate they are not similar in their objectives. Instead of protecting America's system of government, they aim to destroy it, according to their statements.

Since the beginning of the Trump administration, far-left actors have declared their intention to use massive demonstrations to disrupt the American political process as much as possible. A common mantra among far-left groups, starting shortly before the inauguration, was to make America "ungovernable."

Refuse Fascism, a driving force behind the violent, politically motivated riots in Berkeley, was among the left-wing groups at Charlottesville. The group urged confrontation with the white nationalists and took credit for organizing the vandals who toppled a city-owned Confederate statue in Durham, North Carolina this week.

Another far-left group at Charlottesville was CrimethInc, an anarchist group that holds that anarchism is necessary to destroy white supremacy, which the group says cannot be fully extinguished in a democracy. The group advocates for the destruction of hierarchy, including white supremacy, patriarchy, policing, capitalism, and the state.

The Workers World Party, a Marxist-Leninist revolutionary group, was also present at Charlottesville. The group has declared its support for Kim Jong Un's murderous dictatorship in North Korea and has consistently published propaganda-like screeds supporting Venezuela's murderous regime. The group took credit for organizing the vandals who toppled the city-owned Confederate statue in Durham, North Carolina this week.

The Workers World Party's stated goals are classic Marxism, including igniting an international socialist revolution and using the war budget to improve the lives of the working class and oppressed peoples. The group is opposed to all in the "ruling establishment" who hide "behind a veil of 'democracy' and 'human rights.'"

While Workers World is currently fighting (literally) with white nationalists, the group is opposed to all in the "ruling establishment" who the group explains hide "behind a veil of 'democracy' and 'human rights.'" The group's post after Charlottesville concluded, "Long live the independent struggle of this new progressive movement against the fascists, the cops and the capitalist establishment!"

Title: Sen. Dianne Feinstein Urges Hillary Clinton to Address Email Controversy

Article:

In an interview on NBC's "Meet the Press," Sen. Dianne Feinstein (D-CA) has called for former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton to address the ongoing controversy surrounding her use of a personal email account for government business. Feinstein expressed her desire for Clinton to "step up and come out and state exactly what the situation is."

Clinton, who is currently the frontrunner for the 2016 Democratic presidential nomination, has been under scrutiny for conducting all of her official communications through a private email server set up in her Chappaqua, New York home. This has led to criticism over the potential security risks of transmitting sensitive information and speculation about the selective release of emails for official records.

Clinton has so far remained silent on the issue, with her only public statement being a late-night tweet on March 4, in which she called for the Justice Department to release her emails "as soon as possible." However, Clinton did not address the issue during a Saturday night event in Coral Gables, Florida, for the Clinton Global Initiative University.

In contrast, one of Clinton's predecessors, former Secretary of State Colin Powell, stated that he has not retained any emails sent from his personal email account during his tenure at the department in the first George W. Bush administration. "I do not have any to turn over," he said on Sunday. "I did not keep a cache of them. I did not print them off."

Powell added that most of the emails from his account were unclassified and "pretty benign," and he was not concerned if they were recovered. He also noted that many of the emails from his account were addressed to State Department employees and the State.gov domain, but he was unsure if the State Department servers captured those emails or not.

Title: UN Official Urges International Intervention as Islamic State Threatens Syrian Kurdish City of Kobani

Article:

A UN official has issued a warning of impending "humanitarian tragedies" and has pleaded for global intervention on behalf of Kurds trapped in the Syrian city of Kobani, near the Turkish border, as Islamic State (IS) fighters are on the brink of taking control.

Kurds from villages across northern Syria have fled to Kobani for a final stand as IS has swept across vast territories, leaving a trail of death and destruction. The city has been under siege for three weeks, with IS fighters raising their flag over neighborhoods. UN Special Envoy for Syria, Staffan de Mistura, stated that the city is on the verge of falling.

De Mistura said, "The world has seen with its own eyes the images of what happens when a city in Syria or in Iraq is overtaken by the terrorist group called ISIS or Da'esh: massacres, humanitarian tragedies, rapes, horrific violence." He added, "The international community cannot sustain another city falling under ISIS."

With fighting taking place near the Turkish border, international pressure has increased on Ankara to take military action. Turkey has already taken in an estimated 200,000 refugees, and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan stated that the coalition air campaign launched last month would not be enough to halt IS's advance.

Erdogan, whose troops are massed near the border but have not yet taken an offensive posture, called for greater cooperation with the Syrian opposition, which is fighting both extremists and forces loyal to Syrian President Bashar Assad.

The capture of Kobani would give IS control of a large swath of land bordering Turkey and eliminate a vital pocket of Kurdish resistance. It would also provide a link between the group's territory near the ancient Syrian city of Aleppo and its largest operations base at Raqqa in northeastern Syria.

Warplanes believed to be part of the U.S.-led coalition against IS struck militant positions on Tuesday, according to reports. Fighting continued into Tuesday morning on the outskirts of the town, with the Kurds reporting that their defenses benefited from the new round of airstrikes but were still outmatched by the more heavily armed militants.

As of Tuesday, ISIS fighters were reported to have entered the eastern outskirts of the city after capturing more than 300 surrounding Syrian Kurdish villages in the previous three weeks. ISIS raised their black flag in two separate places, one on top of a civilian apartment building and another on a hilltop near a checkpoint at the city's eastern entrance.

The Britain-based Syrian Observatory for Human Rights reported that the Kurds forced the jihadists to withdraw from the eastern part of the town in heavy clashes after midnight Tuesday, adding that five loud explosions were heard in the town as warplanes soared overhead. However, a local Kurdish militia commander estimated to The Wall Street Journal that ISIS fighters were still a mile from the city center.

Before the recent fighting began, the city had been a focal point for refugees fleeing Syria's three-year-long civil war. Between 160,000 and 180,000 people are believed to have fled into Turkey since the IS advance began. A Kurdish politician told Reuters that more than 2,000 Syrian Kurds, including women and children, had been evacuated from the town in the midst of the fighting on Monday.

State Department officials will travel to Turkey later this week to discuss the status of the international coalition, with Retired Marine Gen. John Allen, the White House's special envoy in the fight against ISIS, among those traveling to Turkey.

Despite U.S. pressure to become a full-fledged member of the coalition, and despite the Turkish parliament passing a law giving the government authority to conduct operations against ISIS in Syria or Iraq, Ankara has largely stayed on the sidelines. Fox News reported on Monday that twenty Turkish tanks have been stationed on a hillside overlooking Kobani, ready to strike the city on short notice. However, Turkish authorities have mostly been preoccupied with attempting to control the flow of Kurdish refugees across the border and deal with their protests at the government's inaction.

Also on Tuesday, Turkish media reported that police in Istanbul and at least six other Turkish cities clashed with hundreds of demonstrators. The private Dogan news agency reported clashes breaking out in several Istanbul neighborhoods overnight, as protesters set up barricades, hurled stones, fireworks, and firebombs at police, and set a bus on fire. One police officer was injured. Police used tear gas and water cannon to disperse similar protests in the mostly Kurdish-populated cities of Diyarbakir, Batman, Van, Sirnak, Sanliurfa, and Hakkari.

Title: Venezuelan Opposition Rally Fails to Oust President Maduro, Tensions Escalate with Global Powers

Article:

Venezuelans heeded the call of opposition leader Juan Guaido on Wednesday, taking to the streets in a bid to force President Nicolas Maduro from power. However, the demonstrations, which Guaido described as the "largest march" in Venezuela's history, appeared to have little concrete impact, with many protesters returning home by late afternoon.

Guaido, the head of the opposition-controlled National Assembly, invoked the constitution to assume an interim presidency in January, arguing that Maduro's 2018 re-election was illegitimate. The standoff has increased tensions between the United States and Russia, with each accusing the other of interference in Venezuela's affairs.

In Caracas, National Guards fired tear gas at a hardcore group of demonstrators who remained, and one injured demonstrator was carried by others to a first aid truck, according to ███ video. A young woman died in surgery after being shot during a protest in Caracas, and Guaido confirmed via Twitter that a woman died after being shot.

Despite Guaido's calls for the military to support him, the armed forces leadership has remained loyal to Maduro, who has been in power since the death of his mentor, former President Hugo Chavez, in 2013. Guaido told thousands of supporters that the regime's response to the protests showed they were "not even imagining the maximum pressure."

It remains unclear what more Guaido can do at this point. The Venezuelan opposition has staged large street protests against Maduro in the past, but they have failed to dislodge him despite a deep economic recession and hyperinflation.

Demonstrators said they were prepared for the process of ousting Maduro to last a long time. "We need to keep going," said Laila Amezquita, a 52-year-old nurse from Caracas' downtown Candelaria district. "In three months, Guaido's been able to do what they have not done in 20 years, and one has to be patient."

Others are frustrated that nothing has changed more than three months after Guaido invoked the constitution to assume the interim presidency. Guaido is recognized as Venezuela's legitimate head of state by the United States, the European Union, and others, while Maduro is backed by countries including Russia, China, and Cuba.

Those fault lines are increasingly putting Venezuela at the heart of global geopolitical tensions. The United States has imposed sanctions on the Maduro government and refused to rule out military intervention, although it says it prefers a peaceful transition.

Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov told U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo on Wednesday that further "aggressive steps" in Venezuela would have grave consequences, according to Russia's Foreign Ministry. The Pentagon has acknowledged detailed contingency planning for a potential intervention in Venezuela but has downplayed any active preparations.

The United States has accused Russia of interfering in Venezuela, an ally of Russia since the time of Chavez. Pompeo said Maduro had been expected to flee the country on Tuesday but Russia convinced him to stay, which the Kremlin has denied.

Venezuelan living standards have declined even further in the first several months of the year, with blackouts and water shortages adding to hyperinflation and chronic shortages of food and medicine that have prompted millions to emigrate. Triple the usual daily number of Venezuelans fled across the border to Brazil on Tuesday, according to Brazilian government data.

Maduro, who says Guaido is a puppet of the United States seeking to orchestrate a coup, also called a march on Wednesday. In a speech to supporters gathered near the Miraflores presidential palace, Maduro said he recognized the need for "big changes within the Bolivarian revolution." He did not give details.

Title: Ebola Outbreak in Guinea Rises, Aid Workers Intensify Efforts to Contain Spread

Article:

Aid workers are intensifying their efforts in Guinea to combat a resurgence of the Ebola virus, which has been largely contained in neighboring Sierra Leone and Liberia. The increased activity is due to concerns that the upcoming rainy season could hinder travel to remote villages where new cases of the disease are emerging.

Jordan Tappero, director of the division of global health protection for the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), expressed optimism that Guinea could follow the same trajectory as Sierra Leone and Liberia, where the disease has declined. He stated that the number of personnel in the field in Guinea has tripled, and many other organizations have taken similar actions.

Since the Ebola outbreak began in the jungles of Guinea in December 2013, nearly 25,000 people across West Africa have been infected, with more than 10,000 deaths. The latest weekly total of new cases in Guinea, reported on March 15, was the highest for the nation this year, with 95 cases. However, this week, only 45 new cases were reported, a decrease that is still concerning to World Health Organization (WHO) workers due to the emergence of new infections in unexpected areas.

Many of the outbreaks are in distant villages, and only 38% of new infections in Guinea last week were among people being tracked. This is a low rate that is troubling because it indicates that healthcare workers are not effectively establishing a chain of infection, a crucial element in defeating the virus. The process of contact tracing, or tracking all who have been exposed, is essential to breaking the chain of infection and halting the disease.

Tracing contacts in new infections will become increasingly difficult during the rainy season, which begins in June and is expected to see daily downpours by July. "That's why we have to get down to as close to zero with contact tracing all known, laboratory-confirmed cases by then," Tappero said. "I'll be honest with you, people are fatigued."

In nearby Sierra Leone, where more than 3,700 have died and almost 12,000 were infected, the nation's 6 million residents have been ordered to stay home for three days beginning Friday, except for religious services, in an effort to fight the spread of the disease, according to Associated Press.

Earlier this month, an American health worker ill with Ebola was evacuated from Sierra Leone to the United States and remains in critical condition at the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md. The worker was among 12 new Ebola infections involving caregivers in Sierra Leone and Guinea in the past few weeks. Nearly 500 healthcare workers across West Africa have died of the disease since the outbreak began. In Guinea, the workers affected are often a remote village's only nurse or doctor.

"We really need the rate of healthcare infections to be zero," said Ian Norton, a physician with the World Health Organization.

New infections in Sierra Leone are slowly diminishing, WHO reported. Last week, 84% of the 33 new cases were among people health officials were tracking—good news, WHO said, because it shows health workers are successfully identifying and isolating those who might become infected.

In Liberia, infections fell dramatically, dropping to zero for three straight weeks this month. Beaches and schools re-opened. Students showed up to have their temperatures taken and wash hands before entering class.

More than 4,200 of those killed by the virus were in Liberia, where President Obama deployed about 3,000 troops to build clinics and train health care workers late last year. About 300 troops remain there.

There has been at least one setback. A ban on sporting activities was lifted, and the first soccer match was underway in Monrovia, Liberia's capital, on March 20, with President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf in attendance when word of a new Ebola case broke. A 44-year-old mother of six who worked as a food server at a school fell ill. She rode on a motorbike-taxi to the hospital, a common means of transportation in Monrovia. One small school where she worked has been temporarily closed. Eighty-six people who were in contact with her have been quarantined. The woman died on Friday, according to Reuters.

The Ministry of Health is investigating whether the disease might have been transmitted through sexual contact with an Ebola survivor. Although the man she was dating was released from care more than three months before, research has found that the virus can survive in male sexual organs for an extended period of time.

"We were getting close to the finishing line when this sad event occurred," said Liberian government spokesman Isaac Jackson. "We are all saddened by this development. But we are consoled because we have in place the best system, surveillance, contact tracers, so we are still committed to beating this virus."

Title: Federal Election Commission Receives Complaint Against Rep. Ilhan Omar for Alleged Misuse of Campaign Funds

Article:

The Federal Election Commission (FEC) has received a complaint against Representative Ilhan Omar (D-MN) for alleged misuse of campaign funds. The complaint, filed by the National Legal and Policy Center, alleges that Omar and her campaign violated the prohibition on the personal use of campaign funds by reimbursing political consultant Tim Mynett for his travel in 2019.

According to the complaint, Mynett's formal relationship with Rep. Omar's campaign began in July 2018, with the payment of $7,000 directly to Mynett. However, the reimbursements for Mynett's travel did not commence until April 2019, the same month that Dr. Mynett alleges in her divorce filing that her husband told her of the affair and made a "shocking declaration of love" for Rep. Omar.

The complaint states that Mynett's "more recent travel and long work hours now appear to be more related to his affair with Rep. Omar than his actual work commitments." The National Legal and Policy Center's statement also notes that the timing of the payments to Mynett's firm, E Street Group, coincides with the period after Omar won the contested primary and during the noncompetitive general election in her D+26 district.

Omar has not commented on the issue of campaign funds being improperly used, stating, "I have no interest in allowing the conversation about my personal life to continue and so I have no desire to discuss it." In June, Omar was ordered to pay back thousands of dollars to her campaign after breaking campaign finance laws.

The details of the divorce filing by Dr. Beth Jordan Mynett, alleging her husband's affair with Rep. Omar, were reported by the New York Post on Tuesday. The Washington Examiner reported that the overwhelming majority of Omar's funds spent on the E Street Group were paid after she won the contested primary and during the general election, contrary to FEC rules, as Omar's filings did not designate whether her E Street Group disbursements (or any of her disbursements) were for the primary election or the general election.

Title: Obama and Boehner Prioritize Political Bases Over Policy Initiatives in 2014

Article:

In 2014, both President Barack Obama and House Speaker John Boehner prioritized maintaining the support of their respective political bases over advancing critical policy initiatives.

For the Republican speaker, a commitment to significant immigration changes, including a path to legal status for millions of undocumented workers, was abandoned due to a perceived conservative backlash. The argument from the right was that turning out conservatives was crucial for the 2014 midterm success, and substantial immigration changes would antagonize the base.

President Obama countered by dropping a proposal from his new budget that he had considered essential just a year ago: a more modest calculation of inflation adjustments for Social Security. Previously, this was a key component of entitlement reform and deficit reduction. However, liberals opposed the idea, and pushing it in 2014 could have angered a base that the Democrats needed in November.

When Boehner retreated on immigration, it was the White House and its allies who criticized him for being short-sighted and prioritizing politics over the national interest. Conversely, from Boehner's office, the argument was that the President has no interest in addressing the looming debt crisis and is already conceding defeat with three years left in his term.

The speaker's decision on immigration and Obama's on Social Security can be seen as tactical moves, with both leaders hoping to position themselves politically more favorably in the future. The midterm elections are expected to result in the Republicans maintaining their House majority, with the battle for control of the Senate being the significant 2014 struggle. The President has made it clear that protecting the fragile Democratic majority in the Senate is his top priority.

Organizations focused on deficit reduction and structural budget reforms praised Obama when he embraced the Social Security shift last year, estimating it to save $233 billion over a decade. However, these same centrist organizations criticized his decision to abandon the Social Security change this year as a clear political shift to the left.

The "chained CPI" shift for Social Security is likely to re-emerge as a debating point next year, but Obama could face even more contentious issues anathema to liberals if the GOP manages to take control of the Senate.

With the stakes high, it is clear that leadership in both parties is moving away from an environment of major policy compromise and toward full-scale election positioning. To that end, Obama attended a 2014 Organizing for Action summit on Tuesday, with the goal of trying to defy the midterm historical odds and protect Democratic seats.

Title: Michael Bloomberg's Potential Entry into the 2020 Democratic Primary Race

Article:

Former New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg, known for his ambition and pragmatic approach to politics, is reportedly considering a late entry into the 2020 Democratic primary race. This move comes amid perceived struggles by former Vice President Joe Biden, who is currently the best-known candidate in the contest but has been facing challenges in polls in early primary states.

Biden's poll numbers have been falling behind Massachusetts Senator Elizabeth Warren and are in danger of dropping behind Vermont Senator Bernie Sanders and South Bend, Indiana, Mayor Pete Buttigieg as well. This situation is problematic for Biden, as it raises questions about his ability to attract new support in the remaining months before the Iowa caucuses.

Compounding Biden's financial challenges is his cash deficit compared to Warren, Sanders, and Buttigieg. The trio ended September with over $20 million in the bank, while Biden had less than $9 million. This financial disparity means Biden will likely be unable to compete with his rivals in terms of television advertising and organizational resources once the race moves beyond the first four states.

With Biden showing signs of flagging, the obvious candidate who could benefit is Buttigieg, who has positioned himself in the same pragmatic lane as the former Vice President. There are indications that Buttigieg is gaining ground, particularly in Iowa. However, there are doubts about whether the Democratic Party's establishment wing is ready to back a 37-year-old whose most significant experience to date has been as mayor of his hometown.

Enter Michael Bloomberg, an establishment favorite with a long record of centrist policy-making and significant wealth. Bloomberg's reported preparations to enter the race are likely rooted in Biden's perceived struggles, as well as concerns about a rising Warren and the potential impact she could have on the Democratic Party's chances in the general election.

It is important to note that Biden and Bloomberg are not interchangeable candidates. While Biden has a demonstrated constituency among working-class and minority voters, it is unclear what Bloomberg's "natural" constituency is beyond those who watch "Morning Joe" and ride Amtrak's Acela between New York and Washington, D.C.

Bloomberg's candidacy is a response to the perceived weakness of Biden's campaign and the fear of a rising Warren and her potential impact on the Democratic Party's chances in the general election. The question for Bloomberg is whether he has enough time to turn this opportunity into a viable campaign.

Title: Bipartisan Budget Agreement in Sight as Government Shutdown Threat Recedes

Article:

WASHINGTON (AP) — A bipartisan budget agreement appears to be within reach, as lawmakers work to avoid a repeat of last month's government shutdown. President Donald Trump, however, has hinted at the possibility of another shutdown if he cannot secure his desired immigration policies.

On Tuesday, Trump stated, "I'd love to see a shutdown if we can't get this stuff taken care of," repeating the sentiment for emphasis. This statement was strikingly disconnected from the progress on Capitol Hill, where lawmakers are close to finalizing a short-term spending measure and a broader, long-term budget agreement.

The broader agreement, if approved, would provide significant spending increases for both the Pentagon and domestic federal programs, as well as approve overdue disaster relief money and potentially crucial legislation to increase the government's borrowing limit and avoid a possible default.

Democratic leaders have abandoned their strategy of using the funding fight to secure concessions on immigration, specifically on extending protections for "Dreamer" immigrants who have lived in the U.S. illegally since they were children. Instead, Democrats are preparing to cut a deal that would allocate funds for other priorities, such as combatting opioids, while taking their chances on resolving the immigration impasse later.

The House passed a six-week stopgap spending bill on Tuesday night, with a 245-182 vote, mostly along party lines. The bill contains increases for the military that have long been demanded by Trump and his Republican allies. However, the measure is increasingly likely to be rewritten by the Senate to include legislation implementing the broader budget agreement.

House Democrats canceled a scheduled three-day retreat on Maryland's Eastern Shore to develop a strategy for the midterm elections, citing the pressing issues Congress will likely vote on over the next three days.

The budget negotiations, led by the Senate's top leaders, Republican Mitch McConnell of Kentucky and Chuck Schumer of New York, have intensified in recent days. The looming government shutdown at midnight Thursday has added urgency to the talks. In addition to the military and domestic spending, the deal taking shape would approve overdue disaster relief money and potentially crucial legislation to increase the government's borrowing limit and avoid possible default.

"I think we're on the way to getting an agreement and getting it very soon," said McConnell.

Prospects for addressing immigration, however, remain unclear. The Senate is scheduled to begin a debate next week to address the dilemma of immigrants left vulnerable by the looming expiration of former President Barack Obama's Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program.

Weeks of bargaining have left the two parties divided over how to extend protections for such Dreamer immigrants and a court ruling has blurred the March 5 deadline. McConnell stated Tuesday that while he hopes "we will end up having something," he was unsure if any proposed measure would garner the 60 votes needed for approval.

On Tuesday, White House Chief of Staff John Kelly fueled the immigration dispute as he defended Trump's proposed solution. The retired general noted that the White House proposal would expand protection for some 1.8 million immigrants. This group includes both the 690,000 currently shielded and also "the people that some would say were too afraid to sign up, others would say were too lazy to get off their asses, but they didn't sign up," he said.

Senate Democratic leader Dick Durbin of Illinois, his party's chief immigration negotiator, bristled at the comment. "I'm sorry for that characterization. It doesn't surprise me from Gen. Kelly," he said.

GOP defense hawks are prevailing over the party's depleted ranks of deficit hawks, championing major new spending on military programs. Democrats, meanwhile, are leveraging their influence to increase spending for domestic priorities such as combating opioid misuse.

The result could be the return of trillion-dollar deficits for the first time since Obama's first term. The stopgap spending bill would keep the government open through March 23 to allow time to write and pass detailed follow-up "omnibus" legislation to fund the government through the Sept. 30 end of the fiscal year.

The prospective longer-term budget agreement would provide relief from a budget freeze that lawmakers say threatens military readiness and training as well as domestic priorities such as combating opioid abuse and repairing the government's troubled health care system for veterans.

The temporary funding measure would also reauthorize funding for community health centers, which enjoy widespread bipartisan support. Aides in both parties said the budget measure may also contain a provision to raise the government's $20.5 trillion borrowing limit. Legislation to increase the debt ceiling is always a headache, especially for House GOP leaders whose rank and file have in the past used the votes to register an objection to deficit spending.

Another likely addition is more than $80 billion in long-overdue hurricane relief for Texas, Florida, and Puerto Rico, a top priority of lawmakers in both parties.

Under Congress's arcane ways, a broad-brush agreement to increase legally binding spending "caps"—which would otherwise keep the budgets for the military and domestic agencies essentially frozen—would be approved, then followed by a far more detailed catchall spending bill that would take weeks to negotiate.

It's clear that Senate Democrats have no appetite for another government shutdown. Their unity splintered during last month's three-day closure. House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., had linked progress on the budget with action to address the immigration program, but other Democrats are beginning to agitate for delinking the two, lest the opportunity for a budget pact is lost. And having tried and failed to link progress on the budget to DACA during last month's government shutdown battle, many Democrats aren't spoiling for a repeat.

"It's hard. If we can get a good deal that funds disaster relief, funds domestic priorities, funds the opioid crisis, it would be a difficult call," said Rep. Adam Smith, D-Wash. "DACA's important and it ought to get done. But what's the path?"

Schumer said he and Pelosi are "working from the same page," appearing to discount speculation that she might oppose the coming pact.

Title: Military Leaders Express Concern Over Trump's Sudden Decision to Ban Transgender Personnel

Article:

WASHINGTON - U.S. President Donald Trump's sudden decision to ban transgender personnel from serving in the military has alarmed some senior military officers who were caught off guard by it. Trump's declaration, which came via early morning tweets on Wednesday, appeared to pre-empt an ongoing Pentagon review looking into allowing openly transgender recruits to join the military.

Rights groups and some lawmakers from both parties accused Trump of politically motivated discrimination and said the decision creates uncertainty for transgender active-duty service members and reservists, who say they number in the thousands.

The United States' top military officer, Marine General Joseph Dunford, told the armed forces on Thursday there had been no change yet to Pentagon policy on transgender personnel. Dunford, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, acknowledged the uncertainty that followed Trump's announcement in a note to service chiefs, commanders, and senior enlisted leaders.

"I know there are questions about yesterday's announcement on the transgender policy by the President," Dunford wrote. "There will be no modifications to the current policy until the President's direction has been received by the Secretary of Defense and the Secretary has issued implementation guidance," Dunford said in the message, first reported by Reuters.

Dunford neither voiced support nor opposition to Trump's decision. One official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Dunford in a separate message sent more narrowly to heads of the Army, Navy, Marine Corps, and Air Force acknowledged that Trump's announcement on Wednesday was "unexpected."

The Defense Department had been expected to begin formally allowing transgender people to enlist this year. But Defense Secretary Jim Mattis approved a six-month delay to allow for a review on June 30.

As a presidential candidate, Trump last year had vowed to fight for lesbians, gays, bisexuals, and transgender people. His move on Wednesday was praised by conservative activists and some fellow Republicans.

Trump cited "tremendous medical costs and disruption" as a justification for the ban, a point disputed by experts and advocates for allowing military service to be determined by an individual's capabilities, not gender identity or sexual preference.

The Army's chief of staff, General Mark Milley, said on Thursday that there had been issues with transgender individuals serving in the Army. "I will be candid... This is a complex issue and there (are) a variety of challenges out there that we have to deal with and we have been working through it, but this is not clean-cut either way," he said.

White House spokeswoman Sarah Sanders said implementation of Trump's decision was still being worked out. Separately, the Trump administration on Thursday told a U.S. appeals court in New York that federal law does not ban discrimination against gay employees, a sharp reversal of the position Democratic former President Barack Obama took.

Trump's plan to ban transgender military service members has unleashed legal threats from advocates who say they are seeking plaintiffs who want to sue. Trump's tweets did not make clear when a ban would go into effect, nor whether it applies to serving members of the military or those wishing to join.

If the Defense Department actively roots out transgender people and discharges them from the military, the Pentagon is likely to face an especially contentious fight, legal experts say. "There's no valid justification for excluding transgender people from the military," said Jon Davidson, legal director for LGBT rights group Lambda Legal.

It was also unclear whether it might go beyond active-duty forces and apply to reservists. Indiana National Guard reservist Cameron St. Andrew, who resigned from full-time service after the November election, told Reuters that as a transgender person he was concerned about his status. "I try to be tough about it," he said, but added: "It breaks your spirit down."

One active-duty U.S. military officer, speaking on condition of anonymity, said senior officials were not consulted. "We're scratching our heads and asking where the hell this came from," the officer said by phone. "Maybe the president is in step with some members of Congress and some voters, but he is out of step with today's military. Our service personnel today don't give a damn about the personal lives of their comrades so long as they know they can trust them when it counts."

Title: Legalization of Marijuana and its Impact on the Media Industry

Article:

The New York Times' recent editorial advocating for the legalization of marijuana has sparked discussions about the potential economic and societal implications of such a move. One of the significant effects could be a resurgence in the media industry, as marijuana, like cigarettes and alcohol, could become a lucrative advertising market.

The legalization of marijuana would, at least on some level, legalize its marketing. Cigarette advertising was curbed only after the health effects of smoking became known. The legalization of marijuana acknowledges its benefits, or at least its pleasures, significantly outweighing its negative effects.

The New York Times' editorial suggests that the marijuana industry could transform the media business. This transformation might be facilitated by the nascent marijuana industry's argument for the right to advertise, an argument that, if it prevails, could lead to a growth in media revenue.

One potential solution to address concerns about the impact of marijuana advertising on children could be to restrict advertising to print media, appealing to adults. This approach might protect the young while also potentially revitalizing the print media industry, which currently suffers from a lack of advertising interest and an aging readership.

The legalization of marijuana could also lead to a growth industry in media focused on pot culture and behavior. Companies like Vice Media, which specializes in reaching young, inattentive audiences, have already been successful in this market. The open expression of pot culture and behavior in traditional media could reestablish the connection between mainstream media and the young.

In the past, media had a strong connection to their audience when they embraced and acted out drunkenness. Pot, or pot style, could become part of what is now called content marketing, creating a symbiotic marketing environment that could attract a range of products willing to pay a premium to reach this group of people.

Contemporary media faces challenges due to the enormous number of outlets competing for the attention of American consumers and the lack of a common experience that reliably brings everyone together. Pot, as a unifying cultural principle, could change that.

Michael Wolff, a two-time National Magazine Award winner and author of best-selling books, including "The Man Who Owns the News," writes about the modern media business.

Title: American Teenagers and Their Parents Accused of Attempting to Join ISIS

Article:

Three American teenagers, all of whom are of Sudanese or Somali descent, were intercepted by German authorities at Frankfurt airport and returned to the United States after attempting to travel to Syria to join the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS). The girls, aged 15, 16, and 17, were questioned and released.

The girls' parents claim they had no knowledge of their children's plans to travel. None of the girls had a history of running away before. The incident, along with similar cases in Canada and Australia, has raised concerns about the attraction of ISIS to young Western recruits.

The first indication of trouble came when one of the girls' schools in the Denver area contacted her father, Assad Ibrahim, to inform him that she had not attended class. Ibrahim's daughter initially told him that she was late for class, but officials later filed a runaway report.

The girl also kept quiet about her two friends, Americans of Somali descent, who were reportedly flying with her to Turkey via Germany. The friends' father, Ali Farah, said they had told him they were going to the library. When Farah returned home from work, a visitor arrived, allegedly Ibrahim, who advised him to check if his daughters' passports were missing, which they were, along with $2,000 in cash.

The FBI was subsequently contacted, and the girls were intercepted at Frankfurt airport. The investigation into the girls' travel is unlikely to lead to charges, especially since they are minors, according to two U.S. officials.

Investigators are also unsure if the girls had a specific goal for their travel. The online activity of the girls and their friends did not set off any tripwires typically used by the FBI to flag potential jihadist sympathizers.

The incident in Denver is not an isolated case. In Canada, a 25-year-old radical convert to Islam, Martin Rouleau Couture, ran down two soldiers with his car, killing one, and led police on a chase before his car rolled into a ditch in the town of Saint-Jean-sur-Richelieu, southeast of Montreal. Couture had previously tried to join foreign jihad but was arrested on his way to Turkey.

In addition, a 17-year-old Australian boy appeared in a video with ISIS fighters, threatening to behead Western leaders, including President Obama, and fly the ISIS flag over the White House.

Experts suggest that ISIS's appeal to young Western recruits is not just a radical interpretation of Islam but a search for identity, purpose, and belonging. The slick videos and social media used by ISIS to attract potential recruits have also been a concern for terrorism experts in the United States.

The FBI is currently investigating the online activity of the three girls to see if anyone was helping them. The investigation into their travel is unlikely to lead to charges, especially since they are minors. The case serves as a reminder of the ongoing threat posed by homegrown violent extremists and the need for continued vigilance.

Title: President Obama's Approval Rating Drops to Record Low in New Poll

Article:

President Barack Obama's approval rating has reached a new low of 37 percent in a recent poll by CBS News, marking the lowest approval rating of his presidency. Simultaneously, his disapproval rating has reached a high of 57 percent.

Since October, Obama's approval rating has dropped by 9 points, according to the CBS News poll. Approval of his healthcare overhaul, commonly known as Obamacare, is at an all-time low of 31 percent, with disapproval at 61 percent. The administration is currently dealing with the fallout from a rocky rollout of major parts of the law on October 1. Forty-six percent of respondents said they "disapprove strongly" of the law.

Eighty-eight percent of Republicans disapprove of the law, with little change from last month's 87 percent figure. Approval among independents fell from 38 percent to 27 percent, and approval of Democrats dropped from 74 percent to 58 percent.

Two-thirds of respondents said the signup for insurance on government health care exchanges is not going well, and nearly two-thirds are not confident that the federal HealthCare.gov website will be mostly fixed by December 1. White House press secretary Jay Carney stated that a goal of 80 percent recruitment among all users of the website would be nearly the best result possible. Carney explained that the 20 percent who can't enroll includes people who aren't "comfortable" signing up online or have personal circumstances that are too "complex" to use the website.

A majority of Americans do not favor outright repeal of the law. Seven percent think it's working well and should be kept as is, 48 percent think some changes are needed, and 43 percent think it should be repealed.

During the presidential campaign last fall, 60 percent of voters thought of Mr. Obama as honest and trustworthy, compared to 49 percent of Americans in the poll released Wednesday.

Americans hold dim views of both parties in Congress; just 26 percent approve of how congressional Democrats are doing their job, and 21 percent say the same for congressional Republicans. The mark for Democrats is down slightly from last month's 31 percent, and Republicans ticked up from 18 percent. Disapproval of Democrats increased from 65 percent to 68 percent, and disapproval of Republicans declined from 78 percent to 73 percent.

The CBS News poll of 1,010 adults was conducted from November 15-18 and has a margin of error of 3 percentage points.

Title: Republican Response to Bergdahl's Release: A Political Analysis

Article:

The release of U.S. Army Sergeant Bowe Bergdahl, who was held captive by the Taliban since 2009, has sparked a political debate among Republican legislators. Critics are questioning the decision to exchange five Taliban prisoners held at Guantanamo Bay for Bergdahl's freedom, with some suggesting it could serve as a pretext for impeachment hearings against President Barack Obama.

The controversy stems from the fact that, had a Republican president negotiated the release, the same critics would likely have defended the move. The focus on the negotiation with terrorists, rather than the return of a U.S. prisoner of war, is the crux of the criticism.

Some Republicans argue that the deal sends a message to terrorist groups worldwide that there is value in taking American hostages. However, this assertion has been challenged, as guerrilla forces have been taking hostages since the inception of warfare, and prisoner trades have occurred in Afghanistan in the past.

The long-form profile of Bergdahl written by journalist Mike Hastings in 2012 for Rolling Stone suggests that the GOP may use Bergdahl's personal history and actions as ammunition against him. The profile portrays Bergdahl as a disillusioned soldier who expressed disdain for the military and the U.S. actions in Afghanistan.

The debate over Bergdahl's release and the five Taliban prisoners exchanged for him is likely to continue, potentially escalating into a political soap opera that could last until President Obama's term ends in 2017. The question remains whether Republicans can make this issue resonate beyond their base, as public sentiment seems to favor the return of an American life, regardless of the cost.

Title: Job Market Boom Contrasted with Proposed Guaranteed Jobs Program

Article:

In a remarkable turn of events, 26-year-old software developer David Casarez, who was homeless and jobless, received over 200 job offers after he stood at an intersection in Mountain View, California, with a homemade cardboard sign and a resume. This incident highlights the current robust job market, with more job openings than job seekers.

The unemployment rate is near a half-century low, and unemployment among blacks and Hispanics is at a nearly all-time low. However, some Democratic presidential candidates, including Senators Kirsten Gillibrand (D-NY), Cory Booker (D-NJ), and Bernie Sanders (I-VT), are campaigning for a "guaranteed jobs" program, despite the ongoing economic boom.

The proposed program would guarantee a job and a paycheck for anyone not working, funded by taxpayers. House Democrats introduced guaranteed job legislation last week. Critics argue that these Democrats aim to undo the Trump tax cuts, which they claim are responsible for the economic boom, to fund these make-work jobs and other programs.

The hiring surge is attributed to a significant increase in business investment, up 9.4% during the first half of 2018. Investors are pouring money into private sector companies to buy more vehicles and equipment and increase commercial construction. This increased investment leads to more job opportunities in the private sector.

The tax cuts, particularly the drastic reduction in the corporate tax rate, have encouraged investors to invest more, as they can earn a higher after-tax return on their money. This, in turn, leads to increased hiring.

However, despite the current job market's strength, there are still people who are unemployed, lack skills, and have stopped looking for work. A public jobs program is not the solution to boost the nation's low labor participation rate, as the U.S. already has 41 federal jobs programs costing a total of $17 billion annually with little success in getting people into lasting private sector jobs.

Make-work programs, like the ones proposed by Booker, Gillibrand, and other Democrats, have a poor track record of getting people into lasting private sector jobs, according to a National Bureau of Economic Research survey by David Card of the University of California, Berkeley, and co-authors.

The Democrats pushing for a federal job guarantee are not primarily concerned with ensuring people work, as they vehemently oppose work or work-readiness requirements for Medicaid and other public benefits. Instead, their job guarantee campaign is seen as a thinly disguised effort at radical income redistribution.

Former President Barack Obama has also expressed support for a universal government-guaranteed income, with the goal of closing the "yawning disparities" between rich and poor. This would mean everyone receiving a check from the government, regardless of whether they work or not. In Chicago, the Democratic-controlled municipal legislature is backing a plan to give 1,000 families a $500 monthly stipend, no questions asked, with no work required.

For determined individuals like David Casarez, it is crucial to be aware of the potential consequences of the Democrats' tax hikes and redistributionist schemes, which could stifle the jobs boom and make private sector workers' paychecks fair game for supporting those who choose not to work.

Title: Democrats and Republicans Negotiate Fiscal Cliff Deal, Focus on Tax Increases and Revenue Reform

Article:

As the deadline for the "fiscal cliff" approaches, top Democrats have increased pressure on their Republican counterparts to accept tax increases on the wealthy as part of a broader agreement. House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, a California Democrat, stated that she would not accept a deal without such provisions. Republicans continue to reject outright tax increases but remain open to modifying the tax code and possibly eliminating some deductions, particularly those that benefit the rich.

President Obama has softened his rhetoric in recent days, emphasizing revenue generation from the wealthy income group through closing loopholes or other means, rather than raising tax rates. Finding a compromise that allows both parties to claim they are fulfilling their respective promises is crucial for reaching an agreement before the end of the year.

Sen. Richard J. Durbin, an Illinois Democrat, views the Republicans' openness to adjust or eliminate deductions and loopholes as an opportunity for meaningful agreement. He stated on CNN's "State of the Union" that discussing revenue and tax reform invites Republicans to engage in the conversation.

Congressional Republicans are also under pressure to push for deeper, more permanent changes to the federal government's operations. New Republican Governors Association Chairman Gov. Bobby Jindal of Louisiana urged his party to address the root causes of the nation's fiscal problems, suggesting structural changes such as a balanced-budget amendment to the Constitution, a limit on the growth in government spending, and limiting government spending as a percentage of GDP.

On Sunday, discussions between the two sides continued, following a meeting at the White House on Wednesday between President Obama and leaders from both parties. The president emphasized the need for "tough compromises" to be made and for action to be taken, as tax cuts are set to expire for all taxpayers on Jan. 1 and automatic spending cuts are due to hit most government agencies in the new year.

President Obama has called for any deal to include tax increases on families earning more than $250,000 per year, while insisting that tax cuts be preserved for families below that income level. In the days following his re-election victory over Republican Mitt Romney, House Speaker John A. Boehner offered an olive branch to the White House, signaling that some form of revenue increases would be on the table during negotiations.

However, several Republicans reiterated their preference for deep spending cuts over focusing on the revenue side. Rep. Raul Labrador of Idaho stated on NBC's "Meet the Press" that increasing taxes today and promising spending cuts in the future does not solve the problem. Rep. Tom Price of Georgia expressed doubt that tax increases would have a real impact on deficit-reduction efforts.

Democrats, in turn, are using similar arguments to attack the Republican-backed plan of tax reform and closing loopholes. House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi stated that closing loopholes alone would not generate sufficient revenue. She added that the president has been clear that higher-income individuals must pay their fair share.

Title: House Speaker Accuses Attorney General Barr of Lying to Congress, Threatens Contempt Charges

Article:

In a significant escalation of the ongoing conflict between the White House and Democratic lawmakers, U.S. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi accused Attorney General William Barr of lying to Congress and threatened to hold him in contempt of Congress. The accusation stems from Barr's testimony regarding interactions with Special Counsel Robert Mueller following the conclusion of the Russia investigation.

Democratic lawmakers have accused Barr of misleading Congress by testifying in April that he was unaware of any concern by the special counsel's team about Barr's initial March 24 characterization of the report. This account led President Donald Trump to claim full exoneration. However, Barr failed to mention a March 27 letter he received from Mueller, which expressed concern that Barr's March 24 account did not "fully capture the context, nature, and substance of this Office’s work."

Judiciary Committee Chairman Jerrold Nadler has threatened to hold Barr in contempt of Congress if he does not provide a full, unredacted copy of Mueller's report and the underlying evidence, as the panel has requested by a subpoena with a Wednesday deadline. This could potentially lead to legal steps against the top U.S. law enforcement official.

Pelosi, the top Democrat in Congress, accused Barr of lying to lawmakers about interactions with Mueller after the special counsel ended a 22-month investigation into Russia's efforts to interfere in the 2016 U.S. election to boost Trump's candidacy. "That's a crime," Pelosi told reporters, referring to Barr's congressional testimony.

Justice Department spokeswoman Kerri Kupec called Pelosi's allegation "reckless, irresponsible, and false."

The White House has shown no sign of backing down, with White House legal counsel Emmet Flood stating in a defiant letter that Trump has the right to tell advisers not to testify to congressional panels on the findings of Special Counsel Robert Mueller's Russia inquiry.

The dueling statements mark a sharp escalation in the conflict between the White House and Democrats who control the House of Representatives. With Trump seeking re-election next year, Democrats are weighing whether to try to remove the Republican president from office using the impeachment process while pressing forward with demands for information on his taxes, businesses, and other topics.

Several Democrats have called on Barr, whom Trump appointed after firing Jeff Sessions as attorney general, to resign.
