In a letter to six senators, Health and Human Services Secretary Kathleen Sebelius stated, "I agree with you that these consumers should qualify for this temporary hardship exemption, and I can assure you that the exemption will be available to them."

The specifics of the exemption's implementation remain unclear. However, the response to the Democrats' concerns addresses fears that people who lost coverage due to Obamacare would be left uninsured if they did not find an alternative on state-based markets by Monday, the deadline to have coverage by the new year.

Obamacare's requirements that all health plans provide a range of services contributed to many of these policy cancellations. For weeks, the administration and the law's outside defenders have criticized such plans as sub-par and argued that consumers would be better off with their Obamacare-compliant policies.

The initial concerns were raised by Sens. Jeanne Shaheen of New Hampshire, Angus King of Maine, Mary Landrieu of Louisiana, Heidi Heitkamp of North Dakota, and Mark Warner and Tim Kaine of Virginia. Each of the senators represents a state served by HealthCare.gov, the federal exchange system that experienced widespread web glitches upon its Oct. 1 debut.

The Obama administration has stated that the website is functioning much better as of the start of this month. In response to the senators' concerns, they stated, "We are pleased that the Administration appears to have responded to the concerns we've raised. As a result, this clarifies an option that will help those consumers who have had their plans cancelled this year transition more smoothly into the marketplace." The senators added, "We will closely monitor how the Administration implements this option, and we remain committed to proposing responsible solutions."

Title: Study Finds Link Between Perceived Group Deprivation and Nationalism Among White Majority Populations

Article:

A recent study published in the Political Psychology journal has found a correlation between perceptions of group-based deprivation and increased feelings of nationalism among white majority populations. The study, which surveyed over 15,000 New Zealand registered voters, suggests that nationalistic beliefs can serve as a buffer against the negative psychological consequences of perceiving one's own ethnic group as losing out due to policies that help other groups.

The study, titled "Group-Based Deprivation and Nationalism: A Test of the Deprivation-Nationalism Hypothesis," found that perceptions of group-based deprivation were associated with increased feelings of nationalism, and that nationalistic beliefs increased the psychological wellbeing of those who felt that they were being deprived.

The term "intersectionality" does not appear in the paper, but the study's findings seem to echo the concerns of critics who argue that the promotion of intersectional doctrines, which openly devalue white people, may contribute to the perceived loss of ingroup status among white majority populations.

The study's authors write, "What our model shows, for the first time, is that it is possible for a group to feel unfairly treated within a larger political entity (in this case, the nation) and simultaneously identify strongly with that entity." They suggest that nationalism can serve as a buffer against the negative psychological consequences of perceiving one's own ethnic group as being deprived.

The study's findings imply that the rise of nationalism in white-majority countries may be, in part, a reaction to a perceived loss of ingroup status. This suggests that the promotion of intersectional doctrines, which openly devalue white people, may contribute to the rise of nationalism among white majority populations.

The study's results seem intuitive: if a particular group (of any skin color) is constantly being lectured that they are less worthy than others, and also that complaining about such lectures is itself a symptom of privilege and racism, what other outcome might we realistically expect?

The study's authors argue that their findings have important implications for understanding the rise of nationalism in white-majority countries, and for developing policies that address the psychological needs of those who feel deprived. They suggest that policies that address group-based deprivation may help to reduce feelings of nationalism and promote greater social cohesion.

The study's findings are a reminder that the promotion of intersectional doctrines, which openly devalue white people, may contribute to the rise of nationalism among white majority populations. It is important to recognize that everyone, regardless of their skin color, has the potential to feel deprived and to respond with nationalism. Policies that address group-based deprivation may help to reduce feelings of nationalism and promote greater social cohesion.

Title: Obama and Romney Differ in Approach to Federal Disaster Relief Efforts

Article:

In the aftermath of Hurricane Sandy, President Barack Obama has pledged the full resources of the federal government to aid those affected by the storm. During a speech on Tuesday, Obama stated, "The most important message I have for them is that America's with you. We are standing behind you, and we are going to do everything we can to help you get back on your feet."

In contrast, Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney, during a canned food drive for storm victims in Ohio on Tuesday, emphasized the importance of individual action and local government efforts. Romney recounted a story from his high school days, where a small group of students managed to clean up a trash-strewn football field by each taking responsibility for a small section.

Romney did not suggest that voluntary efforts alone could replace the government's role in disaster relief, but during a Republican primary debate last year, he argued for a more decentralized approach to disaster relief, stating, "Every time you have an occasion to take something from the federal government and send it back to the states, that's the right direction."

State disaster officials have sometimes clashed with the federal government, but President Obama has appointed a disaster professional, Craig Fugate, to head the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA). Fugate, who previously ran Florida's emergency agency, understands the states' perspective and has promised to keep red tape to a minimum during the recovery process.

Republican Governor Chris Christie of New Jersey praised the federal response to the storm, stating, "I have to say, the administration—the president himself and FEMA Administrator Craig Fugate have been outstanding with us so far."

While Texas leads the nation in federal disaster declarations, the federal government's role in disaster relief remains a contentious issue for some Republicans, who have suggested cutting the FEMA budget. During the same GOP debate last year, Romney stated, "We should take all of what we're doing at the federal level and say, what are the things we're doing that we don't have to do? And those things we've got to stop doing."

Romney did not address questions about FEMA funding during Tuesday's canned food drive. President Obama will continue to make the case for an active federal role in disaster relief on Wednesday, with a tour of hard-hit New Jersey.

Title: Senator Marco Rubio Vows to Block Spending Bill Unless Obamacare is Defunded

Article:

Senator Marco Rubio (R-FL) has pledged not to vote for a short-term spending bill to maintain government operations unless it defunds the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare. In a speech at a breakfast event hosted by The Weekly Standard and Concerned Veterans for America, Rubio urged his fellow senators to follow suit.

Rubio's statement comes as the enrollment period for the Obamacare health insurance exchanges is set to begin in October. He described the ongoing debate as coinciding with the "implosion" of Obamacare.

In his speech, Rubio praised America's uniqueness while criticizing President Barack Obama's health care law as "un-implementable." He predicted numerous issues during the rollout of Obamacare this fall, such as delays in the readiness of insurance exchanges and the government's inability to verify individuals' income to ensure they are not receiving excessive insurance subsidies.

Rubio anticipates a critical moment when members of Congress realize they will lose their federal health insurance plans and be forced to enroll in the exchanges in January, a requirement in the law that was not initially intended to be included in the final legislation.

Rubio portrayed the Affordable Care Act as a significant example of the profound philosophical differences between the two major political parties, with budget, environmental, and gun control issues also being key points of contention. In his 20-minute speech, Rubio did not mention immigration, a topic currently under discussion in the House, where he was one of the driving forces behind the bipartisan Senate bill.

Title: Administration Fears Flawed Healthcare Law Component Could Bankrupt Insurance Companies, Jeopardize ObamaCare

Article:

The Obama administration has privately expressed concerns that a flawed component of the healthcare law, known as the "back end," could potentially bankrupt insurance companies and jeopardize ObamaCare itself. According to John Goodman of the National Center for Policy Analysis, the administration has been publicly reassuring the public that everything is functioning correctly, only to abruptly terminate contracts with contractors.

To justify a no-bid contract with Accenture after firing CGI as the lead contractor, the administration released documents from the Department of Health and Human Services and the Center for Medicare and Medicaid Services. These documents revealed the administration's worst fears, stating that the problems with the website could put "the entire health insurance industry at risk," potentially leading to their default and disrupting services and coverage for consumers. If the problems were not fixed by mid-March, they could result in financial harm to the government, and the entire healthcare reform program could be jeopardized.

Despite the "urgent" need officials cited to keep the system from collapsing, the White House spokesman, Jay Carney, stated he was unaware of these statements. Health and Human Services Secretary Kathleen Sebelius, however, gave an upbeat account in early December, stating, "I’m thrilled that we ’re going to have millions of people for the first time that have health security."

Shortly after the website went live, it was revealed that a critical part of the system, the "back end," had not even been built yet. Doug Holtz-Eakin, former head of the Congressional Budget Office, explained that the back end is responsible for transmitting information to insurance companies, allowing them to know who the policyholders are and what policies they have selected. However, the back end has not been built, causing massive confusion and missing information for insurance companies regarding who has signed up and what subsidies they are entitled to.

Sebelius insisted once again on Wednesday that everything would come together, and insurance companies would receive their payments. "I mean we will get them paid," she said. "There is no question about that, so we are on track." For now, officials concede they are relying on estimates from the insurers.

Critics argue that the administration's reliance on the honor system for payments is problematic, as there is no effective way to match policies, people, and federal subsidies. Jim Capretta of the Ethics and Public Policy Center explained, "Here's who we think we have, and here's the subsidy we think they're owed. Please send us a check from the treasury."

The administration emphasizes that fixing the site by mid-March is urgent to prevent the system from descending into chaos and threatening the future of ObamaCare. Meanwhile, a new Quinnipiac poll gives the president poor grades for his management of health care, with 59 percent disapproving while 36 percent approve.

Title: CMS Proposes Changes to Obamacare's Risk Adjustment System to Address Insurer Concerns

Article:

The Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) has released new proposed rules for the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare), aiming to bolster the law's exchanges that have been facing challenges in attracting health insurance companies. The 294-page rule, titled "Notice of Benefit and Payment Parameters for 2018," focuses on changes to the risk adjustment system, a mechanism that distributes risk among participating insurers to ensure no insurer bears an unusually sick and expensive customer base.

The proposed changes aim to factor in data about prescription drug usage and account for beneficiaries who only enroll for part of the year. The goal is to mitigate the high cost of very sick individuals who rely on expensive drugs and people who are gaming the system by paying for insurance only when they need it.

Concerns have been raised about the specifics of the prescription drug changes, with experts suggesting that doctors might write additional unnecessary prescriptions to get the coding right, potentially increasing overall healthcare spending.

The new rules are seen as an acknowledgment by the federal government of the problems with the exchanges. Insurers have been dropping out of Obamacare's exchanges, dramatically raising premiums, and implying they might pull out of even more of the health law marketplaces if their premium hikes are blocked.

The proposed rules are CMS's response to insurer complaints, with the somewhat unusual timing of the release intended to calm insurers. The risk adjustment rules are typically released much later in the year, but with Aetna and other carriers making significant moves to scale back their exchange business, CMS took the step of releasing the proposal now.

While the new rules may quell some of the grumbling from insurers, they are unlikely to have a significant impact on the essential problem that insurers operating in Obamacare's exchanges face: a lack of revenue to cover the claims being made by customers. The problem is not the specific rules by which Obamacare's exchanges operate; it is the health mix and number of customers inside the exchanges.

In summary, the new rules represent small tweaks designed to show insurers that the federal government is still engaged with their business, but the challenges facing Obamacare's exchanges are significant and may not be resolved by these changes alone.

Title: President Obama Discusses Terrorism, NSA, and Other Topics on The Tonight Show

Article:

In his sixth appearance on The Tonight Show, President Barack Obama discussed a range of topics, including terrorism, the temporary closure of U.S. embassies, the NSA, and the George Zimmerman trial.

During the interview, President Obama emphasized the ongoing threat of terrorism, stating, "This radical, violent extremism is still out there, and we've got to stay on top of it." He also addressed the embassy closures, suggesting that travelers should exercise caution and stay informed about potential dangers before traveling.

Regarding the NSA, Obama stated, "We do not have a domestic spying program. What we do have are some mechanisms where we can track a phone number or an email address that we know is connected to some sort of terrorist threat."

On the George Zimmerman trial, Obama expressed a desire for due process, stating, "We don't know yet exactly what he did, other than what he's said on the Internet, and it's important for me not to prejudge something."

The president also addressed the ongoing tension between the U.S. and Russia, particularly in regards to Russia's threat to enforce anti-gay laws at the 2014 Winter Olympics in Sochi. He expressed hope that Russia would ensure the Olympics run smoothly and that athletes would be treated equally.

In lighter moments, Obama praised Senator John McCain, calling him a person of integrity, and joked about the post-White House glow experienced by former presidents and their families. He also spoke about the Trayvon Martin case, expressing empathy for the Martin family and discussing the sensitive nature of the case for African American families.

The interview concluded with Obama praising Jay Leno and expressing his enjoyment of the show.

Title: Media Struggles to Balance Coverage of President Trump's Unconventional Speeches

Article:

The speech delivered by President Donald Trump at his Tuesday evening rally in Milwaukee was, by most standards, an unconventional affair. The president engaged in a lengthy tirade about lightbulbs, toilets, and showers; touted war crimes; joked about a former president being in hell; and expressed a desire to see one of his domestic political opponents imprisoned.

In an attempt to capture the speech's disconcerting oddness, media outlets face a challenge in describing Trump as he is, as a report that seems to portray the president as foolish or anti-Trump can be perceived as biased. For media outlets that view themselves as impartial, efforts to provide a sober, "balanced" look at presidential speeches often result in normalizing behaviors that are far from normal.

A brief report about Trump's Milwaukee speech that aired Wednesday morning on NPR illustrates this phenomenon. The anchor's introduction framed Trump's at times disjointed ramblings as a normal political speech that "ranged widely," and the ensuing report, which originated from member station WUWM Milwaukee Public Radio, characterized his delivery as one in which he "snapped back at Democrats for bringing impeachment proceedings."

"Trump was taking on Democrats on their own territory," the reporter said, when in reality, Trump heaped abuse on them, for instance, suggesting former Vice President Joe Biden is experiencing memory loss.

This NPR clip illustrates how the media subtly normalizes Trump. His speech last night in Milwaukee, in which he ranted about lightbulbs and toilets, touted war crimes, and joked about a former president being in hell, is presented as a typical political speech.

Georgetown University public affairs professor Don Moynihan noted on Twitter that NPR's report about the rally "mentioned specific topics like Iran and impeachment but carefully omitted the insane stuff. This is one way the media strives to present Trump as a normal president."

NPR is not alone in this struggle to cover Trump. As I wrote following a previous Trump rally in Wisconsin last April, outlets including CBS, USA Today, the Associated Press, and The Hill failed to mention in their reporting that Trump pushed dozens of lies and incendiary smears during his speech.

The irony is that the media is one of Trump's foremost targets of abuse. He calls the press the "enemy of the people," yet the very outlets he demeans regularly bend over backward to cover him in the most favorable possible light.

The disconnect between the real Trump and the whitewashed version that emerges from mainstream reporting was captured nicely by Guardian Australia editor Lenore Taylor in a piece she wrote last September headlined, "As a foreign reporter visiting the US I was stunned by Trump's press conference."

"I've read so many stories about his bluster and boasting and ill-founded attacks, I've listened to speeches and hours of analysis, and yet I was still taken back by just how disjointed and meandering the unedited president could sound," Taylor wrote. "I'd understood the dilemma of normalizing Trump's ideas and policies – the racism, misogyny, and demonization of the free press. But watching just one press conference [in real time] helped me understand how the process of reporting about this president can mask and normalize his full and alarming incoherence."

It is difficult to cover Trump, and it is important to honor the public's trust in the press by providing fair and balanced coverage. However, we also have to pay attention to how much more alarming the unfiltered Trump is when compared to the sanitized version that often emerges in mainstream media reporting. The news moves fast. To stay updated, follow Aaron Rupar on Twitter, and read more of ███'s policy and politics coverage.

Title: California Orders Residents to Stay at Home to Combat Coronavirus Spread

Article:

California Governor Gavin Newsom has ordered all residents to stay at home, except for essential activities, to help slow the spread of the novel coronavirus. The order, which affects nearly 40 million people, was announced Thursday and follows similar measures taken in Los Angeles County and the Bay Area earlier in the week.

As of Wednesday evening, California has confirmed 675 cases of COVID-19 and 16 deaths from the disease, placing it behind Washington state and New York, where over 5,000 cases have been reported. The order takes effect immediately and will remain in place indefinitely, with Governor Newsom stating that officials "could not give a deadline that we really could believe in."

The Los Angeles order, which will stay in effect until at least April 19, requires all businesses, including museums, malls, retail stores, and workplaces, to stop operations. Residents are only allowed to leave their homes for essential activities such as picking up food, going to the doctor, or taking a walk in the neighborhood. Businesses will have an additional day to prepare to close, with the order taking effect midnight Thursday.

"We’ve already radically changed how we live in Los Angeles," Mayor Eric Garcetti said during a press briefing. "We need to be painfully honest tonight that we're about to enter into a new way of living here."

The order comes as health officials across California continue to monitor the spread of the virus. The situation is described as dynamic, with Governor Newsom urging residents to stay informed and follow the guidelines set forth by health officials.

Title: Former U.S. National Security Officials Reject Trump's National Emergency Declaration for Border Wall

Article:

A group of nearly 60 former senior U.S. national security officials, including former Secretaries of State Madeleine Albright and John Kerry, former Republican Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel, and others, have rejected President Donald Trump's national emergency declaration to fund his long-promised border wall. In an 11-page letter, they stated that there is no documented emergency at the U.S.-Mexico border.

The letter, first reported by the Washington Post, asserts that diverting funds to the project will "undermine U.S. national security and foreign policy interests." Trump moved to redirect federal funds intended for other purposes to build the border wall after Congress rejected his demand for $5.7 billion in construction money.

The resolution to stop Trump's border emergency is currently being debated in the U.S. House of Representatives, with a vote scheduled for Tuesday. The resolution's fate is less clear in the U.S. Senate, though some Republicans have expressed concern about Trump's declaration. In a separate letter on Monday, 23 former Republican U.S. lawmakers also urged current members of Congress to pass the resolution.

Even if the resolution passes, Trump has stated he would veto it, and Congress would need to muster two-thirds of lawmakers to override a veto. Trump, on Monday, continued to defend the declaration on Twitter, urging Republican senators to stand by him.

The former security officials, in Monday's letter, cited U.S. government statistics showing illegal border crossings at nearly 40-year lows. They also pointed to other government data on drug trafficking that showed most opioids enter the country via legal entry points, something they said a border wall would not stop.

"There is no factual basis for the declaration of a national emergency for the purpose of circumventing the appropriations process and reprogramming billions of dollars in funding to construct a wall at the southern border," they wrote.

While the letter included both Republicans and Democrats, as well as career civil servants who served under presidents of both parties, the bulk of its most senior signatories rose to their top positions under Democratic presidents. Among these former officials were CIA Director and Defense Secretary Leon Panetta, CIA Director John Brennan, White House National Security Adviser Susan Rice, Deputy Secretary of State Antony Blinken, and Deputy CIA Director David Cohen, all of whom held those posts under Democratic President Barack Obama.

However, the list also included lower-level former officials such as John Bellinger, a former State Department legal adviser, and Eliot Cohen, a former State Department counselor, both of whom served under Republican President George W. Bush.

Title: U.S. Senators Request Criminal Investigation into Ex-MI6 Officer over Alleged False Statements

Article:

Two senior U.S. senators, Chuck Grassley and Lindsey Graham, have called for a criminal investigation into former MI6 officer Christopher Steele over a dossier he compiled regarding President Trump's alleged Russian links. During a Senate Judiciary Committee hearing, the Republicans found that Steele had shared details from the dossier with "multiple U.S. news outlets."

This revelation could suggest that Steele may have made "false statements" during his FBI interviews. The senators have since handed over the communications to the U.S. Department of Justice.

The dossier, which alleged that Mr. Trump had colluded with Russian officials during his election campaign and that Kremlin spies filmed him with prostitutes at Moscow's Ritz-Carlton hotel in 2013, has been the subject of numerous official investigations, including one led by Special Counsel Robert Mueller. Both Moscow and Mr. Trump have denied these allegations.

Chuck Grassley, who chairs the committee, stated that the decision to refer the case for criminal investigation was not made lightly but was necessary for "appropriate review." He added, "After reviewing how Mr. Steele conducted himself in distributing information contained in the dossier and how many stop signs the DoJ ignored in its use of the dossier, I believe that a special counsel needs to review this matter."

Grassley further stated, "The rule of law depends on the government and all who work on its behalf playing by the rules themselves. I hope the Department of Justice will carefully review our letter and take appropriate action."

In a joint statement, Grassley and his colleague Lindsey Graham clarified that they were not alleging that Steele had committed any crime. Instead, they had passed on the information for "further investigation only."

The Steele dossier, which became public in January 2017, was compiled after an investigation funded by Republicans trying to block Mr. Trump from becoming the party's presidential candidate. Democrats then took over funding the investigation after he was nominated.

Christopher Steele, who founded and runs Orbis Business Intelligence in London, is said to have shared his findings with both U.S. and UK intelligence in the run-up to the 2016 presidential election. He briefly went into hiding after he was revealed as the dossier's author but subsequently returned to work. The UK law firm representing Mr. Steele declined to comment.

Title: Obama and Holder Call for Reform of Mandatory Minimum Sentencing for Nonviolent Drug Offenders

Article:

President Barack Obama has expressed his support for the abolition of mandatory minimum sentencing for nonviolent drug offenders, following an announcement by Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. on Monday. Holder's statement signaled a potential shift in federal drug-sentencing policy, which has been criticized as unjust and disproportionately affecting minority communities.

In his statement, Holder described the current system as "broken" and called for Congress to consider and pass bipartisan legislation to provide flexibility for federal judges in sentencing nonviolent offenders. The legislation, introduced by Obama and Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Patrick J. Leahy, aims to restore judicial discretion in federal cases.

The United States has the highest incarceration rate in the world, with nearly half of inmates serving time for drug-related crimes. Critics argue that the focus on draconian punishment has done little to enhance public safety and has resulted in decades of damage, particularly to young people.

Many nonviolent offenders find themselves incarcerated for lengthy periods, sometimes for making a single mistake, due to federal mandatory minimum laws implemented in the 1970s, '80s, and '90s. These laws forced judges to deliver sentences far lengthier than they would have if allowed to use their own discretion.

The Associated Press reported this week that, in some cases, young people were sentenced to prison for decades for nonviolent drug crimes, even if they were unaware of the illegal substances in their possession. One such example is the case of a 19-year-old who was sentenced to 10 years in prison for conspiracy for being in a car where drugs were found.

Mandatory minimum sentencing has disproportionately affected minority communities, as these laws often make it impossible for well-meaning judges, law enforcement, and families to do anything to reverse these bad decisions.

One such victim of these laws is Timothy Tyler, who was sentenced to life in prison for selling LSD to a police informant in 1994. Tyler should have been punished for selling drugs, but he should not have to spend the rest of his life in prison for it. Today, Timothy is 45 and will likely spend the rest of his life behind bars, not because a judge thought it was a proper punishment, but because an arbitrary federal law demanded it.

The president and founder of Families Against Mandatory Minimums, Julie Stewart, told Business Insider that Tyler was a "kid" who was following the Grateful Dead. She added, "It always seemed really absurd to me that for this nonviolent guy who was 24 years old, the government could write off his life."

Nonviolent offenders don't always return to society as normal and productive citizens after serving hard time alongside rapists and murderers. Those who are released after decades of imprisonment often have trouble finding employment and suffer from a host of other problems related to their history.

Sen. Rand Paul (Kentucky Republican) has also expressed his support for the reform of mandatory minimum sentencing. He is a member of the Senate Foreign Relations and Homeland Security committees. Obama and Leahy have introduced the Justice Safety Valve Act (S. 619) to permanently restore justice by preserving judicial discretion in federal cases. The legislation aims to be a bipartisan legislative fix to the very problem Holder now addresses.

It is now the responsibility of Congress to work together to change these laws and protect future generations from the damage caused by mandatory minimum sentencing.

Title: Midterm Elections and Controversial Events: A Look at the Kavanaugh Hearings, Immigration Caravan, and Elizabeth Warren's DNA Test

Article:

In the lead-up to the 2018 midterm elections, several controversial events have dominated the headlines, including the immigration caravan from Central America, the contentious confirmation hearings for Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh, and Senator Elizabeth Warren's DNA test results.

The immigration caravan, consisting of over 5,000 mostly Honduran migrants, has been making its way through Mexico, with plans to cross the U.S. border illegally and seek asylum. The timing of the caravan's arrival has raised questions, as it comes just before the midterms, potentially aimed at creating empathy and swaying voters towards progressive candidates advocating for a more relaxed immigration policy.

The Kavanaugh confirmation hearings, marked by protests, walkouts, and disruptions, were intended to portray Republican senators as insensitive to sexual assault allegations made against Kavanaugh. However, the lack of corroborating evidence and the ensuing chaos surrounding the hearings may have had the opposite effect on voters.

Senator Elizabeth Warren's DNA test results, aimed at proving her Native American heritage, instead confirmed that she is likely less than 1% Native American and not from a U.S. tribe. This revelation has been met with skepticism and criticism, as many Americans question the motives behind her claims.

As the midterms approach, progressives hope that these public spectacles focusing on feminist, immigrant, and identity issues will galvanize independents and undecided voters. However, the caravan, the Kavanaugh hearings, and the Warren DNA test may serve to remind voters of the importance of border security, due process, and the rule of law, rather than the intended focus on economic issues.

In the end, the midterms will likely hinge on a variety of factors, and the impact of these events on voter sentiment remains to be seen.

Title: Trump's Presidential Campaign Struggles in Key States Due to Lack of Ground Operations

Article:

The term "Loser" is a colloquialism used in the political sphere to describe a candidate who spends a significant amount of time criticizing the media. This term was famously applied to Bob Dole during his presidential campaign in 1996, marking the end of his bid for the presidency.

In the 2016 presidential race, it is likely that Donald Trump will lose the election, with Hillary Rodham Clinton winning more votes than Trump. This prediction is based on the fact that the type of rhetoric that resonates in conservative circles may not be as popular in the rest of the country, potentially coming off as strange or unsettling. For instance, more people watch the sitcom "The Middle" than watch Sean Hannity's nightly Trump-focused show on Fox News.

Recently, Trump has faced criticism for his comments regarding President Obama and the Islamic State. In an attempt to clarify his remarks, his advisor Hugh Hewitt suggested that Trump meant Obama created the conditions for the Islamic State's rise, rather than founding the group itself. However, Trump insisted that he did indeed mean that President Obama is the founder of ISIS.

Trump's campaign has been criticized for its lack of ground operations in key states. As of last week, the Trump campaign had only one staffer in southwest Ohio and one field office in Florida. This lack of presence is contributing to Trump's poor performance in these states, as well as in Virginia, North Carolina, and Colorado, where Clinton leads him by significant margins.

In addition to the media, Trump has also blamed the media for his perceived negative portrayal, stating that the media is unfair to Republicans. However, it is not the media that is preventing Trump from organizing a presidential campaign, but rather his own campaign's lack of resources and organization.

It is too early to begin the post-election recriminations, but it is worth noting that Trump's performance in the debates against Hillary Rodham Clinton may be a cause for concern, as he has expressed a desire to avoid the debates. This is in stark contrast to other candidates, such as Ted Cruz, who would likely have welcomed multiple debates.

A correction has been made to a previous statement regarding a quote from Trump complaining to Hannity about media coverage. The quote is a fabrication from a satire columnist.

Title: U.S. and Russia's Role in Syria's Ongoing Conflict

Article:

The Syrian conflict, with increasing intensity and lethal weapons on both sides, is threatening to undermine diplomatic efforts aimed at resolving the crisis. Kofi Annan, the United Nations and Arab League's special envoy, is pressing Damascus to halt the violence and respect a cease-fire. However, if Syrian President Bashar al-Assad does not cease violence by mid-July, the United Nations may end its observer mission in the country.

Secretary of State Hillary Clinton continues to advocate for a "managed transition," under which Assad would step aside. Russia's role is considered crucial, and Clinton's claims about helicopter shipments are expected to escalate tensions with Moscow less than a week before President Obama is scheduled to meet with President Vladimir V. Putin at a summit meeting in Mexico.

Administration officials declined to provide details about the helicopters, citing classified information. However, Pentagon sources suggest that Clinton, in her remarks at a Brookings Institution event, was referring to Russian-made attack helicopters that Syria already owns but has not yet deployed against opposition forces. While these helicopters, known as Mi-24s, are flown by Syrian pilots, Russia supplies spare parts and provides maintenance for them.

The use of helicopters is contributing to a growing sense that the conflict could be characterized as a civil war. United Nations peacekeeping operations head Hervé Ladsous stated, "The government of Syria lost some large chunks of territories and several cities to the opposition and wants to retake control of these areas. So now we have confirmed reports not only of the use of tanks and artillery, but also attack helicopters."

Opposition leaders are wary of the term "civil war" because it suggests an even match. Samir Nachar, a member of the Syrian National Council's executive committee, said, "Civil war will not come suddenly in one day or two or five, but you have to look how things are gradually changing on the ground. Can you say to people, 'Don't defend yourselves?' It is impossible."

Council members also expressed caution about reading too much into Clinton's claim, suggesting that it was an open secret for months that the Russians were supplying weapons to Syria. There have been repeated reports of Russian armament ships docking in Syria, although Moscow has always denied that they were carrying the arms used to suppress the protests.

In addition to the United States and Russia, Turkey has been providing support to the opposition, delivering antitank weaponry to the Syrian border, where it is then transferred to smugglers who take it into Syria. The more powerful weapons have been delivered as far south as the suburbs of Damascus, but not into Damascus itself, according to sources in the Syrian National Council.

However, the presence of the antitank missiles has not stemmed the violence. On Tuesday, a team of United Nations cease-fire monitors retreated before reaching Al Heffa in the northwest when hostile crowds attacked their vehicles with stones and metal rods. "The shelling has been continuous," said Houran al-Hafawi, a member of the local coordination committee of Al Heffa. "The Syrian Army is throwing missiles and rockets from helicopters and rocket launchers from the eastern and western entrances."

The debate over Russia's rearming of Syria took an unusual turn on Tuesday when Senator John Cornyn, a Texas Republican, complained that the U.S. military was buying attack helicopters for Afghan security forces from the same Russian weapons company supplying the Assad government. Pentagon press secretary George Little defended the purchases of the Mi-17 helicopters from the Russian company, Rosoboronexport, as important to helping Afghanistan create a credible self-defense force. Little stated, "It's about equipping the Afghan air force with what they need to ensure that they have the capabilities from an air standpoint to defend themselves."

Title: Professor's Predictive Model Suggests High Probability of President Trump's Re-election

Article:

A political science professor, Helmut Norpoth of Stony Brook University, has predicted that President Donald Trump is likely to be re-elected based on his election prediction model. The professor shared this prediction with the website Mediaite.

In 2016, Norpoth's model predicted Trump's victory, despite polls indicating otherwise. The university reported that Norpoth gave Trump an 87-99% chance of beating Hillary Clinton nearly a year before the election, a prediction that proved accurate.

The model, which has correctly predicted 25 out of the last 27 elections, now suggests that President Trump has a 91% chance of being re-elected. The model also indicates that Trump could secure a larger Electoral College majority this time compared to his 2016 victory.

Professor Norpoth's model emphasizes the importance of a candidate's early enthusiasm in the nominating process, disregarding opinion polls. Currently, polls show Joe Biden leading over Trump, but Norpoth points out that many candidates have led in the polls in the spring but lost in the fall.

"The terrain of presidential contests is littered with nominees who saw a poll lead in the spring turn to dust in the fall," Norpoth said.

With the election still several months away, polls can change significantly, especially after the candidates hold their nominating conventions and presidential debates. While the Biden campaign has stated that Biden will engage in three debates with Trump, there are concerns about whether these debates will actually take place, given Biden's perceived gaffes, such as those raised by critics regarding his mental abilities.

The article concludes by encouraging readers to engage in discussions through the publication's social media accounts.

Title: Iranian Oil Tanker Sabiti Hit by Two Explosions Off Saudi Coast

Article:

An Iranian oil tanker, the Sabiti, owned by The National Iran Oil Company, was struck by two explosions approximately 60 miles from the port of Jeddah, Saudi Arabia, around 5am local time on Friday. The incident, which reportedly involved two missiles, caused significant damage to two main storage tanks on board the vessel, resulting in oil leaks into the Red Sea.

The National Iranian Tanker Company, which owns the vessel, stated that the missiles had damaged the two main storage tanks, causing them to leak into the ocean. The ship remained afloat after the attack and, according to tracking data, has turned around and is heading back towards the Persian Gulf.

The Sabiti is carrying 1 million barrels of oil and had not transmitted its location for 57 days prior to the explosions. Iranian tankers often turn off their trackers to evade US sanctions on oil exports.

Iranian media reported that the blasts occurred around 5am and 5.20am local time. The Nour news agency, which is close to the Iranian Revolutionary Guard Corps, stated that the crew of the Sabiti was safe and had managed to get the leak under control.

However, the state-owned National Iranian Tanker Company said that contrary to reports, 'there is no fire aboard the ship and the ship is completely stable.' There was no immediate response from Saudi Arabia regarding the reported attack.

Lt. Pete Pagano, a spokesman for the U.S. Navy's 5th Fleet, which is currently positioned near Iran, said authorities there were "aware of reports of this incident," but declined to comment further.

Iran has not publicly identified who it believes is responsible for the attack on the Sabiti. Iranian Foreign Ministry spokesman Abbas Mousavi stated only that the attack was carried out by those committing "dangerous adventurism." Mousavi added that the Sabiti was struck twice in a half-hour span and an investigation was underway.

Russia's foreign ministry has also stated it is too early to assign blame for the attack. The incident follows a series of attacks on tankers, drones, and oil facilities in the region, with many of these incidents being blamed on Iran.

Oil prices surged more than two percent following the attack, with Brent crude oil rising 2.3 percent to $60.46, and West Texas Intermediate rising 2.1 percent to $54.69. The Iranian tanker was hit following months of tensions around the Arabian Peninsula.

In May, four tankers—two belonging to Saudi Arabia, one to Norway, and one to the UAE—were struck by explosions near the UAE in the Gulf of Oman. An investigation by the UAE, America, and France concluded that holes in the vessels were likely caused by explosive charges placed near the waterline. The US accused Iran of being responsible for the attacks, though may not have directly carried them out.

The attacks led to spiraling tensions around the Gulf, which saw Tehran shoot down an American Navy drone, nearly leading to the US bombing Iran. Tensions rose further last month when a Saudi refinery—the world's largest—and oil field were hit by drones and missiles, which the kingdom said were fired by Iran. The explosions shut down 5.7 million barrels per day (bpd) of production—more than 5 percent of global oil supply.

In May, another four vessels were hit by explosions in the Gulf of Oman, an attack that was also blamed on Iran. Yemen's Houthi group claimed responsibility for the attacks, but a U.S. official said they originated from southwestern Iran. Riyadh blamed Tehran. Iran, which supports the Houthis in Yemen's war, has denied any involvement. Instability in the region was sparked when Donald Trump withdrew the US from the Iran nuclear deal, signed under Barack Obama. The deal, which was also backed by European powers including Russia, had promised the regime economic benefits in return for curtailing its nuclear program in a way that would stop it developing weapons. Trump tore up the deal last year by reimposing crippling sanctions on Iran, prompting Tehran to stop complying with the deal by accelerating its enrichment of uranium and rebuilding stockpiles. The President has said he wants to negotiate a new deal with Tehran, but Iran has refused to enter fresh talks, urging the US to return to the terms of the original deal. While European countries have tried to establish economic measures to skirt the American sanctions, these have been largely ineffective.

Title: Trump Accuses China of Interfering in U.S. Election Over Coronavirus Response

Article:

In an interview with ███ on Wednesday, U.S. President Donald Trump accused China of attempting to interfere in the upcoming U.S. presidential election, stating that Beijing wants his Democratic opponent, Joe Biden, to win to ease pressure on China over trade and other issues. Trump has been critical of China's handling of the coronavirus pandemic, which has resulted in a global death toll of at least 60,000 people in the United States, according to a ███ tally, and has caused a deep recession in the U.S. economy.

Trump has been vocal about his belief that China should have informed the world about the virus sooner. When asked about potential consequences for China, Trump said, "There are many things I can do. We’re looking for what happened." He did not offer specifics regarding the use of tariffs or debt write-offs.

China's foreign ministry stated that it has no interest in interfering in the U.S. presidential election. Spokesman Geng Shuang told reporters during a daily briefing that the Nov. 3 election is the internal affair of the United States, and Beijing hopes Americans will not try to drag China into it.

Trump also discussed the Phase 1 trade deal with Chinese President Xi Jinping, stating that the economic fallout from the virus has "upset very badly" the agreement aimed at reducing chronic U.S. trade deficits with China. A senior Trump administration official said an informal "truce" in the war of words between Trump and Xi now appears to be over.

Trump and his top aides have increased their anti-China rhetoric but have stopped short of directly criticizing Xi, whom Trump has repeatedly called his "friend." Trump initially praised Xi and his government for their response and "transparency" over the virus.

Trump also discussed the defense cooperation agreement with South Korea, stating that Seoul has agreed to pay the United States more money. He would not disclose the amount. The United States stations roughly 28,500 troops in South Korea, a legacy of the 1950-1953 Korean War that ended in an armistice, rather than with a peace treaty.

Trump is leading a triage effort to keep the U.S. economy afloat through stimulus payments to individuals and companies while nudging state governors to carefully reopen their states as new infections decline. Trump sounded wistful about the strong economy before the pandemic, stating, "We were rocking before this happened. We had the greatest economy in history."

Trump's handling of the virus has come under scrutiny, with 43% of Americans approving of his handling of the coronavirus outbreak, according to an ███/Ipsos poll from April 27-28. There was some good news in the coronavirus battle on Wednesday, as Gilead Sciences Inc said its experimental antiviral drug remdesivir was showing progress in treating virus victims. Trump has also sought an accelerated timetable on development of a vaccine.

At the end of the half-hour interview, Trump offered lighthearted remarks about a newly released Navy video purportedly showing an unidentified flying object. "I just wonder if it’s real," he said. "That’s a hell of a video."

Title: Russian Agent Maria Butina Sentenced to 18 Months in Prison for Conspiracy

Article:

A Russian national, Maria Butina, has been sentenced to 18 months in prison for conspiracy in a case involving attempts to infiltrate US political groups. Butina, who pleaded not guilty initially, later admitted to a single count of conspiracy in December. The 30-year-old has been in custody since her arrest in July.

Butina, speaking in court in Washington DC on Friday, expressed remorse for her actions, stating, "I destroyed my own life. I came to the United States not under any orders, but with hope, and now nothing remains but penitence."

Despite Butina's apology, US District Judge Tanya Chutkan was reportedly unmoved, stating that her actions "jeopardized" the country's national security. The judge's sentencing decision complied with the government's sentencing recommendation.

Butina was directed by a senior Russian official to infiltrate conservative political groups, including an unnamed pro-gun lobbying organization presumed to be the National Rifle Association (NRA), which is allied with President Donald Trump's Republican party.

As part of a plea deal, Butina agreed to cooperate with investigators. Judge Chutkan noted on Friday that Butina had provided "substantial assistance" to law enforcement. Prosecutors expect the deal will provide information about Russia's efforts to interfere in US politics.

Butina admitted to working with former Russian lawmaker Alexander Torshin to infiltrate the NRA and pursue backdoor channels of communication to American conservatives who could influence US politics. She failed to report her activities to US authorities, as required by law.

Butina faced a maximum of five years in prison. The case has no connection with the Mueller inquiry into alleged Russian meddling in the 2016 presidential election.

In a statement read in court, one of the prosecutors said Butina had drafted a document called "Diplomacy Project" in March 2015, which called for unofficial communication lines between high-ranking US officials and Russia. The Russian Embassy in Washington described Butina as a "political prisoner" and demanded her immediate release. The Russian government has previously described the case as "fabricated."

Title: Senior Republicans Break Ranks on Tax Pledge, Raising Questions About Norquist's Influence

Article:

For decades, conservative lobbyist Grover Norquist has been known for his pledge to drive Republicans out of office if they did not promise to oppose tax increases. Many lawmakers signed on. However, several senior Republicans are now breaking ranks, willing to consider raising more revenue through taxes as part of a deal with Democrats to avoid a catastrophic budget meltdown.

Tennessee Sen. Bob Corker states that the only pledge he will keep is his oath of office. House Majority Leader Eric Cantor, from Virginia, says no one in his home state is discussing Norquist's pledge, a 1986 invention often referred to as "The Pledge." Georgia Sen. Saxby Chambliss states he cares more about his country than sticking to Norquist's pledge.

This shift in stance from senior members of the Republican party, traditionally firm against tax increases, is significant. While GOP leaders maintain they do not want taxes to increase, the reality of a nation in a debt crisis is forcing some to moderate their opposition to any changes in tax payments to fund the government. Republican legislators and Democratic President Barack Obama's White House are currently negotiating details for tax adjustments and spending cuts before automatic, drastic changes occur at the new year.

Sen. Jeff Sessions of Alabama acknowledged signing Norquist's pledge but stated, "We've got to deal with the crisis we face. We've got to deal with the political reality of the president's victory."

The questioning of Norquist's pledge is leading to speculation about his diminishing power within the GOP. Norquist, the head of the conservative Americans for Tax Reform, opposes any tax increases, whether through eliminating deductions or raising rates. He has maintained a significant level of influence for years, despite not holding public office.

House Speaker John Boehner has dismissed Norquist as "some random person." Nevertheless, Norquist has maintained a certain level of clout for years. Heading into the 2012 elections, 279 lawmakers had signed Norquist's pledge, according to Americans for Tax Reform. However, some who have signed the pledge are having second thoughts. When the new House is seated next year, no more than 212 of them consider themselves bound by the promise.

Sen. Lindsey Graham of South Carolina stated, "I agree with Grover, we should not raise rates. But I think Grover is wrong when it comes to we can't cap deductions and buy down debt." Rep. Peter King of New York suggested the pledge is only valid for a two-year term. Sen. John McCain, the Republican presidential nominee in 2008, stated the pledge is losing its clout.

Title: Healthcare Funding Continues Ahead of Supreme Court Ruling on Affordable Care Act

Article:

The Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) has distributed over $2.7 billion in grants and awards since the conclusion of oral arguments in the Supreme Court case challenging the constitutionality of the Affordable Care Act (ACA) on March 28, according to a review of funding announcements. This is more than double the amount distributed in the three-month period preceding the arguments.

While much of this funding was already in the pipeline before March, the timing for the distribution of specific funds is not rigid, allowing the agency flexibility in the types of funds it disperses. The Supreme Court is expected to announce its decision this week.

The $2.7 billion includes over $90 million in funds for health insurance cooperatives, which HHS announced on Friday. In contrast, the administration distributed approximately $1 billion in grants, loans, and other awards during the three months before the Supreme Court arguments.

An HHS spokesperson disputed the suggestion that there was any change in the timeline due to the court. "This story is flat-out wrong. Since the passage of the Affordable Care Act more than two years ago, we have worked continuously to implement the law and to educate the American people about the benefits," the spokesperson said.

Some Republicans have advocated for a halt in the implementation of the ACA until the Supreme Court ruling. Last year, a draft of the House Labor-HHS appropriations bill, which provides funding for health care agencies, would have frozen all spending on health reform until the court ruled. Sen. Kay Bailey Hutchison (R-Texas) has been pushing a bill that would have blocked any further implementation of the law before the ruling.

Rep. Denny Rehberg (R-MT), chairman of the House Appropriations Subcommittee on Labor, HHS, Education, and Related Agencies, who authored the appropriations bill that would have put implementation funding on hold, criticized the latest HHS spending in a statement.

"It was irresponsible to spend a single dollar implementing the law before the Supreme Court rules, and I fought hard to prevent that money from being spent," Rehberg said.

Title: Biden's Remarks Highlight the Role of Social Norms in Black Political Loyalty and the Consequences of Misunderstanding These Norms

Article:

In a recent book, "Steadfast Democrats," Ismail White and Chryl Laird offer insights into the role of social norms in maintaining black support for the Democratic Party. The authors argue that black Americans prioritize group solidarity in party politics, enforcing a partisan loyalty through a process called "racialized social constraint."

The researchers conducted an experiment during the 2012 presidential election, soliciting a black student convenience sample of 106 participants from a predominantly white university in the Midwest. Participants were randomly assigned to one of three groups, where they were offered $10 to donate to either President Barack Obama or his Republican challenger, Mitt Romney. The results showed that when black participants were in a room with a black norm enforcer, they donated significantly more money to Obama than when they were alone or with a white norm enforcer.

However, Biden's comment, "If you are for Trump, then you ain't black," has sparked controversy, as many black Americans do not believe that white Americans, even Democrats, have the standing to question any black person's "blackness" under any circumstances. The authors argue that the black norm of supporting the Democratic Party is aimed at empowering the group, and Biden's comment might have been perceived as suggesting that black Americans are obligated to support him, rather than him being obligated to them for their support.

To effectively convey his commitment to black Americans, the authors suggest that Biden could signal his commitment to acting on the racial group's behalf. This can take various forms, such as showcasing social connections to prominent black individuals and organizations. Biden has often highlighted his relationship with former president Obama and regularly points to his record by saying, "The NAACP has endorsed me every time I have run."

Political scientist Andrea Benjamin's research suggests that such endorsements can influence black voters' decisions, particularly where race is concerned. Additionally, political scientists Christopher Stout and Keith Baker argue that selecting a black woman as his vice presidential nominee would go a long way to show that commitment. This would be especially potent given the fact that black women are a significant force within the Democratic Party.

In conclusion, understanding the role of social norms in black political loyalty is crucial for political candidates, and enforcing these norms by outsiders can lead to controversy. A more prudent course for a candidate would be to elevate into positions of power people who can enforce these norms effectively, signaling their commitment to the black community's interests.

Title: Senate, White House Confident in Kavanaugh's Confirmation Following FBI Supplemental Investigation

Article:

The Senate Judiciary Committee and the White House have expressed confidence in the confirmation of Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh following the completion of an FBI supplementary background investigation. In a statement, Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Chuck Grassley stated that the investigation did not reveal any new information and found no hint of misconduct.

Grassley said, "I've now received a committee staff briefing on the FBI's supplement to Judge Kavanaugh's background investigation file. There's nothing in it that we didn't already know." He further added that the committee and the FBI could not locate any third parties who could attest to the allegations made against Kavanaugh.

The White House also reviewed the report and, in an official statement, expressed confidence in Kavanaugh's confirmation. Raj Shah, the principal deputy press secretary for the White House, said, "With Leader McConnell's cloture filing, Senators have been given ample time to review this seventh background investigation." He added that this is the last addition to the most comprehensive review of a Supreme Court nominee in history, which includes extensive hearings, multiple committee interviews, over 1,200 questions for the record, and over a half million pages of documents.

President Trump also weighed in on the matter, calling the Kavanaugh confirmation battle a "very important time in our country." He tweeted, "Due Process, Fairness and Common Sense are now on trial!"

The Senate's decision on Kavanaugh's confirmation is pending. With the completion of the FBI investigation, the Senate has been given ample time to review the additional information before making a decision.

Title: Kavanaugh Hearings: A Test of America's Attitude Towards Women's Rights and Belief in Allegations

Article:

The confirmation hearings for Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh, following the sexual assault allegations made by Christine Blasey Ford, have sparked a national debate on women's rights, the #MeToo movement, and the belief in allegations. The hearings, which took place on Thursday, have been a test of how far the #MeToo movement has changed America, with progressive and conservative women expressing their views before and after the extraordinary hearing.

Progressive women, already suspicious of Kavanaugh's social values, have escalated their opposition following the sexual assault claims. Julia Peters, a 33-year-old protester in Washington D.C., stated, "This is not someone we can elect. He will be in there for a lifetime, and we know he does not stand for our values."

Grace Perret, a college junior from New Orleans, Louisiana, is concerned about the potential implications of overturning Roe v Wade, a landmark decision that grants the right to abortion. "This would have devastating implications for poor women especially, who likely cannot afford to travel" to other states to seek abortions, she explained.

The promise "We believe women" is core for Julia, as she and other protesters aim to support Dr. Ford and express their belief in her allegations. Conservative women, on the other hand, are deeply concerned about what they see as an abuse of the confirmation process.

Rachel Gill, a 22-year-old supporter of Kavanaugh, went to Capitol Hill to show her support for the nominee because she believes in the "principle of innocent until proven guilty." "I absolutely do support women who have come forward to talk about these experiences, but I also think there needs to be proof if you're going to take someone to court," she explained.

Talk of a smear campaign against Kavanaugh is common among conservative women, who fear the assault allegations are being weaponized by Democrats to prevent his confirmation. Nancy Wilson, a grandmother of 11, traveled to Washington from Fairfax County, Virginia, with two friends, wearing "I Stand With Brett" T-shirts. They explained they believe women are being misused and want Kavanaugh on the court because he is a "constitutionalist judge."

The hearings have been a moment of reckoning for women's rights in America, with progressive and conservative women expressing their beliefs and emotions. After protesting outside the Senate, Lucy Melchor, a 36-year-old from Chicago, watched the hearings. "I thought Ms. Ford's testimony was heartbreaking and compelling," she said. "It just reinforced that I believe her."

In contrast, Melchor felt Mr. Kavanaugh's testimony turned the attention away from a woman's claims of sexual assault to his anger about the political process. "I was really upset by the level of vitriol that he brought to this. It took the focus away from her and put it on politics," she said.

While progressives found Ms. Ford powerfully believable, conservative women felt exactly the same about Mr. Kavanaugh. Rachel Gill, a supporter of Kavanaugh, stated, "I think they both believe what they are saying. I believe that Ms. Ford probably was assaulted but not by Mr. Kavanaugh."

The hearings have also been a moment of reckoning for women's rights in America. Democrat Ms. Melchor commented, "It's now almost a year since the Me Too movement, and if the cards fall onto the side of not believing her story, it's really detrimental for the women who have been assaulted and will be assaulted in the future. It creates fear for them that they won't be believed in the future, and that's what upsets them the most."

Title: Supreme Court's Decision on Health Care Law: Potential Outcomes and Implications

Article:

The Supreme Court's decision on the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare, is eagerly anticipated, with a variety of plausible outcomes based on the arguments presented during the oral arguments. The court has two other rulings still on its docket, including one on the legality of lying about military medals, which may delay the health care ruling's announcement.

A majority on the court might reject the fundamental overhaul of insurance that lies at the heart of the law, finding its individual mandate unconstitutional. They might also dismiss the closely related requirements that insurers cover everybody who applies and not charge sick people more. However, much or even all of the rest of the law might be left to stand if it survives politically.

The court might go further, declaring that without the insurance provisions, the rest of the statute would never have passed Congress in the first place, and that the whole bill should be rejected. Alternatively, the court might essentially punt, accepting the argument that it was too soon to decide this case. This would keep the bitter partisan debate over the law going full tilt through the November elections and beyond.

Another possible outcome is that the court might assemble enough votes not to strike down the individual mandate, leaving the whole law standing. Before the oral arguments, many thought this outcome most likely; sharp questioning in the courtroom undermined that expectation, but did not put it completely to rest.

The court's decision on the expansion of Medicaid could also influence the core issues. The expansion of Medicaid to millions of additional people for whom private insurance is out of reach could help assure that if the law survives, insurance reaches as many people as possible.

Once the opinions are handed down and posted online, experts will quickly analyze the gist of what the court has wrought. As the scope of their judgment starts to sink in, a much larger public debate will ensue. The words in the lengthy opinions will reverberate in case law for years to come.

Title: Newt Gingrich Discusses Trump's Presidential Campaign, Potential VP Role, and Syrian Refugee Test

Article:

In an interview with The Associated Press on Saturday, former House Speaker Newt Gingrich expressed his support for Donald Trump as a "necessary candidate" reflecting a global anti-establishment sentiment. Gingrich also suggested a test to vet Syrian refugees based on Sharia law, stating it as a means to "vet Muslims if you believe in Western civilization."

Regarding Trump's vice presidential running mate, Gingrich stated that Trump will make his choice late next week, possibly on Thursday or Friday, to have a new vice presidential candidate as a positive story leading into the Republican National Convention on Monday. Gingrich mentioned that he has been vetted for the job but has yet to decide whether to partner with Trump if asked.

Gingrich also commented on the worldwide movement toward anti-establishment sentiment, citing the British vote to leave the EU and electoral successes in Europe by populists as part of this movement. He described Trump as part of this global movement, stating that the establishment perceives Trump as divisive only because they are facing a popular uprising.

Gingrich reiterated his remarks about racism in the United States, stating that white parents cannot know the fears of black parents. He emphasized the need for an open conversation about protecting both the police and the innocent to solve the ongoing issue.

Gingrich was attending a giant annual gathering of the People's Mujahedeen of Iran outside Paris, an exile opposition group calling for regime change in Iran based in France. In the interview, Gingrich expressed support for the group as modern Muslims but had less tolerance for some Syrian refugees and other Muslims. He suggested a test on Sharia law to vet Syrian refugees, stating that belief in Islamic law is incompatible with secular law. Gingrich did not elaborate on how such a test would be administered.

Title: New Hampshire Primary: Marco Rubio's Debate Performance Challenged by GOP Rivals

Article:

Marco Rubio's uneven performance in the recent Republican debate has sparked a renewed effort among three governors to hinder his rise in the race for the GOP presidential nomination. The New Hampshire primary on Tuesday could potentially leave the Republican party with a mix of establishment candidates and no clear favorite to challenge Donald Trump and Ted Cruz, the top-two finishers in the Iowa caucuses.

At the heart of the battle between Rubio and Chris Christie, John Kasich, and Jeb Bush is the question of whether the freshman Florida senator has the experience and policy depth to serve as president, or if he is merely a well-spoken lightweight. Christie launched a series of withering attacks against Rubio in Saturday's debate, and the New Jersey governor criticized Rubio for his reliance on rehearsed talking points.

In the aftermath of the debate, Christie declared the Republican contest a changed race. "There was a march amongst some in the chattering class to anoint Sen. Rubio," Christie said on CNN's State of the Union. "I think after last night, that's over."

Christie and his fellow governors need a strong showing in New Hampshire, as they have staked their White House hopes on the state. Without a strong showing, each will face significant pressure to drop out, as Republican Party leaders seek to rally around a single candidate who can challenge Cruz and Trump.

Trump has maintained a commanding lead in New Hampshire preference polls for months. Cruz is in the mix with Rubio and the governors, though his campaign is more focused on the Southern states that follow later in the primary calendar.

The prospect of Trump or Cruz winning the GOP nomination has caused many Republican leaders to express concern, and this anxiety is likely to increase should New Hampshire voters leave Rubio and the governors clustered together in the primary results, failing to anoint one as their preferred challenger to the front-runners.

A Monmouth University survey released Sunday shows Trump with a commanding double-digit lead over his Republican rivals, with 30 percent of likely Republican primary voters saying they would vote for him. However, there is a cluster of candidates statistically tied for second place: Kasich has 14 percent of would-be voters, Rubio came in with 13 percent, former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush also had 13 percent, and Cruz had 12 percent support.

While most candidates remained unchanged in their polling numbers from last month's Monmouth survey, Bush jumped nine points since January. The Monmouth survey indicated that just 9 percent of N.H. Republican voters are undecided.

Rubio emerged from Iowa looking as though he was that candidate, with a third-place finish in Iowa that was stronger than expected. However, the Florida senator stumbled in Saturday's debate when challenged about his qualifications, repeatedly falling back on a retort meant to distinguish himself from President Barack Obama, who also won the White House as a first-term senator.

Barbara O'Brien, an undecided voter who had been considering voting for Rubio, was convinced he was not the right choice after the debate. "He kept saying the same thing over and over again," said O'Brien, a 67-year-old from Manchester who is one of New Hampshire's many registered independents. "He did not look presidential."

GOP voter Judy McKenna, 66, had been leaning toward Rubio, but said she was "disappointed" in his debate performance. "The governors all made great points about experience, especially Christie, and Rubio did not have any answer to counter that argument," McKenna said.

Rubio acknowledged the criticism during a rally in Londonderry on Sunday morning. He then proceeded to repeat the same line that put him in Christie's crosshairs. "I'm going to say it again," he told the audience of more than 800 gathered in a school cafeteria. "The reason why these things are troubling is because Barack Obama is the first president, at least in my lifetime, that wants to change the country. Change the country, not fix it."

Rubio senior adviser Todd Harris said the candidate's repetition underscores his laser focus on upending the Obama administration's agenda. "We're going to continue to attack Barack Obama's record over and over and over again," Harris said. "I don't think there is any Republican primary voter who was watching that debate who was saying I wish he would lay off of Barack Obama."

Seeking to counter the notion of a misstep, Rubio's campaign said it raised $600,000 during the debate, three times more than it has brought in during previous debates. The fundraising numbers were unverifiable.

The senator's crowds remained large and enthusiastic on Sunday, and some of the many undecided voters who attended his events said they were more bothered by Christie's aggressive demeanor. "It was tiresome," said Katherine Bringhurst, a 66-year-old retired office manager. She is undecided heading into Tuesday's election, but leaning toward Rubio.

Maria Tourlitis, an independent from Hudson, decided to vote for Rubio after hearing him speak in her hometown on Saturday. As she greeted the senator after the event, she leaned in and said: "At the next debate, please stand up to Christie."

If Christie's aggressive attacks on Rubio result in his own standing tumbling, it could benefit Bush, the former governor of Florida, and Kasich, the current governor of Ohio. Both stepped back in the debate to allow Christie to take the lead in targeting Rubio, though they were happy to relish in the afterglow.

"He's a great speaker," Bush said of Rubio, his one-time political protégé, on Fox News Sunday. "But he came across as totally scripted and kind of robotic."

Kasich has prided himself on avoiding direct criticism of his rivals during the campaign, and kept up that strategy both in the debate and as he campaigned Sunday. "Wouldn't it be great if we could win being positive?" Kasich said on Fox News.

Title: Trump Administration Continues Restrictions on Immigrants Amidst COVID-19 Pandemic

Article:

The Trump Administration has continued to implement restrictions on immigrants during the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, using the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) to pass measures that the administration could not implement prior to the pandemic.

In the latest example, the CDC recently amended and extended an order to "suspend the introduction of certain 'covered aliens' into the United States for a period of 30 days." According to the CDC, the extension found that the determinations of the March 20, 2020 order remain correct, and further determined that the suspension of introduction of covered aliens should continue for another 30 days based on the increasing numbers of COVID-19 infections in Canada, Mexico, and the United States.

The amendment allows the administration another way to deny entry to anyone trying to escape violence and civil war to seek refuge in the United States. In 2018, the country witnessed similar attacks against immigrant children and their parents, including the caging of children, separation of families, detention of families, and a continued failure to reunite them.

Former Attorney General Jeff Sessions orchestrated this new "zero tolerance" policy, and later prosecuted everybody caught entering the U.S. as part of the same policy. In addition to the thousands of children separated by their parents, the administration lost track of nearly 6,000 unaccompanied immigrant children.

In June 2018, the Trump administration ended the policy of family separation but substituted it with a policy of family detention. The closing of the family separation practice only came after enormous pressure from the public. Later that year, Trump directed Sessions to alter a 2015 court order titled Reno v. Flores, also known as the Flores Settlement.

This settlement gave immigrant children the protection that they will not be detained for more than 20 days. The rule also states that children be released to a licensed care program within those 20 days. However, the administration has attacked both sides of this protection by altering the rule that allows them to detain children for more than 20 days.

The CDC Amendment and Extension has allowed the administration to rapidly deport children under the context of public health while we are still fighting a pandemic. Lee Gelernt, deputy director of the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) Immigrants' Rights Project, said in an interview with CBS that "this is the most extreme of the Trump administration's anti-children anti-asylum policies..."

Human Rights Watch (HRW) likewise stated that "the United States government should immediately impose a moratorium on deportations during the COVID-19 pandemic to avoid contributing to the global spread of the virus." Despite this, the U.S. ignored the advice from the Human Rights Watch and continued to deport people.

According to HRW, "U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) carried out 232 deportation flights to Latin America and Caribbean countries between February 3 and April 24, 2020." Some of those that were deported tested positive for COVID-19 and were deported to Mexico, Haiti, El Salvador, and Guatemala.

Another recent CBS report stated that "nearly 21,000 removals were carried out in March and April alone, including 899 expulsions of unaccompanied children as young as 10." Children who are being processed under the new CDC Amendment are not being allowed to apply for humanitarian protections they had before. Instead, they are being deported to their home countries, which completely ignores due process.

To receive weekly updates like this in your inbox, subscribe to The ███ newsletter here.

Title: Job Openings Reach Series High of 5.8 Million in July, According to BLS

Article:

The Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) reported that the number of job openings in the United States reached a series high of 5.8 million on the last business day of July. This surpassed the previous high of 5.4 million in May.

The number of hires and separations decreased slightly to 5.0 million and 4.7 million, respectively. The quits rate remained at 1.9% for a fourth consecutive month, while the layoffs and discharges rate declined to 1.1%.

Job openings increased in July for total private and were little changed for government. Several industries experienced a rise in openings, including professional and business services, accommodation and food services, retail trade, and nondurable goods manufacturing.
