The Northeast and South regions saw an increase in job openings.

The number of hires and separations, including quits, layoffs and discharges, and other separations, decreased slightly in July. Over the 12 months ending in July, the number of hires was little changed for total nonfarm and total private, and rose for government. The number of hires increased in accommodation and food services and federal government, but fell in construction and arts, entertainment, and recreation.

Total separations, or turnover, decreased in July for total private and was little changed for government. Quits, layoffs and discharges, and other separations all saw little change over the month. Over the 12 months ending in July, the number of quits increased for total nonfarm, total private, and government. The number of quits increased in several industries, with the largest increases occurring in accommodation and food services, state and local government, and educational services.

Layoffs and discharges decreased over the 12 months ending in July for total nonfarm and total private, and were little changed for government. Other separations increased over the 12 months ending in July for total nonfarm and for government, and edged up for total private. Other separations increased in several industries, with the largest changes occurring in construction, health care and social assistance, and accommodation and food services.

The BLS notes that quits are generally voluntary separations initiated by the employee, while layoffs and discharges are involuntary separations initiated by the employer. Other separations include separations due to retirement, death, disability, as well as transfers to other locations of the same firm. Seasonally adjusted estimates of layoffs and discharges are not available for individual industries.

Title: White House Requests $14 Billion in Emergency Funding for Hurricane Harvey Recovery

Article:

The White House has requested an initial $7.85 billion in emergency relief funding from Congress to address the aftermath of Hurricane Harvey, with an additional $6.7 billion expected to be requested in a subsequent request. This funding is part of the Trump administration's efforts to respond to the devastation caused by the hurricane.

Originally, it was anticipated that the president would ask for $5.5 billion for the Federal Emergency Management Agency's (FEMA) Disaster Relief Fund and an additional $450 billion for a Small Business Administration (SBA) program. However, according to a letter to Speaker Paul Ryan, the White House budget chief, Mick Mulvaney, is requesting $7.4 billion for the relief fund, with the expected $450 billion for the SBA.

The letter also asks that an additional $6.7 billion be made available in a stopgap spending measure that Congress must pass by the end of September to keep the government running. In total, the White House is asking for more than $14 billion as a down payment for recovery efforts in the Gulf.

It is important to note that this requested funding represents only a fraction of the eventual costs of relief efforts in Texas and Louisiana. Congress is currently facing a busy legislative agenda this month, with lawmakers under pressure to raise the debt ceiling by Sept. 29 and to strike a spending deal to fund the government past the end of the month.

President Trump is scheduled to visit Texas for the second time in less than a week on Saturday to assess the damage from the storm, which has left at least 46 people dead and caused billions of dollars in damage. He will also visit Louisiana. The president met with local and state officials in the Corpus Christi area on Tuesday as the storm moved north, hitting the Houston area with a torrent of rain and historic floodwaters.

Title: Justice Department Initiates Process to Ban Bump Stocks

Article:

The United States Department of Justice (DOJ) has initiated steps to ban bump stock devices, which are accessories that accelerate the rate of gunfire, making semi-automatic guns fire at a speed similar to fully automatic firearms. This move follows President Trump's signing of an executive order instructing Attorney General Jeff Sessions to regulate these devices.

On Saturday, Attorney General Sessions announced that his office had submitted a notice to the Office of Management and Budget with the intention of clarifying the definition of "machinegun" and adding bump stocks to the list of banned devices. The notice is one of the first steps in the process of banning bump stocks. After approval by the office, the DOJ plans to "seek to publish this notice as expeditiously as possible."

The order, once implemented, would prohibit individuals from owning, selling, and manufacturing bump stocks. President Trump stated, "President Trump is absolutely committed to ensuring the safety and security of every American and he has directed us to propose a regulation addressing bump stocks."

Bump stocks were found among the weapons used in the Las Vegas shooting that occurred on October 1, 2017, and resulted in the deaths of 58 people. These bump-fire devices utilize the recoil of a semi-automatic firearm to rapidly pull the trigger, mimicking fully automatic firing.

The Las Vegas shooting, the deadliest in recent U.S. history, rekindled the debate on the legality of bump stocks. Congress banned the sale and manufacture of machine guns for civilian use in 1986, and machine guns in circulation before then are tightly regulated, limited in number, and expensive.

The Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives (ATF) has debated the legality of bump stocks for years, issuing a series of opinions, with the most recent determining that the devices were lawful. The ATF's stance on bump stocks has been a topic of contention, with some arguing that the devices should be classified as machineguns due to their ability to mimic fully automatic firearms.

President Trump took on the issue following the Valentine's Day high school shooting in Parkland, Florida. Students and gun-control advocates pressured Trump and other lawmakers to reevaluate current gun laws. He announced the order on bump stocks last month after meeting with survivors of the shooting.

"We must do more to protect our children," Trump said, emphasizing that school safety is a top priority of his administration.

Title: Conservative Response to President Obama's Second Inaugural Address Hardens

Article:

Following President Barack Obama's second inaugural address, conservative responses have solidified, with many expressing a belief that the president's political stance remains unchanged and unlikely to find common ground with conservatives during his second term.

Rep. Paul Ryan (R-WI), the 2012 Republican vice presidential nominee and a potential contender for the 2016 GOP nomination, shared this view in a Tuesday interview on The Laura Ingraham Show. Ryan stated that the president's speech did not seem to be an attempt to reach out to political adversaries, as inaugural addresses typically are.

Ryan, who is also the chairman of the House Budget Committee, accused Obama of misrepresenting the Republican position on entitlement beneficiaries. Ryan argued that conservatives are not labeling those who receive "earned entitlements" like Social Security and Medicare as "takers," but rather focusing on beneficiaries who receive entitlements like Medicaid, which they did not pay for through payroll taxes.

Senate Republicans also alleged on Tuesday that Obama, now freed from the constraints of running for re-election, had revealed his liberal leanings in his speech. Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-KY) told reporters after senators of both parties left their weekly lunchtime party meetings that Obama's speech indicated a return to the era of liberalism. McConnell stated that if the president pursues a liberal agenda, it would not be designed to unite the country or address the pressing issue of deficit and debt.

Sen. John Thune (R-SD) suggested that the president's liberal bent was evident in what he left out of his speech, such as the words "spending" and "debt." Thune argued that the biggest threat to America's future is runaway government spending and accumulating debt.

Crossroads GPS, a nonprofit linked to Karl Rove's American Crossroads political action committee, released a new video on Tuesday that sought to criticize Obama by using the words of journalists and pundits who described Obama's speech as embracing a liberal agenda.

The conservative interpretation of Obama's speech, as expressed by Nicholas Eberstadt, an American Enterprise Institute scholar, provides insight into why the president may be viewed as having antagonized Republicans. Eberstadt detected a take-it-or-leave-it defiance in Obama's speech, suggesting that the president believes the welfare state is no longer up for discussion.

The reaction to the speech a day after its delivery generally mirrored the immediate GOP response following the speech, according to Roll Call.

Title: Iowa Caucus: Presidential Candidates Deliver Closing Arguments Ahead of Monday's Vote

Article:

As the Iowa caucus approaches on Monday, the remaining Democratic presidential candidates are making their final pitches to voters in the Hawkeye State. Here are the closing arguments from some of the key contenders:

Elizabeth Warren:
During a tele-town hall from Washington D.C. earlier this week, Senator Elizabeth Warren emphasized the advantage of women candidates in competitive races. She stated, "The data shows that women have been outperforming men as candidates in competitive races ever since Donald Trump got in." Warren argued that "2020 is not 2016."

Amy Klobuchar:
Senator Amy Klobuchar made a last-minute trip to a bar in Council Bluffs on Tuesday, where she was met by around 100 supporters. Klobuchar also conducted over 20 TV and newspaper interviews in a span of five days last week to reach voters while participating in the impeachment trial.

Bernie Sanders:
Senator Bernie Sanders' closing argument leans on the consistency of his progressive record and his grassroots movement. During a Wednesday night rally in Iowa City, Sanders, calling in from D.C. during a break from the impeachment trial, outlined his plans as president, including raising the minimum wage, legalizing marijuana, passing his Medicare for All bill, protecting women's reproductive rights, fighting climate change, restricting gun access, and overhauling immigration policy.

Joe Biden:
Joe Biden has been arguing that he offers stability and will build on the Obama years. He has been itching for a fight with Trump over guns, health care, foreign policy, national security, morality, and personality. Biden stated, "Trump and I have already gone one round with each other on health care."

In the absence of direct observations, information about the arguments of Pete Buttigieg and other candidates was not available.

The big picture:
Some voters are expressing a desire for a more aggressive approach against Trump. Michael Moore, a filmmaker and Sanders' national campaign co-chair, told a rally that Hillary Clinton "refused" to go to Wisconsin in 2016 and did not give people a reason to vote for her. Voters, volunteers, and campaign staffers have expressed that the 2016 election still haunts them.

What they're saying:
"I want to start hearing people really hammer on Trump because I think they've taken it too easy," said Stuart Howe, an undecided voter met at a Biden campaign stop in Waukee.

Title: Attorney General Holder's Proposed Actions for Ferguson Police Department Reform

Article:

Attorney General Eric Holder stated on Friday that he was prepared to utilize all available federal powers to bring the city of Ferguson, Missouri, into compliance with the Constitution. In response to a question about dismantling the police force, Holder suggested that such a move could be taken if necessary, but clarified that the Department of Justice (DOJ) does not have the power to dismantle local police departments without the city's consent.

The DOJ's approach to working with Ferguson is likely to involve drawing up an agreement where Ferguson's police would remain independent but be monitored by the DOJ. The agreement would be enforced in federal court, and the feds would only take over if the city failed to make the changes outlined in the agreement. This approach is similar to what happened in Oakland in 2012, where the federal government fired the police chief but left the department under the city's control.

If the Ferguson Police Department is to be dismantled, it will only happen if the city agrees to do so or suggests it as an option. The city would be responsible for organizing a replacement police force, as the DOJ does not have the power to create a new police department.

The DOJ's report on Ferguson also highlighted significant issues within the municipal court system, including discriminatory practices and Constitutional violations. Disbanding the police department would only address half of the problems identified, as the court system would still require reform.

The report also noted that the problems in Ferguson are not unique to the city, and that other law enforcement agencies in St. Louis County have contributed to a general distrust of police. If other police departments in the area are not better equipped to handle the situation, a nearby police force may be brought in to take over temporarily or permanently while a new police department is established. However, the report suggests that the problems in the St. Louis area may be more widespread and may require additional investigations and potential lawsuits to address.

Title: Obama's Foreign Policy Legacy: A Blend of Wilsonian and Anti-Wilsonian Elements

 Article:

 In his new residence at 2446 Belmont Road in Washington D.C., former President Barack Obama will live near the home of Woodrow Wilson, who spent his post-presidential years at 2340 S Street. Wilson's foreign policy failure, the Senate's rejection of the U.S. participation in the League of Nations, is a stark contrast to Obama's departure from office with a sense of admiration for America's global standing.

 Two seemingly unimpressed nations are Russia, which is dismembering Ukraine, and China, which is shredding international law by turning the South China Sea into militarized Chinese territory. Obama's policies that brought America to a pinnacle of admiration, as he sees it, were an amalgam of Wilsonian and anti-Wilsonian elements.

 Wilson's grand ambition for America was to reorder the world in a way that would make it unnecessary for America to have grand ambitions. He thought America could lead a restful life after strenuous diplomacy had written rules for the game of nations. Many progressives believe in humanity's natural sociability, disposed to believe that peace among nations is natural and spontaneous, or it would be if other nations would cleanse their minds of the superstitions that prevent them from recognizing the universal validity and demonstrable utility of American principles.

 Obama seemed to doubt that America has much to teach the world, beyond post-Iraq modesty—herewith his Wilsonian dimension—and the power of diplomacy's soft power to tame the world. Although neither the English nor the American nor the Russian nor the Spanish nor the Chinese civil war was ended by negotiations, Obama thought the especially vicious and complex civil war in Syria's sectarian and tribal society could be ended diplomatically. Russian president Vladimir Putin picked a side and helped it win.

 The fact that the world is more disorderly and less lawful than when Obama became president is less his fault than the fault of something about which progressives are skeptical—powerful, unchanging human nature. Humans are, as Job knew, born unto trouble as the sparks fly upward: They are desirous and competitive, and hence are prone to conflict.

 In 2014, when Russia annexed Crimea, Secretary of State John Kerry was disappointed with Putin, saying, more in sorrow than in anger: "You just don't in the 21st century behave in 19th-century fashion." If you do, you place yourself on "the wrong side of history."

 Obama's foreign policy presumed the existence of "the community of nations." Make that History, in progressives' lexicon, a proper noun, an autonomous thing with a mind, or at least a logic, of its own. Kerry's reprimand of Putin expressed a progressive's certitude about progress: The passage of time should ineluctably improve the comportment of nations. Which is why in 1911, the renowned 11th edition of the Encyclopedia Britannica, in its entry on torture, said "the whole subject is one of only historical interest as far as Europe is concerned." The Dachau concentration camp was opened in March 1933.

 Obama's foreign policy presumed the existence of "the community of nations." But that phrase is worse than hackneyed and sentimental, it is oxymoronic: Different nations affirm different notions of justice; a community consists of people made cohesive by a consensus about the nature of justice.

 Obama's second-worst unforced error, second to declaring and then abandoning a "red line" about Syrian chemical weapons, was involving the U.S. military in regime change in Libya. Perhaps this venture appealed to him because it was untainted by any discernible connection with American national interest. He conducted it by "leading from behind," which he described as U.S. forces "being volunteered by others to carry out missions" in Libya. As George Orwell said, "The great enemy of clear language is insincerity."

 Soon, foreign policy will be conducted by a man who, although in 2010 he said WikiLeaks' Julian Assange deserves the death penalty, now seems to trust Assange on the subject of Russian hacking more than he trusts the consensus of the nation's $53 billion civilian intelligence institutions. Time passes and, we are told, brings progress.

Title: California Consumer Privacy Act: The Most Comprehensive U.S. Data Privacy Law

Article:

California has passed a landmark privacy law, the California Consumer Privacy Act (CCPA), which gives residents unprecedented control over their data. The legislation, effective from January 1, 2020, provides California residents with the right to demand companies disclose the information they collect, request a copy of that information, and have their data deleted upon request. Companies are also prohibited from selling information if the consumer instructs them to via a mandatory "Do Not Sell My Personal Information" link on the company's website.

Under the new regulations, consumers can receive a copy of their data by sending a verifiable consumer request to a business. Companies are required to comply with the request within 45 days of receipt. In some cases, companies can extend this time period for a maximum of 90 days total. Consumers may only make a request for information twice a year, and only for a 12-month look-back period.

Companies may face fines of $2,500 to $7,500 per violation of the new law, if the violation is deemed intentional. The CCPA is enforced by the California attorney general.

The CCPA has often been called "GDPR-lite," bearing resemblance to the EU's General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), which went into effect in May 2018. The CCPA applies only to businesses with an annual gross revenue in excess of $25m, derive 50% or more of their annual revenue from selling consumers' personal information, or annually buy, receive, sell, or share the personal information of more than 50,000 consumers, households, or devices for commercial purposes.

The CCPA provides more explicit "opt out" options for users who do not want their personal data sold. Under the CCPA, companies must include a "Do Not Sell My Personal Information" link in a clear and conspicuous location on their websites. Under GDPR, by comparison, businesses do not necessarily need the individual's consent to collect and use data.

The rules also differ in their approaches to the collection of children's data. Under GDPR, parents must provide consent for the processing of data of children under the age of 16. The CCPA requires businesses to obtain consent from parents of children ages 13 and under, while kids older than 13 can provide their own consent.

Some advocates argue that the CCPA does not go far enough, as it does not address data collection effectively and California has few resources to enforce the law in 2020. The law as it is written does not require companies to come to consumers to ask for their data, which is what advocates call "opt in versus opt out." Companies that violate the law will also have the "right to cure," meaning they can change their violating policies after they have been apprehended.

Title: Lawmakers Urged to Uphold Voting Rights Act Amidst Modern Voting Restrictions

Article:

As the nation commemorates the 50th anniversary of the March on Washington, a pivotal event that led to the passage of the Voting Rights Act (VRA) and the Civil Rights Act in 1964, it is crucial to acknowledge the significant political struggle that ensued. The authors emphasize that the VRA's enactment was not an inevitable outcome, but rather the result of bipartisan efforts, particularly by Democrats, who faced political backlash within their party.

Fifty years later, the preservation of the VRA may necessitate a similar display of statesmanship from today's Republicans, as efforts to restrict voting rights are predominantly being pursued by Republicans across the United States. Unlike during the most segregated periods, these modern voting restrictions are primarily aimed at suppressing African-American, Latino, and young votes in swing states to manipulate Congress and the White House elections.

The Supreme Court's recent decision to invalidate Section IV of the VRA, which designated states and localities requiring pre-clearance for changes to voting laws, has left the task of safeguarding minority, young, and elderly voters in the hands of congressional Republicans. In June, the court's conservative majority deemed Section IV unconstitutional, with Chief Justice John Roberts arguing that, "nearly 50 years later, things have changed dramatically" regarding race and voting in America.

However, egregious voting restrictions persist in states with a history of voter suppression. Shortly after the Supreme Court's decision, six states with a history of pernicious voting suppression moved to restrict voting rights, unchecked by the preclearance process. Florida, for instance, is considering resuming its voter purge.

Title: Federal Judge's Ruling on NSA's Call-Tracking Program Delays Obama's Surveillance Reform Decision

Article:

A federal judge's decision on Monday questioning the constitutionality of the National Security Agency's (NSA) massive call-tracking program has delayed President Barack Obama's decision on surveillance reforms. U.S. District Court Judge Richard Leon's ruling that the NSA's metadata program appears to violate the Fourth Amendment was issued just three days after a review group established by Obama delivered its report proposing more than 40 changes to the federal government's surveillance programs.

Obama was initially expected to review the reform proposals before Christmas and announce which ones he would adopt. However, the White House now says that process won't be complete until sometime next month. The delay gives Leon's decision time to resonate and gives surveillance skeptics more time to pressure Obama to endorse significant reforms after Edward Snowden's revelations about NSA surveillance practices.

Leon's ruling could also create the impression that Obama is less concerned about privacy rights than a conservative judge appointed by a previous president. "There have been hints of diversity of opinion in [the interagency process], with some people in the White House more pro-privacy and others less so," said Michelle Richardson of the American Civil Liberties Union, which is pressing for an end to bulk data collection and for greater safeguards on surveillance.

Former NSA Director Michael Hayden, a backer of the call-tracking program, also said the new court ruling could shift the balance in favor of more limits on the NSA's work. Obama has already signaled his plans to impose greater limits on the NSA, but the contours of those changes have only been partially decided, White House officials say.

Among the surveillance doubters who might now have more impact is former Clinton White House Chief of Staff John Podesta, who is set to begin work next month as a counselor to Obama. Podesta has been a longtime privacy advocate and has expressed sympathy with Leon's conclusion that a 34-year-old Supreme Court precedent allowing police to trace a suspected criminal's phone calls without a warrant does not authorize bulk collection of data on virtually every phone call made to, from, or within the U.S.

Leon's decision does not take effect while it is being appealed, and with at least three other lawsuits related to the metadata program in the works, the issue seems highly likely to be resolved by the Supreme Court. However, politically, Leon's ruling could also create the impression that Obama is less concerned about privacy rights than a conservative judge appointed by a previous president.

Title: House Benghazi Committee Reconsiders Pursuit of Hillary Clinton's Email Scandal

Article:

Amid growing accusations from the Democratic party of overreach, especially regarding Hillary Clinton's emails, the House Benghazi Committee is reconsidering the aggressiveness of their investigation into the email scandal that has been a point of contention for the Democratic front-runner. The committee is undecided about whether to call Heather Samuelson, a former Clinton campaign staffer who helped screen Clinton's State Department emails.

The panel's mandate was to investigate the circumstances surrounding the killing of four Americans outside the U.S. consulate in Benghazi, Libya, in 2012, during Clinton's tenure as secretary of state. However, after the revelation that Clinton used a private email server for her State Department correspondence, Republicans on the panel began probing further into whether she had turned over all relevant emails.

The reevaluation follows a Thursday hearing that was widely seen as a success for Clinton, while Republicans failed to strike any decisive blows. The panel's investigation found about 15 Clinton emails that she never turned over, raising GOP suspicions that more might be missing.

However, the email issue only came up briefly at the tail end of her marathon Benghazi hearing. Republicans spent the bulk of their time pressing Clinton over the security failures at the Libyan diplomatic mission and attacking her leadership of the State Department.

Committee Chairman Trey Gowdy (R-S.C.) has long maintained he's only interested in the emails because he wants to assemble a complete record of Clinton's communications when she ran the State Department. The panel will spend the next few weeks interviewing "two individuals whose identities must remain secret," adding to more than 50 of about 70 they've already completed.

The committee spent less than 20 minutes on the matter in the 11-hour hearing. Committee spokesman Jamal Ware said the panel will spend the next few weeks interviewing "two individuals whose identities must remain secret," adding to more than 50 of about 70 they've already completed. In the meantime, the committee might not say much about Clinton for a while, at least until the panel's final report.

"She's an important witness, you can't investigate Benghazi without talking to the secretary of state at the relevant time," Gowdy said shortly after the hearing ended on Thursday night. "In terms of conclusions drawn, I don't draw conclusions until the end... We'll keep going on until we're able to interview all the witnesses that we think have access to relevant information."

Title: Obama and Romney Engage in Damage Control and Prepare for Unemployment Report

Article:

In the aftermath of the first presidential debate on Wednesday, both President Barack Obama and his Republican challenger Mitt Romney have entered a period of damage control and preparation for the upcoming monthly unemployment report. The Labor Department is set to release the September jobs numbers on Friday, which will provide an update on the unemployment rate, currently at 8.1 percent.

Obama, aiming to support his claim during the debate that the economy is on the rebound, needs to present positive economic statistics, especially since Friday's report will be the last of two monthly snapshots before the November election. Romney, during their first debate in Denver, criticized Obama's economic management, stating, "The status quo is not going to cut it."

Following the debate, the Obama campaign announced it would make adjustments and attempt to regain the offensive. At a rally in Denver on Thursday, Obama criticized Romney, stating, "When I got onto the stage I met this very spirited fellow who claimed to be Mitt Romney, but it couldn't have been Mitt Romney, because the real Mitt Romney has been running around the country for the last year promising $5 trillion in tax cuts that favor the wealthy."

The Romney campaign responded, accusing Obama of doubling down on "false attacks." Spokesman Ryan Williams stated, "In full damage-control mode, President Obama today offered no defense of his record and no vision for the future. Rather than a plan to fix our economy, President Obama simply offered more false attacks and renewed his call for job-killing tax hikes."

The explanations from the Obama campaign about what went wrong came as observers from both sides of the political spectrum generally agreed that Romney was the winner of the debate. Romney was quick, polished, and feisty, repeatedly interrupting the moderator and challenging Obama on the facts.

The candidates will debate again on October 16 and for the last time on October 22. The only vice presidential debate is set for October 11. Each candidate will strive to appeal to middle-class voters, who are likely to decide the election, and make the case for why their plans will boost growth. The debate on Wednesday focused exclusively on domestic matters, with both candidates presenting studies and statistics to support their respective positions.

Title: Illinois Cannabis Consumers and Gun Ownership: A Complicated Relationship

Article:

In Illinois, where recreational marijuana sales began on January 1, 2020, cannabis consumers will face higher taxes on their purchases compared to consumers in most other states that have legalized marijuana. However, they do not have to worry about state police confiscating their firearms, thanks to protections included in the 2019 Illinois Cannabis Regulation and Tax Act.

Under federal law, anyone who is an "unlawful user" of a controlled substance, including marijuana, is prohibited from possessing a firearm. When purchasing a firearm from a federally licensed dealer, individuals are required to fill out a form that asks if they are an "unlawful user" of marijuana or any other controlled substance. The form includes a warning that marijuana remains unlawful under federal law, regardless of state-level legalization or decriminalization.

A cannabis consumer who possesses a gun is committing a federal felony, punishable by up to 10 years in prison. A cannabis consumer who answers "no" to the question about illegal drug use while buying a gun is also committing a federal felony, punishable by up to five years in prison.

Illinois also prohibits anyone who has used an illegal drug during the past year from obtaining a Firearm Owner's Identification (FOID) card, which is required to legally own a gun in the state. However, the Illinois Cannabis Regulation and Tax Act states that a person will not be considered an "unlawful user" of marijuana solely due to their possession or use of cannabis in accordance with the Act.

This week, the Illinois State Police (ISP), which oversees the FOID program, confirmed in a Facebook post that it will not revoke cards "based solely on a person's legal use of adult-use cannabis." The ISP added that it will revoke FOID cards where it is demonstrated that an individual is addicted to or is a habitual user of cannabis. The ISP also warned that the use of cannabis is still considered illegal by the federal government and that the purchase of a firearm from a federally licensed firearms dealer is governed by federal law.

Regarding the risk of buying marijuana from a state-licensed retailer tipping off the federal authorities, the Cannabis Regulation and Tax Act states that identifying or personal information of a marijuana purchaser obtained or received in accordance with the Act will not be retained, used, shared, or disclosed for any purpose except as authorized by the Act. Ed Sullivan, a former state legislator who is now a lobbyist for the Illinois State Rifle Association, states that "no cannabis dispensary can share your personal information, unless you authorize them, [with] anyone or any entity. This includes the Illinois State Police (ISP) and the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms & Explosives (ATF)."

However, Sullivan notes that the federal government may have access to information about Illinois patients who participate in the state's pre-existing medical marijuana program. "While Illinois treats cannabis as a prescribed drug, the Federal Government considers cannabis to be a Schedule I narcotic," he writes. "As such, the Federal Government could gain access to your records as a Medical Cannabis User and therefore jeopardize your right to purchase a firearm from a Federal Firearm License [e]."

Sullivan suggests that buying marijuana from recreational dealers may be a safer option for patients concerned about their Second Amendment rights. However, this may not be the case, as the Illinois Compassionate Use of Medical Cannabis Act promises that the list of registered patients will be kept "confidential," to be shared only among the state agencies charged with carrying out the law.

While both the Illinois State Police and Sullivan focus on gun purchases from federally licensed dealers, the federal law banning firearm possession by cannabis consumers also applies to private transfers or even to continued gun ownership by someone who decides to try marijuana now that it's legal in Illinois. Enforcement in these contexts may be difficult, but the fact remains that millions of gun owners are felons in the eyes of the federal government simply because they use an intoxicant that is legal in states accounting for more than a quarter of the country's population.

Title: Americans Divided on Global Warming, Support for Illegal Immigration Reform and Hagel Confirmation

Article:

In his second inaugural address, President Barack Obama reiterated his commitment to addressing climate change and illegal immigration, two contentious issues that continue to divide the American public. According to a new national survey by CNN/ORC International, opinions on global warming and illegal immigration are polarized, with a slight majority favoring a path to legal residency for undocumented immigrants and a majority believing global warming is a man-made phenomenon.

The survey, conducted last week, indicates that 49% of Americans agree with the White House's stance that global warming is a proven fact caused by emissions from cars, power plants, and factories. This is twice the number who believe global warming has not been proven, and the 49% figure is down seven points from 2007. The poll also shows that 24% believe global warming is a proven fact but is not due to man-made sources.

There is an expected partisan divide on the question, with two-thirds of Democrats saying global warming is man-made, compared to 48% among independent voters and 28% among Republicans. The president has faced challenges in the past in getting climate change legislation through Congress, and his efforts to pass comprehensive immigration reform have also been unsuccessful during his first four years in office.

In his inaugural address, Obama emphasized the need for a more welcoming approach to immigration, stating, "our journey is not complete until we find a better way to welcome the striving, hopeful immigrants who still see America as a land of opportunity." By a 53% to 43% margin, people questioned in the poll say the main focus of the federal government should be on developing a plan that would allow undocumented immigrants to become legal residents, rather than deporting them.

This is a switch from 2011, when by a 55% to 42% margin, Americans said that deporting undocumented residents and stopping more of them from coming into the country should be the main focus of U.S. policy on illegal immigration. The poll indicates a partisan and generational divide on the issue, with younger people favoring allowing undocumented immigrants to become legal, and a slight plurality of those 50 and older supporting deportation and border security.

One of the president's biggest domestic accomplishments in his first term was passing the Affordable Care Act, also known as "Obamacare." According to the poll, 51% favor all or most of the provisions in the Affordable Care Act, with 44% opposed to all or most of the provisions in the law. "That's a switch from 2011, when a CNN poll indicated that a majority opposed all or most of the provisions in the health care bill," says CNN Polling Director Keating Holland.

Minutes after his inauguration speech, the president signed documents making official his nominations for some top Cabinet posts, including former Sen. Chuck Hagel as defense secretary. Hagel's nomination has been met with reservations and outright opposition by some senators of both parties, who point to past positions he has taken on Israel, Iran, and the war in Iraq. According to the poll, 48% think the Senate should confirm Hagel, which is twice as high as the number who oppose his confirmation, but with three in ten uncertain of how they feel about the issue, the White House might breathe a little easier if support for Hagel were just over 50% rather than just under that mark, adds Holland. The poll was conducted for CNN by ORC International on Jan. 14-15, with 814 adults nationwide questioned by telephone. The survey's overall sampling error is plus or minus 3.5 percentage points.

Title: Obama Administration's Surveillance of Trump Associates: A Look at the Allegations

Article:

The recent allegations that the Obama administration spied on some of President Trump's associates have sparked a heated debate. However, focusing on the imprecise language in President Trump's tweets may not be the most productive approach. The crux of the matter appears to be that the Obama Justice Department considered a criminal investigation of several Trump associates, which was later converted into an intelligence probe under the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA).

According to former prosecutor Andrew McCarthy in National Review, the Obama Justice Department sought FISA surveillance authorization from the FISA court, but the court initially refused permission. The court's refusal is significant, as the FISA court is known for its solicitude towards government requests for national security surveillance.

In the final weeks of the election, the Obama administration reportedly submitted a narrower request that did not specifically mention Trump. This narrower request was granted by the court, but it is unclear if it involved the tapping of phones, as some reports suggest.

Former Obama officials have issued denials, which McCarthy describes as "disingenuous on several levels." The Obama administration's claim that President Obama did not "order" surveillance of Trump is questionable, as the FISA process is technically the FISA court that "orders" surveillance, and the Justice Department, not the White House, represents the government in FISA court proceedings.

Journalist Mickey Kaus suggests that the close relationship between former Attorney General Loretta Lynch and President Obama makes it unlikely that this was a rogue operation. Trump has called for a congressional investigation, but some argue that what is needed is a special prosecutor to examine the political abuse of surveillance laws by the Obama administration.

If the Obama administration did exceed the limits of FISA surveillance, if they lied to the court, or if information was shared within the government or leaked to outsiders, these actions could be serious crimes. The potential political abuses of the Justice Department and the intelligence surveillance process, if proven, would be a significant concern for democracy.

Glenn Harlan Reynolds, a University of Tennessee law professor, is a member of the USA TODAY's Board of Contributors. Readers can find diverse opinions from the Board of Contributors and other writers on the Opinion front page, on Twitter @USATOpinion, and in the daily Opinion newsletter. Submissions can be made following the publication's guidelines.

Title: Jeffrey Epstein's Death Raises Questions About Prison Conditions and Investigation

Article:

The death of Jeffrey Epstein, a former financier accused of sex trafficking, has been reported as a suicide by federal officials. The circumstances surrounding his death have sparked concerns and raised questions about the actions of officials, with members of Congress demanding answers.

Epstein, a high-profile federal prisoner, was found dead in his cell on Saturday morning. The fact that a federal prisoner could commit suicide defies logic, given the high level of security typically associated with such cases.

Epstein's death has led to doubts about the actions of federal officials, with the FBI announcing an investigation. Attorney General William Barr has expressed his dismay, stating that he is "appalled" by the circumstances. Members of Congress, including Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, have called for answers regarding Epstein's death.

One of the key questions arising from Epstein's death is why he was in solitary confinement in the first place, a situation that is considered inappropriate for a prisoner already at risk of suicide. Epstein was indicted this summer on charges of sex trafficking underage girls and had been in federal custody since then.

Epstein attempted suicide less than two weeks ago and was reportedly placed in solitary confinement and under a suicide watch. The Federal Bureau of Prisons, which had custody over Epstein, and federal prosecutors were aware of his earlier suicide attempt. However, instead of placing him in an administrative segregation unit or a true suicide watch, they put him in solitary confinement, a decision that has raised questions about his death and the investigation surrounding him.

The use of solitary confinement in a penal institution is justified when a prisoner poses a threat to the institution, its staff, is an escape risk, or poses a threat to national security. However, in Epstein's case, he was none of the above.

The conditions of Epstein's confinement have come under scrutiny, with questions about his cell and supervision changes after his first attempt, the level of supervision he received, the objects he was allowed to have, and the response of guards during his death.

The criminal justice system's flaws and failures in Epstein's case have been a source of concern for many. The use of solitary confinement as a tool to demean, degrade, and demoralize a prisoner has been criticized, with the mind-altering seclusion of "solitary" forcing some prisoners into a deep depression from which there is no return.

The full circumstances surrounding Epstein's death remain unclear, and further investigation is necessary to determine the exact cause of his death. The criminal justice system's handling of Epstein's case has raised questions and concerns, and it is hoped that the ongoing investigation will provide answers and ensure justice for all parties involved.

Title: Justice Department May Pursue Legal Action Against States Over Lockdown Measures, Says Attorney General Barr

Article:

Attorney General William Barr has indicated that the U.S. Department of Justice may take legal action against governors who maintain strict lockdown measures after coronavirus outbreaks subside. According to a report by Bloomberg News, Barr has expressed concerns that some lockdown measures infringe on Americans' constitutional rights, including bans on attending church and purchasing firearms.

President Donald Trump's administration issued new guidelines last week for states to begin lifting their lockdown measures once they meet certain coronavirus milestones. Barr stated, "We have to give businesses more freedom to operate in a way that’s reasonably safe. To the extent that governors don’t and impinge on either civil rights or on the national commerce — our common market that we have here — then we’ll have to address that."

The federal government may intervene to support any lawsuits against states believed to be pushing lockdown measures too far, with Michigan being a likely candidate. Hundreds of protesters in Michigan have flaunted distancing guidelines, arguing that Democratic Gov. Gretchen Whitmer is abusing her authority.

Barr stated, "We’re looking carefully at a number of these rules that are being put into place. And if we think one goes too far, we initially try to jawbone the governors into rolling them back or adjusting them. And if they’re not and people bring lawsuits, we file a statement of interest and side with the plaintiffs."

Most states have yet to meet the Trump administration's milestones for entering phase one, which recommend at least 14 days of decreasing cases of both coronavirus and flu-like symptoms; hospital workers must be fully equipped with personal protection equipment and ventilators, and there must be an adequate testing system for healthcare workers.

President Trump, when announcing the phased reopening plan, stated, "All of American society is engaged and mobilized in the war against the invisible enemy. It is clear that our strategy is working, and very strongly working. The data suggests that nationwide we have passed the peak on new cases. Hopefully that will continue, and we will continue to make great progress."

Title: Obama Promotes Jobs Plan, Criticizes Washington Distractions Amidst Ongoing Scandals

Article:

President Barack Obama visited Baltimore on Friday, touring Ellicott Dredges, a manufacturing firm for dredging equipment, to promote his jobs plan and criticize lawmakers for focusing on "chasing every fleeting issue." The visit was the second installment of Mr. Obama's "middle-class jobs and opportunity tour," an effort to promote his economic agenda.

During his visit, Mr. Obama praised Democratic lawmakers from Maryland for their focus on programs to help the middle class. He did not address the ongoing scandals confronting his administration, such as the IRS and the investigation into the terrorist attack on a diplomatic post in Benghazi, Libya, or the Justice Department leak probe targeting the news media.

However, Mr. Obama expressed his frustration with Washington's distractions and partisan games. "I know it can seem frustrating sometimes when it seems like Washington's priorities aren't the same as your priorities," he told plant workers. "I know it often seems like folks down there are more concerned with their jobs than with yours."

The president advocated for $50 billion of infrastructure improvements but said "we've had a little difficulty getting our Republican friends to work with us" to approve the new spending. He announced that he is ordering the federal government to cut red tape to speed up construction projects.

"We've got to up our game when it comes to infrastructure," Mr. Obama said.

Republicans criticized Mr. Obama for not mentioning the Keystone XL pipeline, a project that has been delayed due to environmental concerns. Peter Bowe, president of Ellicott Dredges, testified in favor of the pipeline during a congressional hearing on Thursday, stating that it would create jobs for the company and related industries.

Rep. Andy Harris, a Maryland Republican, criticized Mr. Obama for not taking concrete action to create jobs, stating, "Unfortunately, this visit is just another one of President Obama's campaign-style photo ops. Instead of doing concrete work to create jobs, he's busy giving speeches and taking pictures."

Title: Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker Endorses Ted Cruz for Presidential Nomination

Article:

Republican presidential candidate Ted Cruz secured the endorsement of Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker on Tuesday, as all five remaining candidates campaigned in the state ahead of its primary. Walker, a two-term Republican who previously ran for the presidency, announced his support for Cruz over Donald Trump and Ohio Governor John Kasich.

Walker made the endorsement on Milwaukee conservative talk radio, stating that he believes Cruz is the best-positioned candidate to win the GOP nomination and defeat presumed Democratic rival Hillary Clinton. Walker's endorsement comes after he had previously stated that only Cruz had a chance to unseat Trump.

Trump, who was scheduled to hold a rally in Janesville, Wisconsin, later in the day, had earlier planned to join Kasich and Cruz for a CNN town hall in Milwaukee. In the Democratic race, Vermont Senator Bernie Sanders and Clinton were campaigning around the state.

Walker, who became the first governor in U.S. history to win a recall election in 2012, had hinted at his support for Cruz last week. When he ended his presidential campaign in September, he called for other candidates to join him to take out Trump.

During his presidential campaign, Walker argued that a governor should be the nominee. However, he chose to support Cruz, who until recently had not received the same level of support from the GOP establishment.

"It was an easy call for me to support Ted Cruz," Walker said, highlighting Cruz's consistent positions and his willingness to stand up for his constituents over the interests in Washington.

Cruz supporters cheered as Walker's radio interview was played live at a rally outside of Milwaukee. Trump, in a message posted on Twitter Monday night, made it clear he was not expecting to land Walker's endorsement.

"After the way I beat Gov. Scott Walker (and Jeb, Rand, Marco, and all others) in the Presidential Primaries, no way he would ever endorse me!" Trump wrote, referring specifically to former contenders Jeb Bush and Marco Rubio.

It is unclear how much Walker's endorsement will help Cruz, who has also won the backing of influential conservative talk radio hosts in the Milwaukee market that reach into heavily Republican suburban counties. Walker's approval rating has not exceeded 40 percent in over a year.

Wisconsin has 42 delegates, with 18 going to the statewide winner and 24 divided up to the winner in each of the state's eight congressional districts. Kasich has stated he hopes to win in a couple of congressional districts, as Cruz and Trump battle it out to win the state.

Kasich was campaigning for votes in suburban Milwaukee, while Cruz appeared with Carly Fiorina at a morning rally. On the Democratic side, Clinton was to appear at a gun violence forum in Milwaukee and then head north to Green Bay and west to La Crosse, which is on the Minnesota border. Sanders was stopping in the Milwaukee area and Appleton.

Title: U.S. and North Korea Agree on Nuclear Talks and Repatriation of Remains in Joint Statement

Article:

In a joint statement following the historic summit between U.S. President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un in Singapore, both parties agreed to engage in follow-up nuclear talks with U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo and other top U.S. officials "at the earliest possible date." Additionally, North Korea agreed to recover and repatriate the remains of U.S. soldiers who died during the Korean War.

In a press conference after the summit, President Trump offered mixed messages about the achievements of the meeting. He described success as developing "a relationship" with Kim, characterized the meeting as "the beginning of an arduous process," and stated that Kim had taken only "the first bold step toward a bright new future for his people." At the same time, he described the joint statement as "very comprehensive" and argued that "I don't think you can be any more plain" in terms of the language on denuclearization. He stated that U.S. officials had worked on the substance of the joint statement for months and that the document was "far down the line."

When asked why the document contained no details on how the denuclearization process will work, Trump responded, "Because there was no time. I'm here one day."

President Trump maintained that while he had indeed consented to something the North Koreans have long sought—a meeting between their leader and the American president—he didn't view this as a concession and thought it was as beneficial to the United States as it was for North Korea. The United States hasn't given up anything of value to North Korea, he argued, while "they have given up a tremendous amount." He noted that in addition to North Korea committing to "complete denuclearization" and recovering the remains of American soldiers, he had secured a verbal promise from Kim Jong Un after the signing ceremony in Singapore to shutter a missile-engine testing site. He also listed a number of notable—if limited and in some cases provisional—gestures of goodwill that North Korea made ahead of the summit: halting missile and nuclear tests, releasing three American hostages, closing a nuclear-test site.

However, President Trump then proceeded to, rhetorically at least, make one concession after another to North Korea. He said that U.S. sanctions on North Korea would "come off when we are sure that the nukes are no longer a factor," but then chipped away at that firm stance by adding that "I actually look forward to taking them off" and that it was "OK" that China had recently eased up on sanctions enforcement at its border with North Korea. In announcing that the United States and South Korea would suspend their joint military exercises as long as negotiations progress, he adopted North Korea's longstanding position that these "war games" are "very provocative" rather than legitimate defensive measures. "I know a lot about airplanes. It's very expensive," he said of the drills, which can involve bombers based in Guam. Trump also hinted that he might eventually fulfill the North's longtime objective of booting U.S. forces from Korea. "At some point," he noted, "I want to bring our soldiers back home."

Title: Senate Impeachment Trial: Democrats Express Second Thoughts as Trial Approaches

Article:

The 2019 House Democratic Caucus' goal, as declared by Representative Rashida Tlaib (D-MI), was to impeach President Donald Trump. The House impeached Trump on a straight party-line vote in December 2019, with no Republican support. As the Senate trial approaches, there appears to be a shift in strategy among Democrats, with Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-NY) calling for the Senate to subpoena four new witnesses and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-CA) expressing reluctance to send the articles of impeachment to the Senate.

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-KY) has criticized Schumer's call for new witnesses, stating that it could set a "nightmarish precedent" for future impeachments. McConnell suggested that Schumer is asking the Senate to do the House Democrats' homework, implying that the House's case for impeaching Trump may be inadequate.

The call for new witnesses and additional time before the trial has been interpreted as a sign of Democrats' fear that the House's case for impeachment may fail or be laughed out of the Senate. The Democratic Party has staked its reputation on the impeachment and removal of Trump for allegedly imperiling national security, but some question whether the party's actions reflect the severity of the situation.

Schumer's call for new witnesses also highlights the thinness of Article I of the impeachment, which alleges Trump's "Abuse of Power." Beneath Article I, there is not a single crime listed, such as treason, bribery, or extortion. This has led some to question the nature of the impeachment, as it does not align with the list of impeachable acts the Founding Fathers designated.

The Democratic House could not prove charges of Trump conspiring with Russia to steal the 2016 election, a charge that has been a central focus of the impeachment inquiry. The investigation led by former FBI Director James Comey, which was inherited by Special Counsel Robert Mueller, has been criticized for its handling of the Russia investigation.

Recent reports have emerged suggesting that the FBI and CIA may have manipulated the Russia investigation, potentially setting up Trump foreign policy aide George Papadopoulos to entrap him and use him as an investigative instrument against Trump. The Justice Department's Inspector General, Michael Horowitz, has found that the FISA court warrants used to justify FBI spying were the products of incompetence, mendacity, and possible criminality.

U.S. Attorney John Durham is currently investigating the roots of the FBI investigation, with a focus on the involvement of U.S. and foreign intelligence in the early days of the investigation. Attorney General Bill Barr and Durham have both stated that they do not share Horowitz's view that there was no political bias at the beginning of the investigation of the Trump campaign. Durham has the power to impanel grand juries and bring criminal indictments, and his investigation is expected to continue through the spring and summer.

As the impeachment trial approaches, the media's portrayal of the Russia investigation as a "right-wing conspiracy theory" has been toned down, with the Horowitz report confirming what Trump supporters have been saying for years. The treatment of Carter Page, a former Trump campaign advisor, has also been called into question, with some arguing that he was made a victim of injustice after being used as a tool in the Russia investigation.

Title: A New Era of Change: The Resurgence of the Civil Rights Movement in America

Article:

The current wave of protests against racial injustice in America is sparking a new era of change, reminiscent of the generation that emerged 60 years ago to build the civil rights movement. In a poignant reflection, civil rights activist and journalist John Lewis recalls his personal experience in the fight for equality.

On July 16, 1960, Lewis and seven other friends made history by entering the whites-only Greenville Library in South Carolina, defying segregation laws. This act occurred more than five years after the 1954 Brown v. Board Supreme Court decision, which declared the "separate but equal" doctrine unconstitutional. However, in Greenville, where Lewis grew up, segregation persisted.

Lewis's education was limited due to segregation. He could not apply to local universities like Furman, Clemson, or the University of South Carolina. Instead, he attended the University of Illinois on a football scholarship. When he returned from Christmas vacation in 1959, he was unable to use the public library to complete his assignments due to the lack of resources in the Blacks-only library.

Protests were gaining momentum, with students in Nashville, Greensboro, and other cities initiating sit-ins. The July demonstration at the library marked a turning point in Lewis's life, as it did for many across the South. The protesters faced fierce resistance, with accusations of being outside agitators, socialists, or communists, and violent opposition from private vigilantes and police officers.

Despite these challenges, the movement continued to grow. In 1964, the Public Accommodations Act was passed, ending segregated public facilities. In 1965, the Voting Rights Act was enacted, following the violent police riot on the Edmund Pettus Bridge in Selma, Alabama. Lewis began working with Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in 1965.

The dismantling of legal apartheid opened the way for a new South. Industries and modern companies like CNN moved to the region, and athletic fields became integrated. African Americans began to win elections at various levels. However, as Lewis notes, racism was not eradicated, and institutional structures that enforce racial injustice remain.

Now, a new generation is rising to address these injustices. The demonstrations following George Floyd's murder have been the largest in American history, with millions participating in protests across 2,500 locations. White participation has surpassed that of the first civil rights movement. Politicians are already responding, with reforms to police practices and bans on choke holds. Mississippi legislators have voted to retire the state flag with its Confederate battle emblem.

This new generation of protest holds great promise for America. It will face resistance, not just from politicians like Donald Trump, but also from entrenched interests resistant to change. The movement is focused on reforming areas that threaten the privileged and the powerful, such as criminal injustice, economic inequalities, and basic economic and political rights.

Lewis concludes by emphasizing the potential impact of this movement, stating, "Now this generation has an opportunity to make America better, and the lives and options of millions are at stake in their struggle." This is a time for anyone with a conscience and a pulse to join this extraordinary movement.

Title: Obama Proposes End to Federal Ban on Gun Violence Research

Article:

President Obama has outlined a comprehensive plan to reform America's gun laws, which includes a federal ban on the manufacture and sale of new assault weapons and expanded background checks on firearm purchasers. However, a less-noticed aspect of the plan is the president's attempt to end a 15-year ban on federal research into guns and violence.

In 1996, some conservative members of Congress attempted to eliminate the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's (CDC) National Center for Injury Prevention and Control due to concerns about perceived pro-gun control bias. As a result, the CDC's funding for gun research was redirected to brain-injury research, and Congress added language to the CDC appropriation stating that no funds could be used to advocate or promote gun control.

This language has been a barrier to federal research into gun violence, with some researchers stating that the CDC's website lacks specific links to information about preventing firearm-related violence. The CDC has not conducted extensive studies on the role of guns in violence, and there is little information on basic gun topics such as gun ownership rates, the correlation of gun ownership to homicide rates, and the percentage of guns used in crimes that were obtained legally.

On Wednesday, Obama vowed to end the "freeze" on gun-violence research. He issued a presidential memorandum directing the CDC and other US scientific agencies to conduct research into the causes and prevention of gun violence. Obama based this move on a legal analysis that the existing appropriations language does not block wide-ranging investigations. The CDC will begin by assessing existing strategies for gun violence and identifying the most pressing research questions with the greatest potential public health impact.

Obama also called on Congress to appropriate $10 million to the CDC for further work, including an effort to better understand the relationship between video games, media images, and violence. He also asked for an additional $20 million to expand the National Violent Death Reporting System, which collects anonymous data on the nature of firearms used in murders or suicides, to all 50 states from its current 18.

The president's call for the CDC to dive into research is a legal analysis that it is all right for them to do so under current law. It remains to be seen how eagerly the CDC will take up the banner, and whether pro-gun groups will file suit to try and stop it. As to his calls for Congress to direct more cash to this area, the success of these requests is uncertain, as it is possible that members will see this as a less controversial alternative to more sweeping measures such as the proposed assault-weapons ban, and it is also possible that the current tight fiscal environment will allow Capitol Hill to shuffle the suggestions aside.

Title: Climate Activists Disrupt Annual Harvard-Yale Football Game, Call for Fossil Fuel Divestment

Article:

Climate change activists disrupted the annual Harvard-Yale football game on Saturday, delaying the game for nearly an hour during halftime. The protesters, who were from both universities, unfurled banners with slogans such as "Nobody wins. Yale and Harvard are complicit in climate injustice." They called on the universities to divest their multi-million dollar endowments from fossil fuel companies and companies that hold Puerto Rican debt.

Approximately 150 students gathered on the 50-yard line at Yale Bowl, with loudspeaker announcements and police demanding they leave the field. As protesters clapped and chanted "disclose, divest and reinvest," organizers say several hundred more fans left their seats in the stands to join in. By the time play resumed, several dozen people were issued misdemeanor summonses for disorderly conduct.

Harvard senior Caleb Schwartz, one of the protest organizers who was arrested on Saturday, told NPR the mood on the field was joyful despite the possibility of arrest. "That moment, when we saw people running onto the field, was just really incredible," he said. "I saw organizers around me crying because it was such a beautiful moment."

Schwartz says the Harvard-Yale rivalry game has been played since 1875, and organizers knew alumni from all over the world would be tuning in. "Although it was disruptive and some people were not too happy we were on the field, it was really important because our universities are just not listening to our voices and our generation's calls for urgent climate action," he says.

In a statement, the student groups behind the protest, Fossil Free Yale, the Yale Endowment Justice Coalition, and Fossil Fuel Divest Harvard, wrote:

"Harvard and Yale claim their goal is to create student leaders who can strive toward a more 'just, fair, and promising world' by 'improving the world today and for future generations.' Yet by continuing to invest in industries that mislead the public, smear academics, and deny reality, Harvard and Yale are complicit in tearing down that future."

Harvard and Yale are not the first universities to face criticism over fossil fuel investments. The first campus divestment movements started at Swarthmore College in 2011. Harvard has repeatedly said it would not pursue divestment, while Yale has made some moves in recent years to consider climate change in its investment decisions.

Karen N. Peart, director of University Media Relations at Yale, told NPR in a statement:

"Yale stands firmly for the right to free expression. Today, students from Harvard and Yale expressed their views and delayed the start of the second half of the football game. We stand with the Ivy League in its statement that it is regrettable that the orchestrated protest came during a time when fellow students were participating in a collegiate career-defining contest and an annual tradition when thousands gather from around the world to enjoy and celebrate the storied traditions of both football programs and universities."

Saturday's protest during a marquee rivalry football game attracted widespread attention, including tweets of support from several Democratic presidential candidates including Sen. Elizabeth Warren and Sen. Bernie Sanders. The protest garnered so much interest that Schwartz changed his bus ticket back to Cambridge on Saturday so he could stay and field the deluge of media inquiries. "We will win this fight, and we will get the university to divest," he told NPR from his bus home. "I truly don't think it's a question of if, it's a question of when. And the more pressure we can put on them, the sooner they will."

Title: John Bolton's Controversial Foreign Policy Record and Potential Impact as Secretary of State

Article:

In 2005, John Bolton, a conservative figure known for his criticism of the United Nations, was nominated by President George W. Bush to serve as the U.S. ambassador to the UN. Despite Senate Democrats' filibuster, which limited him to a recess appointment, Bolton's tenure was marked by efforts to reform the UN's Human Rights Commission.

Fast forward to 2018, when President Donald Trump announced his consideration of Bolton as his secretary of state. Bolton's aversion to bureaucracy and his criticism of the UN were seen as appealing qualities for the State Department. However, concerns arise from Bolton's history of advocating for counterproductive military interventions.

One of the most contentious issues in Bolton's foreign policy record is his stance on the 2003 Iraq invasion. Bolton remains firm in his belief that the decision to overthrow Saddam Hussein was correct, despite the ensuing chaos and instability in the Middle East. Similarly, in 2011, Bolton called for the assassination of Libyan dictator Moammar Gaddafi, a move that led to the country's disintegration into anarchy and the rise of ISIS.

On Iran, Bolton has advocated for regime change and the use of conventional bombs to target Iran's nuclear program. His proposed actions would have potentially led to a power vacuum, allowing the Islamic State to gain a foothold and disrupting the anti-ISIS campaign in Iraq, which relies heavily on Iran-linked militias.

In 2009, Bolton suggested that Israel should use nuclear weapons against Iran's nuclear program, a statement that proved to be inaccurate, as Israel did not nuke Iran, and Iran does not currently possess nuclear weapons.

Bolton's stance on Syria's Bashar al-Assad is also noteworthy. In 2013, he expressed opposition to an authorization to use force against Assad, but later stated that conditions were optimal for overthrowing Assad in 2003, implying that the timing was the only issue.

John Bolton's foreign policy record is marked by a consistent support for regime change, a lack of planning for post-intervention scenarios, and a history of controversial and often counterproductive actions. If appointed as secretary of state, his tenure could potentially lead to unintended consequences and financial burdens for the United States.

Title: Obamacare's Impact on Labor Force and Medicaid Prioritization

Article:

The Congressional Budget Office (CBO) has released a report stating that the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare, is estimated to reduce the labor supply by the equivalent of 2.3 million full-time workers. This reduction is a significant increase from the previously estimated 800,000 in 2019.

The report suggests that Obamacare's expansion of Medicaid eligibility may decrease incentives to work. This implies that the health care law may be giving low-income Americans fewer reasons to work, potentially impacting their ability to find and pursue jobs that could transform their lives and those around them.

The report also highlights a concern regarding the prioritization of coverage for able-bodied adults over the needs of persons with disabilities. In 2012, over half a million seniors and people with disabilities on state Medicaid lists were awaiting access to home and community-based services. These services could help keep individuals with disabilities out of institutions, which are often more costly.

Under Obamacare, states receive a greater federal Medicaid match to cover previously ineligible low-income individuals. The Urban Institute estimates that nearly five in six adults to be covered under the Medicaid expansion are adults without children, most in their prime working years. This suggests that Obamacare's incentive structure places a greater emphasis on expanding coverage to these able-bodied adults, who could potentially be working or preparing for work, than helping the individuals with disabilities that Medicaid was initially created to serve.

This discrepancy in prioritization has raised concerns about the compassionate nature of the health care law, with critics arguing that it may increase inequality rather than decrease it. The report concludes that the president's health care law may be discouraging Americans from working, and it questions the priority given to expanding Medicaid coverage to working-age adults over providing care to those with disabilities who are waiting for services.

Title: Democrats Launch Campaign to Shame Republicans Over Expired Unemployment Benefits

Article:

As the final payments from the expired unemployment benefits program are distributed, Democrats have initiated a campaign aimed at shaming Republicans, particularly those in leadership and in swing districts, for allowing the program to lapse during the holiday season.

House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi of California stated, "I don't know if our colleagues who have opposed passing the unemployment-insurance legislation know or care about the impact on families. The impact is very, very strong. It hurts the dignity of a family, of a worker."

A liberal group, Americans United for Change, is running an advertisement on cable television stations. The advertisement states, "You know who had a Merry Christmas? The richest 1 percent, that's who. Republicans in Congress made sure of that, protecting billions in taxpayer giveaways." It continues, "For those facing tough times? Republicans stripped 1.3 million Americans of jobless benefits—folks who want to work, but can't find a job—kicking them to the curb during Christmas."

Republican aides have stated they remain willing to negotiate. Michael Steel, a spokesman for John A. Boehner of Ohio, the speaker of the House, asked, "Why didn't they offer a plan that met the speaker's requirements—fiscally responsible, with something to create jobs—or any plan, for that matter, before they left for the holidays?"

Some Democrats have suggested continuing the program for three months, with the estimated $6 billion in spending offsets coming from agricultural subsidies in the farm bill.

Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky stated on Fox News, "I support unemployment benefits for the 26 weeks that they're paid for. If you extend it beyond that, you do a disservice to these workers. When you allow people to be on unemployment insurance for 99 weeks, you're causing them to become part of this perpetual unemployed group in our economy."

The loss of benefits is expected to drain billions in consumer spending from the economy next year. People losing their federal benefits—often benefits they expected to continue to receive for weeks or months into 2014—have described cutting back on Christmas, driving less, turning off the heat, draining retirement accounts, applying for food stamps, readying to move in with relatives, and missing mortgage payments.

Title: California Imposes Historic Water Cutbacks on Senior Water Rights Holders in Drought-Stricken Northern Region

Article:

California's water authorities have implemented significant water cutbacks for farmers in Northern California, a historic move that challenges the perception that the agriculture industry is receiving preferential treatment during the state's ongoing drought. The cutbacks affect farmers who hold some of the oldest water rights, dating back over a century, for the first time in four decades. These farmers will no longer be permitted to draw water from the San Joaquin River, the Sacramento River, and the delta where the two rivers meet.

State officials stated that the rivers do not have sufficient water to cater to all rights holders due to the current drought conditions. This is not the first time during the drought that the state has restricted water supplies to surface water users, including farmers. The water board has already curtailed nearly 9,000 water rights this year, all of which are junior water rights established post-1914.

For the first time since a severe drought in the late 1970s, California is informing senior water rights holders, who established their claims before 1914, that there is not enough water for them. The recent cutbacks affect rights holders who established their claims between 1903 and 1914.

Further historic cuts could be implemented over the summer, as the State Water Resources Control Board continues to monitor conditions in watersheds across the state. The water board warned that cutbacks could be imminent for even more senior rights holders in various watersheds.

State officials stated that the water rights being curtailed amount to 1.2 million acre-feet, but it is unclear whether the cutbacks will save that exact amount. The water board has hinted in recent months that curtailments for senior rights holders were coming, leading some farmers to store extra water in preparation.

Title: President Trump Signs Executive Order to Streamline Infrastructure Project Environmental Reviews

Article:

President Donald J. Trump has signed an Executive Order aimed at streamlining the environmental review and permitting process for major infrastructure projects in the United States. The order, titled "Establishing Discipline and Accountability in the Environmental Review and Permitting Process for Infrastructure Projects," is designed to make the process more efficient and effective.

The current system for completing environmental reviews has been criticized as fragmented, inefficient, and unpredictable. The Federal Government lacks a system for tracking the costs of the environmental review and permitting process for major infrastructure projects. The Executive Order requires agencies to track these costs.

According to a 2014 Government Accountability Office (GAO) report, it takes an average of 7 years for a complex highway project to go through the entire environmental review process. The National Association of Environmental Professionals reports that a single agency can take 3.7 to 5 years on average to complete an environmental review. One study has found that the average delay of six years for major infrastructure projects costs the U.S. economy trillions.

The new Executive Order implements a One Federal Decision policy under which the lead Federal agency will work with other relevant Federal agencies to complete the environmental reviews and permitting decisions needed for major infrastructure projects. Each agency will sign a joint Record of Decision and all required Federal permits will be issued 90 days later. The order establishes a two-year goal to process environmental documents for major infrastructure projects.

The entire environmental review and permitting process will be reviewed to improve performance across the government, and every agency will be held accountable. The Council on Environmental Quality (CEQ) will develop and implement an action plan to improve environmental reviews Government-wide.
