The CEQ will mediate disagreements between Federal agencies to prevent delays due to bureaucratic disputes.

The Office of Management and Budget (OMB) will develop a two-year Government-wide modernization goal and ensure Federal agencies take meaningful steps to achieve it. Agencies will modify their strategic plans to include agency-specific goals for improving environmental review and permitting processes, and hold their officials accountable. OMB will establish a performance accountability system and score each agency on their implementation of the Executive Order. Poor performance will be considered in budget formulation and could result in the imposition of available penalties.

Agencies will also be held accountable for implementing appropriate best practices that are proven to enhance the environmental review and permitting process. The Executive Order makes clear that environmental protections will be maintained, and that the process should focus more on decision-making and good environmental outcomes rather than bureaucratic process.

President Trump has made infrastructure a priority and has taken action to rebuild America. This Executive Order is part of his ongoing efforts to modernize the nation's infrastructure.

Title: Democratic-aligned Groups Form Alliances to Counter Republican Financial Advantage in 2012 Elections

Article:

In the 2012 general election, Democratic-aligned super PACs and advocacy groups are collaborating to support President Barack Obama and selected House and Senate candidates. This joint effort aims to counter the significant financial resources of Republican groups, which are expected to spend up to $1 billion on their air war.

From newly formed super PACs to unions, environmentalists, and women's groups, Democratic-aligned organizations are forming temporary partnerships to achieve their immediate goals, whether it's supporting a specific candidate or targeting a shared Republican adversary.

Cooperation between outside groups on both sides has occurred in past cycles, but operatives involved in the 2012 efforts claim a new level of intensity and urgency this time around, as liberal advocacy groups strive to protect their interests against a potential $1 billion Republican onslaught.

Bill Burton, the former White House spokesman now helping guide the pro-Obama super PAC Priorities USA Action, stated, "The partnerships are a critical part of our strategy here. We have no doubt that the Koch brothers and Karl Rove are going to have more dollars than us. We knew we could leverage every dollar we have three or four times if we team up."

While campaigns cannot coordinate with independent spending groups, there are no rules preventing cooperation between the myriad interest groups on the right and left, which often share the same political objectives and compete for the same funds. For Democrats, fundraising has been particularly challenging this cycle.

Two recent examples of this collaboration emerged this week, as Priorities USA Action and the labor giant SEIU jointly committed $4 million to Spanish-language television ads criticizing Mitt Romney as hostile to working people. Meanwhile, a coalition of five environmental groups is preparing to launch an almost two-month campaign to boost Democratic Rep. Martin Heinrich in the New Mexico Senate race. The organizations involved—the League of Conservation Voters, the Sierra Club, Defenders of Wildlife, the National Wildlife Federation, and the Natural Resources Defense Council Action Fund—are splitting the cost evenly, according to a strategist familiar with the campaign.

EMILY's List President Stephanie Schriock stated that Democratic organizations have coordinated for years, often through the coalition-building group America Votes, but that teamwork is closer than ever this cycle. In addition to Priorities USA Action, Democrats have established super PACs to focus on both chambers of Congress: Majority PAC, which focuses on the Senate, and House Majority PAC. Key collaborators include SEIU, EMILY's List, LCV, and the public-sector labor group AFSCME.

Schriock explained, "Because resources are tight and we're up against just an avalanche on the Republican side, we knew right away that none of us had resources that we could waste, nor could we in any way duplicate efforts at all." She added that EMILY's List would "move money into whatever vehicle" appears most effective in a given race. Her group partnered earlier this year with VoteVets.org and Majority PAC to run TV commercials for Missouri Sen. Claire McCaskill.

For the groups that are joining forces—sometimes for a single ad campaign, sometimes over a longer period of time—there may be a limit on the total size of the financial pie available. As of now, there are no Koch or Sheldon Adelson-level benefactors on the Democratic side—that is, ideological billionaires willing to pour potentially unlimited funds into their chosen causes.

Title: Surge Pricing During Seattle Shooting Sparks Outrage Among Riders, Companies Cap Prices

Article:

A deadly shooting that erupted in downtown Seattle on Wednesday, resulting in a woman's death and seven injuries, led to a surge in pricing from ride-hailing services Lyft and Uber, causing outrage among some riders. The surge pricing, which typically ranges from $20 to $30, quadrupled as people attempted to escape the chaotic scene.

Riders took to social media to express their displeasure, with some posting images of their inflated charges. Heather Szum tweeted a $122 charge for a ride to West Seattle, stating, "Lovely @lyft. So much for getting away from an active shooter while the buses are delayed/shutdown." Another rider, Lisa Wilkins, posted an image of a charge exceeding $126. A Twitter user under the handle pulkit2911 noted his usual $25 to $35 ride from Seattle to Bellevue skyrocketed to $149.23, writing, "Shame on you lyft."

Spokespersons for both Uber and Lyft stated that surge pricing was capped when it automatically engaged in response to increased demand. They also mentioned that both companies have begun refunding affected customers.

The shooting occurred at approximately 5 p.m. on Pine Street between Third and Fourth avenues, with authorities responding to bullets fired. One woman was killed, and seven men, including a 9-year-old boy, were wounded. The surviving victims were treated for non-life-threatening injuries, and the city's medical examiner's office was set to release the identity of the deceased woman.

A 21-year-old man, Jamel Jackson, who was among the wounded, was arrested and charged with unlawful possession of a firearm. Authorities are still searching for two more suspects, identified as William Ray Toliver and Marquise Tolbert, aged 24.

Photos released by Seattle police show William Ray Tolliver and Marquise Tolbert, the two individuals authorities are seeking in connection with the shootout. A handout image taken by Nikesh Parekh and posted on his Twitter account shows police activity at the scene of the deadly shooting in downtown Seattle, Washington.

The shooting scene was at the same intersection that houses BlueShift, an Amazon office building, where two company employees were among the wounded. Both employees were standing outside when the gunfire erupted, according to KCPQ-TV.

An investigation of the chaotic event forced authorities to shut down several streets. While people complained about the surge in pricing on social media, others also noted when the pricing was capped.

Uber's website includes a page entitled 'Looking out for the Uber Community During an Emergency,' written by the company's global head of physical security. The page notes that Uber has a 'Global Security Center' that monitors and flags 'issues that may affect our business and the communities in which we operate—24 hours a day, 7 days a week.' Pricing is capped when a'major emergency event may have occurred.'

Lyft issued a statement to DailyMail.com, calling the shooting 'tragic.' "Our thoughts are with the victims and their families," the company said.

Title: Hillary Clinton Accuses Benghazi Committee of Being Political Hit Job Aimed at Her

Article:

Former Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton has denounced the House Select Committee on Benghazi, citing controversial remarks by House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy that she claims prove the panel is a political hit job aimed solely at her. Clinton, who is scheduled to testify before the committee later this month, stopped short of calling for the committee's shutdown, stating that is up to Congress.

Clinton, the front-runner for the Democratic presidential nomination, made her comments at a forum in New Hampshire hosted by NBC's "Today." She said, "Now that they have admitted that it is a political partisan committee for the sole purpose of going after me, not trying to make our diplomats who serve in dangerous areas safer, that's up to the Congress."

The Republican-led committee has been investigating the 2012 terror attack on the U.S. diplomatic compound in Benghazi, Libya, which resulted in the death of Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens and three other Americans. The Clinton email scandal, in which she used a private email account to conduct official business as secretary of state, has become a key issue probed by the committee.

Last week, House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy made remarks that the committee's work was responsible for Clinton's declining poll numbers in the presidential contest. In response, Clinton said, "This committee was set up, as they have admitted, for the purpose of making a partisan political issue out of the deaths of four Americans. I would never have done that."

Providing a glimpse of her upcoming testimony, Clinton touted her close relationship with Stevens and said that she would never have used the deaths of Americans to go after her political foes. "I would never have done that," said an indignant Clinton. "Look at the situation they chose to exploit to go after me for political reasons: The death of four Americans in Benghazi. I knew the ambassador. I identified [his body]. I asked him to go there. I asked the president to nominate him."

Clinton expressed eagerness to testify and answer questions on her own terms, provided the committee has not been shut down before her scheduled appearance on Oct. 22. "I'll be there, and I'm looking forward to answering questions about real things when I'm there, and I'm looking forward to having a chance to explain everything we've done, everything I asked to happen," she said. "But it is not appropriate what they have done from obviously their own admission."

Title: Supreme Court Declines to Establish Constitutional Right for Same-sex Marriage, but Consequences Remain Unclear

Article:

The Supreme Court on Monday did not establish a constitutional right for same-sex couples to marry, but instead declined an opportunity to rule definitively on the question. However, the legal landscape is shifting in favor of same-sex couples seeking to marry, with the consequences of the court's decision likely to be significant.

Five states that previously banned same-sex marriage had their state-enacted bans wiped off the books as a result of the Supreme Court's decision. Couples in these states, often referred to as "The Five," could begin marrying regardless of gender as of today, with some obtaining licenses immediately.

In six other states that had banned same-sex marriage, further legal proceedings may be necessary to apply the rulings of the relevant federal circuit courts of appeal. However, as these six states are connected to The Five through the federal circuit system, the same judgment will apply. The implementation of this judgment in these six states is already in motion.

This development brings the number of states where gay marriage has been legalized, either by the state itself or through federal cases, to 30. These states are home to the vast majority of the national population.

There are still opportunities for the Supreme Court to reassert itself in this debate, but the question is whether they choose to do so. Many legal experts have observed a trend in the federal system and a signal from the nine justices who sit at the court's zenith.

The Supreme Court's decision to decline review came after it decided Windsor v. United States in June 2013, which struck down the 1996 Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA). This decision opened the door for other challenges to state laws barring gay marriage or treating gays differently.

Now, as these challenges come in waves, the federal courts at all levels are applying the reasoning from Windsor with great consistency. If the high court wanted to use that as an occasion to declare a constitutional right, it could have taken one or more of the cases it declined today. However, opponents of gay marriage had hoped the court would take such a case to uphold the states' right to ban gay marriage.

Instead, Amy Howe, the editor of the highly regarded SCOTUSBlog, observed that the justices instructed their confreres at lower levels of the pyramid to "keep on doing what you're doing." In other words, there is not a clear majority of the nine justices to settle the matter with a landmark ruling one way or the other.

The Supreme Court could choose to re-enter the fray at some later point, perhaps when another circuit court of appeals weighs in with a ruling that supports the state's right to ban gay marriage. This would at least create a conflict for the Supreme Court to resolve. Or it could revisit the issue later, perhaps when a clear majority has formed either to prohibit gay marriage or to permit it. This might require waiting until Justice Anthony Kennedy, a swing vote on such issues, declares himself, or until the next retirement of a sitting justice and the confirmation of a successor.

However, as the number of legal gay marriages skyrockets, and the practice becomes both legal and common across most of the states and most of the population, a future court is less and less likely to rescind it.

Title: Trump Issues Executive Orders to Streamline Federal Employee Dismissal Process

Article:

President Donald Trump has issued three executive orders on Friday, aimed at reducing the time it takes to dismiss federal employees. According to multiple reports, the changes are expected to save taxpayers $100 million per year.

The orders, announced by White House officials in a call with reporters, will instruct those in charge of federal agencies to prioritize performance over seniority. This move is likely to cause concern among federal employees, as public sector unions traditionally oppose merit-based rules for advancement.

Union officials and experts have labeled the move as an attempt to decrease the power of federal employees' unions, which protect federal workers from unfair terminations and employment practices. The American Federation of Government Employees, the largest federal employee union representing 700,000 government workers, issued a statement calling the move an "assault on public servants."

The phrase "public servant" has been criticized in the past for its connotation that government employees are serving the public, rather than being employed by the public. The notion that employees should not be dismissed for poor performance is a contentious issue, particularly when taxpayers are footing the bill.

Public sector unions are often powerful, especially in deep blue states, making it difficult to dismiss employees for offenses. In 2018, the Los Angeles Unified School District paid off a teacher who was found to have been feeding semen to his students rather than firing him.

President Trump's focus on results, rather than maintaining the opposition's support, is a departure from many modern Republican politicians. This approach may be seen as a scorched-earth strategy by some, but it could potentially prove to be a successful re-election strategy.

Title: House Passes Short-Term Spending Bill, Sending It to Senate for Further Amendments

Article:

The U.S. House of Representatives passed a short-term spending bill on Tuesday, funding domestic programs through March 23, while providing the Department of Defense with a full-year budget of $659 billion. The measure, which passed in a 245-to-182 vote, now moves to the Senate, where Democrats are expected to amend the legislation and send it back to the House for another round of voting.

The bill provides a $52 billion funding boost for the Department of Defense over 2017 levels, but it maintains flat funding for most other government programs for another six weeks. House Republicans argue that the spending bill offers much-needed certainty to U.S. military planners who have expressed frustration with Congress' inability to pass a long-term spending bill.

Democrats, on the other hand, claim that the GOP proposal is an attempt to slash funding for education, infrastructure, and other domestic priorities. House Democratic Leader Nancy Pelosi stated during Tuesday's debate, "Instead of working constructively with Democrats to meet the needs of the American people, Republicans are trying to starve the domestic budget."

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell and Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer announced on Tuesday that they were working on a deal that would lift the tight budget caps that limit how much Congress can provide for defense and non-defense domestic programs alike. The budget caps were set in 2011 as part of an effort to reduce the deficit, but lawmakers have never adhered to those spending limits.

If congressional leaders reach a broad budget deal, it would allow lawmakers to write a long-term government spending bill and potentially end the fiscal brinksmanship that has led to the passage of one short-term funding bill after another. The federal government is currently operating on its fourth short-term funding bill for the fiscal year that began on October 1, 2017, and it is set to expire at midnight on Thursday. If lawmakers do not reach an agreement before then, it would trigger another partial government shutdown, following last month's three-day closure.

The House-passed bill is likely to be changed in the Senate, where Democrats have vowed to block any spending bill that short-shifts funding for domestic spending. It remains unclear if Senate Democrats will move to strip out the extra defense funding, or if they will attach other provisions to address their concerns.

In the House, Democrats also want to address the status of DREAMers, undocumented immigrants who came to the U.S. as children. President Trump plans to end an Obama-era program that shields those immigrants from deportation next month, leaving them in limbo. He has challenged Congress to come up with a legislative solution for immigration and stated on Tuesday, "I'd love to see a shutdown if we don't get this taken care of."

With the House set to recess for their annual retreat on Wednesday, a spokeswoman for the Democratic caucus stated that lawmakers would hold their meetings at the Capitol instead "given the pressing issues Congress will likely vote on over the next three days."

Title: Student Loan Interest Rates Set to Double as Congress Fails to Reach Agreement

Article:

Interest rates on Stafford student loans, the most popular funding source for college students, are set to double from 3.4 percent to 6.8 percent on July 1, 2013, as lawmakers failed to find a bipartisan solution to keep the federally subsidized borrowing costs low. The Senate adjourned Thursday night for the July 4 recess without approving a student loan rate package.

Without new legislation, either to extend the current cap, set a new one, or find another way to peg the loans, the interest rate increase will take effect. The higher rates will add approximately $3,000 to the total interest on a $23,000 student loan repaid over 10 years, according to estimates.

Democrats have sought to keep interest on Stafford loans low, arguing that poor and middle-class students need financial assistance to obtain college educations. Republicans, aiming to cut or control spending, have proposed linking student loans to the financial markets instead of letting Congress set federal lending rates. President Obama included a market-based approach in the budget he sent to Congress earlier this year, sparking opposition from his fellow Democrats.

Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell's spokesman, Don Stewart, expressed hope that President Obama would be able to persuade Democrats to join a bipartisan effort to assist students. Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, however, has stated that tying rates to the 10-year treasury note yield could never pass and that he cannot back a plan without stronger protections for students and parents.

Democrats plan to vote on a one-year extension of the current interest rates on July 10. However, once rates rise, some experts fear generating votes to rein them back in could prove difficult. "The sense of urgency could be lost, and that means interest rates will [stay] higher," said Terry Hartle, senior vice president of the American Council of Education.

Undergraduates currently pay 3.4 percent or 6.8 percent, depending on their loan structures, while graduate students and parents borrow from the government at 7.9 percent interest under the current system. Few students are expected to sign loan documents in July, with many students finalizing aid packages closer to returning to campus in the fall.

"Federal loans are still one of the best options," Hartle said. "But we could see students that are a little pinched by these rates."

Title: GOP Leaders Admit to Artificially Fabricated Fiscal Crisis

Article:

In a surprising turn of events, House Speaker John Boehner and Budget Committee Chairman Paul Ryan have admitted on national television that the fiscal cliffs, sequestrations, and budget battles they have created are not the result of an imminent debt crisis but rather artificially fabricated by ideologues and self-interested politicians.

During yesterday's edition of ABC's "This Week" and CBS's "Face the Nation," both Boehner and Ryan acknowledged that the United States does not have an immediate debt crisis. This admission aligns with President Obama's previous acknowledgment of the same reality.

The significance of this admission goes beyond the politics of a Republican House speaker agreeing with a Democratic president. It reveals a larger truth: the GOP's fiscal alarmism is not a natural reaction to reality but a calculated means to achieve ideological ends.

Boehner's and Obama's statements are factually correct. As Nobel-winning economist Paul Krugman has pointed out, federal debt as a share of GDP will be substantially less than it was at the end of World War II and will also be substantially less than debt in several European countries in the mid- to late 1990s. It is also lower than the 80 percent of GDP level that many economists say starts to put countries in a precarious position.

The long-term debt outlook is only dire because the projections assume without question that "future Congresses will enact huge new deficit-increasing tax cuts and spending hikes." As Krugman writes, "We ’re looking at debt levels that a number of advanced countries, the US included, have had in the past, and dealt with."

Given this reality, it is crucial to address the long-term debt in a pragmatic and sober manner, but not to pretend it is an imminent crisis worthy of draconian austerity measures. Pragmatic solutions include phasing out the Bush tax cuts, reducing defense and war spending, moving toward a single-payer healthcare system, and spending more on social programs that fight economic inequality.

However, the national conversation about the budget is dominated by debt demagogues with ulterior motives. These alarmists create the perception of an immediate crisis to manufacture opportunities to legislate their otherwise politically impossible agenda items, such as Social Security and Medicare cuts, social program cuts, and other shock doctrine prescriptions.

Boehner, Ryan, and other prominent political voices have ignored more prudent ways forward, instead claiming that these shock doctrine prescriptions are required immediately due to the supposed urgency of the debt crisis. By using the supposed urgency as a rationale to create fiscal cliffs, sequestration battles, and debt ceiling crises, they have sought to scare America into abruptly accepting the kind of draconian policies that polls show the public opposes.

With Boehner and Ryan's recent admissions, the charade's most sacred lie has been exposed. In acknowledging that "we do not have an immediate debt crisis," GOP leaders are admitting that there is, in fact, an alternative. They are also admitting that their longtime claims to the contrary were ends-justify-the-means tactics to manufacture an unnecessary panic.

With the truth out in the open, perhaps a more reasoned debate can begin, and more pragmatic policies can finally take center stage.

Title: Second Presidential Debate Predictions: A Tie Likely Due to Changed Expectations and Improved Performance

Article:

The upcoming second presidential debate on Tuesday is expected to result in a draw, according to political analyst J.T. Young. This assessment should not dishearten Republicans, as it does not imply that Mitt Romney will not perform well again. Instead, it signifies that the landscape has shifted due to the impact of the first debate, with factors now in play that are largely beyond Romney's control.

The first debate saw Romney benefit from unrealistically low expectations, a result of President Barack Obama's campaign strategy of personal diminution and the media's readiness to echo it. This advantage is no longer present. Similarly, the high expectations previously held for Obama have been lowered, as it is now clear that he is not the Democratic Demosthenes advertised.

Expectations play a significant role in politics, especially in debates. There are no objective standards for determining a clear winner or loser. The outcome is subjective, measured against the expectations brought to the debates.

Romney's first debate victory was largely due to his performance exceeding the public's pre-debate expectations, while Obama fell significantly below them. The difference was substantial, leading to an undisputed victory for Romney. However, the outcome of the second debate will be less clear, as expectations are now more realistic.

Romney will find it challenging to improve upon his first debate performance. He did all the right things the first time, but replicating the same performance will not be easy. On the other hand, Obama is expected to improve his performance. The Democrats, as demonstrated by Vice President Joe Biden in the vice presidential debate, are determined to be more engaged and passionate this time, appealing to Obama's base.

The Democratic base will not repeat their mistake of the first debate, where they were disengaged and dispassionate. After the first debate, they, along with the media, expressed their disappointment. This time, they will not let their guard down, ensuring there will not be a clear-cut consensus as to who won the debate.

The second debate's likely tie verdict in the media does not mean Romney should not prepare or try to win. Instead, it suggests that Romney has already established his credibility in the first debate, making himself appear at least the equal to Obama in the eyes of much of the broader public. This time, he does not have to extend himself to do so; he just has to be himself.

The president, however, has to extend himself in this debate, carrying a greater need and risk. The risk is evident, as demonstrated during the vice presidential debate. The final reason for the likely tie verdict is that Romney does not have to win; he has already achieved that in the first debate. The president, on the other hand, has to prove himself anew.

This analysis suggests that the second presidential debate is likely to be judged a tie in the media. However, Romney supporters should not be dismayed, as a tie likely means that their candidate has been a victim of his own success.

Title: Black Women's Health Challenges: A Historical and Contemporary Perspective

Article:

Black women face significant health challenges compared to other racial groups, with elevated rates of chronic cardiovascular, inflammatory, and metabolic risk factors. This is evident despite controlling for factors such as smoking, physical exercise, and dietary variables. Black women have the highest body mass index (BMI) in the U.S., with four out of five classified as either "overweight" or "obese."

Historically, this heightened concern about their weight can be traced back nearly three centuries, reflecting the racist stigmatization of black women's bodies. In the late 19th century, medical practitioners often attributed black women's health issues to their presumed inability to control their "animal appetites" - eating, drinking, and fornicating. These assumptions were not based on scientific data but embodied the prevailing racial scientific logic at the time.

Today, the idea that weight is the main problem for black women perpetuates these historically racist ideas and ignores how interrelated social factors impact black women's health. Social determinants, such as workplace discrimination, poor service at restaurants, and online harassment, contribute to higher rates of chronic mental and physical illnesses like heart disease, diabetes, depression, and anxiety.

Studies show that the stigma associated with body weight, rather than the body weight itself, is responsible for some adverse health consequences blamed on obesity, including increased mortality risk. Regardless of income, black women consistently experience weightism in addition to sexism and racism.

Living in racially segregated, high-poverty areas also contributes to disease risk for black women. These neighborhoods often lack potable water, have higher levels of environmental toxins and air pollution, and are disproportionately impacted by a lack of grocery stores offering more nutritious food choices. Food insecurity, which is defined as the lack of access to safe, affordable, and nutritious foods, has a strong association with chronic illness independent of BMI.

Labeling chronic diseases like diabetes or heart conditions as "lifestyle" diseases, when behaviors are not the central problem, is misleading. Difficult life circumstances cause disease. In other words, the predominant reason black women get sick is not because they eat the wrong things but because their lives are often stressful and their neighborhoods are often polluted.

The most effective and ethical approaches for improving health should aim to change the conditions of black women's lives, tackling racism, sexism, and weightism, and providing opportunities for individuals to thrive.

Title: Taliban Agrees to Temporary Ceasefire in Afghanistan, Paving Way for U.S.-Taliban Peace Agreement

Article:

The Taliban's ruling council has agreed to a temporary ceasefire in Afghanistan, providing a potential window for a peace agreement with the United States. The ceasefire, which was demanded by Washington before any peace agreement could be signed, would allow the U.S. to withdraw its troops from Afghanistan, ending its 18-year military engagement, the longest in U.S. history.

The U.S. wants any deal to include a promise from the Taliban that Afghanistan will not be used as a base by terrorist groups. The U.S. currently has an estimated 12,000 troops in Afghanistan.

The Taliban chief must approve the ceasefire decision, but this is expected. The duration of the ceasefire was not specified, and it was not specified when the ceasefire would begin. Four members of the Taliban negotiating team met for a week with the ruling council before they agreed on the brief ceasefire.

Talks were suspended in September when both sides seemed on the verge of signing a peace pact. However, a surge in violence in the capital Kabul killed a U.S. soldier, prompting President Donald Trump to declare the deal "dead." Talks resumed after Trump made a surprise visit to Afghanistan at the end of November, announcing the Taliban were ready to talk and agree to a reduction in violence.

A key pillar of the agreement, which the U.S. and Taliban have been hammering out for over a year, is direct negotiations between Afghans on both sides of the conflict. Those intra-Afghan talks were expected to be held within two weeks of the signing of a U.S.-Taliban peace deal. They will decide what a post-war Afghanistan will look like.

The first item on the agenda is expected to address how to implement a ceasefire between the Taliban and Afghanistan's National Security Forces. The negotiations, however, were expected to be prickly and will cover a variety of thorny issues, including rights of women, free speech, and changes to the country's constitution.

The intra-Afghan talks would also lay out the fate of tens of thousands of Taliban fighters and the heavily armed militias belonging to Afghanistan's warlords. Those warlords have amassed wealth and power since the Taliban were ousted from power in 2001 by the U.S.-led coalition. They were removed after Osama bin Laden's al-Qaida carried out the 9/11 terrorist attacks on the United States. The Taliban had harbored bin Laden, although there was no indication they were aware of al-Qaida's plans to attack the United States.

Even as the Taliban were talking about ceasing hostilities, insurgents carried out an attack in northern Afghanistan on Sunday that killed at least 17 local militiamen. The attack apparently targeted a local militia commander who escaped unharmed. Local Afghan militias commonly operate in remote areas, and are under the command of either the defense or interior ministries.

Last week, a U.S. soldier was killed in combat in the northern Kunduz province. The Taliban claimed they were behind a fatal roadside bombing that targeted American and Afghan forces in Kunduz. The U.S. military said the soldier was not killed in an IED attack but died seizing a Taliban weapons cache.

The U.S. military, in its daily report of military activity, said airstrikes overnight Sunday killed 13 Taliban in attacks throughout the country. Taliban as well as Afghan National Security Forces aided by U.S. air power have carried out daily attacks against each other. The Taliban frequently target Afghan and U.S. forces, as well as government officials. However, scores of Afghan civilians are also killed in the crossfire or by roadside bombs planted by militants. The United Nations has called on all sides in the conflict to reduce civilian casualties. The world body said increased U.S. airstrikes and ground operations by Afghan National Security Forces, as well as relentless Taliban attacks, have contributed to an increase in civilian casualties.

Title: U.S. Officials Overestimate Number of Americans Fighting for ISIS, Says Analyst

Article:

A recent Pew Research poll found that two-thirds of Americans consider the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS) a "major threat" to the United States. However, a closer look at the numbers of Americans fighting for ISIS suggests that such fears may be overblown.

U.S. officials have been inflating the numbers of Americans fighting for ISIS, according to analyst Peter Bergen. For instance, U.S. Secretary of Defense Chuck Hagel stated earlier this month that "We are aware of over 100 U.S. citizens who have U.S. passports who are fighting in the Middle East with ISIL forces." However, the Pentagon later corrected Hagel's statement, clarifying that the 100 count is the total number of Americans fighting for any of the various groups fighting in Syria, some of which are allied with the U.S.

Matthew Olsen, the director of the National Counterterrorism Center, also confirmed that 100 is the total count of the various Americans fighting in Syria and not a count of those fighting for ISIS. Hagel's statement is just the latest in a series of inflated claims regarding the number of Americans fighting with ISIS. Last week, the Washington Times cited anonymous official sources who said there are 300 Americans fighting with ISIS, despite the Pentagon estimating the figure to be more like a dozen.

The case of Somalia offers a cautionary tale. The last sizeable group of Americans who went overseas to fight with an al Qaeda-aligned group are the 29 Americans known to have traveled to fight with the Somali terrorist group Al-Shabaab after the 2006 invasion of Somalia by the Ethiopian army. However, none of those 29 subsequently planned or conducted a terrorist attack inside the United States, according to a survey of more than 240 jihadist terrorism cases since September 11 conducted by the New America Foundation.

Indeed, for more than a third of the American militants who fought with Al-Shabaab, going to Somalia was a one-way ticket. In 2008, a missile strike in Somalia killed Ruben Shumpert, a resident of Seattle. A year later, Burhan Hassan, a 17-year-old from Minneapolis, was killed in the Somali capital, Mogadishu. Abdirizak Bihi, Hassan's uncle, reportedly said at the time, "We believe he was killed because he would have been a key person in the investigation into the recruitment (of young Somali men) here in Minneapolis."

Al-Shabaab militants also are said to have killed Alabama native Omar Hammami, who joined the group in 2006 and took a high-profile position in its media operations before his death last year. At least two Americans fighting for Al-Shabaab died while conducting suicide attacks in Somalia.

Shirwa Ahmed, a 26-year-old from Minnesota, became the first known American to conduct a suicide bombing for an al Qaeda-associated group when he drove a car packed with bombs into a government compound on October 28, 2008. In 2011, the FBI confirmed that Farah Mohamed Beledi, a 27-year-old Minnesota man who was born in Somalia and moved to the United States at age 12, was killed while attempting to detonate a suicide bomb in Somalia.

In addition to the American militants who died in Somalia, six were arrested, four when they returned to the West and two in East Africa. Kamal Said Hassan, a 28-year-old Minneapolis man who traveled to Somalia and attended an Al-Shabaab training camp before returning to the United States, was arrested and in 2009 pleaded guilty to supporting Al-Shabaab. In another case, Mahamud Said Omar, an American resident who helped organize Al-Shabaab's recruitment pipeline and visited a training camp, was arrested in the Netherlands in 2009. Omar was extradited to the United States and in 2012 was convicted on terrorism charges.

Of course, the fact that 13 of the 29 American militants who fought in Somalia remain at large is a reminder that the CIA and FBI also need to pay attention to the potential threat posed by American foreign fighters in Syria. But this is no reason for U.S. officials to overhype the threat posed by ISIS to the United States. Yes, Americans should always be mindful of the threats posed by extremists. But as the case of U.S. citizens in Somalia suggests, Syria could very well end up being a graveyard for Americans fighting there rather than a launch pad for attacks on the United States.

Title: Hillary Clinton's Loss: An Examination of the Role of Sexism in the 2016 Presidential Election

Article:

The 2016 United States Presidential Election saw the defeat of Hillary Clinton by Donald Trump, and the subsequent days following the election witnessed a wave of accusations of sexism as a contributing factor to Clinton's loss.

On social media, under the top-trending hashtag #NotMyPresident, many Americans expressed their belief that misogyny played a significant role in Clinton's electoral failure. MSNBC's Jonathan Alter wrote on election night, "Trump didn't win because of Comey, he won because he's a testosterone candidate and men weren't ready for a woman president."

Vice-presidential candidate Tim Kaine, introducing Clinton before her concession speech, acknowledged the historical significance of Clinton's campaign, stating, "Hillary Clinton has made history in a nation that is good at so many things, but has made it uniquely difficult for a woman to be elected."

Charlotte Alter, writing at Time, argued that Clinton's loss "may be as good a sign as any that we're not ready for glass-breaking yet." She described the "stench of sexism" that allegedly magnified Clinton's flaws and minimized her considerable strengths throughout her campaign.

However, the Clinton campaign itself played up the "glass ceiling" narrative, with Clinton dispensing "woman cards" to supporters and carefully choosing the Javits Center for her election night speech to symbolize her breaking the glass ceiling.

Despite these claims, the article suggests that sexism may not have been the primary cause of Clinton's loss. The article cites numerous reasons for Clinton's defeat, including obvious corruption, lockstep leftism, disastrous health-care prescriptions, abortion fanaticism, and basic incompetence.

The article concludes by referencing a viral video of Clinton expressing frustration over her electoral position, which some compared to a famous scene from the movie Office Space. The article suggests that the accusations of sexism may have contributed to the backlash that led to the election of Donald Trump.

In conclusion, while sexism undeniably exists, the article argues that attributing Clinton's loss to sexism is an oversimplification of the complex factors that led to her defeat in the 2016 Presidential Election.

Title: Health and Human Services Secretary Tom Price Assures No Financial Harm from Obamacare Replacement

Article:

Health and Human Services Secretary Tom Price, in an interview on NBC's "Meet the Press" on Sunday, stated that no American will be financially worse off after the repeal and replacement of the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare). He emphasized that individuals would have the freedom to choose the coverage they desire for themselves and their families, rather than being compelled to buy a specific plan.

The American Health Care Act, the Republican plan to replace Obamacare, was unveiled last week. However, the proposal has faced opposition from a mix of moderate and far-right lawmakers, as well as conservative groups. The plan, which has been marked up and advanced through key committees, aims to have the replacement signed into law before Congress recesses for Easter.

In the interview, Price criticized Obamacare as a system that benefits the government and insurance companies, rather than the American people. He expressed a desire for a system that caters to the needs of the people.

"We need a system that works for people," Price added, stating that he and President Trump believe that a system that is accessible to all and financially feasible for everyone will lead to increased coverage, as opposed to the current trend of people losing coverage and fewer individuals being covered than before.
